 The Altman-Z Bankruptcy-Prediction Algorithm


 


      Question 1 (15 Points)


 


      What are the benefits of utilizing a bankruptcy prediction model such


as Altman’s Z score and how would you apply it to a company? (Use a


specific company such as Microsoft to apply it). Read the appropriate


portions of Module 4 of our Textbook for this Question.


 


      A company’s Altman Z-score provides a reasonably good indication


of a company’s health and, in particular, of its likelihood of going bankrupt


within the next two years. If X is a company, X’s Altman Z-score is the sum


of the following numbers:


 


 


        3.3x(EBIT/total assets)


        1.4x(retained earnings/total assets)


        1.2x(working capital/total assets)


        .99x(sales/total assets)


        0.6x(market value of equity/total liabilities) MVE/TL


  


      In each case, we have a financial ratio multiplied by a coefficient that,


in effect, assigns a certain degree of importance to that ratio. For example,


EBIT/total assets is the ratio of a company’s total earnings (before interest


and taxes) to its assets and is therefore a measure of the amount of work that


those assets are doing. (EBIT is ten times larger than total assets, then total


assets are operating with 1000% efficiency; if ten times smaller, then


operating with 10% efficiency.) Because this is obviously such an important


ratio, it is given a high degree of weight in the form of a large (3.3)


coefficient.


      The next three ratios are similar to EBIT/total assets, but not as


important, since they take into account taxes and interest and other factors


that, although relevant to a company’s health, do not reflect how much work


its assets are doing. As for market value of equity/total liabilities (MVE/TL ),


this represents total value of stock divided by company-debt---in other words,


the real value of equity, after debt is taken into account. This is obviously


important, but it is not as important as the other ratios, since, unlike them, it


says nothing about how much work company assets are doing---it speaks


only to their current value.


      The higher a company’s Altman Z-score, the less likely is imminent


bankruptcy, with a score of 3.0 considered the minimum score of afinancially healthy company. Right now, Amazon’s Altman Z-score is 6.2---


meaning very little chance of bankruptcy. BlackBerry’s current score is


negative, meaning that bankruptcy is highly possible. In 2012, Sears’ score


was 2.3 which is low but almost acceptable. In 2017, it had a score of zero


and declared bankruptcy that years. Historically, bankruptcy predictions


based on Altman Z-scores have been accurate 90% of the time.


 


 


      Case Analysis (85 Points)


 


        Problems in bond ratings and the firms issuing them have led to both


Standard and Poor’s as well as Moody’s modifying their ratings criteria.


Included in these changes is an attempt to capture more risk elements in the


rating process and to more comprehensively quantify potential areas of


concern.


 


      The 2015 document issued by Moody’s explains their ratings


criteria and the ratings they have assigned to the software industry.  It


can be found in the Final Exam Module. This document can be combined


with corporate reporting data to apply these ratings criteria to specific


companies covered by Moody’s. For this examination please use the 201810K for Microsoft provided earlier in the Mid-term Exam Module to


apply bond ratings criteria to that company. In other words, utilize the


analytics Moody’s applies to the software industry including any metrics


that help in identifying and applying both the qualitative and


quantitative criteria noted in the Moody’s Report on Software


Companies.  Please answer the following questions pertaining to the


report.


 


      1)              Discuss the five key factors important to Moody’s in


assessing credit ratings for the industry. (15)


 


      Those five factors are:


 


      Scale


        Business Profile


        Profitability


      Leverage and Coverage


      Financial Policy


 


      Scale is cash flow, including free cash flow (cash flow minus


expenditures). Obviously the bigger the cash flow, especially of free cashflow, the more robust the company.


      A company's business profile refers to its market-share and its range


of goods and markets. A company that has a 100% market share is the only


game in town, so to speak, and is therefore in a good position, and one that


has a 0% market share is not doing any business at all. Obviously the larger a


company's market share, the better. As for diversity of products/services (i.e.


range of products/services), this is important because a company that offers


only one product/service will go out of business if demand for that


products/service dries up. That said, successful companies tend to specialize


(consider A1, Goodyear, Microsoft, Coca Cola), and over-diversification of


products/services can hurt a company. (This happened to A1 when it started


selling seafood sauce, instead of just sticking to steak-sauce.)


        End-market diversity is the number of different markets where goods


are sold. Obviously, the more such diversity, the better, other things equal,


since a company whose eggs (products) are in one basket (market) is


vulnerable to changes in that market. (The ‘other things equal’ rider is


important, since the cost of doing business in a given market might exceed


the benefits.)


        Geographic diversity is the range of venues (economically distinct


areas) where it creates its products/services. As a general rule, some diversity


in this respect is desirable as a hedge against contingencies. For example, if acompany has all its operations in one place, then a single change could ruin


it. (A tornado could destroy its facilities; a new president might decide to


nationalize the corresponding industry; a new mayor might raise taxes; etc.)


        Profitability is the ratio of income to expense (‘bang for buck’,


essentially). The higher this number, the better, for obvious reasons. 


      A company’s leverage is the extent to which it is debt-financed, as


opposed to asset-financed; and a company’s coverage is the extent to which it


is able to services, in most cases, its debt. Insufficient coverage is a sign of


poor financial health, as is excessive leverage.


      A company’s financial policy is the manner in which it deals with its


own assets and liabilities. It is a bad sign if management is overly bearish


(risk-averse), and shies away from all investment-opportunities, but it is no


less a bad sign if it is overly bullish (risk-affine) and invests indiscriminately.


It is a very bad sign if a company is slow to pay off its debts, and a good sign


if it pays them off ahead of schedule, especially if its timeliness has to do


with its having invested the borrowed assets profitably. All of this falls under


the rubric of ‘financial policy.’


 


 


 


      2)              Why is it necessary for Moody’s to apply different weightsfor these factors?  How are these factors measured? (10)


 


      Moody’s weights for these five factors are as follows:


 


      Leverage and Coverage 30%


        Business Profile 25%


 


 


      Financial Policy 20%


      Scale 15%


        Profitability 10%


 


 


      If a company cannot service its debt, it will, for purely legal reasons,


immediately go out of existence (absent a government-bailout or some other,


similarly improbable event). Of the five factors, leverage/coverage is the only


one that relates to a company's legal obligations; the others relate to its


economic viability. There are no laws against investing unwisely or selling


mediocre products; there are laws against not repaying loans, and the penalty


is typically liquidation. Consequently, leverage/coverage is weighted the


most heavily (30%).      A company’s business-profile includes its market-share and also


includes its ability to survive changes in markets. Being so important, it is


weighted the second most heavily (25%).


      A company’s financial policy includes the financial savviness of its


management, along with the ability, or inability, to manage debt and to seize


opportunities. Financial policy is therefore key to a company’s willingness


and ability to grow. Financial policy is key to growth, but not as key to


survival as the first two factors, and it is therefore weighted the third most


heavily (20%).


      A company's scale is its total cash flow, which reflects the amount of


business it is doing. Obviously, a company that is doing a lot of business is,


other things equal, better off than one that is only doing a little business. The


reason scale is so low on the list, with a weighting of only 15%, is that other


things are not always equal. In particular, costs of materials, payroll, interest


on debts, not to mention the abilities of key executives, may have critical


positive or negative effects on a company’s feasibility.


      A company’s profitability is obviously important, since an


unprofitable company is not worth investing in and won’t survive, this being


why profitability is on the list. At the same time, it is long-term profits, not


short-term profits, that matter. A company can be a pump-and-dump scheme


and therefore briefly be very profitable. Consequently, profitability is not tobe weighted too heavily, this being why it is ranked last, with a weighting of


10%.


 


      3)              What are some of the assumptions, limitations and other


considerations noted by Moody’s in employing this methodology? Are


accounting adjustments an issue for Moody’s in applying their criteria?


Please note that if so you are not required to make them but please


discuss briefly what they consist of. (10)


      The most important such assumptions relate to the discount rate that a


company uses when evaluating its own assets. First of all, it cannot be know


with certainty at the present time how the value of money will fluctuate in the


future; so discount-rates are always assumed, as opposed to known. That


said, some discount-rates are more reasonable than others; and when a given


company’s financials are based on overly optimistic discount-rates, Moody’s


looks into the matter and, if the numbers don’t pan out, asks the company in


question to revise its financials accordingly.


              One limitation that Moody’s must adjust for is that accounting


and reporting requirements vary from country to country. Another is that


even the most conservative financial statements are based on assumptions


about interest-rates and markets in general that may prove false.


              There are two kinds of accounting adjustments, standard andnon-standard, each of which is relevant to how Moody’s evaluates company-


financials. Standard-adjustments include securities, pension-plans, R&D


costs, and non-recurring expenses. Non-standard adjustments include debts


reported at ‘fair value’ (market value), as well as likely benefits-obligations


to future former employees of the company.




 


 


      4)              Utilizing the data in the 10K for Microsoft please discuss


the individual factor mapping results using the company’s own data


(financial statements, etc.) and state whether you agree with the


individual ratings assigned by Moody’s for each factor.  (50)


 


      For the 2018 fiscal year, Microsoft’s profitability was 15%. This is


considered a respectable degree of profitability.


      Its current ratio was 2.9. This figure is high, meaning that, at that time,


Microsoft had a high degree of ability to meet its short-term obligations.


      Its quick ratio was 2.86. This figure is high, suggesting that Microsoft


was holding to too much cash and therefore was not using its resources as


efficiently as possible.


        Microsoft's cash flow was about $5 billion (extremely high), and itsnet income was about $16.5 billion (extremely high).


      Its total liabilities were just under $95 billion.


      Moody’s gave Microsoft AAA ratings (the highest possible) in every


category, except for end-market diversity, geographic diversity, and free cash


flow to debt, in which Microsoft received AA ratings.


      In every possible category, without exception, Microsoft was ranked


higher than every single one of its competitors.


      In my judgments, these ratings are most part accurate, with some


tentative qualifications. The first is that a AA FCF/debt ratio may be too high,


given that Microsoft's total liabilities were $95 billion and its free cash flow


in December 2018 was about $5 billion. Microsoft being the juggernaut that


it is, this rating may well be justified; but if an assessment of Microsoft's


FCF/debt were made strictly on the basis of its cash flow and debt, and not on


the basis of anything else, an AA rating might be too high.


      As for end-market diversity and geographic diversity, an AA rating


seems too low, given that Microsoft has a worldwide customer-base and also


has operations on every continent, except for Africa. (This changed in May


2019, when it launched a $100 million facility in Kenya.) 


 


 


  


 Application of Cobit-framework (July 24, 2019)


 


 


      To whom it may concern:


 


      There are many components of the COBIT framework that could be


improved upon at RutgersCo. I will discuss the three that I believe to the


most important. To quote my professor: “There are various components that


assist with IT-governance: Culture, Ethics, and Behavior; People, Skills, and


Competencies; and Services, Infrastructure, and Applications”


(19_06_23_22.19.06.mp4). In this report, I will show that, in the case of


RutgersCo, each of these components needs to be improved.


      Processes: One major problem is a lack of well-defined processes and


procedures for carrying out tasks, especially—ominously---accounting


related tasks. When I first met with the Assistant Controller (in other words,


the second-in-command when it comes to managing RutgersCo’s finance’s),


the first words out of his mouth were: “Boy, am I glad to see you. We need to


get these books closed. The previous controller made a lot of entries himself.


I have been trying to follow his work, but I just can’t quite figure out how he


worked up some of the entries” (RiderCo’s Acquisition of RutgersCo). This


means that procedures for keeping and sharing financial records areinsufficiently defined, which is likely to lead both to loss of revenue,


excessive or insufficient payments in taxes, and regulatory or even criminal


sanctions. Also, the lack of such procedures in this respect leads to extra


work for employees, as this quotation indicates, and also disorients


employees and diminishes their respect for the company.


      This brings me to another component of the COBIT framework that


could be improved at RutgersCo: People, Skills, and Competency. The


accounting team at RutgersCo is feeling frustrated, because some of their best


people were recently fired, making it hard for them to do their job (RiderCo’s


Acquisition of RutgersCo). The purpose of the firings was to free up money


for an ad campaign that totally failed, further angering RutgersCo employees.


The firings diminished net competency as well as overall morale, and the ad


campaign appears, at least to people in RutgersCo accounting department, to


have been a callous attempt on the part of management to make quick money


at the expensive of fundamentals. “People skills and competencies,” my


professor observed, are integral to people “making good decisions” and


thereby keeping the business going (19_06_23_22.19.06.mp4).


      Another Cobit-component that needs work here is Services,


Infrastructure, and Applications. The accounting system is divided into a


number of different modules, each with its own data-base and unable to


communicate with one another in simple user-friendly way (RiderCo’sAcquisition of RutgersCo). This necessitates the use of ad hoc methods of


communication, which require effort and increase the chance of human effort.


Because of the problems with the accounting system, reporting cannot be


automated and has to be done by hand, which is labor-intensive and which


increases the likelihood of human error—and also increases the likelihood of


deliberate falsification on the part of employees, either to minimize effort on


their part or in order to commit fraud.


      These problems relate largely to poor IT-control at RutgersCo. Good


IT-control requires that all employees involved in either the keep or reporting


of finances be using the same system. Right now, this is not the case. There


appear to be independent systems, each with its own database. The fact that


multiple databases are used is likely to lead to multiple sets of company


books, resulting in management having to arbitrarily choose between


different sets of financial records, leading to loss of revenue and possible


legal problems.


      Another IT-related problem is that there are unclear protocols relating


to the cashing of checks. There should be one person or group of persons who


cash checks. But right now, this is not the case, and checks are cashed by


employees who happen to be in possession of them. Since these employees


are in many cases not formally required to do this, the result is likely to that


checks from clients simply are not cashed. Another possibility is that theseemployees embezzle by endorsing the checks to themselves instead of the


company. There should be a well-defined company treasurer, which, at


present, there is not.


      Another IT-related problem is that there are poor policies and poor


communications relating to the commission-levels of sales personnel.


According to one member of the accounting team, practically every single


salesperson had a different agreement with management as to how much he


was to receive in bonuses and as to what his commission-levels were


(RiderCo’s Acquisition of RutgersCo). In fact, it appeared that different


salespersons had simply gone rogue and were simply deciding for themselves


what their commissions should be. This could lead to embezzlement on a


large scale and, at the very least, could least to money-wastage. Also, if, as I


likely under the current scenario, a given salesperson gave inconsistent


reports concerning his commissions and bonuses to different members of the


accounting, the result would be inconsistent records, wasted revenue, and


possible regulatory and even criminal sanctions. “The culture, ethics, and


behavior of individuals”, my professor said, has a significant effect on the


“success of government and management activities”


(19_06_23_22.19.06.mp4), and in the case of RutgersCo, the culture is one of


low morale, there is a lack of internal possibly leading to loose ethics, and


employee-behavior is correspondingly erratic, with an ‘every-man-for-himself’ mentality prevailing.

Works CitedIntroduction


 


      This present work is a financial analysis of Microsoft during the years


2017-2018. 2016 is included when the necessary data is available in course-


documents. Other years are excluded. This analysis is not complete and it


focuses only on the absolutely crucial financial indicators. Microsoft’s


financials are compared to Oracle’s, so as to provide information as to


Microsoft’s performance relative to its competitors.


      Our main source of information about Microsoft is Microsoft’s 2018


10-K form (specifically pages 50-53). Our main source of information about


Oracle is Oracle’s income statement, accessed at


  http://financials.morningstar.com/income-statement/is.html?


  t=ORCL&region=usa&culture=en-US. The financial data provided in those


documents rounds figures to the nearest thousandth. All specific financial


data relating to Microsoft and Oracle come from these sources unless there is


an indication otherwise.


        Microsoft’s performance during this time-period is positive in absolute


terms. Microsoft also marginally outperforms Oracle. That said, the one


companies financials parallel each other to a striking degree: Microsoft has


more total assets, but its performance relative to its total assets is similar to


(though marginally better than) Oracle’s performance relative to its totalassets. Between 2017 and 2018, there are dips in Microsoft’s performance,


but those are corresponding dips in Oracle’s performance, indicating that the


issue is not with Microsoft itself but with the industry as a whole.


 Operating Cash Flow


 


      When conducting a financial analysis of a company, the first step is to


determine its cash flow from operating activities, or operating cash flow


(OCF), this being the amount of money that it generates from its activities,

                                      [1]
excluding long-term investments. In 2016, Microsoft’s OCF was


$33,325,000; in 2017, $35,507,000; and in 2018, $42,884,000. It is a good


sign that Microsoft's OCF was positive during each of these years since this


indicates that its products and services were generating income. A company


whose OCF is zero or negative can still profit since it can make money from


investments and assets, but its products and services are failing to generate


income, and its position is therefore unstable. Also, Microsoft’s OCF grew


over 30% during this period---also a positive sign.


        Microsoft’s net income (revenues minus expenses, i.e. profits) in 2016


was $20,539,000; in 2017, $25, 489,000; and in 2018, $16, 571,000. During


each year, Microsoft’s net income was positive, but its net income fell by


$8,918,000---a drop of over 34% (10K p. 52).


      Oracle’s OCF in 2016 was $13, 561, 000; in 2017, $14,126,000; and


in 2018, $15,386,000. Oracle’s net income in 2016 was $8,901,000; in 2017,


$9,335,000; and in 2018, $3,825,000. Oracle’s OCF was positive during each


of these years, and also increased during this time period by around 13%.Between 2017 and 2018, Oracle’s net income plummeted, falling by over


50%. Since its OCF grew during this period, the fall does not indicate a


decline in demand for Oracle products and services. 


 Common Equity    


 


      In 2016, Microsoft’s common equity (the amount invested by


shareholders) was $68, 465, 000; in 2017, 68, 178,000; and in 2018,


$69,315,000. There was therefore modest growth in Microsoft common


equity during this period. In 2016, Oracle’s common equity was $164, 950,

                                                                  [2]
000; in 2017, $209, 937, 000; and in 2018, $175,569,000. Oracle’s


performance here is more jagged than Microsoft’s but also better on the


whole. 


 Profitability


 


      The next few sections focus on financials relating to Microsoft’s


degree of profitability. We will see that Microsoft is ‘in the black’, so to


speak, and also compares better than Oracle, a representative competitor.


 Return on Equity


 


      In 2015, Microsoft’s return on equity (net income divided by


shareholder’s equity, this being the change in the value of the shareholder’s


equity) was 15.3%; in 2016, 26.9%; in 2017, 31.8%; and in 2018, 19.4%


During each year, ROE is positive. At the same time, there was a decrease


from 2017 to 2018.


      Oracle’s ROE in 2015 was 12.8%; in 2016, 10.3%and in 2017, 9.7%;


and in 2018, 3.4%. In each year, ROE is positive, but much smaller than with


Microsoft. Also, with Oracle, as with Microsoft, we see a 2017-2018 drop.


This parallel suggests that in both cases the drop is a consequence not of


anything company-specific but rather of some larger economic phenomenon.


 


 


 


 2015201620172018


  Microsoft15.3%26.9%31.8%19.4%


  Oracle12.8%10.3%9.7%3.4%


 


 Net Profit Margin


 


      In 2015, Microsoft’s net profit margin (net income divided by total


revenue, i.e. percentage of revenue that Microsoft retained after paying


expenses) was 13.9%; in 2016, 22.5%; in in 107, 26.3%; and in 2018, 15%.


The profit margins are all positive, though there is a (now familiar) 2017-


2018 drop.


      Oracle's net profit margin in 2015 was 27.9%; in 2016, 23.7%; in


2017, 25.3%; and in 2018, 10.2%. Again, profit margins are positive, with a


2017-2018 drop. Microsoft's profit margin appears to track Oracle's,


suggesting that changes in them are due not to company-specific but rather to


industry-wide factors.


 


 


 2015201620172018


  Microsoft15.3%26.9%31.8%19.4%


    Oracle27.9%23.7%25.3%10.2%


 


 


 Asset Turnover


 


      Asset turnover is significant because it is a good measure of a


company’s health. A company with low-asset turnover is not using its assets


efficiently, and a company with high-asset turnover is using them efficiently.


      In 2015, Microsoft’s asset turnover (total revenue divided by total


assets) was 53%; in 2016, 44%; in 2017, 37%; and in 2018, 43%.  In 2015,


Oracle’s asset turnover was 34%; in 2016, 33%; in 2017, 28%; and in 2018,

    [3]
29%. We are seeing parallels—increases in both cases, albeit higher ones in


Microsoft’s case.


 


 


 


 


 2015201620172018


  Microsoft53%44%37%43%


Oracle34%33%28%29%


 


 


 


 Leverage


 

 
      In 2015, Microsoft’s leverage (debt/equity) was 34.7%; in 2016,


56.6%; in 2017, 86.7%; and in 2018, 87.3%. In 2015, Oracle’s asset turnover

 [4]
was 81%; in 2016, 84%; in 2017, 110%; and in 2018, 230%. Both


companies are highly leveraged, but Microsoft’s debt/equity ratio is always


less than one, meaning that it has more assets than debts, and Oracles


debt/equity is greater than one, meaning that is liabilities exceed its assets. A


high degree of leverage can be a bad sign, since it can indicate deficit


financing, but here it is not a bad sign, as it seems to indicate aggressive and

                                                              [5]
successful investments in a growing economic sector.

 Liquidity Ratios


Current Ratio


 


      The current ratio measures a company’s ability to pay its short-term


obligations. The higher the ratio, the lower the likelihood of defaulting on


such debts. Ratios above 1:1 (100%) are considered good, and lower ratios


are considered bad. Microsoft’s current ratio is low, whereas Oracle’s is high


as of 2018, though low before then.


 


 2015201620172018


Microsoft2.52.32.92.9


  Oracle3.74.83.95.1


 


 Quick Ratio


 


      The quick ratio is like the current ratio except that non-liquid assets


are excluded from this figure. As with current ratio, a ratio of 1:1 (100%) or


higher is considered good, and anything lower is considered bad. Again,


Oracle’s quick ratio is better than Microsoft’s.


 


 2015201620172018


Microsoft2.32.32.22.7


  Oracle3.54.43.65.5


 


 


 Ebit Interest Coverage


 


      The Ebit Interest Coverage ratio determines how capable a company is


paying the interest on its debt. Obviously should be a least one, since it will


otherwise be unable to service its loan-debt. The higher the number, the


better. We see here that Microsoft’s numbers compare favorably to Oracles


and are also much higher than one.


 2015201620172018

                           Microsoft Five Forces Analysis


 


Introduction


 


      Microsoft is the world’s two leading supplier of software products, the


other being Apple, with the two companies being nearly equal in terms of net

      [7]
worth. Microsoft is best known for the Windows Operating System, used


on all PC’s, which has a 90% market-share in the digital operating system


market. Microsoft is also known for, and derives enormous revenue from, a


number of other products, including Microsoft Word, Excel, Skype, Bing,

                                                                    [8] 
OneDrive, Minecraft, LinkedIn, Cortana, and PowerPoint.Microsoft’s


annual revenue (as of 2018) is $110 billion, its annual profits are $16 billion,

  
and its market capitalization (overall value) is $775 billion (10K 62).Apple’s


annual revenue (as of 2018) is $230 billion, its profits are $10 billion, and its

                                          [9]
market capitalization is $700 billion. The third largest player in the software


is IBM, with annual revenue of $15 billion, net profits of $3 billion, and


market capitalization of $110 billion (IBIS 22).


      The present study is a Porter’s Five-forces analysis of Microsoft. A


Porter’s Five-forces analysis examines a company in terms of the following


parameters: competition within its industry, potential of new entrants into that


industry, power of suppliers, power of customers, and threat of substitutes.Each of these forces, whether favorable or unfavorable to the company being


analyzed, is ranked as either ‘strong’, ‘moderate’, or ‘weak.’


 Industry Competition (Strong Force)


 


        Competition within the software industry is fierce. There is intense


rivalry on the part of Apple to switch to its operating system. Also, Apple, as


well each of the many lesser players, are highly innovative and are rapidly


developing products that could chip away at Microsoft’s position. Apple, for

 [10]
example, is known for its smart phone, iPods, and computer-tablets.


Microsoft’s versions of these products were not successful, although it did


stave off the potential economic losses by establishing lucrative partnerships


with successful players in these markets, notably Samsung, whose Android


phone operating system is the leading smart-phone operating system and


from the sales of which Microsoft is now the largest beneficiary.


        Switching costs for existing Microsoft customers are high. It is


inconvenient and expensive for users of Windows and related applications to


switch to non-Microsoft products. This is because such products are easy to


use and tend to be bundled together in ways that are highly functional and


that are difficult or impossible to replicate with non-Microsoft products. This


force favors Microsoft.


      Other firms in this industry, including but not limited to Apple, are


extremely innovative and are also aggressive in marketing their products.


Microsoft is not as innovative as Apple or as many of its much smallercompetitors. Microsoft counters this, with some success, by buying up


patents and buying into companies that offer innovations that it is not itself

 [11] 
providing. 


      There is a high degree of product-diversity in the software industry,


which is a strong force that works against Microsoft, since it could lead, and


in some cases has led, to substitutes for Microsoft products and also to


products that simply render them obsolete.


 Bargaining Power of Customers (Weak Force)


 


      Switching costs for Microsoft customers are high, as previously stated,


mainly because Windows, Microsoft’s highest earning product, is easy to use


and also bundled with a number of applications in a way that can be


replicated only with difficulty using non-Microsoft softwares. Microsoft’s


great strength is that it offers products (e.g. Excel, Microsoft Word,


PowerPoint) at least one or two of which many simply have no choice but to


use, and then links that product’s functionality with those of other products


for which those same customers are likely to have at least some use. For


example, all people who do anything involving writing for a living need to


use a product functionally similar to Microsoft Word. If they choose an


alternative to Microsoft Word, they find, first, that those products tend to be


bug-infested and, second, that if they want to convert them into PDF format


or embed photos in them, they are simply out of luck.


      Also, many businesses use Microsoft products and also rely on their


high degree of co-functionality with one another with non-Microsoft


products. This would make it difficult, and in many cases impossible, for


Microsoft’s numerous existing business customers to switch brands.


 Bargaining Power of Suppliers (Moderate Force)


 


      Microsoft offers a range of different products, and it also relies on


many different products and technologies for its own R&D. This makes it


vulnerable to shifts in prices in the corresponding raw materials (IBIS 32). In


particular, Microsoft is vulnerable to shifts in copper (for the copper wiring in


the operating systems that it manufactures) and in petroleum (use for the


plastic in the casing, which it also sells). These are both price-volatile


commodities, potentially posing a problem for Microsoft.


 Threat of Substitutes (Weak Force)


 


      It is often difficult and sometimes impossible for Microsoft customers


to switch to other brands. Non-Microsoft versions of Word and Excel do not


work very well and have lower functionality than their Microsoft


counterparts. Also, Microsoft makes its products easy to use with one another


and with related Non-Microsoft products. For example, Microsoft Word


documents are easily saved to OneDrive, which is Microsoft’s Cloud Storage


service; and Microsoft Word documents can easily be saved as Adobe PDF

 [12]
files (and vice versa).  Also, Microsoft makes it easy to import numbers


into Excel Files, and it has loaded Excel with extremely useful and easy to


use accounting features. These products and integrated functionalities are not


offered by other companies, making switching a non-option in most cases.


      Also, Microsoft aggressively litigates would-be rival purveyors of


alternatives on patent-grounds, helping to perverse its position. At the same


time, Microsoft products can be cloned and pirated. Because the technology


involved in cloning Microsoft products is still rather unwieldy, people are


better off simply buying them from Microsoft. But as those products get


easier to use, this could potentially change. But this is not likely to happen


any time soon, given that these pirated products, though functional on their


own, cannot be used in conjunction with Microsoft products. So for example,while it not hard to clone Microsoft Word software, documents made with


Word-clones cannot be converted into Adobe PDF’s; nor could numerical

 [13] 
data on them imported into Microsoft Excel files.Replicating cross-


application functionalities would involve systematic pirating of Microsoft-


technology, which would not be easy to do.


 Threat of New Entrants (Moderate Force)


 


      Any given Microsoft product can be replicated, either legally or


illegally, and any such product could, on its own, be mass-produced


relatively inexpensively. The problem for would-be competitors is that


Microsoft products are co-functional with many non-Microsoft products and


these Microsoft has exclusivity agreements with these other companies,


which limit the amount of functionality that non-Microsoft products can


have. For example, Microsoft word documents have a feature whereby users


can dictate words, instead of having to type them. This feature is easily


replicated, but it couldn’t be used on PC’s made by any existing company,


since they have contracted with Microsoft  to block use of such application

                                    [14] 
with any non-Microsoft product. 


      At the same time, there are many small companies that already create


analogues of Microsoft-products, and such a company would be a threat if it


had the financing needed to market itself and to establish legally protected


Microsoft-style product-integrations with related companies. The chances of


this are small but not negligible. 


 Conclusion


 


      Microsoft’s position is relatively secure. It offers useful and easy to use


products for low prices, and those products have useful integrations with one


another and with non-Microsoft products. In addition, Microsoft protects


itself against rivals either by contracting with them, as it did with Samsung,


effectively buying them out, or entering into exclusivity agreements that limit


the extent to which non-Microsoft products can have the range of uses as


Microsoft products. Microsoft’s vulnerability is its current lack of


innovativeness. But because Microsoft hedges against this problem by simply


buying out would-be competitors, it is likely to retain its position as one of


the top two software providers for the foreseeable future.


 


                                      Works Cited


Hadad, Jonathan. "IBISWorld Industry Report 51121 Software Publishing in


the US." IBIS World. September 2018.


"Microsoft Form 10-K." SEC. June 2018.


 


                   Reflection Paper: Harvey on Commodity Fetishism


                                  (Politics/Economics)


 


      Tech specs: 2-3 pages, double spaces, worth 20 points (does not need


to be a classically structured essay i.e. no need for intro and conclusion). You


must engage with Harvey’s discussion and concepts from chapter 1 of


Seventeen Contradictions.


 


      Commodity Reflection: Use-value vs. exchange-value


      Pick a commodity (suggestions: medication, education, food, housing,


computers)


      Analyze it in terms of its use-value and its exchange-value


      Where does the contradiction arise? How are these in tension with one


another?


      How might tension or contradiction create inequality? Here you need


to connect it to what you have learned about inequality from Milanovic,


Therborn, and the lectures from week 1.


 


      Evaluation: You must engage with Harvey’s concepts and discussion


from the Introduction and Ch. 1 and you must use some ideas from


Milanovic, Therborn, and week 1 lectures for part 1.4. You will lose points ifyou do not. You will be evaluated on accuracy of information and concepts,


depth of your analysis and grammar and spelling.


 


 


      In a broad spectrum, user-value of a commodity is the material used


such a commodity can be put into and the human needs it can satisfy while


exchange-value of a commodity is the universal equivalence as well as the


qualitative valuation usually monetary. As we examine the role a commodity


plays in the capital market, these two facets of a commodity become more


antagonistic. The antagonism, also known as the contradiction, breed


inequality whether vital existential or material. The essay below evaluates


how housing as a commodity portrays the user-value, exchange-value and


how the tensions or contradictions emanating from these two-sided values


breed inequality.


      A decent house according to the US act is a basic right where each


citizen is entitled to. The use-value of a house is determined by the ability to


satisfy social needs. For instance, a father builds a house to shelter his family


and offer them security and privacy from the unstable world. Another user-


value of housing is for a symbol of status quo where the house is used as an


example in architectural design size and other outstanding features of


admiration. However, such famous houses which act as landmarks can be putinto myriad uses like housing immigrants and conversion into workshops


among others. The Frank Lloyd Wright’s falling water house had an elegance


and beauty that attracted tourists. Nonetheless, the famous which was used as


a workshop for innovation became the epicenter of what nowadays termed as


the Silicon Valley.


      On the other hand, according to Marx’s theory of value, the exchange-


value of a house as a commodity entails production for monetary valuation or


exchange. The Logic of profit rather than the logic of usefulness tends to


dominate in a society where exchange-value is prevalent. Moreover, any


acquisition of a house must follow the required procurement process that


demands giving out money. This occurs through renting, leasing or buying


fully furnished apartments at a cost. In advanced capitalist societies, houses


are built to be sold to whoever requires it or whoever can afford it. The


renowned Georgian terraces of Bath, Bristol, and London were built for the


working class at the end of the eighteenth century. Furthermore, the ability of


a house to appreciate in value with time makes individuals purchase house


only to resell at a profit.


      The user-value and exchange-value of housing surface tensions which


are also known as contradictions. According to (JOHNSTON, 2014), these


contradictions can either be mitigated or spilled over to cause a crisis. Such


tensions include for example according to the American charter, every citizenis entitled to a decent home and majority cannot afford which the government


to chip in and subsidize the houses for them to acquire. However, some


contradictions which spilled over include, the Scandinavian property market


collapse, the fall of Loans and savings in the USA and the great recession


where instead of appreciation of houses, there was falling of prices which led


where owners sold at a loss of their buying price as illustrated in


(JOHNSTON, 2014). Apart from this, gentrification which is an


improvement of the neighborhood can raise the mortgage fee of the house


where the owner has not spent anything to improve it. Moreover, the eruption


of a bad vice like theft which discourages developers will lower the price of


the house despite any renovations to keep it at a cutting edge. Such market


crashes like in America led to 4 million individuals to lose their homes.


Elsewhere in New York, 60% of house owners are renters who during the


great recession went bankrupt making tenants to live in foreclosed houses.


Indeed, the ruthless pursuit aimed at maximizing housing exchange values


has reduced access to housing use values for a bigger portion of the


population, a trend that is prevalent in the society nowadays.


        According to (Therborn, 2012) there are tangible inequalities


emanating from the user-value housing and exchange-value housing. The


vital inequality of health and death is prevalent where individuals who


endeavor in exchange-value housing and end up being frustrated end uphaving a shorter lifespan than those who endeavor in user-value housing.


Moreover, existential inequality is also portrayed where the poor can neither


access the exchange-value housing nor the user-value housing. This is due to


the heavy capital intensity accompanied by such endeavor which their


poverty outlaws them from accessing them. In addition, Material inequality is


predominant where these housing values exclude the poor and favor the rich


only. Material inequality is classified into the inequality of access, inequality


of opportunities and the inequality of rewards where a particular caliber of


people majorly the rich have an upper hand compared to the poor who can do


nothing to reverse the situation. These inequalities are destructive to human


lives and societies. In fact, there is none beneficial.


      In conclusion, housing is a commodity which manifests both user and


exchange values. These values when examined deeply reveal tensions or


contradictions where some can be managed by the government while others


run out of control thus making them risky endeavors. Furthermore, the


contradictions make lead to inequalities which are disastrous to human life


and societies.


 


 


      References


      Therborn, G. (2012). The Killing Fields of Inequality. InternationalJournal Of Health Services, 42(4), 579-589. doi: 10.2190/hs.42.4.a


        JOHNSTON, R. (2014). David Harvey (2014), Seventeen


Contradictions and the End of Capitalism. London: Profile Books. £14.99,


pp. 336, hbk. Journal Of Social Policy, 43(04), 850-852. doi:


  10.1017/s0047279414000440


         Reflection Paper: Defending Marxist Economist (Politics/Economics)


 


      Tech specs: 2-3 pages, double spaces, worth 20 points (does not need


to be a classically structured essay i.e. no need for intro and conclusion). You


must engage with Harvey’s discussion and concepts from chapter 1 of


Seventeen Contradictions.


 


      Commodity Reflection: Use-value vs. exchange-value


      Pick a commodity (suggestions: medication, education, food, housing,


computers)


      Analyze it in terms of its use-value and its exchange-value


      Where does the contradiction arise? How are these in tension with one


another?


      How might tension or contradiction create inequality? Here you need


to connect it to what you have learned about inequality from Milanovic,


Therborn, and the lectures from week 1.


 


      Evaluation: You must engage with Harvey’s concepts and discussion


from the Introduction and Ch. 1 and you must use some ideas from


Milanovic, Therborn, and week 1 lectures for part 1.4. You will lose points if


you do not. You will be evaluated on accuracy of information and concepts,depth of your analysis and grammar and spelling.


 


      The commodity that I will study is housing. We will see that the use-


value of housing diverges enormously from its exchange value and that this


divergence is illustrative of the central conceits of the readings and lectures.


      Let us begin by defining terms and clarifying foundational concepts.


      The use-value of X is X’s degree of utility. Thus, air and water have a


maximally high degree of use-value, since they have a maximally high


degree of utility. Diamonds have a very low degree of use-value, since they


have a low degree of utility.


      The exchange-value of X is how much X sells for on the market. Thus,


air and water usually have a low-degree of exchange value, and diamonds


typically have a high degree of exchange value.


      Why are exchange-value and use-value capable of diverging so much?


There are several reasons.


      First, a given commodity’s use-value is not a function of how much of


that thing there is, but its exchange-value is a function of how much it there


is. The fact there is an unlimited amount of air means that air has no


exchange value, but it does not affect air’s use-value. So to the extent that


exchange-value reflects use—value, it reflects marginal use-value: it reflects


the use-value of the next installment of that commodity—the next pair ofsneakers, the next glass of water, the next parcel of air---which, in cases


where that commodity is unlimited supply approaches zero.


      Second, exchange value is not hewed to marginal use-value per se;


rather, it is hewed to its perceived use-value. If people think that a given car


is useful, even though it useless, that will inflate its exchange its exchange-


value; and if people think that a given car is useless, even though it is useful,


that will deflate the car’s price.


      There is a tendency for perceived use-value to coalesce with actual


use-value. (If a car doesn’t work, people will know it sooner or later.) But


this tendency is indeed just a tendency. And beliefs about utility can diverge


from actual utility by an arbitrarily wide margin for an arbitrarily long period


of time. People spend enormous amounts of money college educations that


appear not only to have no actual use-value (they don’t make people smarter


or more competent and actually seem to detract from both intelligence and


competence). But people believe otherwise, and so it is that the exchange-


value of a college degree may be, even if, as is often the case, its use-value is


zero or negative.


      Also, a college degree has a kind of conventional value---a value that


is determined not by its utility (or marginal utility), but is to some extent


assigned to it by convention---in much the way that paper currency, which


has no intrinsic value, has a kind of conventional value. Which brings us tothe third reason why use-value and exchange-value can coalesce.


      Third, in some cases, objects can be assigned significances of a


conventional or semi-conventional kind. Art-work—even when not


particularly good—can become ‘fashionable’ and can thus have enormous


exchange-value. A lock of Justin Bieber’s hair, though useless in every way,


might well have great exchange value. It isn’t that people wrongly believe it


to have use-value—they don’t. But they do believe it to have value of some


kind---and that fact by itself gives it exchange-value.


        Use-value is reality-based, not perception-based. Exchange-value is


perception-based, not reality-based. For this reason, there is no limit to how


much they can diverge. For reasons that we will soon discuss, this tends to


inflate the value of the assets of the wealthy and to deflate the value of the


assets of the poor, which in turn exacerbates pre-existing inequalities.


      Let us illustrate these points in connection with housing. Smith is a


woodsman who lives in the Yukon. He has discovered a plot of land where


there is oil, but has no intention of telling anyone about it. He builds a sturdy


and functional cabin on that plot land. The use-value of that cabin is


extremely high. But its exchange-value is, at present, nil. And the reason is


the perception of its use-value is horribly off.


      Now let us consider a different scenario. Jones lives in an area where


there is no oil but where there is believed to be oil. He builds a flimsy housethere. That house has almost no actual use-value, but it has tremendous


perceived value and therefore has great exchange-value.


      But when there is a particularly large gulf between the exchange-value


of housing and its use-value, it is not usually because of faulty perceptions


about use-value; it is because the housing in question has been positively or


negatively stigmatized. I myself had a very nice house that cost very little,


simply because it was located in a ‘bad’ part of town. In actuality, that part of


town was perfectly safe and it was also conveniently located. But it was


‘uncool’, causing housing-values to plummet.


      Similarly, there are houses in unsafe and inconveniently located


neighborhoods that are ‘cool’, causing the exchange-values of those houses


to soar.


      When people have large quantities of valuable assets, they are able, it


seems, to inflate the values of those assets through a kind of fiat on their part.


In fact, they don’t have to do much of anything. If certain kinds of paintings


or clothing or personal accessories are common to the wealthy class, their


exchange-values rise in relation to their use-values, which widens the already


wide chasm between the wealthy and the non-wealthy. (If Gucci handbags


are seen as indicative of wealth, then their exchange-value rises, even though


their use-value is fixed and possibly quite low.) Similarly, if certain


commodities are common to the poor, even if they have significant use-value,their exchange-values tend to fall in relation to their use-values, which also


widens the already wide chasm between the wealth and the non-wealthy. (If


clothes from K-mart are seen as indicative of poverty, then their exchange-


value falls, even if their use-values are fixed and possibly quite high.)


      If wealth were hewed to the use-values of assets, this would have a


levelling effect on wealth-distributions: the poor would not be so poor in


relation to the rich, nor would the rich be so rich in relation to the poor. But


because exchange value diverges from use-value, and because exchange-


value is perception-based, the opposite happens: the rich are made richer by


the mere fact of their wealth, and the poor are made poorer by the mere fact


of their lack of it.


      Therborn points out that during the 2008 crisis, people who already


had money (investment-bankers) were able to create wealth for themselves by


creating securities that people believed to have value but in fact had none.


This point is worth elaborating on. The crisis of 2008 wasn’t just preceded by


securities’ being over-valued: that is what caused the crash. Second, the


securities in question were not just any securities; they were housing-backed


securities. So there were two distinct ways in which divergences between


use-value and exchange-value caused the crash. First, worthless housing was


made to seem valuable (its exchange-value was inflated relative to its use-


value). Second, worthless housing-backed securities created the falseappearance of yet additional value, causing a further inflation of exchange-


value in relation to use-value---and creating a kind of purely ‘perception-


based’ capital for those who owned those securities.


      Harvey points out that during this same period, fund-managers were


routinely raking in hundreds and sometimes billions of dollars annually.


Fund-managers make money by dumping over-valued assets and buying


under-valued assets. So their income depends entirely on their detecting


discrepancies between use-value and exchange-value. And their activities


may themselves enlarge those discrepancies: if Warren Buffet dumps the


stock of Company X, the will deflate X’s stock and therefore the exchange-


value of X’s goods, even if those goods hold their use-value; and if he buys


X’s stock, the will inflate X’s stock and therefore the exchange value of its


goods, even if those goods hold their use-value.


      To sum up: Exchange-value is about the perception, not the actuality,


of value, and those who already have wealth are in a uniquely good


perception to skew such perceptions to their own advantage.

                   Some Reflections on the Virtues of the Free Market


                          (Economics/Politics/Current Events)


 


      In California, in 2016, Proposition 64 passed, making recreational


marijuana use legal in the state of California.[15] This seems to have many


upsides, and few downsides. The likely upsides include:


 


      *Revenue to the state of California from taxes on the sale of


Marijuana,


      *An improved economy, owing to the new economic vistas opened up


by the possibility of legally growing, marketing, and distributing marijuana,


        *Decreased contempt for the law, owing to the removal of unpopular


and hard-to-enforce (and impossible-enforce-in-an-equitable-manner)


marijuana laws


        *Shrinkage of a criminal justice system bloated with so-called ‘drug-


offenders’, many of whom have spent years in jail or on parole or probation


for marijuana-related offenses,


        *Freeing up of funds now dedicated to zero-sum bureaucracies


relating probation, parole, and incarceration of pot-offenders, and


      *Improved morale, owing to decreased contempt for the law, owing to


all of these factors. 


      A possible downside is that California will become a state of ‘dope-


fiends.’ But this seems unlikely, given that even though anti-marijuana laws


led to the incarceration of many, they did little or nothing in the way of


preventing people from actually using marijuana. Indeed, there is some


evidence that anti-drug laws increase drug use, or at least have done so in the


United States.[16]


      But one rather serious problem does arise in connection with


California’s Legalization of Pot: What is to happen to people in California


who are currently incarcerated for marijuana-offenses or who, although not


incarcerated, have criminal records because of such offenses?


      One possible answer is: Reverse those convictions: free those


incarceration for such offenses and clear the records of all those, whether


incarcerated or not, who have been convicted of such offenses.


      And this is the solution that is currently being implemented, with little


opposition. San Francisco[17], Los Angeles[18], and other municipalities


have already gone this route , and it looks as the state of California as a whole


will follow suit.[19]


      Within the state of California, there is relatively little opposition to


pot’s (now) legal status, and there is also relatively little opposition to the


reversal of pot-related convictions. The interesting issues here are ones thatare not being debated because they are not even being discussed. Let me


explain.


      In legalizing pot, the state of California has effectively admitted that


the War on Drugs—at least the part of it that was concerned with pot—was a


complete failure. This means that the millions of man-hours on the part of


educators, parole and probation officers, lawyers and judges, and prison-


personnel were all for naught: that they were nothing but a waste of time,


resources and opportunity.


      That in its turn means that much the same is likely true of many other


drug-laws. It means, in other words, that the vast state-apparatuses relating to


the ‘education’ of (prospective and actual) ‘drug-offenders’ is so much


brainwashing, done in furtherance of ruinous polices, and, therefore, that the


juggernaut legal apparatus relating to the enforcement of such laws are


equally misconceived. And this in turn would seem to constitute a very major


victory for a libertarian conception of the rightful role of the State. The


libertarian holds that the state should confine itself to preventing the


commission of clear crimes (e.g. assault, rape, theft, fraud, and the like) and


should refrain from criminalizing acts for reasons of a purely moral as


opposed to pragmatic nature. The War on Drugs had—so it turns out, and so


it was always suspected—very little practical justification, its only possible


justification being that, for reasons of morality, people simply shouldn’t dodrugs. (In the 19th century, there were no anti-drug laws in the United States,


and drug use was considerably lower than it was after the War on Drugs went


into effect. In fact, with each attempt on the government to criminalize drug-


use, drug use went up. The first great example of this was prohibition, which


only increased drinking and also led to wide-spread organized crime.)


      A related point is that, now that pot is legal, the so-called ‘educators’


and other ‘authority figures’ who were involved in the War on Drugs are now


seen as so many bureaucrats who, in addition to being useless, are mere


parasites, contributing nothing and being paid for it, at the expense of the


very tax-payers penalized by their activities.


      It should be pointed that, although right-wing politicians and political


commentators have tended to be anti-drug-legalization[20], right wing


economists—hard-core free-marketeers, in other words—have always been


pro-drug-legalization, their reasons being that anti-drug-laws paralyzed the


free market, encouraged cartelism, and depleted the economy. To quote


Milton Freedman: “See, if you look at the drug war from a purely economic


point of view, the role of the government is to protect the drug cartel. That's


literally true.” https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/18583-see-if-you-look-at-


the-drug-war-from-a


      And in this context, right-wing economists were completely


vindicated. And left wing economists---who are all in favor of government-created jobs, of precisely the kind created by the invidious war on drugs---


have been proven completely wrong.


      The real ‘elephant in the room’, therefore is: How can those who are


(rightly, in my view) in favor of the legalization of drugs be (wrongly, in my


view) opposed to the free-market? When will this cognitive dissonance be


seen for and what it is, and once it is so seen, how will it affect people’s


political thinking?


         When is wealth-redistribution legitimate? (Economics/Philosophy)


 


Can wealth legitimately be spread equally among the people of a nation


based on the philosophers (namely, Kant and W.D. Ross) that you have been


introduced to?


 


      Ross and Kant are both deontologists. In their view, the ends do not as


general rule justify the means. Acting morally, in their view, is not about


being a vigilante who rights social wrongs; it is about treating people with


respect and, in Kant’s case, allowing them to exercise their autonomy freely.


In order for there to be any appreciable wealth, there must be free enterprise.


(The state can take wealth, but cannot generate it.) So in order for there to be


wealth to redistribute, there must be agents who in commercial contexts are


freely exercising their autonomy. And supposing for argument’s sake that


Kant and Ross believed that it would be good if wealth were distributed


equally, they would regard it as morally wrong to try to attain that end by


coercing people and they would regard it as doubly wrong to try to do so by


preventing people from freely exercising their autonomy. And there would be


no way without thwarting people’s autonomy to ensure that ever came to be


evenly distributed. Moreover, there would be no way to keep wealth evenly


distributed except through a coercive, and therefore rights- and autonomy-undermining, government-apparatus. So no—neither Kant nor Ross would


regard there as being any ethical way of seeing to it that wealth came to be, or


continued to be, evenly distributed. Also, it is not clear that, even if there


were some morally innocuous way of getting wealth to be, or to continue to


be, evenly distributed, either philosopher would regard that as a particularly


desirable state of affairs: they would regard it as desirable only to the extent


that it was necessary for people to treat one another with respect—and it is


not entirely clear that it would be particularly conducive to that end.


             An Economic Argument for Drug-legalization (Economics)


 


      My topic is the decriminalization of drugs (in other words, whether


drugs should be made legal). My position is: Yes—they should be made


legal: all of them, unconditionally. Usually when it is argued that drugs


should be legalized, it is argued on the grounds that it is a violation of


people’s personal and civil liberties to punish people for using drugs. And


this may well be true. But in this paper, I will argue that for reasons of a


strictly economic nature, it is necessary to make drugs legal.


      The war on drugs is extremely expensive in many ways. According to


the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 90% of people who are in jail are there for

                                                                                  [21]
drug offenses---because they had drugs on them or were selling drugs. It is


expensive to imprison people. Guards have to be paid, along with contractors,


prison physicians, and so on. And people who are in prison are not able to


contribute to the economy (except in insignificant ways, e.g. by making


license plates or picking up trash on the side of the road). Drug-offenders are


non-violent offenders, and they are also not guilty of theft or fraud or of


anything else that abridges other’s people’s freedoms. When society


imprisons someone who is violent or who steals, it more than gains in


security what it is losing in the way of that person’s potential economic


output. But when society imprisons a so-called ‘drug-offender’, the resultingloss of economic output is in no way counterbalanced by a gain in security.

[22]


      Also, in order to service the ‘war on drugs’, the police force has to be


expanded dramatically. This is expensive; these police officers had to paid,


and so do the associated judges, prosecutors, lawyers, bailiffs, and social


workers. These people would be out of a job if people were not locked up for


‘drug offences’. The more ‘drug offenders’ there are, the more work there is


for these lawyers, social workers and so on. These people depend for their


living on other people thrown in jail and denied the ability to contribute to


society. The police officers, prison guards, social workers and public-sector


lawyers are paid by the government and are therefore simply leaching off of


the tax-payer. The private-sector lawyers are paid by the ‘drug-offenders’


themselves and are therefore no less of an economic liability than their

                              [23]
public-sector counterparts. 


      Laws are expensive. These expenses are justified when they prevent


conduct that is even more expensive than they are. But drug dealing is not


expensive. It is simply a form of commerce and actually contributes to the


economy.


      In fact, if it were legal, it could do much more to contribute to society.


First of all, it could be regulated. The government could make sure that the


drugs being sold were non-toxic and of high quality, which would preventdrug-overdoses, the medical and personal costs of which are astronomical. It


could also prevent drugs from being sold to children. Most importantly, the


legalization of drugs would prevent the sale of drugs from involving actual


criminals. It wouldn’t be violent street gangs selling drugs; it would be


Walgreens.


      Also, most ‘drug-offenders’ are youthful, and they are locked up and


denied education and opportunity precisely when they can most need them.


So not only is society losing their economic output during the time they are in


jail; by depriving of them education, it is diminishing their ability to be


economically productive when they get out of jail.


      This is not to mention that the war on drugs has turned society into a


police state. The war on drugs inflated the criminal justice by a factor of ten.


These people won’t be paid unless there is a corresponding increase in the


number crimes, and they have an extremely strong incentive to ‘manufacture


crime’, which they do by lobbying for extraneous laws that people are likely


to run afoul of, and also by turning people into criminals, which they do by


saddling people with criminal records, making it hard for them to get jobs or


contribute to the economy in any non-criminal way. Also, because drugs are


illegal, drug users who are not otherwise criminals are forced to transact with


criminals; and the war on drugs therefore tends to cause non-criminals to be


absorbed into the underworld---much to the delight of defense prosecutorsand defense-lawyers. Write Nobel Prize winning economist Milton Friedman:


“Addicts are driven to associate with criminals to get the drugs, become


criminals themselves to finance the habit, and risk constant danger of death

                                  [24]
and disease” (Friedman 1972). This is not to mention the staggering health


costs resulting from overdoses and other by-products of the illegality of

      [25]
drugs.


      When it is argued that drugs should be illegal, the argument is simply


that if they were legal, we would be a nation of junkies. But is that true?


Drugs used to be legal. Heroin was created by the same company that makes


Bayer Aspirin and was sold over the counters. Were we a nation of junkies


back then? Less so than now, going by the numbers. A possible explanation


for this is given by Milton Friedman (1972):


 


      Consider first the addict. Legalizing drugs might increase the number


of addicts, but it is not clear that it would. Forbidden fruit is attractive,


particularly to the young. More important, many drug addicts are deliberately


made by pushers, who give likely prospects their first few doses free. It pays


the pusher to do so because, once hooked, the addict is a captive customer. If


drugs were legally available, any possible profit from such inhumane activity


would disappear, since the addict could buy from the cheapest source.


      The more aggressively the ‘war on drugs’ is fought, the more peopleuse drugs. And the reason is that the ‘war on drugs’ isn’t meant to be won; it


is meant to go on in perpetuity, so as to provide easy income for lawyers,


probation officers, and others economic parasites.


 


 


      Friedman, Milton, “Prohibition and Drugs”, 1 May 1972, p. 104


 


Sowell, Thomas. 2014 Why Prohibition Failed And Drugs Should Be


Legalized Retrieved from
