                                           Introduction


 


      Thanks to the internet, it is dramatically easier than it used to be for


consumers to know what is supplied and for suppliers to know what is


demanded. Prices have dropped; quality has increased; selection has grown


exponentially; efficiency has increased exponentially. The internet makes


information easy to acquire and easy to send, and that is why it has


revolutionized commerce (Bauer & Latzer, 2016).


      One of the few economic sectors that the internet has not benefited is


education (Slimp, 2019). Since the world went online in the late '90s, tuitions


have increased, and quality of instruction has fallen. This is deeply


paradoxical. Educators are information-providers; so the internet should in


principle be driving tuitions down and drive quality of instruction up.


      There are two different academic disciplines---Knowledge


Management (KM) and Information Economics (IE)—that should both


explain and solve this problem (Hawamdeh, 2007). KM is the study of how


institutions can improve internal communications and, on that basis, self-


optimize (Dalkir 2018). IE is the study of knowledge-markets (Stiglitz 1985),


a knowledge market being a market in which information is what is bought


and sold. Each of these disciplines is young, with IE coming into existence in


the '80s and KM coming into existence in the '90s. Neither discipline has saidmuch of anything about the failure of the internet to improve education


(Birchler & Butler, 2007). Further, neither has to any degree improved


education or even tried to do so, there being no documented cases of any


school self-optimizing or even trying to self-optimize on the basis of results


from each discipline.


      At the same time, each discipline is rich in results that can be used to


optimize education. The basic tenet of IE is that markets must be transparent


in order to function; in other words, the values of assets must be known and


those assets must be priced accordingly (Stiglitz 1985). The basic tenet of


KM is that organizations must be transparent in order to function; in other


words, the values of employees must be known and those employees must be


positioned accordingly (Dalkir 2018). How these tenets are to be


operationalized depends on the context. But each has been successfully


operationalized in several different contexts, and prima facie there is nothing


about the field of education that would make it especially difficult to figure


how to operationalize them in that context (Friedman, 2012). The only reason


it has not yet been figured out is, evidently, that nobody has tried (Law,


2020).


                                   Background to the Study


 


      In traditional economic theory, it is assumed that all market


participants have equal access to information. This is, of course, false, as


Hayek (1945) observed. People differ radically in respect of what they know.


According to Hayek, these differences will help society, rather than hurt it, so


long as governments don’t manipulate prices. When prices are set by the


market, Hayek reasoned, they correctly degrees of supply and demand, and


anyone who knows what prices are, no matter how ignorant he might


otherwise be, can service demand and profit.


      This model is known as Efficient Market Theory (Arrow, 1999).


Efficient Market Theory (EMT) embodies two distinct contentions: first, that


markets are efficient when assets are appropriately priced; second, that assets


are appropriately priced when governments don’t alter prices. The first


contention has proven to be unqualifiedly accurate (Friedman 2012, Sowell


2016). The second has proven to be true of some markets (Lo 2017) and false


or only partly true of others (Arrow 1996, Sen 2006, Tirole 2017). What


matters in this context is that it is an attempt to figure out how markets must


be arranged if assets, including information, are to be generated and


distributed with maximal efficiency. According to Milton Friedman (1955), a


corollary of EMT is that education cannot be efficient without beingcompletely deregulated.


      In his (1963) paper “Uncertainty and the Welfare Economics of


Medical Care”, Kenneth Arrow proved that it is impossible for knowledge to


be equitably distributed in healthcare markets and that such markets therefore


tend to be inefficient. George Akerlof (1970), Michael Spence (1970) Joseph


Stiglitz (1975) proved the same to be true of information-markets: in other


words, information is not and cannot possibly be equitably distributed in


markets in which information is itself what is bought and sold, a corollary


being that such markets therefore naturally tend to be inefficient. It was with


the work of these three authors that IE became an autonomous subdiscipline


of economics.


      The discipline of information economics has had virtually nothing to


say about education (Akinyemi, 2013). This is surprising for many reasons.


First, the education industry is a textbook case of a knowledge-market. Also,


given how large the US Education Industry is, the macroeconomic


consequences of inefficiencies in it, especially of inefficiencies resulting from


inequitably distributed information, are virtually incalculable. (According to


Bryant and Sarakatsannis (2015) “US education is a $1.5 trillion industry

 
and growing at 5 percent annually.”)Finally, American education is both


highly regulated and highly inefficient, making it an ideal testing ground for


the very kinds of deregulation that economists so vehemently advocate inother industries.


      Like IE, KM has been curiously silent about education. KM came into


existence in the earlyv90's, when companies began hiring Chief Knowledge


Officers. A CKO’s job is to organize and optimally deploy a company’s


‘intangible assets.’ An intangible asset is simply one that is not physical, and


knowledge itself is one of the most important kinds of intangible assets.


Ikujiro Nonaka’s (1991) article “The Knowledge Creating Company”,


published in the Harvard Business Review, introduced the concept of


Knowledge Management to the academic community. In 1998, Thomas


Stewart, editor of the Harvard Business Review, published his book


Intellectual Capital: The New Wealth of Organizations. This helped give


additional credibility to KM, both inside and outside of academia. Within a


few years, it became customary for universities to offer courses in KM.


      The central tenet of KM is that companies gain by treating knowledge


as a veritable asset, comparable to machinery or land, and lose when they


treat it as a mere asset-precursor (Gupta 2004, Dalkir 2018). Exactly what is


involved in treating knowledge as a veritable asset depends on the context.


      Within practically any large company outside of academia, there is at


least one person whose job title is ‘knowledge manager.' But this position


simply doesn't exist in schools and universities, and KM-theoreticians have


said quite literally nothing about how schools and universities can improveinternal communications (Yueh, 2018).


      In this work, we will map what KM and IE have already said and done


onto universities and instruction-markets. But there is an important


preliminary point. There are two very different kinds of Knowledge


Management: Reactive and Proactive (Hunter, 2016). Reactive KM involves


improving communications within an organization that is already mature and


whose structure is therefore largely fixed. Proactive KM involves creating


organizations whose structures guarantee good internal communications. A


consequence of this distinction is that there are two ways of measuring the


efficacy of KM: first, by considering reactive cases of KM, i.e. by


considering the consequences on the part of an already existing and mature


organization to implement principles of KM; second, by considering cases of


proactive KM, i.e. by studying the difference between companies that applied


KM to themselves only after they were mature and companies that were so


designed as to avoid having KM problems in the first place. Some examples


will help clarify these points.


      The Lehman Brothers investment bank was founded in 1844 and by


the early 2000s had become so large that nobody within it, including


management, had more than a fragmentary knowledge of its various


operations. Management became concerned about its lack of knowledge of


Lehman’s operations, fearing that it might be overexposed, and hiredknowledge managers to help make its operations more internally transparent


(Ball, 2018). This proved impossible, since Lehman’s various different


departments enjoyed the autonomy that Lehman’s poor internal


communications allowed them to have and actively fought attempts to expose


their workings. As a result, Lehman invested more than it could afford to lose


and collapsed when, in 2008, those investments proved to be bad ones.


Lehman tried to use reactive KM to solve its problems, but by then its


problems were intractable.


        Compare Lehman with E-trade. Founded in 1982, e-trade offers many


of the same services offered by Lehman. But it was so designed to be


lightweight, with transactions being automated whenever possible and all


digitally logged in a centralized database. Because it is well-organized and


has minimal overhead, E-trade is easy to use and charges its clients a fraction


of what its brick-and-mortar counterparts charge. By practicing proactive


KM, E-trade avoided Lehman-type communications blockages, and its


market share has grown steadily since its inception (Moschella, 2017).


      In general, reactive KM yields only modest results, while proactive


KM often yields spectacular results (Buffet, 2015). E-trade, Amazon,


Microsoft, Apple, Airbnb, and Uber are companies whose success derives


from proactive KM, and these are the very companies that we will discuss


when investigating how KM can benefit education.        KM-based cases of optimization are organization-internal, whereas IE-


based cases of optimization involve whole markets and are therefore


company-external. But IE-based optimization often results from KM-based


optimization, and we will discuss several cases of this. For example,


Amazon, E-trade, and Airbnb are both models of good KM and, partly for


that reason, also led to efficient exchanges of information within markets,


thereby optimizing those markets. But it must be kept in mind that no case of


KM-based optimization is ever actually identical with a case of IE-based


optimization, even though both may involve a single organization. Having


good internal communications is a cause of, but is not identical with,


Amazon’s making it easier for people to exchange information and products


within many different markets (Keiding, 2017).


                                       Problem Statement


 


      The problem here is how to use accepted principles of KM and IE to


optimize education. Information economists have proposed ways to optimize


finance and healthcare, and in some cases those proposals have been


implemented with good results, but they have maintained a veritable wall of


silence as to how their discipline can be used to optimize education (Stankov,


2019).


      This is deeply perplexing. The very purpose of economics is to study


how variations in inputs affect outputs. When more is spent and less is


produced, economists are quick to sound the alarm. In education, costs have


steadily grown over the last fifty years and yet outputs have declined (Busch,


2017). And yet economists have said nothing. The situation is doubly


perplexing, given how much the internet could have optimized education and


given how little it has done so (Pratt & DeDionisio, 2019). Similar points


hold of KM.


      At the same time, these disciplines have created the intellectual


instruments necessary to solve this problem. IE has made it clear how to


optimize information-markets, and KM has made it clear how to optimize


organization-internal communications. Universities are organizations, and


instructions-markets are knowledge-markets. The purpose of this study is tomap what IE has said about knowledge-markets in general onto instruction-


markets specifically and to map what KM has said about organizations in


general onto universities (Bootle, 2019).


                                       Purpose of the Study


 


      The purpose of this work is to show that IE and KM can be just as


successful at optimizing instruction-markets and institutions of learning as


they have been at optimizing knowledge-markets in general and


organizations in general.


      We will discuss several cases of KM being used to optimize


businesses and several cases of IE being used to optimize markets. It will be


shown that each case involved the elimination of a suboptimality similar to


one that vitiates American higher education, and it will then be shown how to


implement the corresponding optimizations thereto.


      When discussing KM-based cases of optimization, we will focus on


four companies: Amazon, E-trade, Uber, and Airbnb. Each of these KM-


success stories corresponds to an IE-success story. This is because good


internal communications allowed each of these companies to improve


communications with its respective market and, on that basis, to improve


those markets. We will describe the structure of each of these companies,


making it clear how that structure conduces to good internal communications.


We will then discuss how these companies were able to dominate and


optimize their respective markets. In each case, it will be made clear how


these companies optimized communications within their respective marketsand how their doing so was responsible for their both dominating and


optimizing those markets.


      We will find that, as each of these companies came to dominate its


respective market, the structure of that market and that company’s internal


structure increasingly mirrored each other. Before these companies came into


existence, those markets were opaque and inefficient. After they came into


existence, they began to become transparent and efficient, like those


companies themselves.


      We will find that these companies have several structural similarities,


in particular:


 


      *Small staff in relation to their business-volumes,


      *Heavy reliance on contract labor,


      *High degree of automation,


      *High employee turnover,


      *High degree of willingness to employ and to fire,


        *Well-defined performance-benchmarks,


      *Minimal middle-management,


      *An emphasis reducing consumer-costs, rather than on justifying high


consumer-costs,


      *An emphasis on minimizing the amount of time between purchaseand receipt of products/services,


      *Minimal reliance on public funding,


        *Non-adversarial relationship to independent and small operators,


      *An emphasis on helping suppliers and consumers find one another,


and


      *Each enables people to do for themselves what they previously had to


pay others to do (Boyd, 2019).


 


      Each of these companies benefits from market-transparency and


deregulation. Their predecessors benefited form market-opacity and


protectionism. E-trade by makes money by allowing people to act as their


own brokers. Its predecessors made money by forcing people to go through


their brokers. Uber makes money by allowing anyone to give a ride to


anyone. Its predecessors made money by contracting with local governments


to restrict would-be competitors from operating. Airbnb makes money by


allowing any given person to rent out his home for a night. Its predecessors


made money by offering lodging to people who simply didn't know that they


had alternatives. Amazon makes money by giving consumers and suppliers


access to each other. Amazon is the first company of its kind, and the markets


that it now services were opaque and inefficient prior to its existence. Each of


these companies makes money because the internet makes informationavailable, and their predecessors made money because the absence of the


internet made it unavailable (Rutherford, 2017).


      When examined, universities prove to be the very antithesis of the


just-described companies, being characterized by high:


 


      *High degree of organizational opacity,


      *Minimal turnover,


      *Low degree of willingness to employ or to fire


      *Complete non-enforcement of economically meaningful


performance-benchmarks,


      *Focus on justifying ever-increasing customer-expenses, instead of


reducing them,


      *Minimal automation,


      *Heavy reliance on incumbent status,


      *Heavy reliance public funding,


      *High degree of exposure to costly labor regulations,


        *Adversarial relationship to independent operators, and


      *Fierce opposition to allowing customers to self-service (McDonald,


2010).


 


      Despite these facts, universities are not struggling financially. On thecontrary, they are flourishing. This is because universities, though often


nominally private, are parastatal organizations that do not compete on the


open market (Cubberly, 2017). This point will be elaborated in Chapter 3.


      It might be surmised that there are formidable legal and regulatory


barriers to creating universities, or university-substitutes, that embody the


transparency and efficiency of an Amazon or an E-trade. This is not the case.


The government is remarkably willing to grant the requisite licenses and is


remarkably slow to regulate licensees out of existence (Mazzucatto, 2017).


We appear to be dealing with a true market vacuum: a case where would-be


suppliers have been slow to notice demand, and the already-mentioned


success-stories strongly suggest ways to service this demand. This will be


discussed in detail in Chapter 4.


                                       Research Questions


 


      An ‘instruction-provider’, as we will be using this term, is an


organization whose purpose is to sell instruction. Thus, a university is an


instruction-provider, as is an online tutoring agency.


      Our primary research question is:


 


      RQ1: What kind of an internal structure must an instruction-provider


if it is to benefit from a transparent instruction-market?


 


      We will find that companies cannot benefit from transparent markets


without themselves helping to make them transparent. For this reason, the


answer to RQ1 is identical with the answer to:


 


      RQ2: What kind of an internal structure must an instruction-provider


if it is to help make instruction-markets more transparent?


 


      Other questions that we will address are:


 


      RQ3: In what ways are existing instruction-providers succeeding and


in what ways are they failing? 


      RQ4: To what extent can be they be so restructured as to stop failing


in those ways, and to what extent does their continued financial well-being


depend on their being so restructured?


 


      RQ5: Are there markets that existing instruction-providers are


systemically incapable of servicing, and if so, how could they be serviced?


 


      RQ1-RQ5 are all practical questions, but the answers to them will help


us answer some important theoretical questions, the main one being


 


      RQ6: Granting that information is necessarily unevenly distributed in


instruction-markets, how can the resulting inefficiencies be minimized?


 


      RQ6 is a specialized form of an open question of Information


Economics, namely:


 


      RQ7: How can information-markets be efficient?


 


      In an information-market, information is ipso facto unevenly


distributed. In an efficient market, information is ipso facto evenlydistributed. Hence the raison d’être for RQ7.


               Advancing Scientific Knowledge and Significance of Study


 


      The primary significance of this study is that it will show how to make


education better by making it profitable. A secondary significance is that it


will show how to make knowledge-markets efficient. The first significance is


practical; the second is theoretical.


      The idea that education is corrupted by being monetized is deeply


entrenched in the popular psyche, despite there being no empirical evidence


to that effect (Busch, 2017). Also, educational institutions, unlike businesses,


are often treated as cultural icons. If a business fails to perform, no one for a


second believes that it should be allowed to hold onto its market share. There


were cries of outrage when the big three automakers were bailed, even


though they employ hundreds of thousands of Americans and are veritable


cornerstones of Americana (Tilleman, 2016). But universities receive more


and more public money as they charge their students more and more for


educations that benefit them less and less; and yet it is seldom so much as


hinted that universities should explain where that money goes. The


underlying conceit seems to be that research and instruction are sacred and


must therefore be insulated from market forces, lest they be ‘bought’


(Samuelson, 2011).


      This conceit is false and injurious. It is not selling out to provide non-defective products and services for an agreed upon price. It is selling out to


take money for defective products and services. The open market doesn’t


allow people to take money for defective or undesired products and services.


If I try to sell paintings that nobody wants or I try to sell cars that don’t work,


I will go out of business. But if my money comes from someone other than


the people who need my services, I can provide defective or useless services


and continue to be funded (Sowell, 2016).


      In any case, it is a fact that monetized information-exchanges are more


efficient non-monetized information-exchanges (Hazlitt, 1985). People who


are financially motivated to avail others of information, they do more quickly


and inexpensively than those who are not and also provide more accurate


information. This insight has been used to optimize many different kinds of


markets, including information-markets, and the present work will show how


it can be used to optimize instruction-markets.


                                   Rationale for Methodology


 


      The basic contention of this work is that information-markets,


including instruction-markets, are transparent when to the extent that they are


monetized and opaque to the extent that they are not, a corollary being that


education is optimized by being monetized.


      This proposition can be established on strictly econometric grounds.


Information, as well as information-quality, can be quantified. Therefore, it is


possible to identify and measure the factors that conduce to information-flow.


Entrepreneurs do this implicitly, and recently mathematicians and economists


have done this explicitly (Roe, 2019). Further, monetary inputs and outputs


can obviously be quantified and can therefore correlated with other


quantifiable inputs and outputs, such as labor, time, and information


(Hayashi, 2011).


        Inevitably, there will be theoretical puzzles relating to the


quantification of information, but they will not affect the contexts that we


will be considering.


        Consequently, our methodology is quantitative; more specifically,


econometrics-based, econometrics being the branch of economics that


quantitative dependencies of economics outputs on economic inputs


(Hayashi, 2011).      The mathematics involved in econometrics can be very simple or very


complex, depending on the context, and fortunately are simple in the contexts


that concern us.


                       Nature of the Research Design for the Study


 


      We will start by comparing our target-companies---Amazon, E-trade,


Uber, and Airbnb---with unsuccessful companies in similar markets. We will


assign an information-efficiency quotient (IEQ) to each company, a given


company’s IEQ being high if it is likely to capitalize on information and low


if it is unlikely to do so. On this basis, we will then identify the structural


characteristics of companies, including instruction-providers, with high


IEQ’s.


      We will then compare information-efficient markets with information-


inefficient markets. The efficient-markets will be those that were made


efficient by our target companies, and the inefficient ones will be those same


markets prior to their being thus optimized. We will then assign IEQ’s to


those various markets, on that basis identifying the structural properties of


high-IEQ markets, including information-markets.


                                       Research Questions


 


      What organizational structure must an instruction-provider have if it is


to provide the best possible instruction at the lowest possible price?


 


      What organizational structure must an instruction-provider have it is to


be sensitive to changes in the kinds of instruction that are demanded and is


also to be able to service those changes?


 


      Is it possible for a profitable instruction-provider to sell results as


opposed to services? If so how?


 


      When does research have to be insulated from market-forces in order


to be good, and when does it have to be exposed to market-forces to be good?


 


      Does tenure lead to transparency or to opacity in instruction-markets?


 


      Why are universities increasingly expensive, despite being an


increasingly bad investment?


 


      Under what circumstances does the information-asymmetries inherentin information-markets, including instruction-markets, drive down the price


of information?


 


      Are there certain kinds of information-providers that benefit from


data-protectionism and market-opacity? Does a company that sells


information about bond markets benefit from a lack of public access to data


about such markets?


 


      What kind of organizational structure must a company have if it is to


benefit from selling instruction that enables people to self-instruct?


 


      Can governments help make instruction-markets more transparent, or


does government-intervention tend to make such markets less transparent?


 


      Are information-providers necessarily put out of business if they do


their job too well?


      Is there a definition of the term ‘rational actor’ that accommodates the


fact that what a person wants changes as he acquires more knowledge and


more intelligence?


 


      We will put forth and defend answers to each of these questions. Hereare some anticipations of what we will find.


        Properly structured instruction-providers benefit from transparency in


their respective markets and are harmed by its absence. At the same time, a


belief to the contrary is embodied in the very structures of most existing


instruction-providers, a consequence being that instruction is more expensive,


less available, and of lower quality than it need be (Friedman, 1993).


        Instruction-providers benefit from market-transparency to the extent


that they provide good instruction and are harmed by it to the extent that they


don’t.


        Information-providers that are not instruction-providers fall into two


very different categories: information-hoarders (companies that make money


by blocking the flow of information and then charging people for it) and


information-seekers (companies that make money by finding information that


would be hard to obtain even in transparent markets), with information-


seekers benefiting from market-transparency and information-hoarders being


harmed it (Seward, 2016).


      The concept of a ‘rational actor’ is a coherent one, and has operational


economic significance, despite the fact that desires vary with changes in


knowledge and intelligence. The reason is that economically rational actor


necessarily desires the information needed to acquire more resources, and this


desire only grows as he acquires more such knowledge (Gawronski, 2016).                                       Definitions of Terms


 


      Parity: A situation in which economic competitors are equally


competent (Hazhimzade, 2017).


 


        Information-parity: A situation in which economic competitors are


equally informed (Clapham, 2014).


 


        Market-transparency: Equal availability of market-relevant


information to all market-participants (Hazhimzade, 2017).


 


        Market-opacity: Absence of market-transparency (Clapham, 2014).


 


      Structural market-opacity: Market-opacity due to deliberate attempts


on the part of governments or market-actors to obstruct the flow of


information (Blackburn, 2016).


 


        Non-structural market-opacity: Market-opacity due to differences in


luck, intelligence, and effort on the part of market participants, and not to


deliberate attempts on anyone's part to obstruct access to information


(Hazhimzade, 2017). 


        Information-provider: Organization whose business is to sell


information (Blackburn, 2016).


 


        Information-hoarder: Information-provider whose business involves


its restricting access to information that would otherwise be available and


then charging for access to said information (Ferguson, 2016).


 


        Information-seeker: Information-provider whose business is to obtain


information that is unavailable only because of limitations on time, effort,


and ability on the part of those want it (Rutherford, 2019).


 


        Data-protectionism: Policy adopted either by governments or private


entities of sequestering otherwise publicly available information for the


purpose of inflating its market-value and of protecting market-positions, not


for the purpose of guaranteeing organizational or public security. Data-


protectionist policies are often represented as serving the interests of national


or organizational security, the distinction between security-driven and


protectionist-driven data-sequestration tends to be clear. Data-protectionism


undermines commerce; security-driven data-sequestration does not (Upton,


2014). 


        Instruction-provider: Organization whose business is to sell instruction


(Upton, 2014).


 


        Parastatal organization: An organization that is nominally private but


functions as a governmental organization. The main difference between


parastatal and genuinely private organizations is not that the former are more


powerful than the latter; sometimes parastatal organizations have very little


power, and sometimes genuinely private organizations are very powerful.


Rather, the difference is that parastatal organizations are insulated from


market-forces and persist despite a failure to provide goods or services for


which there is any obvious demand (Reddy, 2005).


 


        Equilibrium: A market in which prices equal values is said to be in


equilibrium. Disequilibrium leads to inefficiency, since it involves


somebody’s either paying too much or not being paid enough. When prices


are above equilibrium, consumers pay too much; and when prices are below


equilibrium, suppliers are not paid enough (Ferguson, 2017).


 


      Rigid labor market: A labor market in which slow job turnover inflates


labor-costs and diminishes labor-quality (Reddy, 2005). 


      Efficient Market Theory (EMT): The principle that market-relevant


information tends to be equitably distributed, leading to equilibrium, in the


absence of government policies preventing the flow of information


(Hazhimzade, 2017).


                           Assumptions, Limitations, Delimitations


 


      People often have beliefs for which they do not have good evidence.


Such a belief is a hypothesis when it is one’s objective to prove it true, and an


assumption when one has no such objective (Kuczynski, 2009). This work


will be rich in hypotheses but relatively free of assumptions. We will make


relatively few assumptions as the truthfulness of descriptions of markets or of


organizations, since our starting-point will be that opaque markets and


organizations inherently lack credibility. As for transparent markets and


organizations, statements about them are readily verified or falsified and


therefore need not be assumed true or false.


      The discipline of economics is proverbially rich in assumptions, and


those assumptions often prove to be false or irrelevant to real-world


conditions, with the result that the theories based on them prove to be false or


useless. An extreme but otherwise quite standard example of this is EMT.


The crash of 2008 was a consequence of market-opacities resulting from


data-hoarding on the part of private institutions, coupled with credulity on the


part of the public (Soros, 2009).


      In this work, economic principles will be used, but no economic


models or theories will be assumed true. A guiding principle of the present


work is that unregulated commerce tends to be more efficient than regulatedcommerce. But this is never simply assumed in the present work; in some


cases, it is argued for, and in others, it is argued to be false.


      The main assumption that the present work makes is that what is true


of non-information markets, and also of information-markets that are not


instruction-markets, will also hold of instruction-markets. That said, there are


cases of instructions being made more efficient by being monetized, and no


cases of them being made inefficient by being monetized. So this


‘assumption’ of ours is not a pure assumption (Clarey, 2011).


      The most questionable assumption that we will make is that


instruction-markets are not in any way ‘special’---that emotional and cultural


resistances to monetizing instruction, though possible, are not inevitable. This


assumption is questionable given the iconic status that the ‘Academy’ has in


present-day culture, along with the obvious affection people have for their


‘alma maters’, despite exorbitant tuitions and minimal returns-on-investment


(Clarey, 2009).


               Summary and Organization of the Remainder of the Study


 


      In Chapter 2, the histories and structures of our target-companies---


Amazon, E-trade, Uber, and Airbnb---will be given. It will be said how their


structures differ from those of their predecessors and few remaining


competitors. It will be shown our target-companies are more aware of and


able to capitalize on market-data than their predecessor-competitors, and it


will also be explained why. It will also be explained how our target-


companies affected markets. This will involve explaining what these markets


were like before and after the inception of these companies, especially how


information-flow within changed after their inception. In some cases, notably


Amazon, these companies created new markets, the nature and effects of


which we will discuss.


      In Chapter 3, the structures of existing instruction-providers will be


compared with those of our target-companies, and the structures of existing


instruction-markets will be compared with the markets optimized or created


by those companies. Tentative conclusions as to how to optimize existing


instruction-markets will be drawn. Finally, actual examples of efficient


instruction-providers, along with the corresponding markets, will be


discussed and shown to bear out these conclusions.


      In Chapter 4, we will delineate some of the theoretical implications ofthe previous chapters. We will develop the distinction between reactive and


proactive KM. We will also discuss the distinction between normative and


descriptive IE, descriptive IE between the study of how information flows


within existing markets and normative IE being the study of how it should


flow. In relation to this, it will be discussed what both private actors and


governments can do to improve transparency within information-markets. We


will also discuss the threat of parastatal organizations to market-transparency,


especially in relation to information- and instruction-markets, and will


discuss how those can be managed. We will find reason to believe that, in the


United States at the present time, the government is not much of a threat to


transparency within such markets and that, so far as they are opaque, it is


only because private organizations have not made it a priority to make them


transparent.
