             Goldman, Rousseau and von Hayek on the Ideal State (Politics)


 


 


      What kind of state would exist in a free and just society, and why?


Goldman and Rousseau give similar answers to this question; Hayek gives a


very different answer.


      Goldman’s answer is---none. A free and just society is one in which


there is no government and therefore no state. Goldman’s position is that


government is inherently unjust--a bully that exploits and coerces and does


no good: “Just as religion has fettered the human mind, and as property, or


the monopoly of things, has subdued and stifled man’s needs, so has the State


enslaved his spirit, dictating every phase of conduct.” (Anarchism: What it


Really Stands For, p. 4)


      Of course, the question arises: If there is no government (no state),


then what will keep order? Goldman’s answer is that the very crime that it is


supposedly the state’s purpose to prevent is itself a product of the state: “The


most absurd apology for authority and law is that they serve to diminish


crime...So long as every institution of today, economic, political, social, and


moral, conspires to misdirect human energy into wrong channels; so long as


most people are out of place doing the things they hate to do, living a life


they loathe to live, crime will be inevitable, and all the laws on the statutescan only increase, but never do away with, crime.” (Anarchism: What it


Really Stands For, p. 4)


      The idea here seems to be that human beings are inherently


cooperative and, left to their own devices, engage in constructive rather than


mutually antagonistic activity.


        Rousseau’s views are similar to Goldman’s. According to Rousseau,


people are not naturally antagonistic towards one another: “So long as men


remained content with their rustic huts.....they lived free, healthy, honest and


happy lives, so long as their nature allowed, and as they continued to enjoy


the pleasures of mutual and independent intercourse.” (Discourse on


Inequality, p. 9)


      People became antagonistic, according to Rousseau, with the advent of


civilization. Civilization made it possible for people to have more than they


needed. When this happened, people became wealth- and status-driven and,


in order to maximize their wealth and status, took to mutual exploitation:


“[F]rom the moment it appeared advantageous to any one man to have


enough provisions for two, equality disappeared, property was introduced,


work became indispensable, and vast forests became smiling fields, which


man had to water with the sweat of his brow, and where slavery and misery


were soon seen to germinate and grow up with the crops.” (Discourse on


Inequality, p. 8) In other words, human beings are best off living in tribes,tribalism being intermediate between anarchy and civilization.


      There is a serious problem with Rousseau’s position. While there may


be some advantages to a tribal (or pre-civilizational) mode of existence, there


are some serious disadvantages: lack of choices in regards to profession and


lifestyle, lack of medical care, lack of education, confinement to a small


geographical area, lack of technology, and the need to work for every single


meal that one consumes. Also, it is unlikely that tribal life is as placid and


carefree as Rousseau suggests. Tribes attacked one another and were


certainly capable of behaving cruelly towards their own members. And if


tribal life is so idyllic, why don’t people opt for it today?


      Goldman’s thinking is similarly flawed. Goldman may be right that


the state is responsible for some of the crime that it claims to exist to prevent,


and she is surely right that states often behave very unjustly. But without the


state, contracts wouldn’t be enforced and there would be no economies of


scale; and the state is therefore necessary for all of the improvements to life


resulting from economies of scale.


      Rightly taking it for granted that the state is necessary for crime-


prevention and contract enforcement, Hayek advocates what he refers to as


‘liberalism’, this being the view that the state should protect people but


should otherwise not interfere with their lives: “Liberalism is opposed,


however, to supplanting competition by inferior methods of guidingeconomic activity. And it regards competition as superior not only because in


most circumstances it is the most efficient method known but because it is the


only method which does not require the coercive or arbitrary intervention of


authority. It dispenses with the need for ‘conscious social control’ and gives


individuals a chance to decide whether the prospects of a particular


occupation are sufficient to compensate for the disadvantages connected with


it.” (Road to Serfdom, pp. 45-46)


      Is Hayek right that good government is minimal government? There is


certainly considerable evidence for that claim: over-regulated economies (e.g.


the Soviet Union) tend to fail and minimally regulated ones (e.g. the US in its


early days) tend to flourish. More importantly, people should within reason


be allowed to live the way they want to live, and overly invasive


governments make that impossible. This does not mean that Hayek is


unqualifiedly correct, which he probably isn’t, but it suggests that his position


is likely to be a respectable first approximation to the truth.


      By contrast, the views of Goldman and Rousseau are not realistic,


since, as previously explained, anarchy and tribalism fail to avail people of


the freedoms and amenities that they want.    Take-home Exam on Russian History (Politics/History/Current Events)


 


      Discuss the sources of the revolution initiated by the Bolsheviks in


1917. Address all relevant political, social, and economic causes. Was the


revolution avoidable? Did the tsar's reforms after the 1905 Revolution have


any chance at preventing the revolution? Explain.


 


      The Bolshevik Revolution per se had little popular support. But the


Tsar’s government was weak, and towards the end of World War 1, and


largely because of it, more or less just collapsed, at which point the


Bolshevik’s simply ‘picked up’ power. The relevant question isn’t so much


“what caused the Russian Revolution?” as it is “what caused the Tsarist


system of government to lose power and credibility?” And the answer to the


latter is as follows. Russia was largely poor; it was divided between a small


group of very wealthy people and a vastly larger group of very poor people.


Also, there was a growing urban intellectual class that (with some legitimacy)


saw Tsarism as antiquated and unprogressive. The Tsarist system was


proverbially bureaucratic and autocratic (though not, ironically, anywhere


nearly as much as the Soviet system that would replace it). Tsar Nicolas’s


reforms had a ‘too little, too late’ quality. WWI decapitalized Russia and


made it defenseless against the numerically small but determined BolshevikParty, which, as previously stated, was not at that point met by strong


resistance to its (successful) 1917/1918 power-grab.


 


      Describe and discuss Stalin's Five-Year Plans. What was the goal of


these plans? Did Stalin achieve his goals? Were there any negative


consequences? Explain and provide examples.


 


 


      Stalin, though in some ways a ‘strong leader’, was really just an inept


bungler whose methods of statecraft were crude. And his infamous ‘Five


Year Plans” were prime examples of this. The Five-Year Plans were attempts


to modernize and industrialize Russia, by building damns, factories, and the


like, and in this way supposedly modernizing Russia’s economy. It should be


pointed out that much of the labor for the Five Year Plans was slave labor,


supplied by Stalin’s burgeoning Gulag population, which, though initially


created by Stalin’s attempting to hold onto power by incarcerating actual,


possible and conceivable political opposition, soon became (to some extent)


about providing the labor-force for Stalin’s expensive Industrialization


efforts. In any case, the Five Year Plans were successful in some respects;


they did turn the Soviet Union into an industrial and military power. But they


were grand failures in other respects, in that, even though they made theSoviet Union militarily powerful, they made the Soviet people poor and they


also decapitalized the country, which led its collapse 50 years later.


 


 


      Describe the distribution of power under the Soviet model. What


institutions were most powerful? How did this differ from the way power is


supposed to be distributed? Make sure that you provide examples and


address the concept of democratic centralism.


 


      The Communist Party of the Soviet Union would elect a Central


Committee, this being a kind of ‘board of directors’ of the Soviet Union. The


Central Committee would elect a Politburo, this being comparable, within


limits, to the President’s ‘Cabinet.’ The politburo would elect a General


Secretary, who was the Supreme Leader of the entire Soviet Union. The


outcomes of these ‘elections’ were, at least during the Stalin years and to a


lesser extent later, pre-determined by existing political alliances. But that is


the way in which those alliances were given official force. The Central


Committee and Politburo, under the direction of the General Secretary, would


issue edicts/recommendations to local Party Central Committees, which, in


their turn, would run their respective geographical territories.


       What is civil society? Do you agree that civil society is necessary for


the formation of democracy? Explain. How did the Soviet Union deal with


civil society? Has Russia under Putin's leadership been any different? Do


you think Russia can become democratic based on its experiences with civil


society?


 


 


      Civil Society is the totality of institutions and practices and values in a


given country that are not either political or strictly commercial in in nature.


Thus, family, religion (except for state-imposed religion), private morality,


and personal conduct (e.g. one’s conduct outside of political contexts or


commercial exchanges) are aspects of civil society. Civil society is not


technically necessary for democracy. In a society of economic actors---none


of whom had any existence apart from their business interests—there would


still be a need for, and a possibility of, democracy. In fact, democratic


institutions are especially important when it comes to the protection of


economic interests, mainly of one’s right to engage in trade. Under the Soviet


Union, civil society was fiercely repressed. Under Putin, civil society is not


particularly repressed, contrary to what it is chic to say. Russians under Putin


can recreate as they wish and they are free to engage in commerce (even


though they often have to deal with organized crime). 


      How has Putin managed to consolidate power in Russia? Has he


obtained the support of the population and the Duma? If so, how? Evaluate


whether there is any chance at democracy developing under Putin.


 


      Putin began in the KGB. After the Soviet Union fell, he became a


protégé of Boris Yeltsin and was appointed Prime minister by Yeltsin in


1999. Putin later pardoned Yeltsin, thereby indebting the latter to him. Putin


showed strength and decisiveness throughout his career. He began by


imprisoning Oil Oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky, which sent a message to


the other Oligarchs—who threatened to dilute Putin’s power by having a


share of it—to cease to vie for political power. Putin also handled a number


of crises, including the Chechen War and also the seizure of a Moscow movie


theatre by Chechen rebels—in a decisive manner, thus earning the respect, or


at least the fear, of the Russian populace. Putin is in fact popular with the


Russian people (even after allowances are made for likely fabrications on the


part of a Putin-controlled media) because he is seen as having stabilized the


country. And for similar reasons (and with similar qualifications), Putin is


popular with the Duma, having recently won a ‘super-majority’ of support


therein.


       What are the primary problems with the Russian economy? Provide


explanations that engage economic and political factors. Based on this


information, what changes need to occur for the Russian economy to improve


and stabilize? Are these changes likely? Why or why not?


 


      Russia has three major economic problems. First, it relies too much on


energy-exports. Technology is making many economic sectors less energy-


dependent, and Russia’s reliance on a global energy-demand therefore does


not bode well for it.


      Also, Russia suffers from political corruption, which negatively


affects entrepreneurs and also discourages foreign investment in Russia.


      Finally, Russia, partly for the two reasons just mentioned, is suffering


from a ‘brain-drain’: many talented members of intelligence-heavy


professions are leaving Russia for greener pastures.


      In order to hedge against these problems, Russia would need to


diversify its economy, which will be difficult to do unless political corruption


is reigned in. It should be pointed out that there have been relatively non-


corrupt autocracies and there have been, and are, highly corrupt democracies.


So it isn’t necessarily the case that the demise of Putin-style autocracy is a


sine qua non for the improvement of Russia’s economy. (Putinites would


argue that the opposite is the case.) In any case, it doesn’t seem particularlylikely that the needed changes will happen, mainly because no one—not


Putin, not his opponents—seems to have any clear ideas as to how to make it


happen. Nor are there are any obvious ideas as to how to do this. Nor, indeed,


does there seem to be the requisite political will. My personal feeling is that


there were incentive-programs for small businesses in Russia—programs that


incentivized the Russian equivalent of Facebook (which, incidentally, does


exist)---this might lead to the needed sort of economic diversification. But


any views on these matters are necessarily speculative at this point.          Did the founding fathers support or oppose democracy? Was the


    Constitution a democratic document or an anti-democratic document?


                                    (History/Politics)


 


      The US Constitution is at its core a democratic document, and since


the US Constitution is the embodiment of the political views of its framers,


these being the Founding Fathers, it follows that the Founding Fathers


supported democracy. In this paper, it will be shown, largely on the basis of


direct quotes from the original (1789) US Constitution, that the latter is a


largely if not a completely democratic document. Then we will show that


some apparently undemocratic provisions of the Constitution are in fact


democratic. Finally, we will discuss the fact that during the early years of the


republic, only propertied white males could vote, and we will show that this


obviously undemocratic practice does not prove the Constitution or the


Founding Fathers to be undemocratic.


      A democracy is a society in which the people elect their officials. In


the system of government described in the 1789-Constitution, key


government officials are elected and those that are not elected are appointed


by those who are. First of all, provisions are made for the election of


representatives, Senators and a chief executive (or President). In Article I,


Section 2 of the 1789-Constitution says: “The House of Representatives shallbe composed of Members chosen every second Year by the People of the


several States, and the Electors in each State shall have the Qualifications


requisite for Electors of the most numerous Branch of the State


Legislature….”


      This quote makes it that “the People”, this being some subset of the


general population, choose who their governmental representatives will be, at


least within limits.


      Later in Article I, Section 2 it is written that: “Representatives and


direct Taxes shall be apportioned among the several States which may be


included within this Union, according to their respective Numbers, which


shall be determined by adding to the whole Number of free Persons,


including those bound to Service for a Term of Years… When vacancies


happen in the Representation from any State, the Executive Authority thereof


shall issue Writs of Election to fill such Vacancies.”


      The first sentence of this quotations indicates that the degree of


representation given to a state is a function of the number of people in that


state, and the second sentence indicates that it is the citizens of that state who


decide who will represent them.


      The last sentence of Article I, Section 2 states that: “The House of


Representatives…shall have the sole Power of Impeachment.” In other


words, these representatives have the power to remove the President fromOffice (or at least to initiate proceedings to the effect), this being a way of


keeping the President under the control of elected officials.


      The 1789-Constitution intends for the House of Representatives to be


unqualifiedly democratic, since it provides both that the people in a given


state elect their representatives and also that the number of representatives


per state is proportional to that state’s population.


      In Section III of the 1789-Constitution, it is written that: “The Senate


of the United States shall be composed of two Senators from each State,


chosen by the Legislature thereof, for six Years; and each Senator shall have


one Vote.” Thus, the 1789-Constitution intends for the Senate to be a


qualifiedly democratic institution, since although it provides that the people


of a given state shall elect their own Senators, it does not provide that the


number of Senators per state is proportional to that state’s population.


      In Article II, Section 1, it is written that: “The executive Power shall


be vested in a President of the United States of America. He shall hold his


Office during the Term of four Years, and, together with the Vice President,


chosen for the same Term, be elected, as follows.” Each state has a number of


‘electors.’ The number of electors per state is proportional to the population


of that state. The electors for a given state unanimously vote for the


Presidential candidate voted for by a majority of the people in that state. So it


is these electors who directly vote for President; the people only indirectly doso. But these electors always vote in line with the votes cast by the majority


of their constituents.


      Basically, a state’s citizens do not directly vote for President. Rather,


their state directly votes for the President, and they vote for who their state


will vote for.


      This system makes it possible for a Presidential candidate who loses


the popular vote to win the election, and some might regard this system as


undemocratic or only imperfectly democratic. But that is not the only


possible view of the matter. The electoral system gives the vote to states, and


it therefore preserves all of the democratic functions carried out by states.


      There is an important respect in which the United States in 1789 was


not democratic. Only white, male land-owners could vote. Women could not.


Native Americans could not. African-Americans could not. And,


significantly, unpropertied while males could not. (Be it noted that the 1789-


Constitution does not itself restrict the vote to propertied while males. The


Constitutions was silent on the matter, it being the culture at large that limited


suffrage in this way.)


      Why was this? Although an element of racism, sexism and snobbism


may have played a role, this system was primarily about restricting suffrage


to people who had an economic stake in the welfare of the country.


Obviously, slaves did not want the country to be an economic success, sinceit was denying them their freedom, and if given the right to vote, they might


well have voted for its destruction. As for Native Americans, even though the


United States did not enslave them and even though they had commercial ties


to it, their welfare did not depend on its welfare, and for this reason they


could not be counted to vote for its welfare. As for women in this time


period, they were not engaged in commerce and, however positive their


intentions towards the United States, might have been, they could not be


counted upon to vote in an informed manner. The same is true of white males


who had no property: however positive their intentions might have been, they


could not be counted upon to vote in an informed manner.


      Finally, the 1789-Constitution did not prevent anyone from voting,


and it has proved easy to amend so as to grant suffrage to people who did not


previously have it. This was by design. The Founding Fathers designed a


system that had a fundamentally democratic structure. That system has not


always been implemented in a maximally democratic way, but that is only


because it has not always been implemented as it was meant to be.


      In conclusion, the 1789 US-Constitution describes a highly democratic


system of government. Although it contains some apparently undemocratic


provisions, these provisions prove upon analysis not to be undemocratic or to


be only qualifiedly so. As for the fact that only white propertied males could


vote during the early years of this country’s existence, that had no basis in theConstitution, which did not prevent anyone from voting, and was instead a


consequence of the way in which the Constitution was implemented.


                     The Two Faces of China’s Negative Soft Power:


          China’s Belt and Road Initiative as a Case of Negative Soft Power


                                        (Politics)


 


      There are two kinds of power that a nation can have: hard power and


soft power. Hard power is the ability to coerce using military or economic


means. Soft power is about influencing, as opposed to coercing. A nation’s


soft power lies in the appeal of its culture, the sentiments that others have


about its practices, and its general countenance.


      Just as there are two kinds of power, so there are two kinds of soft


power: positive and negative. Positive soft power is the power to influence


other nations to engage in a constructive or affirmative endeavor, e.g. to build


a dam. Negative soft power is the power to influence other nations to engage


in a negative or privative endeavor, e.g. to refuse to transact with some nation


or to withdraw support from


      There are two kinds of negative soft power: the deliberate kind and the


inadvertent kind. In other words, negative soft power can sometimes, be used


deliberately, but it can also just ‘happen’, without its being intended by the


nation in question. An example of deliberate negative soft power would be


the U.S.’s boycotting the Soviet Olympics in 1980: this was not a case of the


US’s coercing anybody, militarily or otherwise. But it sent a message to othernations that the United States took a dim view of the Soviet Union, which


message in turn reinforced those other nations’ existing misgiving about the


Soviet Union.


      A case of inadvertent negative soft power would be the detestation for


the US in the Islamic world that have resulted from the US’s attempts to


grace the Islamic world with its pop culture, which attempts were seen in the


Islamic world not as acts of kindness but as acts of cultural imperialism and


of religious intolerance.


      In this study, I am going to show that China, through its Belts and


Roads Initiate (BRI), is exercising a number of different forms of soft power:


positive, deliberate negative, and inadvertent negative. On the one hand, as


we will see, some see this initiative as a sincere attempt on China’s part to


build economic (and literal) bridges between nations: so to this extent, it is a


case of positive soft power. On the other hand, some see it as attempts on


China’s part to infiltrate other nations: so to this extent it is inadvertent


negative soft power. Finally, China has deliberately represented BRI as being


a conscious attempt on China’s part to rally Asian and African nations


against the US and other Western powers: so to this extent, it is deliberate


negative soft power.


             Interest Groups and Political Parties (Politics/Current Events)


 


        Describe the evolution of political parties in the United States.


      The United States is technically a multi-party system, but in practice,


it is and always has been a two-party system. When the United States was


founded, there were no political parties, in the United States or anywhere


else. The Founding Fathers did not see American as being party-based, and


the Constitution does not even refer to political parties. But political parties


quickly came into existence, quickly stabilizing into the two-party


configuration that we still have today. The first two parties were the


Federalist Party and the Democratic-Republican Party. The Federalist party


concerned with the country’s macro-economic well-being, and the


Democratic-Republican Party was concerned more with the individual’s


welfare and quality of life. The Federalist party corresponded (with some


qualifications) to today’s Republican Party, and the Democratic-Republican


Party corresponded to today’s Democratic Party. (The qualifications relate to


the fact that the Federalist Party was focused mainly on economic matters


and, unlike today’s Republican Party, had little or no interest, or even


negative interest, in ‘religious values’ and ‘family values’ and the like.)


      In fact, for the entirety of the USA’s existence, politics has been


dominated by two parties, one corresponding to today’s Democratic Party,the other corresponding to today’s Republican Party.


      The actual Democratic Party came into existence in the 1830s and was


founded by Andrew Jackson, as an attempt to transfer wealth away from


plutocrats and into the hands of the masses, and the actual Republican Party


was founded in 1854, largely as an attempt to end slavery but also as an


attempt centralize power and unify the country under sustainable macro-


economic policies.


      As the just-stated facts make clear, there have been pronounced shifts


within and between the parties. Someone with Andrew Jackson’s values


would now being seen as the antithesis of a democratic; in fact, Jackson’s


positions were strongly in line with those of current President Donald Trump.


(Trump, though wealthy and though in some ways a supporter of the wealthy,


is also an arch-populist, just as Jackson was.) And Lincoln, though a


Republican, probably had values at least in some ways more in line with


those of contemporary democrats. (That said, Lincoln was in other respects


quite representative of modern Republicanism, mainly in that, despite his


progressive views on race-relations, he represented the interests of the


Corporatistic North over the more agrarian and in some ways pre-capitalist


South.)


      But even more striking than what has changed the American Party


Politics over the last 250 years is what hasn’t changed. During any givenelection cycle, there is one party that focuses on macro-economic policy, and


another that focuses on ‘the little guy’; there is one party that wants to


centralize power and another that wants to decentralize it; there is one party


that wants to cleave to the Constitution, and another that regards the


Constitution as being contraindicated. In some contexts, in some respects, the


Republican Party represents, or is seen as representing, the interests of small


businesses; in other words, the Democratic Party has that role. At certain


junctures, the Republican Party is relatively isolationist and relatively


uninclined to go to war, and the Democratic party, being less isolationist, is


relatively inclined to do so; and at the other junctures, the roles are reversed.


      Despite the differences between the two parties, there was a kind of


equilibrium or stalemate between the Republicans and the Democrats. They


agreed to disagree on certain issues and to agree on others, and their back-


and-forth had a rather automated, kabuki-like quality to it. But with Donald


Trump that changed (whether for better or worse is obviously a matter of


debate). What is distinctive about Trump is that he came into politics from


the outside. He is not a politician; he is a businessman who went into politics.


And this is reflected in his views, which are in some ways more disruptive to


Republican orthodoxies than to Democratic orthodoxies. (Trump actually


conforms quite well to Democratic presumptions about the Republican Party,


and for that same reason Trump does not conform well to Republican effortsto mollify the Democratic Party.) In any case, though, American party


politics was quick to come into existence and assume a form barely


distinguishable from its contemporary form. Be it noted that, in his book


Propaganda, Edmund Bernays, the father of modern advertising, claimed


that, for reasons of psychology, people need political parties and, at the same


time, that they cannot have more than two. And it would seem that Bernays


was right.


                                               France


 


      France has a semipresidential system. What exactly does this mean?


Specifically, address the roles of the executive and legislative branches in


this system. Would you recommend the semipresidential system for other


countries? Explain why or why not


 


      Much like Russia, France has a semi-presidential system of


government, meaning that there is a prime-minister as well as President, both


of whom are answerable to the nation’s legislature. A semi-presidential


system differs from a parliamentary republic in that in the case of a


parliamentary republic the president is a mere figure head, whereas in the


case of a semi-presidential republic has real power. And semi-presidential


system differs from a presidential system in that, whereas in a presidential


system the cabinet is appointed by the president and can also be dismissed by


him, in a semi-presidential system the cabinet is appointed by the legislature


and cannot be unilaterally dismissed by the president. In France, the President


names the Prime Minister.


        France’s government, like the USA’s, is divided into executive,


legislative, and judicial branches. And the judicial branch, like the USA’s, is


divided into a National Assembly, corresponding to the US House ofRepresentative, and a Senate, corresponding to the US senate.


      The legislative process in France, though basically similar to its


American counterpart. In the United States, the Supreme court does not


determine the constitutional of a prospective law; it merely determines the


constitutionality of pre-existing laws, and then only under when their


constitutionality is made salient by criminal or civil litigation. But in France,


in order for a bill to become law, its constitutionality must be determined in


advance (by the Constitutional Adviser) and so must its consistency with


existing National and European laws (by the Conseil d’état). But the largest


difference between the American and the French system is that, whereas the


American system is presidential, the French system is semi-presidential, so


that the French system has a ‘dual executive’ branch.


      The advantage of a semi-presidential over a presidential system is that


it tends to prevent political gridlock, mainly by making it impossible for the


President to exercise power without the support of both the Prime Minister


and the legislature. So the legislature and the executive have trouble drifting


far enough apart from each other for there to be insuperable disagreements


between them. At the same time, this is also, at least in some contexts, a


disadvantage, since it prevents the President taking the bold initiatives that


may be necessary to deal with crises.


      My personal view is that, while there should be checks and balancesand that Presidential authority must be restricted, the presidential has more


than enough checks and balances on the President’s power. By the same


token, the semi-presidential arraignment over-limits the President and


(unless, as is the case in Russia, which is really an autocracy and only


formally a semi-presidential system) and prevents him from taking bold and


(in some contexts) necessary action.


                                               Russia


 


      How has geography influenced Russian political development over the


centuries?


 


      The Russian Empire was physically extremely large. Also, much of it,


being Arctic or Sub-arctic, is very cold. Further, even though it has the


largest coastline of any country, that coastline is on the Arctic Ocean and is


therefore of limited use for either commerce or for Russia’s self-


management. Russia’s size, though in some respects a strength, left it


exposed to invaders and made it difficult to protect, this being why, over the


centuries, it sustained a series of nasty blows at the hands of numerous


Central Asian and East Asian countries.


      Also, whereas the United States is replete with high-quality arable


land, the land in Russia is relatively non-arable and the climate is


inhospitable to many forms of agriculture. Russia’s geographical isolation,


coupled with enormous size and the difficulties involved in Russia-internal


(and therefore largely land-based) travel, had the result that Russia as a whole


was in some ways more backwards than other European nations, being


slower than most other European nations (including some Eastern European


nations) to receive the benefits of political enlightenment. Also, thedifficulties involved in traveling from Russia’s urban centers (e.g. St.


Petersburg and Moscow)—all of which are located in the far West of the


country and in which Russia’s aristocracy as well as its intelligence tended to


reside---created an unusually large cleavage in outlook and in standard of


living between the elite and the non-elite of Russia, which helped make


Russia vulnerable to the 1917 Revolution.


        Additionally, Russia, being large and being difficult to travel within,


was (and is) difficult to govern and to control, which is probably part of what


made Russia slow to adopt democratic rule and which, in turn, was part of


what it made relatively easy for the Bolsheviks to take over. To this day,


Russia is ruled in a semi-autocratic manner, and its lack of arable manner has


resulted in an economy that over-relies in petrol exports.


      Further, its harsh climate and vast internal distances make it difficult


(but not impossible) to develop medium sized business.


   What led to the collapse of the Soviet Union? (Politics/History/Current


                                        Events)


 


      The proximal cause of the collapse of the Soviet Union was the


lowering of gas prices that occurred in the late 80s. Russia, being a defunct,


bureaucratic communist nation had very little economy, and its revenue came


almost entirely from petroleum exports. So when petroleum prices fell in the


late 80s, Russia was completely decapitalized, and its economy literally


ground to a halt: trains containing food didn’t even leave the station, since


worker’s weren’t being paid.


      The fall in prices was deliberate, being the workmanship of strongly


anti-Soviet US President Ronald Reagan, who had already done much to


deplete Soviet coffers by engaging in it a Nuclear Arms Race. (It was unclear


whether it was Reagan’s intention in engaging in the Arms Race to


decapitalize the Soviet Union. Some believe Reagan’s motivations were of a


knee-jerk anti-Communist kind. Others believe that, indeed, Reagan was


deliberately driving the Soviet Union to poverty and subsequent collapse.)


      Because Russia had no legitimate free market on the basis of which to


generate funds, a return to Communism was not an option. At the same time,


Russia had a vast grey-market economy and—as the next few years would


make clear—no shortage of entrepreneurial talent. So (after a years ofeconomic catastrophe, courtesy of Jeffrey Sachs and other Western Economic


advisers) the Iron Hand of State-planning quickly made way for the Invisible


Hand of the free market.


 


      What kind of political system does Russia have now? Is it effective?


Legitimate? Explain.


 


      Russia is a Constitutional (constitution-based) Federal, Semi-


presidential Republic. It is Federal in that, like the United States, it consists


of a plurality of states that have their own individual governments but that are


in their managed by a single (Federal) government. It is semi-Presidential, as


opposed to presidential, in that, although the President is the de jure head of


government, he shares power with a Prime Minister. (In actuality, the Prime


Minister, Vladimir Putin, has more power than the President, Dmitry


Medvedev.)


      In practice, Russia is a semi-autocratic state with democratic elements


—but more of an autocracy than a democracy. This configuration is


legitimate in the Russian people, though far from happy with every aspect of


the job Putin is doing, seem to prefer strong, centralized governance, as


opposed to decentralized, democratic governance.


      So relative to the awesome tasks faced by any possible government ofRussia, the semi-autocratic, semi-democratic approach seems indicated, in


that it combines the decisiveness and crisis-reading of a strong, autocratic


government with the responsiveness to the people’s needs of a democratically


elected government.


 


      Is it possible for Russia to break its dependence on strong leaders? If


so, how will it get rid of Putin? And should it?


 


      While it is an article of faith in the West that ‘democracies’ are good


and ‘autocracies’ are bad, autocracies can sometimes function better. An


example is China: China’s massive economic growth and economic


liberalization over the last 30 years were consequences of sapient, but strong


centralized management. Russia’s economic growth during the last few


decades, though not quite as good as China’s, has still been considerable.


And this seems, at least in part, to have been made possible by the political


stability created by Putin’s rather autocratic ruling style.


      Also, Russia, consisting as it does of a plurality of oftentimes mutually


belligerent nationalities, might be better off, at least for the time being,


having decisive strong rulers, instead of politically driven weak ones. Be it


noted that, whereas only 1/5th of Russians express support for the democratic


leaders they have had (basically Gorbachev and Yeltsin), ½ of Russians still                                                          [26]
have positive feelings about Brezhnev and Stalin!


      So while Putin’s future is unclear and while there is legitimate


disagreement as to his merits, it seems unlikely that Western style democracy


in Russia is particularly likely or desirable any time soon.


           Plato’s Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy (Politics/Philosophy)


 


      For Plato, justice is identical with people staying in their ‘rightful


place.’ (“[T]o do one’s own business, in some shape or other, is justice.” [433


b] ) Plato has a very narrow and hierarchical conception of what a person’s


‘rightful place’ is. He believes that a person’s social position should be


determined by his ‘nature.’ He further believes that one’s ‘nature’ cannot in


any relevant respects change. (“You are, all of you in this community,


brothers. But when god fashioned you, he added gold in the composition of


those of you who are qualified to be Rulers (which is why your prestige is


greatest); he put silver in the Auxiliaries, and iron and bronze in the farmers


and other workers.” [412 e] )


      A corollary is that, for Plato, social strata should be rigidly defined, it


being necessary that the barriers between them be virtually impenetrable.


(““If they [the non-ruling classes] follow these rules, they will be safe


themselves and the saviors of the city; but whenever they come to possess


lands, and houses, and money of their own, they will be householders and


cultivators instead of guardians, and will become hostile masters of their


fellow-citizens rather than their allies.” [416 b] )


      Further, Plato doesn’t acknowledge the legitimacy of a person’s


private life. For him, the entirety of a person’s life should be subordinate tothe interests of the state. Marriages should be arranged. (“We must arrange


for marriage, and make it as sacred an affair as we can. And a sacred


marriage is one that produces the most beneficial results.” [458 e]) And


people must never marry or reproduce with people outside of their social


classes. (“Guardians must ‘mate the best of our men with the best of our


women as often as possible, and the inferior men with the inferior women as


seldom as possible, and bring up only the offspring of the best.’” [459 e] )


      In Plato’s ‘ideal republic’, life is so micromanaged by the state that


there is practically no such thing as private life. Every aspect of each citizen’s


life must be in alignment with the interests of the state, and existence is


completely collectivized. (“Our men and women Guardians should be


forbidden by law to live together in separate households, and all the women


should be common to all the men; similarly, children should be held in


common, and no parent should know its child, or child its parent.” See also:


“They shall have no private property beyond the barest essentials. Second,


none of them shall possess a dwelling-house or storehouse to which all have


not the right of entry. Next, their food shall be provided by the other citizens


as an agreed wage for the duties they perform…” [416 d] )


      Plato correctly states that such a rigidly hierarchical social


arrangement cannot be


      sustained unless the masses are kept ignorant and constantly lied to.(“And no one but the rulers must know what is happening, if we are to avoid


dissension in our Guardian herd.” [459 a] )


      So with respect to the question “To what extent does justice (for Plato)


depend upon the state propagation of falsehoods?”, the answer is:


Completely. For Plato, justice depends on the state’s constantly lying to its


own citizenry. Not only that. It depends on its keeping them ignorant and also


in the resulting gaps in its citizens’ knowledge with carefully constructed


propaganda. Plato himself says this. Plato clearly states that the state must


constantly subject its own citizenry to propaganda (pro-state lies) if the state


is to remain intact and unified, it being Plato’s contention that nothing is


more important than unity and intactness of the state. (“Is there anything


worse for a state to be split and fragmented, or anything better than cohesion


and unity?” [462 b] )


      As for the question “Insofar as deception is necessary to maintain


justice, can Plato’s distinction between benign or beneficial lies and improper


or dangerous ones be sustained?”, the answer is: No--not at all. Of course, the


answer to this question is tautologously ‘yes’ if one accepts Plato’s


conception of ‘justice.’ But according to Plato’s conception of justice,


nobody is entitled to any freedoms of any kind. Since there is no independent


reason to accept such a conception of justice, and every reason to reject, the


actual answer to the above question is indeed: No. The lies that, in Plato’sview, the state should require its citizens to accept are ones that the state must


tell if it is to continue to enforce Plato’s conception of justice, According to


that conception of justice, people do not have the right to listen to the kind of


music they enjoy or marry the people they love or indeed do much of


anything that they personally would like to do. Since such a restrictive


conception of justice is false and evil, any lies that are told to uphold it are


ipso facto evil, and there is therefore to principled distinction between good


and evil lies in relation to such a conception.

                           Politics in the USA, Russia and France


 


                Harvard University Political Science Take-home Exam


 

Political Parties in the United States: A Brief History

                   Political Parties in the United States: A Brief History


 


      Describe the evolution of political parties in the United States.


 


      The United States is technically a multi-party system, but in practice,


it is and always has been a two-party system. When the United States was


founded, there were no political parties, in the United States or anywhere


else. The Founding Fathers did not see American as being party-based, and


the Constitution does not even refer to political parties. But political parties


quickly came into existence, quickly stabilizing into the two-party


configuration that we still have today. The first two parties were the


Federalist Party and the Democratic-Republican Party. The Federalist party


concerned with the country’s macro-economic well-being, and the


Democratic-Republican Party was concerned more with the individual’s


welfare and quality of life. The Federalist party corresponded (with some


qualifications) to today’s Republican Party, and the Democratic-Republican


Party corresponded to today’s Democratic Party. (The qualifications relate to


the fact that the Federalist Party was focused mainly on economic matters


and, unlike today’s Republican Party, had little or no interest, or even


negative interest, in ‘religious values’ and ‘family values’ and the like.)


      In fact, for the entirety of the USA’s existence, politics has beendominated by two parties, one corresponding to today’s Democratic Party,


the other corresponding to today’s Republican Party.


      The actual Democratic Party came into existence in the 1830s and was


founded by Andrew Jackson, as an attempt to transfer wealth away from


plutocrats and into the hands of the masses, and the actual Republican Party


was founded in 1854, largely as an attempt to end slavery but also as an


attempt centralize power and unify the country under sustainable macro-


economic policies.


      As the just-stated facts make clear, there have been pronounced shifts


within and between the parties. Someone with Andrew Jackson’s values


would now being seen as the antithesis of a democratic; in fact, Jackson’s


positions were strongly in line with those of current President Donald Trump.


(Trump, though wealthy and though in some ways a supporter of the wealthy,


is also an arch-populist, just as Jackson was.) And Lincoln, though a


Republican, probably had values at least in some ways more in line with


those of contemporary democrats. (That said, Lincoln was in other respects


quite representative of modern Republicanism, mainly in that, despite his


progressive views on race-relations, he represented the interests of the


Corporatistic North over the more agrarian and in some ways pre-capitalist


South.)


      But even more striking than what has changed the American PartyPolitics over the last 250 years is what hasn’t changed. During any given


election cycle, there is one party that focuses on macro-economic policy, and


another that focuses on ‘the little guy’; there is one party that wants to


centralize power and another that wants to decentralize it; there is one party


that wants to cleave to the Constitution, and another that regards the


Constitution as being contraindicated. In some contexts, in some respects, the


Republican Party represents, or is seen as representing, the interests of small


businesses; in other words, the Democratic Party has that role. At certain


junctures, the Republican Party is relatively isolationist and relatively


uninclined to go to war, and the Democratic party, being less isolationist, is


relatively inclined to do so; and at the other junctures, the roles are reversed.


      Despite the differences between the two parties, there was a kind of


equilibrium or stalemate between the Republicans and the Democrats. They


agreed to disagree on certain issues and to agree on others, and their back-


and-forth had a rather automated, kabuki-like quality to it. But with Donald


Trump that changed (whether for better or worse is obviously a matter of


debate). What is distinctive about Trump is that he came into politics from


the outside. He is not a politician; he is a businessman who went into politics.


And this is reflected in his views, which are in some ways more disruptive to


Republican orthodoxies than to Democratic orthodoxies. (Trump actually


conforms quite well to Democratic presumptions about the Republican Party,and for that same reason Trump does not conform well to Republican efforts


to mollify the Democratic Party.) In any case, though, American party


politics was quick to come into existence and assume a form barely


distinguishable from its contemporary form. Be it noted that, in his book


Propaganda, Edmund Bernays, the father of modern advertising, claimed


that, for reasons of psychology, people need political parties and, at the same


time, that they cannot have more than two. And it would seem that Bernays


was right.


                                   France’s Political System


 


      France has a semipresidential system. What exactly does this mean?


Specifically, address the roles of the executive and legislative branches in


this system. Would you recommend the semipresidential system for other


countries? Explain why or why not


 


      Much like Russia, France has a semi-presidential system of


government, meaning that there is a prime-minister as well as President, both


of whom are answerable to the nation’s legislature. A semi-presidential


system differs from a parliamentary republic in that in the case of a


parliamentary republic the president is a mere figure head, whereas in the


case of a semi-presidential republic has real power. And semi-presidential


system differs from a presidential system in that, whereas in a presidential


system the cabinet is appointed by the president and can also be dismissed by


him, in a semi-presidential system the cabinet is appointed by the legislature


and cannot be unilaterally dismissed by the president. In France, the President


names the Prime Minister.


        France’s government, like the USA’s, is divided into executive,


legislative, and judicial branches. And the judicial branch, like the USA’s, is


divided into a National Assembly, corresponding to the US House ofRepresentative, and a Senate, corresponding to the US senate.


      The legislative process in France, though basically similar to its


American counterpart. In the United States, the Supreme court does not


determine the constitutional of a prospective law; it merely determines the


constitutionality of pre-existing laws, and then only under when their


constitutionality is made salient by criminal or civil litigation. But in France,


in order for a bill to become law, its constitutionality must be determined in


advance (by the Constitutional Adviser) and so must its consistency with


existing National and European laws (by the Conseil d’état). But the largest


difference between the American and the French system is that, whereas the


American system is presidential, the French system is semi-presidential, so


that the French system has a ‘dual executive’ branch.


      The advantage of a semi-presidential over a presidential system is that


it tends to prevent political gridlock, mainly by making it impossible for the


President to exercise power without the support of both the Prime Minister


and the legislature. So the legislature and the executive have trouble drifting


far enough apart from each other for there to be insuperable disagreements


between them. At the same time, this is also, at least in some contexts, a


disadvantage, since it prevents the President taking the bold initiatives that


may be necessary to deal with crises.


      My personal view is that, while there should be checks and balancesand that Presidential authority must be restricted, the presidential has more


than enough checks and balances on the President’s power. By the same


token, the semi-presidential arraignment over-limits the President and


(unless, as is the case in Russia, which is really an autocracy and only


formally a semi-presidential system) and prevents him from taking bold and


(in some contexts) necessary action.


             Russia’s Geography in Relation to its Political Development


 


      How has geography influenced Russian political development over the


centuries?


      The Russian Empire was physically extremely large. Also, much of it,


being Arctic or Sub-arctic, is very cold. Further, even though it has the


largest coastline of any country, that coastline is on the Arctic Ocean and is


therefore of limited use for either commerce or for Russia’s self-


management. Russia’s size, though in some respects a strength, left it


exposed to invaders and made it difficult to protect, this being why, over the


centuries, it sustained a series of nasty blows at the hands of numerous


Central Asian and East Asian countries.


      Also, whereas the United States is replete with high-quality arable


land, the land in Russia is relatively non-arable and the climate is


inhospitable to many forms of agriculture. Russia’s geographical isolation,


coupled with enormous size and the difficulties involved in Russia-internal


(and therefore largely land-based) travel, had the result that Russia as a whole


was in some ways more backwards than other European nations, being


slower than most other European nations (including some Eastern European


nations) to receive the benefits of political enlightenment. Also, the


difficulties involved in traveling from Russia’s urban centers (e.g. St.Petersburg and Moscow)—all of which are located in the far West of the


country and in which Russia’s aristocracy as well as its intelligence tended to


reside---created an unusually large cleavage in outlook and in standard of


living between the elite and the non-elite of Russia, which helped make


Russia vulnerable to the 1917 Revolution.


        Additionally, Russia, being large and being difficult to travel within,


was (and is) difficult to govern and to control, which is probably part of what


made Russia slow to adopt democratic rule and which, in turn, was part of


what it made relatively easy for the Bolsheviks to take over. To this day,


Russia is ruled in a semi-autocratic manner, and its lack of arable manner has


resulted in an economy that over-relies in petrol exports.


      Further, its harsh climate and vast internal distances make it difficult


(but not impossible) to develop medium sized business.


                             The Collapse of the Soviet Union?


 


      What led to the collapse of the USSR?


 


      The proximal cause of the collapse of the Soviet Union was the


lowering of gas prices that occurred in the late 80s. Russia, being a defunct,


bureaucratic communist nation had very little economy, and its revenue came


almost entirely from petroleum exports. So when petroleum prices fell in the


late 80s, Russia was completely decapitalized, and its economy literally


ground to a halt: trains containing food didn’t even leave the station, since


worker’s weren’t being paid.


      The fall in prices was deliberate, being the workmanship of strongly


anti-Soviet US President Ronald Reagan, who had already done much to


deplete Soviet coffers by engaging in it a Nuclear Arms Race. (It was unclear


whether it was Reagan’s intention in engaging in the Arms Race to


decapitalize the Soviet Union. Some believe Reagan’s motivations were of a


knee-jerk anti-Communist kind. Others believe that, indeed, Reagan was


deliberately driving the Soviet Union to poverty and subsequent collapse.)


      Because Russia had no legitimate free market on the basis of which to


generate funds, a return to Communism was not an option. At the same time,


Russia had a vast grey-market economy and—as the next few years wouldmake clear—no shortage of entrepreneurial talent. So (after a years of


economic catastrophe, courtesy of Jeffrey Sachs and other Western Economic


advisers) the Iron Hand of State-planning quickly made way for the Invisible


Hand of the free market.


                               Russia’s Current Political System


 


      What kind of political system does Russia have now? Is it effective?


Legitimate? Explain.


 


      Russia is a Constitutional (constitution-based) Federal, Semi-


presidential Republic. It is Federal in that, like the United States, it consists


of a plurality of states that have their own individual governments but that are


in their managed by a single (Federal) government. It is semi-Presidential, as


opposed to presidential, in that, although the President is the de jure head of


government, he shares power with a Prime Minister. (In actuality, the Prime


Minister, Vladimir Putin, has more power than the President, Dmitry


Medvedev.)


      In practice, Russia is a semi-autocratic state with democratic elements


—but more of an autocracy than a democracy. This configuration is


legitimate in the Russian people, though far from happy with every aspect of


the job Putin is doing, seem to prefer strong, centralized governance, as


opposed to decentralized, democratic governance.


      So relative to the awesome tasks faced by any possible government of


Russia, the semi-autocratic, semi-democratic approach seems indicated, in


that it combines the decisiveness and crisis-reading of a strong, autocraticgovernment with the responsiveness to the people’s needs of a democratically


elected government. 


                          Russia’s Dependence on Strong Leaders


 


      Is it possible for Russia to break its dependence on strong leaders? If


so, how will it get rid of Putin? And should it?


 


      While it is an article of faith in the West that ‘democracies’ are good


and ‘autocracies’ are bad, autocracies can sometimes function better. An


example is China: China’s massive economic growth and economic


liberalization over the last 30 years were consequences of sapient, but strong


centralized management. Russia’s economic growth during the last few


decades, though not quite as good as China’s, has still been considerable.


And this seems, at least in part, to have been made possible by the political


stability created by Putin’s rather autocratic ruling style.


      Also, Russia, consisting as it does of a plurality of oftentimes mutually


belligerent nationalities, might be better off, at least for the time being,


having decisive strong rulers, instead of politically driven weak ones. Be it


noted that, whereas only 1/5th of Russians express support for the democratic


leaders they have had (basically Gorbachev and Yeltsin), ½ of Russians still

                                                          [27]
have positive feelings about Brezhnev and Stalin!


      So while Putin’s future is unclear and while there is legitimatedisagreement as to his merits, it seems unlikely that Western style democracy


in Russia is particularly likely or desirable any time soon.


         Summary of Politics of Economic Growth in the States (Economics)


 


      In the 1980s, rates of economic growth among the various different


states of India were relatively uniform. But in the 1990s, this changes.


Whereas some states (e.g. Bihar, Orissa, UP, Punjab, Rajasthan) stagnated


economically or even declined, rates of economic growth increased in other


states (e.g. Gujarat, Kerala, West Bengal).


      How are these growth differentials to be explained? Let us start by


identifying two plausible but false answers to this question.


      First liberalization in the states in question attracted investment-


capital, which led to growth. Though plausible, this analysis is false, as Table


1A shows there to be no correlation between growth-rates and state-income


during the period in question.


      Second, the states that had high rates of growth during the 1990s were


those that had rates of growth during 1980s, and the high-rates of growth in


the states in question were therefore simply the result of economic inertia.


But this is simply false, as Table 1D shows.


      The actual answer is this: In each case, economic growth was a


combination both of investment-capital along with pre-existing


infrastructure; in other words, if a given Indian state exhibited pronounced


economic growth during the 1990s, it was because of a combination of ahigh-degree of infrastructure on its part and a large amount of outside


investment.


      Thus, states that were given a large amount of capital but had poor


infrastructure did not appreciably grown, and neither did states that had good


infrastructure were given little investment capital. Only those states grew that


satisfied both conditions. And not only is this a priori reasonable; it is the


only explanation not ruled out by the data (see Tables 1A-1D).


                       Should the US have entered WWI? (History)


 


      The U.S. had two prima facie reasons for entering WWI on behalf of


the Allies. First, the American economy stood to gain much if America


fought in the War, specifically if it fought on behalf of the Allies. Second, the


U.S. had reason to regard Germany as a military threat. In this context, it is


necessary to distinguish reasons that the US had to go to war from the actual


causes of its going to war, and it is necessary to distinguish each from what


the US alleged to be the reasons for its going to war. We will see that


although the US had legitimate economic and (to a lesser extent) military


reasons for going to war, these probably were not the actual causes of its


going to War. We will also see that what the US alleged to be its reasons for


going to war were probably identical neither with the legitimate reasons it


had for going to war nor with the actual causes of its doing so.


      WWI began in 1914 when a Serbian nationalist assassinated the


Archduke Ferdinand. This led to a series of territory-disputes among the


nations of Europe, which turned to into a full-blown international war. The


two sides of this war were the Allies and the Central Powers. The Allies


consisted of France, Britain, Russia, Japan and Italy. The Central Powers


consisted Germany, Austria-Hungary, Turkey and Bulgaria.


      For the first 3 years of the War, the US was not involved. PresidentWilson urged neutrality and issued a ‘neutrality-proclamation.’ (Wilson had


been re-elected on an anti-war platform with the slogan ‘he kept us out of


war.’) Most Americans supported him in this.


      Both sides wanted the US to join them. The British had cultural and


linguistic ties to the United States and also controlled transatlantic cables,


allowing them to drench the US with anti-German propaganda. At the same


time, German Americans were one of the largest minorities in the US, and


Kaiser Wilhelm II, the leader of Germany, was hoping for their support.


      Most Americans opposed Germany, partly because of its attack on


neutral Belgium and also because Kaiser Wilhelm seemed to personality


authoritarianism of the worst kind.


      But it wasn’t until America’s economy came to be affected by the war


that the US had any reason to choose sides. The US had been in a recession,


and French-British purchases of American military supplies pulled it out of


that recession, giving the US a reason to want to support the Allies. Germany


also needed American military supplies and would have purchased them, but


the Britain used her navy to cut off all commerce between Germany and the


US. American. In any case, the upshot was that the US had a vibrant trade


with Britain and France and had no trade with Germany, giving the US a


practical reason to side with the former. Thanks to British propaganda,


American citizens were unaware of Britain’s treachery in this context.      Largely because the US was providing the Allies with military


supplies, Germany began to attack American vessels. This stirred up anti-


German sentiment among American citizens,. Thanks to propaganda, much


of it British, American citizens did not know that Germany was merely trying


to prevent the delivery of military supplies that would be used against it.


Thanks also to largely British propaganda, they also didn’t know that had


severed all commercial ties between the US and Germany, thereby severing


good will between those two nations. In any case, German attacks on


American vessels, especially the sinking of the Lusitania in 1915, fueled anti-


German sentiment among the American public.


      Wilson continued to urge neutrality. But the American public began to


turn against him and he was becoming increasingly unpopular. Also, public


figures, most notably former President Theodore Roosevelt, ridiculed Wilson


for being a ‘coward’ who was unwilling to stand up to German aggression.


      There were two key events that caused Wilson to finally change his


position. First, there was the ‘Zimmerman Telegram.’ This was a telegram


sent by German Foreign Minister Arthur Zimmerman to Mexico, in which, in


exchange for Mexico’s help, he promised to help Mexico reclaim the


territories that it had lost in the previous century to the United States. Second,


Germany sunk a number of unarmed American passenger ships, killing


hundreds of American civilians.      At this point, Wilson could no longer remain neutral without losing all


political credibility. So he sought a declaration of War from Congress, his


pitch being that war with Germany was necessary to “make the world safe for


democracy.” The justification for this pitch was that Germany was an


autocracy whereas the Allies were for the most part democracies. Congress


granted Wilson’s request for a declaration of War.


      The actual cause of the US’s going to war was Wilson’s realizing that


to save political face he had to go to war with Germany. Nonetheless, there


were good reasons why it was in the US’s interest to go to War with


Germany. As previously indicated, the US benefited from the War. More


precisely, the sale of American munitions to the Allies gave strength and


vitality to the previously stagnant American economy. Granting that the


primary cause of the US’s going to war was Wilson’s need to salvage what


was left of his political reputation, American economic dependence on the


sale of munitions to the Allies may have made Americans as well as their


elected officials more receptive to the prospect of going to war with


Germany.


      Also, there was, as previously mentioned, at least some reason to


regard Germany as a threat to national security. After all, Germany had


attacked American vessels and it had also indicated that it might want to


collude with Mexico to strip the US of much of her territory. But in actualityGermany was not a real threat to the United States, and most American


decision-makers probably knew this. Germany is very far from the United


States and at the time it did not have either the force structure or the


technology necessary to mount a meaningful assault on the United States---


all of which would have been known to American decision-makers. As for


the Zimmerman Telegram, this did not constitute a prima facie threat to the


United States. But it is extremely unlikely that Mexico would have taken


Germany up on its offer (supposing that it even was a serious offer) and


equally unlikely that Germany, already seriously overextended, could have


been of any use to Mexico---all of which American decision-makers surely


knew. Nonetheless, between the Zimmerman Telegram and the numerous


German attacks on American vessels, Germany was appropriately seen as an


adversary, and the US did therefore have something to gain by this threat to


itself.


      Just before the US entered the war, the allies were about to sign a


peace treaty that was largely favorable to Germany. In effect, they were about


to surrender. Thanks to American involvement in the War, the Allies


ultimately won. In 1919, the Allies and the Central Powers signed the now


infamous Treaty of Versailles, the terms of which were exceedingly punitive


towards Germany. German delegates to the peace talks were shocked at how


severe the terms of the treaty were towards Germany and also how differentthe terms of the treaty were from the term proposed by the Allies when the


armistice that concluded the war was first being negotiated. But the Allies did


not allow Germany to negotiate any of the terms, and the Treaty was signed


by all parties present.


      The Treaty of Versailles demanded that Germany pay damages to the


Allies in the amount of $33 billion, which it simply was not possible for


Germany to do and which Germany could not even try to do without


hobbling its own economy. The Treaty also included provisions preventing


Germany from having a military of scale and therefore preventing it from


defending itself against aggression.


      The Treaty also included a provision to the effect that all of the


signatories would belong to a League of Nations that prohibited its members


from encroaching on each other’s territorial integrity or independence and


that would impose economic sanctions any member that resorted to


belligerence. Not wanting the US to submit to such an arrangement, the US


Senate, led by a group of so-called ‘irreconcilables’, refused to sign the


Treaty.


      Even though there were compelling reasons, mainly economic in


nature, for the US to enter WWI, its decision to do so appears in hindsight to


be misconceived. First of all, even though the US’s supposed reason for


going to war was to ‘make the world safe for democracy’, it had the oppositeeffect. Freedom of speech was suppressed in the United States, so as to


silence voices of opposition to the war. More importantly, the Treaty of


Versailles destroyed the German economy and embittered the German


people. This gave Germany an economic reason as well as an emotional


incentive to remilitarize itself, which in turn disposed to Germany to support


Hitler. Be it noted that in his book The Economic Consequences of Peace,


John Maynard Keynes predicted that the Treaty of Versailles would cause


Germany to remilitarize itself under the rule of a strongman.


      In conclusion, the US had legitimate reasons for entering the war on


behalf of the Allies. But this statement is subject to several heavy


qualifications. First, while the US arguably had two legitimate reasons for


going to war---these being that its doing so stood to invigorate the economy


and that its doing so would protect the US from Germany---only the first


survives scrutiny. Germany was not much of a threat to the United States: it


was too far away and lacked both the requisite force structure and


technology. Second, to the extent that Germany was a threat to the US, it was


a completely self-generated threat. Germany wanted the US not to enter the


war and was only a threat to the US because Britain went out of its way to


make it impossible for the US and Germany to have either profitable or


peaceful relations. Had the US found a way to restore its trade relations with


Germany, Germany would not have been a threat to the US; and howeverdifficult it might have been to restore trade relations with Germany, it would


have been less difficult than going to war with Germany, which cost the US


116,000 soldiers. Also, it is expensive to go to war, and however much the


US economy gained in vitality from war with Germany, it is a distinct


possibility that the gains did not offset the expense, especially when the


200,000 US wounded are taken into account. Further, even if the US did have


to use military force to protect itself from Germany--which it probably didn't-


-and even if the US economy stood to gain by entering the war--which it did


up to a point---those were not the reasons the US actually went to war. The


US actually went to war because Wilson wanted to protect his public image.


Further, in his attempt to justify entering the War, Wilson claimed not that it


would be good for the economy nor that it was necessary to neutralize an


existential threat, but that it was necessary to 'make the world safe for


democracy.' But this wasn't why the US was going to war. Just before the US


entered the war, Germany had already ceased and desisted, and it was only


because the US entered the war that it resumed its attempts to expand. Also,


because the US involvement in the war so obviously had nothing to do with


'making the world safe for democracy', a number of Americans protested US


involvement in the war, to which Wilson responded with the decidedly anti-


democratic measure of criminalizing free speech. So yes, the US had two


arguably legitimate reasons for entering the war, but only one actuallylegitimate reason for doing so; and this reason, in addition to being a


relatively weak one, was not the operative one.


 


 


      Should the US have entered WWI? In your response, consider the


various reasons the U.S. gave for entering the war and the conclusion of


the War with the Treaty of Versailles and the U.S. Senate’s refusal to


sign it.


 The U.S. had multiple legitimate reasons for entering WWI on behalf


of the Allies. First, the American economy stood to gain much if America


fought in the War, specifically if it fought on behalf of the Allies. Second, the


U.S. had reason to regard Germany as a military threat..
