decision-makers probably knew this. Germany is very far from the United


States  and  at  the  time  it  did  not  have  either  the  force  structure  or  the


technology necessary to mount a meaningful assault on the United States---


all of which would have been known to American decision-makers. As for


the Zimmerman Telegram, this did not constitute a prima facie threat to the


United States. But it is extremely unlikely that Mexico would have taken


Germany up on its offer (supposing that it even was a serious offer) and


equally unlikely that Germany, already seriously overextended, could have


been of any use to Mexico---all of which American decision-makers surely


knew.  Nonetheless,  between  the  Zimmerman  Telegram  and  the  numerous


German attacks on American vessels, Germany was appropriately seen as an


adversary, and the US did therefore have something to gain by this threat toitself.


      Just before the US entered the war, the allies were about to sign a


peace treaty that was largely favorable to Germany. In effect, they were about


to  surrender.  Thanks  to  American  involvement  in  the  War,  the  Allies


ultimately won. In 1919, the Allies and the Central Powers signed the now


infamous Treaty of Versailles, the terms of which were exceedingly punitive


towards Germany. German delegates to the peace talks were shocked at how


severe the terms of the treaty were towards Germany and also how different


the terms of the treaty were from the term proposed by the Allies when the


armistice that concluded the war was first being negotiated. But the Allies did


not allow Germany to negotiate any of the terms, and the Treaty was signed


by all parties present.


      The Treaty of Versailles demanded that Germany pay damages to the


Allies in the amount of $33 billion, which it simply was not possible for


Germany  to  do  and  which  Germany  could  not  even  try  to  do  without


hobbling its own economy. The Treaty also included provisions preventing


Germany from having a military of scale and therefore preventing it from


defending itself against aggression.


      The  Treaty  also  included  a  provision  to  the  effect  that  all  of  the


signatories would belong to a League of Nations that prohibited its members


from encroaching on each other’s territorial integrity or independence andthat  would  impose  economic  sanctions  any  member  that  resorted  to


belligerence. Not wanting the US to submit to such an arrangement, the US


Senate,  led  by  a  group  of  so-called  ‘irreconcilables’,  refused  to  sign  the


Treaty.


      Even  though  there  were  compelling  reasons,  mainly  economic  in


nature, for the US to enter WWI, its decision to do so appears in hindsight to


be  misconceived.  First  of  all,  even  though  the  US’s  supposed  reason  for


going to war was to ‘make the world safe for democracy’, it had the opposite


effect.  Freedom  of  speech  was  suppressed  in  the  United  States,  so  as  to


silence  voices  of  opposition  to  the  war.  More  importantly,  the  Treaty  of


Versailles  destroyed  the  German  economy  and  embittered  the  German


people.  This  gave  Germany  an  economic  reason  as  well  as  an  emotional


incentive to remilitarize itself, which in turn disposed to Germany to support


Hitler. Be it noted that in his book The Economic Consequences of Peace,


John Maynard Keynes predicted that the Treaty of Versailles would cause


Germany to remilitarize itself under the rule of a strongman.


      In conclusion, the US did have legitimate reasons to fight with the


Allies  in  WWI.  But,  first  of  all,  these  reasons  were  not  the  US’s  actual


reasons for doing so, though they may have played a supporting role, and,


second of all, the consequences of the US’s involvement in WWI, the main


one being WWII, were so disastrous (and, arguably, so predictably so) thatthe US, whatever its reasons for entering the War, was probably not acting


rationally in doing so.


                     Mill and von Hayek on Free-market Economics


                                (Economics/Philosophy)


 


              1. Power corrupts. How have authors read for the course aimed


    to ensure that government promotes the interests of the governed? In


    your answer, discuss three or more of the following authors: Plato,


      Locke, Madison, Rousseau, Thoreau, Hayek, and Mill


 I will focus on Madison, Mill and von Hayek. All three have the more


or less the same view (government should restrict as little as only possible,


only curtailing freedom to prevent violence), but they have it for slightly


different reasons and have different recommendations as to how to actualize


this conception of gov’t.


        According to Madison, there are two threats to liberty: the government


and other people (the majority ganging up up on the minority). Freedom from


government tyranny is accomplished by dividing the government into


mutually independent branches (e.g. executive/legislative/judiciary), allowing


someone who is being oppressed by one such branch to seek relief from the


others. As for protection from the majority, Madison’s solution is to divide


the government into Federal and local/state, which divides the people up into


a lot of little groups (different states, different counties, different cities),


which makes it hard for them to form blocks that gang up on others. Madisonsays that pure democracy provides no protection to the minority against the


majority, but that a ‘republic’ does do so, a ‘republic’ being indirect


democracy (the people vote for representatives, and the representatives


decide specific issues: the people themselves do not decide how to deal with


specific issues). In this way, gov’t protects people from itself and others and


does the people the maximum amount of good.


 According to Mill, people should be allowed as much freedom as


possible (short of being violent to each other). A major threat to this is the


tyranny of the majority. The way to protect against this is to have


‘proportionate representation’, meaning that if n% of the people vote for


party x, then n% of elected officials should belong to party x. So if 3% of the


people support the green party, 10% the black panther party, 23 % the


libertarian party, etc., then 3% of the members of congress should be green


party members, 10% black panther party members, etc. In this way, there is


majority rule and minority rights.


 According to Hayek, the sole purpose of government should be to


allow the economy to run its course, and government’s role should therefore


be limited to enforcing contracts and preventing crimes and otherwise


allowing the economy to flourish. If the government interferes with the


economy, through planning or through the outright confiscation of property,


then the economy will fail and the people will be the worse for it. Each of these authors wants the people to be protect from gov’t and


from others, but have different views as to how to accomplish this. Hayek’s


view is that the economy will give people what they need, the role of gov’t


being just to keep the economy alive. Madison and Mill want to protect


people from each other, but have different views as to how to do this, with


Mill believing the solution to be proportional representation and Madison


believing the solution to be a Republican form of gov’t.


 


 3. How does private property either promote or inhibit liberty in


    the works of three or more of the following authors: Plato, Locke,


      Rousseau, Mill, Goldman, and Marx & Engels?


              According to Rousseau and Marx/Engels, the institution of


      private property leads people to exploit one another and to turn one


      another into commodities. According to Locke, property allows people


    to develop resources and provide for one another, thereby enhancing


      freedom.


              Rousseau: when people have just enough, there are no problems;


      they are nice to each other. When some people begin to have more than


      they need (surpluses), there are problems. When people start to want


      more than they personally need, they need to exploit others. And this


      means that they need strict laws in place to keep people compliant. So      property (i.e. surplus property: enough property to exchange with


      others) leads to mutual exploitation, enslavement, injustice.


              Marx/Engels: Private property leads people to turn each other


      into property. Under capitalism, people have only as much worth as


      they have economic value. And under capitalism, people want to make


      production efficient, leading to division of labor, leading in turn to


      meaningless tasks for workers and ‘alienated’ labor.


              Locke: Labor is the basis of ownership. I come to own the land


      by tilling it. Without property, therefore, there would be no labor:


      nobody would work metal into machines or land into produce, etc. So


      property involves production and its absence involves its absence. As


    for the idea, that one is stealing from others by acquiring property, that


    is misconceived. In order to cultivate the land, somebody has to own it;


    but if he owns, he creates corns, etc. for everybody to consume that


      weren’t there previously. So property leads to economic growth, which


      leads to a greater bounty for everyone. And when people have


      excessive surpluses of property, they have an incentive to exchange it,


    so the property tends to keep itself relatively evenly distributed.


      Property leads to development of resources and all the advantages and


      freedoms resulting therefrom. Absence of property means lack of


      incentive to work. Property equals freedom to tend to one’s own needs    and needs of others.


  How is Colonialism different from Imperialism? Short Version


                                        (Politics)


 


        Colonialism involves settling another territory or country and


dominating it in that way. Imperialism involves dominating another country


either by settling it or by using force or by commandeering its economy. All


colonialism is imperialism but not vice versa.


      European colonialism from 1492-1789 was about settling new


territories and building new economies. 19th Century European imperialism


was less about building new economies or settling territories than it was


about using military force to take over pre-existing economies. This is what


happened in China in the 19th Century, when Britain used her naval power to


take over worldwide distribution of China-grown tea. To secure her


stranglehold on the international tea-trade, Britain resorted to flooding China


with opium so as to debilitate her inhabitants and make her submit to British


domination of China’s economy.


      European colonialism during 1492-1789 led to the creation of nations


that are to this occupied by descendants of the inhabitants of the colonial


powers in question. European imperialism in the 19th century involved little


European settlement of the territories being dominated, as is evidenced by the


fact that the ethnic composition of those territories has hardly changed at all.(North America is now populated largely by people of European descent.


Africa is only to a very small degree populated by such people.)


      19th Century European imperialism created a large demand for goods


(e.g. tea, silk, rubber) from the territories being dominated, which created


tremendous economic development in Europe. This spurred great


technological innovations, leading to the industrial revolution, along with the


far-reaching social changes entailed thereby.


 


             How is Colonialism different from Imperialism? Long Version


                              (History/Politics/Economics)


 


      First of all, colonialism is not the same thing as imperialism.


Colonialism is when one country settles territory occupied by some other


people. Imperialism is when one country dominates the people in another


territory or country. Although imperialism may involve some of the dominant


country’s citizens settling in the territory that is being dominated, it does not


necessarily do so. Also, there are many different forms that imperialist


domination can take: military, economic, political, religious. (Usually the


domination is either military or economic or both.)


        Colonialism and imperialism, though different, are not mutually


exclusive. All colonialism is imperialism but not all imperialism is


colonialism. If country X dominates country Y, either economically or


military or in some other way, but X’s people do not settle Y, the result is a


case of imperialism without colonialism.


      The colonial expansion in 1492-1789 was just that. In colonizing


North America and Australia the British were not so much leeching off of


pre-existing economies as they were creating new economies, the same being


true, though probably to a lesser extent, of Spanish and Portuguese


colonialism in Central and South America. European colonialism during thisperiod was less about dominating already exiting countries than it was about


creating new countries (which usually involved dominating peoples, albeit


ones who were not organized into nations, at least not in the modern sense).


      By contrast, European Imperialism in the 19th Century was less about


creating new countries than it was about economically taking advantage of


pre-existing ones. (That said, it did involve nation-building up to a point: see


below.) In the 19th Century, the British did not really colonize China, but


they did dominate it. They did this by using British Naval power to give


British merchants control over international sales of tea grown in China. In


order to weaken the Chinese populace, so as to make submit to this


arrangement, the British flooded China with opium, leading to mass opium


addiction among Chinese.


      In the 19th century, the French and British colonized much of Africa.


British colonialism, though exploitative, was less viciously so than French


colonialism and also more constructive, in the sense that to a greater extent


than French colonialism led to stable and relatively autonomous economies.


In any case, both British and French 19th century colonialism were more


about dominating pre-existing groups (not nations in the modern sense of the


word, but nations of a kind) and less about settling new territories. This is


why early European colonialism led to countries in the New World whose


residents are to this day largely or European descent, whereas 19th CenturyBritish and French colonialism hardly affected the ethnic composition of


Africa at all.


      19th Century European imperialism greatly stimulated economic


development in Europe, by creating a huge demand for goods imported from


the countries being dominated (e.g. silk, tea, rubber), which in turn spurred


technological development, thereby giving rise to the Industrial Revolution.


           Was the US a World Leader Between 1946-1991? Long Version


                                    (History/Politics)


 


      The U.S. has been the world leader since WW2. The Soviet Union was


also a leader during the years 1946-1991, mainly because it had a powerful


military and was extremely aggressive in its attempts to bring under countries


under its political control. But the Soviet Union had an obsolete economy and


it poured what few resources it had into its military, the result being that it


collapsed  in  1990  and  now  belongs  to  what  Trotsky  referred  to  as  “the


rubbish heap of history.” By contrast, the U.S. still has the most powerful


economy in the world and, although other nations (mainly Russia, India, and


China) are emerging as fellow world leaders, the U.S.’s absolute position


remained relatively constant. This paper will substantiate the points just made


and  to  this  end  will  discuss  the  Marshall  Plan,  the  Berlin  Blockade,  the


Truman Doctrine, and the conflict between communism and capitalism to


show that U.S. was the dominant leader over the Soviets. Be it noted that the


conflict between communism and capitalism was both economic and military


in nature: it was a conflict between opposing views as to the rightful role of


government and the legitimacy of private property and free enterprise. But


this conflict, though primarily ideological, became militarized, leading to a


45 year ‘cold war’ between the U.S. and the Soviet Union and also involvingseveral wars by proxy, including the Korean War and the Vietnam War.


      After World War II, and to some extent because of it, two countries


emerged as the world’s main powers: the United States and the Soviet Union.


Not only were these two nations the most powerful ones in existence; they


were  also  irreconcilable  adversaries.  This  was  largely  because  the  United


States was (and still is) a capitalist country whereas the Soviet Union was


communist. A capitalist country is one in which private citizens are allowed


to own property and to transact with each other. A communist country is one


in  which  private  citizens  do  not  own  private  property,  at  least  not  on  a


significant  scale,  and  are  not  allowed  to  transact  with  each  other.  In  a


communist country, the government owns everything, and what people have


is  determined  by  government  policy,  not  by  market-forces.  In  a  capitalist


country, what people is determined by market forces. Therefore communism


and capitalism cannot coexist.


      As  soon  as  World  War  II  ended,  the  Soviet  Union  expanded


aggressively. It did not directly take over other countries. Instead, it helped


set up communist regimes in those countries, which would be loyal to the


Soviet  Union  and  through  which  the  Soviet  Union  could  control  those


countries. The Soviet Union immediately succeeded in setting up communist


regimes,  all  of  them  loyal  to  the  Soviet  Union,  in  all  of  Eastern  Europe,


including a large part of Germany, and after a few years, it helped establishcommunist rule in China.


      The Soviets had a large military and a well-educated and also well-


indoctrinated  population,  but  their  economy  was  almost  completely  non-


functional. By contrast, the United States not only had a powerful military


but a booming economy and a correspondingly high standard of living. In


fact, the United States had the world’s largest economy (and still does), while


the Soviet Economy was small relative to its population and also in absolute


terms. (The economies of Japan, Germany, and Great Britain were all larger


than the Soviet Economy.)


      Also, even though the Soviet Union had a powerful military, it was


only able to pay for its military by depleting the rest of its economy. This is


why the Soviet Union simply collapsed in 1990, along with most of the other


communist regimes in the world. This is also why the Soviet Union was so


aggressively expansionist: it had no economy and therefore had to predate on


other economies, which it did up to a point but which the USA resisted in


allied countries and which it therefore was not able to do indefinitely.


      The Soviets’ aggressiveness led to the so-called Truman Doctrine, this


being  the  US’s  commitment  to  prevent  the  Soviet  Union  from  absorbing


additional  countries  into  the  Soviet  Bloc.  The  Truman  Doctrine  officially


came into existence in 1947 when Harry Truman announced to Congress in


1947 that he would block the attempt the Soviets were then making to installCommunist puppet governments in Turkey and Greece. The US’s subsequent


attempts to check Soviet (and, more generally, communist) expansion were


not always successful (though they were ultimately completely successful),


but the very fact that the US made those efforts and thus made it so hard for


the Soviets to expand made the U.S. a protector and therefore a leader of


nations.


      The conflict between the US and USSR was in large measure a ‘cold


war’, meaning that it did not involve overt, direct armed conflicts between


those two powers. But the so-called ‘Cold’ War involved a number of ‘hot’


(actual) wars-by-proxy between the US and USSR. The first of these was the


Korean War, which began when the Soviet-backed North Korean Communist


army (henceforth PAK, short for ‘People’s Army of Korea’) crossed the 38th


Parallel in an effort to assume control of all of Korea. The US intervened and


deployed 550,000 troops in an effort to stop PAK. The US was aided in this


effort by non-communist Korean forces. The US prevented PAK from taking


over the southern half of Korea, but PAK retained control of the Northern


part.


      Since 1953, Korea has been divided into a non-communist southern


part  (South  Korea)  and  a  communist  northern  part  (North  Korea).  North


Korea is currently run by Kim Jong Un, the grandson of Kim-il Sung, the


leader of PAK, and the son of Kim Jong Il. The differences between theKoreas is illustrative of the nature of the Cold War. South Korea is extremely


prosperous and modern. North Korea is desperately poor and its residents for


the most part have little to eat and extremely few freedoms. North Korea is


by every measure a failed state. It survives largely thanks to handouts from


(nominally Communist) China, but its economy is, for the same reasons as


the Soviet economy, a complete failure.


      South Korea was one of the first beneficiaries of the World Bank,


which, though not technically created by any one nation, was largely the


handiwork of the US and Britain. The purpose of the World Bank is to help


struggling economies, mainly by giving them loans but also by providing


them with expertise. After the Korean War, South Korea needed money to


rebuild its shattered infrastructure, and the World Bank loaned it the required


amounts, helping South Korea’s economy become the powerhouse that it is


today. Meanwhile, North Korea depended on Soviet and Chinese loans, still


depending on the latter, and its economy is non-functional.


      Whereas Soviet power had only one side to it - a dark and aggressive


side - US power had two sides to it: an anti-Soviet and sometimes belligerent


side and a non-belligerent, constructive side. The constructive side involved


the US’s being an economic leader, which it did partly by simply having a


booming  economy  and  which  it  did  partly  by  providing  direct  economic


assistance to other countries, which it still does and which it first began doingwith the advent of the Marshall Plan.


      The Marshall Plan was an initiative on the US’s part to rebuild Europe


in the aftermath of WW2. The purpose of the Marshall was to repair the


shattered  economies  of  Europe  by  creating  and  modernizing  industry,


lowering trade-barriers between nations, encouraging commerce between and


within the nations of Europe, and preventing the spread of communism. To


this  end,  the  US  invested  billions  of  its  own  dollars  in  the  economies  of


Europe. The US offered to extend the benefits of the Marshall Plan to the


Soviet Union, but the latter declined and also blocked the US’s attempts to


extend such benefits to Poland and Hungary.


      Europe’s economy, especially the economies of the countries covered


by  the  Marshall  Plan,  boomed  in  the  decades  following  WW2,  and  it  is


overwhelmingly  likely  that  Marshall  Plan  had  a  hand  in  this.  Also,  the


economies that were not covered the by Marshall Plan, mainly the countries


in the Soviet Bloc, did not improve. So granting that the Soviet Union was a


world power of a kind after WW2, it did not did not use its power in a way


that benefited either its own citizens or those of other countries. By contrast,


the United States did use its power benevolently, at least in many contexts


(though obviously not all), and it did not have to deplete its own economy to


either have or exercise that power.


      A stark example the contrast between American power and Soviet wasthe Berlin Blockade. After WW2, control over the city of Berlin was divided


between four powers: France, Britain, US, and Soviet Union. In 1948, in an


effort  to  gain  complete  control  of  Berlin,  the  Soviet  Union  blocked  off


railway,  canal  and  road  access  to  the  parts  of  the  city  under  non-Soviet


control. The US responded by airdropping much needed supplies into those


areas. For fear of starting an all-out war with the US, the Soviets did not try


to  prevent  these  air  supplies  from  coming  in  and  eventually  backed  off,


opening the up the land-ways that it had originally blocked off. The Berlin


Blockade, along with the US’s response to it, made the Soviets look like


malicious predators and made the US look like a hero.


      In 1948, the Soviets overthrew a democratically elected government in


Czechoslovakia and installed a Communist puppet regimes. This was but one


of many instances of Soviet aggression in the immediate aftermath of WW2,


the crisis in Berlin being another, and American and other Western leaders


were  worried,  leading  to  the  creation  in  1949  of  NATO  (North  Atlantic


Treaty Organization), this being a group of Western Nations that agreed to


act as one if the Soviets acted aggressively towards given any one of them.


The  initial  members  of  NATO  were Belgium,  Britain,  Canada,  Denmark,


France, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal and


the United States. Although NATO was created largely in order to contain


Soviet aggression, it had a larger purpose, this being to help different nationshelp one another through crises. And so it is that NATO still exists, even


though the Soviet Union fell long ago, and as of 1999 includes Hungary,


Poland and Czechoslovakia, all former members of the Soviet Bloc.


      Was the US a world leader between 1946-1991? Yes. It led the world


militarily, in that it had the world’s most powerful military and also used it to


defend  against  Soviet  and  Soviet-backed  expansionism.  It  led  the  world


economically, in that it had the world’s largest and most vigorous economy.


And  because  it  it  tried  (sometimes  successfully)  to  use  its  economic  and


military might for good, the US was in some ways a ‘moral’ world leader


during this time-period. The Soviets were world leaders only in the sense that


they had a powerful military. Moreover, when the Soviets did harm, they did


so deliberately: under Stalin they massacred 20,000,000 of their own citizens


and  imprisoned  millions  more  in  Gulags  (political  prisons);  they  helped


install Mao-tse Tung in China, who himself killed (or led to the starvation of)


millions of his own. Mao, in his turn, helped install Pol Pot in Cambodia


who,  during  1975-1979,  killed  2  million  Cambodians,  out  of  a  total


population of 7,000,000. When the US did harm, which it often did (and


probably still does), it was not out of a wish to undermine other countries but


out of a failure to know how to help them properly. So yes--the US was not


only a world leader during this period but the world leader, with the Soviets


being a rather distant second. A Case for Environmental Regulation and against Carbon Taxes


(Economics/Politics)


 


      I would not support replacing existing environmental regulations with


a carbon tax. The reason is that life-and-death issues are not for the free


market to decide. It is not for the free market to decide whether pollution-


generating activity should be regulated, since the economic freedoms lost


because  of  anti-pollution  regulations  are  insignificant  compared  to  the


environmental problems thereby averted. A company's right not to have to


recycle motor oil is not as important as a community's right to have drinkable

      [28]
water.


      Those  who  advocate  replacing  environmental  regulations  with  a


carbon tax argue that giving people economic incentives not to pollute will

                                                                                        [29]
do as much to prevent pollution as fining or jailing people who pollute.


This is misconceived. If people know they’ll be fined or go to jail if they


pollute, they won’t pollute. If people know they stand to increase revenue by


polluting  less,  they  may  pollute  less---or  they  may  not.  The  cost-benefit

                                          [30]
calculus here is extremely complex. Perhaps what a given company stands


to  gain  by  polluting  may  exceed  what  it  has  to  pay  in  carbon  taxes.  Or


perhaps  new  tax  loopholes  might  arise  that  allow  companies  to  write  off


carbon taxes. If executives know that they will be jailed for polluting, theywill not pollute. But if pollution simply generates more operating expenses


and may even lead to backdoor revenue of some kind, they may pollute.


      Many will claim that the debate between different political ideologies-


--between advocates of ‘small government’ (represented by the pro-carbon


taxers) and those who favor ‘big government’ (represented by the anti-carbon

      [31]
taxers). This is a pernicious and false way of representing the matter. Even


those  who  advocate  minimal  government  grant  that  government  should


intervene when the very survival of the governed is at stake, as it is where


matters relating to the integrity of the environment are concerned, and the big


government/small government debate therefore only concerns matters that are


genuinely  optional.  The  legal  status  of  prostitution  and  drug  use  affect  a


society’s moral character but not its very existence, this being why it is ‘big


government’ to prohibit them and ‘small government’ to permit them. But


massive  amounts  of  pollution do threaten  a  society’s  very  existence.


Consequently, a government that permits life-threatening amounts of is not


‘small’ but simply inadequate, and one that prohibits it is not ‘big’ but simply


adequate.  In  fact,  a  government  that protects companies  that  despoil  the


environment  is  the  very  definition  of  a  big  government,  since  it  deprives


many  people  of  health  in  order  to  spare  a  few  people  some  regulatory


inconvenience.


      Relatedly, many will claim that this is a debate different economictheories---between ‘free-marketeers’ (represented by the carbon-taxers) and

                                                              [32]
‘Keynesians’ (represented by the anti-carbon-taxers). Again, this is a very


misleading  characterization  of  the  matter.  Even  the  most  hardcore  free-


marketeer favors government intervention when the market’s very existence


is threatened; and the debate between free-marketeers and their opponents


therefore only concerns matters that are internal to a functioning market, such


as  welfare  and  taxation.  High  taxes  and  generous  unemployment  benefits


affect an economy’s degree of vigor but not its very existence, this being why


free-marketeers want minimal taxes and welfare and their opponents want


non-minimal taxes and welfare. But massive amounts of pollution undermine


the  existence  of  a  free  market  since  they  undermine  the  health  economic


actors, and the market therefore isn’t made less free by anti-pollution laws or


made freer by their absence.

                 Wollstonecraft vs. Marx on Religion (Intellectual History)


 


 Mary Wollstonecraft’s view on religion are very different from Karl


Marx’s. Marx was unambiguously opposed to religion, believing it and all of


the notions associated with, including the idea that there exists a God, to be


nothing but propaganda, by means of which the poor are kept docile. Mary


Wollstonecraft has a much more qualified view on the matter. Her position is


that organized religion can reinforce society’s prejudices. But unlike Marx,


she does not believe that the concepts associated with religion are


categorically false or harmful. In particular, she believes the concept of God


to be one that, if properly understood, can help eliminate prejudice and


improve the lot of the oppressed. I will now systematically describe and then


compare the views of Wollstonecraft and Marx on religion.


 Marx famously describes religion as “the opium of the people”, his


position being that religion is a mere soporific whose purpose is to key the


masses sedated. More precisely, he believes that religion is a smokescreen for


the exploitation of the poor by the rich: “Law, morality, religion”, writes


Marx, “are to him so many bourgeois prejudices, behind which lurk in


ambush just as many bourgeois interests”, (Marx and Engles 12) his point


that religion (along with law and morality) are ways of both looting and


subduing the poor. We are familiar with the proverbial televangelist (e.g.Jimmy Swaggart, Jim Bakker) who feigns piety and religious zeal to


squeezes his congregation for money and to keep them in a state of perpetual


infancy and psychological dependence. We are familiar with cult leader (e.g.


Jim Jones, Charles Manson) who manipulates his followers into giving him


their money, bodies and souls. Marx would not see such people as


aberrations, but rather as embodying the very essence of religion.


 Wollstonecraft has a different conception of religion. Wollstonecraft


is a deist, meaning that she believes the universe to have been created by al


God who, after creating the universe, ceased to have any dealings with it.


Wollstonecraft believes this God to be rational and benevolent and believes


the structure of the universe, in particular human nature, to embody these


virtue: “The wise Being who created us and placed us here. . . .allowed it to


be the case—and thus willed it to be the case—that our passions should help


our reason to develop, because he could see that present evil would produce


future good.” (Wollstonecraft 3) At the same time, as this same quote


indicates, Wollstonecraft believes that God’s rationality and goodness are


embodied not so much in what we are in what we could be: it is up to us to


develop the rationality and goodness that, in Wollstonecraft’s view, God


implanted in us.


 Though a believer in God and religious in that sense, Wollstonecraft


thought ill of organized religion, describing it as “worse than a farce”, (169)her position being that the main consequence of organized religion to be a


kind of psychological “Slavery to...ministers, whose deadly grasp stops the


progress of the human mind, is not yet abolished and won’t be for a long


time.”(38) Wollstonecraft seems to hold that ‘religion’ is legitimate when it is


about the pursuit of enlightenment but not when it is about membership in an


organization.


 Wollstonecraft seems to hold that religion (of the legitimate, non-


institutional variety) will help end sexism, simply because it makes people


more rational and less prejudiced: “Why would God lead us from love of


ourselves to the sublime emotions aroused by the discovery of his wisdom


and goodness, if these feelings weren’t launched so as to improve our nature


(of which they are a part)2 and enable us to enjoy a more godlike portion of


happiness? Firmly convinced that no evil exists in the world that God didn’t


intend to occur, I build my belief on the perfection of God.” (4) As this quote


indicates, Wollstonecraft regards God as a paradigm by emulating whom we


improve ourselves.


 When it comes to organized religion, Marx and Wollstonecraft are in


partial agreement. Both regard organized religions as corrupt and exploitative


and as doing the opposite of what they claim to be doing. But even here Marx


and Wollstonecraft are not in perfect agreement. Wollstonecraft doesn’t


regard organized religion as inherently bad. She seems to hold that ifreligions were better run, they would do what they claimed to do. By


contrast, Marx regards organized religion as inherently bad, his position


being that a ‘well-run’ religion simply does a better job than a poorly run


religion of spreading propaganda.


      When it comes to religion in general, Marx and Wollstonecraft don’t


agree at all. Wollstonecraft holds that religion is inherently good, while


granting that it can be corrupted. Marx holds that a religion cannot possibly


be good, since a religion is simply a way of pacifying the masses with fairy


tales about Gods and other such chimera. For Marx, religion is simply to be


eliminated, his view being that “communism”, which he believes to be the


only path to a just social order, “abolishes eternal truths, it abolishes all


religion, and all morality, instead of constituting them on a new basis.” For


Wollstonecraft, religion is not to be eliminated disengaged from its corrupt


institutional trappings. Thus purified, Wollstonecraft holds, it will exist as a


private relationship between the individual and the Almighty and as such will


liberate the former the bondage of prejudice.


 


 


 


             Carbon Taxes vs. Standing Regulations (Economics/Politics)


 


      I would vote in favor of the carbon tax, and I would do so because it


would help the environment. It would also help the economy; and for reasons


that I will now explain, it would help the environment because it would help


the economy, not despite its doing so. According to the conventional wisdom


of both Democrats and Republicans, the environment can only protect at the


expense of economic growth. Because Republicans accept this and also want


the  economy  to  grow,  they  deny  the  existence  of  climate  change  and,  in

                                                                            [33]
general,  downplay  the  negative  consequences  of  pollution.  Because


Democrats accept this and do not downplay the adverse effects of pollution,


they  downplay  the  adverse  economic  effects  of  environmental  regulation.


Both positions are misconceived. Industrial waste obviously does damage the


environment. (One can debate whether global warming is a reality, but not


whether  dumping  chemicals  into  soil  and  water  hurts  and  human  beings


alike.)  Heavy-duty  regulations  obviously  do  dampen  the  economy’s


performance, since they make it difficult for new companies to break into


markets, force existing ones to increases prices to cover regulatory costs, and


also lead to increased taxes.


      Carbon taxes are hewed to carbon use: the more people use carbon, the


more they are taxed. This rewards energy-efficient conduct. When energybills are too high, people learn how to conserve. They learn not to leave the


lights on when they’re not home and not to blast heat or air-conditioning


unnecessarily. John Cushman argues that a carbon tax would not increase


energy-efficiency  in  those  who  cannot  make  structural  changes  to  their

      [34]
homes. But this argument fails for several reasons. First, they can develop


less wasteful personal habits (e.g. they can choose not to leave the AC on


when they leave for work). Second, the cost of living in an energy-inefficient


apartment  will  be  extremely  high,  especially  with  carbon  taxes,  forcing


tenants to move and forcing landlords to make the needed improvements.


Third, many people can make such changes.  Of course, high energy-bills


currently  incentivize  energy-efficient  behavior,  but  carbon-taxes  would


increase those incentives dramatically.


      Most pollution and resource-depletion result from practices that are


legal  but  wasteful,  e.g.  using  paper  instead  of  e-readers,  environmental

                                                                    [35]
regulations do nothing to discourage such wastefulness. Unlike standing


regulations,  carbon-taxes  would  penalize  legal  but  wasteful  behavior  and

                                          [36]
reward legal and efficient behavior. As a result, carbon-taxes encourage


people  and  companies  to  look  for  ways  to  lessen  their  environmental


footprint and therefore to produce enviro-friendly innovations. Regulations


have this effect up to a point, but for the most part their effect is to wall out

                                                                      [37]
start-up companies that cannot afford to comply with them. As a result, theentrenched companies that can afford to comply with them are ambivalent


about producing technology that would make it easier and less expensive to


comply  with  regulations,  since  such  innovations  would  threaten  their


position.


      Some  regulations  are  helpful  and  necessary.  Regulations  prevent


companies from making air unbreathable and water undrinkable. But carbon-


taxes  will  not  displace  environmental  regulations,  since  carbon-taxes  and


regulations have different bailiwicks: whereas the purpose of regulations is to


eliminate certain practices (e.g. dumping toxic waste in rivers), the purpose of


carbon-taxes is not to criminalize existing practices but to give people an


incentive to make them more efficient and environmentally sustainable.


 


      Sowell, Thomas. 2005. Basic Economics. New York: Basic Books.


 


      Light Pollution Hurts Our Economy and Our Resources. 8 August


2018. Accessed at http://cescos.fau.edu/observatory/lightpol-econ.html


 


      A conservative case for climate action. 8 February 2017. Accessed at:

  climate-action.html?_r=0
