                         Culture and Creativity (Sociology)


 


Assignment: Find a relation between culture, innovation, development, and


creativity.


 


      Culture can be thought of as naturally occurring creativity. What we


do mean when we refer to ‘culture'? What immediately comes to mind is


great music, literature, art, architecture and the like. Of course, the word


‘culture' sometimes refers to the values and understandings that govern the


interactions of a given group of people. This is what is meant when people


say that in Japanese ‘culture', it is considered polite to decline a gift. But


these two meanings of the word ‘culture' are related: Japanese art and music


tend to embody the same values that govern relations among Japanese


people, the same being true of German Culture and Bantu Culture. In general,


the ‘culture’ of a given people is the creative genius that gives rise to the


various values, understandings, and artistic creations that guide them in their


dealings with one another. The very essence of culture, consequently, is


creativity, with the qualification that it occurs organically—not as a result of


a conscious intention on somebody’s part to solve some problem, but as a


natural by-product of interactions between people.


      Because the kind of creativity involved in culture ends up beingembodied in long-standing understandings and traditions, it tends to limit


what it is considered permissible for individuals to do on their own and it


therefore tends to limit innovation. Whereas culture arises organically and


unconsciously, innovation is the result of a conscious resolution on an


individual’s part to use his creative powers to solve some problem. The


phonograph was an innovation. Somebody invented it with the conscious


intention of solving a problem. The same is true of the polio vaccine. By


contrast, beautiful medieval cathedrals were not innovations. They were


original, and they were the products of creative and technical genius. But


they did not come into existence because of some individual’s intention to


solve some problem. Even though many conscious acts of problem-solving


were involved in creating them, the intention to create them was not itself


goal-oriented, and instead arose organically out of largely unconscious,


collective understandings and mores.


        Development is growth. Individuals develop, and so do pluralities of


people. A highly developed individual is one who has cultivated his native


talents, and a highly developed economy or nation is one that has put its


various resources, including the abilities of the individuals composing it, to


good use. Development can be thought of as the creation of a mature being


out of an immature one: an adult is being created, as it were, out of a child; an


advanced nation is being created out of one that is backward. Althoughdevelopment can be the consequence of conscious intention, as when a


person consciously works to develop his abilities as a pianist, it tends to


happen organically: no conscious intention is involved in a caterpillar's


developing into a butterfly. In any case, development, unlike other forms of


creativity, is reflexive in nature. When an infant develops into an adult, the


raw material, as it were, is the infant, and the finished product is the adult.


        Culture, innovation, and development are always manifestations of


creativity. Culture is creativity that is collective and largely unconscious in


nature. Development is creativity that is reflexive in nature and tends not to


have a conscious goal. Innovation is creativity that does have a conscious


goal. So creativity is what is common to culture, innovation, and


development, in that they are all different expressions of it.


                               The American Dream (Politics)


 


      The American Dream can be summed up in one word: opportunity.


The essence of Americanism is opportunity. Everybody has the opportunity


to improve their lives. People are not locked into pre-existing social


arrangements. Whatever circumstances they are born into, they are able to


change and improve their lives. That is what the American Dream is.


      And it is not just a dream: it is to a considerable extent a reality. It


isn’t simply that, in the United States, people are supposed to be able to


change their lives for the better. They actually do so; it is practically a regular


occurrence. In fact, although it may be not the norm, it is certainly a norm.


 In this country, people whose parents did not go to college themselves


frequently go to college and make good lives for themselves, with the result


that, although they themselves started out at one social tier, their own


children are born into a higher social tier, with correspondingly more


opportunities and fewer obstacles to capitalizing on those opportunities. And


there are similar opportunities for change and growth for those who are born


into higher social tiers: they are not required, as they are in other cultures, to


repeat what their parents did. They do not have to assume a position in the


proverbial ‘family business.’ They can strike out on their own. I personally


have known children of investment bankers who became writers andprofessors, and I have known children of professors and writer who became


investment bankers—or who went onto start some entirely new business or


even new kind of business.


      And this last fact brings us to an important fact about the American


Dream. The American Dream isn’t simply about being able to move up


within some pre-existing social structure. It is also about being able to change


that structure. Bill Gates came from a well-to-do family. He could have just


completed his degree at Harvard and more or less just coasted, working as a


computer scientist or financier. But he didn’t just coast; he invented a new


product—nay, a new kind of product: the personal computer. And he didn’t


just invent that product: he made it available to literally billions of people for


a modest price.


      I don’t know what Bill Gates’ personal motivations were in doing this,


but the effect of his actions was to make life easier and better. Right now, in


writing this very essay, I am using the operating system that he invented and


also made available for a modest price. And it is very likely that in reading


this essay, you too are using these same inventions.


      Bill Gates is not alone in this. Think about todays’ IT and tech-giants:


Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, Sergei Brin, Larry Page, Jeff Bezos. All of


these people are Americans, either by birth or by naturalization, and all of


them chose to ‘set up shop’, as it were, in the United States.      Why did they make this choice? Because this country is hospitable to


big ideas and to big innovations. It is hospitable in a purely logistical, as in,


the laws of this country do not discourage it even encourage it, there being,


for example, tax-breaks for start-ups along with government-sponsored


business-education programs. And there is also a special ‘place’, as it were,


in the American psyche for somebody who strikes out on his own and tries to


‘make it big.’ People are people, no matter where you go; and people tend to


respond two novelty with suspicion and they tend to respond to successful


upstarts with envy and fear. And granting that Americans are by no means an


exception to this, there is a value that all Americans seem to have internalized


to the effect that ‘all bets are off’---that there is to be a suspension of all of


the usual pettiness and resentment that is usually directed towards people


who are trying to make something of themselves; that such people are to be


‘given a break’ and allowed to follow their dreams. So if somebody suddenly


quits his job as phone-salesperson in order to start a company, he is not


ridiculed or hassled for doing so. It is understood that, business being what it


is, may not succeed, at least not initially. But over and above the difficulties


that are inherent in starting a business, he is not thwarted for doing so.


      A related point is that in this country, to a much greater degree than in


other countries, people are given a second chance—and a third, and a fourth.


In fact, the whole concept of the second chance is a distinctively Americanconcept. This country is about giving people second chances, in business and


in life in general. Think about the late Anthony Bourdain. At the age of 45,


Bourdain was, in his own words, “basically a fry cook.” And then he boldly


quit his fry cook job and started a career as a combination of explorers, chef,


and cyber-preneur. Before ‘breaking out’, Bourdain had had a decidedly


checkered and uneven career, having numerous battles with substance abuse


and other personal demons. But despite it all, he had his intellect, his


creativity, and his boldness; and he not only succeeded in making money, but


succeeded in re-inventing a tired industry.


      This country’s history is replete with Anthony Bourdain’s---with


people who were on the precipice of financial and emotional disaster but


who, at the last minute, pulled themselves together. Let us not forget that


Harlan (‘Colonel’) Sanders was 65 when he opened his first Kentucky Fried


Chicken Restaurant.


      I would not go so far as to say that at the moment I embody the


American Dream. But I aspire to embody it. I want to become a dentist. I


have always wanted to become a dentist. People ask me ‘Why do you want to


become a dentist, Jonathan?’ And I have no ready response. I honestly


believe that, just as certain people are cut out for finance and others for the


military, so some people really want to help others by fixing their teeth. I


believe that an interest dentistry is a specific evolutionary deviation---thatsuch an interest pre-dates tens of thousands of years the existence of dentistry


in anything like its modern form


      In any case, given my passion for dentistry, it is clear how I need the


American Dream to come through for me: I need the opportunity to learn the


craft of dentistry; I need to learn how to help people as a dentist; and I


therefore need to attend the possible schools and programs. And the


American Dream is coming through for me in that respect. Because I have


worked so hard at my classes and been rewarded with correspondingly high


grades, it is overwhelmingly likely that I will have the privilege of being


accepted to one of the prestigious institutions to which, in pursuit of my own


private American Dream of becoming a dentist, I am seeking admittance


                     Knowledge-capital (Politics/Economics/Philosophy)


 


      In today’s world, property is important, but knowledge is more


important than property. Suppose that Person A has unlimited


knowledge/intelligence but no property, and suppose that Person B has


property but little to no intelligence or knowledge. Person A can probably


acquire property; in fact, there is little limit to how much property he can


acquire. And once Person A has property, there is little or no limit how much


he can make it grow. By contrast, the best Person B can do is hold his


position: he can hold onto the property that he has but (setting aside blind


luck) cannot make it grow. In a market economy, anyone who can figure out


a way to satisfy market demands is able to add to his holdings, and it is


knowledge, and knowledge alone, that enables one to be able to satisfy


market-demands.


      In a feudal economy or a command economy, property seldom passes


from one person to another, tending to remain fixed. Such economies are not


dynamic, and participants in such economies, having as they do little way to


improve their lot, focus more on property-retention than on property-


acquisition. In such an economy, it doesn’t pay to invest in one’s own


education, since there is no guarantee that one will be in a position to market


one’s education. But in a market-economy, there is such a guarantee, since insuch an economy one can always find a way to trade knowledge or skill for


property.


      This is why since the beginning of the Enlightenment, one’s stature in


society has come to depend increasingly on one’s own abilities, including


intellectual abilities, and decreasingly on the social position that one


happened to be born into. A market economy is an Enlightenment (or,


technically, post-Enlightenment economy), and in such an economy one’s


ability to acquire property, and even sometimes just to retain, depends largely


one’s abilities, especially one’s intellectual abilities.


      Kant published his paper “What is Enlightenment?” in 1784. The


Enlightenment was already three centuries old at that point. But it wasn’t


until around this time that Enlightenment views caught up with economic


practice. During the most of the period between around 1550 to 1750, the


average citizen’s ability to transact was severely restricted; in order to play a


given trade, or even engage on some specific venture within a trade that he


was already practicing, he often needed special dispensations from


government officials or from guilds. This was beginning to change in the


mid-1700’s. As a result, the average citizen was increasingly able, and


increasingly obligated, to stake his own claim in the market-place.


      Given that markets were beginning to be free when Kant wrote his


essay, individuals had to start being self-reliant or, to use Kant’s term,‘autonomous.’ In a truly free market, nothing is permanent. Institutions come


and go, depending on what consumers want. Under such circumstances, the


individual cannot rely on fixed institutions or indeed on anything other than


his own ability. This means that people have to decide for themselves how


their lives will be. And this is one of the main points of Kant’s essay, as its


opening words make clear:


 


        “Enlightenment is man's emergence from his self-imposed nonage.


Nonage is the inability to use one's own understanding without another's


guidance. This nonage is self-imposed if its cause lies not in lack of


understanding but in indecision and lack of courage to use one's own mind


without another's guidance. Dare to know! (Sapere aude.) ‘Have the courage


to use your own understanding,’ is therefore the motto of the enlightenment.”


 


      In a non-market economy, the exhortation to ‘have the courage to use


your own understanding’ is without operational meaning. It is well and good


to urge an indentured servant to ‘think for himself’, but even if he does


manage to think for himself, it won’t do him any good in a practical sense.


But in a market-economy that exhortation is on point, since one ultimately


has nothing to rely on in such an economy other than one’s own judgment.


      That in turn is why general education has replaced apprenticeships asthe way of inducting people into the workforce. When the economy was less


free, professions were not constantly being improved or replaced, and one


could guarantee a living for oneself by deciding on a particular trade. Now


that the economy is free and therefore volatile, this doesn’t necessarily work,


and workers, even skilled workers, are constantly having to acquire new


skills in order to earn a living. For this reason, they need the foundation of a


broad education, as opposed to an apprenticeship. Hence Daniel Allen’s


statement in his article “What is Education For?”:


 


      “The dominant policy paradigm attends almost exclusively to


education’s vocational purpose: the goal is to ensure that young people, and


society generally, can compete in a global economy. This view is tightly


connected to a technocratic economic policy that focuses on the


dissemination of skills as a way to reduce inequality in a technology-


dependent economy.”


 


      Implicit in this statement is the idea that one’s financial capital


depends on one’s intellectual capital. A corollary of the latter is that


intellectual capital (including access to knowledge) is at least as important as,


and in some ways more important, possession of property.


      There is another relevant fact, namely, that in market economies, thereis an extremely high degree of specialization and there is a correspondingly


high degree of division of labor. The reason for this is that in market-


economies efficiency is reward and, as Adam Smith points out, a high-degree


of division of labor is efficient:


 


      “The greatest improvement in the productive powers of labour, and the


greater part of the skill, dexterity, and judgment with which it is any where


directed, or applied, seem to have been the effects of the division of


labour…”


 


      Being able to survive in a market-economy thus tends to involve being


able to do highly specialized work. And because market economies are


dynamic, it also tends to involve being able do a series of different


specialized kinds of work. So from the standpoint of competing in a market-


economy, what matters is not having this or that specific body of knowledge,


but is rather having the ability to acquire knowledge-on-demand. In other


words, what matters is access to knowledge, such access being the modern


version of capital.


 


                   Four Essays on Modern History (History/Politics)


 


          Answers to Graduate School Exam Questions about Colonialism,


                            Imperialism, and Nationalism


      1) To what extent was nationalism responsible for the catastrophic


wars of the twentieth century? How did Europeans attempt to curtail the


dangers of nationalism in the wake of World War II? In what ways did


European nationalism persist during the Cold War?


 


      WWI was a consequence of nationalism, in that it involved a number


of nation-states trying to break free of the Austro-Hungarian empire and was


sustained by a conflict between the UK/USA and Germany, which, though it


was largely economic in nature, had a nationalistic character and was


certainly represented in British and American propaganda as being


nationalistic in character.


      Germany lost WWI and was bankrupted by the subsequent peace


accord (the Treaty of Versailles) Hitler convinced the German people that


Germany had made too many concessions to foreign powers and advocated a


policy of nationalism, meaning economic and political self-containment,


which included anti-Semitism, since he saw the Jewish people as being


international in character . Hitler’s nationalism involved his violating thesovereignty of other nations, notably Poland, which served as a precipitating


cause of WW2. Other countries (UK, USA, USSR: the allies) sought to


contain Germany. Germany joined forces with Japan, which, like Germany,


had an intensely nationalistic ethos. The allies won, at which point the US


and USSR entered into a 50 year cold war, which was more about capitalism


vs. communism that it was about this nation vs. that nation.


      The conflicts following WW2, e.g. Korea and Vietnam, were largely


about communism vs. capitalism but had nationalistic components, especially


in the case of Vietnam, which was in part about Vietnamese self-


determination.


      After the USSR fell, the ‘Soviet Empire’ immediately disbanded, with


each of its member-states quickly reverting to its pre-Soviet condition, i.e.


with Poland, Georgia, Hungary etc. all quickly reverting to being Sovereign


states.


        Although nationalism was a factor in the wars of the 20th century, it


was not the only factor. For example, Japan’s involvement in WW2 was


largely about its oil supply being cut off, and the Gulf War, though


supposedly about protecting the Kurdish people, was at least arguably about


providing the US with a continued supply of oil.


 


  


      2) Trace the ideological evolution of Europe during the century


stretching from 1890- 1989. Would it be correct to argue that the


ideological center of gravity shifted leftward during this period? If so,


why? If not, what would be a better description of the ideological


changes that took place during World War I, World War II, and the


inter-war period? What might account for the global rightward shift in


the ideological center of gravity since 1989?


 


      Since WW2, there has been a massive shift away from nationalism to


globalism. This is partly because of the odium that Hitler’s movement


attached to nationalism, but it is also because as the world’s economy simply


became more global, requiring relaxing of boarders and a generally less


xenophobic attitude than might have been acceptable in earlier times.


Relatedly, the British and French empires, mainly the former, disbanded


during this time, partly because it ceased to be seen as acceptable for a


country to colonize other countries, this being a consequence of a leftward


shift in political thinking following WW2.


      During the post WW2 period, there continued to be conflicts between


‘liberal’ and ‘conservative’ ideologies, but whereas these conflicts had


previously been about social conservatism vs. social liberalism (e.g.opponents of women’s suffrage vs. proponents of it), they tended in the


aftermath of WW2 to concern economic liberalism vs. economic


conservatism, with ‘conservatives’ championing the free market and


‘liberals’ championing the ‘welfare state.’


      The ‘global rightward shift’ since 1989 is due to the utter failure of the


Soviet Union and to the consequent loss of faith in a hyper-regulated


economy. As a result of this failure, there came to be tremendous faith in the


free market, and this faith continues to grow. So in this sense there has been a


‘rightward shift’ since 1989. But in other respects, the post-WW2 leftward


shift has continued, with gay rights, transgender rights etc. now being seen as


mainstream and normal. So in sum, since WW2, there has been a rightward


shift in economic thought and a leftward shift in social and political thought,


both of these being due to the success of the free market and the failure of the


controlled.


 


 


      3) Many scholars have argued that between 1492 and 1989,


European culture became increasingly secularized. How valid is this


thesis? If you agree that Europe became more secularized, how can you


explain it? What key developments or events might account for the


process? If you disagree with the thesis, then explain how and whycertain forms of religious practice and sentiment have persisted. Has


religion truly declined in Europe since 1492, or has it simply migrated to


less recognizable domains of human activity, such as nationalistic politics


and culture?


 


      Europe most definitely has become more secular since 1492. This is


mainly because science and technology progress enormously during that


period, making it clear that a number of ‘articles of faith’ (e.g. that the Earth


is the center of the Universe, that people came into existence 6,000 years ago,


etc.) are simply false. Also, as science and technology progressed, people


came to turn to science/technology for answers, which it provided much of


the time, and less to religion, which never had provided particularly cogent


answers and which only offered emotional comforts, as opposed to actual


solutions.


        Religion itself was responsible for its displacement in that Martin


Luther, by breaking away from the Catholic Church, enormously weakened


the power of the latter, thereby making religion more of a personal matter and


less of an institutional matter.


      In the mid-1700s, owing in large part to the works of Locke and Adam


Smith, whose worldviews in their turn owed much to Newtonian scientific


rationalism, European economies came to be increasingly less dominated bypolitical authorities and increasingly driven by market forces.


      People have an impulse to be religious and religion certainly still


exists in the West, much more so in the USA than in Europe, and arguably


some of the fanaticism and dogmatism that used to be reserved for religious


faith was channeled into nationalism. But for the most part religious faith in


the West has been on the decline.


      The key developments leading to secularization, were the birth of


physics and chemistry, the industrial revolution, European colonization of the


New World (which gave European powers enormous incentives to liberalize


trade with one another), the theory of Evolution and, arguably, the


development of psychoanalytic thought.


 


      4) Since 1492, Europeans have increasingly encountered non-


Europeans across the globe, yet the terms of those encounters have


changed over time. Write an essay that traces the history of European


colonization, imperialism, and decolonization from 1492 to 1989.


 


      Europe began colonizing the New World as soon as it discovered it in


1492. The driving forces behind European colonization were largely


economic in nature. Because Europe needed cheap labor to service the


colonies, it forced many non-Europeans into slavery. This gave the colonistseconomic incentives to have racist attitudes towards non-Europeans, since


slavery is not justifiable except on the basis of a deeply racist attitudes


towards those who are enslaved.


      At the same time, colonization assumed different forms in different


places. In North America, colonization was less about exploiting the native


populations than it was about constructing a new economy from scratch. As a


result, the North American economy was based more on skilled labor and


industry than on agriculture and therefore could not be based solely on the


exploitation of one group of people by another. In Central and South


America, however, there were (and still are) large native populations who


could be pressed into slavery (or near slavery). Moreover, those economies,


being largely based on mining (of precious metals) and agriculture (coffee,


sugar, rubber) were based more on unskilled labor than on skilled labor and


could to a greater extent than North American economies be serviced by


slave labor.


      The economy in the United States was ultimately based on the free


market, and for this reason, along with the obvious fact that slavery is


immoral, slavery was abolished in the USA in 1865. This inaugurated a slow


but steady process of eliminating racial attitudes in the New World among


people of European descent.


      During the 19th Century, there was a fierce wave of French andBritish imperialist colonization of Africa and Asia, all of which was


obviously facilitated by a certain degree of racism on their part. After WW2,


and because of it, these empires quickly disbanded, mainly because WW2


was in large part a war against racism, and although racism continues to this


day, it doesn’t exist in the deeply entrenched, institutionally backed way that


it used, this being people are not denied suffrage or other rights on the basis


of race. In a word, WW2 shattered the ideological basis for imperialism, as


well as racism, leading to independence of countries such as India (liberated


from Britain in 1948), Algeria (liberated from France in 1962) and Vietnam


(liberated from France in 1958). In some cases, decolonization involved


armed revolt (as in Algeria), in other it didn’t.


      In short, free market economies are inherently non-racist. They can


involve exploitation and exploitation can be racist in nature. But ultimately


such economies require people to be able to transact with each other to be


able to buy at the lowest price and sell at the highest price, which it tends to


be hard to do if there are racist policies that restrict who can sell their labor


and determine how much they can sell it for.


         Why is the United States so Energy-inefficient? (Sociology)


 


 


      The United States is energy-inefficient in two ways. First, we use


more energy per capita than does any other country. Second, we use energy


less efficiently than other countries, in the sense that we get less work-output


per energy-input.


      A number of specific reasons for this have been proposed. For

        [38]
example:


 


      (i)         There are number of old businesses in the United States that use


antiquated an therefore energy-inefficient methods.


 


      (ii)   There are disproportionately many start-ups in the United States,


and, being managed by neophyte business-administrators, start-ups are


energy-inefficient.


 


      (iii)                       US customers have a taste for luxury and they demand


wastefulness: shoppers demand full-blas AC in the summers and full-blast


heat in the winter.


       (iv)   Many companies in the United States have wasteful business


practices, e.g. their employees leave computers on all night, the reason being


that the employees do not personally have a stake in their host-companies’


being energy-efficient.


 


      But whether taken individually or collectively, (i)-(iv) are not the real


reason why the US is so energy-efficient. (In fact, it isn’t clear that any one of


them is even a reason.) The reason is cultural in nature.


      The United States is all about the the American Dream. And what is


the American Dream? It is about living in the suburbs and commuting 45


minutes by car into the city every day. It is about having not one, but two or


even three cars in the garage. It is about having a large screen TV, and a pool


in the backyard.


      The American Dream is not merely about living well. It is possible to


live well without living wastefully. The American dream is about living well


by living non-austerely.


      The American dream is also about independence. And obviously there


is nothing with this and much that is good about it. But it has come to mean


in practice is that one is seen as a failure in the United States if one takes the


bus. Indeed, no one is more ridiculed and seen as a failure than somebody


who ‘has to take the bus’, instead of driving his own car. And no one is seenas more of a success than somebody who drives an expensive car—not an


economy car, which is almost seen as a sign of poverty, but a gas-guzzler,


like the $85,000 Ford Raptor, which is one quarter as efficient as a Hyundai


Elantra, but also—and perhaps partly for that reason---has around four times


as much social cache.


      American culture is about making it. And making it is equated with


making more money. And the most visible indicators that one has made


money tend involve wasteful practices---large air-conditioned penthouses,


gas-guzzling cars and planes, long weekend commutes to the Hamptons, and


so on.


      Whereas an ancient nation like China or Greece is about culture, the


United States is about economics and economic success. And economic


success, at least as interpreted by most people, is about “conspicuous


consumption”, to use Thorstein Veblen’s expression. And it is the


distinctively American identification of success with consumerism—with


conspicuous consumption, in other words—that the roots of American


energy-inefficiency lie.


             Stalin’s Nationalism vs. Putin’s Nationalism (History/Politics)


 


 


      Putin’s rule is similar in some key respects to Stalin’s. Let us begin by


saying what Stalin did.


 


      Stalin


 


      Stalin was the Marxist dictator of the Soviet Union form 1923-1953.


Stalin had two objectives: He wanted to make Soviet Union be as communist


as possible, and he also wanted to hold onto power. These two objectives of


his were confluent.


        Communism is the doctrine that nobody is to have any private


property (on a commercially significant scale).


      And so it was the Stalin divested people of all of their property. The


State took everything. Farmers gave up their land, their livestock, even their


lodging to the State.


      This was true not just of those in the agricultural sector, but of


everybody. Nobody owned anything. The state owned everything, and


everyone worked for the state.


      Given that the state owned everything, the State was everything. Thenation was everything: it owned everything, decided what kind of work


people were to do, decided who would work in the Gulag and who would be


‘free’, decided who would live and who would die, decided what people


could read, what move is they could watch, and what radio programs they


could listen to. Thus the Soviet Union was indeed completely totalitarian, in


the sense that the state was governed the totality of each person’s existence.


      In the Soviet Union, all action, all commerce, and even all thought


were state controlled (at least, to the extent that control of thought is a


consequence of control of education and media).


      In the Soviet Union, everything existed for the sake of the Soviet


Nation, and the latter was therefore a maximally nationalist nation.


      A consequence of this hyper-nationalism is that different ethnicities


and sub-nationalities were cruelly absorbed into this homogeneous Soviet


behemoth. Sub-national differences were suppressed; all official history was


Soviet history; all education was Soviet education; all official culture was


Soviet Culture. To the extent that Georgian or Ukrainian or Chechen culture


different from Soviet Culture, it was not tolerated. They were not tolerated


because the Soviet Union was to be a single communist nation, not a plurality


of ideologically different nations and not, moreover, a plurality of


ideologically different people.


      A consequence of agricultural collectivization was widespreadfeminine. To some extent this consequence was unintended, being a mere


consequence of administrative incompetence on the part of the Soviet


Leadership. But to a considerable extent, it was deliberate, being used as a


way of defeating sub-nations and bullying them into submission to the Soviet


Union. And so it was that Stalin’s regime actively encourage the


collectivization-caused mass-famine in the Ukraine, which caused the death


of 10,000,000 Ukrainians.


      Vladimir Putin is not quite in the same category as Joseph Stalin. First


of all, Russia under Putin is a capitalist/free-market society. (There are some


restrictions on commerce, but they are comparable to those in the United


States.) But there are some similarities between Putin’s style of leadership


and Stalin’s.


 


      Putin


 


      First of all, Putin, like Stalin, is an arch-nationalist. But whereas


Stalin’s nationalism was a consequence largely of his communism, Putin’s


nationalism is about preserving Russia’s historical identity (or what Putin


perceives to be that identity). Putin wants Russia to retain the religious and


moral traditions that it had before the Soviet Era; he wants Russia to be


Christian, and he wants social and political relations between people toconform to a rather traditionalist paradigm, with traditional gender roles and


traditional views about sexual orientation. (It should be pointed that Putin’s


traditionalism in these respects is quite circumscribed: There are more female


physicians and physicists per capita in Russia than in the United States. And


people are not jailed for being gay in Russia, even though they may be jailed


for being, as Putin sees it, for being gay in a disruptively political manner.)


      Also, under Putin, as under Stalin, there is only limited freedom of the


Press. There are two facets to this. First, the media is not allowed to question


the legitimacy of Putin’s power. Second, the Media is not to discourage the


growth of Western liberalism and anti-traditionalism within Russia.


Obviously, Putin’s nationalism is directly responsible only for the second of


these two facts, the first being a consequence not so much of Putin’s


nationalism as of his simple desire to retain power.


      But Putin’s nationalism is confluent with this desire to stay in power.


As a nationalist, Putin’s intention is to subordinate diversity to a single


national norm. And as somebody who wants to have power, it is in Putin’s


interest to subordinate diversity to a single norm. Also, given that Putin, as


supreme leader, is the state (up to a point), there is (to that extent) no


difference between subordinating everyone in Russia to Russia, on the one


hand, subordinating everybody in Russia to Putin, on the other hand.


      The same was true of Stalin. As a communist-nationalist, Stalinwanted to subordinate diversity to a single nationalist norm. And as


somebody who wanted to hold onto power, it was in Stalin’s interest to


subordinate diversity to a single nationalist norm. And given that Stalin was


the supreme leader, there was to that extent no difference (to that extent)


between subordinating everyone in the Soviet Union to the Soviet Union, on


the one hand, and subordinating everyone in the soviet Union to Stalin, on the


other.


 


                               Why Minimum Wage is Wrong


 


      My topic is minimum wage. The question I will answer is: Should


minimum wage be increased? The answer I will defend is: No, it should not


be increased.


      There are three reasons why it supposedly makes economic sense to


increase minimum wage.


      First, there must be minimum wage (and minimum wage must


periodically be increased) to ensure that workers make enough money for


basic necessities (lodging, food, healthcare): an employee who is physically


ill or malnourished is not a productive employee, and workers must be paid


enough to ensure that they are adequately nourished and have healthcare and


lodging. (Technically, a homeless person can be well nourished and healthy,


but homelessness dramatically increases the likelihood of physical injury and


illness, and workers must therefore be paid enough to have lodging.) In the


short run, underpaying employees saves employers money and might


therefore seem to help businesses grow. But in the long run, businesses that


depend on underpaid workers tend to fail, since underpaid workers tend not

                                                                  [39]
to be physically healthy enough to be competent workers.


      Second, there must be minimum wage (and periodic increases thereof)


if employees are to ensure that workers have a psychologically acceptablestandard of living. If a worker has just enough for food, lodging and


healthcare, he is likely to feel demoralized and also to experience depression


and other forms of mental illness, and mental illness, like physical illness,


diminishes competence. A worker whose life is pure tedium simply won’t


perform very well on the job, especially if his job involves any degree of


cognitive acumen. So even though it may seem to make economic sense for


employers to underpay their employees, the result of doing so is a workforce


that underperforms and therefore fails to contribute both to the businesses

                                                          [40]
that employ them and to the economy as a whole.


      Third, it is important that workers be paid enough not just to be


physically and psychologically healthy but also to have some surplus capital.


There are two reasons why workers need surplus capital. First, they need to


raise their children properly, children being the next generation of workers.


Second, economic growth is largely a consequence of new businesses coming


into existence; people needed surpluses of wealth to start businesses (the bare


minimum won’t suffice); and if workers don’t have such surpluses, then


entire class of people who could start businesses won’t be able to do so. Be it


noted that workers to a greater extent than others have industry-specific


knowledge and may know what kinds of businesses to build and how to build


them. So it is important that they be paid more than the bare minimum, so

                                                                              [41]
that they can at least have a chance to try to build such businesses.      There are three reasons why, despite what was just said, minimum


wage increases (and minimum wage in general) hurt the economy more than


they help it.


      First, when minimum wage is increased above its natural (market)


level, employers have to downsize and also stop hiring, making it hard for


people to find jobs and to make a living. So even though raising minimum


wage from $7.50/hour to $15/hour would seem to put more money in the


pockets of workers, the reality is that this ‘wage-increase’ really amounts in


most cases to a wage-decrease from $7.50/hour to $0/hour, since an

                                        [42]
unemployed worker makes nothing.


      Second, when minimum wage is increased, employers often lack the


funds to compete even after they downsize. Businesses need employees: it is


not an option for them to fire everybody. And minimum wage increases may


make it impossible for them to compete while also paying their employees,

                                    [43]
even after they have downsized.


      Third, when minimum wage increases do not altogether destroy


businesses, they do tend to eat up their profits, leaving them no surplus to


capital to invest back into themselves or into the economy in general. If a


pharmaceutical company has just enough money to pay its staff, it won’t have


enough to invest in research and development, which means it won’t be able


to grow and won’t be able to contribute new medications to the economy. Forthis reason, minimum wage increase result in a lackluster economy and are to

 [44]
be avoided.


      Finally, even though workers should obviously be paid enough for


them and their children to be healthy and educated, while also having some


surplus capital of their own, market forces see to it that this is done naturally.


It isn’t naturally that the government intervene by artificially inflating wages.


And if the government does intervene, the result is that employers have to


pay workers more than their actual market value; in other words, they must


pay workers for work they are not actually doing. This makes it hard for


businesses to stay in business, let alone grow and create new jobs, and this in

                                                                  [45]
turn results in loss of employment and a weak economy.

Economic Exposition           Pot Legalization in California: Prop 64 (Current Events)


 


      In California, in 2016, Proposition 64 passed, making recreational

                                                    [46]
marijuana use legal in the state of California. This seems to have many


upsides, and few downsides. The likely upsides include:


 


      *Revenue to the state of California from taxes on the sale of


Marijuana,


      *An improved economy, owing to the new economic vistas opened up


by the possibility of legally growing, marketing, and distributing marijuana,


        *Decreased contempt for the law, owing to the removal of unpopular


and hard-to-enforce (and impossible-enforce-in-an-equitable-manner)


marijuana laws


        *Shrinkage of a criminal justice system bloated with so-called ‘drug-


offenders’, many of whom have spent years in jail or on parole or probation


for marijuana-related offenses,


        *Freeing up of funds now dedicated to zero-sum


      *Improved morale, owing to decreased contempt


 


                         Zara’s Supply-chain Efficiency (Business)


 


      To: CEO


      Re: Strategic Factors Impacting Wearable Wishes' Competitive


Environment


 


      Our company, Wearable Wishes, has a number of strengths, but our


competitor, Zara, has each of these strengths to a comparable or greater


degree, and it also has several strengths that we lack.


      First of all, Zara is extremely effective at using data-analytics to


determine what customers want and, on that basis, to design fashions that

  [47]
sell. Wearable Wishes certainly does use data-analytics, but it does not use


as effectively as Zara. This, I believe, is because Zara has a well-defined


concept (it provides consumers with lightning-fast access to low-cost but


respectable imitations of the very latest fashions), whereas Wearable Wishes


has a more generic concept (we provide consumers with reasonably


fashionable clothes at moderate prices), with the result that Zara knows


exactly what to look for in data-analytics, whereas we don’t.


      In any case, Zara’s focused use of analytics is a serious threat to us,


since it enables Zara to pinpoint what customers want. This means that Zara


can focus on products that it knows with reasonable certainty will sell. Thisin turn means that it does not waste resources create, shipping, and marketing


products that nobody will buy. We, on the other hand, create, distribute, and


market products that people don’t buy at the original price and that we are


forced to heavily discount to offset costs. Also, because Zara’s products are


so in line with consumer demand, Zara has a special place in the hearts of


potential customers, whereas customers view us, with our relatively batting


average, with a certain suspicion or, at least, without the same respect.


Therefore, the effect on us of Zara’s precision analytics is negative, as it


increases Zara’s market-share and decreases ours.


      Also, Zara’s use of analytics, like all cases of industry-efficiency, has

                                      [48]
a positive effect on the economy. The economy slows down when people


don’t buy. Because of Zara’s effective use of analytics, its products are, so to


speak, flying off the shelves, and Zara therefore has to hire more people----


more people to market, manufacture, design, distribute, and so on. Our failure


to use analytics effectively has the opposite consequence: products remain on


shelves unsold. This means that we lose money and therefore have to let


people go. This in turn means that those people are unemployed, at least for a


while, and therefore spend less, which has a cooling effect on the economy.


Of course, we are a single, medium-sized company, so that cooling effect is


likely to be unnoticeable; but large-scale economic slow-downs are the result


of many little economic slowdowns.      Another important fact about Zara is that it has an unusually high


degree of control over its own supply chain. It is able to create and distribute

                                                                          [49]
products with amazing speed. This benefits Zara in many ways. First of all,


it minimizes the lag time between requests for products and receipt of those


products. If a given retailer wants 10,000 units of a certain kind of handbag,


Zara is able to oblige more or less right away, whereas Zara’s competitors,


including us, take a bit longer. Zara is therefore better than its competitors at


supplying the public with products while they are still fashionable and the

                          [50]
public still wants them. It also, I suspect, creates a willingness on the part


of retailers to do some free marketing on Zara’s behalf. If the owner of retail-


outlet X knows that Zara can fill orders within a matter of days, he will be on

                                                              [51]
the lookout for hot new items and will let Zara know. He will not be very


interested in talking to someone who will take months and months to fill the

                                                                      [52]
order, since, by then, the product in question may be a loser.


      Zara’s fast and efficient supply chain bodes ill for us. We lose


business to Zara, since Zara is able to get the product to customers before we


can, not to mention that merchandise is more likely than ours to be


fashionable when it hits the stores.


      Zara’s efficient supply-chain, like all cases of industrial efficiency,


will have a positive effect on the economy. It will lead to increased sales and


therefore to increased jobs and therefore to increased spending. Our relativelyinefficient supply chain will have the opposite effect, since it leads to


decreased sales, lay-offs, and decreased spending. To be sure, setting aside a


few juggernauts, like Microsoft, the success or failure of any given company


is not likely to have a noticeable effect on the economy. But, as previously


stated, noticeable effects are compounded out of unnoticeable ones.


      All of this said, Zara’s primary strategic advantage, I believe, is not its


use of analytics or its efficient supply-chain, but is rather its highly


differentiated product. Fashion-driven clothes buyers would ideally like to


have hyper-fashionable clothes; but those clothes are far too expensive for


most buyers. Zara has targeted such people and has, in effect, made a deal


with them. It has agreed to sell them inexpensive but creditable knock-offs of


super-fashionable clothes. By contrast, we provide reasonably fashionable,


moderately priced clothes. So we are ‘stuck in the middle’, servicing neither


high-fashionistas nor penny-pinchers, whereas Zara services the former and,


to a greater extent than us, the latter.


      Some might say that Zara and Wearable Fashions do not have the


same target audience and therefore are in competition, with Zara servicing


those who want high fashion and Wearable fashions serving those who want


clothes of the ‘respectable’ variety. I do not agree with this view. Many


people who end up settling for semi-fashionable clothes would like to have


extremely fashionable clothes, and we have to assume that Zara is taking                            [53]
customers away from us. As for the consequences for the economy of


Zara’s highly differentiated, the obvious position is that it has no such


consequence. Again, I disagree. Sales benefit the economy; the absence hurts.


Because of its highly-differentiated line of goods, along with its large


customer-base, Zara’s products sell and therefore stimulate the economy.


Also, Zara’s aggressive use of analytics and its supply-chain efficiency


encourages other companies to step up their game, which in turn leads to


technological and organizational innovations, which in their turn often do


have noticeably positive macroeconomic consequences.


             Microsoft Financial analysis 2016-2018 (Business/Accounting)

Sources        Introduction


      This present work is a financial analysis of Microsoft during the years


2017-2018. 2016 is included when the necessary data is available in course-


documents. Other years are excluded. This analysis is not complete and it


focuses only on the absolutely crucial financial indicators. Microsoft’s


financials are compared to Oracle’s, so as to provide information as to


Microsoft’s performance relative to its competitors.


      Our main source of information about Microsoft is Microsoft’s 2018


10-K form (specifically pages 50-53). Our main source of information about


Oracle is Oracle’s income statement, accessed at


  http://financials.morningstar.com/income-statement/is.html?


  t=ORCL&region=usa&culture=en-US. The financial data provided in those


documents rounds figures to the nearest thousandth. All specific financial


data relating to Microsoft and Oracle come from these sources unless there is


an indication otherwise.


        Microsoft’s performance during this time-period is positive in absolute


terms. Microsoft also marginally outperforms Oracle. That said, the one


companies financials parallel each other to a striking degree: Microsoft has


more total assets, but its performance relative to its total assets is similar to


(though marginally better than) Oracle’s performance relative to its total


assets. Between 2017 and 2018, there are dips in Microsoft’s performance,but those are corresponding dips in Oracle’s performance, indicating that the


issue is not with Microsoft itself but with the industry as a whole.


       Operating Cash Flow


      When conducting a financial analysis of a company, the first step is to


determine its cash flow from operating activities, or operating cash flow


(OCF), this being the amount of money that it generates from its activities,

                                      [54]
excluding long-term investments. In 2016, Microsoft’s OCF was


$33,325,000; in 2017, $35,507,000; and in 2018, $42,884,000. It is a good


sign that Microsoft's OCF was positive during each of these years since this


indicates that its products and services were generating income. A company


whose OCF is zero or negative can still profit since it can make money from


investments and assets, but its products and services are failing to generate


income, and its position is therefore unstable. Also, Microsoft’s OCF grew


over 30% during this period---also a positive sign.


        Microsoft’s net income (revenues minus expenses, i.e. profits) in 2016


was $20,539,000; in 2017, $25, 489,000; and in 2018, $16, 571,000. During


each year, Microsoft’s net income was positive, but its net income fell by


$8,918,000---a drop of over 34%.


      Oracle’s OCF in 2016 was $13, 561, 000; in 2017, $14,126,000; and


in 2018, $15,386,000. Oracle’s net income in 2016 was $8,901,000; in 2017,


$9,335,000; and in 2018, $3,825,000. Oracle’s OCF was positive during each


of these years, and also increased during this time period by around 13%.


Between 2017 and 2018, Oracle’s net income plummeted, falling by over50%. Since its OCF grew during this period, the fall does not indicate a


decline in demand for Oracle products and services.


       Common Equity


      In 2016, Microsoft’s common equity (the amount invested by


shareholders) was $68, 465, 000; in 2017, 68, 178,000; and in 2018,


$69,315,000. There was therefore modest growth in Microsoft common


equity during this period. In 2016, Oracle’s common equity was $164, 950,

                                                                  [55]
000; in 2017, $209, 937, 000; and in 2018, $175,569,000. Oracle’s


performance here is more jagged than Microsoft’s but also better on the


whole.


         Profitability


      The next few sections focus on financials relating to Microsoft’s


degree of profitability. We will see that Microsoft is ‘in the black’, so to


speak, and also compares better than Oracle, a representative competitor.


       Return on Equity


      In 2016, Microsoft’s return on equity (ROE)---in other words, its net


income divided by shareholder’s equity, this being the change in the value of


the shareholder’s equity--- was $20,539,000/$164, 950, 000≈30%; in 2017,


$25, 489,000/68, 178,000≈37%; and in 2018, $16, 571,000/69,315,000≈24%.


During each year, ROE is positive. At the same time, there was a decrease


from 2017 to 2018.


      Oracle’s ROE in 2016 was $8,901,000/$164, 950, 000≈5%; in 2017,


$9,335,000/$209, 937, 000≈4%; and in 2018, $3,825,000/$175,569,000≈2%.


In each year, ROE is positive, but much smaller than with Microsoft. Also,


with Oracle, as with Microsoft, we see a 2017-2018 drop. This parallel


suggests that in both cases the drop is a consequence not of anything


company-specific but rather of some larger economic phenomenon.


       Net Profit Margin


      In 2016, Microsoft’s net profit margin (net income divided by total


revenue, i.e. percentage of revenue that Microsoft retained after paying


expenses) was $20,539,000/$91, 154,000≈23%; in 2017, $25, 489,000/96,


571,000≈26%; and in 2018, $16, 571,000/110,360,000≈15%. The profit


margins are all positive, though there is a (now familiar) 2017-2018 drop.


      Oracle's ROE in 2016 was $8,901,000/$37,047,000≈24%; in 2017,


$9,335,000/$37, 728,000≈25%; and in 2018, $3,825,000/$39,831,000≈10%.


Again, profit margins are positive, with a 2017-2018 drop. Microsoft's profit


margin appears to track Oracle's, suggesting that changes in them are due not


to company-specific but rather to industry-wide factors.


       Asset Turnover


      Asset turnover is significant because it is a good measure of a


company’s health. A company with low-asset turnover is not using its assets


efficiently, and a company with high-asset turnover is using them efficiently.


      In 2017, Microsoft’s asset turnover (total revenue divided by total

 
assets) was $96,571,000/250,312,000≈39%; and in 2018, it was


  $110,360,000/$258,848,000≈43%. In 2017, Oracle’s asset turnover was $37,

                                [56]
  728,000/$134,991,000≈28%; and in 2018, it was

                                      [57]
  $39,831,000/$137,264,000≈29%. We are seeing parallels—increases in


both cases, albeit higher ones in Microsoft’s case.


       Leverage


      In 2017, Microsoft’s leverage (debt/equity) was

 
  $162,601,000/250,312,000≈65%; and in 2018, it was


  $176,130,000/$258,848,000≈68%. In 2017, Oracle’s asset turnover was

 
  $80,745,000/$134,991,000≈60%; and in 2018, it was

                                      [58]
  $91,040,000/$137,264,000≈66%. Both companies are highly leveraged. A


high degree of leverage can be a bad sign, since it can indicate deficit


financing, but here it is not a bad sign, as it seems to indicate aggressive and

                                                              [59]
successful investments in a growing economic sector. 


      Return on Assets


      In 2017, Microsoft’s return on assets (ROA), i.e.net income divided by

 
total assets, was $25,489,000/250,312,000≈10%; and in 2018, it was


  $16,571,000/$258,848,000≈6%. In 2017, Oracle’s asset turnover was

 
$9,335,000/$134,991,000≈7%; and in 2018, it was

                                  [60]
$8,901,000/$137,264,000≈6%. Both ROA’s are low but positive.


         Conclusion


      Microsoft and Oracle are both vigorous companies with high operating


cash flows and asset-turnovers. They are highly leveraged, but this seems to


be because they have thus far profited from aggressive investments in their


own growth.

                                       The Fraud Triangle


 


      What is the fraud triangle, and how should you consider this when


assessing a company's anti-fraud programs and controls?


 


      The Fraud Triangle is a hypothesis put forth by Donald Cressey as to


why high-level corporate fraud occurs. The Fraud Triangle is not concerned


with low-level ‘street level’ scams. Nor is it concerned with ongoing high-


level criminal enterprises, such as Bernie Madoff’s pyramid scheme. The


Fraud Triangle is concerned to explain cases where people who are not career


criminals and who typically have not committed major crimes embezzle large


amounts of money from companies that employ them. The Fraud Triangle is


meant to explain why somebody would use company funds to pay off


personal debts. The Fraud Triangle is not meant to explain the case of


somebody like Bernie Madoff, whose entire company was simply a front


designed to abscond with people’s funds. The Fraud Triangle is intended to


explain cases like that of Carlos Ghosn, an executive at Nissan who used


company funds to cover massive personal investment losses, or like that of


Nick Leeson, a trader for Barings Bank who used company funds to make a


series of unauthorized trades to cover up his financial losses. In other words,


the Fraud is meant to explain cases of high-level fraud committed by peoplewho have legitimate positions within legitimate organizations and who


therefore do not otherwise profile as criminals.


        According to the Fraud Triangle, three conditions must met for such


fraud to occur:


 


      1.            There must be a high degree of financial pressure on the


individual in question. In other words, he must need money desperately,


perhaps because of gambling losses, a drug problem, or (as with Carlos


Ghosn and Nick Leeson) poor investment choices.


      2.            He must have a relatively senior position within the company in


question, since he will not otherwise have access to the funds that intends to


embezzle. (A janitor cannot commit large-scale embezzlement; a CEO or


high-level bond-trader can do so.)


      3.            He must be able to rationalize his act of fraud. In other words,


he must be able to tell himself that he is justified in doing what he is doing,


even though it is illegal and unethical.


 


      Consider the case of Nick Leeson. As a trader at Barings, he was


entrusted with large amounts of company assets. Therefore, he was able to


generate huge losses, placing him under great financial pressure, and he was


also in a position to use company assets to try to cover those losses. Thus,conditions (1) and (2) were met in his case. Finally, Leeson did not have any


legal recourse: there was no one he could go to. He could not go to a bank,


since no bank would be able to loan him the billions of dollars needed to bail


him out; nor could he go to his own employer, since they would fire him and


he would be banned from the industry for life. So he was able to rationalize


his misconduct to himself on these grounds--and that is just what he did.


      There are several ways that a given company can minimize the


likelihood that one of its employees will commit fraud of this kind. These


include:


 


      1.            Running thorough background checks. This lowers the


likelihood of hiring somebody who is psychologically capable of committing


fraud.


      2.            Having clear guidelines relating to the handling of funds and


sensitive information. This creates a climate of transparency, making it hard


for people to commit fraud, and also makes it harder for people to rationalize


committing fraud.


      3.            Secure assets, including passwords and other sensitive


information. This minimizes the opportunity to commit fraud.


      4.            Separating employee-duties. This prevents any single employee


from having access to too much information or to too many funds.      5.            Requiring authorization for employee-transactions involving


more than a certain amount of money. This minimizes the likelihood of theft


and also of Leeson-style losses that incentivize fraud.


      6.            Have an independent firm conduct audits, including surprise


audits, of company accounts. This nips fraud in the bud and also scares


employees into not committing it in the first place.


      7.            Conduct annual internal audits. This gives the company


advance-notice of shortfalls that should be made good before the IRS


conducts an actual audit.


      8.            Have an internal reporting mechanism. This helps nip fraud in


the bud and also scares people into not committing it in the first place.


      9.            Have a company-culture of honesty and transparency. This


makes it hard for fraudsters to rationalize their conduct, which in turn lowers


the likelihood of their committing fraud in the first place.


                 Forensic Accounting Post-Enron (Business/Accounting)


 


        Accounting is the recording and evaluating of business transactions.


Thus, an accountant working for a given business is supposed to keep records


of what that business spent, what it spent it on, and what money it has coming


in. If Smith is Brown’s accountant, then Smith’s job is to keep records of


what Brown spends, what he spends it on, and what money Smith has coming


in. Forensic accounting is the branch of accounting that is concerned with


resolving accounting-related matters that have given rise to legal disputes or


are likely to do so. If Green is a client of Smith and Green believes that the


financial statements that Smith and Brown jointly issue are fraudulent, a


forensic accountant may be called in to determine what the truth of the matter


is. A forensic accountant may be employed privately, as would be the case if


Green is himself an employee of Smith’s firm, or it may be done by the


government, as would be the case if Green works for the Securities and


Exchange Commission.


        Forensic accounting has existed as long as accounting has existed. But


its importance grew in the immediate aftermath of Enron scandal in 2001. In


order to understand how forensic accounting has changed since that time, we


must understand what the Enron scandal involved.


      Enron was a Texas-based energy provider that, while under theleadership of CEO Kenneth Lay, began to expand aggressively and make a


number of bold investments. At first, these moves were lucrative, causing the


value of its stock to rise and enhancing Enron’s prestige. Forbes at one point


ran an article claiming that Enron was “the most creative Energy Company in


the United States.” As a result, Enron continued to make bold financial


moves, buying up new companies and thereby pinning its financial success to


that of these subsidiaries. Unfortunately, many of these ventures failed


utterly, generating large losses for Enron. Enron’s attempts to dig itself out of


this whole through additional ventures failed, with the result that Enron only


dug itself in even deeper.


      Enron was at a crossroads. On the one hand, it could be honest with


shareholders and other stakeholders about its financial situation. On the other


hand, it could attempt to cover up these losses. The first path would be legal,


but would cause the value of the stock to plummet, possibly causing the


company to collapse. The second path would at least temporarily fool


stakeholders into believing that the company was still a good investments,


allowing for a continuation of high-profits, but would be illegal.


      Enron chose the second path, and to this end it enlisted the help of


Arthur Andersen, an accounting firm that Enron had already hired to serve as


an external auditor. Andersen’s legal and ethical duty was to verify that


Enron’s financial disclosures to the public and to stakeholders were accurate.But when Enron began to lose money, it asked Andersen to help cover up the


losses, and Andersen complied. To this end, Anderson engaged in a number


of deceptive accounting practices. In some cases, Anderson used legal


loopholes that allowed them to over-report profits and under-report losses,


and in other cases, Anderson simply destroyed incriminating documents.


Eventually, Enron’s losses caught up with it, since it was never able to make


good on the losses that it had sustained. As a result, Enron simply collapsed,


and its financial malfeasance, including Andersen’s role in falsifying its


financials, was exposed.


      The United States government responded with the Sarbanes-Oxley


(SOX) Act of 2002, the main provisions of which were:


 


      (i) The creation of a Public Company Accountability Oversight Board


(PCAOB): An independent company that scrutinizes the financial conduct of


large companies;


      (ii) The enactment of heightened standards of corporate financial


accountability and transparency, along with stricter penalties for executives


of companies that fall short of these standards; and


      (iii) The creation of ‘conflict of interest’ laws that strictly prohibit


accounting firms from conducting external audits of companies towards


which they might be biased.      When Enron collapsed, its financial statements lost all credibility, and


so did Andersen’s financial statements about Enron’s financial condition. As


a result, new investigators, including forensic accountants and fraud


examiners, had to figure out what Enron’s actual financials were. This


awaked the public to the need for forensic accountants, creating a surge in


demand for their services. This demand has only grown, thanks to the post-


Enron series of financial scandals, including the Madoff Scandal and the


2008 Housing Market Collapse.


      Being a good forensic accountant involves all of the skills involved in


being an ordinary accountant (e.g. a high-concern for detail, a facility with


numbers, and high degree of conscientiousness), but it also involves


additional skills. Unlike ordinary accountants, forensic accountants are


dealing with intentional cover-ups and therefore have to deal not just with


complex financial data but also with deliberate deception. This means that in


addition to being accountants, forensic accountants must also be detectives.


Therefore, they must good at detecting and investigating financial crimes,


including interviewing possible witnesses, using new technologies, and being


familiar with the laws governing such activities. In a word, a forensic


accountant is two parts accountant and one part detective and must therefore


have an accountant’s analytical abilities along with a detective’s intuitive


faculties. 


                         Using the Fraud Triangle to Prevent Fraud


 


      The Fraud Triangle is a theory developed by Donald Cressey to


explain the occurrence of high-level corporate fraud. The Fraud Triangle is


meant to explain cases of fraud carried out by a trusted member of an


organization against that same organization, e.g. a company executive


embezzling funds or using company funds to make personal investments.


According to the Fraud Triangle, instances of this sort of fraud are the result


of a confluence of three factors, namely:


 


      1.            Unusual and extraordinary financial pressure on the individual


in question (e.g. Smith has just gambled away his life-savings);


      2.            The opportunity to commit fraud, meaning that the person in


question is in a position where he is actually able to make fraudulent use of


company money or resources (e.g., Smith is the Chief Financial Officer of the


company in question);


      3.            The ability to rationalize the fraud, meaning that the person in


question can convince himself, and possibly others, that under the


circumstances he was justified in perpetrating fraud (e.g., the company that


employs Smith is itself constantly stealing money from clients, making it


possible for Smith to tell himself that the company deserved to be defrauded). 


      A good example of the kind of fraud that the Fraud Triangle can be


used to explain, and also to prevent, is the case of Nicholas Leeson. Acting in


his capacity as a trader in the Singapore branch of Barings Bank, Leeson


made some legitimate but unsuccessful trades. Rather than admit to his


superiors that he lost company money, he illicitly used additional company


funds to make more investments, hoping to cover his losses. When these


investments failed, the subsequent losses to Barings were so large that the


bank simply collapses, taking much of the securities market along with it.


      The Fraud Triangle makes it clear how companies can prevent the


occurrence of fraud. According to the Fraud Triangle, it tends to be people


who under extreme financial pressure who commit fraud, a corollary being


that companies should not hire such people or at least should give them


positions of financial authority. If somebody has an extremely low credit


rating or has just suffered millions of dollars of losses on the stock market,


that person has a strong incentive to commit fraud, and a company wishing to


avoid the occurrence of fraud in its midst is well-advised not to hire him or at


least not give him a position that would allow him to make inappropriate use


of company money or resources. Of course, not all cases of fraud can be


prevented in this way, since in many cases, including Nicholas Leeson's, the


person in question isn't under extreme financial pressure until after they arehired.


      This brings us to the second part of the Fraud Triangle, according to


which people don’t commit workplace fraud unless their positions within the


company make it possible for them to do so, a corollary being that companies


should limit such opportunities. Nicholas Leeson was able to commandeer


such huge funds because his activities were not being adequately supervised


and because his position made it possible for him to execute large trades


without being given clearance by a supervisor. In general, fraud is likely to


occur when people within a company operate without supervision and when


they have the power to make important decisions without company-


clearance. Consequently, fraud is unlikely to occur when there is adequate


supervision and when there are adequate checks and balances. Companies


wishing to reduce the risk of fraud in their midst should strictly oversee


sensitive activities on the part of employees and should also limit the amount


of power, especially power to use company assets, that any single employee


has.


        According to the third component of the Fraud Triangle, Fraud is more


likely to occur when people are able to justify committing acts of fraud, a


corollary being that the risk of fraud is reduced when they cannot do so. The


ability to rationalize fraud has both internal and external determinants. If a


person lacks integrity, he may be able to rationalize practically any case ofmisconduct on his part, even if that misconduct is not a response to strong


external pressures. Consequently, a good way for a company to reduce the


risk of workplace fraud is to hire people who have integrity and not to hire


people who don’t.


      Also, if a given company treats its own employees well, it gives them


that much less of a way to rationalize perpetrating fraud against that


company. If the CFO of a given company hasn’t received the bonuses he was


promised, he will be that much more tempted to help himself to those funds


through fraudulent means. Further, if a company has unclear or excessively


complex procedures, especially in regards to the financially impactful


activities, then it is that much easier for employees to rationalize fraud; and


the risk of fraud is therefore reduced by having well-defined and intelligible


employee-guidelines in place. Finally, if a company is itself engaged in fraud


(e.g., by providing poor service or by overbilling clients), employees within


that company may feel that the company has lost any moral right not to be


defrauded. A corollary is that companies reduce the risk of fraud in their


midst by themselves being non-fraudulent.


               Money Laundering: Basic Principles (Business/Accounting)


 


      Money laundering is the act of making illegally obtained money

                                          [61]
appear to have been legally obtained. There are many reasons why


terrorists, drug cartels, and criminals of all varieties need to launder the


money they make. First of all, money that is clearly illegally obtained is


evidence of a crime. Second, money that does not appear to have been legally


obtained is difficult to invest. Third, such money is hard to use for large


transactions. Fourth, such money is difficult to use for many kinds of small

                                            [62]
transactions, such as online purchases. Some hypotheticals will help clarify


these points:


        Hypothetical #1: Smith is a drug dealer who has $1,000,000 in


illegally obtained cash. Smith’s ability to use that money is limited so long as


it remains in cash form. Smith therefore sets up a fake business, and he pays a
