friend of his a $1,000 to make $1,000,000 in purchases from this fake


business. The money then goes into a business checking account, and the


money, having been duly ‘laundered’, is available for online purchases,


securities purchases, and the like.


        Hypothetical #2: Jones robs a bank and makes off with $1,000,000 in


cash. There is not much he can do with the cash, since the bills are likely to


be traced. So he convinces Brown, an associate of his, to set up a phonycharity. Jones ‘donates’ the $1,000,000 to this charity. In exchange for a fee,


Brown deposits the money in the charity’s bank account, and he then makes


Jones the trustee of that account.


        Hypothetical #3: Robins runs a large and successful prostitution ring,


leaving him with large quantities of cash. He wants that money to grow,


instead of simply sitting under his mattress. So he buys a large orange ranch


in Florida for $10,000,000 but convinces the seller to record the official


selling price as $10,000. This way, Robins can easily explain to officials how


he came up with the money for his ranch, giving him legal insulation. At the


same time, his money has now been converted into a constant source of


legitimate revenue.


      Here are some actual cases of money laundering:


      Case #1: On February 12, 2019, seven Texas residents (Adrian


Arciniega-Hernandez, Adriana Alejandra Galvan-Constantini, Luis Montes-


Patino, Ravinder Reddy Gudipati, Harsh Jaggi and Neeru Jaggi) were


convicted of drug trafficking and money laundering. These individuals


worked for a Mexican Drug Cartel. They paid legitimate businesses to set up


accounts in which the illegally obtained money was deposited. On record,


these accounts belonged to these businesses and therefore appeared to be

                                                                          [63]
legitimate, but in actuality they were controlled by drug dealers.


      Case #2: December 14, 2018, 36 individuals were convicted ofrunning a sex-trafficking ring based in Thailand and then laundering the


proceeds by depositing them in accounts belonging to fake charities that they

            [64]
had set up. 


      Case #3: On June 18, 2014, Robert Boedigheimer, a Minnesota


attorney, was convicted of laundering the proceeds of illegal narcotics sales.


Boedigheimer purchased several properties in Minnesota, and a client of his,


Brandon Lusk, used money obtained through drug deals to manage those


properties, with both Lusk and Boedigheimer sharing the proceeds from the

                    [65]
subsequent rentals.


      In each of these three cases, a criminal or criminal organization was in


possession of illegally obtained that they could not use, and they either set up


fake businesses or used real businesses to hold that money, thereby making it


appear legitimate. Once that money had been thus ‘laundered’, it was


available to be used to invest in legitimate enterprises, such as the apartment


complexes owned by Robert Boedigheimer. Thus, laundering money allows


it to grow, with the proceeds typically being reinvested in the criminal


enterprise in question, while concealing the source of that money.


      Money laundering involves three stages:


 


      *The Placement Stage: Money is placed in a seemingly legitimate


company or organization. (For example, a drug dealer uses cash to purchase alemon ranch.)


      *The Layering Stage: Money is then filtered through a network of


different companies and organizations. (Said drug dealer deposits the


proceeds from said ranch in numerous different accounts.


      *The integration phase: The money in those accounts is injected back


into the legitimate economy. (Said drug dealer uses the money in said


accounts to purchase stock in Amazon, McDonald's, and other Fortune 500

            [66]
companies.)


 


      There are many different indications that money laundering is taking


place. These include:


 


      *Cash purchases that are being made unusually frequently or in


unusually large amounts. (Robert Boedigheimer paid hundreds of thousands


of dollars in cash for contracting and renovating services.)


      *Large transactions involving recently created legal entities (e.g.


companies or charities), where the values of the transactions are out of


proportion to the likely value of the companies. This is what happened in the


sex-trafficking case discussed above.


      *Large purchases of land or equipment that do not involve the buyer


actually inspecting the land/equipment in question prior to the purchase.      *A series of cases where property is purchased and then ‘flipped’,


especially where the resale price is much higher or lower than the original


price.


        *Somebody’s opening a large number of different accounts within a


short period of time and depositing money in each of those accounts.


      *Heavy use of offshore accounts.


      *Money being shuttled between a plurality of different accounts.


      *Sales involving massive discrepancies between book values and


market values, e.g. a case where the official sales price of a property actually


worth $40,000,000 is $1,000.


      *Inflated invoices, e.g. a restaurant whose official invoices indicate


that its income comes from $300 shrimp cocktails.


        *Obvious discrepancies between a person’s lifestyle and supposed


income. For example, Al Capone’s ‘official’ occupation was furniture maker,


but his lifestyle was obviously not that of a furniture maker.


        *Attempts to sidestep regulatory requirements, such as filling out 8300


forms, as well as unusual or constantly shifting modes of transferring money.

[67]


 


      In most cases, investigators are tipped off by a suspicious individual,


e.g. somebody who finds it suspicious that a low-earning junior associate athis law firm suddenly bought a $300,000 car or a bank official who finds it


suspicious that a client tries to make deposits without filling out the requisite


paperwork.


      Also, a number of legal controls have been instituted, violation of


which automatically alerts the authorities to possible money laundering.


These include laws that require banks and other financial institutions to file


reports on all unusually large transactions and to scrutinize client-information


in such cases. In addition, special investigative agencies have been created,


most notably the Financial Action Task Force, an intergovernmental agency


that enables investigators in different countries work together to investigate

                              [68]
cases of money laundering.


      Once investigators have been alerted to a possible case of money


laundering, their primary mode of investigating is to ‘follow the money.’ For


example, in Case #1 (discussed above) businesses were pressuring their


bankers not to fill out the usual deposit-forms. The banks sounded the alarm,


leading investigators to investigate the source of the money being deposited.


Investigators in Case #2 (discussed above) were tipped off by private citizens


who doubted the legitimacy of some the charities in question. Investigators


then scrutinized those charities and immediately found them to be bogus.


Investigators in Case #3 were tipped off by personal acquaintances of Robert


Boedigheimer, who found it odd that an unsuccessful attorney was suddenlyable to afford several multi-million dollar apartment buildings, leading


investigators to discover the connection between Boedigheimer and Lusk.


      Even though money laundering investigations tend to be extremely


complex, they all have the same two-part structure. Part 1: Somebody reports


some kind of suggestive irregularity to the authorities, for example, a banker


reports a client who pressures him not to fill out the requisite forms, a


neighbor reports another neighbor who is suddenly living above his means.


Part 2: Investigators follow the money: they try to find out where so and so


got the money that is trying to deposit or that he already spent on a new car.


      In conclusion, money laundering makes it possible for illegal


enterprises to conceal and compound their earnings, and it is combatted


through a combination of strict financial regulations and careful subsequent


examination of financial networks.


 


                                       The Valeant Fraud


 


      Valeant has been a major supplier of pharmaceuticals since its


inception. In 1959. The standard strategy for drug companies is based on


research and development (R&D): new medicines are discovered through


research, then manufactured and sold. In 2007, Valeant revenue was a


dangerously low level, and the company looked non-standard strategies for


revenue growth. J. Michael (‘Mike') Pearson, a consultant hired by Valeant,


proposed that Valeant simply stop doing R&D and instead buy patents to


undervalued medications and, having acquired them, raise the prices. The


logic behind this strategy is simple: R&D is extremely expensive and


outcomes are not guaranteed, since scientific can never be guaranteed to


happen. By contrast, Pearson's acquisitions-based strategy involved buying


products that were already known to work and whose price Valeant would be


able to manipulate to its own advantage.


      At first, this strategy worked. In fact, it worked so well, that Valeant


asked Pearson to be its CEO. He accepted and embarked on a campaign of


aggressively buying out smaller pharmaceutical companies, along with the


medicines they supplied, and then inflating the prices of those medications


whenever possible. Valeant’s price-gouging sowed some early seeds of


public distrust in Valeant, which later be harvested.      After a few years, the strategy began to backfire. First of all, other


pharmaceutical companies followed suit, replacing R&D with Pearson’s


acquisitions-based model, making it more expensive to acquire


pharmaceutical companies and therefore thinning its profit margins. Also,


some of these acquisitions were losers; for example, Valeant spent millions to


buy the rights for Potiga, an anti-seizure, believing that it would be a break-


out success; but it failed, and Valeant had nothing to show for.


      Operating jointly, these factors were driving Valeant back into the red.


This is where Pearson and Valeant took a fraudulent turn. Pearson chose not


to let the public know that Valeant was losing money. Instead, he embarked


on a two-prong plan, involving the use of anti-competitive practices to regain


market-share as well as outright fraud to conceal existing losses. Valeant set


up a secret arrangement with Philidor Rx Services, an online pharmacy-


company, whereby Philidor would sell only Valeant products in exchange for


lower prices while billing insurance companies according to the original


prices and then splitting the ‘skim' with Valeant. Though fraudulent, this did


generate real revenue for Valeant. But even with this extra revenue, Valeant's


actual financials were poor, and Pearson used Philidor to carry out a second


scam. This one involved Valeant booking sales to Philidor that were never


made, thereby inflating Valeant's revenue on paper and attracting investment.


In exchange for its role in this Philidor received a cut of the resultinginvestments in Valeant. Eventually, Valeant simply bought out Philidor while


letting the previous Philidor owners remain as the owners of record, thereby


turning Philidor into a full-service, off-the-books money-laundering


operation for Valeant.


      Also, under Pearson’s direction, Valeant was bribing physicians


nationwide to prescribe Valeant-owned medications. Finally, Valeant was


relying increasingly on price-gouging to generate revenue, drawing public ire


and regulatory scrutiny.


      Also, Valeant did not comply with GAAP. When the values of


Valeant’s investments fell, as they increasingly often did, Valeant did not


adjust its financials accordingly, this being a violation of the Full Disclosure


Principle (financial statements must tell the truth, the whole truth, and


nothing but the truth) and also of the Matching Principle (no credits without


debits, or vice versa). Further, it used several different accounting methods,


also a violation of the Full Disclosure Principle.


      A number of factors operating simultaneously led to Valeant’s crash.


Public outrage at Valeant’s price-gouging caused regulatory to scrutinize


Valeant, in search of regulatory or criminal violations. Regulators discovered


that Valeant used opaque and non-standard accounting practices, making


them suspicious; and whey they finally deciphered Valeant’s financials, they


discovered that many of the sales that it had booked with Philidor werefraudulent. This triggered further investigations, which unearthed Valeant’s


other scams.


      Dimitry Khmelnitsky, a financial analyst and Valeant-employee since


2011, realized shortly after being hired that Valeant’s official numbers were


off. He repeatedly tried to apprise Valeant executives of this fact, but they


angrily rebuffed, suggesting that it was an ‘open secret’ that these figures


were phonies. Though there is limited publicly available information on this


matter, the Khmelnitsky situation suggests that the problem with Valeant was


not that Pearson was hiding what he was doing from other Valeant employees


but rather they were in most colluding with him. This makes it unclear what


kinds of internal controls could have been used. Pearson was not stealing


from Valeant; rather, Valeant, under Pearson’s direction, was hiding losses


from investors and manipulating markets. So this was a matter for external,


not for internal controls.


      Even though financial statement fraud was only one of the many forms


of fraud that Valeant committed under Pearson’s direction, it would have


been hard for Valeant to run these scams without cooking the books. It


should be pointed out that Valeant was guilty of three very different kinds of


financial statement fraud. First, it intentionally used cryptic and inconsistent


accounting methods. Second, it booked gains that did not exist; in other


words, it simply made numbers up. Third, it went so far as to buy anothercompany so as to make it easier to concoct fraudulent financials.


      What is most striking about this case to me personally is that Valeant


was entirely speculation-based, whereas other Pharmaceutical companies are


R&D-based, suggesting that when there is financing without product, fraud is


just around the corner.


                                 An Actual Case of ID Theft


 


      1.            What could the victim’s bank have done differently that could


have potentially stopped or limited the fraudulent activity?


 


      Whenever an attempt is made to withdraw a large amount of money


from an account or to cash a check for a large amount, the identity of the


person in question must be verified thoroughly. This did not happen in this


case.  This  is  particularly  inexcusable,  given  that  the  withdrawal  was  for


$5000 from an accounting containing only $5200. First of all, $5000 is a


large amount. Second, it is a large amount relative to the total amount in the


account, which is a red flag. Fraudsters will often try to make off with just


less than what they know to be in the account that they are pillaging. Finally,


the teller noted that the signature, though similar to Jim’s, was slightly off---


another red flag that the bank ignored.


 


      2.            After the fraudulent activity had been discovered, Jim met with


a representative of the check printing company regarding policies/controls


that  the  company  should  consider  implementing  in  order  to  help  identify


fraud in the future. What changes would you recommend to the company?


       The bank’s response to Jim’s query was ambiguous. On the one hand,


they did apprise him of the fact that they had a video of the person who


cashed the check. On the other hand, they were very slow to cooperate with


after making that disclosure. My suspicion is that the bank’s management


realized  that  they  had  ‘dropped  the  ball’,  and  were  attempting  to  dodge


liability for that mistake. I would recommend that the bank double-check the


identification of anyone making withdrawals, triple check in cases when the


withdrawals are large, and quadruple check when there are red flags such as


possibly forged signatures. Also, there should be standardized protocols for


verifying  identify:  only  certain  documents  should  be  used  (e.g.  driver’s


license, Government ID card), and bank staff should be trained how to know


when such documents are valid.


 


      3.            What could the furniture store have done differently that could


have potentially stopped or limited the fraudulent activity?


 


      The  fraudsters  applied  for  financing  at  the  furniture  store,  which


means that they should have been required to present incontrovertible proof


of identity. They were not asked to do this. The employee who approved the


financing later disappeared and turned out to have been involved in other


fraud cases, making it a distinct possibility that this was an ‘inside job.’ Thatcompany, like all companies, should always require proof of identity when


dealing with non-cash purchases.


 


      4.            What could the credit card company have done differently that


could have potentially stopped or limited the fraudulent activity?


 


      The fraudsters applied in person for a credit line in Jim's name, and


they did this without having a valid ID. (And even though they may have had


forged identify papers, most such documents are not very convincing.) The


credit card company should obviously have verified their identity, which did


they did not do. The fact that they were involved in other suspicious cases


involving  the  same  furniture  company  employee  shows  that  they  were


systemically remiss in their responsibility to verify the legitimacy of credit


applications. This in turn suggests that they may have been aware that they


were getting phony applications, but turned a blind eye to since they wanted


the business.


 


      5.            What could have the victim have done differently that could


have potentially helped in this case?


 


      When the victim first noticed a suspicious withdrawal from thisaccount, he should have put a hold on his account and reported the incident to


the bank as possible fraud. He did not do any of this, and this is opened the


door to the fraud that ensued. Also, although he went to the police, he did not


go to legal authorities. The police are not equipped to deal with cases of


financial fraud. One should either go to the FBI or file a motion in Federal


Court under the False Claims Act. The latter is most easily done with the help


of a lawyer, and Jim probably should have at least consulted an attorney


(many of whom do free first-time consultations), which, so far this document


indicates, he did not. (The reason he didn’t, presumably, is that his attorney-


fees might have exceeded the amount he was trying to recover.)


 


      6.                      Is there anything the victim could have done prior to the


fraudulent activity that could have helped?


 


      Jim should probably have made himself better known to the people at


his bank, since, had he done so, they would have known who he was and


would have stopped the fraudsters dead in their tracks. (That said, the article


does mention that some of the tellers knew who he was, which makes the


bank’s  failure  to  prevent  even  more  inexcusable.)  More  importantly,  Jim


obviously  did  something  that  gave  the  fraudsters  access  to  his  personal


information. Whatever it was he did that led to this, he shouldn't have done it.It appears from the document that instead of using checks issued by his bank,


he purchased less expensive checks online. This appears to have been the


weakest link in his defenses. The fraudsters somehow knew that he bought


checks online (perhaps by rooting through his garbage, looking for some such


point of entry), and were able to impersonate Jim by ordering checks in his


name from the same company. Had Jim simply used bank-issued checks, this


situation might have been avoided.


 


      7.            Is there anything else the victim could have done after the


fraudulent activity that could have minimized the fraud?


 


      Jim probably should have moved his money to a different bank, since


his  current  bank  obviously  wasn’t  reliable.  Also,  Jim  should  probably  be


careful about his online behavior, especially in connection with purchases of


checks or other financial instruments. Finally, Jim should henceforth destroy


checks, credit cards, and other such documents before throwing them away;


and, more generally, he should make sure that his financial information is


never physically or digitally made available to anyone who cannot be trusted.


                         A Case of Financial Fraud at a University


 


        ABSTRACT: This nonfictional case of inventory fraud in a university


setting exposes students to fraud detection and investigation. These skills are


becoming increasingly important for auditors, as evidenced by the alarming


rate of fraud. The accounting profession has acknowledged the seriousness of


this issue with the issuance of SAS No. 99, Consideration of Fraud in a


Financial Statement Audit, developed in part to improve detection of frauds


by auditors.


 


      The case raises many of the fraud-related issues faced by accountants:


recognizing red flags indicative of fraud; the importance of a good system of


internal controls; the profile of the typical fraud perpetrator; the fine line


auditors walk when investigating a fraud; the need to develop an audit team


with the appropriate level of expertise which may require members from a


variety of disciplines (e.g., investigative, legal and forensic areas); and the


difficulty of obtaining sufficient evidence to prosecute and convict


perpetrators.


 


 


       Part 1: The Initial Audit


 


      The Internal Audit Department of “X State University”2 performs an


unscheduled audit whenever a university department head desires assistance


in determining the financial status of his department’s operation, and reports


its audit results to the Vice President of Administration and Finance. In


addition, unknown to most university employees, it is standard operating


procedure for the Internal Audit Department to perform an unscheduled audit


prior to the departure of key employees (e.g., an employee responsible for


handling large amounts of cash). In December 1988, the campus computing


services director requested that the Internal Audit Department audit the


campus Microcomputer Store (MCS) operations, prior to the imminent


departure of the MCS manager. The manager had held the position for eight


years. During the past year he purchased a new house in the community, he


had been seen driving a new sports car to work, and he had just returned from


his European honeymoon prior to the start of the audit. The internal auditors


completed the engagement in six weeks. Their findings were as follows:


 


      1) All employees were on the payroll of the MCS and there were no


additional or “ghost” employees on the payroll. The MCS manager earned


approximately $18,000 a year in salary. 


      2) For select samples, the university’s purchasing guidelines were


adhered to by the MCS operation. However, the use of personal computers


was becoming much more common during the 1980s. There was one


personal computer on campus in 1981, but by 1988 there were approximately


1,500 units on campus. Consequently, the volume of computers purchased for


campus use had risen close to 200 percent per year in each of the past five


years.


 


      3) There were no written position descriptions for any of the positions


in the MCS, nor were there any written operations manuals or guidelines for


any daily transactions.


 


      4) Despite their best efforts, the Internal Audit Department was able to


compile only a few fully documented transactions, from requisition/ order, to


receiving, to setup and delivery, to billing and finally to additions in the


Capital Property Control records. The problems noted included: few of the


forms were prenumbered; the files were widely dispersed in the center;


documents were not attached to each other and were not in any particular


order; and often a billing statement or a purchase order would be missing all


related documentation— only a handwritten note by the MCS manager on thebilling statement or purchase order would support the transaction. To


compound these problems, there were no “checks and balances” built into the


MCS accounting system as compensating controls.


 


      5) The direct supervisor for the MCS manager was aware of how the


MCS operated in general, but knew nothing about the operating details of


what was essentially a one-person operation (i.e., the MCS manager).


 


      6) Purchases, as far as the internal auditors were able to ascertain,


approached $1,200,000 in the most recent year.


 


      Required:


 


      1)              What additional work could the Internal Audit Department


perform prior to issuing the audit report?


 


      MCS was doing a large volume of business. This could be verified


even without proper documentation. The university used a large number of


computers, and MCS provided all of them. The auditors could have readily


determined the approximate number of computers used on campus along with


the approximate cost of each unit, and they may even have had thisinformation from the start. Either way, it provided what should have been a


benchmark, in comparison with which the MCS reported earnings would


have obviously fallen suspiciously short. Also, surveillance of MCS during a


period of a week or so, along with scrutiny of the receipts thereby generated,


would have given auditors another similar benchmark. Before submitting


their report, the auditors should have availed themselves of such information


and considered its implications. It is not possible to conduct a meaningful


audit of a business except on the basis of business-volume, and the auditors


failed to take business-volume into account.


 


      2) What recommendations to the campus computing services director


and the university administration would be appropriate for the MCS?


 


      Both parties should have been required to keep careful and easily


understood records of sales, of funds requisitioned from the university, of


purchases made using said funds, and of any other financially impactful


activity on their part.


 


      Part 2: The Plot Thickens


 


      Three weeks later, the Internal Audit Department received a telephonecall from a local repair shop owner who was working on a personal computer


brought in from the public library for warranty repair. However, the box in


which the personal computer was delivered had a shipping address for the


university. There was even a bill of lading in the shipping envelope showing


the university as the ordering party and referencing a university purchase


order number. After verifying the information as factual, one of the internal


auditors contacted the library director, and they met later in the day to


determine how the personal computer had come to be in a box destined for


the university.


 


      The library director told the internal auditor that the library had been


working with a university employee who owned a consulting company called


MCS (Micro-computing Consulting Services). In addition, the library


director indicated that the library had ordered several personal computers and


printers from MCS, as well as the associated software, and had paid the


consultant for the products and his fine service.


 


      Required:


 


      1)              At what point should the Internal Audit Department suspect a


fraud? What actions should be considered to ensure that professional auditingstandards are met? Whom does the Internal Audit Department need to


inform?


 


      The first hint of fraud was that the MCS’s sales- and purchase-records


were so poor. The first relatively definitive indication of fraud was that a


computer that was supposedly the director’s ‘personal’ property was


delivered to the library in official university packaging and with official


university documentation. The fact that the ‘consulting’ company in question


had the same initials as the Microcomputer Store (MCS), though not proof of


fraud, is consistent with it, since it suggests that a deliberate effort was being


made to provide a pre-emptive explanation incriminating data.


 


      2) What red flags might have initially tipped off the internal auditors


that this employee might be involved in a fraud?


 


      The computer that was delivered to the library clearly belonged to the


university, showing that the MCS director was guilty of at least one case of


selling university property for personal profit, and the fact that the source of


this computer had an ongoing business relationship with the university was a


strong indication he was doing this on a consistent basis.


  


      2)              In what ways does the MCS manager fit the profile of the


typical fraud perpetrator?


 


      This was an ongoing pattern of fraud, not a single incident; and it is


difficult to carry out large-scale fraud without having a professional position


that makes it possible and without having the personality-traits involved in


being willing to capitalize on such an opportunity. The MCS-director was


obviously in a good position to perpetrate this fraud—especially so since,


when he was doing so, the computer-business was still young and people,


including auditors, were not yet alive to its financial implications. Also, he


was indeed enterprising, as is evidenced by his creating a consulting


company to serve as a cover for the fraud; and he was cunning, as is


evidenced by his giving his consulting company the same name as MCS. He


was in a position to commit the fraud, he had the intelligence to recognize the


opportunity to commit fraud, and he had the requisite streak of amorality. In


these respects, he was indeed representative of the typical white-collar


fraudster.


 


      Part 3: The Fraud Audit


       The auditors then began to try to uncover the full extent of the


suspected fraud. Department orders for computers, printers and software were


traced to purchases, to sales records and to billing receipts. The Internal Audit


Department even worked directly with computer manufacturers to identify


the serial numbers of all personal computers and printers shipped to the


university in the previous 18 months. The vendors provided all sales records


to assist in the audit, but were unable to provide serial numbers for the


computers shipped to the university.


 


      Tracking sales to campus departments proved to be worthwhile, as


three employees stated that they had made personal purchases from the MCS


manager acting in his “professional capacity.” The employees provided


canceled checks for the purchases, made payable to MCS. The Internal Audit


Department was able to trace some equipment serial numbers back to the


actual university purchase orders and bills of lading. After ten weeks of work,


the Internal Audit Department’s report revealed that they could not account in


full for purchases exceeding $140,000 that had been ordered by MCS, for


which the university had paid the vendors. They also confirmed that


equipment worth slightly more than $14,500 had been ordered and paid for


by the university, but had never been recorded as sold, yet was in the


personal custody of people and organizations who sincerely believed thatthey had bought the equipment from the university. The university did have a


policy for MCS that stated there were to be no sales of hardware, software or


peripheral devices to any private party for personal use; sales were to be


made only to the campus departments for university-related work use.


 


      Required:


 


      1)              What should have been the key points of the audit/fraud


investigation report? What supportable audit conclusions could be drawn?


 


      There are three key facts. First, the MCS-director was generating huge


sales but was unable to account for more than a small fraction of these sales,


suggesting that he was simply pocketing the difference. Second, there were


multiple verified cases of his failing to record to sales that he personally


made and therefore knew of. Third, the MCS-director created a ‘shell'


company to facilitate off-the-books sales of university-owned computers.


These three facts should have been the focus of the investigation report.


 


      2)              What additional steps might have been taken by the Internal


Audit Department or Fraud Examiner to uncover evidence regarding the


existence and the extent of the suspected fraud? 


      The auditors would have had an easier time proving their case if they


had subpoenaed the financial records of the MCS-director's consulting


business. Because he was stealing from the university, the records that he


kept in his capacity as a university employee were poor. But it is a distinct


possibility that his consulting business's records were good, given that he


probably wanted to know how much ‘business' he was doing and given also


that, as he likely knew, he would probably have good financial records to


explain to the IRS, in the event of an audit, why he had made purchases far in


excess of what his $18,000/year university permitted. Such records would


have been a ‘smoking gun.’ That said, they already had several smoking


guns: one for each proven case of his selling university-merchandise off the


books.


 


      3)              What evidence is needed to prove a case of fraud?


 


      Fraud is simply the use of deception to acquire assets to which one has


no legal claim. In this case, proving fraud involved proving that the MCS-


director was using deception to sell university property. This was in fact


proved. The MCS director deliberately created a company whose sole


purpose was to facilitate, and give the appearance of legitimacy to, thetransfer of university-owned computers and the proceeds from the sales


thereof to his person. He also kept obviously fraudulent records.


 


      Part 4: Closure


 


      After extensive discussions with the administration, the university


attorney, the state attorney general (because the university was a public


institution), and the local county attorney, a decision was made not to


criminally prosecute because the attorneys believed the evidence was not


sufficient to obtain a conviction in court. Therefore, the university attempted


to contact the former MCS manager, now living across the country, to see if a


confession and partial restitution could be arranged. After weeks of telephone


calls back and forth, and relentless pressure from the Internal Audit


Department trying to determine the full extent of the fraud, the former MCS


manager hired a local attorney to work with the university to clear his name.


After fully reviewing the Internal Audit Department’s working papers, the


local attorney recommended to his client that restitution in the amount of


$14,500 be provided to the university, with no admission of guilt.


 


      The university did insist on including a summary letter of the situation


in the personnel file of the former employee. All parties agreed to theseconditions, restitution was paid to the university, and the personnel file was


appropriately documented. Shortly after the MCS manager had moved across


the country, he applied for a job with the National Security Council. Three


weeks after the summary letter had been included in his personnel file, a


representative


      of the National Security Council telephoned the university to ensure


that its new employee, the former MCS manager, could receive top-security


clearance. As a result of the evidence contained in the documented personnel


file, the Internal Audit Department was advised soon afterwards that the


clearance was denied and the job offer to the former MCS manager was


withdrawn.


 


 


      Required:


 


      1) Do you think the university should have brought criminal charges


against the MCS manager? Why or why not? Besides the reason of


insufficient evidence, why might a company be unwilling to prosecute a


suspected fraud perpetrator?


 


      The university should have pursued a criminal against the MCS-director. There are several possible reasons for their not doing this. First, the


fact that this fraud happened makes the university's management look


incompetent. A related point is that the university's prestige would have taken


a hard, and well deserved, fall had this matter gone public. Also, universities,


even public ones, charge their students hefty fees, and students and parents


might have questioned the legitimacy of those fees if it turned out that


university-assets were being looted by university employees. Finally, if


charges had been filed, it might have created opened the door to intense


financial scrutiny of the university, and it might not have been able to


withstand such scrutiny. Suppose it turned out, as it might well have, that


several university departments were unable to account for their large sums


they had been by the university. In that case, the state might have investigated


and might have concluded that, in giving state-money to financially


irresponsible departments, the university’s management was criminally


negligent. Unless an organization is certain that its financials are in order, it is


likely to not to escalate scrutiny of its financials, this being why many


organizations, including this one, decline to prosecutor fraudsters in their


own midst.


 


      3)              What other work remains to be done by the internal auditors to


bring this case to a close? 


      The auditors have already done a decent job of determining how much


the MCS-director stole from the university. At this point, their job is


preventative in nature. They and the university need to figure out how to


prevent future frauds like this from occurring. This means that they have to


come up with well-defined protocols relating to financials-records and funds-


requisitions. It also means that they have to identify the various kinds of


fraud that the university’s structure makes it possible to perpetrate; and


having done this, they have to figure out how to close off these opportunities


for fraud. Doing the latter is likely to involve subjecting requests for money


on the part of university departments and employees to extra scrutiny and to


require them to keep good financial records of activities on their part


involving university-assets. It may also involve setting up a full-time internal


‘financial task force’, whose sole function is to police the financial behavior


of university departments and employees.


 


 


      4)              A confession by the MCS manager would have made this an


“open-and-shut” case. Should the internal auditors have tried harder to obtain


a confession, perhaps by relying more upon the university’s legal counsel and


law enforcement officers in the investigation? 


 


      Given that the university did not wish to pursue this as a criminal


matter, they were not in a position to try much harder to elicit a confession.


First of all, the employee had already ‘lawyered up', limiting what the


auditors could do in the way of extracting information, including a


confession, from him. Also, if the auditors had decided to pursue this matter


more aggressively, they would have to have had to have involved the police,


which, for the previously stated reasons, they could not have done without


subjecting themselves to unwanted scrutiny.


 


      4) Fraud researchers have coined the phrase “fraud triangle” to


describe why people commit fraud. The three elements that make up the


fraud triangle are pressure, perceived opportunity and rationalization; all


three must be present for a fraud to occur. The pressure provides the motive


to commit the fraud, and usually involves financial need. The opportunity


typically presents itself in the form of weak or nonexistent internal controls.


Fraud perpetrators must believe that they will be able to commit the fraud and


remain undetected. Finally, fraud perpetrators must be able to rationalize or


justify their fraudulent actions as morally acceptable.


       One of the most common rationalizations is that the fraud perpetrator


will pay back the stolen funds, so that the perpetrator is only “borrowing” the


money for the moment. Apply the fraud triangle to this case and describe the


pressure, perceived opportunity and rationalization that were present and that


allowed the MCS manager to commit his fraud.


 


 


      The MCS-director almost certainly had no intention whatsoever of


paying back the university. This was not a case of somebody making a


mistake and then using fraud to cover up his mistake. This is a case of


somebody who set to steal from the university, did so, and then went to great


lengths, including setting up a shell company, to expand his operation. So


although the MCS-director almost certainly did have a rationalization, it was


not almost certainly not that particular one. We can only guess what his


rationalization, but I suspect that, as a university employee, he told himself


that he was merely properly allocating funds that the university had


misallocated. Universities spend enormous amounts of money on


questionable endeavors, such as sports teams and dorm-room renovations,


and the like; and they also hemorrhage money through bloated internal


bureaucracies. The MCS-director was likely aware of this and told himself


that, in keeping a little off-the-books university money for himself, he wasmerely putting money that the university would otherwise have wasted to


good use.


      The other two components of the fraud triangle are easily accounted


for in his case. The employee in question was clearly under financial


pressure, as his $18,000/year salary was probably not even sufficient to cover


basic living expenses, let alone to subsidize luxury-expenses. As for


opportunity, the employee’s position made it possible for him to sell


university-assets and keep the proceeds, and he was assisted in this by the


university’s slipshod attention to its own finances.


 


                                     The Olympus Fraud


 


      This week is focused on financials statement fraud. You will review


the fraud at Olympus. Please review the articles, fraud report, video, and


conduct your own research to address the following questions:


 


      1.            What fraud schemes were used by Olympus?


 


      The main fraud scheme was tobashi, this being the Japanese term for


concealment of losses. Starting in the late '80s, Olympus invested heavily in


other companies, sometimes by buying them outright. At first, this worked


well; but starting in the early '90s, these investments became losers. Rather


than cutting its losses, Olympus doubled down by making additional, highly


speculative investments. These investments became losers, and Olympus


responded by tripling down---with this new round of investments also


resulting in losses for the company. Instead of coming clean with the public


and with regulators, Olympus decided to hide the losses. It did this by setting


up shell companies to whom it pretended to sell these investments at values


far higher than their actual value. To this end, Olympus set up arrangements


with other parties to front them the money for these pseudo-sales, on the


condition that it be returned, along with a convenience fee. Also, in itsfinancial statements, Olympus recorded the values of its investments at their


initial price, i.e. at the prices when first purchased, instead of at their current,


much lower value. Moreover, in an attempt to put a benign face on the


company, Olympus hired a ‘ringer’ CEO, Michael Wolford, whom they


believed, incorrectly, would neither know about the fraud nor care. Finally, in


its financial statements, Olympus over-represented their intangible assets, i.e.


their goodwill-to-assets ratio.


 


      2.            What is your opinion of Michael Wolford?


 


      Michael Wolford clearly behaved honestly in this context. He knew


that something was wrong and he blew the whistle on Olympus by going to


the British authorities and also by going to the media.


 


      3.            What role did the Japanese media/culture play/or not play in


revealing this case? (would it be different in the US)


 


      When approached by Wolford, the Japanese media refused to cover


the story. In effect, they ‘buried’ it. This allowed the fraud to continue for a


while. More importantly, the fraud probably would not have been possible, at


least not on such a large scale, except in a culture in which the media couldbe expected to ‘play ball’, as the Japanese media did.


 


      4.            How was the fraud uncovered?


 


      As the CEO, albeit a strawman CEO, Michael Wolford did have


access to financial data and to information about ongoing, in particular, the


purchase, at a suspiciously high price, of a medical supplies firm. Wolford


noticed that he was rebuffed when he sounded the alarm to other Olympus


executives. When his inquiries did not cease, Wolford was fired and went to


the British authorities.


 


      5.            What role did the auditors play? Should they be liable?


 


      The auditors, both internal and external, failed utterly to report the


fraud. There was either collusion or extreme incompetence---probably the


former. Although the auditors did not face criminal liability, the Olympus


scandal prompted Japanese lawmakers to tighten regulations on auditors.


 


      6.            What role did Olympus' corporate culture play in this fraud?


 


        Japanese corporate culture, like Japanese culture in general, greatlyvalues stability and not rocking the boat. In American culture, there is a


certain grudging respect for rebels and whistleblowers, who can often expect


some degree of sympathy even they before they have fully proven their own


legitimacy. Not so in Japanese culture, especially corporate culture, in which


not ‘rocking the boat’ is seen almost as an end unto itself. This obviously


allowed the fraud at Olympus to continue for longer it might otherwise have.


All of this said, there is plenty of fraud in American firms; and much as


Americans might like to perceive themselves as cowboys, they too tend to


fall in light with malfeasance, at least in authoritarian settings, such as


corporations.


 


      7.            What was the final outcome of the case?


 


      The Chairman of Olympus, Tsuyoshi Kikukawa, was given a three-


year sentence, as was Hideo Yamada, another executive involved in the


fraud. A third executive, Hisashi Mori, was given a two- and half-year


sentence. In court, Kikukawa took full responsibility for the fraud. IN the


immediate aftermath of the case, Olympus lost 80% of its value, but quickly


rebounded to its pre-scandal value. 


      The Dixon Fraud


 


Submit a 1-2 page paper that discusses what red flags were present in the


Dixon fraud. How did the auditors miss the red flags? How did the


Whistleblower uncover it?


 

                                                      [69]
      There were several red flags in this case. First of all, while


Crundwell was comptroller, the city of Dixon was constantly short of money.


As a result, Dixon police were not able to upgrade their equipment; Dixon


employees who were overdue for raises did not get them; Dixon employees


were fired; and, most strikingly, streets in Dixon were not adequately


maintained. Dixon was constantly running a deficit of millions of dollars---an


excessive amount for a municipality of 15,000, especially given the hefty


yearly pay-outs it received from the State of Illinois.


        Crundwell explained this by lying about these pay-outs, claiming that


they were much smaller than they actually were. But suspicions should have


been aroused.


      Another red flag was that Crundwell, a city employee with a low five-


figure salary, was able to bankroll a huge horse-breeding operation, owned


several properties and several luxury cars.      A third red flag was that Crundwell did Dixon’s banking off-line,


through paper statements. This should have been a red flag to anyone who


knew of it. It was known to Swanson, who did put the pieces together, albeit


rather belatedly.


      Also, the bank in question, Fifth Third Bank, was a local bank, and it


should have known that there was something suspicious about a city


comptroller depositing large sums in a personal account.


      If Dixon City financials were audited during Crundwell’s time as


comptrollers, those audits were far from thorough. The State of Illinois is


presumably supposed to conduct such audits, and the fact that it didn’t is


perhaps the most important fact here. The money that Crundwell embezzled


was, after all, Illinois-state money, and the State of Illinois should have


verified that the funds it was giving to Dixon were being appropriately used.


It did not verify this.


      It is unclear whether anyone in Dixon complained to the State of


Illinois about Dixon’s financial problems. If they didn’t, they should have.


      Rita Crundwell is a sociopath who was defrauding Dixon out of


millions. Such people exist and may even be drawn to positions of financial


responsibility, such as City Comptroller. It is incumbent on others, especially


other officials, to alert the authorities, in this case the State of Illinois, of their


concerns. In this case, those concerns were deep: questionable layoffs of cityemployees, overdue raises, and problems replacing police equipment and


maintaining roads. Given only the information contained in the three articles


that I read, it is unclear how all of this went on for so long. Presumably, it


was because people in a small town like Dixon were slower than people from


big cities to suspect criminal activity, and it was possible that people in


Dixon, including police officers and other officials, were personal


acquaintances with Crundwell, sometimes even having grown up with her,


and were slow to believe that ‘one of their own’ could have committed such a


crime.


      One lesson that I derived from this case study is that subjective


assessments of personality are to be given far less weight in matters relating


to fraud and crime generally than are hard facts, especially hard financial


facts.


 


             Multinationals in Relation to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in


                                        Relation


 


      Part 1


 


      Dear Mr. Marshall,


 


      The FCPA is the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The FCPA was


enacted in 1977, and its purpose is to prevent Americans from engaging in


corrupt businesses practices in foreign countries. The primary purpose of the


FCPA is to prevent Americans doing business abroad from bribing public


officials or using their situation to engage in practices, such as money-


laundering, that would be prohibited in the United States. Under the FCPA,


an American doing business in India, for example, breaking American law by


bribing an Indian official, even if his act is tolerated or even encouraged in


India.


      There are two components to the FCPA. The one component prohibits


Americans doing business in a given foreign country from bribing officials in


that country. The other component requires Americans doing business in a


given country to be extremely transparent about their financial dealings in


that country. They must keep records of all transactions and must neverfalsify or obfuscate those transactions. Additionally, financial records must


not only be accurate, but must also make it easy for auditors to understand the


nature of the transactions recorded. The purpose of the second component of


the second component is to prevent the concealment of bribery or other


corrupt financial transactions. The insistence on easy-to-understand records is


to prevent Americans from using aspects of their situation that would be


unfamiliar to American auditors as a way of concealing acts of corruption.


For example, it would prevent the use of locally but not generally accepted


accounting principles, and it would also prevent the use of local argot to


record transactions.


      India is a country of over 1 billion people. Its economy is rapidly


growing, and there are many economic opportunities there, both for Indians


and for non-Indians. However, there are two serious problems facing people


attempting to business in India. One problem is that the Indian government’s


behavior with respect to businesses in India tends to be extremely corrupt. It


is very much the norm for Indian officials to extort bribes from businesses in


exchange for the right to continuing doing business. The other problem is that


the businesses in Indian are extremely regulated. Businesses must remain in


compliance with a byzantine network of regulations, and this involves time,


energy, and money. Oftentimes, the simplest way for businesses to stay on


the right side of this bureaucracy is to bribe government officials.      That said, American businesses are prosecuted for violating FCPA,


and it is not an option to attempt to circumvent it. This has several


implications for Americans, such as yourself, who wish to do business in


India. The first is that operating expenses are likely to be higher than initially


estimated, because compliance expenses are going to be dramatically higher


than they would be in the United States. Another implication is that you must


operate on the assumption that people in your organization are likely to


violate FCPA provisions, given how lucrative and convenient such violations


can be, and you must be aware of the ways that FCPA-violators falsify


records to conceal acts of bribery. It is less likely that numbers will be


doctored than it is that acts of bribery will be recorded as legitimate business

                        [70]
expenses, for example:


 


      *Travel expenses


        *Consultant fees


        *Entertainment expenses


      *Sales and marketing costs


      *Vendor or supplier payments


        *Discounts or rebates


      *Post-sale service fees


        *Commissions, and        *Write-offs.


 


      Thus, if a given official is bribed, it may be recorded that he was a


consultant who was appropriately compensated. Or the official might have


been bribed with a vacation or with entertainment services, instead of with


cash.


      What these items have in common is that they tend to be vague.


Consulting services, unlike purchases of machinery or land, do not lead to a


verifiable product; and neither do any of the other items listed above.


      The list above is not complete, but it makes it relatively clear how


financials are likely to be distorted to cloak FCPA-violations.


      If any of these items, or any other hard-to-verify items, are unusually


prominent in financial records, FCPA-violations are likely and the matter


should be investigated. Verifying that FCPA-violations have occurred tends


to be difficult, but your objective is not so much to prove the existence of


such violations as it is to pre-empt such violations, which you can do by


treating suspicious financials as evidence of such violations and appropriately


discharging suspected violators while also conducting vigorous internal


audits and setting up a safe and easy way for people to blow the whistle on


FCPA-violations.


       Part II


 


      The case I will discuss involves Walmart’s Mexican subsidiary.


Starting in 2005, Walmart-Mexico began paying large sums to Mexican


officials for licenses to expand within Mexico. The total amount of these


bribes is estimated to be $24 million. The bribes continued until 2011. They


came to end because of an inside whistle-blower, not because of pressure


from either Mexican or American officials. As soon as Walmart became


aware of the situation, it sent in internal auditors to determine exactly what


had happened, and it presented its findings to the US Department of Justice.


        Walmart-investors brought a class-action lawsuit against Walmart, and


in October 2018, Walmart agreed to them $160 million dollars. The SEC


approved the settlement.


      Thus far, the situation has cost Walmart over $900 million dollars. In


addition to the just-mentioned $160 million, Walmart spent over $700 to


ensure that its foreign subsidiaries be FCPA-compliant.


      In September 2016, US prosecutors agreed to drop the case against


Walmart if Walmart paid a fine of $600 million. Walmart declined. Since


then, the case has been in prosecutorial limbo, and there has been no


prosecutorial outcome thus far.


        According to some, this is because President Trump, who is stronglypro-business, does not want to discourage American business with what


might be regarded as unnecessary prosecution of an extremely successful


American retailer. During Trump’s presidency, the Justice department has


sent mixed messages on the matter. On the one hand, Attorney General Jeff


Sessions has said (though not in connection with Walmart specifically) that


he is reluctant to let law-breakers off the hook by granting them DPA’s


(Deferred Prosecution Agreement) or NPA’s (Non-prosecution Agreements).


At the same time, white collar prosecutions under Trump have plummeted,


the reason being, as Trump himself explicitly states, that he does not want to


discourage business and he wants to reserve prosecutorial resources for


violent offenses, drug offenses, and immigration-related offenses. Also,


Trump has expressed his contempt for the FCPA, saying that it hamstrings


American businesses.


      It is a matter of speculation how the case will be resolved, but it is my


opinion extremely unlikely that Walmart will be prosecuted. Walmart is a


major American retailer and employs many Americans; and because of its


low costs, wide selection, and high quality it is much beloved by American


consumers. Trump knows that if he were to prosecute Walmart for FCPA


violations, it would undermine his pro-business message.


      If this is in fact Trump’s reasoning, it is highly defensible reasoning. It


is easy to reside in one country and sit in judgment of the practices in anothercountry. It is in the United States to condemn somebody in India or Mexico


who bribes an official. But businesses operate on thin margins, and


obstreperous officials in a given country can easily drive a business into a


oblivion with paperwork, fines, and the like. Oftentimes, FCPA-violations


involve cases of somebody bribing an official to do something that he could


automatically do in the United States. This appears to be what was happening


with Walmart-Mexico. Walmart-Mexico wanted to open new stores. Mexican


officials were blocking it, supposedly on regulatory grounds, but possibly


because they were waiting for bribes. The American legal system works


reasonably well, but the legal systems of other countries may not work as


well, especially in connection with American business-interests in their


countries. I would therefore suggest that American prosecutors use discretion


when prosecuting FCPA-cases.


        Oftentimes, regulatory requirements are used as a way of extorting


under the table payments. A regulatory in India or Mexico makes a fraction


of what his US counterpart makes, and it is to be expected that he may make


up the difference by extorting money from businesses under his thumb. It is


easy to judge people who give or receive bribes, but in some contexts it is not


realistic to expect strict compliance on anyone’s part with the law. FCPA


seems to make good moral sense, but it make dubious economic sense. Given


that American businesses are likely to violate it and given that unenforceablelaws generate contempt for the law, I would personally suggest softening


FCPA.


                                       The ARCP Fraud


 


      Pick a recent financial statement fraud that has been in the news. Post


your chosen company to the discussion board, if someone has already chosen


that company, then choose another. Write a 2 page paper detailing the fraud:


how did it happen, how was it detected, what controls were lacking, how


could it have been prevented or detected sooner.


 


      In June 2017, Brian Block, CFO (Chief Financial Officer) of ARCP


(American Realty Capital properties) was convicted of using fraudulent


financial statements to exaggerate the success of the company’s holdings.


Block’s presumed reason for doing this was to inflate the price of ARCP’s


shares and also to attract private investors.


      ARCP is a real estate investment trust (REIT), meaning that it makes


money by owning or financing income-producing real estate (meaning rental


or commercial properties). Block’s case involved his using a non-GAAP


measure of performance to exaggerate the values of company holdings. More


precisely, the earning-statements prepared by BLOCK were based on a what


is called AFFO (Adjusted Funds From Operation), AFFO being the measure


typically used to determine the performance of a REIT is known as AFFO.


The formula for AFFO is: 


      AFFO = FFO (Funds from Operations) + rent increases - capital


expenditures - routine maintenance amounts.


 


      The formula for FFO is:


 


      FFO = net income + amortization + depreciation - capital gains from


property sales.


 


      The difference between FFO and AFFO is that AFFO, unlike FFO,


makes allowances for rent increases and capital expenditures. Let ABC be a


REIT. According to AFFO, if the rent on the properties ABC increases but


ABC is otherwise unchanged, then ABC has increased according to AFFO


but has remained the same according to FFO; and if maintenance costs or


capital expenditures for those properties increase, but ABC is otherwise


unchanged, then ABC has lost value according to AFFO but remained the


same according to FFO.


      AFFO is considered by industry insiders to be a more exact measure


than FFO of a REIT’s financial performance. At the same time, AFFO, unlike


FFO, allows money that has not yet been received or spent be considered


when evaluating a REIT. This means that AFFO can be used to inflate ordeflate the value of a REIT, whereas FFO cannot be so used. AFFO therefore


violates the Principle of Conservative Accounting (only count income when


cash has actually been received), this being one of the ten principles of


GAAP, and for this reason is a non-GAAP measure. FFO is a GAAP


financial measure, since it does not violate this or any other GAAP principle.


      Block had promised investors large returns. When those investments


fell short of Block’s promises, he used AFFO to make it appear as though


those investments had performed as promised. ARCP-accountants pointed


out the discrepancy to Block, thinking that he had made an innocent


accounting mistake. Block continued to use AFFO to inflate ARCP’s value.


Moreover, when ARCP’s investments sank so much that Block could no


longer use AFFO alone to cover up the losses, he simply plugged fake


numbers into his mandatory SEC-filings. Block was assisted in these various


cover-ups by Lista McAlister, ARCP’s Chief Accounting Officer. When


investors in ARCP were unable to liquidate their holdings for prices


consistent with the financials prepared by Block, the SEC was brought in and


the gig was up.


        McAlister and Block claimed that they had been instructed by the


company founder and CEO, Nick Schorsch, to perpetrate this fraud. These


accusations have not been substantiated, and Schorsch has not been indicted.


However, Schorsch was forced to resign as CEO; and because of the declinein ARCP’s value caused by this scandal, Schorsch personally lost millions of


dollars.


      Internal auditors were quick to spot the inaccuracies in Block’s


financial statements and cannot be blamed for the debacle. Also, Block had


the support of McAlister and other key personnel at ARCP, who worked


together to mislead or silence internal auditors. Unlike other cases of fraud,


this one was not so much about an absence of internal controls as it is about


an excess of credulity on the part of holders of equity in ARCP. Equity-


holders knew that they financials they were given were prepared using


AFFO, not FFO, and they knew AFFO not to be a GAAP financial measure.


The lesson from this case is less about how organizations should self-police


and more about how consumers should do so. When non-standard metrics are


used, including non-GAAP financial measures, one should know that fraud is


a distinct possibility.


                                 The Basia Skudrzyk Fraud


 


      Use the internet to research a fraud involving one of the schemes


addressed in this week's reading materials. You can use the same scheme you


discussed in the Discussion Board.


      1. Discuss how the fraud was committed.


      2. Discuss controls that could have been in place to deter and detect


this fraud.


      3. How was the fraud detected and what was the outcome?


      4. What were the red flags associated with the scheme?


 


      The case that I will discuss concerns one Barbara “Basia” Skudrzyk,


who on March 7, 2017, was convicted of several counts of fraud in relation to


a lucrative and long-lived personal-purchase scheme that was running at


Washington University, where she was business director for medical


education. Starting in May 2010 continuing right up till her arrest on July 31,


2018, Ms. Skudrzyk used Washington University funds to pay for a wide of


personal range of personal services. She did this by creating, submitting, and


approving false invoices and W2-forms, thereby making it appear as though


the various services purchased were for work done for and at Washington


University. In actuality, each and every one of the services purchases was forher personally. Skudrzyk used the funds to pay for contractors and a


construction company for services performed on her home, a moving


company, a house cleaning service, housepainters, babysitters for her


children, and a divorce lawyer.


      Skudrzyk also purchased Visa gift cards at the Campus Bookstore by


forging another Washington University employee’s signature. She used the


Visa cards for personal purchases. Finally, Skudrzyk got Washington


University to pay for trips for herself and her family. She did this altering


invoices from airlines and hotels, then submitting them to the Division of


Medical Education and approving them.


      In all, Skudrzyk defrauded Washington University of over $400,000.


She was caught not because internal auditors took note, but because the


employee whose signature she was forging received a routine financial


statement saying that he had spent $35,000 of dollars on Visa gift cards. That


employee complained, and auditors were then dispatched.


      There were many red flags. Every invoice submitted by Ms. Skudrzyk


was a red flag. But the only red flag that wasn’t ignored was the routine


financial statement given to the employee whose signature was forged. All


the rest---the five-figure invoices for work that clearly was not being done—


did not even raise an eyebrow.


      The reason for this lies in 


        University departments and divisions are enormously wealthy.


University employees do not typically earn as much as investment bankers or


high-powered attorneys, but they have access to enormous amounts of


money, owing to the extremely wide of range of educational, recreational,


and research-related services provided by a university. Many universities,


including Washington University, are technically private. But their modus


operandi is nothing like that of a business. Businesses compete for


businesses, each trying to better products and services for less money than its


rivals. For this reason, margins are thin and businesses have to be extremely


aware of what they are doing with their own money. Universities are not in a


comparable position. They constantly receive extremely large government


grants and subsidies, and they also benefit from the enormous prestige and


status that universities have, leading to a constant influx of tuition-money,


most of which is financed by government loans. Consequently, universities


can be financially inefficient with relative impunity.


      Skudrzyk knew how loosely money was spent at her institution and


knew how large the sums were, and she saw an opportunity to cash in. As the


head of the Medical Education Division, Skudrzyk knew how much funding


her division could requisition from the university without arousing suspicion.


She also knew what kinds of services universities pay for and was thereforeable to dummy up convincing invoices. Finally, she knew how bureaucratic


and inefficient her university was when it comes to verifying that work paid


for was actually done.


        Washington University could have prevented this disaster by


regularly, aggressively auditing its various departments. The problem with


this proposal is that university expenses tend to be extremely opaque.


Professors are given six-month leaves of absence to write five-page articles;


speakers are paid tens of thousands of dollars to give lectures that virtually


nobody attends; various studies and other forms of research are paid for, the


legitimacy of which is not easy to verify since much of it concerns topics that


are comprehensible only to discipline-insiders. Finally, universities are


supposed to be bastions of culture and thought; they are supposed to be


places where scholars and artists-in-residence and the like can live ‘the life of


the mind’ without being subjected to close financial scrutiny. Goodyear and


McDonalds are willing to have regular, aggressive internal audits, because


their very purpose is to provide well-defined products and services at


minimal cost. Universities are about ‘exploring ideas’, and the like, and


therefore inherently averse to the kind of internal auditing on which any


ordinary business depends.


      We must also remember that when the government goes after a


fraudster, it usually does so because of complaints from customers. The SECgoes after the likes of Bernie Madoff when people complain to it. In the case


of universities, who would be doing the complaining? There are no


shareholders; nor are there investors. So there is no obvious demand for


accountability. Universities therefore don’t have nearly as much of an


incentive as businesses to be mindful of their own financial conduct. And


granting that Washington University could have avoided Skudrzyk-debacle


had it had regular, meaningful internal audits, it did not have the same kind of


incentive as a business to subject itself to such scrutiny.


      That said, if students were given university financial statements---if


they were given documents making it clear exactly how much their university


was spending and what it was spending it on—students would likely begin to


put terrific pressure on universities to self-audit. But for whatever reason—it


may be the mystique universities or it may be the government-backed student


loans---neither students nor their parents demand such financial transparency


of universities. If a given university wished to eliminated expense-padding


and financial fraud in its midst, the way for it do so is to make its own


financials transparent to the people who care—the students and their parents.


Until that happens, we cannot expect universities to scrutinize their own


finances with the same vigor as a business.


                                   The Liberty Bell Fraud


 


      Read the Liberty Bell Hospital case and answer the discussion


questions (on pages 4 and 5 of the case). What factors contributed to this


opportunity to commit fraud?


 


      Matt Harris was hired (albeit as a part-time independent contractor)


without having to undergo a background investigation. A background


investigation might well have revealed a history of fraud or malfeasance,


given that he was fired from his last job. Also, Matt Harris probably


shouldn’t have been hired in the first place, at least not with a thorough


review of his employment record, given that he had just been fired from a


similar position at another organization. Other candidates besides Matt Harris


should have been interviewed for his first position. When Matt Harris was


asked to apply for the full-time position, his record should have been


scrutinized, especially since it involved more responsibility than the previous


position.


 


      What breakdowns in internal control could have been improved so that


this fraud could have been prevented?


       Matt Harris’s vendor account should have been deleted as soon as he


was given the full-time position. He no longer needed a vendor account, and


his having such an account gave him access to sensitive information.


      The CFO should have listened to Alan Walters when Walters


cautioned him about the fact that Harris was a nepotism-hire. Harris should


not have been given access to the safe containing pre-signed checks. When


Downs went on vacation, a more senior person, not a less senior person,


should have been given responsibility for handling the disbursements usually


handled by Downs.


 


      Other than Matt Harris, who bears some responsibility for this fraud?


 


      Tracy Downs, Accounts Payable Manager, bears responsibility since


she violated LBH's policy on nepotism-based hires, did not do a background


check on Matt Harris, did not interview other candidates for the position, and


also did not delete Harris’s vendor account when he took the full-time


position.


      Elinor Linz, Assistant Accounts Payable Manager, bears responsibility


since she did not delete Harris’s vendor account.


      Alan Smith, CFO, bears responsibility since he allowed Harris to


continue to work at LBH, despite knowing that Harris was a nepotism-hire.      Sharon Harris bears responsibility since she recommended her son,


Matt Harris, for the contractor position, knowing that she was violating


LHB’s nepotism-policy and also possibly knowing of fraud in her son’s


background.


 


      Did the Alan Walters, Internal Audit Manager do the right thing?
