      Yes. He alerted the CFO to the fact that hiring Harris was a violation


of company policy, and he also successfully carried out the investigation of


Harris’s fraud, with the end result being a confession on Harris’s part.


 


      Explain how general computer controls and application level controls


could have helped prevent and detect this fraud?


 


      Harris’s vendor account should have been automatically deleted once


it was no longer inactive. Also, if the company had made payments


electronically, instead of through physical checks, this would not have


happened, at least not in this way. By 2003, electronic payments were already


the norm. Additionally, the system should (and could) have been set up to


automatically bar anyone with a vendor’s account from having access to safes


containing checks or other securities, given that anyone with a vendor’saccount can, in effect, send such checks to himself.


                               A Hypothetical Skimming Case


 


      You have just been hired as a Fraud Examiner to investigate an


employee of Ace Auto Supplies store suspected of skimming a percentage of


cash payments made on a daily basis. The employee is a Parts Manager and is


believed to be skimming a portion of all parts sales where cash is used as the


method of payment. The parts are ordered by the customer and the invoice is


generated, which is logged into the system. The parts inventory is adjusted


based on sales entered into the system. The Parts Mgr is responsible for


turning over all sales (cash, check, credit) to the cashier at the end of the day.


The cashier reconciles the total sales for the day to the checks, cash and sales


on credit. The cashier submits the paperwork to Ace's accountant who


prepares a bank deposit slip and deposits the amount based on daily sales.


There is also concern that the accountant is skimming cash before depositing


the amount into the bank at the end of each day.


      Prepare a memo to the Owner of the Auto Dealership covering the


following:


 


      1. Investigative steps needed


      2. Evidence required to prove the fraud


      3. List of interviewees      4. List some questions you would consider asking


 


      Re: Possible Fraud (Cash Skimming)


      To whom It May Concern:


 


      My understanding is that you suspect that two kinds of fraud—


specifically, cash skimming---are being committed within your organization.


As you have described the situation to me, it is possible that the two alleged


fraudsters are colluding, but it is possible that they are not. It is also possible,


and in fact likely, that if there is in fact fraud, three parties are involved in it.


It is possible that these parties are operating independently of one another; it


is also possible that they are colluding.


      I will now identify the steps you must take to verify that fraud is in


fact occurring, along with the steps that you must take if it turns out that


fraud is occurring. If fraud is occurring, these steps will enable you to


determine whether there is collusion among the parties involved.


      I will begin by describing the two fraud schemes that you believe to be


occurring, along with some relevant background facts. Your store sells auto


parts, and you believe that a Parts Manager is skimming some of the money


from cash-sales of those auto parts. Whenever a sale is made, the parts


inventory is duly adjusted. At the end of each workday, the Parts Managerhas to turn over all sales (cash, checks, and credit) to the cashier, who


reconciles said sales to total sales (sold goods multiplied by their prices). The


cashier then submits the paperwork to an accountant, who deposits the


amount of daily sales into the business's bank account.


      For each day falling within the time period during which you suspect


that fraud was being committed, start with that day’s total sales (goods sold


times their prices. Then subtract cash, check, and credit sales from that


number. The amount should be zero. If it is greater than zero, the next step is


to rule out simple accounting errors. To do this, make sure go over each


credit card sale, and make sure that the appropriate amount was charged for


the item in question, and do the same with check sales. If those amounts are


correct, then some of the cash from sales is indeed missing, and cash is


indeed being skimmed.


      That said, we don’t know who is skimming that cash. It could be the


Parts Manager or the Cashier or both. Moreover, they could either be


colluding or operating independently. Below we will discuss how to


determine who is skimming how much.


      If cash has been skimmed thus far in the process, it is still possible that


the accountant is skimming. At the same time, the accountant may be


skimming if no cash has been skimmed. Either way, the same method is used


to determine whether or not the accountant is skimming: simply compare thecashier’s daily statement to the amount that the accountant deposits. If


deposits fall short, then the accountant is skimming.


      The method just used deals with past cases of skimming. It is also


recommended that you perform a ‘sting’, so as to prove the existence of an


on-going act of fraud. Two separate stings would have to be conducted. The


first would involve taking daily sales directly from the Parts Manager and


comparing them against total sales. If cash sales fall short, then the Parts


Manager is skimming. The second sting would involve taking sales directly


from the Parts Manager, comparing them to total sales, then passing them


along to the Cashier without letting the Cashier know that the sales have


already been audited. If the Cashier’s daily report is off, then the Cashier is


skimming.


      If properly conducted, these stings would make it clear exactly who


was skimming how much, and this information would be very useful when


interviewing fraud-suspects. Let us now turn to this topic.


      There are three possible suspects, as we have discussed. If the Parts


Manager is skimming, the Cashier knows it, since the Cashier’s job is to


check the Parts Manager’s receipts against Total Sales. At the same time, the


Cashier could be skimming without the Parts Manager being aware of it.


Further, if either the Parts Manager or the Cashier are skimming, the


Accountant wouldn’t necessarily know it, since the cashier’s paperwork is theonly source of information that he has about sales. Finally, if the accountant


is skimming, neither the Parts Manager nor the Cashier necessarily knows


about it.


      When interviewing, it is best to have as much knowledge as possible.


The ideal situation is to prove that fraud is being committed and to know who


is responsible for what part of that fraud; and unless the accountant is the


only person skimming, the only way to have this knowledge is to conduct the


previously described stings.


      If it is known exactly who is skimming how much, then the questions


the fraud examiner would ask might include:


      How long has this been going on?


      Does anyone else know about it?


      What led you to do this? Were you unhappy with your position or


compensation?


      Are you willing or able to make reparations, so as to minimize civil


and criminal liability?


 


      If you are interviewing one of the three parties, ask questions about the


possible roles of the other two; for example, if interviewing the Parts


Manager, you might ask:


       Does the Cashier know about what you are doing?


      Who came up with the idea, you or him?


      What about the accountant? What is his role in this?


 


        Variations of these questions could be asked when interviewing the


other two parts.


      If it is not known exactly who is doing what, questions have to be


chosen more delicately. You might want to include general questions, along


the lines of:


 


      Are you aware that cash from sales cannot be accounted for?


      Do you know who might be responsible?


      Do you feel that you might have opened the door to skimming on


someone else’s part?


      Are you on good terms with that other person?


      If you could return the money in exchange for legal immunity, would


you be able to do so?


      Is there any way that you can help us prove your innocence in this


matter?


      Are there any loopholes in the system that you are aware of that might


allow people to skim?      Would you be willing to help us identify and close them?


      Would you mind if we went over the books with you? There are a


couple of things we'd like you to clear up. Would that be ok?


      Are you aware that if this goes to court, and you are only responsible


for 10% of the fraud, you are still 100% guilty in the eyes of the law?


      You know that once this goes to the police, it’s out of our hands.


Would you be willing to help us minimize your liability? It’s your best bet.


 


      As for evidence, you simply need:


 


      *Sales proceeds submitted by Parts Manager to Cashier


        *Paperwork proceeds submitted by Cashier to Accountant


      *Deposit Slips/Bank Statements


 


      Testimony from interviews may also be helpful, especially if there is


proof of skimming without a clear indication of who is responsible for what


part of it.


       Fraud Risk Factors in a Hypothetical Multinational Company


 


      Answers that exceed 600 words will be penalized.


 


 


      1.            Answer the following questions based on the information


provided below .


      a. What are fraud risk factors?


      1.            Define 5 fraud risk factors for this company.


 


 


      Risk factor #1: This business has multiple accounting systems,


resulting in potential accounting ambiguities that open the door to fraud.


      Risk factor #2: This company has autocratic, centralized management,


coupled with a geographically dispersed employee-pool. Consequently,


employee behavior is unlikely to be adequately monitored. Also, because of


the various different currencies involved, along with the multiplicity of


different kinds of transactions being conducted, the door is open to a variety


of schemes, involving improper asset valuations, off-balance sheet entities


and liabilities, disclosure fraud, and cash-skimming.


      Risk factor #3: Bonus-driven salaries put great pressure on employeesto do whatever they must to earn, including committing fraud.


      Risk factor #4: Autocratic management may cause employees to


dislike management and to find them unapproachable, thereby giving


employees an incentive to ‘rip off’ the company by committing fraud.


      Risk factor #5: Because of the geographically dispersed employee-


pool, different banking procedures are involved, making money laundering


easier than it would be if activities were confined to a single banking system.


Also, given that the company has never done business in Russia, its


attempting to conduct operations there and to employ Russians makes it


vulnerable to employees who can use their knowledge of local customs,


along with their knowledge of company-vulnerabilities, to commit fraud. It


also exposes the company to ‘shakedowns’ by local criminals, putting


Russia-based employees under pressure to defraud the company.


 


 


      2.            Identify one fraud scheme for each risk factor identified in part


b.


 


      Fraud Scheme Corresponding to Risk Factor #1: Assets/inventory can


be overvalued, with the differences between reported and actual values being


skimmed.      Fraud Scheme Corresponding to Risk Factor #2: Centralized,


autocratic management makes it easy for employees to fail to report sales


actually made and pocket the proceeds.


      Fraud Scheme Corresponding to Risk Factor #3: Bonus-driven salaries


may encourage employees to concoct phony investment deals in an effort to


inflate the revenues they are generating for the company.


      Fraud Scheme Corresponding to Risk Factor #4: Remote and


autocratic management may encourage employees to sell company inventory


and claim that it was robbed.


      Fraud Scheme Corresponding to Risk Factor #5: Exposure to Russian


criminal organizations, along with the potential profits from cooperating with


them, may lead to money laundering schemes, along with bribery of local


officials.


 


      b. Describe the benefits of including personnel from various


departments within the company during your fraud risk assessment.


 


      Each department carries its own windows of opportunity for fraud;


and since one won’t know about these unless one knows about each


department, one’s investigation should draw on the knowledge and


cooperation of people in as many departments as possible. 


      Information for Question 1


      You have just been hired as the Fraud Deterrence Specialist for a


small business. The company is expanding into an emerging market in


Russia. See the following facts about the company:


      · They employee 2,000 people worldwide


      · Have very decentralized accounting and procurement processes


      · Managed by an autocratic CEO


      · Executive management salary is paid through salary and bonus. The


bonus potential is significant and driven by earnings per share.


      · Has never employed anyone in Russia before this expansion.


 


      2.            Answer the three questions below:


 


      a.            Describe the “Behavioral Elements of Fraud.”


 


      The behavioral elements of fraud are the personality traits that


fraudsters are likely to have. These include:


      *A weak or flexible moral compass: The fraudster doesn’t have a strict


moral code and can rationalize theft and fraud.


        *Unstable and toxic relations with others: The fraudster is likely tohave associates of ill-repute and to not have long-term stable and healthy


relations.


        *Deceitfulness: The fraudster is likely to be a liar.


      *Arrogance: The fraudster is to believe his needs to be more important


than the law and to believe himself to be smarter than others and also smarter


than ‘the system.’


        *Creativity and cleverness: The fraudster tends to be intelligent and


creative; and he must be both, given that he has to figure out both how to earn


outside the system and to conceal the fact that he is doing so.


 


      b.            How did the culture at Crazy Eddie promote fraud?


 


      The management at Crazy Eddie’s explicitly encouraged fraud.


Employees were paid in cash, so that tax-liability could be minimized.


Employees were encouraged to overstate losses to insurance companies.


Finally, employees were explicitly encouraged to do what they could to


conceal assets from the government.


 


      c.            What elements of the fraud triangle were present at Crazy


Eddie?


       Employees were paid in cash and therefore given the opportunity to


skim and evade taxes. Employees were also told, implicitly and sometimes


explicitly, that tax-evasion and skimming were legitimate, making it easy for


them to rationalize doing so.


      Finally, Crazy Eddie’s had a low tolerance for low performance,


putting pressure on employees to satisfy performance-benchmarks however


they could.


 


      d. What do you consider to be the most interesting part about the


Crazy Eddie fraud?


 


      To me, the most striking feature of this case was the company’s failure


to try to conceal it. To be sure, Crazy Eddie’s did misreport assets and


revenue. But its now infamous sales campaigns (available on YouTube:


    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ml6S2yiuSWE) dripped with contempt


for established business practices and strongly hinted at a kind of Mafia-like


criminality on the part of its management.


 


      3. Read the following information and then answer questions a & b


below :


      Assume you are an internal auditor for a large, multinational,manufacturing organization with a division in Mexico. One of your


responsibilities is to investigate allegations made on the company’s fraud


hotline. When you arrive at work one morning you learn an anonymous tip


was left on the hotline that alleges fraud involving the division manager.


“Pat’s significant other is a fraudulent vendor,” was the anonymous tip left


on your company’s fraud hotline. Pat is a division manager at your company.


      “Wow. I can’t believe this guy is so blatant,” you are thinking as you


review some accounts payable invoices while following up on this anonymous

      A quick search of the AP file reveals a total of three invoices like the


one in Table 1 (on the next page of this exam), all for identical amounts but


on different dates. The division manager, Pat, has the authority to approve


payment of invoices for less than $10,000. It is obvious to you that the


manager has a created a shell company. You happen to know that Pat’s


significant other is named Kim, hence the name Kimco Marketing. There is


no documentation to support these transactions other than the invoices, all of

      The manager’s office is not more than 30 feet away and Pat can be


seen at the desk. You throw the invoices in a file, grab your buddy in the next


office, and head for Pat’s office. After all, it doesn’t take a brain surgeon to


know what’s going on here. 


        Requirements for Question 4:


 


      a. Should Pat be confronted and interviewed now? Why or why not?


 


      No. It is too soon to interview Pat. Fraud-interviews should not be


fact-finding expeditions. But if Pat were interviewed right now, that is what


that interview would be. It has not yet been established that Pat committed


fraud. It may well be that you are not aware of evidence to support the


legitimacy of these invoices, but you have only been just made aware of the


situation, and you must verify your suspicions before confronting pat.


      Your job right now is to figure out what happened. If you verify your


suspicions, your next job is to figure out what to ask Pat. Before interviewing


Pat, you must know exactly what happened, so that you can control the


interview and maximize the likelihood of a confession.


      When you do interview, make sure not to go in ‘guns blazing.’ Keep


an open mind, and start with non-confrontational questions (e.g. how long


have you worked her?, what is a typical day for you like?). This will help


establish trust. Once you have ‘connected’ with the interviewee, move to


tougher questions.


       b.) Compile a written list of the questions you would ask in the


interview with Pat and the sequence in which they should be asked.


Ultimately, your objective is to determine whether a fraud has been


committed and, if so, obtain a confession from Pat.


 


 


 


 


      What is your current position?


      How long have you worked here?


      What is a typical day for you like?


      Does your job involve providing marketing services? What about


consulting services?


      Can you tell me about that?


      If you provide marketing services, what does that involve?


      Are the fees for marketing services simply for your expertise, or are


they used to defray subcontractor expenses?


      Tell me about some recent marketing clients of yours?


      Do you happen to recall doing work for the E.Z. Pickens


Conglomerate?


      Tell me about that?      Do you recall how much you might have invoiced them?

your contact over there?


      Were they pleased with the work?


      Who else worked with you on this?

mean?

      Are you aware that complete transparency will help me help you?


                           Cybercrime: How to Spot It and Stop It


 


 A cybercrime is any crime that is committed online. If Smith creates a


business website and uses that website to charge people for non-existent


services, he is committing a cyber-crime. If Jones lures young women into


his sex trafficking ring by posting an online advertisement for ‘legitimate


modeling jobs', he is committing a cybercrime. If Brown posts an


advertisement on Craigslist for a car that he doesn't own and then takes


money for it, he has committed a cybercrime.


      There are many different kinds of cybercrime, and there are many


different ways of committing a given kind of cybercrime. Three particularly


common forms of cybercrime are hacking, identity theft, and internet fraud.


      Hacking is simply entry into a cyber-venue, such as a bank account or


student account, to which one does not have authorized access. Suppose I


know Mary Jane's Amazon password. I can use that information to log into


her Amazon account, I am guilty of hacking. If I then make unauthorized


purchases on Mary's account, I am guilty theft in addition to hacking.


Hacking is the cyber-equivalent of breaking and entering; and just as physical


breaking an entering is often a prelude to burglary, so hacking is often a


prelude to theft. Hacking may also be a prelude to a number of other different


internet crimes. Suppose that I log into Mary Jane’s Facebook accountwithout her permission and then impersonate her by sending messages from


her account. Here my act of hacking is a prelude not to property theft, but to


identity theft, this being an extremely common form of cyber-crime.


      Identity theft is the use of the internet to impersonate another person.


In many cases, the purpose of identity theft is property theft. For example,


Smith may steal Brown's identity with the intention of draining Brown's bank


account. But property theft is not always what identity theft is about. Smith


may steal Brown's identity with the intention of destroying his livelihood (by


sending inappropriate messages to his employer from his email account) or of


humiliating him (by posting compromising photos on his social media


accounts).


      Internet fraud is the use of the internet to commit fraud. Each of the


cybercrimes discussed in the first paragraph is a case of internet fraud. The


internet is a magnet for fraudsters since it allows practically anyone to


assume practically any identity. A man can pretend to be a woman; an adult


can pretend to be a child; a lowlife can pretend to be a respected financier.


      One particularly widespread form of internet fraud is internet romance


fraud. Someone will post a phony profile on a dating website, such as


match.com. If the fraudster’s objective is to swindle young males, he or she


may post a photo of an extremely good-looking young woman who is eager


to find a ‘normal guy to have fun with.' If the target is elderly divorcees, thefraudster is likely to post a photo of a distinguished looking executive who


wants to spend ‘a cultured woman who isn't simply after my money.' When


somebody responds, an internet courtship ensues, during which the fraudster


carefully gains the other person's trust. Eventually, the fraudster will try to


capitalize on that trust by defrauding the other person in some way.


      Here is a real-life example. Ken Azeah and Akunna Ejiofor created a


phony profile on an internet dating site, claiming to be a handsome and


distinguished financier. Operating through this persona, Azeah and Ejiofor


cultivated online romances with several different women, manipulating them


into allowing this non-existent person to manage their money, thereby


swindling tens of millions of dollars from them. These women alerted the


authorities, who quickly traced the money. Azeah and Ejiofor were arrested


and convicted of several counts of internet fraud and wire fraud.


      The victims in this case did not exercise due diligence. They gave their


money to someone without first verifying his credentials or even his very


existence. Azeah and Ejiofor were manipulators, not hackers, and their


victims voluntarily gave them every dollar that they took from them, and they


would have avoided this disaster had they simply used their judgment.


Internet fraud, like all fraud, involves taking advantage of wishful thinking,


and as long as one thinks realistically, instead of wishfully, one won’t be the


victim of internet fraud.      Most people have been the victims of some kind of internet fraud.


They may have given money to a company promising to give them lucrative


stay-at-home jobs. They may have signed up given money to online


‘coaches’ who never provided them with meaningful services. They may


have been paid an online ‘lawyer’ for legal advice that they never received.


Or they may have signed up for phony get-rich-quick schemes promoted by


slick YouTubers. The victims of these crimes are always wishful thinkers:


they are people who want to believe that they can make $100,000 working


four hours/day; that a real lawyer will give them counsel for $5; that the


government will simply give them money; that, in short, they can have what


they want without working for it. All internet fraud involves wishful thinking,


and a healthy dose of realism makes one impervious to it.


      One virtually full-proof sign that an online ‘business opportunity’ is a


scam is that one has to pay for it. Real employers pay you; you don’t pay


them. If you are being asked to pay money to make money, you are being


scammed out of your money and also quite possibly being manipulated into


disclosing information to someone who will try to use it to defraud you


further.


      To be sure, internet fraud is only one kind of cybercrime, but internet


fraud tends to be involved in carrying out other kinds of cybercrimes. If


someone is able to steal your identity or hack into an account of yours, thereis a good chance that he manipulated you into giving him personal data. He


may have friended you on Facebook and carefully eased you into giving him


personal data, or he may have sent you an email luring you with the promise


of easy money into setting up an account on a website of his. It is likely that


some element of wishful thinking on your part was involved in this person’s


being in a position to obtain the information that needed to hack into your


accounts and steal your identity.


      There are indeed cybercrimes that do not involve internet fraud and


therefore do not involve wishful thinking on the victim’s part. In some cases,


PayPal or Bank Accounts are raided, and the victim isn’t guilty of any


obvious lapse in judgment. But scrutiny of such cases tends to show that the


victim put too much faith in someone (it may have been a slick salesman or


an unvetted app-designer on Fiverr) and tipped their hand to that person. It is


very unlikely that one’s bank account will be raided or one’s identity stolen


unless one has been too quick to give credence to big talkers without


verifiable credentials.


      To be sure, professionals often have access to personal information,


and they may use that information to commit cybercrimes against those


people. For example, physicians may have access to patient credit card


information, and they could use that information to commit theft or fraud.


But physicians value their careers too much to throw them away for a fewunauthorized credit card purchases, the same being true of all professionals:


lawyers, professors, accountants, and stockbrokers stand to lose much and


gain little by misusing client information. If a given person does have an


incentive to run up unauthorized charges on your credit card, he probably


isn't a professional, and he probably is somebody who could not have


acquired that information without manipulating.


      In conclusion, although there are internet crimes that do not involve


fraud or manipulation, most such crimes do, and the best protection against


internet crime is to use one’s judgment. Verify someone’s credentials before


giving someone your personal information, let alone your money, and assume


the worst if you are unable to verify their credentials.


                                 Fraud Interview Techniques


 


      The purpose of any interview is to elicit information from the person


being interviewed. This is especially difficult to do, when the purpose of the


interview is to elicit information about a crime that the interviewee is known


or believed to have committed. Consequently, someone conducting a fraud


investigation interview has to meet requirements that other interviews do not.


      First of all, the interviewer must know the facts. He must know what


kind of fraud has committed and what it involved; and he must also know


what the likely role is of the person is being interviewed. If the interviewer


doesn’t have this information, he will be ‘fishing’ for information and the


interviewee will know it, making the latter even more disinclined than he


would otherwise be to be open truthful. Also, the interviewee is likely to


‘pied pipe’ such interviewer with false or half-true narratives, which will


prevent the interviewer from focusing on the right issues and asking the right


questions. To be sure, the interviewer need not know all of the relevant facts.


But he must know enough to know what to ask and to know whether a given


statement on the interviewee’s part for truth and relevance.


      Second, the interviewer must be able to make it psychologically easy


for the interviewee to talk. In a fraud interview, the interviewee is being


asked to provide incriminating information about himself, and in this respectfraud interviews are very different from job interviews. If the interviewer


comes on too strong, the interviewee is likely to feel threatened and to ‘clam


up.’ The interviewer must therefore ‘build rapport’ before asks the questions


that he is there to ask. He should come off as approachable and interested in


what the interviewee has to say, and he should also start out with non-


threatening questions that the interviewee can answer truthfully without


incriminating himself. Having established rapport in this way, the interviewer


should gently move on to tougher questions, making sure to frame them in a


way that makes the interviewee feel comfortable answering them. Having


successfully taken this step, the interviewer should ‘turn up the volume’ once


more, this time directly asking about the alleged offense, taking care not to


break his rapport with the interviewee. During this phase of the interview, the


interviewer wants to come off as a confessor, not an accuser: he wants the


interviewee to see him as somebody to whom he can ‘unburden’ himself.


      Third, the interviewer must be prepared. He must choose the venue


appropriately, making sure that there are as few or no distractions or possible


interruptions. To this end, the interviewer must remember to ask the


interviewee to turn off his cell-phone, since the interviewee is likely to dodge


questions by checking his messages, taking incoming calls, and the like.


Also, the interviewer should dress appropriately, since odd attire might make


the interviewee suspicious and unwilling to talk. Most importantly, theinterviewer must know exactly what it is that he wants to ask. He must not


‘wing it' during the interview.


      Fourth, the interviewer must be open-minded. He mustn’t have his


mind made up about who is guilty of what, and he must be prepared for the


possibility that the interviewee will give him legitimate information that


conflicts with his preconceptions. Consequently, the interviewer, while being


prepared, shouldn’t rigidly stick to a script, since the questions he asks must


reflect any new and relevant information that the interviewee has given him.


      Fifth, the interviewer must be quick to pick up on signs of deception,


of which there are many. Deceptive people are reluctant to answer questions


directly, and they are likely to stall and ask for unnecessary clarifications.


They may also volunteer extraneous or excessive information. (For example,


when asked ‘do you know anything about the phony accounts that we


discovered last week?’, a liar may respond by saying: ‘I have never


committed fraud in my life.”) Such a person is likely to have selective


amnesia.(“I don’t recall” is a go-to for many liars, as is “I haven’t heard


that.”) Deceivers are likely to respond with emotional ‘performances’; when


asked a straightforward question (e.g. ‘do you know how stole those treasury


notes?’), a liar may respond being indignant (“how dare you ask such a


question!”). Deceivers are likely to make extraneous movements (e.g. they


are likely to fidget, adjust their ties, stroke their beards, play with rings, flicktheir hair). Their body language is also likely to indicate defensiveness; for


example, they are likely to have an unusually stiff and upright posture or to


cross their legs excessively. When asked questions, liars are not likely to


respond with concise and plausibly answers, and they are likely to dodge the


question in one way or another.


      When conducting a fraud interview, one must be professional. This


involves having the facts and knowing what to ask. But it also means not


having an agenda: not regarding the interviewee either as enemy or a friend,


but simply as a possible source of information who is to be treated


accordingly.


               Some Key Obstacles to Effective Fraud Risk Assessment


 


      There are several obstacles to conducting an effective fraud risk


assessment of a given organization. First of all, a thorough knowledge of the


industry in question is a prerequisite for effective fraud risk assessment.


Suppose that ACME is a company that provides extremely specialized and


high-level financial services. It might be very difficult for an independent


auditor (or any other outside agency) to know exactly what kinds of fraud


ACME employees might be likely to commit. Suppose that ACME handles


large volumes of foreign currency. Because of fluctuating exchange rates, it


might be possible for account-managers to misrepresent earnings and, on this


basis, to siphon off funds for themselves. In this context, effective fraud risk


assessment would involve knowledge of how to interpret complex financial


statements concerning foreign currencies, which would require knowledge


that is more in-depth than most auditors are likely to have.


      Second, a thorough knowledge of the company in question is


necessary for effective fraud risk management. Suppose once again that


ACME provides specialized financial services, often involving foreign


currencies. Also suppose that there are multiple fund-managers servicing


each of ACME’s different accounts. (So if Smith is one of ACME’s clients,


then ten different fund-managers are involved in servicing Smith’s account.)It will be difficult to know exactly who is doing what for a given client, and it


will therefore be hard to know who has access to what kind of information or,


therefore, who is in a position to commit a given kind of fraud. If money goes


missing from one of Smith’s accounts, there will be ten different ACME


employees to investigate, making it hard to conduct a speedy and effective


investigation.


      Third, even if a given auditor (or auditing agency) has the requisite


degree of industry-specific and company-specific information, a prohibitively


high degree of sophistication may be needed to process all of the raw data in


question. Suppose that ACME is an extremely large company that provides


many different kinds of services in many different countries. In a case like, it


would be hard to conduct an ad hoc investigation of each individual branch


of ACME, since the time and expense involved would be excessive, as would


the difficulties in interpreting the resulting information; and it would


probably be necessary to come up with a company-wide fraud risk


assessment program. But coming up with such an assessment would be an


intellectually extremely demanding task.


      Fourth, many companies, especially companies in the fields of finance


and consulting, provide services that are poorly defined. Suppose that ACME


provides ‘project management support’, ACME employees might send


complex invoices that their clients are unlikely to scrutinize, making itpossible to bill for services that were never rendered. Also, those services


might involve creating new accounts or even new holding companies, which


could then be used to create hide losses or gains or simply to hide funds.


      Fifth, while requiring industry-specific and company-specific


knowledge, fraud risk assessment must also be conducted by disinterested


parties, and this makes it inherently difficult to conduct effective fraud risk


assessment. It is hard for any organization to be objective about itself and


therefore to identify fraud in its own midst, but it is hard for outside agencies


avail outside agencies of the information needed to do so.


      Finally, when conducting a fraud risk assessment, it is necessary to


bear in mind what the company will actually be able and willing to do with


the resulting information. Suppose that Smith is an external auditor who


conducts a fraud risk assessment of ACME, and suppose that the ACME-


services that Smith flags as likely to lead to fraud are the very ones that


ACME depends on for most of its revenue. In that case, Smith’s findings may


well fall on deaf ears. In order to avoid this, Smith would have to be very


precise about how exactly the services in question might lead to fraud, and he


would also have to be very precise about how to those services could be


retained while also being so modified or monitored that they were no longer


fraud-conducive. In a situation like this, fraud risk assessment would involve


a high-degree of knowledge, intelligence, and discretion.      In conclusion, effective fraud risk assessment requires a combination


of company-information, industry-information, objectivity, and discretion


that may make it difficult to carry out effectively.


 


                   Five Characteristics of Reliable Employees


 

                                                                          [71]
      In her article Five Characteristics of a Good Work Ethic, Erin


Schreiner identifies what she believes to be some necessary ingredients for a


good work ethic, these being:


 


      Reliability and dependability


      Dedication to the job


        Productivity that doesn’t quit


        Cooperation and teamwork


        Self-disciplined character


 


      Let us briefly discuss each of these:


 


        Reliability and dependability: An employee is only as good as he is


reliable. The most talented surgeon in the world is useless to the hospital that


employs him if he doesn’t show up to work regularly. In fact, as this very


example shows, if someone who has talent is unreliable, that can be a


dangerous situation: given that the surgeon in question is talented, the


hospital will expect him to do that much more than his colleagues; and if he


doesn’t show to work, then that much more work isn’t being done. 


      Dedication to the job: It isn’t enough that employs show up and do


their job. It is necessary that they do their job with distinction. A talented


surgeon who shows up to work but doesn’t apply himself is not only failing


to help his organization but is actively hurting it.


 


        Productivity that doesn’t quit: A dedicated and reliable employee is a


productive employee; an employee who isn’t dedicated or reliable is not a


productive employee. So productivity, though not exactly a character-trait in


and of itself, is a consequence of the first two character-traits.


 


        Cooperation and teamwork: It isn’t enough that an employee be


dedicate and reliable. If he doesn’t cooperate with the organization that


employs him, then his successes won’t be its successes. Such a person may


be a great entrepreneur; but if he is part of a team, then he function as such.


And even if he is an entrepreneur, he still has to work with others—with


suppliers, investors, customers, and employees of his own—and he must, in


that sense, be a team-player. So cooperativeness with one’s team is essential


for success in any enterprise that is not completely solitary.


 


        Self-disciplined character: In order for a person to have any of thepreviously mentioned traits, he must be self-disciplined. Someone who is not


self-disciplined is a ‘slacker’, and slackers are neither reliable, hard-working,


dedicated, or productive; and they are not good team-members. So self-


discipline is, in a way, the root-characteristic of all of the various


characteristics of a good worker.

context, then (up to) 5 bullet/numbered points that are your key messages


about the industry.


 


      *Owing to high start-up and fixed costs, there is a pronounced


tendency towards industry-concentration, with the top three companies


having an 80% market-share.


 


      *Global warming is eating into already thing profit-margins,

      *This industry is sensitive to changes in the economy and can be


expected to grow as long as the economy does and to shrink when it doesn’t.

rivals, owing mainly to the fact that there are very places on Earth whereskiing is possible and also owing to the high maintenance costs.

a minimum number of customers.


 


      *The industry offers a valuable and ultimately non-fungible service


and will therefore remain in existence for the foreseeable future, but market-


concentration will grow, as will barriers-to-entry for non-established players.

accommodations are also included in this industry, but companies that own


and do not operate ski resorts are excluded from the industry.
