        Summary of Industry Structure - how the industry makes money


and the overall contribution/balance of key forces & factors that enable or


inhibit industry profitability.


       Many people enjoy skiing, and there are very few places on Earth


where it is physically possible to do so. The Ski Resort Industry makes


money by giving people an otherwise impossible-to-obtain opportunity to ski.


Consumer demand for the opportunity to ski is sufficiently strong that this


industry is unlikely to collapse, but many factors conspire to make it difficult


for small operators to survive and for large ones to make more than modest


profits. These include


 


        *Season-specificity (no skiing except during Winter)


      *High start-up and maintenance costs


        *Increasing technology-related costs


      *The existence of substitutes (e.g., golf, boating).


 


      Because of the entrenched and relatively widespread nature of the


desire to ski, ski resorts will continue to profit, but those profits will shrink


and be shared by increasingly few market-participants.


 


 


 


           Analytical Assessment of Greg Toppo’s “Do Video Games Inspire


                                      Violence?”


 


      The main point of this article is supposedly that “decades of research


have turned


      up no reliable causal link between playing violent video games and


perpetrating actual violence.” The author repeatedly asserts that playing


violent video games (e.g. Grand Theft Auto) does not cause (or, to put it


more conservatively, encourage) children to carry out actual acts of violent.


But the data that the author cites tends to support the opposite conclusion. To


be sure, that data does not definitively warrant acceptance of the position that


playing video games causes children to be violent; but it is more favorable to


that position than to its negation. As a result, this article consists of a series of


unargued assertions to the effect that playing such games doesn’t lead to


violence, interposed between which is data that tends to undermine that


conclusion along with some entertaining but irrelevant anecdotes.


      The author begins by discussing Adam Lanza. 20-year-old Lanza


killed 20 children in a school yard in 2012. Toppo points out that, as


investigators would come to discover, he spent much of the time leading up


to the shooting by playing video games at a local arcade.


      Of course, this doesn’t prove causality: many people play videogames; most of them do not commit acts of violence thereafter; and, for all


we know, many people of them perform positively saintly acts. But with


regard to the fact that Lanza, by the author’s own admission, spent hours


obsessively playing aggressively-tinged video games, this fact doesn’t


exactly bolster Toppo’s assertion that there is “no… causal link between


playing violent video games and perpetrating actual violence.”


      Bizarrely, Toppo also points out that Lanza’s home video game stash


included a number of violent games, including: “Call of Duty, Dead or Alive


[and] Grand Theft Auto.” Toppo also points out that, in having these games,


Lanza was “like many teens.” But the fact that Lanza had these games, and


almost certainly played them frequently in the years leading up to his


shooting spree, doesn’t exactly support Toppo’s “no causal link” thesis.


      Also, even though Lanza’s crimes were unusually overt and unusually


violent, he was not the only violent criminal in the country. There are many


car-jackings, rapes, physical assaults, acts of vandalism, and even murders,


all committed by males of approximately Lanza’s age, this being the prime


demographic (suggestively) for violent video-game: and what if it turned out


—a possibility that Toppo does not even consider—that a disproportionate


number of these crimes were carried out, and perhaps even immediately


preceded by, people playing such games? Again, that would not definitely


prove causality; it could be a mere correlation. But it wouldn’t help Toppo’scase, and neither does the limited data that Toppo does cite.


      Toppo mentions that there were many video games at the arcade


Lanza frequented that were not violent, e.g. “Dance Dance Revolution.” One


would presume that, in pointing this out, Toppo was making an attempt,


however feeble, to cast doubt on the idea that Lanza’s video-gaming had a


hand in his murderous rampage. But instead of saying this, Toppo says: “Yet


no one knows how any of these games—Dance Dance Revolution included—


might have affected a kid who was clearly struggling.” The point of which


remark seems to be that, indeed, Lanza’s playing video games might have at


least nudged him in the direction of committing mass murder. But instead of


saying that, Toppo says—without having provided a shred of support or even


of due expository build-up--- “The truth is that decades of research have


turned up no reliable causal link between playing violent video games and


perpetrating actual


      violence.”


      And that may be true: but Toppo doesn’t actually cite any of the data


that disproves the existence of such a connection. Toppo mentions that, in


addition to owning (and presumably using) several violent games, Lanza also


had newspaper clippings relating to the infamous 1997 Columbine shooting.


This does not prove that playing violent video games causes people to be


violent, but it certainly doesn’t prove the opposite. And the fact that boththese newspaper clippings and these violent video games were evidently


congenial to Lanza certainly makes it reasonable to suspect, however


tentatively, that there is some kind of affirmative connection, however


tenuous, between Lanza’s gaming and his killing.


      In the next two sections, Toppo discusses the views and research of


different psychologists (e.g. Melzer, Bandura, Gentile), some of whom held,


and provided evidence in favor to the view, that there is a connection


between ‘virtual’ violence (e.g. reading violent comics, playing violent video


games) and actual violence, and some of whom believed and otherwise (and


provided some, albeit feeble, evidence to the contrary). But the totality of the


research-data cited by Toppo is ambiguous at best and, if anything, tends to


support the contention there is a causal link between virtual and actual


violence.


      For example, Toppo cites a study that mentions how, after playing a


violence-themed board-game, children would deal with frustration by


punching a toy clown in the face. (Toppo then feebly asserts that this doesn’t


prove there to be a connection between virtual violence and actual violence.


But it doesn’t prove the opposite; and tends to support such a claim. If you


knew someone who repeatedly punched dolls in the face, would you really


not at some level suspect that person of being violent?) He also mentions a


study according to which children who played violence-themed gamesbecome angry more easily than others and were more given to aggressive


ideation.


      Toppo then mentions, presumably in effort to offset these claims, that


according to one study, there was a slight negative correlation in some


populations between level of violence-themed gaming and levels of actual


violence. But this was one study, which concerned one population, and the


inverse correlation in question was marginal at best. In any case, this


particular claim involves more of a failure to distinguish causation from


correlation than do the claims of his adversaries.


      Toppo then mentions that the number youthful offenders fell even as


the number of violent games grew. This is certainly suggestive, but it is far


from probative, and to think otherwise would involve a rather brazen failure


to distinguish correlation from causation.


      Toppo then mentions that a number of distinguished authors, e.g.


Emily Dickenson and Nathaniel Hawthorne, liked to read violence-themed


literature. Exactly what this proves is deeply unclear. But Toppo seems to be


insinuating that, if there were an actual connection between reading about (or


thinking about) violence and committing acts of violence, then these


distinguished authors would have steered clear of such literature. But if that is


what Toppo is saying—and it must be what he is saying, unless (what is


possible) his inclusion of this material serves no argumentative purpose—then Toppo’s reasoning is weak, to put it mildly.


      Taken by itself, Toppo’s main claim—that decades of research have


turned


      up no reliable causal link between playing violent video games and


perpetrating actual violence”---is perfectly plausible. And it may even be


true. But the data that Toppo himself sites does not support the belief that


there is no such connection. In fact, that data doesn’t even support the much


more modest claim that “decades of research” have failed to produce such


data. Given only what Toppo says—given only the data that he sites---it


seems as though scientific research has generated data suggestive of a link


between virtual and actual violence. In fact, given the totality of the data that


Toppo himself sites, it would be epistemically more conservative to affirm


than to deny the existence of such a link. In conclusion, while it may be there


is no such link, Toppo’s article fails utterly to prove otherwise.


        Throughout the article, Toppo seems to be insinuating that people are


guilty of some sort of prejudice---of some failure to look at their personal


values in light of the actual facts—in holding there to be a causal connection


between virtual and actual violence. Toppo’s ‘position’, if that isn’t too


strong a word, seems to be that, although people attach a negative value to


violent games, there is no reason for them to do so, the facts being what they


are.      There are several points to make here. First, the facts being what they


are, there is reason to hold there to be such a connection. Are there definitive


reasons? No. But is there more reason than not to posit such a link? Probably.


      Second, to the extent that Grand Theft Auto and other such games are


held in contempt, is it not necessarily solely or even primarily because those


games are suspected of promoting violence. Another possibility—a very


distinct possibility—is that people see it as a waste of time to spend all day


playing video games. Indeed, people don’t have much respect for people who


spend all day playing Grand Theft Auto. But they have equally little respect


for people who spend all day playing Pac Man or Galaga. Video games have


their place, but they tend to function as ways for people to procrastinate and


avoid the real world. And so far as gaming is held in contempt, that is


probably way. Going on a Lanza-style shooting spree is one way of being a


loser. Spending all day playing video games is another of being a loser.


      Third, judging by video game sales, it doesn’t seem that there is any


particular societal contempt for gaming. Who buys those games after all? Not


the people who use them---they don’t have money. 15 year old rarely have


enough money of their own buy much of anything. And when they purchase


video games, it is with their parents’ money (and knowledge: the parents


obviously see their children playing those games and know that they were


purchased with allowance-money). So it is, in effect, their parents who arebuying those games. So by all accounts, the contingent of anti-gamers that


Toppo is inveigling against is rather small. Moreover, given only the data that


Toppo sites, that contingent is not completely without good reasons for


thinking ill of virtual recreational violence.


      This raises a larger question, namely: Do the facts ever justify


valuative attitudes? According to David Hume, the answer is “no.” “One


cannot derive an ‘ought’ from an ‘is’”, says Hume.


      But is that really true? If know that Smith is dumping large quantities


of poison in the local reservoir—if I am aware of that fact---do I not have an


obligation to alert the authorities and to make people aware of the fact that


their water supply has been contaminated? It seems that, in this case, unless


common sense is deeply wrong, I can derive an ‘ought’ (I ought to tell the


police about Smith’s behavior) from an ‘is’ (Smith is dumping poison in the


water supply).


      In general, it seems as though normative assertions are answerable to


factual assertions. Let A be the statement:


 


      Jim hurts people for no good reason; it doesn’t even make him feel


good; it just gives him mild sadistic pleasure.


 


      And let B be the statement: 


      Jim is evil or, at the very least, lacking in moral fiber.


 


      It seems that, given A, B cannot reasonably be denied—that there is a


relation of entailment from A to B. If Hume believes otherwise, it is, at least


on the face of it, Hume’s position that is to be rejected.


      In any case, Toppo’s reasoning is so weak that it doesn’t much matter


what ‘ought’ he is saying you should, or should not, derive from what ‘is.’


Toppo has cited some data, the totality of which is compatible with, and


mildly probative of, a causal nexus between virtual and actual violence.


(Personally, I don’t believe there to be such a connection. But Toppo,


ironically, has actually done more to prove there to be such a connection than


to disprove it.) So is Toppo saying that, the data being what it is, we should


not derive “you ought not prohibit youngsters from playing Grand Theft


Auto” from that data? Or is he saying that we should derive “you ought to let


youngsters play Theft Auto” from that data? It doesn’t matter. Because


Toppo’s argument is so weak, and the data he cites so ambiguous, that it is


left open what, if anything, is to be derived from what.


                     Why Barings Fell (Business/Economics)


 


      To: Audit Committee of a Commercial Bank


      Re: Risk Factors and Control Issues Contributing to the Downfall of


Barings Bank


 


      The basic facts of the Leeson case are simple. An unlicensed 25-year-


old broker, Leeson was hired by Barings and placed in charge of its futures


trading operation on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange

          [72]
(SIMEX). Leeson was hard-working and bold, and he initially made


enormous amounts of money for Barings by making large, highly successful


trades. These trades were highly speculative, this being why they were so


lucrative. They were also unauthorized. Leeson went to great lengths to make


the trades seem legitimate. He created a dummy account (Account #88888)


for a non-existent client, through which he routed money from other Barings


accounts to finance his unauthorized trades, and he created an elaborate

 
phony paper trail to throw off auditors. After a few early successes,Leeson’s

 [73]
luck ran out. He placed bad trade after bad trade, dummying up the books


to hide the losses from Baring’s auditors and also from his supervisors. The


auditors were increasingly alarmed by the holes they found in Leeson’s


financials, but Leeson’s supervisors, still believing Leeson to be a successfulearner, dismissed their concerns. In 1995, an earthquake in Japan caused the


Nikkei to plummet, resulting in losses for Leeson that he could not hide and


that exposed his operation for the house of cards that it was. He fled but was


promptly captured, tried, convicted, and incarcerated.


      Barings made several mistakes in connection with Leeson, the first of


which was to hire him in the first place. Leeson was denied a broker’s license


in the United Kingdom because he had lied on his application, claiming that

                                                            [74]
he had educational credentials that he in fact lacked. Given that Leeson


was applying for a job at Barings that would involve him handling other


people’s money, the people reviewing his application should have regarded


this indiscretion on his part as disqualifying from that position. This was a


violation of Principles 1 of Component 1 of COSO 2013: “Principle 1 - The

                                                                        [75]
organization adheres to the principles of integrity and ethics.” A company


is obviously failing to adhere to principles of integrity and ethics if it hires


somebody who lies on official paperwork and then gives him person a


position of fiduciary responsibility.


      Another big mistake Barings made in connection with Leeson was to


put him in charge not only of making trades but also of settling them (i.e. of

                                                                              [76]
seeing to it that the money is transferred from account to account).


Ordinarily, these two jobs are kept separate, so as to prevent the making of


unauthorized trades and also to prevent traders from being able to hide theirtrading activity. This is a violation of COSO 2017 Principle #10, this being to

                                            [77]
identify possible risk-factors for fraud. In addition, when Barings internal


auditors began to sound the alarm about Leeson’s numbers not adding up,


management always took Leeson’s word on the matter, this being a violation


of COSO 2017 Principle #16, this being to review risky behavior and

              [78]
performance.


      A giant red flag in the Leeson case was when it turned out that Leeson


would have needed approximately 70 million pounds (worth over one


hundred million dollars) to finance his trades, this being an amount far in

                                                                      [79]
excess of what any trader could possibly have had access to. Leeson gave a


brief and vague explanation to his supervisor. The supervisor was puzzled by


Leeson’s inadequate explanation but chose to look the other way. Indeed,


there were several occasions when one of Leeson’s supervisors was contacted


by an auditor asking for paperwork relating to Leeson’s trades; and in each


case, the supervisor, being personally chummy with Leeson and also still


under the spell of his charm and earlier successes, chose to look the other


way.


      Leeson’s crooked behavior was ultimately not motivated by financial


pressure. He made his first known unauthorized trade to cover up a minor


loss; but after making good on that loss, he continued, while under absolutely


no financial pressure, to make unauthorized trade after unauthorized trade,indicating that his behavior was not about his circumstances but about his


character. The question is not why he did it (he was crook, who had run afoul


of regulators before working for Barings and was acting accordingly). Nor is


it how he rationalized his behavior. (Criminals don’t always have to


rationalize their conduct; and when they do, the rationalizations can be thin


ones, along the lines of ‘Barings has more money than it knows what do with,


so I’m entitled to my fair share’). As far as the Fraud Triangle goes, the


relevant question here is how Leeson did what he did; and the answer is that


he was in charge of settling the trades he was making, which gave him the


power to generate a phony paper trail and thereby keep internal auditors off


his track, at least until the scam collapsed.


 


                             Internet Crime (Computer Security)


 


        ‘Computer crime’ is a veritable synonym of ‘internet crime.’ Internet


crime always involves the internet. But there are two very different kinds of


crimes that involve the internet. In some cases, the internet is being used in


an honest manner but with the intention of committing a crime. In other


cases, the internet is being used in a dishonest manner, and that is the crime.


      Here is an example of the first kind of crime. I go to a drug website


and purchase a controlled substance. The merchant in question sends me


what I bought; the product is good; and the quantity is what I asked for. In


this case, I am not committing fraud and neither is the merchant. But a crime


has been committed.


      Here is an example of the second kind of crime. I send out emails in


which I claim to be a representative of Bank America. In those emails, I tell


the recipient that their account has been compromised; so they must


immediately provide me with their log-in credentials, so that I can personally


enter their account and secure it. In actuality, I am not a representative of


Bank of America, and I use the information that I receive from the people I


have duped to log into their accounts and abscond with their funds.


      The first crime technically qualifies as an ‘internet crime’, since it


involves the use of the internet. But in reality it is just a case of someonebuying an illicit drug. The second crime seems to be in a different category.


This is because the second case is one where my use of the internet is


deceptive: I am taking advantage of relations of trust and interdependence


that have grown up around the internet. Therefore, the sense in which the


second crime is an internet crime is stronger than the sense in which the first


crime is an internet crime.

                                                                                      [80]
      A list of the top 10 ‘internet crimes’ will help illustrate these points:


 


            Phishing/Spoofing


          Accessing Stored


            Blackmail/Extortion


          Sports Betting


          Non-delivery of Merchandise


          Electronic Harassment


          Child Pornography


            Prostitution


          Drug Trafficking


          Criminal Copyright Infringement


 


 


      Each of these crimes raises important ethical and legal issues. Some ofthese ‘crimes’ are arguably not of great ethical significance. But some of the


items on this list are quite clearly very serious crimes; but, for reasons that we


will discuss, they are extremely difficult to enforce, and the laws that must be


created to enforce are often invasive and abridge people’s personal liberties,


sometimes to what is arguably an inappropriate degree. Let us now discuss


each of these crimes, along with its likely ethical and legal ramifications.


Then we will discuss forms of conduct that might or might not be regarded as


internet crimes, depending on one’s point of view.


        Phishing/spoofing: Phishing/spoofing is pretending online to be


someone who one isn’t in order to get privileged information, usually relating


to bank-accounts, credit cards, and the like. We have already discussed an


example of this: somebody emails Smith pretending to be a bank


representative and thereby tricking Smith into giving up his account-


information.


      There is no doubt that Phishing/spoofing is a serious crime, both


legally and ethically. The problem is that much phishing/spoofing is done


internationally. This means that the identification, apprehension, and


prosecution of phishers/spoofers involves the coordination of different law-


enforcement agencies and prosecutorial offices in different countries. Since


such coordination is very hard to achieve, it is hard to successfully prosecute


people for this crime; and the best defense against it is simply for computer-users to be wary and to be extremely careful with their personal information.

[81]


      Also, since phishing/spoofing involves stealth, the people who commit


this crime are very good at covering their tracks. Plus, one can commit this


crime from anywhere there is an internet connection, and phishing/spoofing


is therefore very different from running a meth lab, for example, which


involves standing facilities.


        Accessing-privileged information: If I use the internet in order to hack


into your OneDrive Storage Account, I am guilty of accessing privileged


information. But not all cases of this crime involve the internet, and in this


respect this particular crime is unique among the crimes being discussed in


this paper. For example, if I use my roommate’s computer to access his


personal records, which I then use for personal gain, I am guilty of accessing


personal-information, even though I did not use the internet to do so.


        Obviously it is both ethically and legally wrong to access personal


information. But the same problem arises here that arose in connection with


phishing/spoofing: many cases of this crime are international in nature and

                                                                                [82]
therefore involve the cooperation of a number of different agencies. Also,


as with phishing/spoofing, this crime is of its very nature secretive. The


prospect of being jailed for this crime is therefore only of limited deterrent


value, and best protection against it is to be careful with one’s personalinformation.


        Blackmail/extortion: This is the use of the internet to blackmail or


extort people, usually with the threat of publicizing private or compromising


materials on YouTube, Facebook or other social media platforms. Here is a


hypothetical example. I make consensual sex tapes of me and my wealthy


girlfriend. After doing this, I threaten to send those tapes to her conservative


parents unless she gives me $10,000. This is blackmail/extortion.


      This sort of crime is common, but unlike the crimes mentioned above,


it is relatively easy to prosecute. This is because both the black-mailer and the


black-mailee tend to be in the same country---often the same city or even


residence---and the black-mailer tends to over-estimate his leverage over the


black-mailed. Thus, in cases like the one describe, the woman is likely to


‘bite the bullet’ and let her parents see the sex tape, in which case the black-


mailer is vulnerable to prosecution. Many people are jailed for so-called


‘revenge porn’, and many such cases start out as unsuccessful attempts to

                              [83]
extort/blackmail someone.


      There is little legal or ethical ambiguity in connection with this type of


crime. It is obviously wrong to blackmail/extort people; moreover, it is illegal


and easily prosecuted.


      Sports betting: People like to gamble, but in most places, including


most places in the United States, it is illegal to gamble. And even when it islegal, it is heavily regulated. For this reason, online illegal betting parlors are


very popular. If a betting parlor services people in the same country, it is


easily shut-down and its owners are easily prosecuted. If it services clients in


other countries, then the usual issues arise relating to the coordination of law-


enforcement in different countries.


      But there are cases of international betting parlors being shut down,


one of which involved an American Citizen who was living abroad but whose


clients were usually American.


      Online betting parlors handle large amounts of money. Therefore, they


need to have stable relations to banks and are fairly easy to trace, unlike


phishing and other internet-crimes.


      One question that arises is whether it is actually immoral to run an


online betting parlor. If people want to gamble on a horse race and to this end


they enlist the services of an online casino, is the casino-owner really guilty


of wrong-doing? He is guilty of an illegal act, but the question is: should that


act be illegal? And that is unclear.


        Non-delivery of merchandise: This is when person x orders something


online from person y and person y doesn’t deliver the product or service in


question. Obviously this sort of crime is extremely common. Moreover, it is


not only illegal but extremely unethical. But it is also relatively easy to avoid


being the victim of such a crime: when procuring a good or service, usereputable intermediaries, such as Amazon, eBay, and Fiverr. These platforms


weed out suspicious actors, and they also refund money spent on bogus


services.


      Electronic harassment: This is when somebody engages in trolling or


other internet-based ways of making another person’s life uncomfortable.


Here is a hypothetical example: Smith doesn’t like Jones. So Smith sends


Jones hundreds of hurtful emails, and Smith also blasts out messages on


Facebook and Twitter in which he speaks ill of Jones. This is electronic


harassment. In some cases, this is illegal; and even when it isn’t illegal, some


of the platforms involved may put an end to it. I personally have known


people who have been banned from Facebook for electronically harassing


other people.


      Not all forms of electronic harassment are illegal or should be illegal.


For example, it should not be illegal to post an ill-willed review of a book on


Amazon, even if the review is without merit. Sometimes freedom of speech is


more important than freedom from hurtful taunts.


      Electronic harassment is sometimes fairly easy to prosecute. The


reason is that people usually harass people whom they know and who live or


work near them. So this eliminates some of the issues, earlier discussed,


relating to the coordination of law-enforcement agencies. ON the other hand,


electronic harassment may involve different states or even different countries,and it is sometimes unlikely the F.B.I. or Interpol will take an interest in a


case of mere harassment.


      Child pornography: Internet pornography accounts for around 25% of


online activity and a comparably high percentage of internet transactions.


Most of this activity is legal. But some of it is not. Child pornography is not,


and yet, sadly, it is extremely popular.


      The good news is that it is relatively easy to prosecute child


pornographers. The reason is that child pornography is an extremely involved


crime. Whereas phishing or accessing of privileged information merely


involve a laptop and some expertise, child pornography involves actual


children, who are often kidnapped; and those children have to be transported,


housed, and fed, all of which leaves a clear forensic trail. As a result, child


pornographers are likely to eventually be caught and prosecuted.


Unfortunately, the child pornography business is booming.


        Prostitution: Prostitutes, like most other merchants in our time,


advertise their services online. Sometimes they advertise their services in a


‘coded’ manner, saying that they offer ‘massage therapy’ or ‘sensual


readjustment.’ But oftentimes they are extremely overt, saying openly that


they will provide sex for money. As a result, it is not uncommon for people to


be arrested and prosecuted for advertising prostitution-services online.


      At the same, there are so many online prostitutes and law-enforcementresources are so sufficiently limited that law enforcement tends to focus more


on the organizers of large-scale prosecution rings than it does on individual


prostitutes.


      Also, given how popular such services are, along with the fact that it is


unclear whether it is morally wrong to exchange sex for money, the public


has only limited interest in seeing crimes of this kind prosecuted. And if


prosecution of it were excessively aggressive, the result could be contempt


for law, which might actually lead to more crime. IN any case, given the high


expected profits along with the low likelihood of a serious criminal sentence,


online prostitution is alive and well and will continue to be so for the

                    [84]
foreseeable future.


      Drug trafficking: this is when people use the internet to buy or sell


illegal drugs. It should be pointed out that most of the drugs that are bought


online are pharmaceuticals, as in, they are products manufactured by actual


pharmaceutical companies and usually sold in the original packaging. Also,


many of the drugs in question are Schedule III or IV, meaning that the


sentences for buying them, or even selling them, are light. To be sure, the


drugs bought online are opiates (Schedule II) and possession of them is a


relatively serious offense and selling them is an extremely serious offense.


But the people who sell them are usually located overseas. And law


enforcement in the countries that host them have extremely little interest inprosecuting them, partly because, even though they are violating American


laws, they are bringing a lot of money and business into their host countries.


Plus, it is unclear whether there is anything ethically wrong with selling a tab


of Xanax or Vicodin to someone overseas. In any case, it is unclear whether


the acting of doing so is morally worse than the act of putting someone in


possession of a Vicodin table in jail for three years. Finally, the online drug


trade, unlike the ‘in-person’ drug-trade, involves little or no violence, and its


existence may even take business away from violent non-internet-based drug


traffickers. For these reasons, the online drug-trade is seen as a more of a


‘gray-market’ than a ‘black-market’ business, and law enforcement is

                      [85]
correspondingly lax.


      In conclusion, there are many different kinds of internet crimes. In


some cases, these crimes are of a morally reprehensible nature (e.g. child


pornography), but in other cases (e.g. prostitution) they are morally


ambiguous or even innocuous. And even when they are unambiguously


wrong, they are often extremely hard to prosecute (cf. phishing/spoofing).


Finally, the best defense against many internet crimes is an attitude of caution


and suspicious. Where most such crimes are concerned, the police are of little


use, but an attitude of wariness is of great help and can make it very unlikely


that one will be the victim of such a crime.


         Bibliography


                http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2012/11/the-10-most-common-


internet-crimes/

          https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/cyber


            http://kellywarnerlaw.com/revenge-porn-laws-50-state-guide/


      Britz Marjle T. 2013 Computer Forensics and Cyber Crime: An


Introduction New York: Pearson


        Goodman, Marc 2015 Future Crime: Insight the Digital Underground


and the Battle for Our Connected World New York: Penguin Random House


 


                       Privatization in African Telecommunications

                                                            [86]
                      Ethio Telecom Being Privatized (Business)


 


      Ethiopia announces that it will sell shares of Ethio Telecom, the

 
nation’s telecommunications company.In effect, Ethiopia is privatizing its


telecommunications company. As a result it is opening Ethio Telecom, and


therefore Ethiopia itself, to foreign investment.


      This is likely to have far-reaching consequences for Ethiopia and for


East Africa as a whole. Ethiopia is Africa’s fastest growing economy. This


move is likely to galvanize Ethiopia’s already rapid growth. It will do this


mainly by attracting foreign investment capital to Ethiopia.


      It has already begun to do this, as major telecommunications


companies, such as South Africa’s MTN, are already positioning themselves


to purchase large positions in Ethio.


        Overall, this development signals that Ethiopia is moving away from a


rigid, bureaucratically managed economy to a flexible private economy.


 


 

                                                                          [87]
                      Nigerian Invents New Kind of Smart Book


 


      Nigeria’s barely functional educational system represents a vast fieldof opportunity for edupreneurs, such as Chizaram Ucheage. Ucheaga, the co-


founder of Mavis Computel, a computer company in Nigeria, just announced


his invention of the “Mavis Pen.”


      The Mavis Pen is a pen with a built-in computer and translation-


software that synchs with a special tablet, also manufactured by Computel.


Working together, the pen-and-tablet translate sentences written on the tablet


into any one of the many different languages used in Nigeria, and


simultaneously produced high-quality and easy to understand vocalizations of


those sentences.


      This is enormously important in a country such as Nigeria, in which


many different languages are spoken and in which people, including


members of a given educational institution, have enormous difficulty making


themselves understood to one another.


      This in turn could stimulate the development of Nigeria’s moribund


education-sector, which in turn would likely stimulate Nigeria’s large but


dysfunctional economy.


 

                                                                                  [88]
              Ethiopia Announces Privatization of its National Airline


 


      Ethiopia just announced that it will privatize its national airlines and


open them up to foreign investment. Ethiopia has done this largely as a wayof jump-starting its large but sluggish economy, which has been hit hard over


the last few years by the failure to launch of several large-scale State projects,


massive national debt, a shortage of high-grade foreign currency, and a high


but under-serviced demand for foreign goods.


      This move will likely inject capital into Ethiopia’s economy, and


hopefully it will trigger a larger waive of interest on the part of foreign-


investors in Ethiopia. Also, the probable improvements in the quality of


Ethiopia’s Airline will likely encourage travel to and from Ethiopia, helping


to establish Ethiopia’s position as a player on the world economic stage, and


will also inspire investor-confidence in Ethiopia.


This move is a part of a larger privatization initiative on Ethiopia’s part that


also included the just-announced forthcoming privatizing of the state


telecommunications company. This move towards privatization is likely to


help actualize Ethiopia’s untapped economic potential.


           The Economic Justification for America’s Involvement in WWI


                                  (Economics/History)


 


      The  US  had  good  reasons  to  enter  the  war.  These  reasons  were


primarily economic in nature: the American economy stood to gain if the


U.S. entered the war and stood to lose if it didn’t. Also, if the US didn’t enter


the war, then at least arguably its safety and territorial integrity were at risk.


      World War 1 began in 1914 and it wasn’t until 1917 that the US got


involved. Wilson initially didn’t want to enter the war. In fact, he was elected


to office on an anti-war platform. But much happened to change Wilson’s


feelings, as well as those of the American public, during those three years.


      First of all, the U.S. fell into a massive recession, but War lifted the


US out of this recession by creating a large market for American military


goods. So the American economy came to depend on the war. Also, in order


to make it possible for the Allies to pay for American goods, a number of


American financiers, including J.P. Morgan, loaned them a large amount of


money, which said financiers would probably not recover if the Allies lost.


      So the U.S. actually had a double economic incentive to enter the War.


First, the American economy depended on it (or at least benefited from it).


Second, large amounts of American capital would be lost if the Allies didn’t


win---which, unless the Americans intervened, was not likely to happen. (Inpoint of fact, Germany had more or less won the war when the U.S. finally


intervened in 1917.)


      Also,  the  Allies,  mainly  Britain,  were  putting  immense  economic


pressure on the US to enter the war on their behalf. Prior to the war, there


was a large volume of trade between the United States and Germany. But


Britain cut off this trade, using her navy to prevent vessels from sailing from


the United States to Germany or vice versa. This was not exactly a positive


incentive to enter the war, but it did remove an incentive that the US had


previously had to enter the war on Germany’s behalf.


        Arguably, Germany was a threat to the United States, and the latter


therefore had to go to war against Germany for reasons of self-preservation.


In any case, the American government tried to convince its own citizens of


this, flooding them with propaganda to this effect. But Germany was not


actually a threat to the United States, and American officials probably did not


believe otherwise, any legitimate reasons they had for involving the US in the


war being economic, not existential, in nature.


      That said, the canonical answer to the question “Why did the US enter


WW1?” is: “Because of German attacks on American vessels, coupled with


the Zimmerman letter.” But Germany was not a military threat to the US, as it


simply  did  not  have  the  ability,  in  terms  of  technology  or  manpower,  to


conduct war with a power of the US’s stature from such a great distance off.In  fact,  just  prior  to  the  US’s  entry  in  the  war,  Germany  had  effectively


‘won’, in the sense that the allies, tired and depleted, were about to sign a


peace accord that heavily favored Germany. Aware of this, Germany very


much  wanted  the  US  not  to  enter  the  war.  True---Germany  did  attack


American vessels, but only because the US such vessels to supply the allies


with military supplies. As for the Zimmerman letter---that was more of a


strategic blunder on Germany’s part---an empty and self-destructive threat—


and the US almost certainly saw it as such.


      German belligerence, including the Zimmerman letter, were used by


American propagandists to rally the American public in favor of war with


Germany. But beyond that, they were not legitimate reasons for the US to


enter the war nor were they were among the causes of its doing so. of the


US’s entry into the War.


      Be it noted that, even though the US did have good economic reasons


for going to war with Germany, it doesn’t follow that these reasons were to


any degree what caused the US to go to war with Germany. In all likelihood,


they  were  not  among  the  causes  (though  they  may  have  served  as


justifications after the fact). The real causes lay in Wilson’s psychology—


specifically in his concern for his deteriorating public image. During his time


in office, Wilson was ridiculed as a weakling and coward (by, among others,


former  President  Theodore  Roosevelt)  for  not  responding  to  Germanbelligerence  with  American  aggression.  The  content  of  these  accusations


wasn’t that Wilson was failing to protect the US from danger; it was that


Wilson was besmirching the dignity of the United States by making it look


weak. Germany was not much more of a threat to the US in 1917 than Iraq


was a threat to the US in 2001; but if George W. Buch hadn’t attacked Iraq in


2001, he would have opened himself to accusations, however ill-founded, of


cowardice  and  weakness;  and  Wilson  was  in  a  similar  situation  vis-à-vis


Germany.  So  to  protect  his  public  image,  Wilson  had  to  go  to  war  with


Germany. And that was the actual cause of America’s entry into WW1.


      Wilson did not openly admit that he was simply knuckling under to


political pressure. He claimed that war with Germany was necessary to ‘make


the world safe for democracy.’ Germany was an autocracy; the Allies were


democracies; therefore, so Wilson claimed, war with Germany was necessary


to protect democracy. This was Wilson’s pitch when seeking a declaration of


war before Congress.


      But a pitch is all it was. Wilson himself obviously didn’t believe it,


given that he had thus far kept the US out of the war, even being reelected on


an anti-war platform. Wilson was simply capitulating. The purpose of pro-


democracy rhetoric was to make it seem as though his decision to go to war


was standing by his principles, when in actuality it was about forfeiting them.


        Nonetheless, even though the causes of the US’s entry into WWI layprimarily  in  Woodrow  Wilson’s  frail  ego,  the  US  did,  as  previously


discussed, have legitimate reasons for going to war. Whether either the US or


the world in general benefited from the former’s involvement in WWI is a


question for another time.

                The Economics of Higher Education in the 21st Century


 


                                              Part I


 


        Introduction to Part I


 


      In the first part of this two-part work, the economics of higher


education are explained. It is made clear how a university’s business model


differs from that of a company that has to compete on the open market, and


on this basis it is explained:


 


      (i) Why universities are in no way threatened by low retention rates


and graduation rates;


      (ii) Why universities cannot significantly improve or otherwise alterthe quality of their educational services without imperiling their very


existences;


      (iii) Why universities do not have to improve the quality of their


educational services;


      (iv) Why universities couldn’t improve the quality of their services


even if they wanted to;


      (v) Why the fact that many universities have low retention- and


graduation-rates does not a represent a business opportunity, or opportunity


of any other kind, for anyone, whether inside or outside of academia; and


      (vi) Why principles of Knowledge Management (KM) that are so


useful when it comes to helping businesses that compete on the open market


are completely useless, and indeed of negative utility, when it comes to


helping universities solve their problems.


 


      In the second part of this work, it is explained how to construct an


online university that is both lucrative and provides instruction that is faster,


better, cheaper, and more useful than the instruction provided by any existing


(or possible) brick-and-mortar university. It is also explained how the


principles of KM can be used to optimize such a university, once it is up and


running.


         Retention-rates and Graduation-rates: Introductory Remarks


 


      A university’s retention rate is the percentage of students who stay


after the first year. A university’s graduation rate is the percentage of students


who graduate within six years of enrollment. These numbers never coincide,


but they track each other. Universities with high retention rates have high


graduation rates, and universities with low retention rates have low


graduation rates.


        Retention rates are necessarily at least as high as graduation rates and


in practice are always higher. Also, even if a university has a graduation rate


of 0%, as is the case with a number of institutions, it doesn't follow that


nobody graduates from it, only that nobody does so within six years of


enrollment.


 


      Do Graduation- and Retention-rates Matter?


 


      From a financial perspective, a university has relatively cogent reasons


to want a high retention rate: when a student doesn’t enroll for a second year,


that university loses business, and it doesn’t when he does. A university has


less strong reasons to want a high graduation rate. If a student comes back


year after year and never graduates, the university makes more money than itdoes if he graduates.


      All of this said, universities with low graduation and retention rates


almost always tend to stay in business. Great Basin College in Nevada has a


retention rate of 4% and a graduation rate of 0%, but it is not in financial


trouble. And Great Basic is not an exception. There are many institutions of


higher learning with graduation rates of 0% and retention rates that are only


marginally higher, and yet not a single one of them is going out of business.


      Would universities with low retention rates like to have higher


retention rates? Of course. Do they need to have higher retention rates?


Evidently not. Is there anything they can do to increase their retention rates?


That is the question. The answer: No. If a university made the systemic


changes to itself necessary to improve retention rates, it would lose most of


its existing customer base. In the pages to come, it will be explained why this


is so, but the main ideas are readily stated.


      Consider the case of Texas College, a private, religious college, only


10% of whose students major in STEM (Science, Math, Engineering,


Technology). Texas College has a 51% retention rate and a 6% graduation


rate. 6% is an extremely low graduation rate: the national average is 53%.


51% is a relatively low retention rate: the national average is around 80%.


Why does Texas College have such low retention and graduation rates? One


very distinct possibility is that students question whether their earnings aftergraduation will compensate for the expenses incurred in the course of getting


a Texas College degree.


      In light of this, suppose that Texas College decided to improve its


retention rates by making its programs of study more practical---by making


them such that those who completed them were better able to compete in the


workforce. Would student retention increase? Maybe. Graduation rates?


Perhaps. But such changes would alienate 90% of their current customer


base.


      Texas College is not a singularity; it is the rule, not the exception.


Universities would as a rule lose far more customers than they would gain


were they to change their courses of such in such a way as to make them


financially more worth doing. It will now be explained why this is so.


 


        Open-market Companies (OMC’s): How they Differ from Universities


 


      Let us refer to companies that compete in the open market as ‘open


market companies' (or OMC's). Such companies include Nike, Oscar Meyer,


Microsoft, and Hyundai. There is one very important difference between


universities and OMC's. OMC's sell products and services. That is what


people pay them for. That is all they pay them for. That is not what people


pay universities for. Universities pay people for degrees. That is whatuniversities sell, and that is what people pay them for; and with relatively


minor qualifications, that is all that people pay them for.


        Universities provide instruction, and they may also provide other


services. But people pay them for degrees and for nothing besides. Consider


the following hypothetical. William & Mary magically improves the quality


of its instruction 100% and it cuts its tuition in half: but it stops issuing


degrees. So whatever it is that one can currently learn at William & Mary


about physics, psychology or any other subject, one can now learn twice as


well for half as much money. But one cannot get a degree in that subject from


William & Mary. Under these circumstances, William & Mary’s enrollment


rate would plummet, possibly to zero. And its enrollment would plummet to


zero if it ceased to give out degrees and it either failed to lower tuition or


managed to improve instruction.


      William & Mary is a reputable institution, and the points just made are


even more brazenly true of less reputable institutions. What would happen to


Great Basin College in Nevada if it ceased to give out degrees? Or to Dalton


State? Or to Oglala Lakota College? Their enrollments would instantly drop


to zero. In actuality, each of these colleges does give out degrees and each is


financially doing extremely well. Moreover, each of these colleges has a


graduation rate of 0% (meaning that 0% of their students graduate within six


years); each has a retention rate in the single digits, and none of them does agood job of guaranteeing high ($60,000+) incomes for its graduates. But each


is not only financially stable but positively flourishing.


 


      Colleges Sell Degrees, not Instruction


 


      Imagine the following. Max is a mathematical genius who has


completely mastered his discipline. (We won’t worry about how he did this.)


He is as good a mathematician as any human being alive. But he doesn’t have


a college degree, and he has never attended college. What can Max do


professionally? He cannot be a professor. He cannot publish in academic


journals. He cannot be a high-school teacher. He cannot work for an online


tutoring agency. He could conceivably work as a freelancer, but he will lack


credibility and will have trouble getting clients.


      If Max wants to ply his trade, he needs a degree, the same way a


construction worker needs a union card. So he has to go to college. And if he


does go to college, why does he do it? To learn? No. To get a degree. He


probably will learn while at college (though he may learn a lot less than if he


were not in college, since he may very well be better at teaching himself than


his professors are at teaching him).


      To be sure, Max doesn’t have to go to college. He can become a


plumber, a police officer, or an enlisted man in the military. He can alsobecome a comedian, or an actor, or an entrepreneur. But he cannot be a


mathematician and be paid for it. (He can do it for free, with the qualification


that nobody will read what he’s writing, let alone pay for it.) Nor can he have


a white-collar job, unless he succeeds as an entrepreneur, which is not likely,


given that his lack of a degree will diminish his credibility in the eyes of


investors and will also make it unlikely that he will acquire the kind of


professional experience that is typically a prerequisite for knowing what the


market wants. In any case, if Max does get a degree---even if while getting it


he learns nothing and indeed becomes less intelligent---it will make it


possible for him to ply his trade and will open up an entire world of


additional professional possibilities.


      Of course, even if Max doesn't get a college degree, he is not


completely without hope, since, being a genius, he is relatively likely to pull


off the financial equivalent of a hole-in-one. But most people are not


geniuses; so let us now consider a hypothetical that makes it clear what


happens to non-geniuses who don't have degrees. Jane is a person of average


or marginally above intelligence who has a degree in psychology. Tammy is


exactly as intelligent as Jane, both psychologically and otherwise, but does


not have a college degree. For Jane, the possibilities are endless. She can


become a social worker or a licensed therapist. She can go to law school. She


can become a Federal Agent. She can get an MBA and become a corporatebureaucrat who is making $120,000/year by the age of 30. She is not


guaranteed any of these outcomes, of course, but they are available to her.


      But what about Tammy? What are her options? She cannot become a


licensed therapist. She cannot work for a corporation, except in a menial


capacity. She cannot be a social worker. She cannot go to law school. She is


quite stuck. Can she become an entrepreneur? Technically, yes. But


entrepreneurs have a success rate of 1%; and most of that 1% tend to be


intellectually gifted and also have to have college degrees, as well as years of


college-degree-based professional experience.


      Would it make a difference if, instead of being intellectually average,


Tammy were in the top 10% of the population? Yes—but not much. Her lack


of a degree would bar her from pretty much all white-collar employment, and


if she tried her hand at entrepreneurship, she would still be even less likely


than most entrepreneurs at succeeding. If Tammy wants white-collar


employment, she can try her hand at selling insurance or real estate—and is


unlikely to succeed at either, simply because, popular conceptions to the


contrary, success-rates in such professions are extremely low. 95% of people


who try to succeed as an insurance salesman quit within a year; more than


quit within three years. Similar figures hold of real estate.[1] And those who


‘succeed’ are likely to be making $20,000/year, working 70 hours/week.


      Setting aside long-shot possibilities, Tammy only has two choices:work in a blue-collar capacity (as a police officer, plumber, secretary, or


some such) or go to college. True—if she goes to college, she is likely to rack


up debt. But, first of all, she will not even have to begin paying off that debt


for many years; and during the intervening years, she can live well, taking


classes she enjoys and living a well-funded, leisurely lifestyle. Moreover,


even after she has to start paying off her student loans, she will have the


option of doing white collar work—of working as a teacher, executive,


consultant, or stock-broker. To be sure, she may have some ‘down-time’


working at Starbucks. But as long as she has that degree, she has options: she


has the option of going to business school, of working as a supervisor at a


company, of getting her Master's in Social Work, or of being a teacher. And


some such option is very likely to materialize. And even during her darkest


hours as a ‘barista', she is in a very different position from her fellow baristas


who don't have college degrees. She is passing through; they are not.


      One often hears about college graduates working at Starbucks and


stuck with massive student loans. These horror stories are no doubt


oftentimes true. What isn't true is that it's not worth it to go to college. In


some ways, college is a lottery. If one majors in political science at an


undistinguished institution, one is not guaranteed the ability to pay off one's


student loans any time soon. Does that mean that one shouldn't go to college?


No, it does not. And one should go to college-for several reasons. First of all,it is not always a lottery: someone with a degree in chemical engineering is


not rolling the dice. Second, even when it is a lottery, it is a lottery worth


playing: the proverbial political science graduate from a low-tier school is


more than able to get a reasonably decent white-collar job sooner or later.


Third, it is a lottery that one can always pull out of: a first- or second-year


political science major at a no-name can drop out and cut her losses. She can


also switch majors, switch schools, or both. Also, she can hedge by taking a


few semesters off, then resume studies, all the while considering other career


options or educational tracks and testing the employment waters.


      People with degrees have options, and people without degrees don’t.


[2] People with useful degrees from high-prestige institutions have many


very good options; people with useless degrees from low prestige institutions


have fewer options and they are not as good—but they are still good in


absolute terms, and they are still plentiful. People without degrees do not


have options. They can hustle or they can have blue collar jobs. It does not


matter how intelligent or skillful they are: without that piece of paper, they


are stuck.


      Colleges sell those degrees. That is what they do. Colleges also


provide instruction. Sometimes that instruction is good, and sometimes it's


useful; usually, it's neither. Either way, that isn't what students are paying for.


They are paying for the degree. And since that is what they are paying for,they are willing to put up with very low-quality instruction. In fact, setting


aside the 15% or so of students who major in engineering, nursing, and the


like, students don't want particularly high-quality instruction: high-quality


instruction is demanding, and since they are paying for degrees, they want to


have to jump through as few hoops as possible to get those degrees.


      To be sure, students are willing to jump through some hoops: students


do want to believe that their degrees have meaning. And in some cases, those


degrees actually do have to have meaning, since the student in question is


planning on entering a field, such as dentistry or engineering, where he won't


be able to function if he doesn't have the requisite knowledge. Also, there are


some students who, though not intending to go into practical fields, actually


do want to hone their intellects while in college. And if colleges improved


instruction—if they made it more demanding and if they made those who


received it more economically competitive---they would indeed attract more


of a certain kind of student: they would attract more savants and truth-


seekers, as well as aspiring doctors and engineers. But for each such student


that they attracted, they would lose ten students in their existing customer


base.


 


        Enrollment-rates Matter: Retention- and Graduation-rates Don’t


       It is assumed that retention-rates must stay above a certain level for a


university to be financially stable. If that is true, the rate in question is


extremely low. There are many universities with retention rates of in the


single digits that are financially perfectly fine[3]. To name just a few:


 


      Great Basin College, Nevada


        Oklahoma State University Inst. of Technology, Okmulgee


      Sam Houston State University, Huntsville, TX


      Texas A&M University, Commerce


      Texas A&M International University, Laredo


      Alabama State University, Montgomery


      Macon State College, Macon, GA


      Dalton State College, Dover, DE


 


      In fact, there is does not appear to be a single case of a university


failing because of low retention rates, even though there are many that have


retention rates that are close to zero.


      This is possible because it isn't retention rates that matter: it is


enrollment rates. If enough people enroll, then the university is financially


ok. It is assumed that if retention rates are low enough, then not enough


people will enroll—the idea being that no one would want to enroll at auniversity that, for whatever reason, is failing to hold onto the vast majority


its incoming freshmen. But this is neither a theoretical necessity nor, as it


turns out, an empirical fact. If a university has an extremely low retention


rate, one possibility is that it is alienating the students who don’t come back


(by being incompetent, expensive, inhospitable, or otherwise deficient). But


that is not the only possibility.


      Suppose that a university’s target-customer is somebody who


desperately wants a college degree but is financially or intellectually just on


the cusp of being able to complete a college degree. It may well that for every


hundred such people who enroll, only four are able to make it to the second


year. When compared to Harvard, with its 98% retention rate, such a


university might seem to be doing badly. But from a business-viewpoint, a


1/25 batting average isn’t necessarily bad: many businesses operate on the


assumption that most people are just ‘window-shopping.’


      Also, the students who don’t come back are not exactly window-


shopping, since they are paying handsomely for the time they are there. In


fact, since most of them drop out before completing the first year, they are


paying not only for the time they are there but also for a great deal of time


they are not there, with the university simply pocketing the difference. Plus,


soon-to-be drop-outs tend to make rather minimal financial demands on


universities: they tend not to go to office-hours, not to submit homework, andin general not to use university-resources.


      Further, if a university has a 4% retention rate, it will scale down its


services and set its prices accordingly. It will not pay for faculty, facilities,


and so on for the students who aren’t going to stay. Moreover, it will set its


prices so that those who do stay are paying to offset any losses generated by


those who didn’t.


      Again, there is nothing unusual about this from a business viewpoint.


A successful angel investor may invest a small amount in 100 companies,


knowing that 99 of will failing and also knowing that the one that succeeds


will make up for the others. Many companies give out free samples, knowing


that they will more than make for their losses as long as one person in a


hundred eventually buys.


      Finally, universities with extremely low retention rates tend to have


extremely high acceptance rates; and they also tend to have moderately high


enrollment rates, since the students they accept have limited options. As a


result, they do a lot of business, despite their low retention rates.


      Of course, when people that a given university has a 4% retention rate,


they then to assume that it wants a higher retention rate. But, first of all, even


if it wants a higher retention rate, it doesn't necessarily need it. Second, it


may not want a higher retention rate, since it may only be able to


accommodate 4% those who enroll and would actually incur losses ifretention rates increased. Third, there may not be anything it can do to


increase its retention rates that wouldn’t alienate most of its customer base.


Fourth, even if there is something that such a university can do to increase its


retention rate, it is very unlikely to be able to change itself in such a way as to


be able to do it. Let us now clarify this last point.


 


        Universities: Their Distinctive Business-model


 


      An OMC can turn on a dime. It can replace its entire labor force. It can


start making new products. It can fire its CEO. Its CEO can fire every besides


himself. An OMC has to be flexible, because it has to change its product to


meet constantly changing consumer demands. But universities sell degrees—


nothing else.[4] In order for people to buy those degrees, the instruction they


provide must on average exceed certain standards. When averaged over time


and when averaged over all of the courses being taught, instruction must rise


above a certain threshold. If the quality of instruction in every subject at a


given university were always execrable, then that university might well


eventually come to grief (though it would not necessarily do so: see below).


But a university won’t necessarily come to grief if it always provides


execrable instruction in some subjects or if it sometimes provides execrable


instructions in all subjects. The instruction has to be just good enough, incertain respects in certain subjects at certain junctures, for there to be a


perception on the part of enough people that it is worth having a degree from


that institution.[5]


      A corollary is that most of a university’s business depends on its


providing instruction that is on average lackluster. Most students at a given


university are just buying a degree; only a few are really working for that


degree. And that degree has prestige, and is therefore worth buying, because


of the efforts of those few. Consequently, the ideal situation for a university


is when its degrees have prestige and as few people as possible are actually


giving them that prestige. For so long as that degree has prestige, the way to


maximize enrollment is to have as few students giving it prestige and as


many as possible merely benefiting from that prestige. The more students are


expected to be responsible for the prestige of that degree, the more


prospective students are likely to shy away from enrolling at that university


in the first place. And the fewer students responsible for it giving it prestige--


-provided that somebody is giving it prestige—the larger the university’s


customer-base.


      When people buy a lawn-mower or a pair of running shoes, what they


are buying actually has to be good; there is no other reason to buy it. But a


degree from Harvard doesn’t have to be backed by good instruction. Suppose


that someone gets a degree from Harvard by cheating on all his papers andexams (without ever getting caught) and without learning anything. That


degree is still an enormously powerful piece of social capital. And that


person, even though he cheated his way through college, is far more likely


than those without a Harvard degree (or equivalent, e.g. a Yale degree) to be


accepted to business school, to get a job at an investment bank, etc.


      In light of these points, suppose that reasonably prestigious university


X does the following. X eliminates tenure. It requires its faculty members to


make sure that their students pass objective tests (tests that have objectively


correct answers and that are not issued by those same faculty members). If a


given faculty member fails to get enough of his students to pass, he is fired


and replaced by someone who will hopefully do the job.


      What would happen to X? Instruction would certainly improve, and


that might well bring in more of a certain kind of student. But most of X's


prospective students would be alienated by it. Most of X's students want the


prestige of a degree from X without having to go through four years of


intellectual boot camp.


      The changes just described would certainly benefit people who did


end up attending X, and it might well make those people more employable


than the X students who preceded them. But would those changes benefit X?


No. X would lose most of its future students and many of its current students.


Contrariwise, in its current condition, X, with its on average quite shoddyfaculty and sup-par courses, is probably doing extremely well financially.


      Suppose that X took a middle-path. Suppose that, without turning


itself into an intellectual boot camp, X improved the quality of its instruction


to the point by a solid margin, so that it was no longer just doing enough to


give prestige to its degrees. If X did this, it would not lose as many as it


would if it became an intellectual boot camp, with uniformly good professors,


but it would still lose a good chunk of those students, and it would be in a


much worse situation, enrollment-wise, than it would be if it simply did the


bare minimum.


      In general, colleges depend on their providing instruction that is on


average just good enough and, consequently, in their demanding, on average,


just enough of their students. If they turn themselves into genuinely


efficiently educational entities, they will alienate most of their present and


future customers. If they even try to make themselves more than just good


enough to preserve the prestige-level of their degrees, they will alienate


enough of their customer-base to appreciably worsen their financial situation.


They optimal path for universities is to issue degrees that are prestigious and


to provide instruction that is just good enough to be compatible with that


objective. A corollary is that universities will often have rather low retention


rates. If a university is doing just enough, it will inevitably sometimes slip


below that threshold, with the result that students bail. 


      How Useful Do Students Really Want Their Educations To Be?


 


      ‘But surely it would be better,’ it will be said, ‘if universities


restructured themselves in such a way that, when their retentions got too low,


they could make the necessary changes to themselves?' Better for whom? If a


given university changed itself in this way, that means it would be able to


letter the ax fall whenever times got tough: nobody would be safe; any given


professor or administrator could lose his job. Also, if an organization


becomes such that it can fire people during lean times, then it can also fire


people during good times: if a given university made itself able to right-size


itself when retention was too low, then anyone could lose their job at any


time, and some people would lose their jobs during good times. And nobody


at a university wants that. [6]


      ‘But there is another, less risky way that universities could guarantee


higher retention rates for themselves,' it will be said. ‘If they simply made


their graduates more employable—and managed to do so without making


their undergraduate curricula alienatingly difficult--then everybody would be


happy: universities would have high retention rates; professors and


administrators would continue to have job-security, and students would have


an assurance that their degrees would pay for themselves.'      As we’ve already pointed out, it wouldn’t be easy, or even possible,


for universities to do this. But there is an even deeper issue that we haven’t


yet discussed. People want to be employed, obviously, but how employable


do they really want to be? Suppose that Smith is employed because he is


employable---because he is useful, in other words. That means that he


employed only as long as he is useful. He might lose his job because of some


slight change in technology or in company objectives. Before Wix came


along, there were armies of people who made a decent living building


websites. All but 1% of those people became useless when Wix and


WordPress became available. They had to repurpose themselves, possibly


completely retrain themselves.


      Also, if Smith is employed because he is useful, that means that, in


order to keep his job, he actually has to be useful: he has to solve problems;


he has to do whatever has to be done: he has to live by his wits. He has to


figure out the left side of the building is sinking; he has to update the


company's computer system by the start of the next business day; he has to


reconstruct his patient's face; and so on. Is this what people want to be doing


when they are 50, 60, 70? Nurses are useful, and a 60-year-old registered


nurse spends her day cleaning out infected wounds and mopping up


biohazardous material. A life of usefulness is not easy.


      What most college students want, at least if their eventual careers areany indication, is to be relatively useless and employed. Explanation: If


somebody who is useless has stable employment, their employment isn’t


contingent on their being useful. Nobody expects redundant bureaucrats and


middle managers to be useful; that is not why they are employed. And their


jobs exceptionally safe precisely because those jobs are not about being


useful.


      When jobs serve very well-defined practical functions, they are easily


lost. If somebody’s living depends on his being able to produce great


paintings or thought, or on his being able to hit a hole in one or to get


acquittals in unwinnable cases, his career is over if he falls just slightly short


once or twice. By contrast, if somebody’s career is about being a bureaucrat


in some corporation or some government agency, and it isn’t quite clear what


he does, he can fall short all he wants: his employment has nothing to do with


his not falling short. If somebody is a mid-level lawyer who has an ill-defined


role in some large corporate case, his job is relatively secure. If somebody is


employed only as long as he gets acquittals, his job is not secure.


      Also, if one is employed only because he is useful, his earnings tend to


wax and wane with his degree of usefulness. If somebody makes a living


solving math problems, and somebody comes along who can do the job just


slightly faster, the first person’s earnings are driven down. A corollary is that


people who make their living by being useful tend not to have inflatedsalaries. By contrast, if somebody is a small part of an organization, with an


ill-defined function within that organization, his earnings tend not to be


hewed to his usefulness (or lack thereof), and he may consequently have an


enormously inflated salary.[7]
