      Most college graduates tend to have well-paid jobs with poorly


defined functions. They end up, to be blunt, being pencil pushers within


corporations or government agencies, and are extremely well-paid for doing


little more than showing up and not making waves. They are not paid to be


useful in the way that a plumber or doctor is useful.


      And that is what most college students want. They don't want their


future incomes to depend on their always being useful. They would like to


know that when they are 55, they can have a comfortable income and a nice


lifestyle without having to prove their usefulness every day. If they end up


being plastic surgeons, they will have to prove their usefulness: nobody pays


a plastic surgeon who botches the job. If they end up working as mid-level


managers in corporate finance, they won't have to prove their usefulness.


      So if colleges made their students more ‘employable' by making them


more ‘useful', they would alienate most of those students. Political science


majors know that their major does not make them useful, and that is part of


the reason they do it. A ‘successful' political science major tends to end up


with a well-paying job that does not have a well-defined function and that isfor that very reason relatively secure. A political science major does run a


heavy risk of having no employment for some time after graduation. But the


truth is he probably will end up with pretty much just the kind of white-collar


job that he expected to have---a good paying job that has no well-defined


function or performance-benchmarks and is therefore secure. A computer


science major is certainly better able to find work, and probably has a wider


range of jobs to choose from; but those jobs have well-defined functions and


  performance-benchmarks and are correspondingly insecure.


 


      The Paradox of Macroeconomic Efficiency


 


      Many people assume that if most of the work-force consists of useless


pencil pushers, that cannot last for long—that there is some kind of


employment ‘bubble’ that will soon burst. Certainly, if a micro-economy—an


economy of 100 people---consisted of people who were not pulling their own


weight, it would not last long. In tiny self-contained villages thousands of


years, people tended to have to be useful in some very well-defined way.


      But in a micro-economy, there is very little division of labor, and labor


tends to be extremely inefficient, that being why nobody can ‘slack off.’ But


in economies of scale, there is enormous division of labor, and only a small


percent of the population actually has to produce. The more advanced aneconomy is, the greater the percentage of people in it who can be useless. In


Cambodia under Pol Pot, there was 100% employment, because everybody


had to be employed, and everybody had to be employed because production


was so inefficient. In Britain in 1820, there very few useless jobs, but the jobs


that people had tended to be difficult and unpleasant. In the United States in


2019, most jobs are useless. They are useless because they can be useless,


because the small part of the population that is productive is so productive


that the rest doesn’t have to be.


      So yes, if the percentage of the population that was actually useful


dropped too close to zero, then the economy would fall apart. But that hasn’t


happened yet and there is no reason to think that it will happen any time


soon. And until it does happen, it is not irrational for people to do easy


majors and bide their time after college until they land a well-paid sinecure.


Contrariwise, if colleges got rid of easy majors and insisted on producing


only useful undergraduates, they would alienate those students.


      But suppose that someone majors in political science at Macon State


and finds himself unable to get a job after graduation. Such people often get


vocational certifications; they become certified emergency medical


technicians, accountants, or computer-technicians. This is extremely


common. When this happens, does it mean that the person in question was


wrong to get a degree in political science (or religious studies…) at MaconCollege (or VCU…)? It obviously means that it didn’t pan out for them, but it


was still very likely a risk worth taking. Had it worked out, they would have


had an easy, stable $75,000/year job. Given that it didn’t work out, they have


some student debt, but nothing irreparable. Plus, many people enjoy their


time in college, however little that time contributed to their being able to


make a living. In any case, although majoring in a non-practical subject at a


low-tier (or even a high-tier) school may not immediately have a good


outcome, it is often a risk that it is rational to take.


 


      When in Doubt, Drop Out: Dispelling the Myth that Only Losers Drop


Out


 


      Mention is often made of the ‘tragedy’ of high college dropout rates.


But is this ‘tragedy’ really a tragedy? No. To be sure, it certainly could be a


mistake for someone to drop out. It is indeed a mistake for someone to drop


out if he is just one term-paper away from a degree that will open vast


professional vistas. But when people drop out, it is usually for good reasons,


and it isn't a tragedy for anyone.


      Harvard has a drop-out rate of close to zero. Virginia Commonwealth


University (VCU) has a 60% drop-out rate. Sul Rock State has a 95% drop-


out rate. Explanation: A Harvard degree is worth the trouble 99% of the time,a VCU degree is worth the trouble 30% of the time, and a Sul Rock State


degree is worth the trouble 5% of the time. It isn’t successful engineering


majors who drop-out of VCU; nor is it successful nursing majors. It is people


who are barely getting by in political science or criminal justice. Much the


same is true of Sul Rock State. When people drop out, it is usually (not


always) because it isn’t worth it for them to stay. When people drop out from


such institutions, it may be to pounce on a job-opportunity that won’t last and


is better than what will be available to them when they graduate. And even if


they don’t have definite plans as to what they will do after they drop out, they


generally do not become indigent. They may become police officers or they


may go to trade school. When people drop out, it is usually because they


believe that they stand to lose more by staying in school than by dropping


out, and in most cases they are right.


      Also, dropping out is often part of a hedging strategy. People who


drop out of college can usually go back. And when people drop out, it is often


to ‘test the waters': they are not sure if their current college is worth the


trouble; so, they drop out to see whether they can do without a degree. If they


find that a degree is necessary, they are likely to return to college.


      It is not possible to become an investment banker or surgeon without a


college degree. But the people who drop out of college are usually not


destined for such positions. If they finish out their degrees in religious studiesor political science from VCU or Sul Rock State, they may become probation


officers, Community College Administrators, or mid-level managers at a


local firm. When they drop out, they may become plumbers, electricians,


computer-technicians, or police officers. And they may find the latter careers


more fulfilling than the former, and the latter may be also be as lucrative as


the former.


      So in most cases, dropping out is not a tragedy for the drop-out. Nor is


it a tragedy for the institution that was dropped out of. If a university has a


drop-out rate of 70%, it adjusts its service and prices accordingly. In any


case, there has not been a single case in the United States of a college


shutting down due to high drop-out rates.


 


          Knowledge-management: Introductory Remarks


 


      In recent years a new discipline has emerged called Knowledge


Management (KM); and for reasons that will become clear, KM is believed to


have the potential to help institutions become more efficient. It might


therefore be surmised that KM could help colleges increase low retention-


rates, the idea being that low retentions are a function of inefficiencies on the


part of colleges. In the second part of this work that KM certainly has the


ability to help construct alternatives to existing colleges. But when it comesto improving retention-rates at existing colleges, there is nothing for KM to


do.


      First of all, what is KM? In order for institutions to capitalize on


opportunities, they must be organized in such a way as to optimize the flow


of relevant information between their members. If there are people in the


Acme Bridge-building Company who know how to build bridges but don’t


know where bridges are needed, and there are Acme-employees who know


where bridges are needed but not how to build them, Acme will succeed if its


employees can share their knowledge and will fail otherwise. KM explains


how Acme must be organized to maximize the likelihood of such exchanges.


In general, KM explains how institutions must be organized if knowledge-


exchanges that must occur are to occur.


      KM can help when poor internal communications are preventing an


institution from accomplishing what it wants to accomplish. KM cannot help


when poor internal communications are not the issue or, of course, when


there simply is no issue. Therefore, KM cannot help universities, since there


is not much of an issue where they are concerned and since, so far as there is


one, poor internal communications are not responsible for it.


 


      Why Knowledge-management Cannot be of Assistance to Universities


       Unlike OMC’s, universities actually depend on poor internal


communications. University departments are highly isolated from and


fiercely independent of one another. On the rare occasions when different


departments cooperate, they do so only at specific junctures, in very


circumscribed ways, after months or years of meetings, and then only with


heavy reservations. By contrast, an OMC would simply fail if its different


departments were comparably isolated.


        Explanation: OMC’s are about providing optimal products and


services, whereas universities are about maintaining prestige, and prestige is


harder to maintain when information is allowed to flow than then when it is


sequestered. In any university, there are innumerable occasions when


students would be well-served by a class that was taught jointly by the


philosophy and psychology departments, or by the philosophy and economics


departments, or by the economics and African studies departments, and so


on. But such joint ventures almost never happen.


      Within their own departments, professors have virtually uncontested


authority, and they have a kind cult status. They cannot be called out, because


each student within that department depends on their good graces. But if a


philosophy professor teamed up with an economics professor, that


philosophy professor could (and probably would) be called out economics


students who were not under his thumb, and the economics professor mightbe called out by philosophy students who were not under his thumb.


Consequently, were departments not mutually isolated and were they in the


habit of cooperating with one another whenever students stood to benefit,


they would have to step up their game considerably to survive the consequent


scrutiny. A professor's survival, as it were, would be that much less prestige-


based and that much more competency-based. And the kind of professor


would do well in this kind of environment is the kind of professor would


demand a lot of his students. Some students do like this kind of professor;


most do not. And most of practically any given university's students would


bolt if that university's professors were replaced with the professors of the


kind who were always ready to take on new subjects and fresh challenges.


Contrariwise, the kinds of professors who do well in actual universities,


where they never have to teach students who are not strictly under their


thumb and where they teach the same material year in and year out, demand


relatively little of students.


      The kind of professor who is always looking for a new challenge is a


high-energy professor: he demands a lot of himself and will tend to demand a


lot of his students. The kind of professor who has his niche is happy to stay


there does not demand much of himself or (apart from a certain degree of


adulation in some cases) of his students. Students of a certain kind are drawn


to professors of the first kind, but most of a university's business comes fromstudents who are more comfortable with professors of the second kind.


Consequently, universities thrive on a low degree of communication between


departments and therefore, as it were, on a certain lack of knowledge-


management.


 


 


      Key Points


 


        Universities are extremely reluctant to change. Universities don't have


to change. Universities would alienate their customers as well as most of their


own  employees  if  they  did  change,  especially  if  those  changes  involved


making  them  better  at  teaching  their  students  and  at  making  them


employable. Universities are doing well financially and otherwise, despite


low  retention-  and  graduation  rates.  The  fact  that  many  universities  have


lower retention- and graduation-rates than they would like does not represent


much  of  a  business  opportunity  for  anyone.  Nor  does  it  represent  an


opportunity to do any real good, since making universities better would lower


their retention- and graduation-rates: making them better at teaching and at


producing employable graduates would be the kiss of death for them. Nor


does  it  represent  an  opportunity  to  try  out  principles  of  knowledge-


management,  since  universities  are  positively dependent on  poor  internalcommunications and therefore on systemically rooted failures of knowledge-


management.


 


 


        Conclusion of Part 1: How to Maximize Revenue by Optimizing


Education


 


      Now for some corollaries of these points. First, if one's desire is to


have a successful business venture, the way to do it is not to try to improve


the retention- and graduation-rates of existing universities. Second, and more


significantly, if one's objective is to improve education—to make it faster,


cheaper, better, and more useful---the way to do it is not to try to ‘fix' existing


universities:  they  are  happy  just  the  way  are  and  are  both  unwilling  and


unable to be fixed. In fact, the idea that one could march into a university and


fix it, and possibly even be paid to do so, is the very definition of absurdity.


Universities are they are, and that's the end of it. Apart from a few religions,


there are no institutions that are as unwilling to change and as resistant to


being tinkered with as universities. Universities do change, but slowly and


only to their own terms, which will make extremely little sense to people


with a bottom-line mentality. Finally, and most significantly, if one wants to


improve education and to make money doing so, there is at the current anenormous  opportunity.  Right  now  is  the  perfect  time  to  make  education


affordable, fast, effective, and also (for the owner of the educational service


in question) extremely lucrative. In the second part of the present work, it


will be described exactly how to do this, and it will be made clear how the


principles of knowledge management can integral to doing so.


 


 


          The Economics of Higher Education in the 21st Century Part II


 


 


        Introduction to Part II


 


      In this part of the book, we will design a university that provides fast,


reliable, and affordable service. For reasons that will be made clear, this


university will be online. This will university will be distinctive in a number


of other ways, all of which will be stated explicitly.


      We will refer to this hypothetical university as DMO (short for


‘digitize, mechanize, optimize’, the idea being that digitization and


mechanization will help to optimize this institution).


      DMO's structure is to a large extent rooted in principles of knowledge


management (KM). So we will begin by saying what KM and by stating theprinciples of KM that are relevant to our project.


 


      What is Knowledge-management (KM)?


 


      Any given person within any given institution needs to have


information in order to do his job properly. KM is the discipline is that


attempts to say how an institution must be organized if the people in it are to


have the highest possible chance of having the information that they need to


do their job.


      Here is an illustration. Smith, Jones, and Brown are the only members


of a three-member firm. Smith is having lunch with Green, a billionaire oil


tycoon and potential client, and Green says that he desperately needs


somebody who is an expert in petroleum engineering. As it happens, Jones is


the world's greatest petroleum engineer, but Smith doesn't know this and


therefore tells Green that he will ‘try to find a petroleum engineer' for him.


Disappointed with this lackluster answer, Green doesn't retain the services of


Smith's firm and they lose a billion-dollar account.


      This situation is the result of poor knowledge-management. The talent


was there, and so was the demand, but the company didn't know that it was


able to service that demand.


      What are some solutions? Smith-Jones-Brown (SJB) could haveweekly board meetings. SJB could institute policies that require a given


member to advise the others of any meetings with possible clients. SJB might


make their policy to send daily memos to one another.


      Being an academic discipline, KM is more interested in producing true


generalizations than it is solving particular problems had by specific


organizations. But those generalizations are legitimate if, and only if, they


can be used to solve such problems, and there is also no way to identify those


generalizations except by dealing with many specific cases.


 


      An Actual Company that Could Benefit from KM


 


      The example just given was obviously artificial. Here is an actual


example of a case where KM is needed to solve a problem. There is a


reasonably prominent online tutoring agency by the name of OneClass


(https://oneclass.com/). It hires reasonably talented people and offers them


what appear to be high rates of pay (e.g. $45 to help with an assignment that


ordinarily should take around one hour to complete). But tutors find for one


hour that they spend with a student, they have to spend around five justifying


their answers to supervisors who can and will withhold pay indefinitely,


usually under the pretext of ensuring that the tutor complies with OneClass’s


rather extensive and vaguely defined procedures. As a result, instructors ofmerit don’t stay for long, and students are left with shoddy and (thanks to all


of the bureaucratic bloat) expensive service. As a result, clients are leaving


OneClass or simply avoiding it, and revenues are falling. Instructors cannot


communicate directly with upper-management; only middle-management can


do that. But the instructors are the ones who both know what the problems


are and have an incentive to make upper management aware of them; so that


information is not relayed to the right people, and the company is


hemorrhaging money.


      KM is supposed to tell us whether this problem can be solved and, if


so, how to solve it. KM is also supposed to tell us how to avoid having


problems like this in the first place. Let us now discuss each of these points.


 


      Who Exactly Sounds the KM-alarm?


 


      A KM-expert cannot be of service to OneClass unless OneClass asks


for his help. For argument’s sake, let us suppose that this happens. A


competent KM-expert would probably suggest downsizing middle-


management, which would free up money, making it possible to charge


students less and hire better tutors. He would also suggest eliminating


bureaucratic hurdles that the instructors have to jump through that waste their


time and drive them away from the company.      Of course, there may not be any single person at a given company who


can decide to enlist the help of a KM-expert, let alone implement the changes


that a KM-expert would suggest making. And if the necessary executive


power is shared by a number of different people, as is often the case, they


may not agree to hire a KM-expert; and if they do hire one, they may not


agree as to whether to implement his recommendations. After all, a KM-


expert might recommend changing the structure of the company in a way that


deprives many of these decision-makers of their power. He may even


recommend firing many of them. They will know this and not hire him. And


if a given self-described KM-expert can be trusted not to recommend


downsizing or otherwise changing management-structure, then he probably


isn’t very good at what he does, since knowledge-management within an


organization cannot be appreciably improved without changing the very


structure of that organization.


 


      KM as Preventative Measure


 


      This brings us to the second scenario. Suppose that somebody wants to


start an online tutoring service that avoids the problems that OneClass has.


Such a person might conceivably hire a KM-expert (or, more likely, use his


own KM-expertise) to design his company in such a way that those problemsdon't arise. In practice, this is what usually happens. Once a company already


exists, especially if it is large, there may not be any way to change that


company without the consent of the very people within that company who are


causing the problems. If the ACME Corporation is run by a board of four


equally powerful people, two of whom are ruining the company and two of


whom are not, they are unlikely to agree to implement the changes suggest by


a competent party who is brought in from the outside, assuming that they can


even agree to enlist such a person's help in the first place. In general, KM


problems are hard to fix but easy to avoid, and they are avoided by designing


companies properly. The mistake made by the people who designed


OneClass was to focus more on policing instructors than on hiring instructors


who don't need to be policed.


 


      KM in Relation to Organizations that Sell Results


 


      Our objective is to design a superior educational service. In this


section, we will state some principles of KM, along with principles of


economics and of simple common sense, that are relevant to that objective.


          Knowledge-management is possible when the organization in question


has definite objectives, and when it does not have definite objectives,


knowledge-management is as difficult as those objectives are vague. If acompany’s objective is to help people to pass some assessment test, then it


tends to be clear whether a given piece of information is worth


communicating to other company members. If a company's objective is to


‘improve wellness' or ‘broaden minds,' then it tends not to be clear whether a


given piece of information is worth relaying.


      When an organization is in the business of providing results,


objectives are well-defined, with correspondingly positive consequences for


knowledge-management within that organization. When an organization


provides services, objectives tend to be vaguely defined, with


correspondingly negative consequences for knowledge-management within


that organization.


      When an organization sells results, prices tend to drop, and when it


sells services, they tend to rise. The first computers were expensive. But once


the first one was built, it was clear what had to be done and it was only a


matter of time before the process was streamlined, the result being computers


that are thousands of times more powerful than the first ones and thousands


of times less expensive. By contrast, when you a hire law firm to settle a


contract dispute, you are not paying for results, since results cannot be


guaranteed in such a situation, and you are therefore paying for services.


Since the law firm therefore profits by selling services, it has every incentive


to draw out the process as much as possible, resulting in soaring costs foryou. In general, when results are sold, there is no money in services, and


services have to be streamlined; and when services are sold, there is no


money in results, and services have to be inflated.


 


      KM in Relation to Organizations that Sell Services


 


      When you hire somebody to build a pool for you, there is a well-


defined objective, and that is what you are paying for. Services are priced


into the end-result, but you are paying for the end result, not the services: if


no pool is built, you are likely to sue the contractor and he will end up paying


you, not the other way around.


      But when services, as opposed to results, are provided, many different


results are ipso facto possible: in a legal dispute, there are innumerably many


possible results intermediate between complete success and complete failure.


A criminal case can result in no time served and twenty years’ probation; five


years served and three years of community service; two years served and


$5,000,000 in fines; and so on.


      Vague benchmarks lead to vague communications, and knowledge


management is only as good as benchmarks are clearly defined. But this is


not necessarily a problem for providers of services. Inefficiency and poor


internal communications are lucrative when the client is paying for services,and they are expensive only when he is paying for results. If a lawyer is


billing by the hour, then he has everything to gain and nothing to lose if he


gets stuck in traffic or his secretary misplaces a file.


      It is only when results are being paid for that the costs of such


inefficiencies cannot be passed onto the client. If a plumber says he’ll fix a


pipe for $100, and it turns out to take him 10 hours to do the job, he can only


charge $100, and he is likely to be lowballed by the competition if he hedges


by quoting a higher price.


        Results-providers compete on efficiency, and their prices tend to be


bid down. Service-providers compete on inefficiency, and their prices tend to


be bid up. A lawyer cannot tell a client what he will get for him. He can only


tell him what he will do for him. He cannot promise an acquittal. But he can


promise to hire around-the-clock private detective; he can promise to


subpoena 100 different witnesses; he can promise to hire a voice-expert; and


so on. So if one lawyer tries to lowball another, it will tend to be not offering


some of these services, which obviously diminishes the client’s faith in him.


A better strategy is for him to offer more services than the first: he’ll get a


team of private detectives, he’ll personally fly to Washington to speak with


the attorney general, and so on. In general, whereas results-markets are


inherently efficient, service-markets are inherently inefficient.


           Service-organizations Depend on Poor KM


 


      When people within a given organization have an incentive to block


communications within it, information tends to be blocked, and people within


service organizations tend to have such incentives. Such organizations make


money by multiplying and drawing out services. Therefore, the management


profits from the inefficiencies that good communication eliminates, and


people within such an organization are paid to create such inefficiencies.


Such an organization profits by having a middle-manager who withholds


information from underlings in order to force tasks to be repeated and in


order to justify various quality-controls. It is only to the extent that an


organization profits from good internal communications that internal


communications are good.


 


      KM Impossible Unless Employment and Pay are Performance-


dependent


 


      When poor performance doesn’t lead to loss of employment,


performance tends to be poor, and performance tends to be good when poor


performance does lead to loss of employment. A corollary is that internal


communications tend to be bad when employment is guaranteed and goodwhen it isn’t.


      When salaries depend on performance, performance tends to be good,


and it tends to be bad when salaries do not depend on performance. A


corollary is that internal communications tend to be good when salaries are


performance-dependent and bad when they aren’t.


 


      No KM without Financial Transparency


 


      It is hard to know who is pulling their weight in an organization, or


exactly how much weight they are pulling, unless clients hire them directly.


Imagine the following. Firm 1 and Firm 2 are both engineering firms, but


there is an important difference between them. When clients go to Firm 1,


they cannot hire engineers directly: they have to hire Firm 1 as a whole, and


Firm 1 then assigns an engineer to them.


      But when clients go to Firm 2, they hire engineers directly. The


engineers who are hired then give a percentage of their earnings to Firm 2, in


exchange for equipment, permits, marketing, credibility, and other important


resources. It’s going to be very for Firm 1 to know who they should promote


and who they should hire. They can rely on reviews from clients, but those do


very little in the way of making it clear how much a given worker is really


doing. (A gruff engineer who single-handedly builds a skyscraper might getmiddling reviews, while an affable engineer who can barely build a birdhouse


gets stellar ones.) And if engineers in Firm 2 can set their own prices, it will


even more clear who is doing how much.


      Also, given that clients cannot hire engineers directly from Firm 1, its


engineers have to take the work that is given to them. That means that


somebody else (a middle manager) will decide whether to award a given


project to a given engineer. Projects will go the wrong people, and the talent


will be misdeployed and underdeployed. Also, given that the customer-


interface will be management, and not the talent itself, the latter will always


be laboring under a glass ceiling, making it hard for them to develop larger


projects and to maximize their contributions to the firm.


        Organization-internal communications are worthless unless they are


based on solid information as to how the organization in question can engage


the market. There is no better way for an organization to have such


information than for its employees to be able to offer their services directly to


clients. This isn’t always possible. No single engineer in an aircraft company


is going to be able to service clients. But it is possible where organizations


that provide instruction are concerned, for reasons that will soon be


discussed.


 


        Expense-padding in Relation to KM 


      When a business is legitimate, it does not inflate costs. Microsoft has


an enormous market-share because it gives people what they are paying for at


a low cost, and it would lose its market-share were it to pad expenses or


otherwise gouge its customers. When a business can provide what it says it


provides, it stands to make more money by keeping quality high and costs


low than by keeping costs high and quality low.


      Businesses are forced to pad and gouge when it isn't by providing the


service that they say they are providing that they make their money. For


example, most life-coaches don't do much of anything. Since they don't


provide a product, there is no way for them to provide that product more


efficiently. For them, the best way to make money is to make what they are


offering to seem important while being vague about it. Clients are lured in


with impressive but vague claims. Once they are there, some actual services


are dribbled out and mixed in with various unnecessary but expensive


services.


      A business of this kind thrives on inefficiency. It cannot give the


customer what he is paying for all at once, since the customer would then


know how little he was really getting. Legitimate services have to be dragged


out and interspersed with extraneous ones. A business of this kind is


concerned with managing expectations. It is not concerned with increasing itsown efficiency: in fact, it is concerned with decreasing it. If a business of this


kind consists of a handful of people, they may all be consciously in on this


fraud. It is certainly possible for Smith, Jones, and Brown to explicitly agree


with each other that they are going to defraud clients. But if such a business


is at all large, most of its employees will have to at least partially accept the


company’s own propaganda: otherwise, it will have trouble recruiting people


and trouble keeping them motivated once they are there. Such a company’s


internal communications therefore tend to be inefficient, since it isn’t clear


what the company does or therefore what there is to say about how it could it


do it better.


 


      A Corollary: Education Must be Digitized Whenever Possible


 


      A corollary is that when education can be digitized, it must be


digitized. Of course, not every kind of instruction can be digitized, at least


not at present. It is very difficult to teach somebody how to play the piano or


perform surgery over the internet. But usually it can be digitized; and should


be whenever possible, since doing so saves time and money and makes it


easy for people to purchase custom-made education from the best instructors


at the lowest possible price. If a university chooses not to digitize educational


services that can be digitized, that is because it isn't primarily by providinginstruction that it makes its money.


 


      DMO: A New and Better Kind of University


 


      Thanks to the points thus far made, we are now in a position to draw


up a blueprint for a new and better kind of institution of higher education. As


previously stated, we will refer to this hypothetical institution as DMO.


      The most important fact about DMO is that students pay for results,


not services. Therefore, a degree from DMO must be proof of competence.


DMO does not sell prestige; it sells competence.


      DMO is not meant to meant to replace existing brick-and-mortar


institutions. DMO is meant to provide maximally efficient and effective


instruction in every area that can be taught digitally, with several heavy


qualifications.


      The main qualification is that a degree from DMO is actual proof of


competence. It follows that DMO will not teach people how to be pilots,


surgeons or plumber. It also follows that DMO will not provide


accreditations in areas, such as history or religious studies, where a degree


cannot possibly constitute proof of competence.


      Another second qualification is that what DMO offers in the way of


instruction covaries in real time with what the market needs people to know.      Third, DMO will offer instruction (and accreditation) in a dramatically


wider range of subjects than any existing (or possible) brick and mortar


institutions. (This qualification is to some extent a corollary of the second.)


      Fourth, DMO will offer many different levels of accreditation in


practically any given of the areas in which it provides instruction. DMO will


offer bachelor’s, master’s and doctoral degrees; but it will offer many other


accreditations.


      Fifth, nobody who graduates from DMO is useless. DMO-graduates


may want to get additional degrees, but they won’t have to: they will already


be employable.


      Sixth, DMO’s objective is to produce people who are competent. It is


not to exclude incompetent people so that it can then take undeserved credit


for the merits of its graduates. Consequently, DMO will not exclude people.


DMO will regard unintelligent people who want a DMO-education as being


in the same category as sick people who go to a hospital: they are there to


improve themselves and will thus receive service.


 


      All Accreditations Examination-based


 


      At DMO, instructors do not issue grades. There are no grades. There


are accreditations. Accreditations are attained by taking examinations. Theseexaminations are graded anonymously (by computer, whenever possible).


They are designed and administered by independent third parties.


      The questions on these examinations have determinate answers. There


will be little or no disagreement among experts how a given question is to be


answered.


      The instructors have access to past accreditations exams. (In fact,


DMO will make such exams available to all students, and possibly to the


general public, free of charge.) But they do not have access to forthcoming


exams.


      One consequence of this arrangement is that there are many subjects


(e.g. history and religious studies) that DMO simply will not teach. Another


consequence is that the instructors at DMO are indeed instructors, not gate-


keepers. It does not matter whether your instructor likes you or what he


thinks of your work. He does not pass you or fail you. You pass if you pass


the accreditation exam and fail if you fail that exam. Your instructor's one job


is to get you to pass that exam. These points will be developed below.


 


      How DMO Turns Non-STEM Students into STEM Students


 


      DMO has two lines in the sand. First, whenever a degree is earned, it


is definite proof of merit. Second, it is always completely clear (to everyone,including employers), what kind of merit a given degree is proof of. If


somebody has an accreditation in discrete mathematics from DMO, then an


employer who needs a discrete math specialist can hire that person with


complete confidence that he will be competent.


      This means that when it comes to the kinds of people who are likely to


major in the humanities and social sciences, DMO has its work cut out for


itself. Its primary solution will be to offer lite science degrees: lite-physics,


lite-math; math for computer scientists; lite biology. In this way, DMO gets


people out of the doldrums of the liberal arts and into STEM.


      In addition to being inherently legitimate, this objective is also highly


attainable. Many people in the humanities, especially philosophy, are actually


highly intelligent. But (for that reason, arguably) they find details rather


annoying. Anyone who has studied physics knows that it’s largely about


details; there are some ‘big ideas’, but it is mainly about grinding out


solutions, oftentimes using rather thorny mathematics. The same is true of all


of the sciences. Yes—there are ‘big ideas.’ But most of them are about


grinding out facts/theorems.


      Because people in the humanities tend to be ‘big idea’ people, they


resent doing the labor involved in STEM subjects. At the same time, they like


and are adept at the ‘big ideas’ part of those disciplines. College majors being


what they are, big idea people tend to have little choice but to flee fromSTEM, including economics, into the likes of poly sci, history, etc. The result


is that these people, despite their considerable intellectual gifts, end up being


completely useless: no matter how advanced you are in political science, you


are not employable (except in a bureaucratic way). Contrariwise, somebody


whose college career consists in his learning the big ideas of science, along


with just enough applications to nail down understanding, is extremely


useful.


      For this reason, DMO will offer a major in ‘general studies in the


sciences.’ There will be variants of this degree, including general studies in


the applied sciences, general studies in the biological sciences, general


studies in information sciences, general studies in health sciences, and the


like.


 


        Emphasis on Instruction as Opposed to Selection


 


        Existing universities are discriminatory; they do not all service all


comers. OMC's (open-market companies) are not like this. Nike doesn't


‘exclude' certain customers; nor does Amazon or Microsoft. Why this


difference? Because OMC's sell products, whereas universities sell prestige.


If universities really sold instruction—in other words, if they made their


money by seeing to it that people left them more competent than they came tothem---they would want as many customers as possible. If they were in the


business of making people smarter, they would want as many people as


possible paying them to make them smarter. But universities are very


selective about who they choose to service, and the reason is that their


product is weak: they are simply not that good at instructing people. (They


are reasonably good at taking people who are already gifted and then pointing


them in the right direction.)


      If I invent a pill that makes people smarter, and I want to make money


by selling that pill, I will obviously want to sell to as many people as


possible. I won’t want to exclude anybody. In fact, the less desirable (the less


intelligent) the customer, the better. By contrast, if invented a pill that doesn’t


make people smarter, or does so only under certain circumstances, I may


want to have a different business model: I may want to vet customers. DMO


has the first business model. Other universities have the second.


 


      More Degree-levels at DMO


 


      An A in a given class at a given university tends not to mean anything.


And even in cases where an A definitely means something, its exact meaning


is deeply unclear. True—an A in engineering 101 means something. But it


means  one  thing  at  M.I.T.  and  something  quite  different  at  VirginiaCommonwealth University. Because individual classes at universities have


either no significances or no determinate significances, accreditations can be


only awarded to people who have taken hulkingly large pluralities of classes.


This is a hedging strategy. The idea is Smith must have at least at least some


merit if he passes a hundred classes, even though many of those of them had


no meaning and few if any had determinate meanings.


      The less guarantee there is that a given class has merit, the larger the


number of classes a student must pass in order to be awarded a degree that is


taken as proof of merit. This limits the number of levels of degrees that a


university can issue. If someone takes six classes a given university, that


doesn’t necessarily mean anything at all; and even if it does mean something,


it isn’t clear exactly what it means, since it isn’t clear what the student had to


do to pass them. (He may have had to have passed some test or other in logic,


but  it  is  not  clear  what  was  on  that  test—or  even  if  there  was  one.  The


situation will vary from school to school and, within a given school, from


professor to professor.)


      But  if  individual  courses  had  guaranteed  meanings,  and  if  it  was


always determinate what those meanings were, then passing so much as a


single class would be definite proof of a definite kind of merit. In that case, a


‘two-year’ degree---in other words, a degree awarded for two-years’ worth of


course-work---would have an enormous amount of meaning. In fact, a oneyear-degree would have meaning. Even a three-month degree---of the right


kind—would have meaning. In general, the greater the guarantee that a given


course  has  meaning,  and  the  greater  the  degree  of  specificity  as  to  what


meaning is, the fewer courses a student will have to take in order for that


student to be recognized as having merit.


      At DMO, there is no such thing as a grade that is not definitive proof


of a well-defined kind of merit. For this reason, a student at DMO can prove


himself to have a high degree of a very definite kind of merit by passing a


relatively  small  number  of  classes.  For  this  reason,  DMO  will,  with


credibility, be able to issue many different levels of degrees. (In fact, any


given course at DMO will itself be a mini-degree, simply because successful


completion of that class constitutes definite proof of a definite kind of merit.)


      This means that students can earn credible degrees from DMO in a


fraction  of  the  time,  and  with  a  fraction  of  the  expense,  that  would  be


involved  in  getting  a  degree  from  another  institution.  It  also  means  that


students would have many options intermediate between getting a degree at


all and spending four to eight years, and wracking up debt, getting a degree


that may have little inherent or practical significance.


 


      Instructors Never to Function as Gatekeepers


       DMO always offers students the ability to ‘test out.’ In other words, a


student can get a given accreditation just by passing the examination in


question: no time need be spent ‘in class.’


      This is necessary. As long as students have the option of testing out, it


is guaranteed that students only pay instructors for actual instruction. When it


isn’t possible to test out, instructors tend to function as gatekeepers: they are


not there to instruct, but rather to open the gates, as they see fit. If instructors


are paid to be gatekeepers, there is no guarantee that they are good


instructors.


 


        Payments to Go Straight from Student to Instructor


 


      At DMO, a hires a given instructor only if he believes that instructor


to be able to help some accreditation exam that the professor himself does not


grade. This means that students will not want to work with instructors who


are failures at getting students to pass these exams and will want to work


instructors who can get them to pass. It also means that students will be


willing to pay more for instructors who are likely to get them to pass than for


those who unlikely to do so.


      This means that students and instructors must be able to negotiate


prices directly. If the student pays DMO, and DMO then supplies the studentwith an instructor, the student is no longer able to choose competent


instructors and to not choose incompetent ones. This means that incompetent


instructors will not pay the price for their incompetence and competent ones


will not be rewarded for their competence. This in turn means that instruction


will be poor. Therefore, students must negotiate prices directly with


instructors, and payments must go straight to the instructor. The instructor


will give a percentage of his earnings to DMO in exchange for use of the


platform, business volume, credibility, instructional materials, and the like.


      An immediate corollary is that there is no permanent employment at


DMO, let alone tenure, only contract-work. Another corollary is that


instructor-revenue is determined entirely by instructor-competence.


 


      The Inverted Payment Pyramid


 


      At a conventional university, the money flows down. Students pay the


university; the university pays instructors. The result: expensive and bad


education. At DMO, the money flows up. Instructors are directly sought by


students based on their performance-statistics, with instructors keeping most


of what the student pays and the rest, probably around 20%, going to defray


overhead costs.


      This will make DMO lean and functional. Because the student knowswhere his money is going, there is not very much DMO can do to over-


charge or mis-charge. Also, since management has to work within the limits


set by that 20%, bureaucrat will be impossible, and management will have


strong incentives to hire and retain instructors who are able to service large


market-sectors.


 


      25 Desiderata that DMO Must Satisfy


 


      Let us now state all of these points as explicitly concisely as possible.


      Any given degree issued by DMO will be definite proof of a definite


kind of merit; and to do this, as well as satisfy the objectives that we have


seen to be involved therein, DMO satisfy the following twenty-five


desiderata:


 


      1. DMO must be accredited. Students must be able to receive


recognized degrees.


      2. DMO must be online.


      3. Instruction must be largely (though not entirely) individualized.


      4. There must be clear, universally recognize performance-


benchmarks for students in all academic areas.


      5. There must be similar benchmarks for instructors (this is a corollaryof the last point).


      6. Students hire instructors directly.


      7. Instructor-rates are determined by the student and the instructor, not


by DMO. The instructor gives a cut of his earnings to DMO, in exchange for


DMO’s resources (these being the platform, educational resources,


marketing, credibility, large business volume, and the like).


      8. Instructor-statistics are always available to prospective students.


These statistics include number of accreditation-tests pasts by students and


the exact identifies of such tests. Instructor-pay is therefore based on volume


of work and satisfaction of such benchmarks.


      9. Satisfaction of such benchmarks is never to be decided by the


professors. Consequently, there are no ‘grades’ per se, only accreditation


exams. A corollary is that assignments, including papers, are always simply


exercises; they do not result in grades or accreditations. Those assignments


can and will be responded to (read and commented on) by such people, but


those responses will not constitute grades or formal actions of any kind, their


sole purpose being to illuminate.


      10. The questions on these accreditation exams admit of clear,


unambiguous and universally recognizable answers. A corollary is questions


relating to course-specific topics will not occur on these tests.


      11. Instructors are minimally policed. They can teach what they want,how they want.


      12. Instructors are encouraged to take performance-tests of their own


(similar to and sometimes identical with those taken by their own students)


and to publicly display their scores on these. Initially, instructors will


inevitably have the usual credentials (doctorates from brick-and-mortar


institutions, along with publications). And they are allowed to showcase


these, but with time these will become increasingly less important.


      13. There is no tenure.


      14. Termination is reserved for two kinds of circumstances: failure to


take on students that are making themselves available at agreed-upon rates


and gross misconduct (invoicing non-existent sessions, lying to students


about qualifications, and the like).


      15. There must be a wider variety of disciplines and degrees than in


current institutions of higher learning.


      16. The student’s situation should not be binary—it should not be


either ‘degree’ or ‘no degree.’ There should be a score that corresponds to


objective and verifiable accomplishments on the student’s part, a degree


being issued only when that score reaches a predetermined target.


      17. Disciplines that have no practical value should either be jettisoned


or modified so to have practical value. (Realistically, they will usually be


replaced with generalized versions of practical disciplines.)      18. Disciplines that do not admit of objective assessments should


either be jettisoned or modified so to admit of such assessments.


      19. Universally applicable tests of intelligence and critical reasoning


should be administered, to prove that the student is not only acquiring


subject-specific knowledge but is also becoming a better thinker. These will


be administered and graded free of charge. The student does not have to take


them, but if he does take them and his performance exceeds a certain


threshold, they count as credentials. There will be instructors who specialize


in helping students with these tests.


      20. DMO will always have past copies of these tests, and of all other


accreditation-exams, but DMO instructors will not create them. DMO will


contract with outside parties to generate the relevant tests, which will not be


revealed to DMO instructors until after they have been taken.


      21. The use of student evaluations should be minimized or eliminated.


Student input should concern the professionalism of the instructor. The


instructor's merit should be determined by student-performance, not by


opinion or sentiment.


      22. Students should be able to switch between instructors easily, so as


to prevent their education from being jammed up by personal conflicts with


instructors


      23. The contents of curricula should be publicly accessible, so thatstudents can start working on them prior to enrolling in DMO. This is to


ensure that instructors actually instruct, instead of just being gate-keepers.


      24. Hirings are to be made exclusively on proven or probable success


helping students pass accreditation exams. Therefore, publications are


irrelevant to hiring decision, and so are letters of reference.


      25. Mini-majors should be offered: miniature degrees in economics,


physics, and so on.


 


        Conclusion of Part 2


 


        Existing universities are failing in many respects. Most of the degrees


they issue have literally no objective significance and utterly fail to provide


definitive proof of merit. Moreover, universities are expensive and slow.


Finally, they are discriminatory, in that they prevent the very people who


need their services from receiving them. They do this in two ways. First, they


turn people away who want to study at them. (Though non-ideal, this is


forgivable, given their limited resources of space and manpower.) Second


(and far less forgivably), they turn their own students away from courses of


study that would actually benefit them: they offer very few practical courses


of study, and they load those courses of study with so many stumbling blocks


that people who could be creditable practitioners of the corresponding fieldsend up being exiled into useless, soft majors. Theoretically, universities are


supposed to instruct; but they don’t instruct, so much as they wall out people


who need instruction, choosing to open the gates only to people who can self-


teach their way through their majors.


      There is little hope of reforming universities. They don't want to be


reformed, and they don't stand to gain by being reformed. (See Part 1, as well


the Conclusion of the Present Work.) Nor are they asking to be reformed.


      But this doesn’t matter, since there is no need to reform them. In the


present work, we put forth a detailed plan for a university (DMO) that will do


what existing universities are failing to do, and nothing is preventing


anybody from implementing that plan.


      The essence of DMO is that it is results-based, not service-based.


DMO-instructors are instructors, not gatekeepers. They are paid directly by


students to help those students pass independently administered accreditation


exams, successful completion of which is always definitive proof of a well-


defined as well as useful form of competence. Consequently, instructor-


earnings depend only on the quality and volume of their work.


      Because each successfully completed examination has universally


recognizable and well-defined significance, a DMO-student need only a small


number of courses to provide definitive proof that he has a given skill or is


employable in a given respect. It also allows DMO to offer a much widerrange of courses of study than its conventional brick-and-mortar counterparts,


giving it the ability to absorb people into STEM majors who at conventional


universities would be exiled to the limbo of the liberal arts.


      A consequence of this model is that student-costs are always hewed to


the actual value of the instruction they are receiving. Thanks to the resulting


high-quality of instruction, DMO need not deny service to anyone, since its


reputation is based on how much it improves its students, not on how smart


they are to begin with.


      Once in existence, DMO will be the very embodiment of optimal


  knowledge-management. The instructors will have no choice but to charge


exactly what their services are worth; and because the instructors pay the


management, and not the other way around, the management will be forced


to hire and retain the best instructors, and they will also have every reason not


to bloat up their own ranks with redundant personnel, since the money for


such a person would come out of their own end.


 


        Conclusion of the Present Work


 


      Other things being equal, some universities would like to have higher


retention rates than they currently have. But other things are not equal. If


universities made the kinds of systemic changes to themselves needed toguarantee higher retention rates, they would alienate most of their current


customers.


      Also, universities don’t need higher retention rates. There are many


universities with retention rates that are well under 50% (and graduation rates


that are in the single digits), and not a single one of them is even close to


closing its doors. The only brick-and-mortar university that has even come


close to shutting down in the last twenty years is Sweet Briar, a private


women's college, and it had (and continues to have) a 71% retention rate.


(The national average is just over 50%.)


      Finally, even if universities do need them, they are doing much, apart


from some marketing, to increase them. They are not changing their prices,


their services or their business-model; and they are certainly not asking


outside experts to come in and house-clean.


      It has been suggested that universities might improve their retention


rates through judicious use of knowledge management. Though prima facie


reasonable, this suggestion is quite misconceived. The reason is that


universities depend for their very existences on poor knowledge


management. Some organizations survive by being efficient: they make their


money by providing people with well-defined results. Such organizations


need good knowledge management. Microsoft is in this category, along with


Nike, Walmart, and Hyundai.      Other organizations survive by being inefficient: they make their


money by providing services that don’t have definite results and by making


those services as expensive as possible. Organizations that provide


marketing, therapy, coaching and other similarly nebulous services tend to


fall into this category. Most marketing firms would go out of business


immediately if they were only paid for results, and it is therefore a marketing


firm’s financial interest to keep the ratio of services to results as high as it can


without entirely losing credibility. Such an organization wants to be able to


justify high billings without producing corresponding results, and it does this


by hiring useless ‘experts’, conducting various studies, having useless


meetings, and the like. Consequently, many people within such an


organization have strong incentives not to communicate efficiently, since


efficient communications would tend to expose them a useless. It also means


that it isn’t clear what is worth communicating, since the company’s


objectives are vague and internally incoherent.


        Universities fall into this category. They do provide some legitimate


services, but these only account for a fraction of their revenue, the rest


coming from overpriced ancillary services. For this reason, universities do


not have a well-defined bottom-line. In certain respects, they may want to


improve instruction, but that is hardly their endgame. They need to provide


enough instruction to maintain their prestige. But they don’t want instructionto be too good, since that will alienate most of their customers. So they need


some legitimate personnel and some illegitimate ones, and they need to


provide some legitimate services and some illegitimate ones. Their objectives


are therefore vague and incoherent, and it is correspondingly unclear what


kind of information university-employees should make one another aware of.


        Universities don’t want to be better, and they are right not to want to


be better, since their business would dry up if they were better. This does not


mean that all is lost. It just means that the way to provide the public with


better instruction is not to make universities better. The right way to provide


the public with better instruction is to create a new kind of educational


service that is results-based and whose revenue is hewed to its pedagogical


efficacy. In this work, we have seen in detail exactly how to do this.


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 



      [1] Be it noted that there is an entire industry dedicated to swindling


people who don't have college degrees by taking their money in exchange for


the temporary illusion that they can have a white-collar profession. Primerica,


Mary Kay Cosmetics, Herbalife, Equinox, Amway, Vector: These are all


multi-level marketing schemes. Each has the same structure. People are


recruited to be ‘sales representatives.' No college degree is needed (or had, in


most cases). The ‘sales representative' pays for leads and products and


training, all because he has been told that he will make this money back. He


finds that it is virtually impossible to make a single sale, and he would have


to make many sales to recover his losses. The only way he can make money


is by recruiting more sales representatives, to whom he sells the same bill of


goods that his own recruiter sold to him. And even if he is an extremely


successful recruiter, he is still extremely unlikely to make more than a


pittance or even just to break even.


      Why do these people do it? Up to a point, it is because they are


gullible. But ultimately it is because they want the prestige of a white-collar


career. They want to be ‘executives.' And each of these companies refers toits recruits as ‘executives.' At Primerica, the moment you become licensed,


you are a ‘team leader' and an ‘executive', and you are allowed to claim that


you have your own office. (You time-share an office with around thirty other


‘executives.')


 


      [2] This subject to the obvious counterexamples and qualifications,


e.g. ‘Dog’ the Bounty Hunter is financially successful despite not having a


college degree. But such counterexamples and qualifications are just that.


And when scrutinized, they tend to confirm the proposition in question.


Before having his own T.V. show, ‘Dog’ spent 18 months in prison in Texas


for drug dealing, which he wouldn’t have had to have done had he had a


college degree. And most people who go to prison don’t turn their


experiences into T.V. shows. In fact, the basis of that show’s success lay in


the fact that he was seen as an ‘everyman’ who made good, despite the odds.


      [3] https://www.cbsnews.com/news/25-universities-with-the-worst-


graduation-rates/


 


      [4] A high-prestige university, such as UCLA or Harvard, may make


some money selling adult-learning classes and the like, but the revenue from


such services is less than one-tenth of one percent of the revenue from


students who are enrolled in degree programs. 


      [5] Also, universities provide far less instruction than people assume.


Capable students tend to teach themselves. Students at Harvard and M.I.T.


tend to be auto-didacts. The professor may do a bit of explaining, but he is


more in the nature of an enforcer: he is there to make sure that students do the


assignments, and students who are not able to figure out on their own how to


do the assignments, mainly on the basis of a textbook and only to a minimal


extent on the basis of lectures, will not last. So a university could always


provide terrible instruction in every discipline, so long as the students there


were sufficiently able to teach themselves the materials. And this is not just a


hypothetical possibility: it is a fairly good approximation to how colleges


actually function. Students who do good work tend to be independently


motivated and teach themselves. The courses help them learn, but not by


teaching so much as by forcing them to do problem-sets, write essays, and the


like. Professors are there not so much to instruct as to police.


 


      [6] That is why the fact that universities sometimes want to raise their


retention rates doesn’t represent much of an opportunity for business


consultants. If an OMC wants to right-size itself, it is more than willing to let


people go: in fact, it will often hire consultants precisely to tell who to let go


of. But universities don’t want to right-size themselves by downsizing. Theydon’t even particularly want to right-size themselves, for the reasons already


given. And although they may sometimes want higher retention rates, the


changes they are willing to make themselves to have them are extremely


marginal, and university officials will be deeply uneasy about the idea of


someone from the private sector telling them where to let the ax fall, as it


were.


 


      [7] We often hear about law school graduates can’t find work and are


stuck with hundreds of thousands of dollars in student debt, and we often


hear about how lawyer-jobs are becoming more scarce, not just relative to the


number of applicants, but in absolute terms, owing in part to the automation


of some legal services. His this slowed the rate of applications to law school?


Not one bit. Application-rates are climbing. Is this because these applicants


are ignorant or lazy or defective in some way? Not necessarily.


      First of all, when recent law school graduates complain about their lot,


they are often comparing themselves to law school graduates who got six-


figure jobs right out of law school. A law school graduate today may be more


likely than in times past to have to wait before getting a job. But if a law-


school graduate lands what would be considered a low-end lawyer-job—if he


lands a position as a low-level counselor in an obscure government-agency or


as in-house counsel at a small college or regional bank---he will make farmore money and have far more job security than the vast majority of the


population. And most people who go to law school do get jobs as lawyers,


and those jobs are extremely lucrative and secure compared to most jobs. The


lawyers who have those jobs may self-identify as failures; they may wish that


they were star-lawyers at white-shoe law-firms making $500,000/year,


instead of being undistinguished lawyers making $90,000/year. But in


absolute terms they are doing well.


      There are law school graduates who simply fail to find jobs as


lawyers. But according to the American Bar Association, approximately


87.5% end up having stable employment as lawyers, and the mean salary is


$90,000.


            (http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/thanks_to_shrinking_class_size_a_greater_percentage_of_new_law_grads_find_e


      So yes—some law-school graduates never work as lawyers, but most


do, and they are prospering.


      Are these lawyers useful? No. Not in general. In fact, they tend to be


negatively useful. They make money because, owing to their position, they


can obstruct commerce, and people have to pay them in order to allow their


trade.


                       United Airlines vs. Alaska Airlines (Business)


 


        Summary of the Company


 


        According to United Airlines’ company overview webpage, United


Airlines operates approximately 4,600 flights a day to 354 airports across five


continents. In 2017, United operated more than 1.6 million flights carrying


more than 148 million customers. United is proud to have the world's most


comprehensive route network, including U.S. mainland hubs in Chicago,


Denver, Houston, Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco and Washington,


D.C.


 


      Target Customer, Marketing Environment & Marketing Mix


 


      Without a clear understanding of the target audience, a company will


not have a successful e-commerce presence, as stated in our textbook. There


is a broad customer market for airline companies because transportation


services are advantageous to both business and leisure travelers, which makes


it difficult to pinpoint the typical customer.


 


      Weighing the criteria depends on the customer. For example,customers traveling for business prefer convenience, on time arrivals, and


frequent flyer programs. However, customers traveling for leisure favor


affordable airfare and bag fees, customer service and cabin comfort.


 


 


 


        Targeting a market by choosing which group the airline would like to


appeal to allows the company to strategically position themselves against the


competition.


 


      Major Competitors


 


      Major competitors of United Airlines include Alaska, Virgin America,


Southwest Airlines, Delta Airlines, American Airlines, and JetBlue. Each


airline has different strengths and weaknesses that can be studied by United


and used as an opportunity to learn from the competition.


 


      Alaska Airlines leads the competition because it appeals to all


customers criteria including airfare, arrival times, baggage handling and


customer satisfaction. Alaska Airlines has also recently merged with Virgin


America. Southwest Airlines and Delta Airlines both lead the market in twospecific areas; airfare prices and customer satisfaction. American Airlines


attempts to meet all criteria but has mediocre results across the board.


Recently, JetBlue has slipped to the competition because of its smaller


network.


 


      United Airlines has struggled in the past with customer satisfaction


and complaints in the public eye. Because of the negative media attention,


United has shown improvement in that area, and still holds strong as one of


the top airline competitors.
