                              E-COMMERCE RATIONALE


 


      United Airlines wants to stand out when it comes to customer


experience and overall satisfaction. The rationale behind their e-commerce


strategy is to bring together services and packages to their customers who


visit the website. Nearly two decades ago they launched a subsidiary that was


dedicated to its e-commerce and wireless business platforms. Just like most


firms in the era of advancing mobile technology, United Airlines wanted to


jump at the opportunity in the rapidly developing e-commerce arena. United


Airlines launched a dashboard within their website that helps customers


search for travel package deals, flight information, and an option to speak to a


travel agent. United's new Web site lets customers research fares andschedules, check flight information, and access Mileage Plus account


information directly from the home page. United is also focusing on reducing


the amount of clicks a guest would have to conduct before navigating to their


desired information or purchase. Customer satisfaction would increase if the


website was easy to navigate. The guest would also be more likely to


purchase services if they could quickly find what they are looking for. United


Airlines focal point was to increase customer satisfaction and increase their


return on investment.


 


      United Airlines began ramping up their e-commerce model within the


consolidation phase of the e-commerce historical time-line. This was the era


when e-commerce changed to include complex services far beyond retail


goods. Many travel companies began taking advantage of the web to


strengthen sales and market to a broader audience. Airline companies also


started e-commerce plans which included vacation packages. This era was


very business driven and was carried by the lower prices of personal


computers and mobile devices. According to an article in Computer World


Magazine, “United announced plans to launch a 70-person e-commerce


subsidiary dedicated to online and wireless strategies. In addition to its Web


site, United has launched CollegeTravelNetwork.com, an online service


created to address the travel requirements of college students. It's alsodeveloping an online travel store with Aliso Viejo, Calif.-based retailer


Buy.com Inc. It is scheduled to debut this month (Colett).” This article was


written January 24, 2000, a time when most Airlines were really starting to


develop a strong e-commerce plan and broaden their web capabilities. A


recent search reveals that United’s additional travel websites, such as


  CollegeTravelNetwork.com, have failed and cease to exist. United Airlines


rationale was on target but they failed to execute in parallel endeavors.


      United Airlines rolled out a variety of online travel services to guests


nearly two decades ago. According to the same article by Computer World


Magazine, “the moves follow a steady stream of e-commerce activity by the


Chicago- based airline as it looks to capitalize on the $4.2 billion online


travel market, which is projected to grow to $16.6 billion by 2003, according


to Jupiter Communication Inc. in New York (Colett).” United Airlines has


been strategizing not only in the areas of marketing flight services but


competing with the online travel market. A recent visit to one of their


websites, vacations.united.com, presents a variety of vacation packages that


complement their flights. This website presents a vacation planning website


similar to that of competing travel planning websites. The website offers deal


packages joined with their flight services to major vacation destinations.


They also offer web services that can connect you to a company travel agent


who can quickly help you find the best deals. Looking through these variousonline services, I feel that United Airlines is focusing on providing


convenience and excellent customer service to their guests.


      This strategy was built roughly two decades ago and many other


competing airlines have also launched the same services. Delta Airlines also


offers travel packages to many top vacation destinations, connects customers


to travel agents, rental cars, and flight with hotel packages. Alaska Airlines


offers group travel arrangements for couples and guests planning wedding


celebrations. They also offer very competitive travel packages to top


destinations. Alaska Airlines also has a website feature titled “ask Jenn”


which is an instant message system with an airline representative that can


answer most questions about flight and travel arrangements. Looking through


these websites I believe most of the companies in the airline industry all have


the same strategy behind their e-commerce platforms, to provide mobile and


desktop customer service to their customers.


      Not much has changed since United Airlines created an e-commerce


unit and rolled out web services. There has been more of a focus on Mobile


e-commerce. The website is set up so that transactions can be made easily


when on the go, using a mobile phone, tablet, or laptop. The webpage also


has an android and iPhone hyperlink so guests can download the application


on mobile devices. United Airlines, like other companies in the industry,


understands that mobile transactions are increasing as those technologieskeep advancing. The mobile platform paved way for people to access the


internet from a wide variety of mobile devices and laptops. Individuals who


are always traveling, such as businessmen, use mobile devices to plan travel


arrangements. United Airlines recognizes that developing a fast and


convenient mobile e-commerce strategy will help increase transactions.


      United Airlines also presently uses social marketing to strategically


measure their market reach. United uses the steps in the social marketing


process to generate engagement, encourage visitors to share their likes, create


a foundation for community, and increase their brand strength. On the bottom


of United Airlines’ webpage there are links to many of the most popular


social networks. A visitor can click these links and be encouraged to join


United Airlines’ social community. United uses LinkedIn, Facebook,


Instagram, Twitter, Hub, and YouTube to measure market reach and build a


community of brand loyal customers. According to an article from the


Chicago Tribune, “Experts are starting to link companies’ social media


activities with their bottom lines. One report by J.D. Power & Associates


found a correlation between overall satisfaction with a company’s social


marketing efforts and consumer likelihood to buy something from that


company. It also affected the overall perception of the company. Members of


the social media team at United are sometimes dealing one-on-one with a


customer on Facebook or Twitter about a missed flight connection, orblasting out messages to hundreds of thousands about the airline’s newest


airfare promotion (Karp).” United Airlines believes that if it builds a strong


social marketing presence then customers will more likely buy flights and


travel services.


      I believe that United Airlines’ social marketing approach is sub-par


and fails to stand out from their competitors. United Airlines developed their


social marketing approach alongside competitors and only work on keeping


their presence known. According to the Chicago Tribune article, “Chicago-


based United Airlines, the world’s largest carrier, is not a leader in using


social media, at least yet. It ranks below industry average on many of the


newfangled social media metrics, such as interactions, response time and


Twitter followers. Even after several years of prominence for social media,


United and companies in many industries are still trying to figure it out —


trying to decide just how seriously to take it and what to use it for; fruitlessly


trying to calculate a return on investment. One thing is certain: Corporate


America, until recently, could mostly ignore Twitter, Facebook, Google Plus,


Pinterest, Instagram, YouTube, and LinkedIn. Now it does so at its peril.


United, like others, is winging it and learning on the fly (Karp).” United


Airlines social marketing attempts seem as only an act to stay in the game. A


recent visit to their Instagram account mostly shows pictures of their planes


in flight. I don’t feel any of the pictures are conveying a message of greatservice to their social community. United’s competitors, such as Alaska


Airlines, are sharing videos of their teams as they help improve services and


technology.


      United Airlines needs to take advantage of social media platforms and


convey a message that peaks travel consumers interests. According to an


Article in Forbes Magazine, “Every blog post, image, video, or comment you


share is a chance for someone to react, and every reaction could lead to a site


visit, and eventually a conversion. Not every interaction with your brand


results in a conversion, but every positive interaction increases the likelihood


of an eventual conversion. Even if your click-through rates are low, the sheer


number of opportunities you have on social media is significant (Demers)”.


United Airlines began their strategy in the consolidation era of e-commerce,


when building a model and developing a strategy was new to most travel and


airline companies. E-commerce is now in the reinvention period which


depends on social marketing. The increasing growth of social media now


transforms marketing. Many firms have created teams of marketers who


solely focus on social networks, word-of-mouth, viral marketing, and metrics


that highlight marketing reach through these platforms.


      Despite the weak presence on some social networks, United Airlines


does have a strong following on Facebook. With over 1 million followers


who share United’s photos and articles. They encourage their subscribers toshare personal travel photos and enter contests to win travel packages and


flights. They also have quick responses to their social communities’ questions


and concerns. United typically responds within an hour after receiving a


Facebook message. United Airlines social marketing is primarily focused on


their Facebook page. Focusing on Facebook is most likely due to the 2 billion


active users on the social network. United Airlines might want to focus on


other social networks as well; Twitter, Instagram, and Pinterest all having


hundreds of millions of subscribers.


      Since developing their online strategy, I believe that United Airlines


needs to still focus on staying competitive if they want to stand out in their


industry. According to a recent article by Time Magazine, United Airlines


comes in 9th in customer satisfaction and affordability. The article from Time


Magazine is titled “The 9 Biggest U.S. Airlines, Ranked from Best to Worst.”


According to the article, “the pool of U.S. airlines considered included the


nine largest domestic airlines. Criteria included average fair price, year-over-


year ticket pricing changes, and the cost per kilometer for passengers;


average departure and arrival delay time, number of on time arrivals, number


of cancelled flights, and amount of denied boardings; baggage and change


fees (Renzulli and Leonhardt).” United Airlines most likely would like to


improve the e-commerce strategy that they developed years ago and stay


competitive within the industry. They began developing their e-commercemodel during the early stages of consolidation. The plan was most likely to


have the same services and offerings as other airlines and travel companies.


United Airlines may be working on a new strategy that takes advantage of


social communities and viral marketing. Most companies are now trying to


find ways to offer packages based on personalization and tastes of their


customers.


 


 


        E-COMMERCE RECOMMENDATIONS






First of all, United Airlines has some enormous advantages over its current


competitors. It offers more flights to more destinations than most, if not all,


of its competitors. It’s fares are relatively affordable, being one of the less


expensive airlines to fly. United Airlines is a household name, with a well-


deserved reputation for high-quality affordable service.


      What United does not have is a coherent web-presence. On YouTube,


if one searches “United Airlines”, here (with only a few inconsequential


omissions) are the very first listings that come up:


      Video shows a passenger forcibly dragged off a United Airlines plane


      United Airlines apologizes after reports of flight attendant's bizarrebehavior


      Watch: United Airlines staffer fights with passenger over baggage


      United Airlines 737 900ER Economy Class Trip Report (accompanied


by a picture of an empty Airplane)


      Shame On You United Airlines


      Everything Wrong With United Airlines


      United (United’s Official YouTube Channel)


  https://www.youtube.com/user/united


      Ellen on United Airlines' Latest Headlines (Accompanied by photo of


grinning comedian presumably making fun of United)


      United Airlines 14 hour flight San Francisco to Hong Kong Flight


report!


      United Airlines: Woman claims United gave away her first class seat


to Texas lawmaker - TomoNews


        DISGUSTING! United Airlines' Dog "Accident" Sparks Outrage,


Student Walkout Threats, and More...


      Puppy dies after being put in overhead bin on United Airlines flight


      United Airlines Isn't The Only One Dragging People Off Planes!


      FS2004 - Midway Disaster (United Airlines Flight 553)


      FS2004 - September 11 - The South Tower Attack (United Airlines


Flight 175)      Martin Short Takes Shots at Bill O'Reilly, United Airlines and Jimmy


Fallon


      United Airlines...Fuck You


      United Airlines Commercial (Jimmy Kimmel Live)


      United Airlines passenger apparently dragged off flight after refusing


to give up seat


      United Airlines jet apparently loses engine covering midflight


      Jim Cramer On United Airlines Dog Death Incident | CNBC


      United Airlines gives away toddler's seat, forces mom to carry him


during flight


      Engine on United Airlines plane falls apart on flight to Hawaii


 


      Despite being a safe and affordable airline with excellent customer


service, United Airlines has the become the butt of the nation’s jokes. And its


own official YouTube channel does not meaningfully offset this. The


Channel’s official promo video has to do with the Special Olympics—


sporting events for physically and mentally challenged individuals. This is


obviously meant to make United look caring and non-corporate. But, first of


all, it has no relevance to anything relating to air-travel. Second, it


subliminally sends the message that United is associated with mentally


deficient people, which message is reinforced by the search-adjacent videosmaking of United. Third, even though United’s Commitment to the special


Olympics is admirable, it comes off as apologetic and therefore gives


credence to the (largely spurious) negative statements being made about it.


Finally, United has a number of outstanding strengths: it can get people to


practically any place on Earth in quickly, efficiently, affordably, and


enjoyable. And yet in its YouTube Channel, United is not showcasing these


strengths. It is actually burying them.


      Also, when continues the YouTube search for United, one finds that


many, if not most, of the videos are positive, reporting extremely good


cuisine, a comfortable cabin, courteous attendants and good service.


      Further, there are no videos that discuss United’s true strength: its


ability to get people to more destinations than practically any other airline, at


a price equal to or lower than most of its competitors.


      So here is what United needs to do in terms of its YouTube-presence


(and, by implication, in terms of its e-presence as a whole).


      First, it needs to focus on its strengths. Its functional strengths, not


some irrelevant and obviously PR-motivated strengths relating to its


tenderness of heart. What are its functional strengths?


      Its ability to fly to people to more places for less money than other


airlines.


      Its good food      Its comfortable cabins


      Its courteous staff


      Its in-flight entertainment and amenities.


      It should project strength and focus, and confuse and mislead


prospective customers with material that has no relevance to what United can


offer its customers.


        United’s guiding principle in terms of its web-presence should be:


Stick with the logo. United’s logo is excellent: it is an abstract image of a


globe—very elegant and functional, and instantly recognizable. The fact that


the logo is a globe indicates (correctly) that United has global reach—that it


flies everywhere. The fact that globe is abstract and geometrical suggests


(correctly) that United is functional and efficient.


        United’s current P.R. campaign (at least to the extent that its YouTube


presence makes it clear what this campaign is) does not emphasize how


functional United is. And this must change.

         Four Papers on Business-theory: Marketing Strategy, Joint Venture,


                        Counter-trade, Ethnocentric Staffing


 What is strategy? How does strategy relate to a firm's profitability?


 


      Strategy (in other words, marketing strategy) is the development on


the part of a firm of a long-term plan of action for remaining competitive in a


competitive and dynamic market. The default position for a firm is to react to


changes in the market and hope for the best. This is obviously not the best


approach---in fact, it isn’t really an approach at all. The best approach is a


deliberate approach. Marketing strategy is simply about having a deliberate,


pro-active attitude towards the market.


      Any viable marketing strategy answers three key questions:


 


      Where are we know?


      Where we want to go?


      How will we get there?


 


      Here is an example. Suppose that I am running an online tutoring


service. Right now, I am the only person on staff; so I have to do all of the


work. This involves me doing an inordinate amount of work: I have to spend


all day writing papers, solving math problems, and so on; which is


excessively labor-intensive and which does not pay particularly well, since


the people who need this knd of help tend to be students who have limitedmeans.


      That is ‘where I am.’


      What about ‘where do I want to go?’ I want to have an agency that


employs hundreds of tutors, much like Chegg or Varsity. I also want to


corner some part of the market that is still open. I know from personal


experience that one part of the market that is wide open is the part consisting


of relatively advanced students who need high-level tutors who can help with


dissertations and other advanced projects. If I can capture that market, then


my firm will have a stable place in the market; and it might even be in a


position to take over markets that the current online agencies (Chegg,


Varsity, Wyzant) control.


      What about: ‘How do I get there?’ ‘Getting there’ involves several


steps. First, I have to sharpen my vision for the agency: Do I want to compete


on quality or on price? Let us suppose that I want to compete on quality---


that I will let other agencies offer cheap tutorials and will myself focus on


providing people with good tutorials. In that case, I will be able to hire top-


people, since I will be able to offer them competitive wages. Then I have to


figure out mechanics: Will a student needs a tutor, will tutors an alert through


an app on their phone? Will they get an email? Or will they have to be logged


into the site?


      ‘Getting there’ involves answering a myriad of questions, sometechnical, some conceptual. For example, what is my brand? In other words,


what is my company concept? How can I have a public presence that is both


compelling and accurate?


        Marketing strategy is simply an attempt to answer the totality of these


questions in a way that helps the firm in question retain a competitive edge


and also hedge against the inevitably surprises that come with being in a


dynamic and competitive business environment.


 What is a joint venture? What type of joint venture is most common? Provide


an example of a joint venture.


 


      A joint venture is an agreement between two firms to carry out some


specific task. Consider the following. Smith develops technology that reads


people’s intentions directly off of changes in their brain-waves. Jones


manufactures cell phones. Smith and Jones decide to work together to create


a line of cell phones that do not even need to be physically dialed, as they


respond directly to changes in their owner’s brain-waves by dialing the


correct number. Smith and Jones do not want to form a single company; each


wants to retain his corporate autonomy. So they don’t want to merge. But for


this particular project, they need each other, since Jones needs Smith for the


software and Smith needs Jones for the hardware.


      A joint venture is not the same thing as a partnership. A partnership is


a single business venture that involves multiple parties. Profits are shared;


taxes are shared; and there is common management. In a joint venture, on the


other hand, there are two separate companies, two separate revenue-streams,


two separate sets of liabilities, and separate management.


      A joint venture is also not the same thing as a consortium. Aconsortium is a loose arrangement of companies that agree to cooperate with


one another but are otherwise not intertwined. Suppose that Publishing hoses


X, Y, and Z jointly control the book-market. But they decide that, instead of


competing with one another, they will divide up that market into three sub-


markets, with X controlling one of those sub-market, Y controlling another,


and Z controlling the third. Otherwise, X, Y, and Z are separate from each


other. This is a consortium.


      An example of a joint venture is Caradigm. Microsoft specializes in


computer-related technology and software. General Electric specializes in


appliances. The two teamed up to form Caradigm, a joint venture that


manufactures ‘smart’ medical technology, such as machines that help make


medical diagnoses more accurate.


      The most typical sort of joint venture is a 50/50 venture, in which each


party has 50% claim to the profits and to which each party contributes is own


people.


 Explain countertrade and its purpose


 


        Countertrade is the act of paying for goods/services with other


goods/services, instead of with money. Imagine the following. Country X has


wheat; country Y has oil; X needs oil; and Y needs wheat. Neither has


money. So they agree to exchange oil for wheat. This is an example of


counter-trade.


      The term ‘counter-trade’ tends to refer to exchanges made between


countries (or whole economies). But it is easily illustrated in with examples


of trade at the individual level. Imagine the following. Smith is a talented


piano teacher who has no money for rent. Jones desperately wants piano


instruction and he also has an extra room, but he has no money for piano


lessons. So Smith and Jones agree that Smith will get ‘free’ lodging if he


gives piano lessons to Jones, and Jones will get ‘free’ piano lessons if he


gives lodging to Smith.


      Why would Smith and Jones agree to such an arrangement? Couldn’t


Smith simply sell piano lessons on the open market and then pay for rent with


the proceeds? And couldn’t Jones simply rent out his extra room on the open


market and then pay for piano lessons with the proceeds?


      That would be the appropriate course of action in many contexts, but


not all. First of all, there is no reason to this if the exact thing that Joneswants is piano lessons from Smith and if, moreover, the exact thing that


Smith wants is a room in Jones’ house. In other words, if the exact thing


Smith would want to do with the proceeds from his lessons was rent a room


in Jones’ house and the very thing that Jones would want to do the proceeds


from renting out his room was buy lessons from Smith, then they might as


well engage in a direct exchange, without using the intermediary of currency.


      Also, there might be reasons why a direct exchange would not only be


feasible but necessary. First of all, even if the market-value of Smith’s


lessons is $100/hour, it doesn’t follow that Smith will actually make that


much from his lessons. He has to market himself, which is expensive. He has


to drive from lesson to lesson, which is expensive. He has to have safeguards


in place, which protect him in case a client’s check bounces. And so on. Also,


his personality might be such that, whereas some people love, many others


can’t stand him and aren’t willing to pay him anything for his services. So it


might be a lot simpler for Smith, and also less expensive, if he is paid in


lodging, rather than trying to get paid in currency. For similar reasons, it


might be easier and less expensive for Jones to be paid for his room in piano


lessons, rather than in currency.


      In general, ‘market-prices’ are really just averages of actual prices;


and the price that a given person/organization might actually receive for its


products/services might fall short of the market-prices. And when thishappens, it might behoove that entity to engage in counter-trade.


      Also, currency-based transactions presuppose a stable currency. If


there is hyper-inflation, the value of the rent-money that Jones charges for his


room might evaporate overnight, as might the value of the lesson-money that


Smith charges.


      Another possible reason for engaging in counter-trade is that the


product/services involved might be so valuable that constitute a kind of de


facto currency. What would you rather have? Oil or money? Probably oil,


since it is guaranteed to hold its value, whereas money is not.


      It is for these reasons, or reasons similar to them, that whole nations


engage in counter-trade. Iraq has always been oil-rich, even though it has


often been cash-poor; and Iraq therefore has a strong incentive to pay for


goods/services with oil, rather than with cash. And other countries may be in


a similar situation. For example, India tends to be wheat-rich, even though it


also tends to be cash-poor. Also, India cannot service its own oil-needs, and


its currency isn’t very strong. Finally, Iraq doesn’t have wheat but needs and


India has wheat. For this reason, Iraq and India have engaged wheat-for-oil


exchanges, this being an example of counter-trade.Why should a firm pursue an ethnocentric approach to staffing? What are the


disadvantages of this approach? Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of


a polycentric approach to staffing.


 


      Let X be a company that is headquartered in Madison, Wisconsin but


does business in Africa, Asia, the Middle East, Europe, South America, as


well as North America. X has an ethnocentric approach to staffing if hires


people locally for its non-local positions. So if it hires people in Madison (or


at least the United States) and then sends those people to manage its branches


in Afraid, Asia, etc., then X has an ethnocentric approach to staffing.


      The idea behind ethnocentric staffing is that the people who are hired,


being of the same culture as the parent company, will quickly adopt its


methods and understand its ways, whereas (so the ethnocentric theory goes),


people hired regionally may be slow to absorb the company’s methods and


vision and may steer it in the wrong direction.


      There are a number of advantages to the ethnocentric approach. First,


it will be easier for central management to coordinate with regional


employees. Second, it will be easier to train people for regional positions.


Third, it will be easier to instill the company’s vision in the minds of regional


employees. Fourth, there may be greater loyalty on the part of the localemployees, since the company will be their ‘lifeline’, as it were, whereas that


is not likely to be the case for locally hired employees.


      Also, in many cases, there may not be a sufficiently developed or large


labor market for it to be possible for companies to hire regionally. For


example, let’s say a medical services company wants to set up shop in a


backwards village in the middle of the jungle. It cannot hire locally; in fact,


the very reason there is a demand for its services may be the paucity of local


people with the requisite abilities.


      A polycentric approach to staffing is one that is not ethnocentric. So


under a polycentric approach, Company X hires people regionally. It does not


‘import’ its own people from headquarters into its different regional


branches. Rather, it hires people from those regions to staff those branches.


      There are several possible advantages to this approach. First, labor


might be considerably cheaper. Let Y be an American tech company that has


branches in India. It will be much cheaper for Y to hire Indians to staff its


Indian branches than it would be to hire Americans to do so.


      Also, local employees might have a better understanding of the local


legal and regulatory environments, as well as of its general customs.


      Also, they are also more likely to gain the trust of the locals, which


can help with finding clients and with avoiding legal and regulatory snares.


        Moreover, in some cases, the locals might actually have the requiredskills in greater abundance than in the locale of company-headquarters. For


example, let Z be a medical-services company based in Fairbanks Alaska that


has branches in India. Z will probably have an easier time staffing its Indian


branches with Indian physicians than it would staffing them with ‘exports’


from Fairbanks Alaska.


      Finally, in some cases, people hired ‘on-site’, instead of exported from


company-headquarters, may be more loyal to the company than would such


exports. This is likely to be the case if the company in question pays better


than its regional competitors. For example, let W be a medical services


company based in Chicago, Illinois that has branches in Bangladesh. W is


likely able to out-pay its regional Bangladeshi competitors several times over.


And in this case, locally hired Bangladeshi physicians might be far more


loyal to W than would American physicians, hired in Chicago, simply


because the latter could always return to the United States and find jobs that


paid as much if not more, whereas their Bangladeshi counterparts would not


have this option.


      In conclusion, whether an ethnocentric approach to staffing is to be


preferred to a polycentric approach or vice versa depends both on the nature


of the company in question as well as the conditions that obtain in locations


of that company’s regional branches. Depending on the values of these


variables in a given context, it might be less expensive, and also moreconductive to the company’s integrity, for that company to take an


ethnocentric approach; or, contrariwise, 


                         The Secret of IKEA’s Success (Business)




The opening case describes IKEA’s global strategy and the way the company


tailors its offerings to meet customer demands. When IKEA first expanded to


the United States in the 1980s, it saw disappointing sales as U.S. consumers


expected its products to be larger than was typical in Western Europe (where


IKEA was founded). Once IKEA developed larger sizes to accommodate


American tastes, sales improved. IKEA built on this experience when


expanding into China in the early 2000s and found success by reshaping its


stores and offerings to accommodate Chinese culture. 




What are the characteristics of IKEA’s global strategy? Who are its target


customers? How does the design of its stores and offerings fit into this


strategy and the market that IKEA is trying to reach?


How well does IKEA’s strategy translate in other cultures outside of Western


Europe? What are some advantages to maintaining a consistent global


strategy? What are some disadvantages?


 


      IKEA targets customers who are budget-conscious but not ‘cheap’. Its


strategy is one of efficiency and economy---of pleasing customers, and


getting their business, by being functional.      First of all, IKEA sells high-quality but affordable wooden furniture. It


thus appeals to people who are thinking in functional terms—people who


want to live tastefully but on a budget.


      These same people are likely to have a streak of do-it-yourself-ism and


self-reliance and are thus willing to do a little extra work if that’s what it


takes to remain within budge. And so it is that most of IKEA’s furniture


requires assembly: not labor-intensive complex assembly—but enough


assembly to keep the cost of said furniture low but not so much as to alienate


IKEA’s customers.


      This understated adaptiveness to customer-needs is expressed in other


aspects of IKEA’s business-model. For example, when IKEA first opened in


the United States, sales were poor, owing to the fact that IKEA’s furniture


was not large enough for American consumers. (IKEA had thus far done


business in Europe, where apartments, and therefore furnishings, tend to be


small.) IKEA dealt with this by adapting: it offered its American customers


American-sized (large) products. And sales promptly went through the roof.


      When IKEA opened up in China, it made similar concessions to


Chinese culture. The floor-plan of IKEA stores in China was made to mimic


that of Chinese apartments. And because many Chinese apartments have


balconies, IKEA’s China-stores had balcony-sections.


      IKEA provides its customers with a ‘total shopping experience.’Going to an IKEA is more like going to a museum than it is like going to a


normal store. The store itself is aesthetically pleasing, highlighting the


aesthetics of the furniture inside. And the store has a labyrinthine floorplan


which (literally and figuratively) draws in customers, encouraging them to


buy. Also, most IKEA stores are located in ex-urban areas, so that going to


IKEA is a journey-unto-itself—an occasion---rather than a causal and


insignificant experience.


      In conclusion, IKEA has a well-defined customer base (budget-


minded, middle class consumers) and a well-defined line of goods. But it is


willing to make targeted alterations to those goods to adapt to local needs,


and it subtly but non-manipulatively insinuates itself into the minds of


buyers, encouraging them to buy, which it does, ultimately, by making IKEA


be a concept as much as it is an actual purveyor of goods.


      And there it is: it is because IKEA is a concept, as opposed to a mere


retailer, that it does so well.


                             Strategy and Profitability (Business)


 


  What is strategy? How does strategy relate to a firm's profitability?


 


      Strategy (in other words, marketing strategy) is the development on


the part of a firm of a long-term plan of action for remaining competitive in a


competitive and dynamic market. The default position for a firm is to react to


changes in the market and hope for the best. This is obviously not the best


approach---in fact, it isn’t really an approach at all. The best approach is a


deliberate approach. Marketing strategy is simply about having a deliberate,


pro-active attitude towards the market.


      Any viable marketing strategy answers three key questions:


 


      Where are we know?


      Where we want to go?


      How will we get there?


 


      Here is an example. Suppose that I am running an online tutoring


service. Right now, I am the only person on staff; so I have to do all of the


work. This involves me doing an inordinate amount of work: I have to spend


all day writing papers, solving math problems, and so on; which isexcessively labor-intensive and which does not pay particularly well, since


the people who need this knd of help tend to be students who have limited


means.


      That is ‘where I am.’


      What about ‘where do I want to go?’ I want to have an agency that


employs hundreds of tutors, much like Chegg or Varsity. I also want to


corner some part of the market that is still open. I know from personal


experience that one part of the market that is wide open is the part consisting


of relatively advanced students who need high-level tutors who can help with


dissertations and other advanced projects. If I can capture that market, then


my firm will have a stable place in the market; and it might even be in a


position to take over markets that the current online agencies (Chegg,


Varsity, Wyzant) control.


      What about: ‘How do I get there?’ ‘Getting there’ involves several


steps. First, I have to sharpen my vision for the agency: Do I want to compete


on quality or on price? Let us suppose that I want to compete on quality---


that I will let other agencies offer cheap tutorials and will myself focus on


providing people with good tutorials. In that case, I will be able to hire top-


people, since I will be able to offer them competitive wages. Then I have to


figure out mechanics: Will a student needs a tutor, will tutors an alert through


an app on their phone? Will they get an email? Or will they have to be loggedinto the site?


      ‘Getting there’ involves answering a myriad of questions, some


technical, some conceptual. For example, what is my brand? In other words,


what is my company concept? How can I have a public presence that is both


compelling and accurate?


        Marketing strategy is simply an attempt to answer the totality of these


questions in a way that helps the firm in question retain a competitive edge


and also hedge against the inevitably surprises that come with being in a


dynamic and competitive business environment.
