             Facebook: Why and How it Makes Money (Business)


 


      Today’s date is June 22, 2018. On May 12, I predicted that during the


next month Facebook would grow. I was right. On May 12, FB sat at 187.71,


and it is currently at 202.24, which represents growth of 7.65%. FB’s low


during this period was on May 18, when it hit 183.61; and its high was on


June 20, when it 203.55.


      My reasons for predicting that Facebook would grow were simply that


it has been growing. Apart from a hiccup in March 2018, when it fell from


185.09 to 152.22, Facebook’s growth during the previous year has been


steady and rapid. On June 22, 2017, it stood at 151.85; and on June 22, 2018,


it stands at 202.24. That means that it is grown 33% over the last years.


      But it was not just Facebook’s performance over the previous year that


led me to predict that it would grow. I personally use Facebook. All of my


friends use Facebook. I don’t know anyone who doesn’t have a Facebook


account (even though I do many people who don’t often use their accounts).


Also, Facebook doesn’t really have any well-defined competition. Facebook


provides a cyber-venue where people can set up virtual identities for


themselves. They can be whoever they want to be, and they can assemble


vast networks of Facebook ‘friends’ around themselves who can counted on


to support their cyber-identities. (If a Facebook ‘friend’ doesn’t toe one’sline, then one simply ‘unfriends’ that person.) So Facebook allows people to


create virtual neighborhoods for themselves, in which they are surrounded by


adoring yes-men and in which their views and their very selves are flooded


with constant validation.


      Facebook’s ‘rivals’ aren’t really rivals at all. Facebook’s main


competitor is Twitter. But Twitter is indeed about ‘tweeting’---blasting out


‘tweets’, a tweet being a short message (120 words or less), usually about


some news-development. When an author has a new book out on Amazon, he


will ‘tweet’ about it. Or when a politician announces a new policy or


position, he may tweet about it. Or if somebody posts to Quora.com (an


online discussion-forum, where people exchange information), he can tweet


about it.


      So Twitter is useful for receiving and getting updates. But that is


pretty much all that it is useful for. It is not useful for people who don’t have


independent followings. It is not useful for people who don’t have new


messages that are of general interest to blast out. Twitter doesn’t allow people


to feel special, at least not in the way that Facebook does. So Twitter doesn’t


really offer the same service as Facebook.


      But Facebook does offer the same services as Twitter. One can ‘blast


out’ updates to one’s profile. For example, if someone publishes a book on


Amazon, he can automatically create a Facebook post about. (On Amazon,and indeed on almost all websites, the Facebook-blast icon is right next to the


Twitter-blast button.)


      Also, Facebook allows people to create business pages for themselves.


So businesses have an interest in being present on Facebook. Facebook also


allows people/businesses to create video advertisements for themselves.


These are not free, and that is a major source of revenue for Facebook.


      But Facebook’s main source of revenue is from advertising purchased


by large companies, e.g. McDonald’s, Coca Cola, Visa, Budweiser and Nike.


It generates literally billions of dollars/year in advertising revenue from major


corporations.


        Facebook recently introduced a mobile app, so that people can post


and receive posts on their smart phones. The mobile app displays


advertisements. The mobile app is extremely popular with users, and


Facebook’s advertising revenue consequently sored with the introduction of


its mobile.


      Also, Facebook owns Instagram—a popular photo and video-sharing


site—which is itself a major source of advertising revenue, both from


micropreneurs and from mega-corporations.


      In conclusion, given what Facebook provides (a virtual identity,


complete with adoring ‘friends’) and given that nobody else provides it, its


growth for the near future seems assured.                             Gret Satell on Marketing (Business)


 


        Marketing is defined as “the action or business of promoting and


selling products or services, including market research and advertising.” In


his article “ 4 Principles of Marketing Strategy In The Digital Age”, Gret


Satell makes four suggestions to people who are trying to market a product or


service:


Clarify business objectives. (Are you trying to make immediate sales? Build


brand-awareness? Develop a loyal customer-base? Get a lot of customers? Or


get a few very wealthy customers?)


Identify emerging opportunities (If your service/product is threatened by a


competitor, will you embrace that competition and perhaps turn it to your


advantage? Or will you turn a blind eye to it and become a dinosaur?)


      Decouple strategy and innovation. (Be innovative when it comes to


products and services. But when it comes to marketing, be effective, not


necessarily innovative. If you are trying to cure a disease, be innovative. If


you are trying to make people aware of your cure, being innovative isn’t


necessarily the best idea.)


      Build open assets in the market. (Merely aking people aware of your


product is no longer enough to drive sales. In fact, it might simply make


people aware of the kind of product you are offering, which will in turn causepeople to google-search for a cheap alternative to your product. What you


have to do is build an interface—something that gets money from the


customer in exchange for product—right into your methods of making them


aware of the product. So, to give a real life example, you make people aware


of your business by building awareness of your business into your tutoring


sessions, telling your customers that if they want psychoanalysis online for


less, the should go to: www.freudinstitute.com)


      What this article makes clear is that marketing isn’t just about getting


people to be aware of a pre-existing product; it is about creating a product


that can be marketed in the first place and the marketing of which is to some


extent self-funding. We have moved beyond the 1950’s model of ‘make


people aware and they will buy’ to ‘make people’s being aware the same as


their buying.’


                 An Exercise in Rational Decision-making (Business)


        Scenario 1: You have worked at your company for eleven (11) years.


You have returned to college to earn a Bachelor’s degree in order to increase


your chances for a promotion. You are nearly finished with your degree,


when a supervisor’s position in a competing company becomes available in


another state. The start date is in two (2) weeks, during your final exam


period for your courses. The position offers a $15,000 per year salary


increase, a car allowance, and relocation expenses. Your former supervisor


works for the company and is recommending you for the position based on


your outstanding job performance; if you want the job, it’s yours. All of the


other supervisors at this level in the company have Master’s degrees, so you


know that you would be expected to earn your Bachelor’s degree and


continue on to a Master’s degree. Your present company offers tuition


reimbursement, but the new company does not.


 


      Step 1: Define the problem: The main problem here is new job starts


during exams, successful completion of which is itself a precondition for


getting the new job. The reason this is a problem—a dilemma, in other words


—is that the new job pays better than the existing job and, for that reason,


probably represents a career opening in other ways.


      Step 2: Analyze the problem: The situation is ambiguous in other,opposed ways. First of all, the existing job offers tuition reimbursement,


whereas the new job does not. This to some extent offsets the meaningfulness


of the new job offer. If tuition costs exceed $15,000, which is certainly


possible, then the new job may not be that much of an improvement on the


old one. Also, while the new company will cover relocation expenses, this is


a zero-sum gain, given that there is no need to have those expenses covered


unless the job-offer is accepted.


      Step 3: Generate options: There are four possible options. 1: Keep


one’s current job. 2. Take the second job and, moreover, do so within the new


employer’s time-frame (meaning that one must find a way to take one’s final


exams while also starting work at the new job in two weeks’ time). 3. Ask the


new employer if he will allow you to start the new job late. 4. Try to


reschedule final exams.


      Step 4: Options 3 and 4 may be non-starters: it is hard, if not


impossible, to get exams rescheduled (and, even if they are rescheduled, the


result could be a grade-destroying disruption of one’s routine). And the new


employer may not grant the extension. (If they need somebody in two weeks,


they are likely to pass you over if you cannot start in two weeks.) Option 2 is


possibly only if the new job is located nearby, which may not be the case.


Option 1 is the only option that is guaranteed to be a viable one.


      Step 5: The best option—and, arguably, the only real one—is to keepone’s current job and take one’s exams on schedule. And this is by no means


a bad option. First of all, the person who gave you a glowing


recommendation for the new job is your current boss; so he is likely to keep


his eye out for future options for you, both inside and outside of your current


positions, and some of those options may be even more lucrative than the job


you were just offered. Also, given that your current employer will reimburse


you for tuition, you will be free of a massive debt if you keep your current


job and may even be able to get advanced degrees without incurring debt.


Also, you have no history with the new employer, and things might not work


out there, in which case you would be left with a huge amount of debt and no


prospects. So Option 1 is the best one.


      Step 6: How to implement the solution: Option 1, in addition to be the


best option, is also the most conservative. And little has to be done to


implement it. Indeed, it is self-implement. Simply tell your current employer


that you like your current job (with him) so much that you want to stay, and


take it from there. Also, you can simply tell him the truth—that the new job


would be logistically hard for you to take and the expected pay-off doesn’t


quite counter-balance the likely downside.


                           Organizational Analysis of McDonals


                          Including SWOT Analysis (Business)


 


      The company that I will analyze is McDonalds.


      First of all, 81% of McDonalds restaurants are franchises. In other


words, they are not owned by McDonalds by itself. Rather, people buy the


rights to use the McDonalds name and to use McDonalds products and


methods. McDonalds itself owns only 19% of McDonalds restaurants.


      The McDonalds internal hierarchy is as follows:


 


      Chairman and CEO


      President and COO


      Executive Vice President


      Zone Manager


      Regional Manager


      Operations Manager


      Area Supervisor, District Manager


        General Manager


        Department Manager


      Shift Manager, Swing Manager, Floor Supervisor


      Crew Trainer      Crew member


 


      Three facts about McDonalds organizational structure deserve special


attention.


      First, McDonalds has a global hierarchy. It has outlets in practically


every country in the world. But the activities of each and every store, whether


a franchise or McDonald’s owned, is under the control of McDonalds’ CEO.


In this respect, McDonalds has a fairly standard corporate structure.


      A more distinctive feature of McDonalds’ organizational structure is


that its main divisions are performance-based. Until 2015, McDonalds’ main


divisions were geographical, there being divisions for: (a) US, (b) Europe, (c)


Asia/Pacific, (d) Middle-East/Africa, and (e) other countries, including


Canada and Latin American countries. In 2015, McDonalds replaced these


divisions with performance-based divisions: (a) US, (b) international lead


markets, (c) High Growth Markets, and (d) Foundational Markets.


        McDonalds is also divided into three functional groups: (i) Human


Resources Group, (ii) Supply-chain and Franchising Group, and (c) a Legal


Group.


        McDonalds has to provide food of uniformly high quality to literally


hundreds of millions of customers every day. For this reason, the nature of


work within McDonalds, whether at the level of a crewmember or of mid-level executive, is highly routinized and subject to automatic checks and


controls. Because McDonalds has to provide extremely fast and virtually


flawless service to so many people, there is practically zero tolerance of


errors and virtually every aspect of daily-work, setting aside the very highest


echelons of the company, are routinized. This can lead to a dull and


demoralizing experience for most McDonalds workers, which is responsible


for the fact that “you should work at McDonalds” is considered the highest


insult to someone who has professional ambitions. Overall, the work-


environment at McDonalds is humane but discouragingly dull.


      Let us now examine McDonalds’ strengths and weaknesses. Here are


its main strengths:


 


        *Consistently good food


      *Low prices


        *Extremely wide availability


        *Extremely fast service


      *Clean and aesthetic restaurants


        *Household name


      *Excellent name brand recognition


      *High consumer confidence in brand


      *42% market share        *Universally beloved items, e.g. Big Mac, Fried, Chick McNuggets


              *The ability, because of its size, to order products and service at


      low rates, giving it an ‘unfair’ competitive advantage over rivals; for


      example, McDonalds’ has a special arrangement with Coca Cola


      whereby it can buy Coca Cola for less than any of its (McDonalds’)


      competitors.


              *High-level of food innovation


              *Menu that varies (within limits) depending on the region


              *Generally sanitary and aesthetic restaurants


              *Few or no health-related concerns, unlike other chain-


      restaurants, e.g. Denny’s.


              *Is making vigorous and successful efforts to minimize its


      impact on the environment.


              *Consistently successful marketing campaigns, unlike its rivals,


    e.g. Burger King, which often resorted to somewhat ill-willed (and for


    that reason unsuccessful) marketing campaigns, such as the infamous


      ‘Herb’ commercial of the ‘80s.


 


      At the same time, McDonald’s has non-trivial and growing


weaknesses:


               *Growing competition from fast-food rivals (KFC, Burger,


      Wendy’s, Starbucks)


              *Competition from chains outside of the fast food-category (e.g.


      Starbucks, which recently introduced breakfast meals to compete with


      McDonalds’ breakfast meals)


              *Competition from restaurant chains that provide food that is


      healthier and better and that, although not exactly ‘fast food’, is still


      made and served quickly, e.g. Chick-a-fillet, Chipotle, Veggie Grill and


      Native Foods.


              *The (probably correct) perception that McDonalds is


      responsible for a great deal of obesity and poor health.


              *The widely held association between ‘person who eats at


      McDonalds’ and ‘loser who has no self-respect.’


 


 


              Ultimately, however, McDonalds’ strengths exceed its


      weakness. First of all, McDonalds has many healthy options on its


      menu that are surprisingly delicious. So despite the efforts its


      detractors, McDonalds cannot be painted with the same dark brush as


      Marlborough or other unambiguously health-destructive companies.


      Also, McDonalds is the second most popular fast-food chain in China,      which has a population of 1.3 billion. So over all, McDonalds’


      corporate health is excellent, notwithstanding a mild slowing of its rate


    of growth over the last few years.        Analysis of Case 2: Why the Candidate Should Decline the Job Offer


                                    (Business/Ethics)


 


      Under the circumstances described, I would have to decline the job


offer. There are, at least arguably, some circumstances under which it is


morally acceptable to take a job for which one has not yet received the


requisite training. It would be acceptable so long as two conditions held.


First, the candidate has a reasonable expectation that he can acquire the


requisite skills in a sufficiently timely manner that he will be able to fulfill his


legal and professional obligations to his employer. Second, the stakes are


low, in the sense that, should he fail to learn the requisite skills sufficiently


quickly, there would be no adverse affects (for either the company or for


society) of a serious nature.


      In the scenario in question, neither of these conditions is likely to be


fulfilled. First of all, practically any job relating to the building or use of


spacecrafts is going to be enormously complex and will likely require skills


that are not easily or quickly acquired and that a given person, no matter how


intellectually gifted, can predict with certainty that he will acquire within a


tiny window of time. Second, if the candidate in question takes the job and--


as is likely--is not able to do the job adequately, the consequences would


likely be serious. First, there is a distinct chance that his incompetent willslow down or possibly even put an end to the project in question. This would


have disastrous financial and logistical consequences for the company in


question. Also, the purpose of the mission in question might be to help with


scientific, possibly even medical, research, in which case the candidate's


incompetence could slow down and or diminish the quality of that research.


Moreover, the mission in question might even be a part of a larger


international diplomatic or peace-keeping effort, in which case the


candidate's incompetence could potentially have negative consequences on a


geopolitical scale.


      To be sure, if the candidate in question is sufficiently talented at the


subject in question, he may well be able to take the job without hurting


anyone and without being remiss in his obligations to the company. But


unless the candidate knows with certainty that he will able to learn the


requisite skills, he cannot legitimately take the job in question, for the reasons


just stated.


      I would like to illustrate these points with some examples from my


own life.


      I work for a tutoring agency. I am listed as a math and economics


tutor. In order to get to be listed with the tutoring agency as a math tutor or an


economics tutor, one has to pass assessment-tests in those disciplines. I pass


those tests. But sometimes the agency wanted me to help clients who neededhelp with material far more advanced than anything covered by those


assessment tests. Because I like a challenge, I initially always accepted these


clients, confident as I was that, even though I did not at that instant have the


requisite abilities, I could acquire them quickly enough.


      And around 75% of the time I was right: I was able to master the new


material in question quickly enough that I could fulfill my responsibilities to


both the client and to the agency. But around 25% of the time I was wrong.


And the results were not good. First of all, the client was charged for my


time, even though I wasn't able to help the client. (Sometimes the agency


would refund the money. But in order for this to happen, the client had to go


through a rather arduous process.) Second, even when the client was refunded


his money, he could not be refunded the time that he lost working with me,


which was sometimes more valuable than the lost money, since oftentimes


the client's needs were time-sensitive.


      Also, by taking on a client whose needs I couldn't adequately service, I


was making the tutoring agency look bad, which, though probably not a


breach of contract on my part, is a breech, it seems to me, of some kind of


implicit, ethical understanding that an employee has with his employer.


      Be it noted that in the cases just described, the stakes were extremely


low. In working with these clients, I was not helping launch a rocket into


outer space; I was not involved in scientific or medical research; and themoney and time that were lost were infinitesimal compared to what would be


lost, in the way of both money and time, in the case of an incompetent


employee of an aerospace company.


      There is one thing about my tutoring experience that I should point


out. Sometimes, when I 'rolled the dice' by taking on a client who needed


help with the material that I was not yet familiar with, I was not only able to


help the client, but do a particularly good job with him. For it sometimes


turned out that I had a knack with that material, which fact, combined with


the freshness and enthusiasm that I could bring to this (to me) new material,


enabled me to go 'above and beyond', as it were, in the way of helping the


client.


      But even though this did sometimes happen, I could not, when taking


on such a client, predict with reasonable certainty that it would happen. For


all I knew, I was just as likely as not to fail the client. Which, in fact, often


happened. And which, when it did happen, was a minor catastrophe---the


proportions of which paled in comparison to those of the catastrophe that


would likely result in the situation where someone takes an aerospace-job for


which he is not qualified.


      When one takes a job, one is entering into a contract. And according to


the terms of that contract, one must be qualified to perform that job


adequately. If one cannot perform that job adequately, then one cannot ingood faith take that job. We must therefore conclude that, given only the


information described in the scenario in question, the person who is offered


the job should decline the job-offer.


         Internal vs. External Stakeholders: An Analysis of Three Companies


                                    (Business/Finance)


 


 


      In this paper, I will describe a what a corporate stakeholder is, paying


special attention to the difference between internal and external corporate


stakeholders; and I will do this by (i) describing two small companies and


then using these examples to (ii) describe Amazon.


      A ‘stakeholder’ in a given corporation (or ‘corporate stakeholder’) is


anyone whose fortunes depend on those of that company. An ‘internal


stakeholder’ is anyone who has a financial or otherwise direct interest in the


company, e.g. shareholders, sole proprietors, investors, employees. An


‘external stakeholder’ is anyone who depends on the company, but does not


have a direct financial interest in it, such as customers/clients or other


beneficiaries (including labor-unions that might benefit from the company’s


welfare).


      To give a trivial example, I run small corporation that provides people


with online piano lessons. It is publicly traded. I own most but not all of the


stock. I have also have 10 employees.


      The internal stake holders in that company are myself and the other


people who own equity in the company. I am the primary internal stakeholderof this company.


      My company’s chief external stakeholders are clients. This is because


we provide a relatively unique service and our clients would have a very


difficult finding another person or company to satisfy their demand for that


service. Other external stakeholders in this company include the companies


whose technology we use. For example, we use an app called ZOOM, which


makes it very easy to conduct real-time online meetings (including music


lessons).


      Here is another example. A friend of mine is a psychoanalyst and


popular author who founded, runs, and is the primary shareholder in a


company, called The Freud Institute (www.freudinstitute.com) that provides


people with online psychoanalysis and psychotherapy, with a special focus on


the treatment of OCD. The Freud Institute is publicly traded.


      The internal stakeholders are my friend, the owner and CEO, as well


as the various shareholders, including the angel investors, each of whom has


equity in the company. The company’s employees (these being my friend and


his small staff of psychologists, as well IT-personnel), are also among its


internal stakeholders. The external stakeholders are the clients, all of whom


depend on the company, since it provides a unique, as well as effective,


service.


      When we are dealing with a company of scale, such as Amazon, thestory is commensurately more complex. Amazon’s internal stakeholders


include all those who are financially invested in the company. Jeff Bezos, as


the CEO and primary shareholder, is the primary internal stakeholder. But all


of Amazon’s millions of shareholders are internal stakeholders, as are all of


its hundreds of thousands of employees.


        Among Amazon’s external stakeholders are all its various customers,


including the schools and government-agencies that depend on their being to


have ready access to the instructional and educational materials that Amazon


makes available. Also, included among its external stakeholders are the


various businesses, including sole-proprietorships, that use Amazon’s


platform to ply their trade. Thus, businesses such as Loreal, Levi’s, and


Centrum are all external stakeholders, since, although they do not necessarily


own shares in Amazon and aren’t employees of it or even contractors, profit


by using Amazon to sell their products. Also, the millions of authors who


self-publish on Amazon and sell their work through KDP (Kindle Direct


Publishing) are either internal or external stakeholders of Amazon, depending


on where exactly one draws the line between the two classes of stakeholders.


      Amazon has many other external stakeholders. Given how much the


entire United States depends on Amazon for both commercial and


entertainment purposes, the USA as a whole is an external stakeholder in


Amazon. Also, many T.V. Shows (e.g. Sex and the City, the Sopranos, theVikings, Six Feet Under) and Movies (e.g. Insomnia, the Boiler Room,


Shutter Island, Casino, Goodfellas) are watched through Amazon Prime


Video. If Amazon were to cease to exist or discontinue its video services, the


owners and distributors of these shows and movies would suffer or would at


least have to change their business-model.


      Also, Amazon employs large numbers of people overseas, especially


in Asia. Many regional and even national economies in this area are external


stakeholders in Amazon. Also, to promote good will between itself and


communities in these areas, Amazon has many pro bono outreach programs,


which provide food, medical assistance, and other forms of social assistance


to these communities. And the beneficiaries of these programs are external


stakeholders in Amazon.


      Why it is important to know about who represents you in the Texas


Legislature. Be specific.                        Variables in a Marketing-study (Business)


 


      The marketing variables that I want to study are:


 


      Men vs. Women


      Married vs. Single


 


      The study is conducted as follows:


      100 single men are randomly chosen. (They are known to be single


men, but otherwise are randomly chosen.)


      100 single women are randomly chosen. (They are known to be single


women, but otherwise are randomly chosen.)


      100 married men are randomly chosen. (They are known to be married


men, but otherwise are randomly chosen.)


      100 married women are randomly chosen. (They are known to be


married women, but otherwise are randomly chosen.)


      Each member of each of these four groups has to play a video game


called ‘store credit.’ In that game, they are given one unit of store credit,


which they can use towards the purchase of one item in a virtual store. Inside


this store there are 10 items, one of which is the inflatable lounger, 2 of


which are male-specific, 2 of which are female-specific, and five of which(not including the lounger) are gender-neutral. Each item in the store costs


one virtual unit of currency. In real life, the items are all price-comparable.


      Out of each group of 100, some whlle number of individuals will buy,


corresponding to the percentage of buyers in the corresponding groups of


people. So if there is a 37 in a given cell in the table, that means that 37/100


people in the corresponding group chose to buy the lounger, i.e. that people


in that group are 37% likely to buy the lounger.


 


      Results:


 


      Men Women


 


      Single 88 45


 


      Married 62 21


 


 


      The dependent variable is the probability of buying


 


      The dependent variable is the probability of a given person in a given


group of buying.      The two main effects are that men buy more than women and single


people buy more than married ones. The main interaction effect is that gender


and marital status blunt existing tendencies to purchase.


                     Target:  Corporate Case-study (Business)


 


      Target is a ‘discount-retailer’, similar to Sears or Walmart, a


‘discount-retailer’ being a store where goods are sold for a lower price than at


most retailers. Discount-retailers are generally able to charge less because


they offer wider-variety than other stores and therefore have a larger


customer-base, thus being able to stay afloat while charging less per product.


This holds of Target. At the same time, Target distinguishes itself from other


discount stores, especially Walmart, by providing a dramatically more


aesthetic shopping experience thus creating a sense of elegance, while also


providing reasonably competitive (though not hyper-competitive) prices.


      Target was originally founded in 1902 by George Dayton under the


name The Goodfellow Dry Goods underwent several name-changes, finally


settling on Target in 1962. The first Target store opened in Minneapolis,


Minnesota in 1962.


      After Walmart, Target is the second largest discount-retailer in the


United States, generating $934 billion in revenue in 2017. There are some


important differences between Target and Walmart, which help explain both


why Target does less well than Walmart but at the same time does better than


all but the one of its many competitors.


      First of all, why does Walmart outperform Target? Because Walmartis simply about low prices, so it spends little on aesthetics. A Walmart store


is essentially a giant warehouse; it has no ‘style.’ By contrast, Target has a


distinctive style and a warm feel to it, much more similar to that of an old-


fashioned department store. At the same time, Target offers lower prices than


most other retailers (though not nearly as low as Walmart, charging around


20% more on average than Walmart).


      So Target’s customer-base consists of budget-conscious professionals,


whereas Walmart’s consists of people who simply want to minimize


expenses. These differences are reflected in a number of different ways.


Walmart takes food stamps; Target does not. Walmarts tend to be located in


low-income neighborhoods; Targets tend to be located in more upscale


venues.


      Since the 1970’s Target’s growth has been exponential: In 1962, there


were 24 Target Stores; now there are 1,916. Also, Target has always been


opportunistic and quick to enter new markets. It was first retailer to stock


Amazon Kindle Reading devices. When Circuit City fell in 2009, Target


absorbed much of its business by offering a wider range of electronics. And


as of 10 years ago, most Target stores contain entire grocery-stories.


      Walmart does considerably more business than Target, for the simple


reason that its prices are much lower. But Target has been much more


aggressive than Walmart in moving into the realm of e-commerce. And thisfact, coupled with the decidedly more welcoming shopping experience that


Target offers, may enable Target to remain competitive in the years to come.


 


                   Prejudice as Psychological Resistance (Psychology)


 


        Freud’s thought sheds great light on the resistance that many people


to change and to ugly truths about themselves, and for this reason Freud’s


thought is particularly helpful when it comes to understanding the


phenomenon of prejudice. It will help if we first make some general remarks


about prejudice and then map Freud’s thought onto these points.


        Prejudice is prejudgment: If somebody is prejudiced against women,


he prejudges women, meaning that he forms a negative opinion of them


before he has enough information to have an informed opinion. One of the


very purposes of Freud’s theoretical system is to elucidate the nature


prejudices of the second, emotionally-driven. The reason is that such


prejudices are nothing other than what Freud refers to as resistance: “When


we undertake to cure a patient, writes Freud, “to free him from the


symptoms of his malady, he confronts us with a vigorous, tenacious


resistance that lasts during the whole time of the treatment.” (Freud,


Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 130). Kindle


Edition.) In other words, when the analyst tells the patient what is wrong


with him, the patient fights the analyst, refusing to believe what he is being


told, simply because he doesn’t want to believe it. Of course, there are cases


where the analyst is wrong and the patient ‘resists’ him for that reason, buthere are concerned with cases where the patient resists for the very reason


that the analyst is right. And that is the basis of the patient’s resistance, it is


because the patient benefits in some way from the delusion of which the


analyst is trying to disabuse him.


        According to Freud, getting humanity to accept psychoanalytic


thought involved getting it to overcome two prejudices. “One of these


assertions offends an intellectual prejudice,” Freud writes, “the other an


aesthetic-moral one.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to


  Psychoanalysis (p. 10). Kindle Edition.) The intellectual prejudice is that


mental activity must be conscious, this being the exact opposite of the


psychoanalytic principle that “the psychic processes are in themselves


unconscious, and that those which are conscious are merely isolated acts and


parts of the total psychic life.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to


  Psychoanalysis (p. 10). Kindle Edition.) The “aesthetic-moral” prejudice is


that the psychological role of sexuality in humans is relatively restricted,


being confined to activities that relate more or less directly to sex, whereas


  psychoanalysis alleges that the role of sexuality in the human mind extends


far beyond the desire to have intercourse, as it is also involved in the


development mental illness as well as in intellectual and artistic creation.


“Those instinctive impulses which one can only call sexual in the narrower


as well as in the wider sense,” Freud writes, “play an uncommonly largerole in the causation of nervous and mental diseases, and…these same


sexual impulses have made contributions whose value cannot be


overestimated to the highest cultural, artistic and social achievements of the


human mind.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis


(p. 10). Kindle Edition.)


        Freud’s explanation of these prejudices is that “it is a predisposition


of human nature to consider an unpleasant idea untrue.” Human beings want


to see themselves as pure, and therefore not as comprising unconscious


depths that are teeming with bestial impulses. “Society thus brands what is


unpleasant as untrue,” Freud writes, “denying the conclusions of


  psychoanalysis with logical and pertinent arguments.” In other words,


people come up with arguments to legitimate their prejudices against


psychoanalysis. But because these arguments “originate from affective


sources,” Freud writes, “society holds to these prejudices against all


attempts at refutation.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to


  Psychoanalysis (p. 11). Kindle Edition.) In other words, because these


arguments are intended to safeguard prejudices, people refuse to see the


errors in them and refuse to change their minds.


      “When we undertake to cure a patient,” Freud writes, “to free him


from the symptoms of his malady, he confronts us with a vigorous, tenacious


resistance that lasts during the whole time of the treatment.” (Freud,Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 130). Kindle


Edition.) This resistance is rooted in fear: the patient fears what the analysis


is going to reveal about him, this fear being manifested as resistance. At the


same time, the patient does want to improve, this being why he entered into


psychoanalysis in the first place, and to this extent he is willing to overcome


his fear of the truth about himself. If the patient’s fear prevails, his prejudices


against the truth remain and he won’t change.


        In general, prejudices represent fear of change; and when people stop


feeling threatened by change, they stop being prejudiced. Before women had


the right to vote, men felt threatened by the prospect of women having that


right and were prejudiced against them acquiring that right. Now that it is


taken for granted that women should be able to vote, men don’t feel


threatened by their being able to do so and are no longer prejudiced against


it.


        But we must bear in mind that people don’t see their prejudices as


prejudices, since they always rationalize them. “The patient” writes Freud,


“produces all the phenomena of this resistance without even recognizing it


as such. (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p.


130). Kindle Edition.) When women were fighting for the right to vote, the


men who were prejudiced against this did not believed their opposition to it


be based in reason: their motivations were emotional in nature, but theyrationalized those motivations, convincing themselves that they were


legitimate. Though they are speaking falsely, prejudiced people are speaking


sincerely when they say that they are not prejudiced, since people who are


prejudiced don’t know it. It follows, sadly, that human beings will always


have their prejudices; for as we know from Freud, people believe what they


want to believe as long as they can find an excuse to believe it, and they will


fiercely resist attempts to disabuse of them of their delusions.


                     A Freudian Analysis of Prejudice (Psychology)


 


        Prejudice is prejudgment. If Smith refuses to hire Brown, without even


considering her credentials, simply because Brown is a woman, then Smith is


have a prejudiced response to Brown. But there are two very different kinds


prejudice. There is the kind where somebody has drawn an overly broad on


the basis of insufficient data, and there is the case where somebody is


emotionally committed the falsehood in question. If Smith’s reason for not


hiring women is that, owing to his not having the relevant information, he


honestly but mistakenly believes that no woman is qualified for the job in


question, then Smith’s prejudice is of the first kind. If Smith’s reason is that,


owing to a deep-seated resentment of women, he positively refuses to


consider the idea that a woman might be qualified and goes out of his way to


rationalize away information to the contrary, then Smith’s prejudice is of the


second.


      One of the very purposes of Freud’s theoretical system is to elucidate


the nature prejudices of the second, emotionally-driven. The reason is that


such prejudices are nothing other than what Freud refers to as resistance:


“When we undertake to cure a patient, writes Freud, “to free him from the


symptoms of his malady, he confronts us with a vigorous, tenacious


resistance that lasts during the whole time of the treatment.” (Freud,Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 130). Kindle


Edition.) In other words, when the analyst tells the patient what is wrong with


him, the patient fights the analyst, refusing to believe what he is being told,


simply because he doesn’t want to believe it. Of course, there are cases where


the analyst is wrong and the patient ‘resists’ him for that reason, but here are


concerned with cases where the patient resists for the very reason that the


analyst is right. And that is the basis of the patient’s resistance, it is because


the patient benefits in some way from the delusion of which the analyst is


trying to disabuse him.


      In light of these points, suppose that Smith’s refusal to hire Brown


embodies a deep-seated prejudice towards women. In that case, Smith’s


decision represents a resistance on his part to admitting to some truth about


women that he finds threatening. That truth might be that women are


intellectually equal to men and that he might therefore lose his job to a


woman. Or might be a part of him self-identifies as a woman and he has


developed a generalized scorn for women as a way of distancing himself


from that side of himself. Whatever the case, Smith’s prejudice is a form of


fear-driven flight from some painful truth. This is true of prejudice in general.


      A related point is that prejudice always involves fear of change.


Whatever it is that Smith is afraid of—it might be finding a new job or


finding a new gender-identity--- Smith’s prejudice towards women involveshis wanting the status quo to remain the same. This is true of true of prejudice


in general, and it is a point that Freud often makes in connection with


resistances to psychoanalysis. Discussing patients of his whose conditions


spared them having to perform military service, Freud writes: “If they were


treated as malingerers and if their illness was made highly uncomfortable,


they recovered; if after being ostensibly restored they were sent back into


service, they promptly took flight once more into illness. Nothing could be


done with them.” (Freud, Sigmund. The Problem of Lay Analysis. Kindle


Locations 101355-101358. ) These patients held onto their illnesses when


they benefited from them and recovered from them when they didn’t. “And


the same is true of neurotics in civil life”, Freud then says. “They complain of


their illness but exploit it with all their strength; and if someone tries to take it


away from them, they defend it like the proverbial lioness with her young.”


(Freud, Sigmund. The Problem of Lay Analysis. Kindle Locations 101355-


101358.)


      And there we have it: people hold onto their prejudices as long as they


stand to gain from them and drop them as soon as they don’t. Smith will be


prejudiced towards women as long as Smith feels that he stands more to gain


than to lose by having this prejudice, and as soon as he begins to feel


otherwise, that prejudice will begin to melt away. In general, prejudices are


defenses against change; and when people stop feeling threatened by change,they stop being prejudiced. Before women had the right to vote, men felt


threatened by the prospect of women having that right and were prejudiced


against them acquiring that right. Now that it is taken for granted that women


should be able to vote, men don’t feel threatened by their being able to do so


and are no longer prejudiced against it.


      But we must bear in mind that people don’t see their prejudices as


prejudices, since they always rationalize them. This is a point that Freud


makes when discussing resistance:


 


              The patient, moreover, produces all the phenomena of this


      resistance without even recognizing it as such; it is always a great


      advance to have brought him to the point of understanding this


      conception and reckoning with it. Just consider, this patient suffers


      from his symptoms and causes those about him to suffer with him. He


    is willing, moreover, to take upon himself so many sacrifices of time,


      money, effort and self-denial in order to be freed. And yet he struggles,


    in the very interests of his malady, against one who would help him.


      How improbable this assertion must sound! (Freud, Sigmund. A


      General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 130). Kindle Edition.)


 


      If Smith consciously knows that he has no good reason not to hireBrown but still decides not to hire her, his decision, though hateful and


wrong, is not about prejudice. Prejudice always involves denial and


rationalization. When women were fighting for the right to vote, the men who


were prejudiced against this did not believed their opposition to it be based in


reason: their motivations were emotional in nature, but they rationalized


those motivations, convincing themselves that they were legitimate. Though


they are speaking falsely, prejudiced people are speaking sincerely when they


say that they are not prejudiced, since people who are prejudiced don’t know


it. It follows, sadly, that human beings will always have their prejudices; for


as we know from Freud, people believe what they want to believe as long as


they can find an excuse to believe it, and they will fiercely resist attempts to


disabuse of them of their delusions.


               Freud on Sublimation: Why His Analysis is Still Relevant


                                      (Psychology)


 


      Freud often discusses ‘sublimation’, this being the process of directing


instincts away from their original aims towards aims of a non-instinctual and


constructive kind:


 


              We believe that civilization was forged by the driving


      force of vital necessity, at the cost of instinct-satisfaction, and


    that the process is to a large extent constantly repeated anew,


      since each individual who newly enters the human community


      repeats the sacrifices of his instinct-satisfaction for the sake of the


      common good. Among the instinctive forces thus utilized, the


      sexual impulses play a significant role. They are thereby


      sublimated, i.e., they are diverted from their sexual goals and


      directed to ends socially higher and no longer sexual. The sexual


      instincts are poorly tamed. Each individual who wishes to ally


      himself with the achievements of civilization is exposed to the


      danger of having his sexual instincts rebel against this


      sublimation. Society can conceive of no more serious menace to


    its civilization than would arise through the satisfying of the      sexual instincts by their redirection toward their original goals.


    (A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis, Chapter 1)


 


      To clarify: A person’s ability to be more than an animal depends on


his being to ‘sublimate’ his instinctual derives (i.e. to direct away them away


from their original ends, e.g. the sexual act, and press them into the service of


objectives that are non-animalistic and ‘constructive’, e.g. scientific


endeavor). But an instinct can never be entirely sublimated, as there is always


some portion of them that must be discharged directly. And instincts that are


not discharged through sublimation tend to be a threat to the social order.


      To illustrate: Suppose that Jones has done some horrible injustice to


Smith and that Smith is therefore homicidally angry towards Jones. If Smith


simply bludgeons Jones, Smith will not in any way grow as a person. But


suppose that Smith channels his rage into an attempt to improve the social


conditions that led to the injustice in question: in that case, Smith will


develop as a person and, in so doing, he will also contribute to society. This


is what Freud is referring to when he discusses ‘sublimation.’


        Sublimation of this kind very much seems to exist. People are not in


general able to vent rage directly; the best they can do in most cases is to


channel their rage into self-improvement: they become writers, athletes,


physicians, or some such. Much the same seems to be true of sexuality. Mostpeople are not able to have sex whenever they want to with whomever they


want to, and at least some of this undischarged sexual energy is expressed in


artistic creation (for example): instead of ravaging attractive women, one


paints them (or writes novels about them).


      How this ties into the 21st Century: In the past, men used to have to


sublimate their libido by cultivating a long-term relationship with a single


woman, and they had to sublimate much of the remainder of their libido by


converting it into the platonic love involved in raising children properly. But


in the 21st Century, it is common for single men to stay single, opting for


‘flings’ rather than relationships and families; and it is also common for men


in marriages to become single, oftentimes with the result that they revert to


their previous ‘swingle’ status.


      This means that there are two respects in which men are no longer


required to sublimate their sexuality. First, they don’t have to cultivate long-


term monogamous relationships (which, though partly about the sexual act,


are largely about love and moral responsibility). Second, they don’t have to


sublimate their libido into (non-sexual) love and concern for children.


      It is obvious how children are negatively affected by this: children


need a father. (If, as some maintain, mental illness is on the rise among


children, the absence of ‘present’ fathers is a likely factor.) Where women are


concerned, the effects are more ambiguous. A woman may have a lot to gainby getting out of a long-term relationship with a woman, even if she has


children, or by not getting into one in the first place. But women desire and


benefit from the emotional and financial security that long-term relationships


tend to bring; and this may be why, according to some sources, women are


not happier now than they were fifty years ago: what their gains in power and


freedom have added to their happiness their loss of security has taken away.


         Failure to Sublimate: A Freudian Analysis of the Peter Pan Syndrome


                              (Psychology/Current Events)


 


      A concept that is central to Freud’s thought is that of sublimation, this


being the process of preventing an instinctual drive from discharging itself


directly and forcing it to discharge itself in a way that is both non-instinctual


and also conducive to the development of the individual. For example, for


sexual impulses to be sublimated is for them to be “diverted from their sexual


goals and directed to ends socially higher and no longer sexual.” (Freud,


Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 10). Kindle Edition.)


A person is sublimating his sexuality, if instead of discharging it in the act of


sex, he expresses it by producing art or literature concerning sexuality or by


studying the psychology of human sexuality.


      In this paper, it will be argued that there are some important respects


in which men in the 21st century are no longer required to sublimate their


sexuality. Whereas a man in earlier times was required to sublimate his


sexuality by channeling it into stable long-term emotional and financial


relationships with his wife and children, men today have the option of never


‘settling down’ and of opting instead for a never-ending series of casual


relationships. Consequently, men are less likely than they were in times past


to be dependable husbands and fathers and they are also less likely to marryor have children in the first place. This perpetual infantilism on the part of


men harms anyone who depends on them, including wives, girlfriends,


children, and even themselves.


      In Chapter 1 of his General Introduction to Psychoanalysis, Freud


writes: “Society can conceive of no more serious menace to its civilization


than would arise through the satisfying of the sexual instincts by their


redirection toward their original goals.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General


Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 10). Kindle Edition.) Here Freud is


speaking specifically about sexuality, but what he is saying is true of all


instinctual drives. Failure to sublimate instincts of any kind is a threat to


civilization, since civilization obviously isn’t possible unless people control


their urges. If sexuality and aggression were redirected “towards their


original goals”, the result would be anarchy, not civilization.


      Freud holds that sublimation is not only necessary for civilization but


sufficient for it: “[C]ivilization was forged by the driving force of vital


necessity, at the cost of instinct-satisfaction, and that the process is to a large


extent constantly repeated anew, since each individual who newly enters the


human community repeats the sacrifices of his instinct-satisfaction for the


sake of the common good.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to


Psychoanalysis (p. 10). Kindle Edition.)


        Sublimating an instinct is very different from simply not acting on it.Sublimating an instinct is a way of discharging it and is therefore a way of


avoiding the instinctual frustration that results from simply abstaining from


acting on it. When sexual abstinence does not involve sublimation, Freud


writes, its “pathological power is unimpaired” (Freud, Sigmund. A General


Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 156). Kindle Edition). The “pathological


effect of abstinence” (Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to


Psychoanalysis (p. 155). Kindle Edition) is avoided only when “sexual desire


relinquishes either its goal of partial gratification of desire, or the goal of


desire toward reproduction, and adopts another aim, genetically related to the


abandoned one, save that it is no longer sexual but must be termed social.”


(Freud, Sigmund. A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 155). Kindle


Edition.) In other words, sheer abstinence leads to psychopathology, and


sexuality must therefore either be sublimated or directly gratified if


psychopathology is to be avoided.


      There is one last preliminary point to make before we can map these


points onto the topic of 21st century men. According to Freud, sublimation


only works up to a point. It is not possible to sublimate an instinctual drive


completely; some portion of that drive will remain unsublimated and will


therefore lead to instinctual frustration unless acted on directly:


“Sublimation”, writes Freud, “can never account for more than a certain


small fraction of the libido, and finally most people possess the capacity forsublimation only to a very slight degree.” (Freud, Sigmund. A General


Introduction to Psychoanalysis (p. 156). Kindle Edition.) In other words,


sublimation mitigates but does not eliminate the need to express instincts


directly, and instincts must to some extent be directly gratified.


      In Freud’s time, sex outside of marriage was heavily stigmatized. (For


women, the stigma was extremely strong. For men it was much weaker but


still non-trivial.) And although there were obviously ‘Casanovas’ in Freud’s


time, it was as a general rule much harder for men, and exponentially harder


for women, to gratify their sexual desires without getting and staying


married. It was very difficult for a man to have a fulfilling sex life without


getting married. Consequently, it was necessary for men to sublimate much


of their raw sexuality into the non-sexual libido that is involved in building


and maintaining a long-term relationship.


      All of this has changed. A man is not looked down for having sex


outside of marriage or for not getting married or for getting married and then


divorcing. So a man’s being sexually fulfilled no longer depends on his being


in a committed relationship, and he is therefore able to express his sexuality


in a relatively unsublimated way: he can simply have a series of sex-based


‘flings’, not having to bother with long-term relationships or the heavy


responsibilities involved therein.


      In some ways, this is positive, not just for men but also for women. Solong as marriage was considered a sacred and inviolable institution, men and


women were locked into restrictive gender roles, with women having little


choice but to be homemakers, making it virtually impossible for them to have


careers. As for the man, he was locked into heavy financial responsibilities to


his wife and children, forcing him to spend his days toiling on their behalf.


Also, when marriages were sexually or otherwise unfulfilling, the husband


and the wife had little choice but endure the situation. Nowadays, people are


not locked into unhappy marriages; and both men and women have many


more personal and professional freedoms than they used to.


      At the same time, there are casualties. First of all, children need both a


mother and a father, and the likelihood that a child will grow up without both


parents is now incalculably higher than it used to be. Also, even though


women need and deserve to have the ability to choose between different men,


women do tend to be considerably more relationship-oriented than men, and


because men now have such a casual attitude towards relationships, women


have extremely little assurance that a man they are with is in it for the long-


term. Also, men are extremely willing to lie about whether they intend to be


in relationships for the long term, and although men have probably always


had some inclination to deceive women about their intentions in this regard,


they can now do so with little or no fear of censure from society.


      But there is a deeper problem with today’s ‘hook-up’ culture---thatwhen sexual gratification is too available, life tends to become cheap and


emotionally hollow, this being why, as Freud takes pains to explain,


excessive sexual permissiveness tends to accompany civilizational decline:


“In times in which there were no difficulties standing in the way of sexual


satisfaction, such as perhaps during the decline of the ancient civilizations,


love became worthless and life empty, and strong reaction-formations were


required to restore indispensable affective values.” (Freud, Sigmund. On The


Universal Tendency To Debasement In The Sphere Of Love. Kindle


Locations 56931-56933). In a word, when sex is overly available, the result is


a certain loss of maturity and moral fiber, today’s hook-up culture being a


case in point.
