           Attachment Theory and Mental Illness (Clinical Psychology)


 


      The basic tenet of Attachment Theory (AT) is that a person’s


emotional attachments influence the way in which he deals with problematic


situations and, moreover, that the way in which he deals with problematic

                                                  [89]
situations influences his relations to others. AT is not a single theory.

                                                                                    [90]
Rather it is a cluster of theories that are all based on the just-stated tenet.


      The first question that arises is whether that tenet is correct. The


answer is clearly ‘yes.’ It is a matter of common knowledge that people who


have healthy and secure attachments, particularly in early life, are


psychologically healthier than people who do not. In fact, a knowledge of this


fact seems to be embodied in parental instincts, given the fact that parents,


especially mothers, are naturally inclined to bond with their children,

                                                      [91]
especially when they are young and vulnerable.


      In any case, there is no denying that healthy early-life relationships,


especially with caregivers, is conducive to psychological health, this being


the basic tenet of AT. One of the main objectives of the various theories


composing AT is to make it clear exactly how early-life attachments affect

                                                                              [92]
one’s personality, including one’s emotional attachments to others.


Another such objective is to make it clear how to treat people who did not

                                                                              [93]
have the benefit of unambiguously positive early-life attachments.        Granting that the basis of AT lies in commonsense, its beginnings as a


scientific discipline can be traced to Sigmund Freud (1856-1939), who


explicitly stated on several occasions that a person's character-architecture as


an adult is largely a consequence of his relations in early life to his parents


and who, moreover, tried to work out in detail exactly how early-life

                                                                              [94]
attachments to parents determine a person’s psychological profile. Stated


as simply as possible, Freud’s position was that a psychologically healthy


adult is someone whose parents loved him but did not spoil him, it being the


mother’s job is to provide love and the father’s job to provide discipline. A


mother’s love leads to self-love, according to Freud, and a father’s discipline


leads to self-discipline, with a person’s success as an adult depending on his

                                                                        [95]
having a healthy combination of self-love and self-discipline.


      Though foreshadowed by Freud’s work, AT came into existence in

                                                            [96]
earnest with the work of John Bowlby (1907-1990). Bowlby was a


psychoanalyst who studied the effects of separating children from caregivers.


Bowlby observed that the children who reacted the most violently to


separation from caregivers were the first to be given substitute-caregivers and


were therefore the most likely to survive. On this basis, Bowlby hypothesized


that these extreme behaviors were survival mechanisms that were reinforced


by natural selection.


      Bowlby coined the term “attachment behavioral system” (ABS) torefer to the behaviors and attitudes that determine how a given person forms

                                                      [97]
relationships and also deals with abandonment. Bowlby held that a


person’s ABS is largely determined by the nature of his early-life


relationships with caregivers. Bowlby also held that in order to become a


healthy adult, a child needed to have at least one stable attachment with a


caregiver.


        Research based on Bowlby’s work led to the hypothesis that there are


four basic attachment patterns in infants: Secure, Anxious-ambivalent,

                                          [98]
Anxious-avoidant, and Disorganized.


      Infants with secure attachments to their caregivers are happy and self-


confident while in the presence of the caregiver; they boldly explore the room


and initiate relations with others. When they caregiver leaves, they are


distressed but functional, and they are unambiguously happy when she

                                                                          [99]
returns. Such infants have nurturing and dependable caregivers. 


      Infants with anxious-ambivalent attachments are cautious and


concerned; they do not boldly explore their surroundings. When the caregiver


is present, they are worried that the caregiver will soon leave. They are


distressed when the caregiver leaves, but do not greet the caregiver when she


returns. Such infants have emotionally withdrawn and unreliable caregivers.

[100]


      Infants with anxious-avoidant attachments are not distressed when thecaregiver leaves, and they avoid the caregiver when she returns. They tend to


focus on toys and other purely physical aspects of their environment and have


a diminished interest in other people. Such infants have abusive caregivers.

[101]


      Infants with disorganized attachments respond with fear to returning


caregivers. They may actively avoid the caregiver; they may pretend to be


unconscious; they may rise up defiantly; or they cycle through all of these


behaviors. Such infants have extremely abusive or highly unreliable

 [102]
caregivers.


      Further research strongly indicates that these four attachment patterns

                                                          [103]
are present not just in infants but also in children.


      Children with secure attachments have positive relations with others.


They see others as helpful and that is how others regard them. They do not

                                                        [104]
hesitate to ask others for help but are not clingy.


      Children with anxious-ambivalent attachments are insecure. They

 [105]
cling to their primary caregivers and avoid their peers.


      Children with anxious-avoidant attachments have trouble dealing with


stress and are reluctant to enlist the help others. They tend to develop


antisocial behavior patterns, such as lying and bullying, and they tend to self-

 [106]
isolate.


      Children with disorganized attachments may either bully others orisolate themselves from others. Such children are extremely reluctant to ask

 [107]
for others for help, and they tend to be disruptive and hard to manage.


      There is good evidence that a child’s attachment pattern tends to be


identical with the one that he had as an infant, but it is an open question

                                              [108]
whether they are categorically identical.


      In the 1980s, it was discovered that these attachment patterns, or

                                              [109]
analogues thereof, are present in adults.


      Adults with secure attachments tend to be happy with their


relationships. They enjoy the company of their friends and partners but are


not clingy. They are not reluctant to ask for help but are not needy.


      Adults with anxious-ambivalent attachments are clingy and desperate.


They feel incomplete unless in a relationship. But when in a relationship,


they alienate their partners by being jealous and emotionally demanding.


      Adults with anxious-avoidant attachments are loners who regard


interpersonal relationships as encumbrances. They deal with emotional


conflicts with others by withdrawing. They value independence and focus


their energy on developing themselves.


      Adults with disorganized attachments alternate between clinging to


others and withdrawing from others. They tend to have unpredictable mood


swings and have difficulty forming lasting relationships.


      There is some evidence that adults can have different attachment                                                  [110]
patterns from those they had earlier in life.


      There is extremely strong evidence that inadequate early-life


attachments give rise not only to maladaptive personality traits but to full-

                            [111]
blown psychopathology. According to Mikulincer and Shaver (2012),


“attachment insecurities (of both the anxious and avoidant varieties) are


associated with depression, clinically significant anxiety, obsessive-


compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), suicidal


tendencies, and eating disorders.” According to Kuczynski (2012), the


explanation that OCD, PTSD, and eating disorders all involve fear- or


trauma-driven self-isolation. The obsessive-compulsive is the quintessential


loner, hiding not just from the world but from his own emotions, especially


his own rage, by barricading himself behind irrational, and therefore fantasy-


based, obsessions and compulsions. Compulsive eaters, as well as


compulsive non-eaters, are engaged in a similar form of escapism. Those


afflicted by PTSD have suffered extreme trauma and have shut themselves


off from the world as a way of coping. In any case, it is an empirical fact that


people whose early-life attachments are of the anxious-ambivalent variety


attachments are more likely than others to be afflicted by such disorders, and


the most obvious explanation is that such people’s early-life attachments


dispose them to deal with trauma not by connecting with others but by


withdrawing.      Later in the same article, Mikulincer and Shaver (2012) write that


“Anxious attachment is associated with dependent, histrionic, and borderline


disorders, whereas avoidant attachment is y associated with schizoid and


avoidant disorders.” Assuming this true, what is the explanation? Kuczynski


(2012) puts forward a plausible answer. Schizoid and other psychotic


disorders involve a scrambling of the subject’s very grasp of reality: not only


are his emotions out of alignment with reality; his grasp of reality itself has


been undermined, and he is therefore alienated from reality in the most


radical way possible. The reason, according to Kuczynski, is that the early-


life attachments of those with such disorders were negative, as opposed to


ambiguous, disposing them to flee from reality in the most radical way


possible. By contrast, those with histrionic, borderline, and dependent


disorders, have a fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality, but their


emotions are not appropriate to the information thereby made available to


them. The reason, according to Kuczynski, is that early-life attachments of


those with such disorders were ambivalent, disposing them to keep their


distance from external reality without altogether abandoning it. In any case,


whatever the correct explanations are of these facts, it is an empirical fact that


people who suffer from schizoid and other psychotic disorders tend to have


avoidant early-life attachments and that people who suffer from borderline,


histrionic, and dependent disorders, as well as anxiety-mediated disorders,tend to have ambivalent early-life attachments.


        Although people with the afflictions thus far discussed have more


relationship-issues than others, they value relationships, and they within


limits are able to form and maintain meaningful attachments to others. This is


not true of everyone. In particular, psychopaths do not form meaningful


attachments with others and have no desire to do so. In this context, a


‘psychopath’ is defined as someone who lacks conscience and whose


behavior therefore consistently embodies a callous disregard for others, a


high degree of manipulativeness and deceitfulness, and in some cases a high


degree of impulsivity, often leading to reckless behavior, including drug

                              [112]
addiction and promiscuity.


        Psychopaths use others; they do not have relationships with them,


except of a purely pragmatic kind. (More precisely, to the extent that a given


person is a psychopath, he cannot have meaningful relations with others.) The


question arises: What kind of early-life attachments are psychopaths likely to


have had? This question has been researched and definitively answered:


Psychopaths are likely to have had attachments of the disorganized variety to


caregivers. Although there is some evidence that some people are ‘genetic’


psychopaths, most psychopaths were treated either coldly or cruelly by key


caregivers in early life, their attachments to said caregivers strongly tending

                                      [113]
to be of the disorganized variety.      Before moving forward, let us organize the points thus far made.


Inadequate early-life relationships, especially with caregivers, adversely


affect mental health and make it difficult to maintain healthy relationships. If


a given adult has a mental illness, the kind of mental illness that he has is in


part determined by the way in which his early-life attachments to caregivers


were inadequate. Anxious-ambivalent early-life attachments are dispositive


of neurosis. Anxious-avoidant early-life attachments are dispositive of


psychosis. Disorganized early-life attachments are dispositive of


psychopathy. The neurotic tends to be distrustful of others and ambivalent


towards actual and prospective partners, making it difficult for him to form


and maintain healthy relationships. The psychotic’s grasp of external reality


is damaged, making it hard for the psychotic to engage any aspect of the


external world, with the result that attachments are disrupted, and sometimes


leading to wholesale disengagement from it, with the result that attachments


are undermined. The psychopath cannot have meaningful relations with


others and does not wish to have such relations.


        Psychopaths do not benefit from psychotherapy and they cannot have

                                      [114]
meaningful relations with others. But neurotics and psychotics can benefit

                                                                            [115]
from therapy, and they can have meaningful relations with others, making


it necessary to ask what therapists do to maximize the likelihood of their


having and maintain such relations. Although we obviously cannot provide adefinitive answer to this question in this context, we can provide some useful


fragments of such an answer.


      First of all, good adult relationships are not the solution to the


problems caused by bad early-life relationships. Good adult relationships are


consequences of solutions to the problems caused by bad early life


relationships. Suppose that Smith is an adult who has OCD in consequence of


his having insecure early life attachments. It may well be that Smith does not


have any healthy relationships. But if so, that is a consequence of his OCD;


and the problem that Smith must solve—and that his therapist, if he has one,


must solve---is that he has OCD. If by some stroke of good luck, Smith does


manage to initiate and maintain a good relationship, that will indeed improve


his life and is likely to make the problems caused by his OCD more tractable.


But Smith will be impaired until he has either eliminated his OCD or found a


way to function despite it. Moreover, as long as Smith has OCD, it will


dramatically decrease his ability to initiate positive relationships or, if does


manage to do so, maintain them.


      In general, as long as a person is seriously mentally ill, his ability to


establish or maintain healthy relationships is seriously compromised. Indeed,


people with mental illnesses tend to form relationships that validate their


symptoms, rather than alleviating them. People with borderline personality


disorder, for example, are likely to seek romantic partners who are likely toabandon them and who are therefore likely to reinforce their fears of


abandonment; and when a borderline finds a partner who will not abandon

                                                                      [116]
her, she often unconsciously manipulates him into doing so.


      To be sure, becoming psychologically healthy involves having healthy


relationships. But unless mental issues are addressed on their own terms,


unhealthy relationships are likely and healthy ones are unlikely.


      The very first healthy relationship that a therapist should help his


patient have is with himself. The patient-therapist relationship must be secure


if the therapist is to help the patient. No matter how insightful the therapist is,


he cannot help the patient except by way of a secure relationship with him.


Indeed, a secure patient-therapist relationship will by itself do more in the


way of helping the patient have healthy relationships than any amount of

                                                                  [117]
intellectual insight on the therapist’s part possibly could.


      I would like to end by noting two observations I have made from my


own practice. First, when I have been able to help patients, it was not by


helping them get what they wanted; it was by helping them use their


judgment. Whenever I have had a patient who insisted that she needed a


boyfriend having such and such characteristics, the patient never benefited


from efforts on my part to help her find such a person. Sometimes she did,


and sometimes I helped her do so; but the relationship would simply run its


course, and the patient's problems persisted. When I have given patients whatthey wanted, I was enabling them and making their problems worse. When I


have given patients what they needed, I was actually helping them. And what


they needed was always to develop their ability to make informed decisions.


It is not always within a therapist’s power to eliminate symptoms or to gratify


desires, but it is always within a therapist’s power to help the patient make


rational decisions. Patients who develop good judgment improve, and those


who lack it don’t; and therapists are therefore under a categorical obligation

                                                                          [118]
to help their patients learn how to be rational and autonomous.

                     Why We Lie (Psychology/Evolutionary Theory)


 


        Research Question


 


      Clearly state your research question. Normally, this will take the form


of: Why and how did ______ evolve in humans?


 


      How and why did deception evolve in human beings? That is my


question.


 


      Please note that most of your will have to “operationalize” whatever


word you put in that blank. So for example if my question was about religion


- I would have to define what mean by religion.


 


      Make sure you do so in this section.


 


      Deception: The intentional misleading of a sapient being. This can be


done through explicit verbal representations or in a purely ‘implicit’ manner


(e.g. by leaving false but incriminating evidence).


 


      State your hypothesis. Tell me why you think this. 


      Hypothesis: Deception evolved in human beings for two reasons.


First, stealth is necessary to survive, for both carnivores and herbivores.


Second, deception is necessary to survive and to succeed in society. So there


has been both natural and selection for deceivers among both pre-society as


well as society-internal people.


 


      References


      Please list at least one peer reviewed journal article that you feel is


related to your topic. You do not have to summarize it, just list it here. Please


use AJPA formatting - https://laverne.libguides.com/citations/ajpa (Links to


an external site.)Links to an external site.


 


 


      Ayala, Francisco. “The Biological Roots of Morality.” Biology and


Philosophy (3): 232-252 (1987).                        Unconditioned Stimuli (Psychology)


 


      After viewing the video available in this week's content, come up with


your own example of classical conditioning. Identify the NS, UCS, UCR, CS


and CR for your example.


Come up with your own example for operant conditioning. What is the


operant response? How can this behavior be increased with positive


reinforcement? Negative reinforcement


Using a second example of operant conditioning, how can the behavior be


decreased using positive punishment? Negative punishment?


 


      Neutral Stimulus


        Unconditioned stimulus


        Unconditioned response


        Conditioned Response


        Conditioned stimulus


 


 


      An example of a conditioned response: Smith lives at home. When the


doorbell rings, it is usually for some insignificant reason (somebody asking


for donations or some such), and he doesn’t have any particular response toit. But then Smith develops a raging drug habit. Since he doesn’t like to leave


home, he has his drug dealer deliver his drugs to his home. As a result, when


the doorbell rings, he is elated, since he associates the sound of the door bell


with the euphoria of drugs.


      Here the neutral stimulus is the doorbell. The unconditioned stimulus


is Smith’s experiencing pleasure in response to taking drugs. The conditioned


stimulus is the sound of the door bell after Smith comes to respond positively


to it in consequence of his associating it with drug-induced euphoria. The


conditioned response is the just-stated positive response to the door bell.


 


      An example of operant conditioning: Tim works at a quarry. His job is


to put rocks in a bag. In order to get paid his usual wage, Timmy has to put


10 rocks in a bag per hour. For every extra rock that he bags, he is given a $1


bonus. As a result, Timmy’s level productivity increases. Here the operant


response is Timmy’s bagging more rocks than he usually would. And


because Timmy is rewarded for each uptick in his level of productivity, his


productivity increases with each additional reward: and so it is that that the


target-behavior (Timmy’s bagging rocks) increases with positive


reinforcement.


 


      Another example of operant conditioning: Jim also works at a quarrybagging rocks. Jim’s supervisor is sadistic. No matter how many rocks Jim


bags, his supervisor whips him. But the more rocks he bags in a given unit of


time, the fewer whippings he receives. As a result, Jim’s level of productivity


(the number of rocks he bags in a given unit of time) increases. And because


the extent to which Jim is penalized decreases with each uptick in his


productivity, his productivity increases with each punishment: and so it is


that the (Jimmy’s bagging rocks) increases with negative reinforcement.


                   Goring and Lombroso on Criminality (Psychology)


 


 


      1.            Who was Charles Goring? (what was his occupation, what was


he known for, etc.) (1 paragraph)


 


      Charles Goring (1870-1919) was a British medical doctor who is


known today for his attempt to study criminality in a statistical and scientific

                  [119]
manner (p. 517). Throughout the ages, there have been different views on


what causes crime. Some have believed crime to be motivated by demonic


possession. (Obviously this is now a fringe view, but it may well have been


the default view back when religion had a tighter grip on thought.) Others


hold that criminality is a consequence of environmental pressures: criminals


are made, not born. This is the ‘liberal’ view, which became prominent


during the enlightenment and was developed by social contract-theorists.


Then there is the hereditarian view: criminals are born, not made. Views of


this kind have probably existed in some form as long crime itself has, and


they may even be the view that people are naturally inclined to take; but it is


a fact that a great deal about a person’s psychology is genetically


predetermined, and such views on criminality seem to have support in this


fact Goring’s contribution to the study of crime lay not so much in his viewsabout crime, as in his attempt to study in a non-prejudicial, thoroughly


statistical manner (p. 516). He personally believed that criminality was a


consequence of genetically determined mental and physical ‘feebleness’ of


some kind (p. 518). This view is dubious and his own researches provided


little support for it; but his careful methods of research are seen by many as


inaugurating the ‘scientific’ study of criminality, this being why is still


acclaimed.


 


              2.            Describe the study that Goring did and the purpose of that


      study. (1 paragraph)


 


      Goring tried to look for the basis of criminality in statistical


correlations (p. 519). He conducted a study in which he tried to correlate


criminality, or certain forms thereof, with certain mental and physical traits.


There were 37 physical traits, which included hair-color, nose-shape, head-


shape left-handedness, and six mental traits, which included ‘temper’, degree


of egoism, and degree of intelligence (p. 517). Goring’s initial study failed to


reveal robust correlations. He dealt with this by trying to correlate these


physical and mental characteristics with different criminal subpopulations


(e.g. violent offenders, non-violent swindlers, sex-offenders). Though this too


yielded paltry results, it was in many ways a prototype for modern statisticalstudies.


 


              3.            What was Goring’s view on Lombroso’s work? Include in


    your response a discussion of Goring’s 3 critiques. (1-2 paragraphs)


 


      Cesare Lombroso was a thoroughgoing hereditarian about crime,


meaning that he believed criminality to be a consequence of one’s inborn


‘nature’, not of environmental influences. In and of itself, this view is not


without merit, but the particular version of it that Lombroso held was not


very plausible. Lombroso seemed to hold that criminals looked like criminals,


with bulbous eyes, heavy brows, and hunched backs. Criminals, in


Lombroso’s views, are ghouls who are born that way, like the proverbial


hunchbacked henchman of the mad scientist in the movies. Goring was


opposed to this view, a version of which he himself, as to Lombroso’s


unscientific way of arriving at this view. Goring held that there were three


respects in which Lombroso’s work failed to be scientific. First, Lombroso’s


research was based on impressions (‘so and so is disfigured’), not on


measurements (‘so and so’s index finger has length n’). Second, Lombroso


categorized traits as either being normal or deviant, instead of regarding them


approximating to greater or lesser degrees to some statistical norm. (The


second criticism seems to be a corollary of the first.) Third, because of theimpressionistic, non-measurement-based nature of Lombroso’s work, his


‘results’ are hard to reproduce (p. 517).


      In my view, Goring's critique of Lombroso is rather shallow. The


reason Lombroso's ‘results' are hard to reproduce is that they are obviously


false. People with hunchbacks and web-fingers are not particularly likely to


commit crimes, and people with normal backs and fingers are not particularly


likely not to commit crime. If Lombroso had been right that criminals had


distinctive physiognomies, then it would have behooved him to correlate


degrees of criminality with spinal deformities and the like. But since those


correlations aren't there in the first place, there is nothing to measure, this


being why Goring’s own researches yielded so little. ‘Criminal’ is not a


biological category. A ‘criminal’ is somebody who breaks the law: and who it


is that breaks the law, and why, varies from context to context. In some


situations, e.g. Cambodia under Pol Pot, it was non-psychopathic not to break


the law; in others, Denmark in 1970, it was the other way around. Goring


went to great lengths to generate ‘scientific' statistics, but those statistics all


embodied the dubious supposition that ‘criminal' is a biological or zoological


category, like ‘raccoon' or ‘marigold', and can be studied as such.


 


              4.            What did Goring see as the “real cure” for criminality?


      Explain fully. (1 paragraph) 


      Goring believed that the only real way to control crime was to prohibit


criminals from reproducing (p. 523). Goring believed that criminality could


be lessened by appropriately the criminally inclined. But he saw how high


recidivism rates were among criminals, even those who in his view had been


appropriately ‘educated’, and he therefore believed that the only real solution


was to prevent them from reproducing. This reasoning is not entirely


misconceived: if people who carry the gene for a certain disease are not


allowed to reproduce, then there will be fewer occurrences of that disease;


and if, as Goring seemed to believe, there is a criminal ‘gene’, then not


allowing people with that gene to reproduce will lower the rate of crime. But


the existence of a criminal ‘gene’ is doubtful. As for the high rate of


recidivism among ‘appropriately educated’ criminals, that is likely a


consequence of their limited economic opportunities.


 


              5.            Explain how Goring’s cure for criminality and other


      Positivists translate into the views of the Nazis and their treatment of


      Jews during World War II. (1-2 paragraphs)


 


      The Nazis obviously believed in ethnonationalism, and they also had


certain views about moral and biological ‘purity’ that they wished to uphold.While it is certainly possible, even likely, that certain Nazis read works by


Lombroso, Goring, and other positivists (genetic determinists), they probably


had independent motivations for their political and racial platform. Frankly,


the works of Lombroso and Goring are academic in nature and are not very


compelling; so it’s unlikely that they did much to contribute to the rise of


National Socialism, though they may on occasion have been cited by Nazis in


defense of certain measures of theirs. Also, while the Nazis do seem to have


targeted people with physical and mental disabilities for extermination, it is


not 100% unclear that this was their bone of contention with Jews. Indeed,


Nazi propaganda suggests that the Nazis regarded Jews as worthy


adversaries, not as learning-disabled unfortunates.


 


      6.            Describe your overall experience at the Jewish Museum. (What


was your overall impression? What was most memorable to you?) (1 page)


 


      I believe that my experience of the Jewish Museum in Rome was


colored by the fact that I am both Jewish and American. To the Jewish part of


me, the museum felt familiar; and to the American part of me, it felt


unfamiliar. I was struck by the elegant austerity of the museum and by the


way its aesthetics contrasted with those of Rome itself. Italy is a great cultural


capital and was the source of much great painting and sculpture. In someways, the Jewish Museum of Rome is a part of this artistic tradition, and in


other ways it is not. Its architecture is quintessentially Greco-Roman. From


the outside, it looks like a cathedral. On the inside, however, it is very


different. There are no paintings or sculptures. There are elegant decorations


and there is great attention to aesthetics, but no paintings or stained-glass


depictions of cherubs or angels or anything of the sort. The reason for this is


Orthodox Judaism strictly forbids the creation of iconic representations. My


rabbi explained to me that this derives from the ancient Hebrew belief that


sculpting and painting could be used to create monuments to false gods,


along with the belief that attempts to depict G*d detracted from his greatness.


The result is that the Jewish Museum of Rome, unlike a traditional


Occidental museum, has a rather minimalist quality.


      I very much admired the elegant minimalism of the Jewish Museum,


but a part of me was also relieved to rejoin the more visually oriented


‘outside’ world and all of its teeming imagery. I myself am an enthusiastic


‘gamer’ and need my daily dose of explosive, video-based imagery. The


Jewish Museum’s tone was ascetic and disapproving of such indulgences. I


have read about Amish villages; and from what I know, they are similarly


austere. One has to admire the Amish, because of their self-discipline and


self-reliance, but a part of me feels that life should be more than an exercise


in moral purity. My reaction to the Jewish Museum of Rome was similarlyambivalent.

      Katz v. United States, 389 US 347 - Supreme Court 1967


        Maryland v. King, 569 U.S. 435, 463 (2013)


      Michigan Dep't of State Police v. Sitz 496 U.S. 444, 455 (1990)


      New York v. Burger, 482 U.S. 691, 699 (1987)


      Smith v. Maryland, 442 U.S. 735, 740 (1979)


      United States v. Miller, 425 U.S. 435, 443 (1976)


      United States v. Montoya, 382 F.3d 911, 915 (13th Cir. 2007)


 


                             STATEMENT OF JURISDICTION


 


      The United States District Court for the District of West Dakota had


jurisdiction pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3231. In Case No. 18-CR-0909 (VGG),


the District Court entered the judgment on December 12, 2018. On December


13, 2018, Ms. Collins filed a timely notice of appeal. See FED. R. APP. P.


4(b)(1).


      In Case No. 18-6028, the United States Court of Appeals for the


Seventeenth District entered the judgment on February 1, 2019, the same day


Ms. Collins filed a timely petition for Writ of Certiorari, which was granted.


                                   QUESTION PRESENTED


 


      The government’s case against. Donatella Collins rested entirely on


information obtained through a warrantless and suspicionless search of a


medical base containing medical records. Collins moved to exclude this


information, and the District Court denied this motion, claiming that


individuals have no expectation of privacy in medical records held in third-


party databases and claiming also that the search was administrative and


therefore exempt from 4th Amendment warrant requirements. The District


Court denied Collins subsequent appeal on the same grounds, as well as on


the grounds that enforcement of the Controlled Substance Act constitutes a


public health imperative and therefore supersedes 4th Amendment


protections. Accordingly, the parties are direct to address the following


questions:


 


        Whether an individual has a reasonable expectation of privacy in


medical records that are held by a third party,


 


        Whether a search that is conducted solely for the purpose of obtaining


information on the basis of which to arrest and convict, and serves no strictly


regulatory function, qualifies as an administrative search, and 


        Whether violations of laws regulating the sale and possession of


narcotics are a sufficiently grave and imminent threat to public health and


safety as to warrant suspension of 4th Amendment protections.                                  STANDARD OF REVIEW


 


      The  question  at  hand  is  whether  the  government’s  search  of  the


defendant’s  medical  records  violated  the  defendant’s  4th  Amendment


protections against unreasonable search and seizure. This is a question of law,


not of fact, and is therefore to be decided de novo. See United  States  v.


Montoya, 382 F.3d 911, 915 (13th Cir. 2007): “When reviewing an appeal


from the denial of a motion to suppress evidence, an appellate court reviews


legal questions de novo and factual findings for clear error.”


      The government must show that the information obtained from the


search of the database containing Collins’ medical records did not violate a


reasonable expectation of privacy on her part and did not violate her rights of


property, security, and personal liberty. Accordingly Boyd v. United States,


116 U. S. 616, 630 (1886), sets a relevant standard, namely that “any forcible


and compulsory extortion of a man's own testimony or of his private papers


to be used as evidence to convict him of crime or to forfeit his goods, is


within the condemnation.” In other words, convictions cannot be based on


private  effects,  including  “papers”,  which  obviously  includes  electronic


records.


      Katz v. United States, 389 US 347 - Supreme Court 1967 directly


speaks to the question whether Collins’ medical records were in fact private,offering  the  following  test,  now  adopted  by  U.S.  Courts:  “[T]here  is  a


twofold requirement, first that a person have exhibited an actual (subjective)


expectation of privacy and, second, that the expectation be one that society is


prepared to recognize as ‘reasonable.’”


      Also relevant is City of Los Angeles v. Patel, 135 S. Ct. 2443, 2452


(2015), in which the Court ruled that a warrantless search is justified only if


“the  primary  purpose  of  the  search  [is]  distinguishable  from  the  general


interest in crime control.” If the government’s search in this case was for the


purpose  of  investigating  and  prosecuting  crime,  then  it  was  not  an


administrative search.


      Finally, in Ferguson v. Charleston, 532 US 67 - Supreme Court 2001,


the Court Ruled that a warrantless and suspicionless search can be justified


on public health and safety grounds only if the “hazard giving rise to the


alleged special need must be a concrete danger, not merely a hypothetical


one.” In other words, for the government to be justified in conducting a


warrantless and suspicionless search of Collins’ medical records, the


government would have had to have had to have known of a specific threat


posed by Collins’ activities that they could only stop by searching her


medical records. The mere possibility that Collins’ criminal activities might


have harmed public health would not be enough to justify such a search.


                                  STATEMENT OF THE CASE


 


      The Drug Enforcement Agency (“DEA”) arrested Donatella Collins


for distributing and possessing with intent to distribute large quantities of


Percocet and Oxycodone, both of which are controlled substances. The DEA


arrested Collins on the basis of information contained in the West Dakota


Controlled Substances Database (“Medical Database”). The Medical


Database contains records of all physician prescriptions made in the


corresponding geographical area. These records indicated that Collins had


obtained prescriptions for quantities of Percocet and Oxycodone that


exceeded what any possible medical condition could have required to use.


These records also indicated that Collins had “doctor shopped”, in that she


had gone to several different doctors and had made multiple appointments


only with physicians who continually prescribed her the controlled


substances in question. The DEA had no information besides that which it


had obtained from the Database on the basis of which to arrest Collins.


      Collins was indicted on multiple counts of distributing and possessing


with intent to distribute controlled substances. Collins’ attorney moved to


suppress the information that the DEA had obtained from the Database on the


grounds that Collins’ medical records were private and therefore that the 4th


Amendment required the DEA to have probable cause before searching thoserecords for information on the basis of which to arrest or investigate Collins.


Had this motion to suppress been granted, the case would have been thrown


out, but the presiding judge, the Honorable Victoria Gelberg, denied the


motion. Judge Gelberg provided three arguments for her position. First, no


probable cause was needed to search Collins' medical records or to use them


as the sole basis for arresting her, since those records were being held by a


third party, namely the Database. Second, Collins had little or no reasonable


expectation of privacy owing to the fact that the medical profession,


specifically the issuing of prescriptions, is so highly regulated. Third, warrant


requirements are waived when law enforcement has “special need” for


“specified information” about individuals, especially when the information in


question relates to activity involving a highly regulated industry, both factors


being operative in Collins’ case.


      Collins then plead guilty to the charges. However, her attorney later


filed a motion with the US Court of Appeals for the 17th District to vacate


the plea on the grounds that the government’s case against her was based


entirely on information obtained from an illegal search of private medical


records of hers. The Court rejected this motion on the following grounds.


First, information kept by third parties is not private and therefore do not fall


within the scope of the 4th Amendment. Second, the highly regulated nature


of the issuing of prescription drugs further weakens any expectation ofprivacy that Collins might otherwise have had and allows prescription drug


records to be searched and used as evidence without probable cause. Third,


enforcement of drug laws is a public health imperative and therefore permits


both warrantless and suspicionless searches.


                               SUMMARY OF ARGUMENT


 


      Patient records are quintessentially private and fall squarely within the


scope of the 4th Amendment protections against unreasonable search and


seizure. Without doctor-patient confidentiality, many people who need


medical attention either altogether avoid physicians and therefore won’t


receive it or will withhold critical information physicians and therefore won’t


receive the care they need. If medical records cease to be treated as private,


then doctor-patient confidentiality is undermined, leading to a true public


health crisis. Using the Controlled Substances Act, or any other law or


“statutory regime”, as a justification for undermining doctor-patient privilege


would cause a true public health hazard, and it is therefore very nearly the


opposite of the truth to claim, as both of the aforementioned Courts do, that


the need to enforce drug laws constitutes a public health imperative. For this


very reason, it is also irrelevant that the prescription drug industry is highly


regulated. Regulations justify waivers of Constitutional protections only


when enforcement of those regulations is needed to avert a health or safety


disaster; and in this case, the disaster would be caused, not prevented, by


regulation-driven violations of Constitutional protections.


      Acts performed under the threat of having medical care withheld are


performed under duress. Therefore, if the patient signs over his medicalrecords to a third party, knowing that his only option is to be denied medical


care, he is acting duress. It is therefore irrelevant that records of medical


prescriptions are held by third parties: patients consent to this only because


their medical care depends on it, and their consent is therefore tendered under


duress. The law requires patients to sign over their medical records to third


parties, the alternative being non-receipt of medical care, and their doing so


does not constitute a legitimately tendered waiver of Constitutional


Protections.


                                           ARGUMENT


 


        According to the 4th Amendment of the Bill of Rights of the United


States Constitution:


 


              The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses,


      papers, and effects against unreasonable searches and seizures shall not


    be violated; and no warrants shall issue but upon probable cause,


      supported by oath or affirmation and particularly describing the place


    to be searched and the persons or things to be seized.


 


      Medical records are textbook cases of “papers and effects.” Also,


given the highly personal nature of medical records, one’s “person” is clearly


violated by unreasonable searches of such records. Accordingly, in Boyd v.


United States, 116 U. S. 616, 630 (1886), the Supreme Court wrote that 4th


Amendment Protections:


 


              [4th Amendment Protections] apply to all invasions on the part


    of the government and its employees of the sanctity of a man's home


    and the privacies of life. It is not the breaking of his doors, and the


      rummaging of his drawers, 647*647 that constitutes the essence of the      offense; but it is the invasion of his indefeasible right of personal


      security, personal liberty and private property . . . . [Emphasis added.]


 


        Donatella Collins' medical records were searched without cause and


use to prosecute and incarcerate her. This constitutes an "invasion of [her]


indefeasible right of personal security, personal liberty, and private property.”


Importantly, the Court in Boyd. v. United States writes:


 


              Breaking into a house and opening boxes and drawers are


      circumstances of aggravation; but any forcible and compulsory


      extortion of a man's own testimony or of his private papers to be used


    as evidence to convict him of crime or to forfeit his goods, is within the


      condemnation.


 


      In other words, the very essence of an unreasonable search and seizure


is the warrantless obtaining and subsequent use as evidence to convict of


personal information, this being exactly what happened to Collins.


      When explaining why she denied Collins’ first motion to suppress the


information obtained from the Medical Database, Judge Gelberg writes that,


according to the Supreme Court, “individuals do not have a reasonable


expectation of privacy in records held by third parties. Smith v. Maryland,442 US 735 - Supreme Court 1979] at 743–44; United States v. Miller, 425


U.S. 435, 443 (1976).” But neither of these two cases is relevant. In Smith v.


Maryland, the defendant had ‘mugged’ (assaulted and robbed) a woman, who


then gave a description of the assailant to the police. The assailant then called


the woman on the phone and left obscene and threatening message. On the


basis of this information, the police wiretapped the defendant’s phone and


thereby obtained proof of his guilt. The defendant moved to have this


information suppressed on the grounds that his 4th Amendment rights had


been violated by the wiretap. The Supreme Court ruled that they had not.


      In Smith v. Maryland, the police obtained a warrant for the wiretap,


and the purpose of the wiretap was not to ‘fish’ for incriminating information


but was rather to corroborate independently obtained such information. Also,


by continuing to use his phone to harass the victim, the defendant had turned


his phone into the locus of an ongoing crime, voiding any expectation of


privacy that he might have, much someone is voiding his expectation of


privacy in his own home if he throws rocks at pedestrians from his window.


The case of Donatella Collins is not comparable. When the DEA searched her


medical records, they had no probable cause and had not obtained a warrant,


and they had no independent evidence of a crime.


      In United States v. Miller, the defendant’s vehicle had been found to


contain untaxed alcohol and illegal distillery equipment. On this basis, thepolice obtained warrants for the defendant’s bank records, which confirmed


that he was running a bootlegging operation. He was convicted and appealed


the conviction on the ground that his the search of his bank records violated


his 4th Amendment rights. The Supreme Court upheld his conviction, saying


that his 4th Amendment rights had not been violated.


      In Miller, there was probable cause for a search of the defendant’s


bank records and a warrant had been obtained. The search and use of Collins’


medical records, by contrast, was both suspicionless and warrantless.


      Gelberg later writes that “prescription drug records are not in the


possession of the patient, or even the hospital or physician with whom the


patient may share an expectation of privacy. See Ferguson v. City of


Charleston, 532 U.S. 67, 78 (2001). In Ferguson, the Supreme Court


overturned convictions of illegal drug use and drug-related crimes on the


grounds that the evidence of such crimes was derived from warrantless and


suspicionless searches of patient medical records conducted for purposes of


law enforcement, not for reasons of public safety or health. Delivering the


opinion of the Court, Justice Stevens writes that because “the immediate


objective of the searches was to generate evidence for law enforcement


purposes in order to reach that goal”, those searches and the use of


information derived from them to investigate and prosecute “is inconsistent


with the Fourth Amendment.” Ferguson therefore supports Collins’ motionto suppress.


      Gelberg later writes that there are few or no 4th Amendment


protections against “administrative searches”, meaning searches that are


conducted by government agencies for regulatory purposes. In defense of this


claim, Gelburg cites New York v. Burger, 482 U.S. 691, 699 (1987) and City


of Los Angeles v. Patel, 135 S. Ct. 2443, 2454 (2015). Neither case is on


point. In Burger, the defendant operated a junkyard without a license, a


violation of law, and also did not keep records, also a violation of law. The


police came to conduct a routine inspection, which the defendant permitted,


and arrested him when they discovered stolen vehicles, leading to a


conviction for trafficking in stolen vehicles. The defendant appealed his


conviction on the grounds that the search of his business violated his 4th


Amendment rights. The Supreme Court upheld the conviction on the grounds


that the defendant knew that his business was subject to routine inspections


and therefore had a diminished expectation of privacy.


 Burger is not on point. First of all, the defendant personally consented


to the inspection. Second, and more importantly, the inspection was routine


and was not conducted in order to search for incrimination information.


Collins was not running a business that was subject to routine inspections;


nor was she running a business, such as a junkyard, that must be regularly


inspected to prevent behaviors (such as improperly disposing of toxic waste)that can immediately have massive consequences for public safety. In fact,


Collins had a heightened expectation of privacy, given that the records of


hers that were searched were medical records. Nor is Patel on point, since, in


it, the Supreme Court ruled that hotel owners are not required to turn over


guest records to police unless the latter have a warrant, such records being


protected by the 4th Amendment.


      In stating its reasons for rejecting Collins’ motion to have her guilty


plea vacated, 17th District Court puts forth the same arguments as Gelburg,


making the same claims as Gelberg as to their being supported by Miller,


Burger, Patel, and Smith. Since we have already considered these arguments,


we need not review them afresh. The 17th District Court also claims that


Dep't of State Police v. Sitz, 496 U.S. 444, 455 (1990) and Maryland v. King,


569 U.S. 435, 463 (2013) are on point. Neither case is in fact on point. Sitz


concerns the legality of DUI checkpoints, the Supreme Court Ruling that they


are in fact Constitutional and do not violate 4th Amendment rights. A drunk


driver is an immediate and extreme threat to public safety, since such a


person is operating heavy machinery in a manner that is likely to result in


loss of life and limb and is also likely to cause public roadways and other


public utilities to be unusable. Consequently, the 4th Amendment does as


little to protect drunk drivers from DUI checkpoints as it does to prevent


police from detaining a drunkard who is brandishing a weapon in a crowdedpublic square. Collins was not an immediate or extreme threat to public


safety, there being no immediate or grave threat to public safety that the DEA


was averting by searching through her records, and Sitz is therefore


irrelevant.


 Maryland v. King is also irrelevant. In Maryland, the Supreme Court


ruled that the police were within their rights to take DNA samples from


people whom they had already arrested. The Court’s position in Maryland is


that if the police already had strong enough evidence to arrest a given person


for a given crime, then it could use DNA samples, obtained through cheek


swabs, to corroborate said evidence, in much the way they can use


fingerprints. Consequently, Maryland concerns cases where the police


already have enough information for an arrested to be warranted and does not


concern suspicionless or warrantless searches for information. Since the


search of Collins medical records was suspicionless and warrantless, there


being no evidence apartment from the information thereby obtained to


investigate or arrest Collins, there is no parallel with Maryland.


      Both of the courts involved in Collins case obliquely suggest that drug


dealers are such a threat to public safety that their 4th Amendment


protections are voided, and both courts seem to regard the highly regulated


nature of the medical industry as being proof of this. Both contentions are


false. If an industry is highly regulated, it follows that people involved in ithave to comply with regulations and laws specific to their professions, and it


therefore follows that they are more exposed than they would otherwise be to


civil and criminal indictments following from regulatory activity. The DEA


officers who conducted suspicionless and warrantless searches of her medical


records were not regulators and were not functioning as regulators. Their sole


purpose was to find evidence on which to make arrests. This was not


regulatory activity that led to an arrest, as was the case in Burger, and as


would be the case if a stockbroker were arrested for stock-fraud following a


routine SEC-audit of his records.


      Katz v. United States, 389 US 347 - Supreme Court 1967 is on point.


In Katz the Supreme Court overturned a conviction on the grounds that the


information leading to that conviction was obtained through warrantless,


suspicionless electronic surveillance of a public phone used by the defendant.


Concurring with the Court’s opinion, Justice Harlan wrote: “[T]here is a


twofold requirement, first that a person have exhibited an actual (subjective)


expectation of privacy and, second, that the expectation be one that society is


prepared to recognize as ‘reasonable.’” This two-prong litmus test has


become the standard by which courts have come to adjudicate putative


violations of 4th Amendment protections, and there is no doubt that in


Collins’ case, the government has failed both prongs of this test. It failed the


first prong, since exchanges with one’s physician, including the recordsresulting therefrom, are, and for many centuries have been, the Common Law


privacy gold standard. Hence the requirement that insurance companies


handle patient medical records in accordance with guidelines that “assure that


such information is provided and utilized in a manner that appropriately


protects the confidentiality of the information and the privacy of individuals


receiving health care services and items” (Health (Insurance Portability and


Accountability Act of 1996 Pub. L. 104-191, 110 Stat. 1936 (2012) SEC.


1128 (C) B (ii) CONFIDENTIALITY), and the related requirement that


“Each person….who maintains or transmits health information shall maintain


reasonable and appropriate administrative, technical, and physical


safeguards… to ensure the integrity and confidentiality of the information…


[and] to protect against any reasonably anticipated…threats or hazards to the


security or integrity of the information; and…unauthorized uses or


disclosures of the information; and …otherwise to ensure compliance with


this part by the officers and employees of such person (Health Insurance


Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, Pub. L. 104-191, 110 Stat. 1936


(2012) SEC. 1173 (2) SAFEGUARDS).


      The government’s behavior fails the second prong since Collins own


behavior, however criminal it may have been, was predicated on the very


supposition that her exchanges with the physicians in question were her


business and nobody else’s. Indeed, the government tacitly admitted as muchin its very method of investigating this case. It did not approach any of


Collins’ doctors directly, knowing that they would have had deeply


entrenched professional resistances to divulging patient information, and


consciously used the Medical Database as a workaround. It is not a defense


of the government's behavior that Collins was abusing her expectation of


privacy, since rights don’t cease to exist when criminals take advantage of


them.


        Moreover, rights don’t cease to exist when statutes are enacted that


violate them, rendering null and void the 17th District Court’s claim that:


“The very statutory regime permitting this investigation, the CSA, supports


the finding that Congress does not view these records as inherently private


and weakens the asserted expectation of privacy." If the CSA (Controlled


Substance Act) warrants violations of Constitutional Rights, then it is the


CSA that must be modified, not those rights. Moreover, while there may be


cogent reasons for strictly regulating the buying and selling of certain


substances, it cannot plausibly be held that public safety and health require


the government to strip drug dealers and users of Constitutional protections.


      Finally, the arguments put forth by both courts, along with the


Government’s suspicionless and warrantless search of the Medical Database,


are inconsistent with the CSA itself. According to Title 21 United States


Code (USC) Controlled Substances Act Part E (b), law enforcement isauthorized to enter ‘controlled premises’ (meaning databases or physical


locations containing records of transactions involving controlled substances,


such as prescriptions or pharmacy records) only “[f]or the purpose of


inspecting, copying, and verifying the correctness of records, reports, or other


documents”---in other words, to ensure compliance with regulations, not to


conduct criminal investigations. Moreover, the officer conducting such an


inspection must “upon stating his purpose and presenting to the owner,


operator, or agent in charge of such premises (A) appropriate credentials and


(B) a written notice of his inspection authority”---advance notice must be


given and the inspections must be done overtly, not with stealth. Finally,


warrantless inspections are permissible only under the following five


circumstances:


 


      (1) with the consent of the owner, operator, or agent in charge of the


controlled premises;


      (2) in situations presenting imminent danger to health or safety;


      (3) in situations involving inspection of conveyances where there is


reasonable cause to believe that the mobility of the conveyance makes it


impracticable to obtain a warrant;


      (4) in any other exceptional or emergency circumstance where time or


opportunity to apply for a warrant is lacking; or      (5) in any other situations where a warrant is not constitutionally


required.


 


      We have already shown that (2) does not apply in this case, and it is


self-evident that (3)-(5) also do not apply. Only (1) can credibly be argued to


apply, and the government’s entire case therefore rests upon the


government’s contention that, since Collins was not herself the proprietor of


the Medical Database, (1) permitted the government to search said database.


However, (1) grants no such authority to the government, given that, as


previously established, Collins’ expectation of Doctor-patient confidentiality


followed her into the Database. Consequently, the government’s case, resting


as it does on information obtained through an illegal search, is without


foundation.


 


                                         CONCLUSION


 


        According to the two Courts that denied Collins’ two motions, Collins


medical records were not protected by the 4th Amendment for the following


three reasons. First, they were held by third parties. Second, the drug-


prescription industry is highly regulated and therefore exposes those involved


in it to lower expectations of privacy. Third, drug dealing is a threat to public


safety, much like drunk driving, and therefore warrants a curtailing of 4th


Amendment rights.


      Each of these arguments is misconceived. When patients agree to let


third parties keep their records, they do so either because they expect their


doctor-patient privilege to continue to be honored or because their need for


medical care outweighs their concern over potential violations of privacy and


confidentiality. Consequently, when patients sign over their records to third


parties, they either don't relinquish their expectation of privacy or they do so


under duress (and therefore, in effect, not at all). Second, if an industry is


highly regulated, that does indeed expose those involved in it to legal


obligations additional to those borne by all citizens, and it therefore exposes


them to civil and criminal liability resulting from regulatory activity. But this


is irrelevant in Collins’ case, since in searching through her records, the DEA


were not functioning as regulators.      It cannot plausibly be maintained that people who illegally sell


oxycodone and Percocet constitute a sufficiently clear and present threat to


public safety to warrant suspensions of their Constitutional rights. What


would be a threat to public safety would be the lack of medical care and


inadequate medical care resulting from the erosion of doctor-patient privilege


that would result if patient records were stripped of 4th Amendment


protections, as they would be if the 17th District Court’s ruling were upheld.


      Finally, when statutes are enacted that are incompatible with


Constitutional Protections, it is those statutes that must be modified, not those


protections. According to the 17th District Court, the “statutory regime”


constituted by the CSA demands an erosion of 4th Amendment Protections.


If this is true, then it is the CSA that must be modified, not those protections.


                                   Motion to Quash


 


      IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF OKLAHOMA COUNTY


                            STATE OF OKLAHOMA


 


 


THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA,)

Plaintiff,)

                                                )


Sandi Koufax)


                                                )


                Defendant.)


 


    MOTION TO QUASH AND DISMISS FOR INSUFFICIENT


EVIDENCE


 


COMES NOW the defendant Sandi Koufax, by and through undersigned


counsel, Petra Martinez, and moves that the charge against her be quashedand dismissed for insufficient evidence on the grounds that the State’s


evidence is wholly insufficient to establish that Ms. Koufax committed


assault and battery with a dangerous weapon on March 3, 2017. In support,


Ms. Koufax shows the following: Ms. Koufax is charged with one Count of


Assault and Battery with a Dangerous Weapon in violation of  21 O.S. 21-


645. Randy Johnson, the alleged victim and the State’s only witness, states in


his own testimony that he was not afraid for his own well-being and,


moreover, that he did not have a reasonable apprehension of injury, this being


an element of assault (Curry v. Streater, 213 P. 3d 550 - Okla: Supreme


Court 2009). Moreover, Mr. Johnson explicitly states that Ms. Koufax lacked


an apparent ability to execute the threat of any kind of violence, this too


being a necessary element of assault (Curry v. Streater, supra).


Consequently, the necessary elements of assault are lacking here, and the


indictment must therefore be quashed. 


                                BRIEF IN SUPPORT


    A. Statement of Facts


      Ms. Koufax was shopping at the Dollar Tree Store, where Mr. Johnson


worked as a clerk. According to Mr. Johnson, Ms. Koufax left the store and


the buzzer went off, indicating that Ms. Koufax was in possession of an item


that had not been paid for. According to Mr. Johnson, he ran outside the store


to confront Ms. Koufax, claiming that he asked her to give back a pair of pink


pants that he saw her shove in her purse. (PH Tr. at 10) Ms. Koufax refused,


and Mr. Johnson called the police (PH Tr. at 10) Mr. Johnson alleges that,


while talking with the police, Ms. Koufax struck him several times in the face


“using  her  fists.”  (PH  Tr.  at  11)  By  his  own  admission,  Mr.  Johnson


responded not by fleeing but by shoving Ms. Koufax to the ground, then


forcibly taking her purse from her and running back into the store. (PH Tr. at


12) Mr. Johnson emphasizes that he was not at this point in any way afraid of


Ms. Koufax. He emphasizes his ability to deal with any threat that she might


have represented, point out that “I been in enough altercations…that I kinda


know how to defend myself”. (PH Tr. at 11)  Mr. Johnson makes it clear that,


instead of fleeing from Ms. Koufax, he gently pushed her, which caused her


to “go down”, owing to her “wobbly” and enfeebled condition. (PH Tr. at 12)


      Mr. Johnson alleges that he then ran behind a counter, at which pointMs. Koufax allegedly threw M&M’s and other small items at Mr. Johnson


(PH Tr. at 12). According to Mr. Johnson, Ms. Koufax then picked up a


ceramic  bowl,  with  the  apparent  intention  of  throwing  it  in  his  general


direction. (PH Tr. at 12) He indicates that he was not afraid of being struck


by said bowl, for the reason that “I was dodging everything she was throwing


at me.” (PH Tr. at 15). Mr. Johnson indicates that there was a glass cigarette


case behind him and that, had Ms. Koufax been able to throw the ceramic


bowl, she would have shattered the cigarette case. (PH Tr. at 12) Mr. Johnson


claims that he then charged at Ms. Koufax and tackled her. He explicitly


states  that  his  intention  was  to  prevent  Ms.  Koufax  from  damaging  the


cigarette case: “And she grabs one of those [ceramic bowls] and she's fixing


to throw it. And, you know, if I jumped out of the way then it woulda hit the


cigarette case behind me and shattered the glass.” (PH Tr. at 12-13) Later in


the proceedings, Mr. Johnson confirms that this was indeed his intention: “I


was  dodging  everything  she  was  throwing  at  me.  And  if  I  dodged  the


cigarette case was right behind me. So I didn't want it to hit the cigarette case


or  it  would've  broken  the  glass.”  Mr.  Johnson  testifies  that  after  he  had


charged at Ms. Koufax, with the intention of preventing her from shattering


the cigarette case, and while he was in the process of forcibly subduing her,


she struck him with the ceramic bowl: “So I run around the counter, you


know, so she wouldn't throw it. And she hits me in the side of the head withit.”  (PH Tr. at 13).


      There is an ambiguity in Mr. Johnson’s testimony. At one point, he


indicates that he and Mr. Koufax were on different sides of the counter and


that he therefore had to run from out behind the counter in order to prevent


her from throwing the ceramic bowl at the cigarette display: “When she rared


--  when  she  picked  it  up  and  did  like  this  (indicated)  I  came  around  the


counter  really  quick  to  stop  her,  basically  what  I  did.”  (PH  Tr.  at  16).


Immediately thereafter, however, Mr. Johnson says that when Ms. Koufax


attempted to throw the ceramic bowl, he and she were on the same side of the


counter. Defense counsel asked Mr. Johnson: “So when she went to throw it


you guys were on, the same side of the counter?”, to which he replied: “Yeah.


Yeah. I was standing right next to her.” (PH Tr. at 16). Notwithstanding this


ambiguity in his testimony, Mr. Johnson is adamant that his objective was to


prevent damage to the display case and was not concerned that Mr. Koufax


was going to harm him.


      There  are  discrepancies  between  Mr.  Johnson’s  testimony  and  Ms.


Koufax’s testimony. Ms. Koufax agrees that she left the store with a pair of


pink pants that stole, and she agrees that Mr. Johnson followed her. But Ms.


Koufax claims that Mr. Johnson simply grabbed her from behind (PH Tr. at


20), leading to a struggle between them, which eventuated in Mr. Johnson’s


through Ms. Koufax on and the ground (PH Tr. at 20) and forcibly grabbingher purse from her and running into the store with it. (PH Tr. at 20)  In


agreement  with  Mr.  Johnson’s  testimony,  Ms.  Koufax  alleges  that  Mr.


Johnson came out from behind the counter, except that, according to Ms.


Koufax, Mr. Johnson grabbed her hand, then grabbed and forcibly pushed her


backwards. Ms. Koufax claims that she does not recall striking Mr. Johnson


with a ceramic bowl. (PH Tr. at 22) 


 


    B. The testimony of the state’s sole witness, Mr. Randy Johnson,  is


          unambiguously  to  the  effect  that  he  was  not  in  imminent


          apprehension of harmful or offensive contact with Ms. Koufax,


        and one the elements of assault is therefore absent. 


 


      Ms. Koufax did not put the alleged victim imminent apprehension of


fear of harmful or offensive contact with her, and for this reason there are no


grounds for an assault charge against Ms. Koufax: See Adams v. Garvin


Cnty. Bd. of Cnty. Comm'rs, 2016 U.S. Dist.: “The elements of assault are:


(1) that the defendant acted intending to cause a harmful or offensive contact


with the person, or an imminent apprehension of such a contact, and (2) the


other person is put in such imminent apprehension. OUJI No. 19.1”  In


particular, Mr. Johnson’s testimony makes it clear that when Ms. Koufax


allegedly struck him with the ceramic bowl, it was in response to Mr.Johnson’s charging her and subduing her with the intention only of preventing


her from damaging a cigarette case. On direct examination, Mr. Johnson


testifies: “And she grabs one of those and she's fixing to throw it. And, you


know, if I jumped out of the way then it woulda hit the cigarette case behind


me and shattered the glass. So I run around the counter, you know, so she


wouldn't throw it. And she hits me in the side of the head with it.” (PH Tr. at


12-13) .” Mr. Johnson is effectively saying that because he was afraid for the


cigarette case and was not afraid for his own safety, he charged Ms. Koufax


and attempted to wrest the ceramic bowl from her, this being the immediate


cause of the alleged battery. Simply put, the precipitating cause of the alleged


battery was the absence on Mr. Johnson’s part of imminent apprehension of


harmful or offensive contact. Mr. Johnson’s later testimony confirms this: “I


came around the counter at that point in time so that she wouldn't throw it


right there and destroy the cigarette cabinet. And when I came around the


counter she hit me in the head with it.”


        Assuming it accurate, Mr. Johnson’s testimony establishes that Ms.


Koufax was far too incapacitated to be such a threat. “[S]he rared back, tried


to hit me again. And I blocked it and, like I said, she was pretty wobbly and


she fell into… this huge display of Coke and chips…and just starts wallerin'


around.” (PH Tr. At 13)  In other words, Ms. Koufax wasn’t even able to pick


herself up, her attempts to do so merely resulting in her ‘wallering around.’ Inother words, Ms. Koufax was unable to stand up and could only thrash about.


     An element of assault is “an apparent ability to execute the threat”


of violence. (Curry v. Streater, supra.) Ms. Koufax lacked this ability, and


there was therefore no assault. Consequently, there was no assault and battery


with a dangerous weapon, since “The elements of assault and battery with a


dangerous weapon are the commission of an assault and battery upon another


by means of any deadly weapon as is likely to produce death. 21 O.S. 1981,


652.” (Ashinsky v. State, 780 P. 2d 201 - Okla: Court of Criminal Appeals


1989.) Consequently, the elements requisite for a charge Assault and Battery


with a Dangerous Weapon in violation of  21 O.S. 21-645 is absent.


      Accordingly, this case must be dismissed.


      WHEREFORE,  based  on  the  above  and  foregoing,  Ms.  Koufax


respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant his Motion to Quash and


Dismiss for Insufficient Evidence.


                                                        Respectfully submitted,
