 Legal Negotiation Exercise Reflection Paper 2: The Negotiation – Clients


                                    (Law School)


 


      Please write a 2-4 page reflection paper on the following questions, as


well as anything else you want to share about the experience.


 


              1.            Now that you have completed the negotiation, do you


      think your attorney prepared you adequately? If not, what did you think


    you should have been better prepared for?


 


 


      My sister and I were adequately prepared, but this was because we


prepared ourselves; it was not, I am sorry to say, because our attorney


prepared us. Before entering into negotiations, we should have had known the


following:


 


      *How much money my brother was receiving from the V.A.


      *How much money he was receiving from other parties


      *What his assets were (stocks, bonds, properties, etc.)


      *Whether he was completely unable to work, partly unable to work, or


able to work (but choosing not to).      *Whether his alleged inability to work, which he claims to be the


result of a hand injury, is to any degree a consequence of psychological or


emotional impairment and, if so, whether he has violent or anti-social


tendencies.


      *How much money (if any) he was spending on attorney fees


      *What his emotional disposition towards us was and, in particular,


what had been motivating him to behave so selfishly towards us (was it mere


selfishness or was it active malice?)


      *Whether or not he is psychologically well and, if not, whether he is


physically dangerous (relevant because we have children and will soon be his


neighbor).


 


      Had we had this information, we could very possibly have negotiated


a much better deal for ourselves. We entered negotiations assuming that


Robert had no funds and that his behavior was motivated by financial


desperation, not by ill will. But we did not know that to be the case, and we


still don't. The house in question is large and Robert could have shared it with


us at little inconvenience to himself. He did not do so, forcing us to pay high


rents, even though, as Robert well knew, my sister and I (unlike Robert) have


children, have grueling jobs, and pay high rents. In retrospect, Robert’s


behavior embodied callous indifference towards the welfare of me, my sister,and our children; and he wouldn’t even talk to us until we forced him to do so


by ceasing to pay the mortgage. In light of these facts, Robert’s behavior


might have been driven by active ill will towards us, and not by financial


desperation. Therefore, contrary to what we have been assuming, Robert


might have had money. Also, given how poorly Robert treated us, I am not


entirely comfortable with the idea that he will be our neighbor. Additionally,


Robert’s lack of character throughout all of this casts doubt on his credibility,


making it unclear whether he is in fact disabled and unable to make a living.


Had it turned out that Robert was simply malingering, my sister and I would


have entered negotiations with a very different, and much less compromising


mindset.


      It was probably not our attorney’s job to get us this information, but it


was, I believe, his responsibility to at least make it clear that this information


might be helpful to us. Our attorney did not do this; he simply took


everything Robert said at face value and accepted his offer without question.


It might turn out that Robert, who is now our new neighbor, is emotionally


antagonistic towards us, or that Robert uses his new position as our neighbor


to find a new way to sponge off of us, our attorney. If so, our attorney is to be


blamed for not making us aware of these possible outcomes.


 


              2.            Did you achieve your goals? Do you feel satisfied with    the outcome of the negotiation? Why or why not? Did you attorney


      prepare you for achieving everything you wanted?


 


      For the most part, we did succeed in achieving our objectives. Our


main objective was to reclaim our fair share of the property that our father


had left us while not alienating or dispossessing our brother; and we did


achieve that goal.


      That said, I am not entirely satisfied with the outcome of the


negotiation. This is because I now question whether our objective was the


right one. My brother did not exhibit any empathy towards me, my sister, or


our families. This makes me think that we made too many concessions to


him, and it makes wonder whether he is someone I want to be living next


door to my children or myself. Time will tell; he may turn out to be an


excellent neighbor and uncle to my children. But I believe that, in light of his


previous behavior, our attorney should have made some inquiries into his


mental health and his attitudes towards me and my sister, which, judging by


his past behavior, were not positive.


 


              3.            Do you think your attorney did an effective job of


      representing your position? Why or why not? Do you think your


      attorney could have achieved a better outcome if s/he had done      anything differently?


 


      I do not believe I was particularly well-prepared. My brother’s


behavior had been callous and possibly a bit deranged. For that reason, I


should have been less quick to assume that he had the same degree of familial


warmth towards me and my sister that she and I have towards him, and I also


should have done more to find out what his actual financial and professional


situation was. That said, I believe that my attorney should at least have


alerted us to the possibility that my brother was not well-disposed towards


and therefore was not somebody we would want to have as a neighbor. I


believe this to be a part of a pattern on my attorney’s part of taking the least


confrontational path. I am not saying that we necessarily should have been


more confrontational; nor am I saying that the outcome was a bad one. What


I am saying is that I don’t have enough information to know whether the


outcome was a good one. My attorney should have provided me with the


relevant information or at the very least with the need to have it.


 


              4.            Do you think you and your attorney used your


      confidential information effectively in the negotiation? If not, why not?


 


      I did not disclose anything to my attorney that had to be keptconfidential.


 


              5.            What did your attorney do well? What do you think s/he


      could have done better?


 


      My attorney did show up to proceedings, and he had clearly read the


relevant documents, filed the relevant paperwork, and so far as I could tell


was familiar with the relevant points of law. Also, my attorney did not


undermine me and my sister in our attempt to secure a decent outcome,


which we succeeded in doing. I would therefore say that my attorney did


technically fulfill his obligations.


      I would not say that he fulfilled them distinction, however. My


brother's behavior prior to these proceedings had been positively anti-social.


He had taken over a five-bedroom house and refused to let either me or my


sister or any mutual family members so much as stay there, let alone live


there; and he did this knowing that my sister and I work full-time jobs, have


families, and are under financial stress. And he did it without ever paying


rent: he made me and my sister pay his way and gave us nothing in return. To


me, this suggests a low degree of morality on my brother's part. This should


have indicated to my attorney that we might not want to be living next door


to Robert. It also suggests that should have looked more closely into Robert’spsychological condition before deciding to be neighbors with him. As my


new neighbor, is Robert going to find a new way to sponge off of my


resources? If we refuse to give him money, will he threaten me or my family?


The answer to each of these questions may well be ‘no', but I don't know that;


and I believe that, in light of these unknowns, my attorney probably should at


the very least have me and my sister to reconsider whether we wanted Robert


to have the cottage along with access to the driveway. I am not trying to be


alarmist, but there is nothing in Robert's behavior in all of this that indicates


any degree of goodwill towards me or my sister; and I’m a bit disappointed


that I am having to worry about all this now, after an agreement has been


reached.


 


 


              6.            What, if anything, surprised you about the negotiation


      experience?


 


      What surprised me was the extent to which the proceedings were


influenced by the personalities involved. I had previously seen the law as


dispassionate in nature and assumed that legal proceedings, including


negotiations, were conducted in an unemotional, strictly law-driven way.


This turned out not to be the case. Obviously the law was relevant, but I cameto see that the law permits a number of different outcomes, it being up to the


attorneys involved, and possibly also their clients, to decide which specific


outcome is actualized.


      Another thing that I came to see is that, before retaining an attorney,


one should do more to think about what one wants one’s attorney to do. As


they are represented on TV and in the movies, lawyers are fearless and are


always looking for new angles of attack. If this case is any indication,


lawyers are rather passive and will do what they are professionally required


to do but cannot be counted to do much more than that.


 


 


              7.            Overall, do you think this exercise was a good learning


      experience?


 


      I do. Before I took part in this exercise, I thought that a given case was


determined by the law along with the facts of the case. I now think that the


law and the facts of the case are a framework that excludes certain outcomes


while permitting a wide range of other possible outcomes, it being up to the


attorneys, their clients, and other human beings involved to determine which


of those outcomes becomes the actual one.


                                       Adverse Possession


 


        Camero & Camero Law Associates


      305 NW 5th St


        Oklahoma City, OK 73102


 


      7 February 2019


 


      Mr. Jason Williams


      313 NE 21st St


        Oklahoma City, OK 73105


 


      Dear Mr. Williams,


 


      I  am  writing  you  concerning  the  dispute  with  your  neighbor  Mr.


George  Smith.  Mr.  Smith  is  in  effect  claiming  that  he  has  come  into


possession of this land through what is known as adverse possession, this


being the process of taking ownership of land to which one does not have


title  by  occupying  it.  In  order  for  Mr.  Smith’s  claim  to  hold  up,  five


conditions have to be met. First, George Smith must have represented himself


to others as the owner of the land. Second, he must not have concealed hisoccupancy of the land in question. Third, he must not have occupied the land


with  you.  Fourth,  he  must  not  have  been  occupying  the  land  with  your


consent. Fifth, he must have been occupying the land without interruption for


at least fifteen years.


 


      If  Mr.  Smith  does  satisfy  all  five  conditions,  you  have  two  years


starting from the date of the beginning of your dispute with Mr. Smith to


dispute Mr. Smith’s claim. Also, if Mr. Smith has been polluting or damaging


the property in question, that might weight against him in a court of law.


Additionally, if land that originally belonged to Mr. Smith is on your side of


the fence, then you might have an adverse possession claim to that land.


 


      I would suggest hiring an Oklahoma real estate lawyer to determine


whether  or  not  all  five  of  the  above  conditions  have  been  met  and  also


whether  Mr.  Smith  has  been  polluting  the  land  in  question  or  otherwise


weakening his claim to it. If it turns out that his claim still holds, I would


suggest having your lawyer reach out to Mr. Smith and propose a friendly


compromise, to which, for many reasons, Mr. Smith may prove amenable.


 


        Sincerely,


       Joaquin Camero, Attorney at Law


        Camero & Camero Law Associates


      Tel. (210) 602-6109


          joaquincamero@hotmail.com


 


             I am more than my LSAT Scores (Law School Application)


 


      I am an extremely proud person, and I always try to avoid making


excuses of myself. In this context, however, I believe I owe it to all parties to


explain why my LSAT are not an accurate reflection of my abilities as a law


student or lawyer.


      English is my second language. Not only is it my second language:


Before I went to college I was completely immersed in a Spanish-speaking


culture. All of my friends, family and professional acquaintances spoke


Spanish and Spanish alone. When it became incumbent on me to learn to


become professionally, and not just functionally, fluent in English, I did so


quickly, and with great joy. But it is very easy for native speakers of English


to underestimate the degree to which sensitivity to linguistic nuances affect


one’s ability to do well on standardized tests, especially on the LSAT.


      I am not making excuses. I want to provide my future clients with


maximally good service, and to that end nothing less than complete and total


fluency will suffice. My LSAT scores, which were average, were a wake-up


call for me. Since then, I have spent every spare moment of every day


immersing myself in the subtleties of English legalese. I have also much


more conscious of the logical nuances that are buried within the linguistic


nuances in legal documents.      There are people who come to this country not speaking English and


who ace the LSATS a few years thereafter. Such people are to be admired,


but I don’t know that they are to be used as a reference-point. I have known


many people who are functionally fluent in English and who, when working


in their native language, are geniuses, but who can barely function at a


professional level when speaking English. I believe that such people are more


the norm than the exception.


      My objective, I would like to emphasize, is to be exception, not the


rule: I want to be a superlative law student and lawyer---and I will be. I will


be because I intend to be, and because I have the discipline, focus, and


attention to detail necessary to do so. It is my responsibility, however, to


avail you of all the relevant facts about myself, and English being my second


language (and one that I did not begin to learn until mid teens) is, I believe,


not without relevance.


      I also believe that my performance on the LSAT was marred by the


fact that I was working two jobs, completing an MBA, and working every


day on behalf of a prisoner of the State of Texas whose rights had been


violated and who, thanks in part to my efforts, was released less than one


month ago. This is not an excuse. There are many people who work two jobs


and are sleep-deprived on the day of the LSAT but who perform brilliantly


nonetheless. Echoing what I said earlier, however, such superlative cases arenot always the best yardsticks. They are not to be discarded as mere statistical


outliers, but their significance, if I may wax philosophical, is that they raise


the bar and is not that they are the bar.


      I would like to confess that I was reluctant to write this statement. I


take great pride in being self-reliant. Looking back, this may have hurt me at


some junctures, as there have been many times when I declined assistance


from which I could have benefited. This happened during my first year of


college. Having just suffered tremendous personal and financial loss, I


refused any kind of help from anyone, and I certainly could have used it. But


I turned my situation around, got A’s in classes that I had previously barely


passed, and graduated with high honors. I was able to carry out this turn


around because it became important to me to do well in college, and I will


excel in every aspect of my legal studies because it is a personal mission of


mine to do so.


      As I would like to believe that my written work indicates, my


command of the English language has now reached the point where I will


have no difficulty dealing with the intricacies of legal English. I thank you


for the giving me the opportunity to clear up this matter and thank you for


your consideration.


                     Describe Your Background (College Application)


 


      Tech specs: Minimum three full paragraphs (one paragraph for each


question), maximum five paragraphs, worth 10 points (does not need to be a


classically structured essay i.e. no need for intro and conclusion).


 


        Self-reflection on class


      1 How would you describe your class background?


 


      I was a solidly middle class. My father was the manager of a


pharmacy, and my mother was a stay-at-home mom. We lived well but not


opulently. One day my father sustained an injury while on the job. (Even


though he was a manager, he sometimes had to stack boxes, either as part of


his regular duties or because he had to fill in for an absent employee.) After


that, he was more or less bed-ridden. He had health and disability insurance,


but they were inadequate. They simply didn’t pay what they had agreed to


pay. My mother had to get a job as a waitress, and we had to move to a


smaller house in a worse neighborhood.


      It wasn’t all bad, though. We were still together. And, even though my


father, being incapacitated, was unhappy, we still had good times. Also, my


father had played the market over the years (not, as it turns, with greatsuccess); and he tried to teach me the tricks of that trade. But it was very


complicated, and I was never really able to identify trends in the market that


would result in a windfall for me. Also, some of the concepts, e.g. price-to-


earnings ratio, were hard to understand and even hard to apply in practice.


        Anyway, I am now in college and, so I believe, am on my way back to


a respectable middle-class existence. But my experiences have made realize


how fragile one’s economic condition is, and these movies are opening my


eyes to the wealth-disparities that are responsible for the precariousness of


what I used to believe to be a ‘solidly middle- class’ mode of existence.


 


 


      2 What do you think about wealth and inequality in the US today?


Engage with the films, readings, and lectures.


 


      I have lived in the middle class and also in the lower class (albeit in


the upper echelons of it---in the ‘upper lower class’, as it were). I did not find


life in either category particularly unpleasant (even though life in each


stratum had its share of problems). Life in the middle class was fairly


‘luxurious’. We had a large house, lived in a quiet and peaceful suburban


neighborhood, and had a number of amenities. But my father seemed to be


working all the time—he left home at 7:00 am and did not come back untilaround 7:00 pm. And I always secretly wondered if all that work was really


worth it.


      When my father was laid off, we downshifted into the lower class. Our


apartment and neighborhood were rather squalid and dingy and depressing.


But we will had food, heat, internet and all of the other basic amenities.


      While in college, I have become friends with some people who come


from the ‘top 1%’ of this country—the so-called ‘super rich’, and I have been


to their houses and vacationed with them. Here is what I noticed. They had


very nice houses. Many of them had servants. And one or two had tennis


courts in their back yards!


      But the ‘bread winner’ in one of these super rich households seemed


to be working all the time and had little time for his/her children. The


children were in some respects in a very good place. They did not have to


work (at least not in a serious way) during college, which left them time to


focus on their studies. (Which some of them did, resulting in good grades and


well-developed minds. Others squandered their money and time, partying and


doing drugs.) And when they left college, they did not have any debt. But the


parent or parents who were responsible for their money did not, it seemed,


spend enough time with them. So their wealth was a mixed bag, I thought.


      It was clear to me from my personal experience that there are massive


income disparities in this country, and the movies, especially WealthInequality in America, made the precise extent of those disparities very clear


to me. But I didn’t really see all that many structural differences between my


life, during the lower-class part of my upbringing, and those of my super-


wealthy friends. I got the feeling that better health care was available to the


latter. And I also saw with my own eyes that those who were born into super


wealthy families seemed, in some cases (not all), to have the option of not


working. But, strangely, a lot of them did have to work. (Apparently, their


wealthy parents did not want them to be ‘on the dole’, to use an expression


that my one of my super rich friend’s father would use.)


      So yes, there are massive income disparities. But the really important


things---food, lodging, leisure time—seem to be available to members of all


classes. The one really important thing that does not seem to be available to


poor people is good health care.


      Of course, these points do not hold universally. The Isle of Flowers,


with its graphic footage of children rummaging through piles of garbage for


food, made it clear that, in some societies, being lower class means not


having enough food (and certainly not enough clean food), possibly not


having clean water, almost certainly not having adequate health care,


probably not having a decent education, and very likely living a short (and in


many ways unpleasant) life. But in the United States, even the poor (with the


exception of the absolute poorest, such as homeless people) don’t seem tohave it quite so bad.


 


 


 


      3 How do you think you are or are not affected by wealth inequality?


 


      There are a couple of ways. First, because of my straitened family


circumstances, I have to work. This takes time away from my studies, which


I feel limits me. It actually limits in a couple of ways. First, it makes it harder


for me to get the kinds of grades that I probably need to get to pull myself up


socioeconomically. Second, it makes it hard to absorb the information in


question, which means that my mind is not being benefited as much from my


education as it could be. Also, even though I work, which offsets expenses to


some extent, I will still have a lot of debt after college. And while I don’t


know exactly how it will impact my life, the impact probably won’t be


positive.


      So I think the main way that my socioeconomic status affects my life


is that it takes away time—time that I sorely need, especially at this crucial


juncture of my development.


      But quite frankly, that isn’t so much a consequence of ‘the injustices


of capitalism’ as it is of the fact that education is very expensive. And I don’tknow why it is so expensive, and the movies we watched didn’t really


address that question. My father put himself through college on the basis of a


part-time job. He lived without roommates in what he described as a pretty


nice apartment. And he had no debt after college. All of which probably ties


in in some way to the growing income disparities in this country. But I don’t


immediately see the nature of the tie-in, and the movies, though informative,


did not shed light on that particular topic.


                               Personal Statement (Law School)


 


      Personal Statement: Please attach a document of no more than two


(2) double-spaced, typed pages. One of the goals of the Admissions


Committee, at Texas A&M University School of Law, when making


decisions is to admit a diverse student body that will contribute to a


collaborative and progressive learning environment. Academic background


and strength of performance, though important, are not the only criteria


evaluated in the application process. For this reason, a personal statement,


written by you, is required as part of the application. In this statement we


seek information about you and your interest in transferring to Texas A&M


University School of Law.


 


      I am a proud Latino-American who was raised bilingual and bi-


cultural. Whereas others who are similarly bicultural tend to view their


identities in political terms, I view my identity in economic terms. While I


doubt that all Latino-Americans are in ideological lockstep, I do not doubt


that all Latino-Americans wish to have meaningful and prosperous careers.


And this is just what is happening: the Latino-American community is


becoming increasingly significant as an economic force. For this reason,


Latinos are increasingly likely to become doctors, lawyers, and entrepreneurs,with the result that Latinos are increasingly in need of business-related


services, e.g. financial services, marketing services, IT-services, and, of


course, legal services.


      My objective is to become a tax lawyer who services the burgeoning


Latino-American business-sector. Given how complex the US Tax Code is, it


is very hard for a business owner to prepare his own taxes without either


overpaying dramatically, thereby cutting into his already thin margins, or


exposing himself to civil or criminal liability, thereby jeopardizing his very


freedom. Moreover, Latino entrepreneurs are likely to need legal


representatives who are fluent in both Spanish and English and who are


equally at home in both Latino-American society and mainstream American


society. The rapid proliferation of Latino-run American businesses therefore


represents an opportunity for someone of my linguistic and cultural


background.


      It also represents an opportunity that my skills and personal


experience give me the ability to service. I have personally known many


aspiring Latino-entrepreneurs. Those who succeeded were always realistic


about the financial and legal dimensions of running a business, always


making sure that, before any problems arose, they had adequate funding and


competent legal representation. The ones who tried to keep start-up costs low


by foregoing adequate legal representation ended up spending far more intaxes than they would have spent on a competent tax-attorney, and as a result,


they did not have enough capital reserves left over to run the business. These


were not incompetent people. They often had very good products and


services to offer, and many of them organized their businesses intelligently


and cost-effectively. But they didn’t realize, until after it was too late, that


taxes are a business’s greatest operating expense, and they ended up having


to close shop, often with nothing to show for their efforts besides massive


back-taxes.


      At first, I found this discouraging. But I soon came to realize that I


could help improve the situation. I have always been very comfortable with


numbers and with complex procedures; and I have always had an affinity for


business, having received a bachelor’s (from Texas A&M) in International


Business Administration and an MBA (also from Texas A&M) with a


specialization in finance. In addition, I have worked with or for innumerable


small to mid-sized businesses in Texas. Coupled with my cultural


background, my training and experience in business make me unusually


capable of servicing the complex needs of the exploding Latino-American


business community.


      For this reason, it is very important to me that I practice law in Texas


and also, consequently, that I receive my J.D. from an institution, such as the


Texas A&M University School of Law, that commands the respect of thevarious different business communities in Texas, while also giving me the


legal training needed to be of assistance to them. I need a top-notch legal


education from an institution that will give me the skills and the backing


needed to provide the best possible legal service to a very specific


community within Texas. There are few law schools, if any, that can do as


good a job of this as the Texas A&M University School of Law, and it is


therefore my ardent desire to have the privilege to study there.


 


        Addendum: Please attach a document, no longer than one (1)


double-spaced, typed page, pertaining to any area of the application for


which you would like to provide clarification or additional explanation.


 


      I wish to provide legal services for businesses in Texas; and I want to


ensure that when I begin my career, I am already able to provide all of my


clients with the best possible legal representation. This will not be possible if


I attend a law school where my training is purely theoretical, since my initial


clients will have to suffer from my lack of experience; but it will possible if I


attend a law school, such as the Texas A&M University School of Law, that


gives its students the opportunity to provide people with actual tax-related


and business-related legal services. The Entrepreneurship Law Clinic will


give me just the kind of experience that I need to understand the basics ofpracticing business-related law, and the Low Income Tax Law Clinic will


give me just the kind of experience that I will need to understand the basics


of practicing tax law.


      I have known many people who went to law school and specialized in


a given area, only to find out that they lacked the experience necessary to


help their clients. I do not want to be in that position. Also, the very fact that


Texas A&M offers these clinics to its students shows that it wants its students


to be well-prepared and to be able to help people of limited means to


overcome the legal hurdles that are holding them back in life. While I wish to


prosper as an attorney, I wish to do so by making life easier for people,


especially for aspiring entrepreneurs. My distinct impression is that the Texas


A&M University School of Law makes it possible for its graduates to do


both. For this reason, as well as those stated previously, no law school is as


well-equipped as the Texas A&M University School of Law to give me what


I need to launch my legal career.


             My Career as a Computer Security Expert (Job Application)


 


      After graduating from college, I plan on working full-time as a


computer-security specialist. A computer-security specialist prevents


individual computers as well as computer-networks from being accessed by


unauthorized users and from being corrupted by malware and viruses.


      The field of computer-security developed in the 1990’s, at more or


less the same time that the internet developed. As the internet became more


and more widely used, security-issues became increasingly severe: criminals


quickly learned how to commit theft and to defraud computer-users in a


variety of ways. And the field of computer-security had to keep pace with


these bad actors, who, as a rule, are extremely clever and determined.


      The first computer-security specialists were ‘computer nerds’ who


enjoyed working with computers and who understood the security-issues to


which individual users and networks were vulnerable. In some cases, these


very people were themselves hackers or ex-hackers.


      The early computer specialists tended not have to have formal


credentials, and even today many security-specialists have little or no formal


training. But over the years, as the computer-security profession became


more and more established and as companies came to depend on them more


and more, it has increasingly become the norm for security-specialists to haveundergraduate, and sometimes graduate, degrees in computer science.


      In the computer-security field, there are no accreditation procedures


comparable to the Medial Boards or the Bar Exam. Generally, entry into the


field of computer-security is based on competence, not on accreditations.


      The length of training varies depending on the level of ability of the


person in question, but it usually corresponds to length of time that it takes to


get an undergraduate degree, this being 4-6 years.


      There are few formal barriers to getting an internship, but


demonstrable competence in the field, along with evident willingness to


learn, are de facto requirements; and evidence of formal training, such as a


degree, also helps.


      The potential employers are companies that have computer-networks.


Included in this category are financial organizations, schools and universities,


medical research organizations, hospitals, law enforcement agencies, all


government (including military) organizations, and companies that develop


proprietary technologies, including computer-related technologies.


        Potential employers can be located anywhere where there are


computer-networks.


      The work environment depends on the institution in question. At


financial institutions, they tend to be formal and conservative. At start-ups,


the environment is more relaxed (but the amount of work done at start-upsmight actually exceed what is done at a commercial bank). Oftentimes,


computer-security experts work from home.


      The income range varies enormously, depending mainly on the


responsibilities of the specialists in question. If he is working in a subordinate


capacity for a small start-up, he might make $30,000/year or less. If he is in


charge of computer-security at Goldman Sachs, he might make upwards of


$2,000,000/year. As a general rule, companies don’t employ security-


specialists unless they have a strong need for them and are therefore willing


to pay dearly for their services. The average is probably in the low six-figures


range.


      The typical day of a cyber-security expert involves the following


tasks:


 


        *Auditing code, to make sure that it is secure.


        *Looking for ways that a company’s computer network could be


broken into.


        *Looking for ways that a company’s facilities could be physically


broken into (prevention of physical theft of documents and other sensitive


materials).


      *Writing reports.


        *Discussing said reports with the employer and with other security-experts.


        *Discussing possible ways to fix problems with the employer and


other experts.


 


      The pros of this field are:


 


        *Stimulating work


      *High salaries


        *Requires creativity


      *A changing and dynamic work environment


      *Low likelihood of one’s skills becoming economically irrelevant


 


      The cons include:


 


      *A great deal of intense and intellectual challenging training,


including training in high-level mathematics that many are not able to


understand


        *High-stress work environment


      *One’s employment depends on one’s skill-level and performance:


there is no equivalent of a partnership or of tenure


      *Work is not limited to the work-day: it is expected that security-specialists will self-educate in their down-time: one cannot ‘leave work at the


office.’


      *Lack of predictability.


 


      This sort of work appeals to highly intelligent and creative people. It


appeals to people who do not like routine and desire the intellectual


equivalent of adventure. It does not appeal to ‘button down’ people who like


security and routine. Ironically, the computer-security business is not for


people who demand safety and security; it is for people who are able to deal


with uncertainty and whose desire to learn outweighs their desire for the


comfort of routine. It also appeals to people who want to be relevant and to


work in an area that won’t become part of the rubbish heap of obsolete


professions (e.g. insurance salesman, travel agents, horse-shoe makers).


      The field of computer security is highly dynamic, and it is ideal for


people, such as myself, who are interested in crime and its prevention. I have


always been interested in true crime, this being my favorite book-genre, and


this, along with my passion for computers, is what led me into this field. A


list of the top 10 computer-related crimes (listed according to their suspected


impact on society) will make it clear just how appealing the computer-


security field is to someone who, like myself, is interested in crime:


                 1. Phishing/spoofing: Use of fake-websites/misleading emails


        to lure people into giving up security-related information, such as


          bank-account numbers (e.g. the well-known ‘Nigerian Monarch’


        Scam, whereby someone pretending to be a deposed Nigerian


          monarch asks for $10,000 in funds, with the promise of


          reciprocating with $10,000,000 in funds);


                2. Blackmail/extortion: Use of the internet to extort/blackmail


          people into doing one’s bidding (e.g. threatening to post


          compromising footage on Facebook/YouTube unless money is


        handed over);


                3. Accessing stored communications: Availing oneself of


          computer-stored information, such as social security numbers of


          bank-records, to which one does not have legal access (e.g. a bank-


        teller helping himself to customer credit-card information and then


          using said information to make purchases);


                4. Online gambling: Gambling at illegal online Casinos;


                5. Non-delivery of merchandise: Accepting money for a


          product or service posted online but then not delivering said


          product/service (e.g. someone who posts on ad for a car on


          Craigslist and takes money for it but does not deliver said vehicle to


          purchaser—which vehicle may not even exist);                6. Electronic harassment: Using the internet to harass


          someone, e.g. making libelous or unflattering claims about a given


          person to all that person’s Facebook friends;


                7. Child pornography: Use of the internet to


            sell/publicize/disseminate sexually themed photographs of minors;


                8. Prostitution: Use of the internet to advertise/perpetrate acts


        of prostitution (e.g. having a website where one advertises one’s


        erotic services (cf. the following website


              https://pornstars4escort.com/daphne-rosen-escort/ )


                9. Drug-trafficking: Use of the internet to purchase illegal


        narcotics (cf. the following website


              https://pornstars4escort.com/daphne-rosen-escort/


              https://deluxepharmacy.net/no-rx/buy-vicodin-es-7-5mg-online/


                  10.                  Criminal copyright infringement: Use of the


          internet to copy and possibly sell materitl to which one does not own


        the copyright (cf. the following website, which sells illegal pdf’s of


          copyrighted books http://www.trickswant.com/analytic-


          philosophy.pdf )


 


      As this list makes clear, computer-security is not a career for the faint-


hearted, but rather for those with a sense of adventure and a desire to live onthe edge. And there are therefore few careers that are as interesting, or as


economically relevant, as computer-security.

      Essay 1 (500-750 words)


      What are your motivations for applying to TRIUM in relation to your


current short and long term professional objectives?


 


      As an owner of two night vision camera patents, I am fascinated


with the process that an idea must endure in order to become a


marketable and manufacturable product. Military technology and


readiness has been and will continue to be on the forefront of industry,


leading the world in technological breakthroughs and advancements. Not


only is this an exciting industry to be in, but one that continues to grow


in parallel with national security obligations and concerns.


      My short term goal is almost complete. Throughout a 20 year


career within Naval Special Warfare as a Navy SEAL in a Tier One


organization, I have learned how to follow exemplary leaders and


learned how to lead exemplary men. My expertise is currently focused on


requirements and acquisitions specifically within the United States


Special Operations Command (SOCOM). Industry uses SOCOM astheir test bed for research, innovation and evaluation. It is here that


products are imagined, forged, redesigned and polished until they are


either rejected or accepted as the next advancement in military


readiness. I have gained access to an elite network next to none and been


privileged to expand that network into the civilian industry by working


numerous government Special Access Program of Records advancing


next generation soldier systems and technologies.


       I have a strong network, and I want to acquire the skills


necessary to put my network to the best possible use. An EMBA from


Trium will give me precisely those skills. In addition, it will expand my


network in much needed ways. In particular, it will connect me to people


who can mediate between my network, which is largely military-based,


and the non-military organizations that I would be dealing with as an


entrepreneur. Thus, TRIUM will supplement my existing skill-set and


network in ways that will enable me to maximize the amount of good


that I can do with them.


 During the first twenty years of my professional life, I acquired

To this end, I need to acquire a top-notch understanding of every aspect

      I have been privileged to serve with the elite of the United States

      There is a more specific reason why an education from TRIUM

to have courage. These are the very attributes that business leaders have,

 Even though I have a military background and (in some respects) a

      Essay 3 (up to 500 words)


      Share a work experience that changed your professional outlook.


Describe any challenging aspects and outcomes. 


        Collaboration rather than competition is the key to success. My


strongest attributes are my ability to network and find value in every


person or organization. One of the greatest compliments I have ever


received was from a fellow coworker describing me as “the glue in every


situation.” There are two dimensions to this compliment      . First,   I am


unusually able and willing to fix problems as they arise.           Second,   I


                       know how to identify the people who have the skills needed


to solve a given problem, and I am able to get those people to work do


      On my eighth deployment as a Navy SEAL at a Tier One


command, I was called on for a unique project in a remote and


dangerous location in Afghanistan. Due to political infighting within


several specialized US Government agencies, all tactical operations had


been shut down at this particular location. Because of my skills as a


negotiator and collaborator, I was specifically selected to fly out to this


austere location in order to de-escalate the situation. Upon arrival, I


assessed the strengths and weakness of all assets. Instead of removing the


problem assets, I reorganized, redelegated and changed how missions


were executed. I then took charge of these teams   and included members


of the US Navy SEALs and local Afghan forces. Within one week,


operations were back up and running and our teams launched on fivetargets capturing seven terrorists within a short five week period.     The


“new” organization was so successful that higher headquarters asked us


to slow down.


      This experience changed my professional outlook in several


positive ways. I learned that my own strengths go beyond skills as a Navy


Seal: I learned that interpersonal skills and leadership. I learned that I


have abilities that are valuable outside the military and, more


specifically, within the business world. I can unite people under a single


vision, and I can get them to set aside their differences and work as a


team in pursuit of a common objective, and one         of my greatest


strengths is my ability     to bring people of varying backgrounds and


cultures together and drive them towards a single vision. I also learned


that success is rarely gained from the skills of the individual or even one


team, but rather a compromise and collaboration of strategic vision


towards a shared objective that benefits all parties involved.


      The United States 4x100 swimming relay team pulled off a miracle


 comeback from behind during the 2008 Beijing Summer Olympics. In a


speech by one of the team members about the struggle in achieving goals,


Garrett-Weber said, “when you share success, people will come out of


the woodwork to be on your team.” I choose TRIUM because of its


people and network of diverse expertise and cultures. With this networkand collaboration I will be able to glue together any team for ultimate


success beyond reproach.

                       How I Benefited from this Course (Sociology)


 


      I benefited immeasurably from this course, both intellectually and


personally. I never used to think of myself as a writer, but Professor Martin


changed that, helping me learn how to express myself in writing and to


appreciate the writing of others.


      The timing of this class was ideal. I moved here from another country


just a few months ago. The experience was jarring, to say the least, and I


often felt vulnerable and disoriented. The process of drafting my personal


narrative helped me clarify my thoughts and gave me a much-needed sense of


control. In this last essay, I not only tried to express thoughts but to share a


vision, to this end taking great pains to give an accurate and vivid description


of a Chinese New Year Celebration.


        Although I have found every assignment to be challenging and


rewarding, I found the play review to be especially so. The play was a true


accomplishment, beautifully written and skillfully presented. Because I was


so absorbed in the play, it was hard for me to analyze it as I was watching it,


and it was psychologically difficult for me to do so. I also found myself


inadvertently planning out my essay, which distracted me from the play,


which distracted me and made the process of drafting the original play review


harder than it would otherwise have been. There is also the fact that I read thewrong book before watching the play, which, though funny in retrospect, left


me a tad confused while watching the play. Fortunately, I am suitemates with


two theatre majors, who gave me the right book, which I immediately read,


and who also arranged for me to interview one of the stage managers. The


interview proved most enlightening, helping me understand the stage


techniques that were used as well as complexities relating to the lighting and


other aspects of the production process.


      This is my first e-portfolio, and I have greatly enjoyed the process and


hope that my enjoyment of it came through in my work. I chose to use a light


shade of blue sun-kissed water for the background on each page, having


always had a special love for the ocean. I also included some videos of my


home on the welcome page, hoping in this way to give my fellow students a


better idea of who I am. I poured my heart into this portfolio, and I think that


will give it lasting emotional value to me and I hope that it makes it valuable


to others as well.


      Ten weeks ago, when my advisor suggested that I enroll in a WRD103


class, I was a little bit skeptical. I tend to be more comfortable in emotionally


disengaged classes (such as Computer Science and Math) and have always


felt out of my element in classes where I had to engage the emotional side of


my nature. This class awaked some part of me and helped connect with a


creative side of myself that my other classes did not speak to. I had troubleduring the first few weeks, becoming flustered when I was called upon to


speak, not always being to say what I was thinking. As the weeks passed,


however, I became a little more collected and found myself thoroughly


enjoying the class. It helped that Professor Martin always had time to talk and


always made me feel very much at ease. Most importantly, this class made it


much easier and also more pleasant for me to express myself in writing, and

                       Personal Statement (Law School Application)


 


      As a proud first-generation Latino-American, I have always had


tremendous admiration for the American legal system. The legal system in


Mexico, where I was born and raised, is much more concerned with rights


than it is with freedoms. On paper, that legal system is admirable. But in its


attempt to protect individual rights, it has undermined commercial freedoms:


because of tight regulations, it is difficult for the impecunious to start and run


a business. This has held back the economy, leading to depressed wages and


limited job opportunities. The American Legal system does a remarkably


good job of balancing individual freedoms with commercial rights. Lawyers


are necessary to maintain that delicate balance, and that is why I want to be a


lawyer.


      It is also why I want to specialize in tax law. In order to function and


to protect the rights of individuals, the government needs funds and it


therefore needs to tax. At the same time, the American Tax Code, much like


the American legal system as a whole, balances the need to fund civic


institutions with the need to allow people to transact and generate wealth. It


does this through a complex set of provisions, including allowances for


business deductions, that ensure that the people and businesses in the highest


tax-brackets can honor their tax-obligations while still providing the servicesthat led to their prosperity. As Adam Smith wrote in 1776, when a tax-code is


too rigid and punitive, revenues from taxes drop off and corruption displaces


law.


      My desire to study at the University of Houston Law Center is in


many ways a consequence of my admiration of the American Legal system.


Renowned for many different strengths, the University of Houston Law


Center is particularly well-known for its practical, no-nonsense approach to


legal instruction. That is what I need. While I have tremendous respect for


theoretical jurisprudence, my objective is to help real people with real legal


issues. I also want specialized, high-quality instruction in the area of tax law,


since I want there to be as little delay as possible between my graduation-date


and the time I can provide the best possible service for my clients. For this


reason, there is no law school better suited to my needs or better able to help


contribute to society than the University of Houston Law Center.


      I am always trying to improve myself. I spoke very little English


before my arrival in this country at the age of 16, but I did not let that hold


me back. Even though this has led me to underperform academically,


especially on standardized tests, I am a lifelong learning and I see problems


as opportunities. Instead of letting my English-language difficulties hold me


back, I focused on quantitative disciplines, eventually receiving my MBA


with a specialization in finance. My studies in business school helped meunderstand my native country’s economic difficulties and have helped me


understand the deep importance that the American legal system has had in


this nation’s continuing success. With the benefit of a University of Houston


Law Center education, I can be a part of that success and can help others be a


part of it as well. I thank you for considering my application.
