                   The American Dream (College Application)


 


 


      The American Dream can be summed up in one word: opportunity.


The essence of Americanism is opportunity. Everybody has the opportunity


to improve their lives. People are not locked into pre-existing social


arrangements. Whatever circumstances they are born into, they are able to


change and improve their lives. That is what the American Dream is.


      And it is not just a dream: it is to a considerable extent a reality. It


isn’t simply that, in the United States, people are supposed to be able to


change their lives for the better. They actually do so; it is practically a regular


occurrence. In fact, although it may not be the norm, it is certainly a norm.


 In this country, people whose parents did not go to college themselves


frequently go to college and make good lives for themselves, with the result


that, although they themselves started out at one social tier, their own


children are born into a higher social tier, with correspondingly more


opportunities and fewer obstacles to capitalizing on those opportunities. And


there are similar opportunities for change and growth for those who are born


into higher social tiers: they are not required, as they are in other cultures, to


repeat what their parents did. They do not have to assume a position in the


proverbial ‘family business.’ They can strike out on their own. I personallyhave known children of investment bankers who became writers and


professors, and I have known children of professors and writers who became


investment bankers—or who went on to start some entirely new business or


even new kind of business.


      The American Dream isn’t simply about being able to move up within


some pre-existing social structure. It is also about being able to change that


structure. Bill Gates came from a well-to-do family. He could have just


completed his degree at Harvard and more or less just coasted, working as a


computer scientist or financier. But he didn’t just coast; he invented a new


product—nay, a new kind of product: the personal computer. And he didn’t


just invent that product: he made it available to literally billions of people for


a modest price.


      Bill Gates is not alone in this. Think about todays’ IT and tech-giants:


Mark Zuckerberg, Elon Musk, Sergei Brin, Larry Page, Jeff Bezos. All of


these people are Americans, either by birth or by naturalization, and all of


them chose to ‘set up shop’ in the United States.


      Why did they make this choice? Because this country is hospitable to


big ideas and to big innovations. It is hospitable in a purely logistical, as in,


the laws of this country do not discourage it and even encourage it, there


being tax-breaks for start-ups as well as government-sponsored business-


education programs.      I would not go so far as to say that at the moment I embody the


American Dream. But I aspire to embody it. I want to become a dentist. I


have always wanted to become a dentist. People ask me ‘Why do you want to


become a dentist, Jonathan?’ And I have no ready response. I honestly


believe that, just as certain people are cut out for finance and others for the


military, so some people really want to help others by fixing their teeth. I


believe that an interest dentistry is a specific evolutionary deviation---that


such an interest pre-dates tens of thousands of years the existence of dentistry


in anything like its modern form


      In any case, given my passion for dentistry, it is clear how I need the


American Dream to come through for me: I need the opportunity to learn the


craft of dentistry; I need to learn how to help people as a dentist; and I


therefore need to attend the possible schools and programs. And the


American Dream is coming through for me in that respect. Because I have


worked so hard at my classes and been rewarded with correspondingly high


grades, it is overwhelmingly likely that I will have the privilege of being


accepted to one of the prestigious institutions to which, in pursuit of my own


private American Dream of becoming a dentist, I am seeking admittance


 


                     Geico Job Application (Application Essay)


 


        Describe how you exemplify 3 of GEICO’s core values: Integrity,


Service, and Growth. (450-600 words)


 


      Geico is a household name, and it’s a household name because it


provides people with a valuable service. It allows people to wake up in the


morning knowing they are protected. That is why I personally get my car


insurance from Geico: it provides a great product at a great price.


      Geico wouldn’t be the company that it is if it didn’t live up to its core


values: Integrity, Service, and Growth. Geico could probably charge a little


more or provide slightly less good service and still get away with it. But it


doesn’t: and that’s integrity. Geico could probably just ‘coast’. But it doesn’t:


it is always on the go, always expanding: and that’s growth. And Geico


doesn’t have to give back to the community; it could just keep its earnings


and look the other way. But it doesn’t, because it cares: and that’s service.


      And that is how I try to be. I never take the easy way out. If I have a


tough assignment, I do it. And if I can’t do it initially, I will just keep trying.


When I was young, schoolwork didn’t come easy to me. I struggled. At first,


I was so frustrated that I thought I’d never make it to high-school, let along


through it. But I kept my nose to the grindstone. And I not only became adecent student: I became an outstanding one, achieving great prowess in


science and math. That is why I am heading to the University of Georgia,


where I will complete my degree in biology.


      I take pride in my integrity. I take pride in doing the right thing, even


when the going gets tough. I take pride in it because it’s the right thing to do


and also because down the line it is the prudent thing to do. I could have just


slacked off. But I didn’t, and now I am reaping the rewards. And I’m proud


of that.


      But I’m also humble. Nobody can go it alone. Everybody needs


somebody. I had good people on my side: good parents and good friends. But


not everybody is so lucky. Whenever I pass by a homeless person, I realize


that. That is why I spend at least one day a week doing charity work with my


Church. We provide food, medicine, and emergency shelter to the homeless.


We really make a difference, and I’m part of that—and I’m proud of that. I


am proud to serve my community.


      But the thing that I most proud is my ability to grow. When life gives


me lemons, I make lemonade. If I have to do a tough assignment, I do it. I


don’t wallow. Sometimes the first step is pretty hard; sometimes I have to


conquer insecurities to get the ball rolling. But I always face my fears; I don’t


let them stop me. I just what has to be done. If I’m out of shape, I start


exercising. If I don’t know the material for a class, I study harder. If my workisn’t good enough, I work even harder than before. And I do this because that


is how to grow: one grows by challenging oneself, by doing the things that


one has trouble with—until they become the things that one is best at! That is


why I am about, and that is what Geico is about. And I really respect that


about Geico, and that is why I would be honored to work for you.


                       Personal Statement (Law School Application)


 


 


      When I was 15, my older brother Enrique was arrested for capital


murder. I was stunned. Enrique was my hero. I had a tough childhood, and he


was always there for me. I did not know how to emotionally process his


arrest. There were too many ambiguities. In his way, Enrique was a fiercely


moral person: tough, loyal, a ‘stand-up guy,' as they say. But he wasn't afraid


to break the law. That was part of what made admire him. He did what he


wanted to do. He wasn't a ‘square'; he was ‘cool.' Most of all, he never


backed down from a fight.


      This time was no exception. He was insulted and he fought back, as he


always did. But something went wrong. What was supposed to be a fist-fight


turned into a gun-fight, and the other man died. I wasn’t there, so I don’t


know the specifics. But that’s the gist of it. Within a year of his arrest,


Enrique pled guilty to capital murder. He never discussed the specifics of the


incident, nor did he ever claim that he was innocent. I got the feeling that he


realized that he had made a terrible mistake and wanted to salvage what was


left of his life.


      What made this traumatic for me was not that my hero had taken a


fall. It was that he stopped being my hero, because I now saw where hismachismo and heroism led—nowhere. I had been following in Enrique’s


footsteps—skipping school, being a ‘tough guy’, having no well-defined


goals beyond being ‘cool.’ The life ‘plan’ of mine imploded the night


Enrique was arrested. But I didn’t have an alternative plan. And for a while,


driven by rage at my brother, and maybe even at myself, I redoubled my


efforts to be a ‘tough guy', like my brother. But it didn't quite work, and I


didn't know what to do. People talk about their ‘mid-life crisis': I was having


a mid-adolescence crisis.


        Meanwhile, Enrique was stoically silent. It was painful for me to visit


him, but I did. He said little, just asked me how I was. I always got the


feeling there was something he wanted to say to me but couldn’t. I think he


sensed that I hadn’t changed enough to understand what he wanted to tell me.


      I went to college, but my performance was half-hearted and lack-


luster. I left college and worked at some dead-end jobs to support myself. I


would occasionally touch base with my old friends, but I no longer identified


with them. They were on the exact same path as Enrique, living in the same


fantasy-world as him, and I knew how foolish it was. As time went by, I


heard of arrests, followed by long sentences. I knew there was nothing there


for me. But I also knew that there was no future for me stacking boxes,


making Subway sandwiches, or whatever it was I was doing that month to


pay the bills.      I realized that I had to make a choice. I could wallow or I could have a


future. Really, there was no choice. Enrique’s situation made that clear to me.


I decided to re-enroll in college. I visited my brother and told of my decision.


“Me allegro,” he said, smiling for the first time in all the years I’d visited


him. “Estas tomando la decision correcta.” (I’m glad. You’re making the right


decisión.) He opened up to me for the first time in years, if not ever. He told


me that he had struggled in school because of a learning disability—a fact I’d


never known. He told me about his tough guy routine was really about


cowardice---that, if he had actually been tough, he would have focused on


preparing for a career, instead of being the neighborhood tough guy.


      This hit me like a ton of bricks, and it removed any last hint of doubt


that I might have had about going back to college. I plunged back into my


studies. There was only one problem. I still didn’t know what I wanted to do


with my life! But I was suddenly seized with a desire to help my brother, and


I decided to do just that while figuring out my own situation. I found out that


my brother would serve the minimum amount of time if he got a college


degree. I told him about it, and he was reluctant at first. But he did it, passing


the entrance exam with flying colors. He got his degree a few years later, and


last month he was paroled and now getting his master’s in psychology.


        Meanwhile, I did respectably in college, though I still didn’t quite


know what my end-game was. I knew I liked business and had a knack fornumbers and finance. I had several lucrative jobs in banking and finance, and


eventually got my MBA. But something was missing. I was happy, but I


wasn’t fulfilled. I came to realize that, even though I enjoyed finance, it


wasn’t what I valued. I wanted to make a difference, and because of the


situation with Enrique, I had some idea where a difference could and should


be made, and I knew that I had to become a lawyer to make that difference.


        Incarceration is mainly about punishment and deterrence, but to some


extent it is about rehabilitation. My brother the genuinely rehabilitative thread


that runs through the criminal justice system, and he latched onto it. And now


he’s a better person. Before he went to prison, he had no intention of


contributing to society, and now he does—and he’s doing so. He made a


terrible mistake and had to be punished. But situations are multidimensional,


and penal systems should make allowances for that fact. Time spent in


prison, even for serious crimes, should not be completely wasted. Of course,


prison should not be pleasant. But as I discovered from my brother’s case,


when people go to prison, they usually do so mainly because they don’t know


what else to do. They feel ‘stuck’ and trapped and powerless, and they lash


out. Most prisoners will eventually leave prison, and we owe it to society to


make sure that they can function in society. Prisoners don’t give back to


society; ex-prisoners sometimes do. I would like prisons to have more of a


‘correctional’ component than they currently do. To do that I not only need tobe a lawyer but need high-level guidance. Unlike other law programs, UNT


Dallas is genuinely dedicated to instructing students in both the academic and


practical aspects of the practice of law; and unlike other law programs, UNT


Dallas is very genuinely concerned to improve the criminal justice system.


For these reasons, no law school is better to help me in my ambitious and


idealistic quest than UNT Dallas. Thank you for your consideration.


 


                 Breaching Patriarchal Throwness with a Hatpin (Feminist


                                    Theory/Politics)


                            A Feminist Breaching Experiment


 


      A ‘breaching experiment’ involves a person’s deliberately behaving in


an unconventional way so as to elicit overt manifestations of the


psychological forces underlying that convention. To take a rather trivial


example, someone might choose to greet people by hugging them instead of


shaking hands. If some people responded with extreme enthusiasm, that


would suggest that the purpose of handshake-greetings is indeed to suppress


certain kinds of emotion that people would rather act on. If, on the other


hand, other people reacted with horror or fear, that would suggest that the


purpose of handshake-greetings was to provide people with a sense of safety


and security, possibly from perceived external threats and also possibly from


emotions of their own that they would rather keep tightly controlled.


      The concept of a breaching experiment was first articulated by Harold


Garfinkel (1967), who described their purpose as being to disrupt the


“background expectancies” (1967, p. 36) that members of a given society use


as “a scheme of interpretation (1967, p. 36)”, the objective being to bring to


the surface the prejudices, presumptions and emotional commitments in


which those expectancies are rooted: “Procedurally”, Garfinkel (1967, p. 37)writes:


 


              [I]t is my preference to start with familiar scenes; to produce and


      sustain bewilderment, consternation, and confusion; to produce the


      socially structured facts of anxiety, shame, guilt, and indignation; and


    to produce disorganized interaction should tell us something about how


    the structures of everyday activities are ordinarily and routinely


      produced and maintained (Garfinkel 1967, pp. 37-38).


 


      In other words, by acting counter-conventionally, one causes people to


act in ways that expose the forces responsible for the conventions being


violated.


      One problem with breaching experiments is that they may be too


successful in the way of provoking emotional responses. For example, with


the just-described hugging-experiment, some people, even men, might


respond to unsolicited hugs as acts of aggression, and others, perceiving them


as advances, might respond with inappropriate counter-advances. Such an


experiment, unless designed and conducted judiciously, could alienate people


and possibly even have legal consequences. This is clearly true of breaching


experiments that involve violations of law or of religious customs. However


arbitrary a given convention might seem, it is likely to have deep emotionalroots, and it may be unwise to violate it.


      It was with such considerations in mind that I designed my own


breaching experiment. I wanted my experiment to involve my acting in a way


that is natural to me and expresses who I am, while also involving


unconventional and deliberately provocative behavior. At the same time, I


wanted my experiment to be ‘safe’, in the sense that I would not myself or


others in physical or legal harm and would not alienate family or professional


associates. I thus decided on a rather simple but (so I believe) powerful


experiment: During one of my biweekly online sessions with my ESL


(English as a Second Language) Instructor, I would wear a giant, explosively


bawdy Victorian Era women's hat that I have, and I would see how my rather


straight-laced and, in every sense, stereotypically masculine instructor would


respond.


      Some background information is necessary here. I am an artist, and as


an artist, I focus on jewelry and other decorative clothing-relating. Of course,


jewelry, though worn by both sexes, is primarily for female use, Jewelry,


especially when worn by women, has multiple functions, including enhancing


beauty and also expressing individuality. Much the same is true of decorative


women's clothing, as the photo below illustrates:


          When meeting with my ESL Instructor, I wore a very similar hat,


complete with a gauzy vale that half hid my face. I had not told my instructor


that I would wear this hat, and prior to this point, I had not behaved at all


unconventionally. When my instructor saw the hat, he looked startled but


quickly suppressed this reaction and quickly returned to a semblance of his


usual, tightly controlled, highly professional demeanor. As was his wont, he


did focus on the lesson, refraining from asking questions that fell outside its


scope, including questions about my odd attire.


        However, I noticed throughout the lesson that he seemed troubled.


Ordinarily, he never missed a beat, always being quick to understand and


cogently respond to my queries. This time, however, he did a number of


double-takes, obviously due to distraction. Also, a certain levity that he


usually had, a certain gaiety underlying his professionalism, seemed absent.


He usually seemed to enjoy our lessons, but this time his performance,


though adequate, seemed labored and stilted.


      Apart from a one or two oblique and cryptic remarks (along the lines


of ‘that's quite a chapeau you're wearing today, Moneerah!'), my tutor (let's


call him ‘John') did not explicitly mention my hat and didn't ask why I was


wearing it, and therefore had to rely on non-verbal queues for information


about his mental state. Nonetheless, it was clear from his stilted and


uncharacteristically anxious behavior that he was put off, more so than couldbe explained by my wearing an out-of-date article of clothing. Also, female


acquaintances of mine, even professional acquaintances, responded very


differently when I ‘surprised’ them, as I occasionally did, by wearing


similarly unconventional items of clothing or jewelry. They responded with


laughter and merriment; they were not ill at ease.


      For this reason, I believe that John's reaction was largely gender-based


and was rooted in extremely archaic views of his concerning gender-


relations. Some background about this particular kind of hat will help put this


in context. In 19th Century Britain, custom strictly forbade ‘proper' women


from wearing clothing that was at all revealing, and women thus wore


clothing that completely hid their bodies along with hats that shrouded their


faces. At the same time, their clothing, though concealing their bodies, was


also flamboyantly feminine. Whereas women today often dress much like


men---often wearing jeans. T-shirts, sneakers, and other gender-neutral,


functional items of clothing---Victorian and Edwardian Era female attire was


always expressively and, one might even say, outrageously feminine: Dresses


were exaggerations of the female figure, tightly cinched in at the waist and


exploding everywhere else; and women would seldom even leave the house


without wearing highly decorative hats, like the one depicted above. Thus,


women were expected to act with extreme self-restraint in matters relating to


physical relations while also being expected to be hyper-feminine.      At this time, women in Britain (and elsewhere) did not have the right


to vote and had limited economic and legal rights. They relied largely on their


husbands for protection, making them vulnerable to unwanted advances from


men and even outright assault. As a result, some women took to stabbing


male assailants with the oversized pins that kept their oversized hats affixed


to their hair. (See the photos above.) Because of the resulting ‘hatpin peril,'


hatpins came to be seen as weapons and it became illegal for women to wear


oversized hats. So by a curious reversal, these exaggeratedly and


oppressively feminine hats became instruments of a rather lethal feminine


backlash against men, which happened to coincide with the beginnings of the


women's suffrage movements in the United Kingdom and the United States.


      While the ‘hatpin peril' was still in progress, the spectacle of a young


woman wearing an oversized hat, complete with a hatpin, must have aroused


complex emotions in men. On the one hand, they were surely drawn in by the


exaggeratedly feminine clothing and intrigued by the suggestively half-


hidden faces. On the other hand, they were threatened by the prominently


displayed hatpins and very likely also saw these hatpins as acts of defiance


against a patriarchal, arousing outrage. But these feelings of indignation were


probably experienced only half-consciously, since the hat pins, being internal


to clothing styles that represented submission to the patriarchy, were


correspondingly ambiguous.      The results of this breaching experiment are best understood in terms


of Heidegger’s concept of throwness. Dasein has both active and passive


modalities, and throwness is one of Dasein’s passive modalities. According


to Heidegger, Dasein, though fundamentally free, has to exercise its freedom


within the constraints set by physical health, emotional ties to others, and


social conventions and rules. One is, as it were, ‘thrown’ into a world that


comes ready-made with various pre-existing facts, including facts relating to


one’s physical condition as well as rules and preconceptions as to how


people, oneself included, must act.


      There are both objective and subjective aspects to throwness. The


objective aspects include out facts relating to society and also to one’s


biological condition. The subjective aspects include the psychological


mechanisms, including the prejudices and preconceptions, involved in one’s


reactions to these objective facts. A person’s having a certain anatomical


configuration is an objective fact and thus corresponds to the objective


dimension of that person’s throwness into the world. That person’s


psychological reaction to his or her anatomical configuration---how that


person ‘owns’ his or her biological condition---corresponds to the subjective


aspect of his/her throwness.


        Heidegger refers to the subjective component of throwness as


“fallness”: “ ‘Fallenness’ into the 'world'”, Heidegger writes, “means anabsorption in Being-with-one-another, in so far as the latter is guided by idle


talk, curiosity, and ambiguity” (Being and Time, p. 220). The idea is that one


is “fallen” in so far as one is simply ‘drifting’ with the flow of one’s whims


and other people’s expectations. Thus, fallenness is not an inevitable


consequence of throwness; rather, it is a consequence of throwness only to


the extent that one is not taking charge of own existence. This is what


Heidegger is referring to when he writes:


 


              Thrownness is neither a 'fact that is finished' nor a Fact that is


      settled.1 Dasein's facticity is such that as long as it is what it is, Dasein


      remains in the throw, and is sucked into the turbulence of the "they's"


      inauthenticity. Thrownness, in which facticity lets itself be seen


      phenomenally, belongs to Dasein, for which, in its Being, that very


      Being is an issue. Dasein exists factically (Being and Time, p. 220).


 


      My breaching experiment involved a disruption of an objective aspect


of John’s ‘fallenness’ by way of a disruption of his ‘throwness.’ In this


context, John’s ‘throwness’ consists in his coming into existence in a world


that is, at least historically, largely patriarchal; and his falleness in this


context consists in his psychological acquiescence to any preconceptions


associated with that state of affairs. By wearing this hat, complete with itssimultaneously decorative and lethal hatpin, I was sending an ambiguous yet


disruptive message to John, that message being to the effect that the


patriarchy is crumbling. This message aroused feelings of fear and concern


and, for that reason, so I suspect, caused John to rethink some of his


preconceptions about women.


      I should point out that John’s reaction to the breaching experiment was


complex; and though this was in part due to the ambiguous nature of the


message I was sending, it was also due, I suspect, to the complex nature of


John’s belief- and value-systems---my point being that John may not quite be


the paradigm of patriarchal conservatism that this discussion might lead one


to believe. Indeed, if John's feelings had been uniformly patriarchal or


chauvinistic, he might have dismissed the situation, regarding it as a joke or


as a mere oddity, and not been troubled or ‘disrupted' by it. Somebody who is


a dyed-in-the-wool male chauvinist doesn't feel threatened by female lawyers


or doctors, as he simply dismisses them without further thought. This, I think,


illustrates an important fact about breaching experiments, namely, that they


operate on veritable ‘breaches' or faultlines---places of conflict--in a person's


worldview, a corollary being that breaching experiments are ineffective


where there are no such fault lines.


        Significantly, I believe that, even though it was my intention only to


disrupt John's worldhood, my breaching experiment may also have disruptedmy own. As a 21st Century female, I have internalized various post-


patriarchal views as to how women ought to behave. Women in our time are


expected to behave in much the same way as men, and in many contexts are


even expected to dress in much the same way (e.g. the go-to outfit for both


genders is sneakers, jeans, and a t-shirt, whereas in previous times the


genders had very different go-to outfits). When I donned my Victorian Era


Hat-and-hatpin, I felt myself thrust back in history to a time when women


were expected to dress, act, and think very differently from men. Most


women today, myself included, are glad that we live in times that are so


much more enlightened in terms of gender relations. However, I did find


myself very much enjoying wearing this exaggeratedly feminine, Victorian


Era chapeau, and the reason, I believe, is that it allowed me to express a side


of myself and my womanhood that women are discouraged from expressing


in our time. Women are now expected to be straightforward and businesslike;


and this costume-hat was anything but straightforward and business-like, and


almost demanded that I act and think with a degree of coquetry and


subterfuge that would otherwise be impossible. The experience of


psychologically time-traveling back into this other era, when women were


forced to be so different from men, coupled with the fact that I was able to


make this psychological journey with far more ease than I would have


thought possible, disrupted some of my own post-patriarchal views aboutwomanhood and gender-relations, as it led me to think that, whereas in the


past, women were forced to be different from men and thus forced to


suppress an important side of themselves, women in our time are forced to be


the same as men and thus forced to suppress a different equally important


side of themselves.


      It is fitting that my breaching experiment ended up having such


complex and ambiguous results, since the ambiguous nature of gender and


gender-relations lies at the center of my breaching experiment. While


representing women's submission to a patriarchal order, jewelry and other


decorative attire, such as my chapeau, have also represented pride and self-


individuation. Throughout history, large, proud displays of jewelry and


fashion have been a way for all people to advertise their wealth and status.


But for women, they have been especially important in this respect, as they


have been historically been barred from owning property in many


civilizations, and jewelry for ages functioned as a socially acceptable way to


concentrate wealth while also adorning the body. But jewelry can sometimes


have a hidden utility for women. Historically excluded from the owning and


operating of weapons, women have often had to improvise their own means


of defense against attackers (typically of the male variety), a prime example


of this being the famous ladies’ hat pin that we have been discussing, which,


as we have discussed, became a self-defense strategy against “mashers”(sexual predators) on the emerging public transportation systems of the early


twentieth century. The historical significance of the resulting “Hatpin Panic”


is that it led to increased awareness of violence against women,


empowerment of women to travel alone, and helped initiate the women’s


Suffrage movement. This piece combines the proud plumage of the peacock


with a flash of danger at the barely-concealed combination of adornment and


weapon.


      So we see that, within this simple garment, there is a great deal of


historical significance and a great deal of ambiguity. What I did not count on,


when designing the experiment, was that my own worldview (and


worldhood) would be breached. In retrospect, however, I should have


expected as much, given that it is hard for one person to disrupt another’s


worldhood without disrupting one’s own, since both parties are likely to have


many preconceptions in common owing to their both being ‘thrown’, to use


Heidegger’s term, into a common set of historical circumstances.


                           Cornell West on Malcolm X (Politics)


 


      There are many perspectives to take on Malcolm X. Some see him as a


hero, a champion of civil rights; others see him as excessively concerned with


race and therefore unnecessarily divisive. Some see him as someone who


wanted to build a new and better society; others see him as a hate-filled


demagogue who wanted to destroy more than the wanted to create. In his


article Firebrand, Professor Cornell West takes the position that Malcolm X


was a hero. Indeed, there is not a single critical word of the man in this


article, the purpose of which, it would appear, is not to discuss specifics


relating to Malcolm X’s vision for the United States or to his achievements,


but simply rather to cast his decidedly complex legacy in an unambiguously


positive light.


      Malcolm X (1925-1965) was an African Civil Rights Activist working


at the same time as Dr. Martin Luther King. However, Malcolm X and


Martin Luther King had very different views as to what the African American


community should strive for and what methods they should use. Martin


Luther King wanted integration and equality. Malcolm X wanted separation,


famously saying “no white man wants integration, no sane black man wants


integration.” Born Malcolm Little, he changed his last name to “X” as a way


of casting off his ‘slave name’, as he called it, and also as a way of sendingthe message that African-Americans had been stripped of their identity by


white Europeans and had to reclaim it.


      Also, whereas Martin Luther King believed civil disobedience to be


the road to social reform, always urging his followers to refrain from


violence, Malcolm X was skeptical about the effectiveness of peaceful


methods, his famous rallying cry being “by any means necessary.”


      Finally, whereas Martin Luther King was a Christian minister,


Malcolm X converted to Islam, becoming the head of the Nation of Islam.


Malcolm X rejected Christianity and embraced Islam because he saw the


former as white and the latter as black or at least as compatible with the


interests of blacks.


      Not even Malcolm X’s bitterest detractors deny the magnitude of his


accomplishments. Thanks in large part to Malcolm X’s leadership, the Nation


of Islam demands and receives integrity, self-respect, and respect for others


from its millions of followers. Firebrand does not discuss Malcolm X’s


specific accomplishments, however. Indeed, it does little in the way of stating


facts as to who Malcolm X was, when he lived, or what he achieved. It


consists rather of skillfully rendered characterizations of this great and


controversial figure.


      We would expect no less of Cornell West. After receiving his Ph.D. in


philosophy at Princeton, Cornell West held professorships in ReligiousStudies, Philosophy, and Africana at a number of prestigious institutions


including Princeton and Harvard. Dr. West’s work focuses on race relations


between whites and blacks in America, his position being that despite the


appearance of racial progress, blacks are still discriminated against, albeit in


subtler ways than in times past. Indeed Dr. West says as much in this article.


He describes what he believes Malcolm X would say to Martin Luther King


if the two met today: “Brother Martin,” says Malcolm X, “Marcus Garvey


and others have told us the vast majority of black people will never be treated


with dignity. They will always live lives of ruin tied to the prison system…


Some [African Americans] may go all the way to the White House, but even


there’s still going to be crack houses, the prison-industrial complex,


unemployment getting worse and worse.”


      Cornell West approves of these sentiments. Indeed these are his


sentiments, expressed in his words, albeit through the character of Malcolm


X. We don't know that Malcolm X would have agreed, especially given that


Malcolm X did not have fixed views and towards the end of his life


expressed guarded optimism about race relations.


      There are several places in the article where Cornell West ‘quotes’


Malcolm X, except that it is not the historical Malcolm X who is quoted, but


rather a fictionalized version of Malcolm X created by Cornell West. “What


do you think would happen after 400 years of slavery and Jim Crow andlynching”, West ‘quotes’ Malcolm X as saying. “Do you think you would


respond non-violently? What’s your history like? Let’s look at how you have


responded when you were oppressed. George Washington—guerilla fighter!”


These might have been Malcolm X’s sentiments, but they are West’s words,


as is each of the other ‘quotations’ of Malcolm X that occurs in the article.


      It is an extremely effective technique, and West uses it very skillfully.


It wasn’t until after I’d had some to process the article that I realized that it


was less about what Malcolm X thought and more about what Cornell West


thinks.


      And that’s what this article is really about. It's not a historical piece


about Malcolm X. (Apart from the date of Malcolm X's death, the only


biographical fact about Malcolm X that is referenced is that he was a Sunni


Muslim leader.) Nor is it an exposition of Malcolm X's thoughts. (Malcolm X


is not actually quoted even once. Nor is it said what specifically he believed.)


Malcolm X is eloquently characterized. “He was music in motion,” West


writes. “He was jazz in motion…He could be lyrical and funny, and in the


next moment, he’d shift and push you against the wall.” These are


characterizations, not statements of historical fact. It is being said what kind


of person Malcolm X was, not what he did. The same is true of each of the


descriptions occurring in this article.


      This raises the question: Is this article really about Malcolm X? Thisarticle expresses very definite views, and although it attributes those views to


Malcolm X, it doesn't site any quotations or other historical data, opting


instead for evocative hypotheticals and broad characterizations. This suggests


that Malcolm X is functioning as a foil for Cornell West's own views. This is


not to denigrate Dr. West. Far from it—his literary powers are in full


evidence here, as is the depth of his convictions.


       Fork etiquette (Anthropology)


 


        Dinner Fork


      When used in conjunction with a knife to cut and consume food in


Western social settings, two forms of fork etiquette are common. In the


European style, the diner keeps the fork in his or her left hand, while in the


American style the fork is shifted between the left and right hands. The


American style is most common in the United States, but the European style


is considered proper in other countries.


        Originally, the traditional European method, once the fork was


adopted as a utensil, was to transfer the fork to the right hand after cutting


food, as it had been considered proper for all utensils to be used with the right


hand only. This tradition was brought to America by British colonists and is


still in use in the United States. Europe adopted the more rapid style of eating


in relatively modern times.


      European style


      The European style, also called the continental style, is to hold the


fork in the left hand and the knife in the right. Once a bite-sized piece of food


has been cut, it is conducted straight to the mouth by the left hand. For other


food items, such as potatoes, vegetables or rice, the blade of the knife is used


to assist or guide placement of the food on the back of the fork. The tinesremain pointing down.


      The knife and fork are both held with the handle running along the


palm and extending out to be held by thumb and forefinger. This style is


sometimes called "hidden handle" because the palm conceals the handle.


        American style


      In the American style, also called the zig-zag method or fork


switching, the knife is initially held in the right hand and the fork in the left.


Holding food to the plate with the fork tines-down, a single bite-sized piece is


cut with the knife. The knife is then set down on the plate, the fork


transferred from the left hand to the right hand, and the food is brought to the


mouth for consumption. The fork is then transferred back to the left hand and


the knife is picked up with the right. In contrast to the European hidden


handle grip, in the American style the fork is held much like a spoon or pen


once it is transferred to the right hand to convey food to the mouth. Though


called "American style", this style originated in Europe.


      Hybrid style


      Etiquette experts have noted that the American style is in decline,


being replaced in the United States by a hybrid of the American and


European styles. In this style, the fork is not switched between hands between


cutting and eating, and is also deployed "tines-up" as a scoop when


convenient. 


 


 


 































 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


  


 


 


 


 


 


 


  


                         McClatchey on Race and IQ (Current Events)


 


 


      This assignment is a follow up to the McClatchey HS Race and IQ


article and your first responses. My goal here is to make you question your


initial reaction and challenge the way you approached the article and


questions. At a minimum, I want to show you a different perspective to this -


one that I argue is extremely important to understand.


        Questions - Please answer them in the text box below:


 


              1.            Most people attack the student and his experiment as


      racist? Why? If you think it is actually racist - tell me what specifically


      about it makes it racist? Make sure you think about this before


      answering. If you do not think it is racist - why isn't it?


 


      I do not think it matters whether it is ‘racist’, whatever that means.


What matters is whether it is a legitimate science project. A hypothesis is put


forth (namely, race correlates with IQ). That hypothesis is either true or false.


That is the only question that matters. The psychology of the person who puts


forth the hypothesis is irrelevant, unless it corrupts the way in which he


attempts to answer the question at hand.      Also, what exactly does it mean to say that this person is ‘racist’? If it


means that he believes there to be non-trivial psychological differences


between the races, then, yes, he is racist---but in that case, the charge that he


is racist is trivial and question-begging, since the very thing that he is trying


to show that is ‘racism’, in this sense of the word, is empirically justified.


      Is he ‘racist’ in some other sense? Does he hate black or Hispanic? We


don’t know. And for what it is worth, I rather suspect not. Somebody who


hated them probably would probably simply accept some invidious


stereotypical characterization of them, without bothering to look into the


merits of that characterization.


      My guess, for what it is worth, is that he feels that his education has


been compromised by people who have race-based agendas and whose


primary agendas are not education-related in nature .


      But this point is entirely speculative, and the very fact that it is


speculative confirms the emptiness of the allegation that this person is


‘racist.’


 


 


              2.            What if the actual results are true? What if there are actual


    IQ differences between populations of humans? Does this change how


      you view the experiment and aftermath? In other words, do you still      think it is racist? Or do you still agree that it should have been taken


      down?


 


      This person’s project concerns groups of people. But merit always has


to be judged on person-by-person basis. Given only that I belong to some


group of people whose members are unusually likely to be good physician, it


does not follow that I personally am a good physician. And if I am applying


for a position as a physician, my personal merits have to be assessed. It is


irrelevant what the merits are of other members of some peer-group of mine.


      Also, it is never racist to look for answers to open empirical questions.


The person who is doing this experiment is not prejudging anything. He is


asking a question and citing relevant data. What is prejudicial is to denounce


this person’s project as ‘racist’, without even seeing what the relevant facts.


Obviously people who describe this person as ‘racist’ are assuming a priori


that the results of the experiment will be unfavorable to people of color. If


they were certain that the facts were on their side, they would welcome


empirical inquiry into the matter. But they are so convinced that the data is


unfavorable to their cause, that, before even examining that data, they


denounce anyone, such as this student-scientist, who proposed to examine it.


So the student is the least prejudicial of all of the parties involved, since his


view is to at least wait and see what the data is before making assumptions asto what that data will show.


 


              3.            Most of you will have assumed that the student's


      conclusion is not true - meaning most of you think there are no IQ


      differences between human populations. How did you come to this


      conclusion? Do you have any evidence that points to this? Have you


      done any research on this?


 


      I myself did not come to that conclusion. There are obviously


differences between individuals, and there are obviously differences between


groups of people. Whether there are differences (relating to IQ) between


different ethnic groups is another matter. But if one looks at the histories of


different ethnicieis, and different sub-ethnicities, it is not so unreasonable to


suppose that there are differences in IQ (and possibly in values) between


different (sub)ethnicities. Consider the tiny nation of Scotland---it produced


Hume, Smith, Maxwell, Reid, Scott, and many others who made massive


intellectual contributions to civilization. Are we really so sure that Scots are


configured in exactly the same way as members of each and every other


ethnic group?


      To be sure, given only that the nation of Scotland produced great


economists, whereas the nation of Samoa has not (to my knowledge), itdoesn’t follow that Somoans are innately less talented at economics than


Scots. But the supposition that there is some innate difference is one possible


explanation, and it cannot be ruled out a priori.


 


              4.            Most of you agreed with the taking down of this


      experiment. Try to take the opposite position on it. Why is it a bad idea


    to shut down science and scientific experiments? It doesn't appear as if


      school officials had any evidence that points to his conclusion being


      incorrect - should they have shut it down without any research or


      discussion?


 


      The school officials are timid bureaucrats who are taking the path of


least resistance. Today’s society being what it is, one will have less of an


uphill battle on one’s hand if one shuts down ostensibly ‘racist’ projects than


if one green-lights them. But I don’t agree with the decision. What about


freedom of speech? What about freedom of thought? And suppose that this


project, or some follow-up project, proved that blacks (some other group of


color) had some intellectual aptitude that whites lack? Wouldn’t we want to


know that? Couldn’t that fact possibly be of relevance to educational


curricula? But if we pre-emptively prohibit such projects from being


undertaken, we will never know. It is not possible to block off one avenue ofinquiry without blocking off a number of intersecting avenues of inquiry.


 


              5.            Whether or not you agreed with shutting down the


      experiment - answer this. If we disagree with something or perhaps


      have questions on something - is there a better way to engage with it


      rather than shutting it down? Explain your answer.


 


      Yes there is. One can say: In protecting this student’s right to ask


questions, we are protecting everybody’s right to do, including those whose


viewpoints are opposed to this student’s. Also, the assumption embodied in


not shutting down the project is that there will be mayhem of some kind—


possibly even riots. But that, it seems to me, is a racist assumption. (In my


personal experience, the people who responded the most adversely to


supposed instances of ‘racism’ were whites who wanted to virtue-signal their


non-racism.)


 


      Rubric


      10 points - Student demonstrates critical thinking; well thought out


responses. All questions are answers in this manner.


      5 points - Student demonstrates critical thinking/well thought out


responses in 4 or less questions      0 points - Student does not answer questions. Student answers


questions with minimal effort. Critical thinking is not apparent in most


answers.


                   Freedom of Speech: Its Scope and Limits (Politics)


 


      What are your initial reactions to what you read?


 


      My initial reaction was straightforward. A science project was done. It


attempted to solve an anomaly (namely, why are people of certain ethnicities


disproportionately well represented in an academic program designed for


gifted students?). And that project put forth a prima facie reasonable (and


data-consistent) hypothesis that, if correct, certainly would eliminate the


anomaly. Is that hypothesis correct? I don’t know. But that is not the relevant


question. The relevant question is: Is it sufficiently reasonable, and


sufficiently explanatory of the data-set in question, that it ought to be


considered? And the answer is ‘yes.’




Do you agree with the school taking down this science experiment? Why or


why not?


 


      No, I don’t agree with what the school did. First of all, freedom of


speech should always be protected. Freedom of speech does not protect


speech that is intentionally taunting or aggressive or inflammatory. But this


does not fall into that category; the results of sober, if politically incorrect,scientific investigations are ipso facto non-inflammatory. It is only if people


make them inflammatory—by politicizing them, usually with inflammatory


reactions of their own---that they become inflammatory. But in that case, it is


the reaction to the original speech-act, not that speech-act itself, that is


inflammatory and that therefore doesn’t deserve to be protected as free


speech.


      In any case, if the schools’ policy is to encourage free thought and free


discussion---which includes free scientific inquiry—then it should have


suppressed this project. If the school’s policy is to suppress the truth in the


interests of political or social stability, that is fine, but it must not then make a


grand show—as this school almost certainly does—of being interested in


‘getting to the bottom of race relations in this country.’ Sometimes truth ahs


to be suppressed, for reasons of civil peace and order. But, first of all, this is


one of those times. Second, if that is what is being done, then the school has


to be honest about it. Also, if the school is so afraid that members of the


groups in questin will react violently, then that issue ought to be addressed.


And if it doesn’t fear as much—which, in my view, it probably shouldn’t---


then there is no need to suppress the project in the first place.




Imagine you were this student's teacher. He comes up to you and poses this


research question - he wants to know if there are differences in IQ betweenracial groups. How do you respond and why?


 


      As a teacher, it is one’s duty to answer questions honestly, if not


always accurately. (This assumes that the questions are relevant; if the


question is irrelevant, I would not answer it, on the grounds that it is indeed


irrelevant.) So that the question fell within the scope of the class I was


teaching, I would answer the student by saying that reputable scholars, e.g.


William Shockley and Francis Crick, have indeed generated data that is


consistent with the hypothesis that there are disparities in intelligence


between different groups. At the same time, I would point out that other


reputable scholars have put forth other ways of modelling the data. Finally, I


would say that IQ-tests are an extremely narrow and only limitedly reliable


measure of intelligence, with the qualification that they do have some


evidential value.




Can you spot something potentially disingenuous with the newspaper article


(Hint: It's something to do with the title)?


 


Frankly, I thought that the article was fairly sincere and balanced. The title of


the article--- High school science fair project questioning African American


intelligence sparks outrage---made the science fare project in question seemmore tendentious and aggressive than it actually was. In and of itself, that


project was fairly innocuous and embodied standard scientific practice.


Imagine the following. Scientist X is studying a colony of ants and notices


that the ants separate into different groups, with each group specializing in


some task that is of a different difficulty level from the tasks done by each of


the other groups. In that case, if the scientist posited that those groups were


populated by ants of different intellectual levels, he would just be using


scientific sound judgment. In this case, the student-scientist is, arguably,


behaving in much the same way. It is true that someone with a racist agenda


could use that project to further his own aims, but the project itself was


simply science. And science is often incompatible with our desires, as


Darwin’s theory aptly illustrates.




 


 


 


                     Defending Freedom of Speech (Ethics/Politics)


 


      What are your initial reactions to what you read?

              1)              Does contractualism deal with any of the above views?


      Yes. Contractualism obviously deals with the dying-promise situation.


      You entered into a contract with the person when you agreed to put


      flowers on that person’s beloved’s grave, and you are not contractually


      bound to carry out that promise.


 


              2)              Would the contractualist approach undermine the QALY      view? Yes. The QALY view is strictly utilitarian in nature and is


      therefore anti-deontological and therefore anti-contractualist. The


      QALY view is basically: if X’s death brings more net joy then X’s life,


      then don’t waste resources trying to save X. The contractualist position


    is: If you have a contract (whether explicit or implicit) with someone,


      then it must be honored, even if violating it increases overall welfare.


      And if somebody is alive, then others--- in particular, medical people


      from whom that person is seeking treatment---are likely to have


      contractual obligations to that person.


 


              3)              Would contractualism ever answer specifically the


      ageism objection? The ageism objection to QALY is to the effect that it


      discriminates against people on the basis of their age. Contractualism


      would agree with the ageism objection on this point. According to


      contractualism, a deal is a deal, whether the person has many good


      years ahead or few. And that is also, in effect, the import of the ageism


      objection.


 


 


           Why College Admissions Should Continue to be Based at least in                    part on Standardized Test Scores (Public Policy)


 


      In her article “Is it finally time to get rid of the SAT and ACT College


Admissions Tests”, Valerie Strauss claims that by basing admissions-


decisions on SAT and ACT scores, colleges and universities are somehow


perpetuating some kind of systemic bias against those who are


underprivileged. To this end, Strauss cites the fact that people from higher


socioeconomic strata outperform those from the lower socioeconomic strata


on SAT’s and ACT’s, the implication being that those tests ‘rig’ college


admissions in favor of those who are already well-to-do. In this paper, a case


will be made that Strauss’s suggestion, if implemented, would have


disastrous consequences: instead of resulting a fair college admissions


system, it would eliminate a metric that helps educators evaluate their own


effectiveness and would consequently result in worse education for


everybody, rich and poor alike.


      The first point is that if economically underprivileged people are


underperforming on a test, the right response is to educate them better; it is


not to get rid of the test. Consider the following hypothetical. In country X,


each citizen must, upon turning 18, to two years of some kind of physical


labor; and tests of physical ability are used to determine exactly who does


what. If a given person cannot do a single push-up, then that person is notgiven a job that requires enormous amounts of physical strength. If someone


cannot run more than ten feet without passing out, that person is not assigned


a job that involves great physical endurance. In country X, wealthy people


are more healthy than poor people, simply because wealth people in X have


better medical care than poor people, are better nourished, drink cleaner


water, and so on. Consequently, wealthy people in X vastly outperform poor


people on these tests of physical aptitude. How should the government


respond? Should it declare these physical tests to be ‘unjust’? Should it get


rid of all tests that expose the differences in fitness and health between rich


and poor? No. That would be the worst possible course of action, as it would


hide the injustices in question. The right response is to keep using those


metrics and to improve the performance of those whose performance is


currently substandard.


      Strauss’s reasoning, if relativized to this hypothetical, would require


the government of X to get rid of these fitness tests. This would make it hard


to know whose fitness-levels had to improved and would perpetuate the


whatever it was that was lowering the fitness levels of poor people. It would


also make it hard to know whether attempts improve health and fitness were


effective. Similarly, if the SAT’s and ACT’s ceased to be used, the result


would simply be to cloak—not to fix—whatever it was that was responsible


for the differences between rich and poor in respect of their scores on thesetests. Hiding inequalities does not eliminate them; it exacerbates them and


makes them harder to correct.


      Further, Strauss’s suggest that we scrap the SAT’s and ACT’s would


deprive universities of an enormously valuable metric. On average, people


who score high on these tests stay in college and do well in college, whereas


people who score low do poorly and are highly likely to drop out. See Figures


1-3.


 


      Figure 1 First Year GPA by SAT Score
