      Figure 5 Graduation Rates by First-Year GPA      Adapted from: Belnap, Noel. Towards Higher Graduation Rates.


Community Scholar, 16(7), 13.


 


        Figures 1-3 show that those who do well on the SAT tend to well in


college and also to graduate, and they also show that those who do poorly on


the SAT tend to do poorly and not to graduate. For what it is worth, this is


consistent with my personal experience. To my knowledge, the people I


know from high school did well on the SAT’s and ACT’s are flourishing in


college, and those who did poorly are struggling and some have even dropped


out.


      Straus writes: “For years, questions have been raised about the validity


and value of SAT and ACT scores in college admissions. The College Board


has paid for research touting the “predictive value” of SAT scores in


forecasting how students will do in college and beyond, but critics have


questioned the research.” We have just seen statistical proof of the claim thatthey are predictive of academic success. To be sure, there are enormously


gifted people who do poorly on standardized tests and there are people who


lack substance who do well on them. These are not perfect tests by any


stretch of the imagination. But given a thousand people who scored in the top


5% on the SAT’s and a thousand who scored in the bottom 5%, the former


group is much more likely to yield college-ready students than the latter, and


universities would be foolish to spurn the use of SAT’s and other such


metrics.


      Also, granting that standardized fail to measure creativity and insight


and granting that their diagnostic value is indeed quite limited, they are one


of the few meaningful data-points that college admissions have. Grades often


reflect biases, either positive or negative, on the part of instructors, and


‘extra-curricular activities’, though laudable, are not little relevance to


scholarly potential.


      I have a much older sister, and when she was growing up, my parents


did not have enough money to send her to a good school. As a result, her


education suffered and her SAT scores were mediocre. When I was growing


up, my parents had the resources to send me to a good school, with the result


that I did well on the SAT’s and am currently doing respectably in college.


Part of what my motivated my father to earn more was his knowledge that he


needed to do so to give me a good education, and my sister’s less thanoptimal test scores.


      Strauss tries to muddy the waters by linking the SAT’s to cheating on


the part of people of means: “Is it finally time for colleges and universities to


stop requiring applicants to take the SAT and ACT college admissions


exams?” Strauss asks at the beginning of her article. “The question, long


asked by testing critics, is being revived with new urgency amid the


explosive college admissions bribery scandal rocking the world of higher


education. As part of an investigation they called Operation Varsity Blues,


federal prosecutors last week charged some 50 people, including famous


Hollywood actresses and wealthy financiers. The alleged schemes included


hiring impostors to take SAT and ACT exams, or rigging the test by asking


for additional time to take it even when that wasn’t necessary.”


      This is not good reasoning. Obviously, these people were wrong to


cheat, but the right response is not to get rid of the SAT but simply to make


sure that people don’t cheat on it. Suppose that people bribed officials to be


given life-saving medication that was in short supply. By Strauss’s reasoning,


we should get rid of the medication. By my reasoning, we should prevent


fraudulent use of it.


 


      In the United States, College admissions are to a large extent


determined by one’s performance on the SAT or ACT. To be sure, one’sscores on these tests are not the only relevant factor, but admissions-


committees give them enormous weight. Someone with low board scores will


have a tough time getting into a top school, let alone being scholarship


money. Is this right? Should one’s performance on a four-hour multiple-


choice test determine where one goes to college or even whether one does so?


Author and education-writer Strauss answers with a resounding "no", and she


brilliantly defends her answers in her Washington Post Article "Is it finally


time to get rid of the SAT and ACT college admissions test?" According to


Strauss, SAT and ACT scores are no less a reflection of socioeconomic


privilege than of actual merit. In defense of this, she cites the statistical fact


that people from impoverished backgrounds do worse on these tests than


people from wealthy backgrounds. Lest it be thought that wealthy test-takers


might simply be more intelligent than poor ones, Strauss points out that the


wealthy, unlike the poor, have the option of hiring private instructors to boost


their performance on such tests. “[K]ids from poor families do worse than


kids with money”, Strauss writes. “Wealthy parents can provide benefits that


many poor families can’t, such as tutors [and] learning opportunities.” For


good measure, Strauss reinforces this already weighty claim by quoting Bob


Schaeffer, Director of Public Education at Fair Test. “How”, Schaeffer asks,


“can any college admissions office tell whether the ACT/SAT score they


receive reflects an applicant’s actual test-taking skills or whether it wasinflated by test-coaching ‘steroids’?” (Strauss, 3) This is consistent with my


personal experience. When raising my oldest sister, who is twelve years older


than I am, my parents had little money and therefore little to invest in her


education. When raising me, my parents did have resources and invested


heavily in my education. As a result, I outperformed her on the SAT by a


hefty margin, her Math score being 450 and mine being 750. My sister is


actually mathematically gifted; but because of her straitened circumstances,


she was forced to teach herself material that I had the privilege being taught


by qualified instructors. My sister's low SAT scores closed off a lot of


opportunities that would have been available to her had she had better


instruction. She is obviously not an isolated case, and I am therefore inclined


to agree with Strauss that SAT and ACT scores are quite as much a measure


of wealth as they are of merit. Less than one month ago, Strauss points out,


the FBI arrested over 50 wealthy financiers and famous actors for either


hiring impostors to take their SAT's for their children and for other forms of


SAT-related fraud. This shows us that people with money have the option not


only of inflating but of falsifying their children’s test-scores; and according to


Strauss, it constitutes an additional reason to marginalize the relevance of


SAT and ACT scores to college admissions. Once again, Strauss quotes Bob


Schaeffer, according to whom the wealthy have used a wide variety of ruses


to falsify their children’s scores: “Those…schemes”, writes Schaeffer, “haveincluded hiring impersonators to take the exams; making phony “disability’


claims to gain extra test-taking time; paying to change wrong answers or fill


in missing responses; and bribing proctors and test-site supervisors to ignore


these illegal acts.”(Strauss). I attended an elite private school in Thailand, and


many of my classmates were given unlimited amounts of time to take tests


because their parents had bribed psychiatrists to claim that they had medical


conditions, such as ADHD, that warranted such dispensations. It was


disturbing to me to see friends of mine cheat their way into having high test


scores.


      “In some cases,” Strauss writes, “test administration in an entire


country has had to be canceled at the last minute because of credible cheating


allegations.” (Strauss, 2). In 2017, the SAT's were canceled in Thailand,


when it was discovered that a number of students had been using high-tech


glasses to have the answers fed to them. I remember a friend of my sister’s


sobbing when she found out that she would not able to take the test. In


situations where cheating is rampant, those who choose not to engage in it are


penalized for their own integrity; and this, as Strauss points out, is yet another


reason why SAT and ACT scores should be optional for college applicants.


      Strauss's arguments are compelling. Money can be used to inflate or


even falsify SAT and ACT scores. So long as college admissions are based


on such scores, people from wealthy families have an unfair advantage andthose who have the integrity not to cheat are at an unfair disadvantage. The


poor will continue to be unfairly deprived of the blessings of a college


education so long as college admissions are based on SAT and ACT scores,


and Strauss is therefore right that making these tests optional would do much


to level the playing field.


                     Being a Voter in Texas (Current Events)


 


      Why it is important to know about who represents you in the Texas


Legislature. Be specific.


 


 


      I live in Houston Texas (specially, in 77017), which is in many


respects a diverse and dynamic city. In a city of this size, there are inevitably


many pressing issues; and in a city as culturally rich and diverse as Houston


—as blessed by a wealth of different cultures and as cursed by the manifold


difficulties striking equitable balances between so many different viewpoints-


--state legislators have awesome responsibilities. It is their responsibility to


make sure that the school board does its job, that city workers do their jobs,


that hospitals, parks and basic public services are in working order. Further,


state representatives must see to it that municipal workers do their job while


also seeing to it that their district is hospitable to business. And it is


proverbially difficult for representatives (or officials of any kind, for that


matter) strike this balance. Our state representative in 77071 is Mary Ann


Perez. Frankly, I myself have very little information about Representative


Perez, so I cannot pass judgment. But her website


(http://votemaryannperez.com/) provided next to no information about herviews, which I found disconcerting, especially since one’s state


representative is in many ways one’s go-to when one has problems within


one’s own community. Obviously senators and congresspersons, having as


they do both local and nation-level responsibilities, cannot be expected to


respond promptly to strictly local problems. And precisely because state-


representatives are there to step into that breech, it is especially helpful to


know who one’s state representative is and how well he/she represents your


interest.


             Three Takeaways from The Young Turks’ ‘Iceland does the


                          Unimaginable’ (Current Events)


 


      Takeaway 1: In the US, bankers seem to have an almost special status.


This may be a consequence of our nation’s high regard for wealth. Or it may


be a consequence of the fact that they use their immense wealth to influence


legislation and law-enforcement.


      Takeaway 2: In the US, regulators rationalize their failure to


prosecutor bank-fraud on the grounds that, because banks are so big, doing so


could disrupt the economy. But the real reason is likely that these regulators


are ‘on the pad’, i.e. have been bought off.


      Takeaway 3: The spuriousness of this excuse on the part of regulator’s


is evidenced by that fact that in Iceland, where they sent their top bankers to


jail for fraud, the economy picked up as a result.


            Three Takeaways from WSJ Video about the European Union


 


      One reason that the Economic Union was created in order to bind


nations together in such a way that it would not be in their interest go to war


with each other. Thus, it was at least in part the traumatic experience of


World Wars I and II that led Europe to see itself as needing to be


economically unified. 


      Another reason for establishing the EU was to consolidate the various


European economies into a single super-economy that would be competitive


no the world market.


 


      Because the EU comprises so many different economies and because


it requires various different governments to agree on monetary policy, it takes


a very long time to make decisions, with the result) that it cannot act quickly


enough in crisis situations. And this is what happened with Greece: Greece


couldn’t pay its debts, and because the EU couldn’t act quickly enough to


contain the situation, Greece’s economy dragged down the other economies


of the EU with it.


 


 


             Summary and Analysis of Tomatoland (Politics/Current Events)


 


        Tomatoland, by Barry Estabrook, is about the tomato industry in


Florida, where about 70% of American tomatoes are grown. The book


carefully describes the inhuman conditions under which workers in this


industry labor, and it also discusses the manifold health consequences for


these workers (and to a lesser extent all tomato-consumers in the US) of the


heavy-duty chemicals and pesticides involved in the growth of tomatoes in


Florida. The author repeatedly points out that Florida tomatoes are extremely


bland and unsavory, especially as compared with tomatoes grown without


pesticides, the point being that all of this loss and suffering is for naught. The


author also describes the failure of the legal system to improve any aspect of


this situation: it ignores the fact that slave labor is involved (and, indeed,


heavily relied on); it ignores the abysmal working conditions of non-enslaved


workers; and it ignores the adverse health effects of the industrial chemicals


used in the process, which include sky-high cancer rates and limbless


offspring. Finally, the author discusses some attempts that politicians and


activists have made to remedy the situation, and he also discusses cases


where people have produced quality-tomatoes without dehumanizing their


workers and without using lethal chemicals.


      The book starts out by describing the origins of the American tomatoindustry. Tomatoes, like potatoes, were unknown to Europeans until the


Spanish were introduced to them by the Aztecs and Incas. These tomatoes


were small and did not have the smooth, near-spherical shape had by the


tomatoes we currently use. The large, round tomatoes that we are familiar


with are the handiwork of Alexander Livingston, an American entrepreneur


and horticulturalist. Livingston first cultivated such tomatoes in the 1820s.


Livingston’s distinctively round and succulent-looking tomatoes were a hit,


and the American tomato-industry was born.


      In the 1870s, Florida became a tomato-producer, owing mainly to the


fact that, thanks to recently built railroads, it was possible to quickly transport


produce from Florida to the Northeast. Because of Florida’s climate,


tomatoes can be grown there year-round. But with this qualification, so the


author says, Florida is in many ways a terrible place to grow tomatoes.


Because Florida is so hot, tomatoes have to be drenched in chemicals to keep


them from being eaten by vermin. (In cooler climates, by contrast, chemicals


need not be used, at least not in such abundance, granting that year-round


tomato-growth is not a possibility in such places.)


      The author then shifts his discussion to the various chemical used in


the growth of Florida tomatoes, going into great detail about the staggering


costs both to human life, especially (but not exclusively) those of the workers


involved, and to Florida’s ecosystem. After discussing the damage done tovarious native species (e.g. alligators and herons unable to reproduce and


dying in droves), the author carefully describes the plight of the workers


involved. (In this context, the author is discussing people who ‘choose’ to


have these jobs.) If it rains, the workers cannot work and therefore aren’t


paid. If there is moisture on the crops, they have to wait, without pay, until it


dries before they can start working. On a good day, after working 12 hours,


they are lucky to take home $70. Because they don’t have automobiles, they


have no choice but to live near the tomato-fields, and landlords charge them


outrageously high-rents, which eat up most of their salaries. They are often


made ill by the chemicals they are handling and oftentimes cannot afford


gloves or other basic protective gear. Because of these toxins, their children


are unusually likely to be born with severe defects, including not having


limbs or genitalia. But these workers don’t have insurance and therefore can’t


pay for medical treatment for themselves or their children. And if a worker so


much as complains of illness while on the job, he is likely to be fired and left


without any source of income. Because the workers are undocumented, they


are not protected by unions and, indeed, have minimal legal protections of


any kind.


      The workers’ lack of legal protections brings the author to what I


found to be the most poignant and informative part of the book: the


discussion of the huge role of slave labor involved in the Florida tomato-industry. Many of the people picking tomatoes in Florida are veritable slaves.


The companies that own the fields have agreements with human-traffickers


who supply them with these workers, the latter having been abducted and


forced to work, with no benefits and minimal pay, under the most brutal


conditions. If they try to escape, they are beaten or killed.


      In the last part of the book, the author describes attempts that people


have made to improve the situation. He talks about various civil rights and


legal activists who are trying to improve working conditions, as well as purge


the entire industry of slave labor. He also discusses the case of a Princeton


graduate who started a successful tomato-business in Pennsylvania that,


although not as lucrative as its sinister Florida counterparts, is relatively


successful financial and also produces higher-quality tomatoes.


      I found this book to be readable and engaging, mainly because it was


so loaded with very specific and very striking (usually strikingly grim)


information about a relatively large sector of the American economy. There


are very few statistics and very little analysis, but there is a wealth of


carefully described, first-hand facts, and that this is this book’s greatest


strength.


      It is also its greatest weakness. The author doesn’t explain why the


Florida tomato-industry is so fraught with injustice. Why are conditions for


workers so poor in this particular industry, and why is slave-labor used in thisparticular industry? Does this industry require the use of slave labor? Are its


profit-margins so thin? If so, why? And why does the US government look


the other way? Is the Florida tomato industry such an important part of the


US economy that the government won't adequately police it? Is the United


States actually without the financial resources to defray the costs of not


dehumanizing workers in this industry?


      The author does mention one or two cases of reasonable successful


companies that grew tomatoes without resorting unfair labor practices and


without using ecocidal amounts of toxic chemicals. But each of these


‘companies’, as the author also points, though only in passing, was really just


a single person, and that person did not have an operation of scale. The reader


is thus left without an answer to the question: What is the alternative to the


current state of affairs?


      At no point does the author explicitly put forth an economic


explanation of the situation. So far as any such analysis is provided, it is


confined to the usual mantra that ‘corporations’ are to blame. Nor does the


author say how the situation can be improved. He spends a great deal of time


talking about the efforts of various activists, along with the politicians (e.g.


Bernie Sanders) who are sympathetic to them. But from what we can gather,


these activists and politicians have done very little to improve the situation.


      This is not surprising. It isn’t activists and politicians who improvelabor-conditions. It is economic development. When the industrial revolution


first began in Britain, working conditions were appalling and injury- and


fatality-rates were sky-high. Thanks to industrialization itself, Britain


eventually became wealthy enough that it no longer needed to rely on


exploitative labor practices, at which point labor unions became powerful and


labor laws were put in place. Regulation can only do so much. If companies


don’t have the money to pay their workers, they will either go out of business


or use slave-labor, and there is nothing that regulation by itself can do to


change this. Regulators can shut down companies that have unfair labor


practices—and they should do so. But regulators cannot magically give these


companies the funds that they need to pay their employees an honest wage.


And if an industry-sector is sufficiently large, the government may choose


not to regulate, especially if regulation will cause that sector to implode.


Therefore, it has to be figured out how this industry-sector can be so


modified that it doesn’t need to rely on unfair labor practices---and Estabrook


says nothing about how to do this. Nor does Estabrook say anything as to


how tomatoes can be mass-produced without using toxic chemicals.


      In sum: I enjoyed this book enormously, because it was so rich in first-


hand facts, as opposed to empty statistics and abstract analysis. The problem


discussed by the author is malfeasance on the part of tomato-growers in


Florida, specifically in connection with grossly exploitative labor practicesand also in connection with their use of environment- and health-destroying


chemicals. The author doesn’t put forth an argument at all: he states facts.


These facts make it clear that there is a problem, and they make it clear what


that problem is (slave labor, underpaid workers, illness among workers and to


some extent among the general public, and destruction of wildlife). What the


author doesn’t say that is that people responsible for these horrors are


obviously aware of them, and they wouldn’t continue to perpetrate them


unless they had extremely strong financial incentives for doing so. And the


author also doesn’t say why they have these incentives or how they honorable


conduct on their part can be incentivized. So yes—Tomatoland is replete with


solid evidence for specific factual claims, e.g. claims relating to worker-


illness and worker-exploitation. But explanations are proposed and a fortiori


no evidence or reasoning is adduced in their favor. The author did do a


creditable job of explaining the history of Florida’s tomato-industry, but he


doesn’t even try to identify the financial pressures that are responsible for its


continued existence or for its abhorrent practices. As earlier stated, what I


found most striking about this book was the discussion of slave labor in this


industry-sector: I do not believe that the author is exaggerating. This is not an


acceptable situation, and we as a nation must address it. But it seems to be


entirely off of our national radar—a fact that I also find striking (and


disturbing). 


       A Demographic Analysis of Dropout-likelihood and Dropout-


rationality


 


 


 


                                            Abstract


      In the fall of 2017, approximately 5 million people enrolled in college


in the United States, and 56% of them had dropped out by the end of the


school year (National Center for Education Statistics, 2019). In the present


work, we will find that, contrary to what is generally assumed, people who


drop out tend to be rational to do so. First, we will establish (1) that the


greater the likely financial pay-off of a college degree, the less likely one is to


drop out. Then we will establish (2) that the more likely a college degree is to


lead to an emotionally satisfying career, the less likely one is to drop out. 


      Claim (1) will be established on the basis of analysis of existing


statistics. IQ is directly correlated with SAT-scores and SAT-scores are


directly correlated with graduation-probability. The higher a given college-


graduate’s SAT-scores, the greater the probable financial benefits of a college


degree and the smaller the probable costs. The costs of college to those who


score in the top percentile on the SAT are negligible compared to the gains. It


therefore tends to be irrational for such people to drop out, and their drop-outrate is less than 1%. Strikingly, the dropout rate for those who score in the top


percentile on the SAT are invariant with respect to gender, ethnicity, and

                                                        th
personal finances. For those who score in the 40 percentile or below, the


costs of a college degree a exceed the benefits. It therefore tends to be


rational for such people to drop out of college, and over 60% of them do so.


Dropout-rates within the class of low IQ dropouts are not invariant with


respect to gender, ethnicity, and personal finances, minorities and males


being marginally more likely Caucasians and females to drop out, and the


socioeconomically underprivileged being non-marginally more likely than


the socioeconomically privileged to do so. The higher the SAT, the more


invariant dropout-rates become with respect to these variables.


      Within the class of low (<110) IQ graduates, those whose careers are


based on vocational training received outside of college earn approximately


20% more than those whose careers are based on their college degrees.


Within the class of low IQ persons who do not have vocational certifications,


those with college degrees earn only marginally more than those without


college degrees and earn less after student-debt is adjusted for. Moreover, the


jobs that members of the one group are likely to have coincide for the most


part with those that members of the other group are likely to have.


        Earnings therefore depend on IQ, vocational training, and college-


degree. For those on the lower end of the IQ spectrum, vocational training ispositively dispositive of high net earnings in those on the lower end of the IQ


spectrum and a college degree is dispositive of low net earnings. In those on


the upper end of the IQ spectrum, a college degree is dispositive of high net


earnings and vocational training does not in general have an appreciable


effect either way. More precisely, the aforementioned variables generate the


following earnings hierarchy:


      (i)         Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (ii)   High non-graduates without vocational training


      (iii)                       Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (iv)   High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (v)         Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vi)   High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vii)                       High IQ graduates with vocational training


      (viii)                 High IQ graduates without vocational training


 


      Claim (2) cannot be established on the basis of existing statistics. This


is not statistics are inherently incapable of settling the matter; it is simply


because the existing statistical data does not exist. Consequently, the present


researcher had to generate that data on his own, by administering a carefully


constructed questionnaire the just-mentioned eight-groups of people, the


defeasible presumption being that career-satisfaction levels will, to at leastsome degree, track, earnings levels.


      1.

      Introduction


      College dropout rates are currently over 50% and have been for over a


decade (Pevin, 2015). This is often described as a ‘tragedy’ (Wolf, 2017) or a


‘scandal’ (Kirp, 2019). On the face of it, this is understandable. Dropping out


is a form of quitting, and quitting is in many contexts a form of failure. Also,


a college degree has come to be associated in the popular psyche with ‘the


good life’---two cars in the driveway, a house in the suburbs, and so on


(Corn, 2017). Also, just as Hillary Clinton said, college graduates do on


average earn approximately $1,000,000 during their lifetimes than non-


graduates (Bartik, 2016). Finally, it is obvious to many people that if they


hadn’t gone to college, they wouldn’t have the careers that they do have: they


wouldn’t be investment bankers or physicians or attorneys (Altoni et al.,


2016).


      The truth is, however, that the dropout rates are not high enough.


There is relatively definitive evidence of this of a purely objective, statistical


nature. We will discuss this evidence in detail in the present work, but the


upshot of it is easily stated: Those with high IQ’s economically benefit from


college, and those with low IQ’s don’t. The reason for this, quite simply, is


that people with low IQ’s derive little economic benefit from academic


courses of study and are economically better off learning and practicing atrade. Not only is this the obvious, off-the-cuff explanation: it is, as we will


go to great lengths to show, a matter of demonstrable statistical fact. These


claims will be established on the basis of rigorous statistical analysis.


      Of course, money isn’t everything. Given only that someone with a


low IQ stands to earn more money practicing a trade than he does using his


college degree, it doesn’t follow that he is more fulfilled if he takes the first


path. That said, we will show that he is in fact more fulfilled. We will show


on the basis of survey-data that low IQ college graduates, not including those


whose careers are based on vocational training received outside of college,


are among the least fulfilled sub-populations in the country. The happiest


sub-population, as those same surveys indicate, consists of high IQ college


graduates, and the second happiest is vocationally trained college non-


graduates.


      We will establish this by administering a carefully constructed


questionnaire to eight groups of people. The groups in question are:


      (i)         Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (ii)   High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (iii)                       Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (iv)   High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (v)         Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vi)   High IQ non-graduates with vocational training      (vii)                       High IQ graduates with vocational training


      (viii)                 High IQ graduates without vocational training


      2.            The survey uses a seven-point Likert-scale, making it possible


to condense questionnaire-results into a single figure and therefore making it


possible to establish quantitative comparisons between survey-results.


      3.            Survey results will establish the following ‘fulfillment-


hierarchy’:


      (ix)   Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (x)         High non-graduates without vocational training


      (xi)   Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (xii)                       High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (xiii)                 Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (xiv)                       High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (xv)   High IQ graduates with vocational training


      (xvi)                       High IQ graduates without vocational training


      The reasons for targeting these specific groups is that, as we will see,


dropout-likelihood and dropout-rationality depend on IQ and vocational-


training.        Background of the Study


              There is plenty of statistical data concerning college-dropoutism,


but this data has not been properly interpreted. Attempts have been made to


correlate dropout-rates with ethnicity (Shapiro et al., 2017), distance from


home (Patterson Silver Wolf et al., 2017), relationship-status (Adams et al.,


2016), eating disorders (Lipson et al., 2017), mental health (Eisenberg, 2016),


video game usage (Schmitt et al., 2015), and personal finances (Britt et al.,


2017)---all to little or no avail. What the statistical data makes absolutely


clear is that people with extremely high SAT/ACT scores (henceforth ‘test-


scores’) seldom drop out and that people with low test-scores usually drop


out. The data also makes it clear that test-scores correlate with IQ (Armstrong


et al., 2017), warranting the conclusion that dropout-likelihood correlates


inversely with IQ. This is invariant across genders, ethnicities, relationship-


statuses and the like. Further, the statistical data makes it clear towards the


lower end of the IQ spectrum, the economic benefits of a college degree


become marginal at best and also those benefits are directly dependent on IQ,


with those in the gifted range economically benefitting enormously from


college.


      Be it noted that the statistical data does not directly disclose any of


this, even though, when scrutinized, it clearly does indicate as much. The


correlation between dropout-likelihood and IQ is readily enough established.The correlation between dropout-rationality and IQ is not as easily


established, granting that the difficulties in establishing it are ultimately


purely technical in nature. Neither correlation is particularly hard to establish


given the available statistical data, making it hard (but also, given our


purposes, unnecessary) to explain why these correlations have not yet been


established.


  A consequence of the fact that it has not thus far been established


exactly who drops out is that it also has not been established how


economically rational it is for those who drop out to do so. A consequence of


this latter fact, in its turn, is that economic dropout-rationality has not yet


been correlated with emotional dropout-rationality. In other words, the degree


to which it is economically rational for a given person to drop out of college


has not been correlated with the degree to which his doing so conduces to his


having an emotionally fulfilling career.        Problem Statement


      Prior to this study it was not known exactly who dropped out or why;


nor, therefore, was it known to what extent it was rational for those who


dropped out to do so. The purpose of this study is to answer each of these


questions, with special attention being paid to the relationship between


dropoutism and career-satisfaction. An expected consequence of this study


will be a need to reframe our thinking about college-dropouts and college-


dropoutism. Thus far, we have regarded dropouts as being the failures


(Hollander et al., 2017) and those trying to prevent them dropping out as the


heroes (Moriña et al., 2017; Bullard, 2018).


      This study will show that it is the other way around. Forcing people to


go to college who are not inclined to do so deprives them of income and


professional fulfillment and is also enormously expensive for society as a


whole. There are many reasons for this. First of all, there are many people


who are happy and financially successful as auto-mechanics---or electricians


or plumbers or as practitioners of some other trade---who would be miserable


if, instead of learning their trade, they had gone to college. Many such people


are gifted at their trade, and many people need their services and pay


handsomely for them. Those same people would in many cases not be faring


as well had they opted for a college-based path. They would often struggle


with the coursework and either drop out, in which case they are likely to self-identify as failures, or choose a major that gives them no marketable skills, in


which case they are likely to be failures.


      Also, trades (e.g. auto-repair, plumbing, carpentry) are inherently


useful. A person with an IQ can become a master plumber or auto-mechanic;


and if they do, they will never have to worry about employment. Also, many


people who learn trades launch successful businesses of their own based on


those trades, and 70% of successful small to medium-sized business are


started in this way. But liberal arts degrees, however much intrinsic value


they may have, tend to provide those who have them with very little in the


way of marketable skills. There is no obvious way for an intellectually


average or even moderately intelligent person to monetize a degree in English


or History or Philosophy. If someone is intellectually gifted, he may be able


to find a way to leverage into a successful career of some kind; he may


become a journalist or professor or financier. But these are long-shots even


those who are intellectually gifted, and for most they are simply out of the


question. The result is that most people with liberal arts degrees find


themselves in an extremely competitive job-market with little to offer to


prospective employers and no skills on the basis of which to become self-


employed.


      It is assumed that STEM degrees, unlike degrees humanities and social


sciences degrees, are inherently useful. This position is misconceived. Firstof all, most STEM are intellectually out of reach for most of the population,


including most of the college population. Second, most STEM degrees,


including those that are within the intellectual reach of the average college


student, are not inherently useful. A degree in biology does not by itself


qualify anyone to do anything. In the case of someone who is intellectually


gifted, a degree in biology may eventuate in that person’s being a physician


or researcher, but usually only on the condition that the person in question


spend years in graduate school or medical school. But these are low-


probability outcomes for someone of average or even moderately high


intelligence, and a degree in biology opens up very few professional avenues


for such a person. To be sure, somebody with a bachelor’s degree in


petroleum engineering or computer science is for that reason alone likely to


have excellent professional prospects, the same being true, albeit to a lesser


extent, of someone with a bachelor’s in chemistry. But less than 20% of


college students are able to complete even the first year of any given one of


these majors.


      As for mathematics and physics, degrees in these fields, in and of


themselves, do very little to make those who have them employable. To be


sure, people with bachelor’s degrees in these fields are relatively likely to


achieve professional success, but their becoming successful usually involves


their spending years after college becoming proficient in areas (e.g.programming, architecture, finance) that are only tangentially related to their


undergraduate degrees. But all of this is moot, given that less than 10% of all


college students are able to complete even the first year of either of these


majors.


      Today (July 3, 2019), the Washington Post reported that only 27% of


people with college degree have jobs in areas relating to their college degrees


(Plummer, 2019). By contrast, over 90% of those with vocational degrees


have jobs in the areas of their degrees (Wladawsky-Berger, 2018). This is


understandable. A credential in HVAC or plumbing or computer-


maintenance makes one very useful; a degree in English or Religious Studies


does not. A consequence is minor economic downturns greatly effect


employment- and income levels of college graduates but have little effect on


those of tradespersons (Alonso, 2015; Jahn et al., 2015; Friedman, 2018;


Arnold, 2018; Levin-Waldman, 2018).      Purpose of the Study


      The purpose of this study is to determine how rational it is for those


who drop out of college to do so. This will involve figuring how exactly who


drops out of college, i.e. we must first identify the characteristics that dispose


someone to drop out of college. Having done this, we must correlate dropout-


likelihood with probably average future earnings and also with probably


average degree of career-satisfaction.


        Ultimately, what we refer to as ‘rationality’ coincides not with


economic rationality but with emotional rationality. Stated simply, for a


person to be rational is for him to make decisions that conduce to his


emotional well-being. This often involves making decisions that conduce to


one’s financial well-being. But economic rationality cannot be identified with


rationality since someone who makes decisions that make wealthy but


suicidally depressed is ceteris paribus less rational than someone who makes


decisions that make him fulfilled but only moderately wealthy (Bennett,


2016).


      This is not a purely theoretical point. Setting aside those who simply


don’t earn enough to satisfy basic needs, there is surprisingly little correlation


between happiness-levels and income (Easterlin, 2015). Happiness is more


easily correlated less with how much they earn than with how they earn it


(Oishi et al., 2015). Lawyers who earn under $100,000 have extremely lowrates of career-satisfaction, and most entrepreneurs who earn more than


$25,000/year have extremely high rates of career satisfaction (Hessels et al.,


2018).


      Because rationality clearly involves being able to make decisions that


conduce to one’s own emotional well-being, we cannot go so far as to


identify rationality with economic rationality (Christiansen, 2017). But there


are important reasons not to disregard the concept of economic rationality.


First of all, if people who are dropping out of college are rational to do so,


that suggests that instead of wasting resources trying to keep them in college,


we should use resources to identify and improve access to alternative


professional paths. Second, economic rationality is completely objective:


whereas people’s emotional self-assessments, though prima facie credible,


may be replete with rationalizations, there is no denying how much a given


person earns or what kind of work he does to earn it (Ervas, 2017). In this


study, consequently, we will investigate both the economic and the emotional


rationality of college-dropoutism.      Research Questions and/or Hypotheses 


      This study will investigate in what ways and to what degrees the


consequences of dropping out of college depend on IQ and receipt of


vocational training. Given the fact that many ‘high-IQ’ careers (e.g.


physician, investment banker, professor) are simply out of the question for


those who do not have college degrees, there exists a reasonable, if


defeasible, presumption to the effect that it is in general more rational than


not for those in the intellectually gifted range to graduate from college. What


is less obvious is whether the same is true of those on the other end of the IQ


spectrum. Day-to-day experience suggests that, where such people are


concerned, a college degree tends to lead to a tedious and low-level office


job. Day-to-day experience also suggests that, when such people receive


vocational training and careers based thereupon, their work, though arduous,


tends to be both lucrative and fulfilling. To put it bluntly and informally,


auto-mechanics, super-intendents, welders, Emergency Medical Technicians,


and Web-designers seem to enjoy their work, whereas secretaries, probation


officers, intake-coordinators, low-level administrators, and office-workers do


not seem to enjoy their work. Of course, these claims, being based only on


personal experience, cannot be asserted with confidence, it being the purpose


the present study to subject them to systematic scrutiny.


        Consequently, the following research question guides this qualitativestudy:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college behaving


rationally in doing so?


      There are two versions of RQ1, namely:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college being
            F


financially rational in doing so? In other words, to what extent does their


doing so lead to increased earnings?


      And:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college being
            E


emotionally rational in doing so? In other words, to what extent does their


doing so lead to increased career-satisfaction?


      In order to answer RQ1, we must first answer some other questions, in


particular:


      RQ2: Who drops out of college? In other words, what characteristics


are dispositive of a person’s dropping out of college? (Is it poverty, mental


illness, physical illness, unstable home life, low IQ, etc.?)


      RQ2 can be answered on the basis of existing statistical data, the


answer being:


      HQ2: The higher a given person’s IQ, the less likely he is to drop out


of college.


      RQ1 is also to be answered on the basis of statistical analysis. The
            Fnull-answer is:


      HQ1: A person’s IQ does not in general have any bearing, positive
            F0


or negative, on whether it is financially for that person to drop out of


college.  


      The expected answer is:


      HQ1: The higher a given person’s IQ, the less financially rational it is
            F


for him to drop out of college.


 


 


      RQ1: is not to be answered on the basis of existing statistical data.
            E


We will attempt to answer it on the basis of survey data. The null answer is:


      HQ1: A given person’s dropping out of college may conduce to
            E


increased career-satisfaction or to decreased career-satisfaction; and whether


it does the one as opposed to the other is completely random and of his


major, his intelligence level, and indeed any other given fact about him.


      The expected answer


      HQ1: Categorizing people by IQ and college degree status generates
            E


the following career-satisfaction hierarchy:


      (i)         Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (ii)   High non-graduates without vocational training      (iii)                       Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (iv)   High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (v)         Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vi)   High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vii)                       High IQ graduates with vocational training


      (viii)                 High IQ graduates without vocational training


      HQ1 is the ‘expected’ answer in three senses. First, it is consistent
            E


with statements made, but not adequately supported, in credible publications


(Looseley et al., 2019). Second, it is consistent with my personal and


professional experience. Third, it is consistent with small, informal studies


that I have conducted in anticipation of the present study.       Advancing Scientific Knowledge and Significance of the Study


      This study has manifold practical and theoretical significances. First of


all, if the hypotheses stated above are correct, then the enormous resources


that are being spent trying to prevent people from dropping out of college


should instead be spent trying to build alternatives to college (Bok, 2017).


Also, right now, k-12 education is essentially college-prep education


(Harbour, 2015), and the current study is likely to show that this is


misconceived: where many students are concerned, possibly most, the focus


should not be on getting them into college, but on constructing alternatives to


college. Also, as we will see, when low persons in the non-gifted IQ range


have careers that they find fulfilling, those careers are based on vocational


training, not on college degrees, and, what is more, those careers service vital


and otherwise insufficiently serviced economic sectors. Right now, thanks to


the exclusive focus on getting people, regardless of their talents, into and


through college, many people are being steered away from careers that they


would enjoy and be good at and that would benefit society. Governments and


government-related bureaucracies being what they, might cannot necessarily


expect the existing educational establishment to right-size itself, and the


private sector may therefore have to step into this breech.


      This study also has significance of a purely theoretical kind for the


fields of psychology and economics. According to the hypotheses statedabove, entrepreneurs have higher levels of career satisfaction than ‘corporate


wage-slaves’ who earn three times as much, and people who practice traces,


such as plumbing and auto-repair, are happier than probation officers and


administrators who earn twice as much. If correct, this tells us a great deal


about human motivations, and it also tells us that what drives economic


progress is not the desire for money so much as it is the desire for money that


is acquired in a way that is consistent with one’s values and personality


(Pagenelli, 2015).      Rationale for Methodology


              There are three different investigative methodologies:


quantitative, qualitative, and mixed. Quantitative methodologies attempt to


assign numerical values to relevant factors and to investigate relations of


dependence and predictability holding among such values (Hempel, 1965;


Curtis et al., 2016); Salmon, 2017). Suppose for example that violent crime in


Small Town USA has increased 500% over the last decade. A quantitative


analysis of this phenomenon would try to find some numerically determinate


variable (or variable-set) x (e.g. consistently decreasing funding for law-


enforcement) such that changes in x correlated with the rise in crime in Small


Town. Qualitative methods investigate causal relations holding among forces


that either have not yet been quantified or cannot be quantified in any


principled way. A qualitative analysis of the rise in crime in Small Town


might involve case-studies of specific criminals, or interviews with criminals


or victims of crime or law-enforcement personnel, the purpose being to elicit


relevant information (e.g. information about changes in cultural norms). A


mixed methodology is one that involves elements of both qualitative and


quantitative methodologies (Rudestam & Newton, 2015). When applied to


the rise in crime in Small Town, such an approach might involve a


combination of the methods must described.


      There are two components to this project: a purely statisticalcomponent, in which the demographics of dropoutism are investigated, and a


survey-based component, in which the psychology of dropoutism is


investigated. In each case, the methodology used is quantitative. But there are


important differences between the methodologies used, owing to the fact that,


whereas the statistics needed to investigate the financial aspects of


dropoutism already exist, the statistics needed to investigate its consequences


for career-satisfaction do not yet exist, requiring us to generate those statistics


ourselves. Consequently, the methodology used in the one case related only


to the analysis of statistics, whereas the methodology used in the other case


related both the analysis and to the generation of statistics.                    Nature of the Research Design of the Study


      Both parts of the inquiry were quantitative and causal-correlational in


nature. The statistical part correlates dropout rates with IQ and subsequent


earnings; the psychological part correlates earnings with levels of career-


satisfaction. The statistical part involved nothing more than finding


correlations so tight that they were obviously causal and then using


commonsense to infer what the operative causal relations were. For example,


there is an extremely tight connection between low SAT score and high


freshman dropout-likelihood, but it is obvious that a low SAT score is not


itself the cause of someone’s dropping out of college. An inability to do


academic work is the cause, and this inability is manifested both in low SAT


scores and also in poor performance in first-year college classes, the latter


often being the immediate precursor of (voluntary or involuntary) permanent


departure from college (Mabel et al., 2018).


      The psychological part involved administering surveys whose results


could be represented as a single variable. Our objective here is to compare


earnings with levels of career-satisfaction. Earnings are given by a single


figure (e.g. $170,000/year), and we therefore need career-satisfaction to be


represented by a single quantity if we are to correlate it with earnings and,


consequently, if we are to determine how emotionally rational those who


drop out are in doing so, i.e. if we are to determine degrees of dropout-
                                                                                  Erationality (Chen et al., 2016)        Definitions of Terms


      Dropout. In this context, a ‘dropout’ is somebody who drops out of


college and does not return. Somebody who takes a year off is not a dropout.


        Dropoutism. The phenomenon of people dropping out of college.


          Dropout-likelihood. The probability that a given person will drop out


of college.


        Dropout-probability. Synonymous with “dropout-likelihood.”


        Dropout-rationality. The degree to which it is rational for a given


person to drop out of college.


        Dropout-rationality. The degree to which it is economically rational
                E


for a given person to drop out of college.


        Dropout-rationality. The degree to which it is emotionally rational
                F


(i.e. conducive to career-satisfaction) for a given person to drop out of


college.


          Dropout-non-vocational. Somebody who drops out of college and


then receives vocational training


        Dropout-vocational. Somebody who drops out of college and then


receives vocational training.


        Dropoutism. A neologism used to denote the phenomenon of people


dropping out of college.


        Economic Rationality. Ability to make decisions that maximizeearnings. The concept of economic rationality is well defined, given that


earnings can be quantified. Some scholars have attempted to broaden the


concept of economic rationality to include other variables, such as quality of


life, but these extensions of the concept of tend to strip it of operational


significance. Importantly, economic rationality, narrowly construed,


correlates with other quantifiable variables, such as health and longevity,


which in their turn bear on quality of life.


        Graduate. In this context, a ‘graduate’ is someone who graduates from


college.


        Graduation-likelihood: The probability that a given person will


graduate from college.


      IQ. Short of ‘intelligence quotient.’ Existing ways of determining IQ


are deeply flawed, as is evidenced by the quite routine occurrence of people


who apparently do poorly on IQ tests but whose professional


accomplishments unambiguously indicate extremely intelligence. That said,


however unreliable the standard IQ tests may be with respect to geniuses and


other outliers, they have proven reliable and useful and reliable when dealing


with large populations, and IQ scores generated by such tests are therefore


useful in the context of this study.


          Graduation-probability: Synonym of “graduation-likelihood.”


        IQ-comparable (adjective). x and y are IQ-comparable if they are inthe same IQ range.


        IQ-comparables (noun). x and y are IQ-comparables if they are IQ-


comparable.


        Non-dropouts. A neologism used to denote someone who has either


graduated or is currently in college and has not dropped out of college thus


far. 


        Non-attendant. A neologism used to denote someone who simply


doesn’t attend college at all.


        Rationality. Ability to make decisions that maximize one’s welfare.


The concept of rationality simpliciter is of limited utility, owing to the


absence of clear benchmarks, and often gives way to the better-defined


concept of economic rationality.


      RQ. Given a particular IQ, the corresponding RQ is the ratio of


average lifetime earnings of college graduates with that IQ to average


lifetime earnings of non-graduates with that IQ. So RQ corresponding to IQ


103 is the ratio of average lifetime earnings of graduates with an IQ of 103 to


average lifetime earnings of non-graduates with an IQ of 103.


        Test-score. Refers only to SAT and ACT scores. Oftentimes, the terms


“SAT score”, “ACT score” and “SAT/ACT score” will be used; but


whenever “test-score” is used, it is used to refer only to SAT/ACT scores.        Assumptions, Limitations, Delimitations


              It is assumed that the statistical data that we are not ourselves


generating is reliable. This assumption is warranted, given that in each case


that data was collected by a reliable agency, such as the National Center for


Education Statistics. We are also assuming that is administering the survey


that we are using will in fact administer it to populations of the appropriate


types. For example, when we task the survey company with administering


our survey to people who have vocational certifications, we are assuming that


they are in fact doing so. This assumption is warranted given that we are


using a reputable survey-service.


      There is one very serious delimitation, namely that it cannot be ruled


out that survey-results express wishful-thinking and rationalization (Daviaux


et al. 2016). This is inherent in all psychological surveys (Taswell, 2015).


That said, there are three ways in which we are hedging against this


possibility. First, we will always have information about the respondent’s


economic-situation, simply the company that is directly administering the


survey will target people according to their demographics, including their


earnings. Second, each population will be issued multiple different surveys;


and if there is a tendency for a given population to respond disingenuously on


a given survey, its answers on that survey are likely to conflict with its


answers on the other surveys (Cosco et al., 2016). Finally, the surveys beingused are already widely used and their efficacy has been established.        Summary and Organization of the Remainder of the Study


              Chapter 2 will review the existing literature relating to the topic


of this study, along with the relevant statistics. The statistical data is


abundant. The literature, however, tends to be inconsistent with or non-


explanatory of the statistical data. In Chapter 2, we will state the relevant


statistics in detail and provide creditable models of them.  In Chapter 3,


methodology will be discussed. We will identify the underpinnings of the


statistical work done in Chapter 2 and will also explain exactly how we will


be using surveys to elicit information relating to career-satisfaction. In


Chapter 4, we will analyze the survey results, and we will also restate, this


time in more detail, the results of our statistical analysis of dropoutism; and


we will compare those two bodies of data. In Chapter 5, we will identify the


changes in public policy and also in personal conduct that are indicated by


the contents of Chapter 4.


              Chapters 1-3 are already complete. The survey has already been


constructed; the survey-company has verified that it can send the requisite


number of surveys to the relevant populations; and the researcher has already


familiarized himself with the survey software. Chapter 4 should be complete


before October 2019, and Chapter 5 by January 1, 2010.


                               Chapter 2: Literature Review      Introduction to the Chapter


      It is easy to find out how many people don’t graduate from college


(NCES, 2019a). It is also easy, though not quite as easy, to find out how


many people within a given demographic fail to graduate from college


(NCES, 2019b). It is not possible to find information to the effect that a


person's likelihood of dropping out is a function of his having characteristic


X, for some appropriate value of X. Blacks are less likely to graduate from


college than whites (Shapiro et al., 2017), but 43% of blacks have college


degrees and 43% of whites don't (Stout et al., 2018), and being as opposed to


white, or vice versa, therefore cannot be the missing value of X in “X is why


people drop out.” Similarly, males are more likely to drop out than females


(Strumbos et al., 2016); but the differences are marginal, and “being male” is


therefore not the missing value of X. Dropout-rates cannot even be explained


in terms of poor financials. High-performing college students from


impoverished backgrounds are less likely to drop out than poor-performing


students from wealthy backgrounds (Korn et al., 2015; Yeager et al., 2016),


and extremely high performing students from impoverished backgrounds


have only marginally higher rates of dropoutism than comparably performing


students from wealthy backgrounds (Hoxby et al., 2013). So poor financials,


though obviously a contributing factor, are not the or even a principle factor.


Religious people are less likely to graduate than non-religious people(Tentsho et al., 2019); and people who have formally diagnosed as having a


serious mental illness are less likely to graduate than those who have not been


so diagnosed (Naslund et al., 2015). Even if we form the intersection of each


these ‘less-than' groups---even if we consider the class of socioeconomically


disadvantaged, religious, mentally ill, minority males--the resulting group


still has a graduation rate of around 25%, showing that none of the


characteristics is more than marginally responsible for the phenomenon of


dropoutism.


      Given that we don’t know what causes people to drop out, we don’t


know how economically rational it is for people who drop out to do so. We


are given extremely broad statistical claims, e.g. ‘college graduates out-earn

 
non-graduates by $1,000,000’ (Witteveenet al., 2017), that supposedly settle


the issue—but clearly don’t. Does staying in college always conduce to


higher earnings? If not, when does it do so? We do not have answers to these


questions.


      Nor do we have an answer to the question: How emotionally rational


is it for people who drop out of college to do so? In other words, to what


extent does their doing so conduce to their fulfillment or career-satisfaction?


The presumption is that dropouts tend to end up slaving away at menial, low-


paying jobs, whereas graduates tend to end up having intellectual demanding,


high-paying careers. But this presumption is indeed just that.  In this chapter,we will review the literature, along with the statistics, bearing on these


matters. The literature is of little use, we will find, but the statistical data is of


use, if properly interpreted.                     Identification of the Gap


      Who drops out of college and why, and what are they gaining and


foregoing by doing so? These questions have not been answered. There is an


abundance of literature concerning the demographics of dropoutism, but the


claims therein made, even if correct, have little or no explanatory force.


      Within the last five years, it has been alleged, by scholars publishing


in reputable journals, that dropoutism is ‘linked’ to:


        *Ethnicity (Boyraz, 2016)


        *Drug/alcohol abuse (Ho, 2016)


      *Mental illness (Mitchell, 2016)


        *Religious belief (Li, 2017)


      *Video game usage (Cochran, 2018)


      *Absence of easily accessed academic advisers and psychotherapists


(Lovelace, 2017)


      *Poor dormitory and living conditions (Li, 2019)


      *Level of parents’ education (Stewart, 2015)


        *Parents’ combined income (Stewart, 2015), and


        *Relationship status (DeLuca, 2016).


      Only 30% of African Americans graduate from college. Therefore,


there is a ‘link’ between race and dropout-likelihood (Tate, 2017).


      Dropouts are more likely than non-dropouts to play video-games.Therefore, there is a ‘link’ between video-game usage and dropout-likelihood


(Dunckley, 2016).


      Dropouts are more likely than non-dropouts to have experienced


serious childhood trauma. Therefore, there is a ‘link’ between childhood-


trauma and dropout-likelihood (Dube, 2018).


      Dropouts are more likely to be religious than non-dropouts. Therefore,


there is a ‘link’ between religious belief and dropout-likelihood.


      Dropouts often cite relationship issues when explaining why they


dropped out. Therefore, there is a ‘link’ between relationship-status and


dropout-likelihood (Legg, 2017).


      Dropouts more likely than non-dropouts to self-describe or be


formally described as depressed or otherwise mentally ill. Therefore, there is


a ‘link’ between depression/mental illness and dropout-likelihood (Marsh,


2017).


      People from low-income homes are more likely than those from high-


income homes to drop out. Therefore, there is a ‘link' between parents'


income and dropout-likelihood (Jaschik, 2015).


      People whose parents did not complete college are more likely to drop


out than those whose parents did complete college. Therefore, there is a ‘link’


between parents’ education-level and dropout-likelihood (Casey, 2018).


      Dropouts are (in 2019) more likely than to be male than female.Therefore, there is a ‘link’ between gender and dropout-likelihood (Samuels,


2017).


      Let us scrutinize these claims. 30% of African Americans do graduate


from college. So the ‘link’ between ethnicity is at best weak (Paul, 2018).


        Non-dropouts are as likely as dropouts to claim to be suffering from


‘serious relationship issues.’ (Greenburg, 2011).


        Although may cases of dropping do appear to be precipitated by


mental illness, depression and suicidal ideation are in fact markedly more


common among non-dropouts, being particularly high in those who enroll in


doctoral programs (Wong, 2018).


        Students from “low-income” homes are indeed 600% more likely high


income students to drop out, if ‘low income’ and ‘high income’ are taken to


mean, respectively, “annual income of less than $30,000” and “annual


income of more than $250,000”—but only because the graduation rate in the


second group is less than 3%. Therefore, the ‘low parental income’ theory at


most describes an ancillary factor.


      Religious students are only around 10% more likely than non-religious


students to drop out. Also, this figure varies enormously depending on the


religious denomination. Mormons have an exceedingly low drop-out rate, as


do Orthodox Jews (Saxe et al. 2013).


        Non-dropouts are as likely as dropouts to be dissatisfied withdormitory-conditions, with their social lives, and with the degree of access to


student-advisers and psychotherapists (Beiter et al. 2015).


      Dropouts are at most only marginally more likely than non-dropouts to


play video-games excessively or to abuse drugs/alcohol, and there is some


indication that video-game usage helps prevent those with severe depression


from dropping out of college (Parker, 2019).


      There are deeper problems with these studies. Maybe people who drop


out drink/do drugs/play video games because they don’t want to be in


college. In other words, maybe their desire to drop out is the cause, and their


engaging in these maladaptive behaviors is the effect. This is not a mere


theoretical possibility, as we are about to say.


      Also, maybe soon-to-be dropouts are right not to want to be in college.


Maybe they are depressed about being in college because they suspect that it


is a waste of their time and money. Indeed, this is likely the case, we will


find.


      African Americans with test-scores (SAT/ACT scores) in 90th


percentile and above are minimally likely to drop out and are less likely to do

                                                            th
so than their white counterparts.  Students in the 95 percentile above have


less than a one percent change of dropping out, regardless of gender,


ethnicity, religious denomination, drug/alcohol use, mental


illness/depression, relationship-status, and indeed any other given variable.             


      A related fact is that students who drop out are overwhelmingly likely


to be struggling academically, which is consistent with what we have said


about IQ vis-à-vis dropout-likelihood and also with the fact, noted by Allen et


al. (2017), that ACT-scores are predictive of graduation-likelihood.


  


      Figure 1 ACT vis-à-vis Likelihood of Having a 4.0 Average Freshman


Year      Adapted from: Jeff Allen and Justin Radunzel, “Relating ACT


Composite Score to Different Levels of First Year College GPA.” ACT Table


4, May 2017.


 

                                                                          th
        Approximately 80% of students with test scores in the 40 percentile


or below drop out of college (Rothwell, 2017); and this figure is almost


invariant with respect to gender, ethnicity, religious denomination,


drug/alcohol use, mental illness/depression, relationship-status, and indeed


any other given variable (Cooper, 2014). The totality of this data suggests


that ethnicity, relationship status, etc. contribute to dropoutism only in those


in the middle-range, suggesting that they function only as contributory


causes.


      Also, there is a complete absence of data concerning the immediate


aftermath of a person’s dropping out. It may be that their rates of depression,


drug-use, etc. decrease. This is an open empirical question. If the answer is


‘yes’, then college was, to so speak, the disease, and dropping out the cure.


      More importantly, what are the economic prospects of those who drop


out? Do they lose opportunities or gain them? We can’t answer that until we


can identify some variable that correlates tightly with high dropout rates and


then correlate that same variable with economic prospects. The literature has


not identified this X-factor.      Another deeply striking fact about the scholarly literature is that it


always takes it as a given that dropping out is failure. It is not asked why


students drop out. Nor is it asked what they gain by doing so. Sometimes it is


asked what they would have lost by not dropping out; but the answers


subsequently given are strictly financial in nature and, more importantly,


don’t involve consideration of important sub-divisions within the class of


non-graduates, in particular, the distinction between those who receive


vocational training and those who do not.        Identification of the Gap (Continued): The Statistical Data


      The academic literature is disappointing. The statistics are more


illuminating. There are two statistics that are especially important: those


relating IQ to test-scores (SAT/ACTS scores) to graduation rates, and those


relating test-scores to IQ. The higher the test-score, the higher the likelihood


of graduation (See Figures 1-9); and the higher the IQ, the higher, the test-


score (See Figures 10-11). In each case, we are dealing with strictly


monotonic correlations; and these nearly monotonic correlations explain


many of the weak correlations earlier discussed.


 























      Figure 2 Graduation Rate by SAT Score Nation-wide        Retrieved from: http://blog.numbersbox.com/2015/05/pell-grants-test-


scores-and-graduation.html and http://www.hamiltonproject.org
