      The statistical data relating to ACT/SAT scores is independentlycorroborated by the fact that the graduation rate of a given college is a


function of the average SAT scores of its students: the higher the average


SAT score, the higher the graduation rate. To be sure, we are not dealing with


strictly monotonic correlations. First of all, schools falling into special


categories, e.g. theological seminaries, may have different graduation-rates


from test-score-comparable liberal arts colleges. Also, there are cases average


test-scores at colleges differ marginally (i.e. by less than 15 percentiles) but


where the one has a higher graduation-rate than the other. But within these


limits, average SAT/ACT-score correlates strictly monotonically with higher


graduation-rates. See Figure 9.


      Once it becomes clear who drops out and why, it becomes possible to


answer important questions that have not yet been systematically


investigated, let alone answered, namely: What are the prospects for


dropouts? What do they stand to gain by dropping out and what do they stand


to lose? What kinds of careers do they subsequently have? Are they satisfied


with those careers? How do their levels of career-satisfaction compare with


those of non-dropouts? Answering these questions involves dealing with


important theoretical issues, which we will now discuss.         Theoretical Foundations and/or Conceptual Framework


              The phenomenon of dropoutism has thus far been studied from


cultural, political, and emotional perspectives. It has been taken for granted


that high dropout rates are a ‘tragedy’, and scholarship has consisted, with


few or no exceptions, to find someone or something to blame. In some cases,


the blame is placed on psychopathology: dropouts are alleged to be drug


addicts, alcoholics, victims of childhood trauma, or simply mentally ill. In


other cases, the blame is placed on classism or racism: dropouts do not have


the right skin color or do not come from the right background. In other cases,


blame is placed on inhospitable university environments: there are not


enough student counselors or dormitories are too crowded. 


        Universities have vigorously implemented policies based on these


analyses. They have built new and better recreational facilities and


dormitories (Taylor, C. G., 2017); they have hired additional academic


advisers and, in many cases, have made round-the-clock tutoring services


available to students (Han et al., 2018); and they have hired extra


psychologists and substance-abuse specialists (Uddin et al., 2019).


Meanwhile, dropout rates are not only climbing but accelerating (Facchini et


al., 2019).


              The reason is that dropoutism is not a political or psychological


or cultural issue; it is an economic issue.  The less a person stands to benefitfrom a college degree, the more likely he is to drop out. The dropout rate for

                                  th
those with SAT’s above the 85 percentile is less than 25%, and the


economic and professional benefits to such a person of a college degree are

                                                                                        th
extremely high. The dropout rate for someone with the SAT’s below the 40


percentile is almost 75%, and the benefits of a degree to such a person are


minimal. See Figures 12-15.


              Strikingly, philosophy majors are the only humanities majors


whose earnings are comparable to those of upper end STEM-majors, and


economics majors are the only social science majors to have such earnings.


This is consistent with the high IQ of those with degrees in these disciplines.


See Figures 15-20.


 








      Figure 6 Income by SAT


 


      Adapted from: https://pumpkinperson.com/2016/02/11/the-incredible-


correlation-between-iq-income/


  


      High IQ students who graduate are overwhelmingly likely to befinancially successful and to have rewarding careers. The outcomes for low


IQ graduates are very different. If they do not get vocational training, they


end up unemployed, intermittently employed at menial jobs, or continuously


employed in low-level administrative positions. The less someone stands to


gain by staying in college, the more likely he is to drop out. If they do get


vocational training and have careers based thereupon, they have moderately


high incomes and rewarding careers, but are worse off than IQ-comparable


people who skipped college altogether and started their vocational careers


earlier.


        Outcomes for low IQ non-graduates are highly polarized. Those who


do not get vocational training are much more likely than IQ-comparable


graduates without vocational training to be unemployed or turn to crime.


Those who do get vocational training are far less likely than IQ-comparable


graduates without vocational training to be unemployed and under-employed,


and they out-earn such graduates by a wide margin. Job-satisfaction for low-


IQ graduates without vocational training is extremely low, and it is extremely


high for vocationally trained low IQ graduates and non-graduates. Low IQ


graduates vocationally trained graduates earn less than low-IQ vocationally


trained non-attendants. Low IQ vocationally trained non-attendants are more


likely than IQ-comparable vocationally trained dropouts to earn more


$100,000+ annually, and the latter are more likely than IQ-comparable non-vocationally trained graduates to do so.


      In order to understand these results, we must know what low IQ


graduates are likely to major in, since this affects how they are likely to be


employed. Let us now turn to this matter and to the corresponding body of


literature.      Review of the Literature


      In order to understand the economic prospects of dropouts, we must


know what people of a given intelligence-level are likely to major.


Fortunately, this information is readily available and does not have to be


inferred.

       This information makes it possible to identify where low IQ college


graduates are likely to be employed. Low IQ graduates are obviously likely to


have had low IQ majors, these being Criminal Justice up to Psychology


(inclusive). Choosing psychology as the cut-off was not arbitrary, since it is


much more internally IQ-differentiated than psychology and since the career-


outcomes of business-majors are correspondingly more diverse, economically


and otherwise.


        Non-vocationally trained graduates with degrees in low IQ majors


who find stable employment are overwhelmingly likely to end up in the


following professional areas (Abel et al., 2014 and Nunley et al., 2016):


      *Probation and parole services


        *Corrections and prison administration


      *Social work


        *Elementary school teaching and administration


        *Flight-attendant and airport ground-attendant


      *Secretarial


        *Human resources


        *Drug-counseling


        *Convenience store management


        *Intake-coordination


      *Customer service      *Sales and telemarketing


        *Military and Coast Guard


          *Restaurant-management

      Most people with degrees in low IQ majors who do not have jobs


falling into one of these categories do not have stable employment.       Many of the just-mentioned career-paths require credentialing, in


some cases a master’s degree, additional to the bachelor’s degree.


      The presence of people from high IQ majors (religious studies and


above) in these professions is less than 1%.


        Non-vocationally trained recipients of low-IQ degrees make up less


than 1% of all successful (earning at least $20,000/annually) entrepreneurs.      Literature Review: Vocational Careers


        IQ-comparable people with vocational training, be they graduates or


non-graduates, tend to work in the following areas (Bureau of Labor


Statistics, 2019): 


        *General automotive


        *Carpentry


      *Plumbing


      *Nursing


        *Respiratory therapist


        *Electrician

        *Dental Assistant

        *Phlebotomy.


      *Welding


      *Network administration


      27% of successful entrepreneurs worked in these areas and then


became entrepreneurs by becoming self-employed in those same areas


(Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2019).      Average annual salaries in these areas, not adjusted for debt, are


approximately $48,870.

      The presumption is that those with neither college degrees nor


vocational training are in the worst economic position possible. This statistic


provide little support for this position. First of all, the probable careers of low


IQ graduates overlap to a high degree with those of low IQ non-vocationally


trained non-graduates. 70% of employed non-graduates with no vocational


certifications, as well as 40% of low IQ graduates, have jobs falling into one


of the following categories (Kroeger et al., 2016):


      *Server


        *Cashier


        *Warehouse/factory worker  


        *Insurance-sales


        *Custodial


        *Agricultural worker


      *Police Officer/Sheriff’s deputy


        *Military (infantry/non-commissioned officer)


      *Security guard


      *Hotel desk-worker/bellhop


      The average for these positions is $40,877.


        Approximately 15% of low IQ graduates go into education and socialworkers, and 15% go into various other professions (e.g. lab technician) that


either formally or informally require college degrees (Howell et al., 2015).


        SAT/ACT-scores in these professions are on average slightly lower


than those in low IQ majors (Hutchinson).




















 Figure 19 Unadjusted Salaries for Low IQ Non-graduate Non-


vocationals


      Adapted from: https://www.glassdoor.com


  Figure 20 Debt-adjusted Salaries for Low IQ Non-graduate Non-


vocationals


      Adapted from: https://www.glassdoor.com 


 Figure 21 Debt- and Tax-adjusted Salaries for Low IQ Non-graduate


Non-vocationals


      Adapted from: https://www.glassdoor.com Figure 22 Debt- and Tax-adjusted Salaries for Non-graduate Non-


vocationals, Low IQ Graduates, and Vocationals


      Adapted from: https://www.glassdoor.com      Literature Review: Financial Costs and Benefits of Low IQ Degree


      The lowest IQ majors are social work, education, psychology, criminal


justice, and variants thereof. People graduating with degrees in these fields on

 
average have around $25,000 in student-loan debt (Schmeiseret al., 2016).


Since work in the corresponding fields often involves getting a master's


degree or some other advanced degree, they usually have to take on more


debt before they can be employed in those fields (Webber et al., 2017).


Consequently, the average amount of student loan debt for licensed social


workers is approximately $60,000; for licensed psychologists, $65,000; for


schoolteachers, $45,000; probation and parole officers, $32,000 (Bowen,


2018).


      The median monthly amount of payments on student loan debts in


these fields are $600, and it takes people employed in these fields an average


of 25 years to pay off their student loan debts. This makes sense when it is


taken into account that these are interesting bearing loans and also that


median annual salaries in these fields just slightly $20,000 (Popescu, 2018).


      Student loan debt for non-attendants with vocational training is


$8,000; for dropouts with vocational training, $13,450; and for graduates


with vocational training, $31,000. The average amount of time needed to


repay student loans for non-attendants with vocational training is two years;


for vocationally trained dropouts, four years; and for vocationally trainedgraduates, 11 years (Odinet, 2019).


      Literature Review: Career Satisfaction


      How fulfilling are careers based on low IQ majors in comparison with


careers based on vocational training? There is very little literature, and very


few statistics, bearing directly on this question. There is considerable


literature and statistical data indirectly bearing on it.


      First of all, there is literature, as well as statistical data, concerning


levels of career satisfaction among probation and parole officers, social


workers, and the other careers that graduates with low IQ majors tend to end


up with.


      This body of literature is sparse and internally contradictory, with


some authors saying that career-satisfaction is very low and others saying that


it is moderately high, with each school of thought having its own statistics.


No definitive conclusions can be drawn from it.


      The higher the average SAT scores at a given college, the lower its


dropout rate and the higher the earnings of its graduates. Harvard’s average


board scores are in the top 1%; its dropout rate is less than 1%; and annual


graduate earnings are in the top 1%. The average SAT scores at Fort Valley

                        th
State are below the 45 percentile for the nation; the dropout rate is over

                                                            th
70%; and annual graduate earnings are below the 45 percentile. Within these


two extremes, dropout rates and graduate-earnings are strictly orderedaccording to average student test-score.


      Also, the higher the average test-scores at a given college, the smaller


the percentage of students who earn degrees in low IQ majors. In fact, some


high IQ majors, notably philosophy, are not even offered at the lower-end


schools; and many low IQ majors are not offered at higher-end schools.


              When surveyed, dropouts seldom cite difficulty with coursework


as their reason for dropping out. They are more likely to cite financial


difficulties, trouble balancing schoolwork with family and personal


relationships, homesickness, and inability to focus (Daley, 2010; McDermott


et al., 2019). 


      The statistics tell a different story. Less than one percent of students

                            th
with test scores in the 85 percentile and above drop out; more than 95

                                                  th
percent of students with test scores in the 40 percentile and below drop out.


Students in the first category take on 250% debt for every year spent in


college than do students in the second category, but 80% of students in the


first category pay back their student loans within 10 years, whereas only 20%


of students in the second category do so (Webber, 2016).  A student’s


dropout-likelihood is therefore a function not of the size of his financial


obligations but of his eventual ability to meet those obligations, and it is


therefore a function of the financial benefit to him of a college degree. The


greater than benefit, the lower the dropout-likelihood.          Summary


      The people who stand to lose money by dropping out almost never do,

                                                                                  th
the dropout rate being next to zero for those with test-scores above 85


percentile, these being the people who benefit the most from a college degree.


For people in this category, the financial benefits of a college degree are


unambiguous.


      For those who do drop out, those benefits are ambiguous. The lower a


person’s IQ, the more likely he is to drop out of college, and the greater are


the financial benefits to him of vocational work.


      This is not to say that those who drop out are always making the right


choice. In many cases, they are not. Although unemployment among


vocationally trained non-graduates is lower than that of college graduates,


unemployment among non-graduates, on the whole, is more than twice as


high. For those in the middle of the bell curve, the situation is objectively


ambiguous: they stand to gain as much by staying in college as they do by


opting for a vocational career. That said, the more economically rational it is


for a given person to drop out, the more likely he is to do so. Dropout-


likelihood tracks dropout-rationality. 
                            F


      What is not clear is whether dropout-likelihood tracks dropout-
                                                                                E


rationality. This is not easily deduced from information about the financial


implications of dropping out. It is in principle deducible from other objectivedata, such as suicide rates, rates of drug abuse, and the like. But, firstly,


supposing that low-IQ college graduates had the same rates of suicide, drug


use, etc. as vocationally trained IQ-comparables, it wouldn't necessarily


follow that they were equally satisfied with their careers. Second, the relevant


data simply isn't available. For these reasons, we will ascertain relative


degrees of career satisfaction through the use of surveys.


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


                                   Chapter 3 Methodology


      Introduction


      The purpose of this quantitative-correlational study was to determine


the causes of dropoutism. This involved finding a principled way of


determining the financial and emotional prospects for those dropping out, the


reason being people considering dropping out likely make their decision on


the basis of at least some kind of awareness of the advantages and


disadvantages of doing so. When scrutinized, the statistical data clearly


indicates that dropout-likelihood is a direct function of dropout-rationality.
                                                                          F


      This finding is at odds with the vast majority of scholarly and non-


scholarly literature on the matter, the premise of which is that dropping out is


a form of failure is therefore a consequence of intellectual, emotional, or


financial deficits of some kind (Xiao et al., 2017; Welton et al., 2015;


Vasquez et al., 2015; Lavine et al., 1029; Swidey, 2016; Rivera-McCutchen,


2016). A strikingly high percentage of scholarly articles on this matter


attribute dropoutism to mental illness (Bishop, 2016), even though the actual


data is totally inconsistent with this (Kosyluk et al., 2016). In fact, those who


are behaving the most rationally are those who are either maximally likely to


drop out or maximally likely not to do so, since in those cases the financial


consequences of dropping out are unambiguous; and people at those extremes


categorically make the rational decision. The more remote a given student isfrom those extremes, the less the consequences of dropping out differ from


those of not doing so and, consequently, the less obviously rational that


person’s decision must necessarily be.


        Researchers and journalists tend to focus on the middle-of-the-road


cases and are quick to pounce on even the feeblest indication of pathology on


the student’s part. They blame it on depression (Ho et al., 2016), alcoholism


(Kiciman et al., 2018), general lack of self-restraint (Nevarez, 2017), and the

 
like, even though there is literally no indication that these mid-range


dropouts are more depressed or debauched than those who don’t drop out.


        Researchers and journalists are quick to seize upon ‘findings’ on the


part of university psychologist to the effect that 40% of college students are


“binge drinkers” and that upwards of a third of college students are “seriously


depressed” (Sharma et al., 2018). What isn’t reported is that if these figures


were correct, then universities would have rates of depression comparable to


those of most Federal prisons and alcoholism rates higher than among those


who end up there (Holliday et al., 2016).  Most importantly, if such a higher


percentage of students are mentally ill drug addicts, the first question to ask


is whether universities are the right place for them. Finally, we have found


that college students are strikingly sane, at least when it comes to deciding


whether or not to drop out. Also striking is that those at the lower end of the


IQ spectrum are quite as rational in this regard as those at the upper end.      Prior research has not correctly explained why students drop out or


whether they are behaving in a financially rational manner in doing so. Nor,


therefore, has it been explained whether they are behaving in an emotionally


rational manner. In the pages to come, we will address this issue.        Statement of the Problem


      Prior to this study, it was not known to what extent people who drop


out of college are in doing so behaving in either a financially or emotionally


rational manner. We have found that they are behaving in a financially


rational manner. This suggests that they are also behaving in an emotionally


rational manner. In the pages to come, we will determine whether or not this


is in fact the case.


      Enormous resources are expended trying to prevent people from


dropping out of college. Given that students tend to be serving their own


financial interests by dropping out, those resources should be invested in


college-alternative educational and professional tracks, so as to maximize the


pay-off for them of leaving college, instead of being used, as they are now, to


delegitimate their doing so. Should it turn out that students who choose


vocational training over college higher degrees of career satisfaction than IQ-


comparable college graduates, then there is that much more reason to


reallocate resources in this way.      Research Questions and Hypotheses


      Our objective in this study is to answer the following question:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college behaving


rationally in doing so?


      There are two versions of RQ1, namely:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college being
            F


financially rational in doing so? In other words, to what extent does their


doing so lead to increased earnings?


      And:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college being
            E


emotionally rational in doing so? In other words, to what extent does their


doing so lead to increased career-satisfaction?


      We have already answered RQ1. the answer being:
                                            F


      HQ1: On balance, those who drop out of college are to a statistically
            F


significant degree improving their levels of career satisfaction.


      Now must now answer RQ1. There are three answers to this question:
                                        E


      HQ1: Those who drop out of college are thereby doing more to
            ER


increase their level of career-satisfaction than to diminish it.


      HQ1: On balance, those who drop out of college are not thereby
            EN


appreciably increasing or diminishing their levels of career-satisfaction.      HQ1:  Those who drop out of college are thereby doing more to
            EI


diminish their level of career-satisfaction than to increase it.


      For reasons already discussed, we will answer this question on the


basis of data generated by surveys that we administer. Whenever we


administer a survey to a given group, we must also administer it to the


appropriate complement-group. For example, if we were interested in levels


of emotional satisfaction among people who drink tomato juice, we would


want to survey consumers of tomato-juice as well as non-consumers. In the


context of this study, there are several pairs of complement-groups.


      Given that we are comparing dropouts to graduates, we must


administer surveys to members of both groups and compare the results.


      Given that a person’s dropout-likelihood is inversely proportional his


IQ, the most important comparison to make is between low IQ dropouts and


low IQ graduates, and we must administer surveys to both populations and


compare the results.


      Given that dropouts with vocational training considerably out-earn


dropouts without vocational training, and also out-earn IQ-comparable


graduates without vocational training, we must administer surveys to


dropout-vocationals and dropout-non-vocationals and compare the results.


      Given that low IQ graduates often receive vocational training and then


have careers based on that training, we must administer surveys to membersof that group and compare the results with those from surveys administered


to low IQ non-graduate vocationals.


      The groups just mentioned are those on whose members a college


degree confers relatively little benefit. In order to understand the results of


the just-mentioned surveys, we must also administer surveys to high IQ


college graduate and then compare the results with those of the above-


mentioned surveys. We will also want to administer surveys to high IQ non-


graduates. The results will directly help us understand how people with high


IQ’s benefit from college, and it may shed indirect light on the benefits, or


lack thereof, to other populations.


      The relevant independent variables are therefore (i) IQ, (ii) graduate or


non-graduation, and (iii) vocationally trained or not.  The independent


variable in this case is degree of career-satisfaction.


      The researcher had no choice but to construct his own questionnaire,


owing to the fact that no existing questionnaire sufficed for the purposes of


this investigation. There exist many time-tested questionnaires that measure


satisfaction with one's job, i.e. with one’s current position. But one’s level of


satisfaction with one’s career is often very different from one’s level of


satisfaction with one’s career. (A given physician can love being a physician


but hate his current position.) Nor were any of the many existing life-


satisfaction questionnaires usable, since career-satisfaction and life-satisfaction, though linked, are distinct. (A given person can have love his


career but have relationship or family-difficulties that leave him unfulfilled.)


There exist many questionnaires relating to satisfaction with certain specific


career-paths, but these were obviously too narrow for our purposes. Further,


it was necessary that our questionnaire not assume that the respondent


actually had a career, given that many of the respondents were likely to be


unemployed, intermittently employed, or menially employed. So even if there


did exist reputable career-satisfaction questionnaires, we might not have been


able to use them. Finally, we needed a questionnaire that could be used


effectively with each of the following populations:


      * Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training,


      * Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      * Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      * Low IQ graduates with vocational training,


      * High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      * High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      * High IQ graduates without vocational training


      *High IQ graduates with vocational training


      This fact imposed significant constraints on the structure of the


questionnaire to be used. It had to be intelligible to people who varied widely


in education-level, intelligence, and profession. It also had to elicit relativelyspecific information without leading the respondents towards a given answer.


No existing questionnaire of the appropriate kind satisfied these constraints,


leaving it to the researcher to construct one.


      A professional service was used to administer the survey to people


according to custom variables, College Degree Status, Vocational Training


Status, SAT/ACT-score, and college-major. Therefore, respondents did not


have to answer questions relating to their test-scores or college majors and


only had to answer questions relating to career-satisfaction. All questions


were required.


      The possible to answers to each question were:


        1=Strongly Disagree


        2=Disagree


      3=Slightly Disagree


        4=Neither Agree Nor Disagree


      5=Slightly Agree


      6=Agree


        7=Strongly Agree


      The answers generated seven-point Likert-scale representing career-


satisfaction.


      The minimum sample size was 115 for each of the eight populations


surveyed, with a total of 920.      Figure 23 G*Power Calculations


      For the purposes of our G*Power calculations, we operated on the


assumption that we were generating a parametric two-tailed Pearson’s


correlation. Technically, this is not the case. The variables in our case are,


respectively, (a) membership in one of the eight populations in question and(b) survey-score. Neither of those variables is continuous, the reason being


that, as is the case with any survey-generated correlation, (DiNunno, 2011)


both of the variables range over finite sets of integers. That said, this


inaccuracy is innocuous when computing sample sizes for surveys, provided


that, for computational purposes, the correlation in question is treated as two-


tailed Pearson correlation (Nardi, 2019).


      Surveys will be professionally administered online.The survey-service


estimated the completion rate to be 76%. Consequently, surveys have to be


sent to at least 151 people/target-population, making for a total of 1,208


surveys to be sent, with approximately 850 of them likely to be completed.      Research Methodology


              The methodology used in this study is quantitative. When


determining the economic rationality of dropoutism, we used a relatively


strictly statistical method. We found a numerical variable, namely SAT/ACT


score, this being a proxy for IQ, that statistically correlated to an extremely


high degree (ρ<.02) with graduation-probability. We then looked at future


earnings of both graduates and dropouts. We then correlated IQ with the


financial costs and benefits of a college degree. Benefits vary directly with


IQ, we found, and costs vary indirectly, and they cancel each other out in the


middle range of the IQ spectrum. 


              When determining the emotional rationality of dropoutism, our


methodology was also quantitative. Having correlated dropout-probability


with dropout-rationality, it remained only to see whether dropout-rationality
              FF


correlated with dropout-rationality. Given that dropout-rationality is
                          EF


expressed as a dollar amount and therefore as a single number, it is necessary


that dropout-rationality also be expressed by a single number if it is to be
            E


compared with dropout-rationality. Prior to this study, dropout-rationality
                          FE


had never even been ascertained, let alone expressed as a single figure, and


we ourselves had to figure out (i) how to assign dropout-rationality quotients
                                                                E


to people and (ii) whose dropout-rationality was what.
                                    E              This was readily done. First of all, dropping out is emotionally


rational to the extent that doing so makes one more fulfilled than similar


people who graduated. Given that the benefits of a college degree reliably


correlate with IQ and IQ alone, two people are to be regarded as ‘similar’ just


in case they are IQ-comparable. Therefore, for people of a given intelligence


level, dropout-rationality is hewed to, and may therefore be identified with,
              E


the extent to which they are more fulfilled than IQ-comparable graduates.


      Having thus operationally defined ‘dropout-rationality’, we must find


a way to correlate degrees of career-satisfaction with graduation-status. Given


the veritable absence of career-satisfaction surveys, apart from ones that were


extremely demographic-specific, we have no choice but to construct a survey


of our own, which we will administer, using a professional survey service, to


randomly chosen samples of each of the eight populations in question.


(SAT/ACT-scores served as proxies for IQ.) The results are expected to


enable us to rank the following the groups by average level of wellness and


consequently to rank groups (1), (2), (5) and (6) according to dropout-
                                                                                E


rationality.


      (i)         Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (ii)   High non-graduates without vocational training


      (iii)                       Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (iv)   High IQ non-graduates without vocational training      (v)         Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vi)   High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (vii)                       High IQ graduates with vocational training


      (viii)                 High IQ graduates without vocational training      Research Design


      The methodology used in this phase of the study is both correlational


and non-experimental. The study is correlational because we were


investigating the dependence of one set of variables (personal and financial


fulfillment) on another. An experimental approach is neither possible (given


that the variables, e.g. IQ and educational status, were ones that we could not


alter) nor necessary (given how many people there are who differ in the


relevant respects but are otherwise comparable).


      Eight different groups will be surveyed, and respondents therefore


must be pre-screened for test-scores (this being the best available proxy for


IQ), college degree, and vocational training. Since IQ, college degree, and


vocational training are the independent variables in this study, they must be


screened for. Apart from those variables, sampling must be random, so that


results are in no way predetermined by selection-bias.


      The minimum sample size for each of the seven groups was 115. Since


eight groups were surveyed, the total number surveyed (meaning that they


complete a survey) will be 920. Given the predicted response-rate of 76, the


number of people to whom surveys will have to be given is 1,208.


      The objective of the surveys is to rank populations in terms of career-


satisfaction, where the populations are defined by (i) their average IQ’s, (ii)


their either having or not having college degrees and (ii) their either being ornot being vocationally trained. Our concern is not ‘absolute’ but rather


relative levels of career of satisfaction. Should it turn out that low IQ


graduates without vocational training have moderate degrees of career-


satisfaction, that would not be as meaningful as it would be should it turn out


out that low IQ dropouts with vocational training have high levels of career


satisfaction. 


      Since the survey uses a seven-point Likert scale, survey results for


individuals will  expressed in a single number. Results for populations will be


averaged, and these averages will be used to generate rankings among the


populations surveyed.        Population and Sample Selection


      There are eight targeted populations:


      (1) Low IQ non-graduates without vocational training,


      (2) Low IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (3) Low IQ graduates without vocational training


      (4) Low IQ graduates with vocational training,


      (5) High IQ non-graduates without vocational training


      (6) High IQ non-graduates with vocational training


      (7) High IQ graduates without vocational training


      (8) High IQ graduates with vocational training


      Within the United States, each of these populations is in the millions.


The general statistical rule of thumb is that given a population of over


1,000,000, if n% group of 115 randomly chosen members of that population


has a given characteristics, then n±5% of the population have that


characteristics (Nardi, 2018). For example, given population of 1,000,000, if


115 members of that population are randomly chosen and 75 (65%) of them


like chocolate ice-cream, then 65±10% of the original population like


chocolate ice-cream. In other words, between 60% and 70% of the original


population like chocolate ice-cream.


      But these points only hold when the information that is sought about


the population in question can be given with a simple “yes” or “no” (Beckeret al., 2016). For example, if the question is "do you prefer to chocolate to


vanilla?", then, if 115 randomly chosen members from a population of


1,000,000 are surveyed, there is a 5% error margin. But this error margin may


shrink even if sample-size and population-size are held fixed. It shrinks if the


answers to the survey questions involve rankings (e.g. “Strongly agree,


Agree, Slightly Agree…”) and the answers are bunched around one of the


extremes. Suppose the survey question is “how good a job do you feel


Senator X is doing?”, and 115 people are randomly chosen, with all political


affiliations, economic strata, ethnicities, etc. being evenly represented; and


suppose that the respondent has to answer with a number between 1 and 10


(1=completely bad and 10=perfect). If 98% of the answers are 1’s, or if 99%


are 10’s, then the error margin drops to under 5% (Hopkins et al., 2018).


      Also relevant is the case where a survey is asking for a ranking, as


opposed to a simple ‘yes’ or ‘no’, and, moreover, the survey is attempting to


elicit that information through multiple different versions of the same query.


If answers on individual questionnaires tend to be bunched around one of the


extremes and if, moreover, averages of survey-responses in their turn are


bunched around extremes, then the error-margin is lowered considerably.


Suppose, as before, that we are trying to find out how Senator X’s


constituents feel about the job he is doing, except that this time, instead of


just asking “is he doing a good job?”, we ask a number of different versionsof this question, e.g. “has your financial situation improved since X took


office?”, “has the quality of tap water improved?”, “is your neighborhood


more safe?”, etc., with the possible answers, as before, being a ranking of 1


through 10, with 1 being maximally bad and 10 being maximally good.


Under this circumstance, if answers on a given survey tend to be bunched


around one of the extremes and if, moreover, the overwhelming majority of


survey-responses are bunched around the same extreme, then the error-


margin is much lower than ceteris paribus it would otherwise be (Benjamin


et al., 2018).


      Finally, and perhaps most importantly, a 5% error margin may be


more than acceptable in some contexts. Here is an example of such a context.


The objective of a given survey is to establish a ranking of some kind among


different populations. The survey is administered and survey-results are in. It


turns out that, even after taking the error-margin into account, those results


generate unambiguous ranking. Under these circumstances, the error-margin


is of no consequence, even if it is wide in absolute terms. Contrariwise, if the


error-margin has to be extremely narrow to establish the ranking in question,


then the ranking is that much less worth establishing, since its extremes are


that much closer to each other. We have seen how dropout-rationality
                                                                    F


depends on the variables in question; if dropout-rationality depends on them
                                                      E


in a similar way, then wide error-margins can be tolerated.         Instrumentation


              Since there no pre-existing career-satisfaction questionnaires,


we had to come up with our own. That said, we had two sources of support in


the existing literature. First, there is an abundance of cogent literature as to


what constitutes a ‘dream job’, which is a tolerable synonym for ‘ideal


career’ (Li et al., 2016). Second, there were reputable job-satisfaction surveys


with questions that, when answered affirmatively, are consistent with the


respondent’s having a position that he regards as being a career and a


fulfilling one at that (Khamisa et al., 2015).


              The best and most research suggests that a ‘dream job’ for a


given person is one that satisfies three conditions: The job-holder is good at


it; it is work that he regards as benefiting the world; conditions are supportive


and conduce to a ‘state of flow’, including reasonable pay, schedule that fits


one’s lifestyle, non-antagonistic co-workers, and the like.


      Importantly, although reasonable pay is necessary for a dream job,


satisfaction-returns on pay over and above that amount quickly diminish


(Türkoglu et al., 2017; Deeba et al., 2015). This entails that compensation is


not what makes a job reasonable: if the person likes the job, he will do it for a


reasonable amount; and he doesn’t like it, no amount of money will make it


fulfilling for him, even though enough money induce to keep doing it.


Another interesting fact is that a job's being a dream-job doesn't depend on itsnot being stressful. If X is John's dream job, it will continue to be his dream


job even it becomes increasingly stressful, provided the stress-levels are not


incapacitating; and if X is not John's dream job, decreasing job-related stress,


even to the point of non-existence, won't turn X into a dream job.  


              In terms of questionnaire-design, the basic desiderata for


psychometric tests, such as this one, are as follows (Sijtsma et al., 2017;


Nardi, 2018). 


        Questions must be clear. “Are you paid enough?” is clear. “Would it


not necessarily be so bad if you were better remunerated than you currently


are?” is not clear.


        Questions must not be tendentiously phrased. “Do you find your work


engaging?” is non-tendentiously and non-judgmentally phrased. “Does your


work, despite its menial and insignificant character, manage to interest you?”


is tendentiously and judgmentally phrased.


        Questions should not be vague or overly theoretical. “Are your clients


happy with your work?” is non-vague. “In the long-term, does the economy


benefit from your work?” is vague and overly theoretical.


        Questions should not be circuitous. The respondent should not feel


that games are being played. “Do you get along with your boss” is direct. “If


your boss became a spokesperson for a fast-food chain, would that make you


want to stop eating there?” is circuitous and manipulative.      Also, the questionnaire should not be too long. Otherwise, response


rates will decline and answer-quality will deteriorate in those who complete


the questionnaire.


      Finally, when information about the respondent’s attitudes is being


sought, it is necessary to ask questions relating to different ways in which


that attitude might actually guide his thought and behavior. Simply asking


“do you like your career?” will not elicit fine-grained information about the


respondent’s attitude towards his career and may even elicit a defensive


response. Fine-grained and sincere responses are more likely to be elicited by


questions such as the following:


      “Do you regard difficult assignments as inconveniences or as


challenges?”


      “Do you find yourself thinking about how to improve your


professional skills even when you are not on the job?”


      “Do you tend to throw yourself into your work when you have


personal problems?”


      “Do you work even when don’t have to?”


              The researcher constructed a test satisfying these desiderata.


Also, the test is sufficiently similar to proven and reputable job-satisfaction


questionnaires as to minimize the risk of its failing of its purpose, while also,


unlike existing questionnaires, eliciting information specific to therespondent’s level of career-satisfaction (as opposed to job-satisfaction).         Validity


      Validity is being ensured in the following ways.


      First, a reputable professional survey-service has already been retained


to administer the survey to the eight demographics in question. This service


provides automated, reliable analytics and always complies with legal and


professional protocols.


      Second, questions are clearly and modeled on those of reputable


questionnaires, within the limits set by the differences in subject-matter.


Also, the survey company has a grading system whereby survey-efficacy is


assessed before the survey is administered; and this surveyed a score of


100%.


      Third, questions will initially administered to small samples, and then


scaled up when results from initial surveys show that error margins were


unlikely to vitiate results. Tight, demographically-driven clusterings of


responses diminish error-margins and warrant upscaling; and the absence of


such clusterings warrant changing the survey, so as to increase confidence-


intervals, before re-administering.


      Finally, we only need error-margins to be as narrow as was consistent


with their establishing unambiguous rankings. The fact that one of the


variables is discontinuous made any other standard of precision irrelevant.


Therefore, once initial surveys established that error-margins are narrowenough to yield an unambiguous ranking, we will be free to administer the


survey to a large population.        Reliability


      The survey consists of 20 questions. Four of the questions are


concerned with the respondent’s perception of his own abilities at his work.


Four are concerned with his feelings as to his level of enthusiasm for his


work. Four concern his beliefs as to how much good for the world he believes


himself to do. Four concern his beliefs as to whether he is adequately


compensated. Four concern his beliefs as to whether his clients, co-workers,


and supervisors adequately appreciate his work. No two questions within any


given one of these five question-groups are identical, but answers to


questions within a given group should elicit similar responses. Consequently,


consistency of responses within groups indicates a high-degree of reliability


and validity, and low consistency indicates low degree of reliability and


validity.


      The survey-company software approved the survey for clarity and ease


of use and probable high (76%) completion of rate. At the researcher’s


request (and expense), a manual review of the questions was conducted, in


light of information concerning the nature of the research being conducted.


No changes were recommended.      Data Collection and Management


      The survey-service will prescreen for the relevant variables (test-score,


college graduation, vocationally trained). Respondents will not be


prescreened for income, since surveys must be distributed randomly within


each population group. Potential respondents will be sent an email with a link


to the survey.


      The email contains a description of the survey, the number of


questions, and the nature of those questions. It is stated that the questions


were multiple choice. It is also stated that no information would ever be


publicized concerning an individual respondent’s answers. It is made clear


that the survey had no relation to their work or any aspect of their life and


that their responses, or decision not to do or to complete the survey, will have


no effect on any aspect of their lives. It is also stated that survey results


would be kept for a minimum of three years. The purpose of the survey is


also stated, along with the disclaimer that this is research being conducted by


a doctoral candidate and is not an official government action of any kind. The


identity of the researcher is not disclosed, nor is any other identifying


information.


      No ‘frill material’ is included. Itis not said that responses would


‘enrich scholarship’ or anything of the sort. It is not suggested or stated that


negative consequences will follow from non-responses or certain kinds ofresponses or that good consequences will follow from completed surveys or


from certain kinds of responses. The tone is neutral and no imagery or


suggestive fonts, italicizations, capitalizations, colorings, or other


iconographies are used.


      If email recipients click on the link, they are taken to page where this


information is repeated and where they are presented with two boxes: I


CONSENT and I DO NOT CONSENT. If they click on the first box, they are


taken to the survey proper.      Data Analysis Procedures


      Our research question is:


      RQ1: To what extent are those who drop out of college being
            E


emotionally rational in doing so? In other words, to what extent does their


doing so lead to increased career-satisfaction?


      In order to answer RQ1, we first had to answer:


      RQ2: Who drops out of college? In other words, what characteristics


are dispositive of a person’s dropping out of college? (Is it poverty, mental


illness, physical illness, unstable home life, low IQ, etc.?)


      We found the answer to be:


      HQ2: The higher a given person’s IQ, the less likely he is to drop out


of college.


      In the course of generating HQ2, we discovered that:


      HQ1: The higher a given person’s IQ, the less financially rational it is
            F


for him to drop out of college.


      This established the following earnings-ranking (from bottom to top):


      (1)         Low IQ, non-vocationally trained non-graduates


      (2)         High IQ non-vocationally trained non-graduates


      (3)         Low IQ, non-vocationally trained graduates


      (4)         Low IQ vocationally trained graduates


      (5)         Low IQ vocationally trained non-graduates      (6)         High IQ vocationally trained non-graduates


      (7)         High IQ vocationally trained graduates


      (8)         High IQ non-vocationally trained graduates


      The need to discover whether career-satisfaction generated a similar


hierarchy governed our data-analysis procedures. Questionnaires pre-screen


for the dependence variables (test-scores, graduation-status, vocational-


status). The survey-software will be set to do the following:


      (i)         Provide data for each respondent


      (ii)   Find average value for each question for each target-population


      (iii)                       Average these averages by population, as to generate an


overall career-satisfaction score for each population.


      We are operating on the assumption that answers are up to 10%


inaccurate, even though that actual error-margin is less than 5%.       Ethical Considerations


      We will administer surveys by way of a reputable company that will


not spam anyone, invade their privacy, offer incentives, or otherwise violate


the rights of respondents or skew responses. The questions are phrased in


such a way that respondents will know that their responses, whatsoever they


might be, are genuinely valued.        Limitations and Delimitations


      The results generated will not have validity across any society at all


times or across all societies at a given time. This study is not intended to


establish universally applicable sociological principles. It would be important


to know how existing economic conditions and government policies affected


the realities discussed in this study.


      Another limitation is that this study does not examine the internal


structure of any of the populations involved. For example, the population of


high IQ non-vocationally trained college graduates is internally stratified,


with some of its member loving their careers and others hating them, and it


would be worth how it was stratified and why. The same is true of each of the


sub-populations.


      Finally, it would be worth seeing if the results we obtain, whatever


they might be, hold up when larger populations are concerned.        Summary


      In the first two chapters, we discovered extremely tight connections


between IQ and both dropout-rate and dropout-rationality. With those in the


upper IQ range, a college degree was more significant than vocational


training. With those in all IQ ranges, dropout-behavior tracked dropout-


rationality. It is unambiguously rational for those in the very low IQ range to


drop out and that is they do. It is unambiguously rational for people in the


upper IQ range to graduate from college, and that what they do. It is


ambiguously rational for those in the lower-medium range to drop out, and


that is what half of them do.


      Given this information, the question to ask is whether the degree to


which is emotionally rational to drop out, in the sense of being conducive to


career-satisfaction, tracks the degree to which it is financially rationally to do


so. We figured out how to answer this question. Having already discovered


that IQ, college-graduation status, and vocational status generated an earnings


hierarchy, we simply had to find out whether they also generated a career-


satisfaction hierarchy. 


      Because there did not exist any statistics that explicitly or implicitly


answered this question, we have to generate those statistics ourselves.


Because there do not exist any questionnaires that we could use, we had to


design our own questionnaire; and we did so, taking care to model it, asclosely as its distinctive subject-matter allowed, on existing questionnaires.


Because we designed our own questionnaire, we had to make sure that it


covered the relevant variables, and we also had to see to it that it generated


credible information. This was labor intensive but well worth it.
