      Brice, M. (2016). Seven Surprising Health Benefits of Coffee. Medical


Daily. Discusses recent research that proves caffeine to have a number of


important health benefits, including longer life, low likelihood of contracting


Alzheimer’s, and improved long-term memory.


      Meeusen, R., & Decroix, L. (2018). Nutritional supplements and the


brain. International journal of sport nutrition and exercise metabolism, 28(2),


200-211. A survey of numerous recent studies concerning the effect of


caffeine on the bloodstream’s ability to transport oxygen and on the


consequent long- and short-term health-effects of caffeine.


      Spiller, G. A. (2019). Caffeine. CRC Press. A comprehensive, non-


partisan analysis of recent scientific work concerning the health-effects of


caffeine, as well as the economics of the coffee- and tea-industries. Special


attention is paid to recent findings concerning the probable link between


increased neural plasticity and elevated levels of caffeine intake.


        Turnbull, D., Rodricks, J. V., Mariano, G. F., & Chowdhury, F.


(2017). Caffeine and cardiovascular health. Regulatory Toxicology and


Pharmacology, 89, 165-185. Describes a series of studies in which the effects


of caffeine on cardiovascular health were shown to be positive and,


consequently, not to be similar to those of other agents, such as sodium andnicotine, that increase heartrate and blood-pressure.


      Winerdal, M., Urmaliya, V., Winerdal, M. E., Fredholm, B. B.,


Winqvist, O., & Ådén, U. (2017). Single dose caffeine protects the neonatal


mouse brain against hypoxia ischemia. PloS one, 12(1), e0170545. A detailed


discussion of striking findings on the part of researchers concerning the use


of caffeine to minimize hypoxia-induced brain-damage in neonatal mice.


        Yousefi‐Nooraie, R., Akbari‐Kamrani, M., & Mortaz‐Hedjri, S.


(2018). Caffeine for cognition. The Cochrane database of systematic


reviews, 2018(8). A discussion of recent studies concerning the alleged


neuro-protective properties of caffeine. Provides clear, quantitative data to


the effect that caffeine improves performance on standardized tests. 


                            Who started the Cold War?


 


              The Soviet Union’s political ideology was inherently aggressive


and expansionistic, and that—and that alone—is why the Cold War


happened. It is obviously more politically correct to take the view that both of


the two major parties involved in the Cold War were equally responsible for


its genesis. But that isn’t at all true, for reasons to be discussed. Nor is it true


that, once the Cold War had begun, the situation was morally symmetrical,


with both parties behaving equally morally and equally immorally. The


situation was fundamentally asymmetrical. This was because communism—


especially, the particularly invidious form of it on which the USSR was based


—was not simply one political system among others. Bolshevik communism


was not intended to bring peace or prosperity either to the Russian people or


to the rest of the world; and the founders of the Soviet Union had every


intention of bringing about a war, or some kind or other, with the ‘decadent


West’, especially the United States.


      “It is better than half the world perish and the other half be


communist”, said Lenin, founder the Soviet Union, “than the entire human


race live and communism perish.” Before World War II, the Soviet


Leadership, headed by Joseph Stalin, had already deliberately starved onethird of the Ukrainian population to death, as a way of breaking Ukrainian


resistance to Soviet rule. In additions, millions of people in all of the Soviet


Republics had been shot, imprisoned in the Gulag, or forced to relocate en


masse. Freedom of speech was non-existent; private property was equally


non-existent; living conditions were wretched; there were virtually no


personal, religious, or commercial freedoms of any kind. Although some


people obviously had more power than others, nobody had any legal rights of


any kind. Stalinist Russia was the purest example in human history of a state


that was inimical to its own people.


      In popular culture, we are often told that Stalin corrupted the


revolution. “The revolution began with noble ideals”, we are told. “Trotsky


and Lenin wanted to create a just and egalitarian social order, but Stalin


seized power and derailed the Revolution.” Lenin and Trotsky had


deliberately created a hyper-authoritarian state, and they used it to break the


Russian the middle class, as well as most of the rest of Russian society.


Lenin’s great ‘theoretical innovation’ as a Marxist was his belief that that, in


order for a Marxist state to be created, it was necessary that a ‘revolutionary


vanguard’, operating without any other party’s consent, autonomously take


power and, once in power, forcibly impose communism on society. As for


Trotsky, his great “innovation” as a Marxist was his belief in “permanent


revolution” in all countries. In Trotsky’s view, the rightful objective of aMarxist “revolutionary vanguard” was to impose Marxist communism on all


nations, not just on this or that specific nation.


      Lenin and Trotsky were in complete agreement on all of these points.


In fact, their only significant points of disagreement concerned matters that


were internal to Marxist theory and proved to be of no significance. For


example, Trotsky, unlike Lenin and Marx, held that labor unions were not


inimical to the long-term interests of the ‘proletariat.’ But since there were no


labor unions in Russia, this disagreement was not important. Also, Lenin and


Trotsky made it their objective to strip all Russians, including peasants, of all


of their assets and to kill those who resisted. They rationalized this by saying


that anyone who had any assets and did not immediately relinquish them was


for that very reason a ‘kulak’ (meaning an exploitative landowner,


comparable to a feudal lord) who, as such, had to be ‘exterminated.’ During


World War 1, when the Red Cross entered Russia to provide food and


medicine to the sick and malnourished Russian peasants, Lenin and Trotsky


organized troops to drive them out of Russia, which they succeeded in doing


and which they rationalized by saying that the Russian peasantry had to


suffer as much as possible so that they would come to hate the Tsarist order


and join them in overthrowing it. 


      Stalin did indeed seize power; but he was only able to do so because


the Communist Party had total power and he belonged to it. The CommunistParty had total power because Lenin and Trotsky fought for decades to give it


total power. Stalin and Trotsky were indeed foes, but not because they had


important ideological disagreements. Quite the contrary, they were in perfect


agreement as to what kind of government Russia was to have, their only


disagreement concerning who was to be in charge of it.


      Stalin exiled Trotsky in 1928; and by the start of WWII, Stalin had


long since had total power. Stalin used World War II to expand his power


base to other countries, his first move in this direction being to absorb all of


Eastern Europe into the Soviet Union. It is generally believed that this was


the beginning of the Cold War. Not so. Before the Soviet Union had even


been established, Lenin and Trotsky had agitated for Communist revolution


in the United States and Britain and had already established a network of


‘fellow travelers.’ After WWII ended, the Soviet Union had real power; and


Stalin, and the many others who wanted to spread the gospel of Marxist


communism, had soviet military power behind them and therefore no longer


had to rely solely on agitation and other such grass-roots measures. But the


so-called ‘Cold War’ was merely a militarized continuation of a campaign to


take control of the West that had been occurring since the first decade of the

th
20 century. This led to the wholesale Marxist takeover of China, North


Korea, Cuba, and Cambodia.


      The United States’ role in the Cold War was entirely defensive, inevery sense. To be sure, it made many terrible mistakes. It fought


communism where it wasn’t a significant threat (e.g. Vietnam, Angola) and


didn’t fight it where it was a significant threat (e.g. Eastern Europe, right after


the end of WWII). But the Soviet Union was the aggressor. Also, the Soviet


Union’s economy was completely broken; so even though its post-Stalinist


leaders lacked the Marxist ardor of their predecessors, they had no choice but


to expand, since their economy wasn’t self-sufficient. (When the Soviet


Union fell in 1989, it was because it simply ran out of money.) The United


States had a booming economy during the Cold War—and before it, except


during the early 1930s—and stood to gain little, from its wars-by-proxy with


the Soviet Union. It did not gain resources or land or trading partners; and it


also lost good will and credibility, with its own citizens and with the rest of


the world. But the Soviet Union had everything to gain from its engagements


abroad; and those engagements where what kept it economically afloat


during its short existence.


      In conclusion, the Cold War was a war of Soviet aggression, fueled by


a commitment to aggressive expansionism that was built into its very system


by its founders and catalyzed by its desperate need for resources. For the


United States, the Cold War was a losing proposition; the United States did


not profit from its engagements in Vietnam or Korea or Cuba or Guyana or


Angola. Moreover, those engagements were public relations disasters. Theonly reason the United States undertook them is that it was trying to keep


Soviet aggression in check. 


                 Who was a better President? Eisenhower or JFK?


 


        Ultimately, Eisenhower was a better president than JFK. This is not


because JFK failed to accomplish anything during his presidency: he


accomplished a great deal; and his list of presidential accomplishments is


longer and more illustrious than Eisenhower’s list. It isn’t because he did too


little that JFK was less of a President than Eisenhower, but rather because he


did too much. The American people take it for granted that their President is


supposed to solve their problems. This is largely JFK’s doing: thanks to him,


government is now expected to be, for lack of a better term, a ‘big brother’—


a righter of wrongs, as opposed to a neutral administrator, with the result that


government is now so large that nobody’s rights are secure. Eisenhower’s


presidency, by contrast, was emotionally neutral and, unlike JFK’s, did not


pave the way for the situation we have now, in which the government is


omnipresent.


      Let us start by listing Eisenhower’s main presidential

                  [120]
accomplishments:


      *He balanced the budget.


      *He created the highway system.


      *He kept America out of war.


      *He ended the Korean war and did so on terms that were at leastreasonably consistent with American interests.


      *He signed the first Civil Rights Acts into law.


 


      Now let us state his main presidential failures (or what are taken to be

    [121]
such):


 


      *He failed to end the Cold War.


      *He failed to help the American farmer.


        *Economic growth, though steady, was slow.


      *He did not combat the hard-right, McCarthyite wing of the


Republican Party.


      *He did not promote Civil Rights sufficiently aggressively.


 


      Notice that Eisenhower’s supposed ‘failures’ as a President were


really about his not taking an interventionist, moralizing role in American


affairs. When we say that Eisenhower ‘should’ have done more to combat


McCarthyism, what is the justification? McCarthy had a position; other


people had different positions. It may have been Eisenhower’s responsibility


to curb criminal misconduct on McCarthy’s part, but it was not his


responsibility to extirpate all support for McCarthy’s political views. So this


‘failure’ of Eisenhower’s was a failure only relative to an activist,Kennedyesque conception of government.


      Now let us look at Kennedy’s presidential achievements and failings,

                                              [122]
starting with his (alleged) achievements:


 


      *He averted nuclear war.


      *He founded the peace corp.


      *He encouraged public service on the part of Americans.


      *He helped usher in affirmative action, equal pay, and civil rights.


      *He started the US space program.


      *He gave a temporary boost to the economy. 


 


      Now let us look at his failures:


 


      *He gave arms to many (then) US allies, many of which are now


dangerous actors.


      *He deepened our involvement in Viet Nam.


      *He failed to remove Castro from power, emboldening the Soviets to


threaten us with Nuclear war.


 


      JFK’s achievements are impressive—but dubious. The theme we see


running through his presidency is that it is the President’s job to be a hero: arighter of wrongs, as opposed to a mere administrator---which sometimes has


positive effects (e.g. civil rights), sometimes has negative ones (e.g. Viet


Nam), and sometimes has ambiguous effects (e.g. expansion of money supply


and credit, leading to temporary economic spike), but has led to over-


expansions of government in both domestic and foreign policy.


      Sadly, unless there is an actual crisis, it is the government’s job to


govern—not to inspire, not to create a utopia, not even to eliminate all


injustices. Eisenhower’s Presidency was a blank compare to Kennedy’s, his


main accomplishment being the construction of the national highway system.


Kennedy’s system was certainly not a blank, and he was obviously in many


respects a singularly good president; but his legacy was that Presidents are


supposed to be heroes, not mere civil servants, which has caused politics to


become much more ideological and divisive than it has to be and which,


consequently, has impaired the effectiveness of government.


                   Who was a better President? Nixon or LBJ?


 


        Richard Nixon is now made out to be a bigoted right-wing extremist,


and LBJ is made out to be the exact opposite, the conventional wisdom that


Richard Nixon was an oppressor and LBJ a champion of the oppressed. But


this position is not consistent with their actual political legacies. Under LBJ,


and to a large extent because of him, the United States government engaged


in aggressive campaigns to improve education and to fight poverty,


unemployment, and racial discrimination. But the aftermath of these


measures is increased unemployment among African Americans, a


dysfunctional educational system for everybody, and a bloated and hyper-


authoritarian Federal government. Richard Nixon, by contrast, did have at


least some unambiguous successes as President and must therefore be


regarded as better President than LBJ.


      Let us start by listing what many would regard as LBJ’s greatest


accomplishments:


 


      *He created the welfare system, with its general financial provisions


for those in dire economic straits.


      *He signed into law measures that aggressively racism towards ethnic


minorities illegal in all but the most completely personal contexts.      *He increased Federal funding, as well as oversight, of education by a


factor of ten.


 


      LBJ’s greatest mistake as President is generally believed to be his


decision to deep American involvement in Viet Nam.


 


      What about Richard Nixon? What were his greatest accomplishments


as President?


 


        *Nixon founded the EPA.


      *Nixon officially recognized Communist China, which, by his


      intention, hastened the demise of the Soviet Union.


        *Nixon ended the Viet Nam war


 


              What were Nixon’s greatest mistakes?


 


      *He used the instruments of government to cover up a crime that he


committed.


      *He deepened American involvement in Viet Nam before ending the


war.


      *He started the War on Drugs.      *He took America off the gold standard.


 


      With regard to the last item, I do not myself know that this was a


mistake; but it is sufficiently often mentioned that I felt obliged to include it.


As for the War on Drugs, for various reasons (the main being that penalizes


lifestyles, as opposed to crimes, and therefore turns the police into thought


police), I believe this to be one of the worst mistakes ever made in the history


of public policy, and it is, in my judgment, the blackest spot on Nixon’s


legacy.


      Given only what we’ve said thus far, LBJ appears to be the obvious


front-runner. But not so fast! LBJ’s ‘War on Poverty’ created more poverty,


especially among the very groups that it was intended to help. Prior to LBJ’s


great reforms,


 


        *Unemployment among African Americans was lower than it is.


      *African Americans were considerably more likely to own their


      businesses than they are now


        *African Americans were more likely to be employed as engineers


and to have trades.


      *Crime among African Americans was lower, as were incarceration


rates.      *Income-gaps between Caucasians and African Americans were


      smaller, as were education-gaps.


      *Public education was better and less expensive.


      *The Federal government was smaller.


      *The cost of living was lower.


      *Rates of depression and mental illness were lower.


      *Rates of homeownership, including among African Americans, were


higher.


        *Levels of well-being, including among African Americans, were


higher.


 


      In a word, each of LBJ’s signature policies, though admirable in


intent, seriously backfired. Also, LBJ’s decisions concerning Viet Nam cost


lives on both sides, while failing to advance American interests.


      By contrast, Nixon’s good deeds as Presidents have stood the test of


time. By recognizing China, Nixon created infighting within the Communist


bloc and thereby paved the way for the demise of Soviet Communism. AS for


the EPA, it does water it is supposed to do: it protects the environment,


including wildlife, and helps keep water clean and water drinkable. As for


Nixon’s behavior vis-à-vis Vietnam, this, like many other aspects of his


presidency, was ambiguous. But he did end the war, despite being underpressure from his own base to continue it; and that is more than can be said


for Johnson.


      In conclusion, LBJ clearly meant well, but his policies to a large


extent did the opposite of what they were supposed to do. According to


economists, this is because those policies replaced the invisible hand of


supply-and-demand with the dead hand of government policy, leading to a


weakened economy and a consequent loss of wealth across the board,


especially for those on the bottom economic rung. I suspect that there is more


to the story. I personally do not believe that welfare is particularly


destructive, economically or otherwise, and I don’t believe LBJ was wrong to


implement generous welfare policies. But his expansion of government was


too fast and too large, its aftermath being a government that is too large and


is too involved in people’s lives.


 


     Technology-caused Job-shortages and the Need for Universal Welfare


 


How, if at all, will artificial jobs affect employment in the future? Are you an


optimist on this score, or a pessimist?


 


 


        Artificial intelligence eliminates several jobs for each job that it


creates. This is what has been happening since AI’s very inception, and this is


what will continue to happen. Some people claim that AI creates as many


jobs as it eliminates. This is false, and it is the purpose of this essay to prove


that it is false. I will start by showing that it is inherent in what technology is


that technological advancement decreases the amount of work that there is for


people to do. I will then explain why this is doubly true of AI. I will end by


discussing how government should deal with the job-shortage that AI  will


inevitably lead to.


      Technology reduces the need to work, and it makes the work that it


doesn’t eliminate less difficult. Thanks to tractors, sewing-machines, and gas-


powered drills, it takes little effort to do in an afternoon what it would take


months of back-breaking labor to do by hand.  What is true of cars, tractors,


and sewing machines is true of AI-based technologies:  thanks to


smartphone-apps and computer-programs, it takes little effort, as well as littletraining, to do in a single afternoon what would otherwise be impossible or


would require months of intense intellectual work on the part of a trained


professional.


      Many people have either lost jobs to technology or fear that they soon


will. Right-wing economists have argued that such people are wrong.


According to such economists, technology creates a job for every job that it


takes away. In their view, technology took jobs away from cobblers, but it


created new jobs for the engineers needed to build and maintain the machines


that made cobblers unnecessary. Similarly, so they argue, AI is taking jobs


away from stockbrokers, but it has created new jobs for the programmers


needed to service the e-platforms that eliminated the need for stockbrokers. In


general, so it is argued, technology needs people to service it and therefore


creates jobs that take the place of those that it eliminates.


      This position is false and always has been. In societies that have little


or no technology, the unemployment rate tends to be zero. There was no


unemployment in Cambodia under Pol Pot; nor was there any in an Eskimo


fishing community in the year 1600. The reason is the same in each case:


where there is no technology, labor is inefficient, and everybody must


therefore work. To be sure, new technology does indeed create new kinds of


work: before there were cars, there were no auto-mechanics; and before there


were smartphones, there were no app-developers. But the purpose oftechnology is to minimize how much work we have to do; it is not to alter the


nature of what we have to do while keeping its quantity the same. If cars,


tractors, and fork-lifts didn’t lighten workloads, we wouldn’t have much use


for them. Consequently, there is no truth whatsoever to the idea that


technological advancement creates as much work as it eliminates.


      Why was such an absurd position ever argued for? The main reason is


that the economists who advocate this position want to minimize the amount


of government-interference in the economy. Their position is that


government regulation restricts commerce and thwarts economic


development: and in most contexts, they are right, since a society cannot


function for long unless its members are allowed to exchange goods and


services. But even if unregulated societies economically outperform regulated


ones, it doesn’t follow that the government should never regulate. Second,


unemployment benefits are not a form of government regulation and don’t


have the same invidious economic effects as regulations. The law that


prevents people from teaching unless they have a master’s degree in


education is a regulation, since it prevents the market from deciding who


works and gives that power to the government. The laws prevent people from


killing and robbing are not regulations, since they don’t do this, and neither,


for the same reason, are the laws that give people welfare benefits. To be


sure, welfare benefits are not economically innocuous, since they have to bepaid for out of people’s taxes; but granting that excessive taxation hurts an


economy, moderate taxation is sometimes a necessity, this being a case in


point.


      Technology has always eliminated jobs; but in times past, the contrary


position, though false, was at least defensible. Pre-AI technology did not run


itself, and its effect was not so much to eliminate employment as it was to


make employment less about physical labor and more about knowing how to


operate labor-saving machines. When the tractor came into existence,


agricultural work became that much less about physical labor and that much


more about knowing how to operate a tractor. But the story is very different


when tractors are replaced by self-operating tractors and when, more


generally, machines are replaced by robots. True—people will still be needed


to maintain those robots, but there will be very few such jobs in relation to


the number of labor jobs lost, and those jobs will also require unusually high


levels of training and intellectual acumen. In general, a slight improvements


in technology creates massive gains in efficiency and a corresponding drop in


the demand for a given person’s labor.


      This is cause for alarm if people are still required to work for food,


lodging, and other necessities, since new technology, especially AI-based


technology, makes most people economically redundant. But it is not a cause


for alarm if people are not forced to work for basic necessities. And thanks tothe surpluses of wealth created by the very technologies that make most


people economically redundant, there is no reason for most people to work.


      The standard response to this is that, unless people are forced to work,


they will become parasites and society will fall apart. But the truth is that


most people right now are parasites: most jobs are not necessary and cost


society more than they are worth. Somebody who receives $20,000 in welfare


is quite harmless. But a redundant police officer or government bureaucrat is


not harmless, since, unlike the welfare recipient, that person has power. This


is not to say that all government employees and police officers are useless.


But there is no way to create jobs for people without giving them at least


some power. Even the lowliest and most unnecessary clerk can jam up


legitimate business—and is likely to do so to make himself feel important.


Creating jobs for unemployable people gives them the ability to prevent


employable people from contributing, and it is therefore best simply to give


them money for basic necessities. Ironically, the belief of right-wing


economists that everyone should have to compete in the arena of commerce,


with its consequent refusal on the part of government to give welfare to


people who simply cannot do so, leads to the creation of vast numbers of jobs


that benefit nobody, including those who have them. I therefore suggest that a


universal welfare policy be instituted. In this I am in agreement with many


distinguished people, including economically informed right-wing figures,such as Richard Nixon, who was one of the first public figures to advocate


such a policy, as well as technology-wise left-wing figures, such as Mark


Zuckerberg.


               Ideas as Networks: Reflecting on Steven Johnson’s


                          “Where Good Ideas Come From”


 


      In his TED Talk “Where Good Ideas Come From”, Steven Johnson

                                                      [123]
outlines a new (or what he believes to be a new) view as to the genesis of


ideas. In his talk, Johnson focused mainly on ideas of significance, such as


Evolutionary Theory (his own example) or psychoanalytic theory; but


assuming that his model is correct, it may well hold of ideas in general. The


traditional view, according to Johnson, is that great ideas represent existential


leaps: the great thinker in question is just ‘sitting there’, as it were, and the


great idea in question ‘happens upon him,’ like a visitation. The stock


example is Newton sitting under a tree, when an apple falls on his head,


whereupon the concept gravity force flashes into his mind.


      Before we even consider what Johnson says, we can already see some


of the holes in this picture. A lot of objects fall on a lot of people’s heads, but


very few of them respond by having scientific insights. This suggests that,


when such an event leads to such a realization, it isn’t so much by creating a


new idea as it is by jolting the thinker in question into finally seeing the


significance of some constellation of ideas that is already at work within him.


When the apple fell on Newton’s head—supposing for argument’s sake that


the story is actually true--it gave him one last tidbit of information, deliveredin the form of a rousing shock, that brought together a previously all-but-


unified network of ideas that he had been working on.


      And this is basically what Johnson says. “We have this very rich


vocabulary for describing moments of inspiration,” writes Johnson (3:17).


“We have the flash of insight, the stroke of insight, we have epiphanies, we


have eureka moments, we have the light-bulb moment.” Embodied in all of


these metaphors, Johnson continues, is the idea that an idea is a self-


contained “single thing,” when in actuality, Johnson says, “an idea is a


network.” 


      Johnson then points out that what we think of as an idea involves


pluralities of neurons firing simultaneously, which, assuming that each neural


firing carries its own quantum of information, suggests that ‘an’ idea is really


a lot of little ideas coming together. (I find this reasoning persuasive, since


the idea that individual neurons bear no information strikes me as a non-


starter.) Having made clear what, speaking anatomically, ideas are, he then


asks: What kinds of environments conduce to idea-creation? When he poses


this question, it is not clear whether Johnson is referring to physical


environments or social environments or both; but his answer suggests that he


is referring to what might be called ‘socio-physical environments’, meaning


environments that are defined both by their physical and their social


properties. Johnson argues that great ideas surface in open spaces wherepeople can move and also talk freely. It is not in cubicles that people come up


with ideas, Johnson says, nor is it in the laboratory. It is in an open space,


such as the cafeteria or the boardroom, where people are not insulated and


where they can be exposed to other people’s thoughts.


      Johnson begins his talk by pointing out that the beginning of the


modern scientific era coincided with the invention of the coffee house; and he


says that this is not a coincidence, partly because, when that happened, coffee


replaced alcohol as the drink of choice, which obviously gave intellectual


activity a boost, but also, so he argues, because the coffee houses of the day


were physically spacious and encouraged free exchanges of ideas. (This idea


of Johnson’s is consistent with the fact that a number of great writers and


composers worked in coffee houses: Bach, Hemingway, Sartre, and countless


others.)


      Later in the talk, Johnson discusses how many a supposed case of a


great scientific ‘Eureka-moment’ was either a myth, sometimes put forth by


the scientist in question himself, or was at most the culmination of a long


period of gestation. Johnson references the case of Darwin specifically, who


claimed to come up with evolutionary theory in just such a flash, but careful


examination of whose scientific records shows that he had been working on


the idea for decades.


      Johnson does not make it explicit how these two ideas—first, thatopen and movement-friendly spaces encourage idea-generation and, second,


that ideas are networks, not self-contained units—are related. But the idea


seems to be that, because an individual idea is really a convergence of a lot of


little ideas, they are most likely to be formed in places where a number of


people, each with his own ‘little idea’, can exchange and amalgamate their


little ideas into one big one. Just as idea-creation in an individual mind


involves internal networks of neural-firings, so idea-creation in pluralities of


individuals involves external networks of verbal exchanges, which


exchanges, Johnson suggests, are most likely to happen where there is


freedom of movement and a corresponding freedom of speech.


      My own experience is consistent with Johnson’s hypothesis. I myself


have had ideas while sitting in a cubicle, but those were usually derivatives of


ideas formed as a result of the kinds of free and open exchanges that Johnson


discusses. Also, when people are physically shut up in cubicles or in other


prison-cell-like spaces, their physical surroundings are, as it were, telling


them not to be free or let their ideas roam. I myself know a number of


talented writers, thinkers, and artists; and when looking for a new apartment


or home, each and every one of them wants space, quiet, and natural light.


None of them, if given an option, chooses to work in a cramped space. And I


have noticed that, although some of them are slovenly, their work-spaces


have an uncluttered and open quality: they may not make their beds and theymay leave a sock or t-shirt on the floor; but they don’t obstruct their own


physical movement with knick-knacks or bulky furniture. In the living spaces


of my less creative friends, so I have also noticed, there is likely to be extra


physical ‘junk’, for lack of a better word (e.g. space-hogging beanbags or


sofas) as well as junk in the aesthetic sense (e.g. crass posters and cheap


artwork)---all of which tends to be absent from the dwelling-places of my


more creative acquaintances, suggesting that Johnson may well be right to


link intellectual innovation to certain kinds of physical spaces. 


                 Are we born good? Response to: “Born Good?”


                  (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRvVFW85IcU)


 


      Two questions arise in connection with this video. First, are babies


born with a sense of right and wrong? Second, what does this video have to


say on this matter?


      Let us start with the first question. Unless people were predisposed to


be moral, they would never develop morality. People can learn math because


they naturally think in terms of quantities, and learning math is therefore a


matter of correctly deploying aptitudes and tendencies. People can learn


music because they instinctively respond to music (babies are soothed by


classical music and sometimes rock to the beat of a song that they hear) and


even  instinctively produce it (babies rhythmically beats their hands on table


tops and sometimes produce inchoate singing-like sounds).


      Similarly, babies can learn morality because they are already


empathically connected with others and, for this reason, instinctively


distinguish between kind and cruel behavior. To be sure, an infant’s moral


code is not that it would be feasible for an adult, or even a child, to have,


since it doesn’t embody a sufficiently deep understanding of the


accommodations that must be made to others if society and even personal


relationships are to work. But, as anyone who has had a younger siblingknows, babies are quick to bond with others and are also quick to respond to


kindness with kindness and to meanness with coldness or hostility---all of


which bespeaks a certain innate morality. And a child’s moral education is


about shaping its innate moral code, not creating it out of nothing.


      Some children turn into psychopaths or criminals. But when this


happens, it is not, at least not categorically, because they were born without


moral codes, but is rather because their innate senses of morality were


decommissioned by adverse circumstances.


      So the answer to the question ‘are people innately moral?’ is: Yes—


people are born with a certain morality, albeit one that, like the rest of one’s


mind, has to be sculpted and honed before it can be society-ready.


      As for the video, it too answered this question in the affirmative, and it


supported that answer with relevant experimental data (e.g. babies preferred


the friendly looking teddy bears to the unfriendly looking ones). At the same


time, as someone who has nephews and nieces and younger siblings, there


was nothing in the video about infant-behavior or psychology that I did not


already know, and the video also didn’t answer any of the relevant follow-up


questions, including the question ‘why do some people become bad if they


are innately good?’, as well as the question ‘given that people are innately


moral, what is moral instruction about?’, both of which we answered just


now.                         An Exercise in Legal Interpretation


 


 


      It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly acquire, receive, or


otherwise transfer any human organ for valuable consideration for use in


human transplantation if the transfer affects interstate commerce. The


preceding sentence does not apply with respect to human organ paired


donation.


 

                                                                      [124]
      42 U.S. Code § 274e. Prohibition of organ purchases


 


      Both programs violate Section 301 of FOTA (henceforth simply


‘FOTA’, since we are only concerned with Section 301). They


unambiguously violate it relative to intentionalist, purposivist, and pragmatist


conceptions of legal interpretation; and they ambiguously violate it relative to


a textualist conception. It is only relative to a strictly textualist approach that


either one of them could plausibly be construed as not being a violation of


FOTA, but even this is doubtful. 


      The upshot of FOTA is that organs may not be bought and sold for


money or money-equivalents. In this context, the term “tangible


consideration” obviously refers to money or money-equivalents, such asproperty or services. Significantly, FOTA, originally enacted in 1984, was


amended in 2013 to use the term “valuable consideration” instead of

                            [125]
“tangible consideration.” “Tangible consideration” is an offer of a tangible


asset, and in accounting a “tangible asset” is a physical asset, such as a piece


of equipment. Cash is an intangible asset, as are stocks and bonds and all


other securities. Since the purpose of FOTA is clearly to prevent the


exchanging of organs for any relatively liquid asset, “tangible consideration”


was therefore too narrow in scope, since it didn’t exclude any securities,


including cash, and therefore had to replaced be “valuable consideration.” 


      Health World’s Program 1 (henceforth ‘HP1’) is a proposal to the


effect that, if a given person X elects to donate a kidney to Health World,


then Health World will wire $50,000 to a charity of X’s choosing. Health


World’s Program 2 (henceforth ‘HP2’) is to the effect that, if X elects to


donate a kidney, Health World will wire $50,000 to some other person Y of


X’s choosing, with the qualification that Y be classified as ‘poor’ according


to World Bank standards.


      There are two preliminary points. First, the question here is not


whether HP1 and HP2 are morally legitimate. There may well be good moral


reasons for their existence, especially given the fact that there is a shortage of


viable kidney’s despite the abundant potential supply; and they may even be


well intentioned, in the sense that the objective of those behind them mayindeed be to make kidneys available to those who need them. All of that is


simply irrelevant, , however, and the question here is simply whether Health


Programs 1 and 2 violate FOTA. The answer is that they do.


        Program 1, if put into effect, would simply allow for the creation of


organ-money ‘laundromats.’ Poor person X wants to sell his kidney to organ-


trafficker Y. FOTA prohibits Y from directly giving X the money. HP1


creates a backdoor. Y can create a ‘charity’ of his own (or, more likely, he


has already done so), which, though it may discharge some legitimate


charitable services, is basically just a front for Y’s organ-trafficking business.


Alternately, Y can bribe or otherwise corrupt an operative of some existing


charitable agency to collude with Y in his organ-trafficking business.


      This is not an idle hypothetical, but a veritable inevitability. Charities,


especially international ones, are proverbially difficult to oversee; and even


the most reputable ones, such as UNICEF, keep the lion’s share of the money


they receive in charitable donations, supposedly for the purpose of defraying


overhead costs. It is reported that less than 17% of the money donated to


UNICEF actually makes it to UNICEF’S supposed beneficiaries, the rest

                                                [126]
being eaten up by UNICEF-related costs. Given how desperate many


people are for money and given how much money people are willing to pay


for organs, the introduction of a backdoor involving charities would simply


be an invitation to create front-charities or to turn existing charities intoparties to the organ-trade.


      Also, given the costs involved in running a charity, such as World


Health, and given also the dubious nature of World Health’s ambit, it would


likely be forced to resort to de facto organ-trafficking simply to stay afloat


financially. Charities are expensive to run, as the case of UNICEF shows,


even when the services they provide are unambiguously legal and moral, and


World Health would likely be insolvent if forced to rely on legal cashflow.


      Here is an analogy. In most parts of the United States, prostitution is


illegal. Suppose that sex workers came up with an arrangement whereby,


instead of receiving direct payment, they would provide sexual favors in


exchange for large cash donations to charities. First of all, those sex workers


will not even put forth such a proposal unless they already have an agreement


with the charities to cut them in financially. This is not a slur on sex workers;


it is simply to point out that, like all workers, they need to be paid and must


know that they will be paid before entering into an arrangement of this kind.


Further, if such a proposal were enacted, ‘charities’ would instantly spring up


to take advantage of the situation. UNICEF and other conventional charities


don’t create this sort of ‘feeding frenzy’, since they don’t provide a work-


around for people wishing to engage in extremely lucrative black-market


activities. HP1 does create such a workaround.


      The purpose of FOTA is to prevent the exchanging of organs foranything having cash-value. So from a purposivist perspective, HP1 is


unambiguously a violation of FOTA. Given that, supply and demand being


what they are, HP1 would effectively nullify FOTA, or at the very least force


violators of it to assume the appearance of being philanthropists, HP1 is a


violation of FOTA—additionally so since, in addition to providing a


workaround for such violators, it would also tarnish the reputations of


charities in general. Given that the intentions of the framers of HP1 were


clearly to prevent the exchanging of organs for cash or cash-equivalents,


HP1, which simply reroutes cash-for-organs through ‘charities’, is


unambiguously a violation of FOTA.


      It is only from a narrowly textualist perspective that HP1 can be


construed as not being a violation of FOTA. Here is the original (1984)


reading of the relevant part of the statute:


 


      It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly acquire, receive, or


otherwise transfer any human organ for tangible consideration for use in


human transplantation if the transfer affects interstate commerce. The


preceding sentence does not apply with respect to human organ paired

          [127]
donation.


 


      If Y offers to donate money to X in exchange for X’s kidney, Y isoffering ‘valuable’ consideration, but not ‘tangible’ consideration. As


previously stated, tangible consideration is offer of a tangible asset, and a


tangible asset is a physical asset, such as a tractor. Even cash, as also


previously stated, is not a ‘tangible asset.’ Nor are copyrights or even


physical services. So yes---law-makers opened up a serious loophole by using


the term ‘tangible consideration.’ Technically, the 1984 version makes it


legal to sell organs for cash; it prohibits the sale of organs for physical assets


but otherwise doesn’t criminalize it.


      But this only shows how little weight is to be placed on the term


‘tangible.’ The statute is obviously intended to prohibit the cash-sale of


organs, this being why, in FOTA’s aftermath, organ-trafficking remained

                                                      [128]
quite as underground as it had previously been. So again—yes: Thanks to


the term “tangible asset”, FOTA (1984) can, on a textualist reading, be


construed to permit HP1---but only because, on such a reading, it can be


construed to permit organ-sales in general. All of which shows that, in this


context, a strictly textualist approach is not the right one.


      All of this applies with to HP2, which proposes that, if Y wants to pay


for X’s kidney, he can do so, provided that the money goes to some poor


person Z of X’s choosing. HP2 is simply proposing that organ-sales be


middled through intermediaries or agents—who, for legal reasons, will claim


to be ‘friends’, or some such. Such a transaction is not legitimated by the‘paired donation’ provision in FOTA, for the simple reason that paired


donation does not involve anyone’s being paid, directly or indirectly, to give


up their organs. HP2 violates FOTA from a purposivist perspective, given


that the purpose of FOTA is to prevent organ-sales; from an intentionalist


perspective, given that the intention of the law-makers in question is to


prevent organ-sales; and from a pragmatist perspective, given that the


intention of the law-makers in question is to prevent organ-sales along with


the collateral damage that would result, including loss of credibility to


legitimate charitable organizations, done by organ-sales. From a strictly


textualist perspective, HP2 is in the clear, thanks to the term ‘tangible


consideration’, in virtue of which even straight organ-for-cash transactions


are technically legal. But this, echoing what we said earlier, only shows the


irrelevance in this context of a strictly textualist construction.


 


                           Posts for Business Ethics Class


Can you think of an example where someone has been honest but not ethical,


                        as Carter (assigned reading) says?


 


Yes! I have known many people who used honesty about little things to be


dishonest about big things. Somebody would fail to repay a debt to me, and


then, when I called them on it, they would quibble about my wording to cloak


what was really happening. And their quibbles were technically accurate; I


might have said that the money was loaned 28 days ago, and they would


point out that it was 27 or 29, or whatnot, and then make the exchange be


about my supposed looseness with words, or whatnot, when the truth is that


they were failing to honor an agreement that they not only willingly entered


into but positively inveigled me into entering into with them. So yes, honesty,


when misdeployed, can be a way of distracting and deceiving. 


       What was your decision in "Desperate Air?" Sell? Not sell? Why?


 


My decision was not to sell, at least not without first disclosing the problem


to the prospective buyers. Even though I could effectuate the sale  without


being in violation of Florida law, I would still have deceived  the other parties


to the deal, and I would also have put many people's physical health in


jeopardy. Not to mention that, when these problems surfaced, which they


inevitably would, my company and I would look like liars who cared not one


straw for honesty in business or for human welfare. So no---no sale without


first disclosing all material facts, the hazardous waste issues definitely being


of the material variety.


         How far would YOU have gone in the obedience experiment?


 


Speaking personally, whatever I would have done in that context, I would


have done because I personally wanted to do it, not because I was 'under


orders' to do it. In my experience, people who say 'I'm just doing my job' or


'my hands are tied' are either lying or, if they're telling the truth, then they


should quit those jobs. If I had decided to shock the subjects (or do what I


believed to be shocking them), I would have done so out of sadism, or some


other purely personal motive, not out of some ethic of obedience, and I would


have admitted as much to myself. This is not to say that I would have acted


sadistically--I'm inclined to think that I would have been in the 10% who


bailed. But whatever I ended up doing, I wouldn't have used the excuse that I


was 'following orders'-especially since, in this context, there would be no real


reason for me to follows those orders. 


 Reactions to the Jones Day report on the rankings scandal at the Fox School


 


Perhaps I'm a tad jaded, but I think that this case of misconduct--and it was


misconduct--is a bit of a red herring. People lie; it isn't good, but there it is. I


think that Fox's focus should be optimizing its operations---providing the best


possible instruction at the lowest possible price--rather than on rankings and


on acts of contrition relating thereto. It's not good that numbers were fudged;


but it happened, and the focus now should not be to chastise and take pounds


of flesh. It should be to ensure that Temple students, and other Temple-


stakeholders, are given the maximal value for their considerable financial


investment. I am much more interested in being the best possible education


than I am seeing people be taken to the woodshed, and this frenzy of


accusations and apologies seems to be more about public relations than about


quality of instruction. 


 Can you apply ideas from the Bazerman and Tenbrunsel article to McCoy's


                      dilemma in the Parable of the Sadhu?


 


Yes, there is a connection, in that people who behave questionably tend to


rationalize, this being the point, or one of the points, of both the Bazerman


article and the Parable of the Sadhu. 


When people are selling, Bazerman points out, they overvalue assets; when


they are buying, they undervalue them. When they are accused of


misconduct, they deny and double-down; and when no accusations are


pending, their defensive rationalizations miraculously vanish.


As for Parable of the Sadhu, its main point is similar. A given person chooses


not to help someone who needs his help, and he is left with a gnawing feeling


of guilt that, unless he chooses to atone, he must rationalize away.   Almost


anyone in that position who chose not to save the man would rationalize his


decision in some way or other. "I work hard, and I deserve a little me time."


"I can't solve everyone's problems; as long as I'm not actively causing harm, I


deserve no censure." "Why should I help him? Would he help me if the tables


were turned?" 


Similarly, almost anyone whose livelihood depends on compliance with the


corporate line will toe that line and then rationalize it. "I have mouths tofeed." "This company does more good than harm, and it doesn't deserve to go


down over some petty financial impropriety." "If I don't cover up this mess,


someone else will." 


 


 Will it be possible for you to maintain your ethical values yet succeed in the


                                    business world?


 


Yes, 100%. Succeeding in business is about providing agreed upon services


for agreed upon prices. Who succeeds in business? Is it people who make bad


cards and bad shoes? No. It's people who make good cars and good shoes and


charge fair prices for them. People in business who gouge or deceive don't


last long. Business is about providing people with services that they need and


want and ask for and doing so for an agreed upon fee. Business, therefore, is


about helping people and being compensated accordingly. So I think that a


certain integrity is not only compatible with business success but positively


necessary for it. As for the apparent exceptions to this--Bernie Madoff, Ken


Lay, Ivan Boesky--these people are not really in business; they are merely


pretending to be--they are crooks posing as businessmen and therefore are not


counterexamples to my position.


 


                 Have you ever been in the "Endgame" scenario?


 


Yes, I have been in many such situations. I have had friends who broke rules,


sometimes serious ones, and I had to decide what to do. And I chose personal


loyalty over concern for the rules--even though the people I was covering for


had made very real and very unambiguous mistakes. For example, when I


was in the eighth grade, I found out that a friend of mine had deliberately


made a series of unauthorized purchases with other people's credit cards--


which is a deeply wrong thing to do. But I didn't turn him in. He ended up


being caught a week later, saving me the trouble of having to make a tough


decision. But I was very reluctant to 'snitch' on him, even though he was


doing wrong, and I don't know what I would have done had he not been


caught.


Frankly, there is nobody, even when truly good people are taken into account,


who is as good as he holds himself out as being. One way to deal with this is


to admit it and not hold oneself out as a paragon of morality. Another way is


to live with the hypocrisy. I prefer the first path. I try to a good person, but I


know I'm not perfect and I therefore choose not to judge others. For this


reason, if I were to make a mistake, even a serious one, I would be given a


certain leeway not accorded in such circumstances to more judgmental


people.     What is your "home base" ethical theory? (from the Deckop chapter)


 


 


My home base is universalism (or 'deontology' as some seem to call it). And I


think the same is true of all human beings. When deciding how to treat my


mother or best friend, I don't run through a series of cost-benefit calculations


regarding the maximization of utility; I decide on grounds of loyalty and


empathy. In extreme cases, this would not hold: if, for example, my best


friend turned out to be a mass-murderer, then I would choose turning him


over being loyal. But such a decision, it seems to me, would still not


necessarily be made on strictly utilitarian grounds, as it would embody a


certain instinctual regard for other members of society, towards whom I do


feel a certain natural kinship and with regard to whom it would be very


unnatural, almost counter-biological, for me to behave in a complete callous


manner. I don't know that anyone, with the possible exception of a few


policy-makers, ever makes decisions on strictly utilitarian grounds, as there


always seems to be an implicit regard for other people's subjecthood and


dignity.


 Is THE social responsibility of business to increase its profits? -- Who's right:


                                Friedman or Mackey?


 


Mackey is right, and Friedman is wrong.Considered as a member of society,


a hit man has a responsibility to behave decently; but considered as a hit man,


a hit man's only responsibility is to fulfill his contracts. Similarly, considered


as a part of society, a business has a responsibility to be decent; but


considered as a business, a business's only responsibility is to profit. Milton


Friedman and others have held that economic pressures and moral ultimately


coincide--that if business's focus on their bottom line, they will automatically


have to right-size themselves with respect to people's rights. There is a certain


truth in that position, but it is far from being categorically true. There is


money in misconduct. There are sex-traffickers, organ-hustlers, and other


black marketeers who don't exactly do good but make a decent living. So I


would submit that, precisely because businesses do not, in their capacity as


businesses, have any responsibility to do good, they should be given external


incentives in the form of regulations and laws. Consequently, Mackay is


right, not Friedman.


 


 Were WalMart to increase its pay and benefit level to those of Costco (Stone


article) or TJ's (Wilke article), or LaColumbe (Carmichael article) would it be


                        more or less financially successful?


 


It would obviously be less successful, and it would also be able to employ


fewer people. Walmart has very low prices; and its fuel bill per unit of space


is lower than that of its competitors, which means that it takes less of a toll on


the environment, per unit product, than the  much lauded 'mom-and-pop'


store, which, despite its hallowed place in American iconography, is


competing with a 19th century coal factory for the title of most ecocidally


inefficient entity in the world. 


A friend of mine works at Walmart; he is paid reasonably well and finds the


work tolerable--and he's glad to have it, since he doesn't have too many


options. But if Walmart started paying its employees executive salaries, then


half of them would have to go, and its prices would soar. These are facts. 


The Walmart people do what they do not because they're evil, but because


economic forces make it hard to be saints--and, as Milton Friedman and


others have said, may even make it contraindicated. 


 Have you ever had a "Sadhu" dropped at your feet (so to speak). If so, what


                                      did you do?


 


Yes, on several occasions. Just last week, a friend of mine was injured and


bleeding. His injuries were not life-threatening, but he definitely needed


attention. I had a choice: help him and get blood all over my new car or spare


my car and not help him. I helped him. The car looks terrible now, but I did


the right thing. 


When I have chosen not to help a soul in need, it was generally because the


cost to myself was greater than the cost to that other person. If my friend had


had a highly contagious illness that was sure to kill me if I gave him a ride,


then no, I would not have helped him; but short of that, I would have--and


did. 


 Do you think corporations are living up to their original purpose in society?


 


Yes, I do think that corporations are doing what they are supposed to be


doing. They are supposed to be providing consumers with products that the


latter are willing to pay for, and they do just that, since they would go out of


business if they didn't. 


Are they bad actors? Probably, in some respects. But if we dislike them so


much, whey are still around? Because we need them, and we like what they


do. We want cars, shoes, etc., and that's what they give us--at very low prices


to boot. 


If companies treated each and every employee like royalty, the cost of a pair


of sneakers would be astronomical. So before we tell 'the corporations' to take


a hike, we have to confront that very real economic fact.


It is fashionable to bash corporations, and I myself bash them from time to


time. And I know from personal experience that working at one is simply


horrid. That said, when it comes time to buy shoes or Ipods or computers or


cameras or shirts or just about anything else, setting aside a few very


specialized items, where do I turn? The village cobbler? The corner


fruitstand? No! I go to Walmart or Amazon, and I buy items made by Nike or


Apple or Dell. And those items--you must grant--work really well. Companies exist only as long as people buy from them. If Microsoft made a


bad product, it would go out of existence. So granting that corporations often


behave badly, I cannot, without hypocrisy, weigh in against them. And before


others do so, they have to ask themselves: what is the alternative? 


 


 


   Identify an argument in an article, book etc. that does poorly on TWO or


more of the 7 standards Paul & Elder say help assess critical thinking. Briefly


                                        discuss.


 


 


The book I chose is 'Being and Time' by Martin Heidegger. I have been told


that it is a great work; but I found scarcely a single intelligible sentence in it.


Plus, I also found repeated use of the same undefined terms ("existential",


"authenticity", "throwness"), often with confusing variations. So far as I


could understand it, it seemed to be saying that human beings are being true


to themselves when they work with their hands but not when they work for


companies or bureaucracies, the idea being that the latter are soul-robbingly


parasitical organizations. Which--if that is what Heidegger is saying-is fine,


but could have been, and has been said, better and certainly more concisely.


I'd have to give this work an F on clarity, logic, and organization.  


Here is a characteristic quotation: 


"inquiring or in choosing. This holds true-and by no means least-for that


understanding which is rooted in Dasein's ownmost Being, and for the


possibility of developing it-namely, for ontological understanding.


When tradition thus becomes master, it does so in such a way that whatit 'transmits' is made so inaccessible, proximally and for the most part,


that it rather becomes concealed. Tradition takes what has come down to


us and delivers it over to self-evidence; it blocks our access to those


primordial 'sources' from which the categories and concepts handed down


to us have been in part quite genuinely drawn'! Indeed it makes us forget


that they have had such an origin, and makes us suppose that the necessity of

philologically 'objective' ["sachliche"], Dasein no longer understands the


most elcmentary conditions which would alone enable it to go back to

the meaning of Being is one that has not been attended to and one that

-merely material for reworking, as it was for In the Middle Ages

systematics, however, is by no means a mere joining together of traditional


pieces into a single edifice. Though its basic conceptions of Being have


been taken over dogmatically from the Greeks, a great deal of unpretentious

peculiar character which the Scholastics gave it, Greek ontology has, in


its essentials, travelled the path that leads through the Disputationes


metaphysicae of Suarez to the 'metaphysics' and transcendental philosophy of


modern times, determining even the foundations and the aims of Hegel's..."

      Great post! You made a profound point, namely, that the Evil


Genius scenario is concerned not just with epistemology but also with


political and even personal life. Ordinarily, the Evil Genius scenario is


taken as a way of motivating skepticism, its purpose being to show that our


sensory experiences could in principle be hallucinations. But if Descartes’


objective had been to make a strictly epistemological point, he wouldn’t


have used such a pregnant metaphor; he would have attributed the 


hallucinations in question to impersonal forces, such as a chemical


balance, not to a sentient being, let alone a malicious God-like one.


      During this time, science was proving the erroneousness of


Scripture and the Catholic Church was being outed as a malicious


deceiver. And as this was happening, the Church responded maliciously


and defensively, sometimes simply killing the scientists in question. I


believe that the ‘demon’ of which Descartes speaks was a metaphor for the


Catholic Church. I do not believe that this was by Descartes’ conscious


intention, but it was nonetheless intentional, albeit unconsciously so.


 


 


 


         Madisen Domayer posted Oct 14, 2019 4:48 PM


 


      The argument of the evil genius is confusing. Trying to understand


that we “live” in a world where everything is full of deceptions is hard to


grasp. It hard to imagine everything I think or see as being false, or


possibly false. I think this relates to his argument of conscious vs.


consciousness. Conscious refers to what we believe while consciousness is


what is true. According to the evil genius theory, our conscious and


consciousness are not the same, for our conscious is full of deception. One


way to disprove this theory is finding ideas that we can ensure exist


without doubt, such as counting numbers and knowing the alphabet. This


concept relates to the Cogito Ergo Sum argument. Since I think something


is true, it has to exist, despite the evil genius theory. If I can think it, it is


real. I think these two theories can become confusing, but if you think of


them as two separate idea, even two that contract teach other, they seem to


make more since.


 


              I don’t think the Evil Genius scenario is quite as opaque as you


make it out to be. The idea is simply that our sense-perceptions could be


hallucinations. I grant that Descartes muddies the waters a bit by attributing


those hallucinations to an ‘evil demon’, which introduces potentiallyconfusing political and emotional resonances into the scenario. But the point


is clear enough: what we regard as accurate awarenesses could be delusions.


              In response to which, Descartes rightly asks: What is it that I


could not fail to be right about? What is my Archimedean point in my


question for knowledge? Supposing that I am the victim of deliberate and


systematic deception, what is that, for all that, I could not possibly be


deceived about? Descartes’ answer is—I know that I doubt, and therefore


think, and therefore exist. In a word—I think, therefore I am. The mere


existence of doubt proves the existence of thought and, consequently, of one’s


own existence. And Descartes is right about this: one’s own thought, even if


that thought assumes the form of doubt, affirms one’s own existence.


              Descartes also believes that, on this slender basis, he can prove


that we in fact know what we think we know—that, in particular, we can


prove that, as a general rule, our sensory experiences are accurate, the same


being true, with some qualifications, of the inferences we draw from them.


Although I agree with Descartes that we do in fact have much of the


knowledge that we attribute to ourselves, I don’t know that ‘I think, therefore


I am’ is, or even could be, the basis of that knowledge. The actual basis of


our knowledge of the external world is derived from considerations of


continuity and coherence, as in, we must posit an external world answering


to our ‘perceptual narrative’ in order to render the gaps in that narrativenon-anomalous. I listened to an interesting audiobook about this:


  https://www.audible.com/pd/Guide-to-Descartes-Meditations-

                             Economics Quiz on Elasticity


 


Elasticity of demand formula


Elasticity = %change in demand/%change in price


 


  1. Elasticity = -1.2 price increase =.02


      Solve for x


      -1.2=x/.02


      X=-.024


 


  2. Elasticity = -1.2


      Wish to increase sales by 10%


      Solve for x


      -1.2=1.10/x


      X==11/12=-.917


 


  3. Income elasticity = 3.6, income increases by 4%, what effect on


      demand?


      Solve for x, 3.6=x/.04


      X=.144


   4. Elasticity of supply=1.5, price increases 2%, what effect on quantity


      supplied?


      Solve for x, 1.5=x/.02


      X=.03


 


  5. Farmer’s yields up 30%


      Farm output elasticity=--.75


      What effect on revenue?


      Solve for x, -.75=.3/x


      X=-.4


      Therefore, yield increases by 30% but demand decreases by 40%. So


      percentage of output not demanded has increased, and net revenue


      (revenue minus expenses) has therefore decreased.


 


  6. Demand curve: p=200-.2q


      MPC=50+.1q


      MEC=.1q


 


      Private equilibrium=intersection of p=200-.2q and 50+.1q->q=500      Social equilibrium= =intersection of p=200-.2q and .1q->q=2000/3










 


 


  7. What level of tax will lead to social equilibrium?


      Tax = MEC at social equilibrium = .1(2000/3)=66.67


 


  8. Does tax create deadweight loss


      Deadweight loss=economic inefficiency


      Question ambiguous


      Taxing negative externality eliminates deadweight loss. So this


      particular tax ($66.67) does not create deadweight loss.


      Taxing non-externality does create deadweight loss, since the amount


      taxed is unpaid work, leading to inefficiency


      Professor seems to have had second disambiguation in mind, but your      answer correct given the context.


 


  9. At private equilibrium, calculate elasticity of demand


      Private equilibrium -> 500->p/q=100/500


        Elasticity=125/-25=-5


      Elasticity of demand at private equilibrium=-5(1/5)=-1
