                   Summary of Video about Milgram Experiment


                    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f97VYdkHZK8


 


                                Critical Viewing Form


 


                                        BA 3102


 


Instructions: Please address each item below for each movie.  The total


length of your critical viewing form responses should be approximately one-


half to one page, single spaced.  This form will be graded on a pass/fail


basis.  To pass, you need to provide reasonably detailed and insightful


answers to the items below. 


 


1.   Briefly summarize the basic plot, or issue that the movie addresses.


 


The video concerned the Milgram experiment, along with a recent recreation


thereof. In these experiments, volunteers were ordered to commit acts that, so


they were led to believe, caused intense pain to human beings. (In reality, the


people being tortured were actors and were not experiencing pain, but the


volunteers did not know this and had every reason to believe otherwise.) 90%


of the volunteers followed orders to a tee, their ‘excuse’ (or ‘justification’,depending on how you look it) being ‘I had my orders; the rest is not my


responsibility.’ The point of these videos seems to be that people don’t take


responsibility for their behavior unless they have to.


 


2.  What do you think is the most interesting point in the movie?


 


I found it interesting that there was little or no difference between men and


women in respect of how willing they were to follow orders even when those


orders involved inflicting pain. Unlike the commentators, however, I did not


find the result particularly surprising. Supposing for argument’s sake that


women are more empathic, this empathy can either play out in the form of


empathic connectedness to one’s supervisor or to one’s victim; and, as it


turns out, it is more likely to play out in the former way.


 


3.  What is the most controversial statement you’ve heard?


 


It may be that my own life-experiences have biased me, or it may be that I


have already internalized and accepted the results of the Milgram experiment;


but what I found most controversial was the assumption, made by all parties


involved, that a human being’s go-to is just behavior and that unjust behavior


requires that special rationalizations be operative. In my own experience,people tend to take the path of least resistance; they do what is expedient, not


for the most part what is principled. To be sure, setting aside the odd


psychopath, people choose expediency within the limits set by social


acceptability; but, in my own experience, people who act with integrity


despite strong social incentives to act without it are more the exception than


the rule; and I found the frequently made assertion to the contrary to be


particularly controversial, at least relative to my own starting assumptions.


 


4.  What is the most important ethical issue that the movie is addressing? 


Please explain.


 


Do people do what is right or what is expedient? If the movie is to be trusted,


which it is, the answer is: they do what is expedient. It may not have been the


intention of Stanley Milgram or of the movie-makers to make this point;


perhaps it was their intention to make a case that people’s moral judgment is


easily skewed, with the result that, despite having the best of intentions, they


act wrongly. And maybe that is what it shows: but I think the reality


uncovered here is simply that people are more self-interested than ethical.


 


 


  


 


 Racism and Sexism


                                  BA 3102 Online


                          Reflection Paper #2 Instructions


 


Please take the Implicit Association Test and reflect on your results.  The test


is on the web, located at www.understandingprejudice.org/iat.  Take the race


and gender/career IAT tests. You need not report your scores.  In your paper,


please answer these questions:


 


  1. Do you think that the tests measure unconscious bias with respect to


      race and gender? Please be specific in discussing aspects of the test


      that you think are or are not valid for measuring unconscious bias.


 


 


2.  Either way, do you think unconscious bias exists in society (regarding


race and/or gender)?  If not, why not; if you think it does, how might it show


itself in the organizational context? 


 


 


If you have questions about how the test works, go to


    https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit/demo/background/faqs.html; it may beable to answer them.


 


Please note that research shows that the order in which the faces are


presented to you does have an effect, but the effect is very small and usually


does not have a significant effect on your results.  Also, please note that there


are other tests in addition to the race and gender/career tests.  If you wish to


take one or more of these, go to this site:


      https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit/demo/takeatest.html.  You need not log


in.  Just enter as a guest.


 


Your paper should be one to two double spaced pages, using 1 inch margins


and a normal sized font.  Your reflection paper will be graded on a pass/fail


basis.  To pass, you need to make a reasonable case for your point of view


and meet the page requirement.


 


      There were two tests: one concerning gender, the other concerning


race. The test on gender definitely did a good job of measuring the degree to


which the test-taker associates career with masculinity and family with


femininity. According to the test, I myself do strongly associate masculinity


with work and femininity with family. I do not regard this as a bias. I used to


be an ardent feminist; but, ironically, it was female acquaintances of minewho convinced to soften my pro-feminist attitudes. They told me that


feminism forced them to have to work, which left them little time for family


and children, which, so they told me, they deeply resented.


      When in public, I always defer to politically correct positions; and I


also think that gender-roles are in fact easily overvalued. I know many men


who are dismal professionals and many women who are highly competent


ones; and the issue is not, frankly, one that greatly exercises me. In any case,


the test did accurately gauge my feelings about traditional gender roles, with


the qualification that I would not refer to those feelings as ‘biases’, since,


when confronted with a woman who clearly feels at home in the workplace,


or a man who clearly feels at home at home (pun intended), I strongly feel


that the woman belongs in the workplace and the man belongs at home.


      As for the test on racism, it did a good job of measuring one’s feelings


concerning one’s feelings about blacks (if one is white) or whites (if one is


black). That said, even if one unconsciously regards whites as superior to


blacks or vice versa, that is not, in and of itself, racism, since it is actions that


are racist, not feelings. Somebody who has an anti-black bias but resists it


when making decisions—when deciding who to hire, for example---is not


racist, even though he may have the emotional underpinnings of racism. 


      Humans should not be condemned if, at a given moment, they have a


politically incorrect sentiment, since feelings are fluid and will tend to right-size themselves as the occasion demands. I used to have preconceptions


about Chinese culture; then I got involved with a Chinese woman and, as a


result, developed a pro-Chinese bias, which in its turn led to an anti-Western


bias. I do not think such reversals are unusual; and I also think that, although


people inevitably have preferences, some of them not entirely well-informed,


they tend at the end of the day to be reasonably fair-minded when it comes to


matters of race.


      Are their unconscious racial biases in our society? Of course there are.


There are three hundred million people in this country, and practically any


given American, including those who pose as completely politically correct,


inevitably have ‘in-group’ biases. But, first of all, the people who go out of


their way to show how politically correct they are often, in my experience,


have politically driven and unnatural views about members of other groups.


They treat a given black person as a black person, not as a black person.


Individual blacks, like individual whites, want to move forward


professionally; they fall in love; they fall out of love; and so on. The same


being true of individual members of any other given group. And in my


experience, people who are excessively concerned with political correctness


seem to be focused, ironically, on group-affiliations, as opposed to individual


characteristics.


      More importantly, what is important is not how individual members ofa society feel but how they act. Behaviors can be managed, through laws and


policies and the like, but emotions cannot be directly managed—and should


not be directly managed. And whatever the private sentiments of individual


American may be—and those sentiments vary widely, even within a given


demographic---I don’t see that there is systematic denial of opportunity or of


justice to people based on gender or race. There are laws and institutions that


are intended to protect would-be targets of discriminatory conduct—and, as


far as I can tell, do a creditable job of doing so. Finally, I think that the


personal sentiments of individual Americans tend to follow official policy in


this regard, with the consequence that we are not on the whole a particularly


racist or sexist or otherwise bigoted group.


 


   Answers to (somebody else’s) Questions about Orwell’s “Shooting and


                          Elephant” (My content in italics)


 


1. Who Orwell represents in the story? Does he represent the empire? How


  native people see him?


2. What decision did Orwell make about the elephant? Why? To what


  extent was the correct decision?


3. Why the elephant deserves to die? or live? Why Orwell shoot the


  elephant? What was his motivation?


4. What is the symbol of the elephant? Does the elephant symbolize the


  imperialistic British empire?


5. Did Orwell feel peer pressure? Does Orwell was a powerful man?


Beyond Questions


1. Orwell said, there is a mask, and your face grows to fit it. In our life,


  How many times we decide to wear a mask to fit in? Are we looking to


  be accepted by others?


2. Are we ever becoming ourselves? Are we always fulfilling the role that


  is expected of us?


3. Is social media influencing our role of who we are? Are we in the


  puppet role?


4. Do we have a responsibility in our homes, jobs, and community to do  what is right?


5. What am I going to do to become true to myself? Am I going to keep


  doing what others expected me to do?


 


Hi Sahillys! I am a big Orwell fan, and I have read “Shooting an


Elephant.” So I will try to answer your questions:


1*. First of all, “Shooting an Elephant” (SAE) is not a story; it is non-


fiction. Orwell was a civil servant in Burma, and this is a true story about


one of his experiences there. And yes, Orwell represents the British


Empire. Actually, both he and the elephant represent the British Empire,


each of them being, its own way, wounded and faltering, like (so it is


suggested) the British Empire.


2*. Orwell had a legal and moral duty to kill the elephant, given that it was


on a rampage. So he did in fact behave correctly.


3*. I don’t know that the elephant deserved to die, but it was killing people;


so it had to be dispatched.


4*. Yes, the elephant symbolizes the British Empire---or is meant to.


Orwell was a liberal anti-colonialist; and the point of SAE is to depict the


British Empire as bombastic and oppressive.


5*. I believe that Orwell’s behavior in this context was not so much about


personal pressure as it was about professional obligation. And no, Orwellwas not a particularly powerful person. He never had much money or


status and died in a poor house.


1*. Some people wear masks; others don’t. Those who wear masks tend to


so most of the time, if not all of the time. Those who don’t do so are rarely


phony.


2*. Some people are who they are and live honestly; others aren’t and


don’t. We are not all in the same boat, as far being honest and living


authentically are concerned. Some people embrace who they are and don’t


buckle under peer pressure; others collapse like a house of cards.


Anthropologists say that, given a group of twenty people, 19 do what the


rest do and one decides for himself what to do.


3*. People who are real in real life are real in social media; people who


are fake in real life are fake in social media. The former are less drawn to


social media than the latter and are likely to use it primarily for reasons of


a practical as opposed to emotional nature.


4*. Yes, tautologously so. If it is right, then we have a responsibility to do


it; and if it is wrong, we have a responsibility not to do it. These are


definitional truths.


5*. Nothing is preventing you from being you except you. People are what


they choose to be.


  


 


                 When is it a good for a company to decentralize?


 


      Given only the information provided, Derek should fight the holacracy


initiative. Given additional information, the verdict might be different, but


none of the information provided warrants decentralizing Contect; in fact,


that information suggests that the opposite path is the appropriate one. Also,


the changes involved in the holacracy initiative would be far-reaching and


would have unpredictable consequences; and such an initiative would


therefore be contraindicated in this context, since Contect’s growth has been


steady and might well be jeopardized by such an initiative.


      Contect is a global construction company with many regional offices.


Given that Contect is global, it might seem to be a good idea to decentralize.


After all, each of its branch offices knows better than central management


what it has to do and what constraints it is operating within; and it might


therefore seem reasonable to implement a Holacracy-style decentralization-


initiative. Also, decentralization has been proven to be the way to go in many


contexts. One way for a corporation to decentralize is for it to become a


franchise, and sometimes this is extremely profitable, as the case of


McDonald’s shows.


      This does not appear to be one of those times. “Without centralized


oversight of projects,” it says in the Case Study, “any single subsidiary’smissteps risked taking down the entire company,” the reason being that


Contect is a construction-company. Construction-projects are magnets for


civil and criminal litigation. There is a high probability of deliberately or


accidentally violating local laws. If a Contect regional manager decides to cut


costs by flouting some regulation, the result could be large numbers of deaths


and injuries, a likely result being that Contect as a whole is targeted for


criminal and civil actions and either shut down because of a legal action or


bankrupted out of existence. Also, we know about a case where poor


decisions on the part of a Contect regional office led to losses of


approximately $700,000,000 as well as loss of reputation.


      It’s one thing to make Big Macs. It is quite another to make buildings.


There is a single uniform recipe for all Big Macs. There cannot possibly be


anything similar in the case of buildings. In addition, success in the


construction-business is largely about not making mistakes. Suppose that


Contect builds 100 buildings that don’t fall down and one building that does


fall down. That one building is more than enough to shut off Contect’s lights


and possibly put its leaders in prison. Of course, if there is a case of food-


poisoning at a single McDonald’s, that too could cause major problems for


the McDonald’s corporation. But McDonald’s can hedge against that by


insisting that all franchises strictly follow a script; and this is not possible in


the case of Contect, since no two buildings are the same.      In some contexts, decentralization is appropriate. A personal


acquaintance of mine runs an extremely successful online consulting


business; and although he is the boss, each employee has almost complete


autonomy. This person (let’s call him “Smith”) is himself very talented and


he hired five or six very talented people; he finds them business and in


exchange they ‘kick up’ a percentage, but nobody gives orders to anybody.


His motto is “hire good people and leave them alone.” Smith’s overhead


costs are minimal; there is no bureaucratic redundancy; and everyone who


works for him is happy, since they have complete freedom. At Smith’s firm,


there are no group meetings. When Smith meets with people, it is always


one-on-one. And those occasions are rare. If an employee is


underperforming, he is given a brief warning or just let go; and if he is


performing adequately, he is not likely to hear anything.


      I know another person (let’s call him “Brown”) who started a


consulting business in a similar professional area. Brown’s business-model is


very different from Smith’s. Brown wants rules and predictability; and he


insists on regular group-meetings and group-outings, and the like. The


problem is that Brown’s company is small, and its employees find it hard to


bring clients in, or to service existing clients, without getting blowback of


some kind from Brown. Brown managed to borrow millions of dollars to start


his business, which is why his business is still up and running, but it has beenlosing money since day one, unlike Smith’s business, which began with a


$20,000 loan and is making money since day one.


      The kind of anarchical approach to management that Brian Robertson


is talking about makes a lot of sense when profits depend on creativity, as is


the case with Smith’s firm; and it also makes a lot of sense when well-


defined procedures can take the place of central management, as is the case


with McDonald’s. It makes less sense with a company, such as Contect,


whose product is buildings, as opposed to ideas, and whose production-


process cannot in any way be predetermined by some McFormula.


Implementing Holacracy might benefit Contect, but it would also be


extremely risky; and the risk is not worth taking, since Contect is currently


doing well.


  


                            A Tough Business Decision


 


Instructions:  Please answer the questions below.  The length of your written


case assignment form responses should be approximately one to one and a


half pages, single spaced.  This form will be graded on a pass/fail basis.  To


pass, you need to provide reasonably detailed and insightful answers to the


questions below. 


 


      You have a decision to make as Nash.  To simplify things, assume that


you can either (A.) sell the property to Fledgling (you won’t face legal


repercussions), or (B.) not sell the property (delaying the sale while you


investigate the toxic waste will likely kill the sale). 


 


1. What/who are the main stakeholders to your decision?  List them with a


  brief explanation.


 


The stakeholders are all of the parties who stand to be affected by my


(Nash’s) decision.


Nash. Therefore,


*I myself am a major stakeholder, since I stand to lose my job and even mycareer if I make the wrong decision (and also, indeed, if I make the right one).


*DAC as a whole is another stakeholder---and probably the largest one, since


its solvency is at stake, as well as its reputation.


*All employees of DAC are stakeholders, with higher ranking employees


having commensurately more at stake than lower ranking ones.


*The people who are planning on purchasing the land are stakeholders. And


finally


*Anyone whose health might be adversely affected by the deal is a


stakeholder, since, of course, one’s health is one’s most important asset.


 


 


2. What would you do?  Sell it or not sell it?  Why?


 


      The question is not whether or not to sell, but whether or not to make


all parties involved aware of the relevant facts. And the answer to that


question is: yes. I know that there are threats to people’s health on that land,


and I have a moral, if not a legal, obligation to apprise any people who might


be either selling or buying that land of those facts.


    I have a moral obligation to the people who are buying it, because the


deal will not be in good faith if I don’t do so and also because, if they aren’t


given this information, their own health and those of their tenants will bejeopardized, not to mention that they may well be lost to criminal and civil


liability.


      Also, if I don’t make Williams, my boss, aware of the relevant facts,


then, first of all, he won’t be in a position to make a morally informed


decision and, what’s more, he could blame the entire situation on me if all


goes awry, which is very likely.


 


3. Please indicate whether your decision in 2. is more consistent with


    utilitarianism, profit maximization, or universalism, and explain why.


    I would make Williams aware of the facts. For practical reasons, I


would tell him that I was doing this to protect the airline’s reputation and to


protect him civil and criminal fallout. I would also point out to him that the


airline’s current cashflow problems would be negligible compared to the


problems to which not disclosing the situation might lead. Finally, we have


no idea how the buyers will react: for all we know, they will still want the


land, granting that they will probably be able to bargain down the price.


    We are dealing a potential case of serious criminal negligence. Further,


I don’t even know that I would lose out financially by coming clean with


Williams and also with the buyers. Finally, if Williams is smart, then he


knows that, if he greenlights the deal without disclosing what he knows, I


will be a witness to what he did. This does not mean that Williams let mekeep my job. But if he fires me, I will still have my reputation and my


integrity; and if I don’t tell him, I will very likely lose both. And the situation


being what it is, the probability is that I will eventually lose both. Conclusion:


Tell Williams and give him the chance to come clean with the buyers; and if


he doesn’t, play the hero and go them directly, which, as Williams knows,


would make it hard for him to fire me without turning himself into a villain


and which, in addition, is the right thing to do.


 


                                 An Ethical Quandry


 


        Instructions:  Please answer the questions below.  The length of your


video case assignment form responses should be approximately one page,


single spaced.  This form will be graded on a pass/fail basis.  To pass, you


need to provide reasonably detailed and insightful answers to the questions


below. 


 


      1.            After part one if the video case, Julia is confronted with a


decision: Should she turn left, into town, and report the accident to the


police?  Or should she turn right and go home?  What do you think is the


most ethical decision?


 


              Obviously, the ethical decision is to take responsibility. In a


way, the fact that it was ‘accidental’---in the sense that it was caused by


negligence—makes the situation less morally complicated, not more.


Suppose that, for some reason or other, had targeted this person, perhaps


because of a vendetta or perhaps simply because she was just plain evil. In


that case, of course, her act of killing the other person would have been


unambiguously evil, but her subsequent act of not turning herself in, though


itself evil in its right, would at least have not been hypocritical.              Moreover, she would not under that circumstance have been guilty of


negligence---that is, of simply not taking full responsibility for her own


actions before committing them. It is not too much to demand of a person that


they not drink and drive and also that they not, while driving, rummage


around items that they drop. I myself constantly have occasion to drive while


tired or under the influence of Ambien, and I myself also frequently have


occasion to change the radio while driving or to pick up items that I drop. But


I don’t---not because I morally perfect, but simply because I am not a


complete degenerate.


              But Julia was negligent, and her behavior was hypocritical. She


had spent the entire evening reveling in accolades given to her for her civic


mindedness. But then when the very same social system that conferred those


honors demanded that she take care to drive carefully, she failed to do so; and


when it then required her to take responsibility for this lapse of hers, she


again failed to take responsibility.


              Julia’s failure to turn herself, though understandable, bespoke a


lack of integrity as well as a lack of regard for the very community-norms


that she allowed herself to be so praised for upholding, and she therefore


cannot be said to have behaved rightly in not turning herself in.


              Of course, the de rigueur response is that such considerations


are irrelevant, since we have to consider the hypothetical as it is presented tous, not as it might be were it real. But moral injunctions derive their force


from their ability to hold up when the facts continue to pile on. It is easy to


fabricate some context in which it would benefit one more to skip out on a


debt than to pay it; but the moral injunction derives its practical forces from


the hard-learned lessons about the consequences of not paying one’s debts,


the same being true of the moral injunction to turn oneself in for crimes for


which one simply ‘knows’ one would otherwise not be held responsible.


 


      2.            After watching the second part of the video case (i.e., “part 3),


do you think you made the right choice for Julia?  That is, does part 3 change


anything for you?


 


              It does not. If anything, the fact that the other driver was drunk


means that, from a purely utilitarian perspective, Julia should have turned


herself in. For had she done so, she would have been commended for her


honesty and probably also legally exonerated. But as it stands, she is a liar


and law-breaker, her decision puts on the wrong side not only of universalist


but also quite possible of utilitarian conceptions of morality.


 


 


      3.  Please indicate whether your decision in 1. is more consistent withutilitarianism or universalism, and explain why.


 


              Assuming for argument’s sake that the various beneficiaries of


Julia’s teaching and charitable deeds really did depend on her specifically for


assistance, then her decision to skip out taking responsibility for her crime is


justifiable from a utilitarian perspective, the reason being that the more would


suffer than would benefit from her going to jail or otherwise losing her ability


to continue her charitable work. From a Kantian or Universalist perspective,


according to which moral laws are inviolable and are not mere means to


desired ends, then, of course, her conduct was immoral. That said, if


psychological and sociological realities are taken into account, it is less than


clear that the utilitarian and universalist verdicts would differ. In all


likelihood, the loss of self-respect that Julia would like experience might well


undermine her moral fiber and, for that reason, her ability and willingness to


continue her work. Also, in all likelihood, there would be people who could


step into the breech if she had to stop her work. People have great respect for


people who take responsibility, and had Julia done so, she might well have


been given a pass, and also retained her self-respect, none of which will


happen if she continues the cover-up and is then found out. 


      Legitimate Line Extensions as an Alternative to Front-businesses


                        The Solution to the Pizza Puzzle


 


 


Section I. There are two ways to implement this proposal: relative to one of


them, there may be a moral dilemma; and relative to the other, there is no


moral dilemma. Taken one way, Brittany is proposing that high-quality pizza


be given to the guests at competitive prices through a ‘front’ of sorts, this


front being a hotel-service that is posing as an independent business. Taken


another way, Brittany is proposing that the hotel go into the Pizza business.


In other words, she is proposing a line-extension: instead of simply providing


lodging and other strictly hotel-related services, the hotel will also provide


pizza, doing so not just for hotel-guests but for the general public.


      Regardless of how her proposal is interpreted, the primary


stakeholders are the same, these being: the hotel-owners, including


shareholders and creditors, the hotel-employees, the hotel guests, and the


general pizza-consuming public. If the hotel launches an independent pizza


business, which sells and delivers pizza to the general public, then the general


public is more of a stakeholder than it would be if the pizza-service is


implemented in a purely in-house way; but it is a stakeholder either way,since it is either being given or denied a valuable service. Also, regardless of


how the proposal is carried out, competitor pizza-providers are also


stakeholders, with the qualification that, unlike the other stakeholders, they


are negatively affected if the venture in question is a success.


      Of course, Brittany’s proposal can simply be rejected, which means


that there are three options, each with distinctive effects on the various


stakeholders involved. Importantly, the ethical complexion of the case


depends very much on the quality and prices of the pizza being provided. But


in keeping with the terms of the hypothetical, we will operate on the


assumption that the pizza continues to be reasonably priced and of high


quality.

                                house Pizza Servicebased PizzaReject Brittany’s

      Section II.  There are three frameworks within which to evaluate the


available options in this context: utilitarian, universalist, and profit-


maximization. It will be argued that, in this particular case, all of these


frameworks yield the same verdict, the reason being that in the long-term it is


hard for a business to be profitable if it isn’t benefiting its consumers.


      Let us consider each of the three possible decisions, beginning with


the decision to reject Brittany’s proposal. In that case, the hotel loses money.


It probably has to raise costs in order to compensate for these losses.


Customers end up being gouged, not to mention that they miss out on a nice


dining experience, and the hotel loses business.


      Now let us suppose that the hotel has an inhouse pizza-service that


poses as an independent business. First of all, a business’s obligation is to


provide agreed upon services for agreed upon prices. If you pay me to build


you a swimming pool, what matters is whether the job gets done at the agreed


upon price. If I pretend to subcontract to my cousin Jerry, while in fact doing


the job myself, that is irrelevant, so long as you are not being deceived as to


the quality of the work being done. The only material considerations in thissort of context are (i) quality of work and (ii) payment-related agreements.


(In some contexts—for example, with lawyers or financial-service providers-


--there can be conflict-of-interest issues; but that is not an operative


consideration in the pool-case or the pizza-case. Also, conflicts of interest are


only material because they impact quality of service: a lawyer can’t


effectively represent opposing parties, after all.)


      Also, in-house businesses of this kind are very common. I personally


have never been to a hotel where there weren’t restaurants and sometimes


other services that had their own names and branding but clearly had no


existence outside of the hotel in question. Plus, if the hotel actually invests in


special uniforms for the delivery-personnel and otherwise enhances branding,


the effect is not so much to deceive customers as to enhance their experience.


People will happily pay $200 for a $10 steak if they are also given nice


service. The mark-up becomes unambiguously ethically problematic only


when it is used to hide low-quality. If I charge you $200 for a steak and a


show (possibly in the form of a well-attired delivery-person) and I only give


you a steak, then I am in breech; but if I give you both, I am not in breech.


      From a utilitarian standpoint, this would be a respectable option; from


a universalist perspective, this would be questionable, given the element of


dishonesty involved; and from a profit-maximization perspective, it would be


questionable, since it is not clear whether the expenses incurred would beoffset by the hotel’s own pizza-consuming base.


        Consequently, the ideal path here would be to create a pizza service


that also services the general public. This would eliminate any hint of


dishonesty and would also broaden the service’s customer-base, which would


help defray the various sunk costs involved in purchasing the uniforms, doing


in-house promotion, and the like. Also, there would be little reason not to go


this route, since most of the work, including the branding as well as product-


creation, would already have been done. This approach, assuming that it was


properly carried out, would therefore be optimal from all three of the


perspectives in question, granting, of course, that no business venture can be


known with certainty to succeed.


      As for the null path, that of simply rejecting Brittany’s offer, that


would be safe in the short-term but would eat into the hotel’s bottom line and


would also cut the hotel out of a potentially lucrative market, while also


depriving the public of a great pizza.


      This case helps us weigh in on the debate between John Mackay and


Milton Friedman, Friedman’s position being that a business’s sole concern is


to profit, since the ‘invisible hand’ of the market will take care of any ethical


problems involved, and Mackay’s position being that a business has to meet


the market half-way when it comes to holding itself to ethical norms.


Ultimately, Mackay’s position is the right one. Businesses do not profit bybeing ethical; they profit by giving their customers what they want. If the


general public wants toxic waste and assassins-for-hire, businesses can profit


by providing these unethical services.


      Friedman seems to hold that transactional ethics are identical with


ethics in general, which they often are but sometimes are not. Economists,


including Kenneth Arrow and Amartya Sen, have focused a great deal in the


last few decades on negative ‘externalities’ which the market’s invisible hand


does not do a very good job of mitigating, an externality being an unintended


by-product of an economic transaction. Heavy industry generates pollution;


for-profit prisons incentivize the manufacturing of crime; and unregulated


agriculture incentivizes the creation of cheap but unhealthy foods. These are


all examples of externalities, and the free market has not been proven to do as


good a job of mitigating them as Friedman and other free-marketeers hold.


This means that it is incumbent either on government regulation or the moral


integrity of business-owners to do damage control.


      Another problem that Friedman overlooks is that, when not restrained


either by ethics or law, businesses tend to collude with government. The


government is staffed by human beings who need to eat and pay rent, the


same being true of businesses; and it is only to be expected that, given the


opportunity, businesses will do their best to use the government to shut out


competitors and also to insulate themselves from the law. Realisticallyspeaking, if someone is running a $20,000,000,000 business, they are likely


to make donations to politicians, who in their turn will be expected to curb


regulatory and law-enforcement agencies. Without either government


regulation or personal integrity on the part of executives, it is likely that such


collusion will rise to unacceptable levels.


      All of this said, Friedman’s position is still more true than false and


isn’t as opposed to Mackay’s position as it initially seems to be. A business


that is focused only on the bottom line is likely in the long run to do shoddy


work and therefore to fail financially. If the public detests you and your


product, which they will if you are ill-serving them and also squeezing out


competitors, it will be hard to stay afloat, even with government cooperation.


The reason is simply that the economy is much too large even for the


government to control, this being why Enron and Bernie Madoff and Lehman


Brothers, came to a screeching and disastrous halt. Each was ‘chummy’ with


regulators, but there is only so much regulators can do to pacify shareholders


who have lost everything. So yes—Friedman is probably right that economic


rationality probably does eliminate many negative externalities, but he also


probably overestimates the extent to which economic actors are long-term


rational.


 


Section III.  I would choose to create the pizza service, complete with newbranding, and would at least offer it to the general public, so as to offset the


possible element of dishonesty and also to test market-demand for what


might prove to be a lucrative product. The hotel has already gone to the


trouble of creating a pizza that is as good as that of its competitors. If it takes


no action, it will continue to lose money, which decision would be a loser


relative to each of the moral frameworks in question. 


      At the same time, if it goes to the trouble of buying special outfits for


delivery personnel, giving them the requisite training, and so on, then it might


as offer the pizza to the general public, since it would at that point have


created the product and branding; and if it wanted to offer the product to the


public, it would be all but ready to do so, give or take some non-trivial but


manageable concerns relating to delivery and production-capacity.


      This would be 100% honest and, if successful, would maximize the


benefit to all of the stakeholders. Further, there is already proof-of-product,


meaning that the hotel’s pizza is already known to be good; and, of course,


all of the investment in machinery and personnel is already at this point sunk,


making a maximum-value approach advisable. Of course, the do-nothing


approach is an option, but businesses that shirk from opportunities to grow


tend to die, and it also isn’t clear that it is an option for the hotel, given how


much it is already losing in pizza-based revenue. In conclusion, the line-


extension option, involving a real pizza business servicing both hotel guestsand non-guests, is from all the relevant perspectives the indicated path.


     Legal vs. Substantive Freedom and the Paradox of the Free Market


        Reflections on works by Hall, Debord, and Morgan & Tierney


 


This paper is a critical response to three articles: “The Commodity as


Spectacle”, by Guy Debord; “The Spectacle of the Other”, by Stuart Hall; and


“An Illustrated Guide to Guy Debord’s ‘The Society of the Spectacle’”, by


Tiernan Morgan and Lauren Purje. Each one of these articles had most, if not


all, of the following five characteristics:


 


(a)                     It correctly points out that a society that is market-based, as


      opposed to culture-based, inevitably turns people into objects;


(b)                     Despite making this important point, not a single one of these


      articles discusses pornography, which is the best conceivable


      illustration of the fact that market-based societies turn people into


      objects or, to use Debord’s term, ‘mere spectacles’;


(c)                     Up to a point, each of these articles is itself an example of the


      very commodity-fetishism that it is its very purpose to expose and heap


      scorn on; 


(d)                     Although each of these papers does expose a deep problem with


    all economy-based societies--namely, that human beings are turned into


      objects it does so much as attempt to identify a constructive way of      responding to this fact; and finally,


(e)                     Although, as just stated, each of these papers identified this


      important problem with market-based societies, there is an important


      corollary that each of them hints at but not a single one of them clearly


      states, namely, that the various freedoms that people necessarily have


    in a given market-economy---in particular, the freedoms to own and


      exchange goods and services---inevitably lead to complete mutual


      enslavement on the part of that society’s members, albeit under the


      pretexts of ‘universal legal protection of individual rights’ and


      ‘economic and individual freedom.’


 


      Let us now clarify and substantiate each of these points, and relate it to


the articles in question.  First of all, what better example of “the Commodity


as Spectacle”, to use Guy Debord’s term, could there be than a stripper or


pornographic actress? Debord himself does not mention these professions,


and yet they are the best conceivable examples of his point that the free-


market turns people into mere ‘spectacles.’ For here we have a human being


who has been turned into a commodity that is in the most literal possible way


a spectacle. This woman is paid to be ‘stripped’ of her clothing—and dignity


—and turned into a pure spectacle—something that exists only to be


consumed and that is consumed by being looked at.      This is not to say that strippers and pornographic actresses are forced


into their professions: in most cases they are not. But in a way, the fact that


they enter these professions ‘freely’ only shows how insidiously and


deceptively destroying of freedom the so-called ‘free market’ really is. First


of all, if a woman is abducted and forced to become a pornographic actress,


that does not redound to the discredit of capitalism. Capitalism is about


people transacting with one another. In other words, it is about people having


and using the legal right to dispose of their own assets in a manner of their


own choosing. Since the woman was forced into prostitution, her being a


prostitute is not the  result of a transaction (being kidnapped and forced into a


certain line of work is not a way of transacting, after all), and it therefore falls


outside the scope of what a capitalist system permits.


      So let us consider the case where the woman ‘freely’ becomes a


stripper or pornographic actress. Why has this woman chosen this path? Very


simple. She needs money; in a market-economy, she has no value over and


above what people are willing to give her in the form of money; and unless


she has the wherewithal to become a high-level professional, such as a


medical doctor or computer-programmer, her options are either (i) earn a


paltry income doing time-consuming, soul-destroying menial work (e.g. work


as a waitress or telemarketer) or (ii) make real money by literally turning


herself into a spectacle.         Pornographers and consumers of pornography will say that this


woman ‘did this to herself’—that she ‘did it freely.’ And after a fashion, they


are right. Like all members of a market-economy, this woman started off with


certain legal ‘freedoms’; and in order to eat and pay rent, she disposed of


those freedoms in a manner that, given the options available to her, was the


most ‘rational’ and that she consequently ‘freely’ chose. And yet all of this


‘freedom’ and ‘rationality’ has been turned against itself and made its


possessor into a slave: this woman may be legally free, but how much more


freedom than an actual slave does she actually have? If a slave tries to escape,


he may be hunted down and beaten, maybe even killed. If this woman refuses


to either work ten hours a day in a cubicle or spend those same ten hours


dancing naked under neon lights, she will be out on the streets and either die


of exposure or be jailed for vagrancy. Incidentally, supposing for argument’s


sake that she does choose to live on the streets, the various petty convictions


that she will wrack up as a result will make it impossible for her to get any


kind of job that pays enough money to live on. So no—her situation is not, at


least not unambiguously, different from that of an actual slave, even though


her every move is carried out ‘freely.’


      Debord writes:


 


      The spectacle subjugates living men to itself to the extent that theeconomy has totally subjugated them. It is no more than the economy


developing for itself. It is the true reflection of the production of things, and


the false objectification of the producers (Debord, 142).


 


 


      How much more impactful this statement would have been had it been


followed by a specific example! And what better illustration of it could there


be than the just-discussed completely literal one!


      Debord’s article is the work of someone with a powerful intellect. It


reads much like Marx’s “Theses on Feuerbach” and seems to have been


modeled on them, both consisting of deep but obscure epigrams that would


be a lot less obscure if concretely illustrated. And not a single one of the forty


epigrams composing this work involves a concrete illustration-even though


illustrations abound, as we have seen.


      Presumably, it was presumably for this very reason that Morgan and


Purje wrote their article “An Illustrated Guide to Guy Debord’s ‘The Society


of the Spectacle’”. Though brilliant, this article suffers from one major flaw:


it doesn’t contain any illustrations. Yes—it contains ‘illustrations’ in the


sense that it there is art-work in it; but it is quite as devoid of specific


examples of the phenomenon in question (that the ‘free market’ turns people


into two-dimensional spectacle-commodities) as Debord’s work itself. Andits attempt to clarify Debord’s meaning do not in my view do Debord’s work


justice:


 


      As spectators, we regularly experience advertisements for rival


products — Pepsi and Coca-Cola, Delta and US Airways, The X-


Factor and The Voice. Often we’re presented with conflicting desires or


messages. For instance, a television drama depicting an AA meeting might


be preceded by a glamorous vodka advertisement. Such logical


inconsistencies are buried by the spectacle’s relentless proffering of goods


and imagery. Gradually, we begin to conflate visibility with value (Morgan


and Purje).


 


      Yes, technically speaking, it is ironic that the same consumers are


being shown ads for booze are also being shown ads for ways to get off of


booze. But this isn’t exactly a ‘logical inconsistency.’ It is, indeed, just a


humorous irony: advertisements are seen by millions of people; some of


them want vodka and others want to drop drinking vodka---just as some of


them want to buy sneakers and others want to buy dress shoes.


      Also, Morgan and Purje are interpreting Debord overly literally. In


their view, Debord is making the pedestrian point that, in a market-society,


people focus almost as much on packaging—on the wrapper and theribbons and the like—as they do on the actual product. But Debord is


trying to make a much deeper point—one to the effect that capitalistic


transactionalism drains turns human beings into soulless widgets who, as


such, have nothing on the ‘inside’ and are therefore pure ‘outside’—pure


appearance in other words.


      As for Stuart Hall’s “The Spectacle of the Other” (Hall, 2001), this


work was a combination of very sharp and accurate and also very


misconceived. Hall points out that, thanks to predatory capitalistic practices,


human beings were enslaved and that this was subsequently rationalized on


free-market grounds. This is true, of course. Hall then insightfully says that


capitalism ‘otherizes’ human beings—which it does, in that, in a ‘free’


market system, people do not interact, so much as they transact, with the


result that kinship and moral ties are dissolved in an acid bath of


acquisitiveness.


      Where, in my view, Hall goes quite astray is his contention capitalism


reinforces distinctions of race and gender. As Marx and Engels themselves


said, capitalism does quite the opposite: capitalism replaces the biological


with the financial: biologically rooted instincts---both wholesome ones, such


as feelings of warmth for friends and family, as well ugly offshoots, such as


chauvinism and racism---are replaced by cold calculations, with friends and


family and even children having only as much worth as an accountingprogram says they have. So yes—historically, just as Hall says, capitalism led


to acts of profiteering that involved exploiting racial differences. What Hall


fails to say is that, when capitalism is allowed to run its course, it


dehumanizes everybody: all people—man, woman, black, white—are equally


required to toil in cubicles for paychecks that barely cover their rent; and if,


in order to tend to a sick child or make a much needed visit to the doctor’s


office, they take so much as a day off without ‘written permission’ from their


supervisor, they are rewarded for it by having their livelihood cut off—none


 


 


 


Debord, G. (2006). The commodity as spectacle. Media and cultural studies:


  Keyworks, 117-21.


 


Hall, S. (2001). The spectacle of the other. Discourse theory and practice: A


  reader, 324-344.


 


Morgan, Tiernan and Purje, Lauren (2016). “An Illustrated Guide to Guy


  Debord’s ‘The Society of the Spectacle’”. Retrieved from:


      https://hyperallergic.com/313435/an-illustrated-guide-to-guy-debords-the-


  society-of-the-spectacle/

                                        psychological realities underlying these

                                  to know whether people’s private attitudes have


                                    kept pace with the just-mentioned legal and

                              Section 3.Research Theory


          3.1 TheoreticalUltimately, the foundations for this study


              Foundationslie in Levi-Strauss’s structural approach to


                                          anthropological research and in James


                                    Gibson’s ecological approach to psychological


                                                          research.


                                        According to Levi-Strauss’s structuralism,


                                      human interrelations are governed by rules,


                                      most of them implicit, that are defined in


                                        terms of binaries, such as black/white,


                                      good/bad, boss/underlying, and male/female


                                      (Levi-Strauss, 1963). It is to be stressed that


                                      the rules in question are not laws or even


                                          conventions. Rather, they are largely


                                      unconscious understandings that, although


                                    having some biological roots, are changeable


                                      and only assume rigid forms when given


                                    external reinforcement in the form of statutes                                      and other expressions of institutional force.


                                              According to Gibson’s ecological


                                      methodology, interactions among organisms,


                                        including human beings, are guided by


                                      implicit understandings as to how maintain


                                      viable equilibria in a sustainable manner


                                            (Gibson, 1977). Oftentimes, these


                                          understandings give rise to enlightened


                                      practices, but they may also lead to behavior


                                      that, although productive in times past, has


                                      long since ceased to be so (Gibson, 2002).


                                          Structuralism has been used with great


                                    advantage in the study of racism, including in


                                        the medical profession, by a number of


                                    scholars, including Bonilla-Silva (1996) and


                                    Viruell-Fuentes (2012), who have shown that


                                      otherwise inexplicable and highly invidious


                                        forms of racism, such as Jim Crow and


                                        Apartheid, can be understood, though


                                    obviously not justified, if mapped onto Levi-


                                      Strauss’s structuralism Bonilla-Silva (1996).                                          As for Gibson’s ecological school of


                                        psychological research, Anderson (1999),


                                      Williams (2001), and Krieger (2014) have


                                      done extensive work showing that racial


                                      institutions, as well as their psychological


                                    residues, can be understood along Gibsonian


                                      lines by regarding them as over-deployed


                                        defensive-mechanisms, comparable to those


                                      that mediate asthma, lupus, and other auto-


                                          immune disorders (Krieger, 2014).

 Discussion Post #8 (worth 30 points; at least 200 words):  Due by Saturday,


Oct 26th, by 11:30 p.m.


 


Read the introduction to the theme of “Culture and Identity” on pp.


428-430.  Then read Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s “The Yellow


Wallpaper” on pp. 442-454 (I've also put an audio reading of the story


above, so you can listen to it as well.)  Then read any ONE other piece


of fiction or poetry or drama or nonfiction from the “Culture and


Identity” theme from pp. 428-575.  Again, though, you may NOT use


the same piece for post #8 as you did for post #7


 


For discussion post #8, there are two parts: 


First for part A (worth 15 points).  SUMMARIZE “The Yellow Wallpaper”


and the other piece you read with one FULL paragraph of 6-8 sentences (at


least 50 words) given to each piece for a total of at least 100 words for


this part (remember, your summaries should be detailed enough to SHOW


you read well . . .). Make sure when you do your post that you give the


title of the piece you are responding to, as well as the pages it is on in


our text. 


 


For part B (worth 15 points).  Then RESPOND to the story and other piece


and/or the ideas in them in some way--either creatively or critically (for


critical, for example, see the handout called "An Inductive/Inquiry


Approach to Studying Texts" in week two’s module or the “Glossary of


Critical Approaches” on pp. 946-954).  You might write several questions


(as outlined in the Inquiry Approach) or you might choose one of the


critical approaches and analyze the story or stories from that perspective. 


Or you could compare/contrast the story and the other piece in terms of


what they say about the theme of “Culture and Identity.”  Or you could


write about how you interpreted these pieces.  These are just some


suggestions for ways you can respond to literature you have read.


 If you want to do a creative response, then write your own "mini-story"or


poem about this theme or in the style/vein/voice of one of the pieces you


read.


 


Or you can answer/address this question:  Charlotte Perkins Gilman said


that she wrote this piece as a feminist protest against the way women were


treated during her time.  Do you see this character as protesting or not?  Is


she trying to create a different kind of identity for herself than the one that


was acceptable for women at that time—or is she just mentally unstable? 


Write about her and this story and compare it to the other piece you read


somehow.


 


For the response part, I am looking for at least 100 words for this part


also.  The more detail the better; the more thoughtful/thought-provoking,


the better!


 


 


 


Jennifer Johnson posted Oct 19, 2019


 


The Yellow Wallpaper by Charlotte Perkins Gilman (page 442-454)From the beginning this story will open the doors to a psychological thriller


that will leave you wanting more all the way to the end.  It begins by


detailing the daily struggles of a Physician named John and his wife who


seem to operate strangely in their personal relationship.   John is his wife’s


physician and that will hinder her ability to cope with her mental illness


throughout the story.  John seems to be in true denial of his wife’s mental


condition. This story will lead you to believe that John’s wife is going


through postpartum depression in many ways.  He has taken her away to a


beautiful yet older rental home to heal, and ultimately this home will begin to


unravel her mental illness.  She becomes obsessed with things she sees and


begins to write about them in her journals.  The story will explain how John’s


wife is hiding a lot of her fears and feelings.  She begins to write a secretive


journal detailing the things she is experiencing and seeing in the rental


house.  The yellow wallpaper in the house will have a major significance to


the story and will add to the wife’s perception of reality.  She begins to see an


imprisoned woman within the yellow wallpaper which will leave the reader


wondering.  At times this story will go from documenting the first person


struggles of anxiety and depression to something that is a bit evil and full of


suspense.   


 


 Hi Jennifer! I very much enjoyed your post. But I feel that you simply stated


the ‘cold facts’ of the case, as it were. Yes, this woman is obviously cycling


into psychosis, possibly caused by post-partum depression, and yes she does


start to project onto the wall-papers. But what, in your opinion, does all of


this mean? In other words, what is it that isn’t said but lies beneath the


surface of these events? For example, is the husband deliberately torturing


her? If so, why? Is there a larger conceit at work concerning gender


relations? If so, what? I would be very interested on your thoughts on these


matters! -Monzer


 


A Poet To His Baby Son by James Weldon Johnson (page 504-505)


 


This poem is about a father who wants his son to grow up to be something


great.  As his son lays in front of him as a baby, he begins to think of the


future and what his son will grow up to be.  His son is described as being


blessed with his mother’s face and cursed with his father’s mind.  He wants


his son to grow up to be a banker, a politician, leader or a type of go getter. 


The father seems to have strong opinions on what he does not want is son to


be.  He states, “Take the advice of a father who knows.”  He clearly does not


want his son to become a poet.  He defines in the poem that it is no time or


place for poets today.  He views the language of poets as an unknown tonguetoday.


 


Great post! What are your thoughts on the father’s values? Is the father


right to have such specific views as to what constitutes success? And why


does he have them? Is it because he is himself unfulfilled? Or is it just that


he is ‘old school’ and has rather retrograde beliefs about how life is to be


lived? Finally, what are your own views on these matters? Are you a poet


who others tried to force into some pre-existing professional template?


Cheers, Monzer


 


Questions about the Yellow Wallpaper


 


What type of physician is John?  Does he have any experience with mental


illness or postpartum depression?  Is a psychiatrist? What type of physician is


her brother? 


 


Probably a general practitioner who, if given the choice, would specialize in


psychiatry. 


 


How did she really feel about the yellow wallpaper?  She used words like


flamboyant, repellent, revolting and unclean.  Did she really hate the yellowwallpaper?


 


She does not like it. It is clinical and fake.


 


 


The story mentioned that Mary is good with the baby.  Is this their first


baby?  Has Mary been there as the caregiver for more than one child for John


and his wife?  Does Mary know she has postpartum and that’s why they are


at the rental house?


 


I don’t know that she thinks in quite such logical, transactional terms.


 


In the story she states she is angry enough to do something desperate.  She


also mentions she has a hidden rope.  Does John take her suicide signs


seriously?  Does John know that his wife could be suicidal? 


 


He is probably deliberately causing her to be suicidal, or so the subtext


suggests.


 


John takes it as far as to take his wife to a rental house to recover from


postpartum depression.  Has John seen signs that would make him think hiswife would harm their child?   


 


Great suggestion, but his objective seems to be to hurt, not to protect.


 


Questions A Poet To His Baby Son


 


Why does the author think becoming a poet is such a bad choice?  Is the


author a poet himself?


 


He thinks it’s a bad choice, because, financially speaking, it is a bad


choice. Pan-handlers make more money than poets.


 


Why does the author think that poets are unfortunate fellows?   Why doesn’t


he want his son to grow up to be like one?  Is that because you cannot earn a


living being a poet?  The poem says that poetry is unknown tongue?  Does he


think that no one reads or respects poetry anymore?


 


He thinks this, because they have no earning power and are therefore


defenseless. Plus, there are great poets who have day-jobs, such as Wallace


Stevens, who was an investment banker. Even Shakespeare made his living


as an actor, not as a poet or playwright. 


It seems the author wants the best for his son.  Why would he be critical of


what he does not want his son to be when he grows up?


 


Asked and answered. See above.


 


Why would the author think that poetry is not a good way of communicating


love for his son if he is writing his own son a poem like this? 


 


Poetry is a great way to communicate love, but it isn’t a good way to pay the


bills. A friend of mine is a poet, and he always had to ask other people for


money, including me. One day I lent him my car, and he just drove away.


With my dog and birth-certificate.


 


How would the author feel if his son grew up to become a poet and read this


poem that was written for him as a baby?  Would be feel regretful that he has


such harsh feeling on poets knowing his own son became one?


less


 


That really depends. It depends on the father and also depends on the son’s


situation. Is he writing the poem from his mansion or from his jail cell?

triumphant feeling, the confidence in success, which not seldom brings actual success along with it.”

being the father’s job to temper that self-love with the necessary degree of self-discipline.

 Cleckley (1950), Kernberg (1984, 1984b, 1985), Hare (1993). Be it noted that there are different
degrees of psychopathy: a given person might have a high degree of professional integrity, and to that
extent by non-psychopathic, but otherwise be highly psychopathic. This was the case with Jeffrey
MacDonald, the Army doctor who slaughtered his whole family and had no remorse at all doing so.
Jeffrey MacDonald's performance as a physician was consistently exemplary, there being no indication
that it was in any way corrupted by psychopathy, even though there is no doubt that Dr. MacDonald
was otherwise a textbook case of a psychopath. Dr. MacDonald's case is in no way a singularity, there
being many cases of psychopaths who, like Dr. MacDonald, are non-psychopathic in specific contexts.
